Light dryness from bitterness as well. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready, and lightly sticky balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a nice Irish red/ESB style. All around good complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt and light-moderate fruity yeast/earthy hop flavors; very smooth and easy to drink. A nicely enjoyable offering.
Draft sampler pours light brown color with a nice off white head. Aroma is sweet with grains and malts. Taste is rich roasted malts and grains.
Tap at gratzi. Nose is sweetish and warm. Full body and clean with some malt. Great color. Decent for a red and wouldn't turn away but not amazing.
Bottle. Milky caramel malt and hay aroma. Dark amber with small head. Lightly sweet nutty toffee malt and mildly bitter herbal hay flavor. Medium body. Decent.
At Buckeyes vs MD... Amber pour with thin head. Balanced malt and hop flavor easy drinking... Cheer the Bucks on to victory !!! Go Bucks!!!

Draft sampler at the Elevator. Deep amber pour with a moderate white head that lasted and had good lacing. Medium toasted sweet aroma. Light body. Light sweet toasted malt flavor with a moderate finish. Smooth drinkable brew.

Sample at the brewpub - Pours bright amber with a creamy offwhite head. Aromas of toffee, caramel, and a little dough. Flavor is one dimensional malty. but that one dimension is pretty tasty. Toasted malts, caramel, and a touch of light german hops on the finish but not much. Palate was buttery and medium bodied.
From notes: Malty flavor and smooth flavor. Easy drinkning but uninspiring.

This beer was a reddish amber color and had a small, bubbly white head that left a small amount of lace. The aroma was lightly of hops and malt. The flavor was of malt and caramel. The finish was medium, with elements of the caramel, and tangy. Not a bad beer.
A little too sweet for my taste. At first I was like, “wow, this is really good”. And then by the third sip I had to switch with Dogbrick because it was just too sweet to finish.

Rerate 3/07/06: This is the March selection in Elevator’s "MBA" program. Pours amber/orange with a medium thin off-white head and thin spotty lacing. Lots of malt and caramel in the nose. Medium-bodied with a nice smoothness. Sweet malt flavor is still pretty one-dimensional. There are just enough hops to keep it from being overly sweet. The finish is straightforward malt and lasts pretty well. Score remains the same. 6/03/02 (3.4): This used to be my favorite Elevator offering, but the last time I had it, the malty flavor was almost sickengly sweet by the time I got to the end of the glass. That aside, this is still a good beer, but I would suggest keeping it to one glass. Nice amber color and medium head with good lacing. Sweet, malty aroma.

column1: Elevator Dirty Dicks Nut Brown Ale
column5: Thin bodied and only the faintest hint of sweetness. Tried at the brewery in 2019 during ASEH 2019.

column1: Elevator Dirty Dicks Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft - Dark toasty malts. Deep cloudy brown with a rich beige get head. Dark fruit and some malty sweetness. Not very true to style.

column1: Elevator Dirty Dicks Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft - pours brown white head - nose/taste of caramel, light barley, toast, metallic - med body

column1: Elevator Dirty Dicks Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft sampler pours light brown with a white head. The aroma is of roasted malt and a decent amount of nuttiness. The tatse had a nice roast malt backbone with a big nuttiness present and a hint of dark fruits and a slight bitterness

column1: Elevator Dirty Dicks Nut Brown Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. pours clear copper-brown with a good head. Good but not exceptional aroma. Moderate strength. The flavor is a bit bolder and has a nice, lasting roasted grain finish and aftertaste. Enough hops to add flavor in addition to keeping he bitter/sweet balance near even.

column1: Elevator Dirty Dicks Nut Brown Ale
column5: On draft at the taproom. Brown pour, off-white head. Aroma of nuts and caramel. Tastes of roasted malt, earthy, cocoa. Light, easy.

column1: Elevator Dirty Dicks Nut Brown Ale
column5: Good brown ale. Smooth and balanced. Great poor dark brown with little lacing.

column1: Elevator Dirty Dicks Nut Brown Ale
column5: Tasted at 2013 Dayton Alefest- I got it for the name but it was an excellent brown ale. Carmel flavor with an excellent malt flavor on the tongue. ---Rated via Beer Buddy

column1: Elevator Dirty Dicks Nut Brown Ale
column5: Pours a chestnut brown with little to no head. Aroma of metal, nuttiness, and mocha. Taste is that of roasted hazelnuts, a touch of metal, and just the right body. A great nut brown second to Bell’s BB.

column1: Elevator Dirty Dicks Nut Brown Ale
column5: Taster on tap at Casa. Kind of an unnerving name. Clear orange-red brown color. Little off-white head. Loose lace. Light bitter taste. Medium body. Crisp carbonation. Kind of a light bite in the texture, slight metallic. Nutty flavor, light hint of chocolate, earthy bitter hop. OK. Not great. Not much to it.

Not bad. True to style, tasty, nothing to offend. Commendable. On the critical side, there’s nothing particularly noteworthy about this beer either. It is dark, it has a faint tan head, it smells roasty, it tastes mildly roasty and of dark malt, and it finishes nice and dry in your mouth. There is a touch of coppery metallicness that seems just a touch off, but other than that, this beer was pretty good but not terribly out of the ordinary. Solid. I’d have it again, but I wouldn’t make a special trip for it. I had it on tap at Elevator.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours darkest brown with a medium tan head. Roasty aroma of coffee and malt with some metallic character. Flavor is roasty and sweet with some coffee and chocolate and no trace of the metal that was in the nose. Good stuff.
Pours a dark brown with a small tan head. Taste of roasted malts. Pint at Elevator Brewing Company

Dark brown porter covered by a slice of beige head. Quite aromatic for a dark beer. This is roasty, yes, but mostly cerealic, hinting at a certain oatmeal character. Instead of taking the classic chocolate/coffee route, it heads towards licorice territory. In doing so, it manages to reach out towards a fair fruity background that haunts the finish with its tasty blackberry and dark grape hints. It remains mostly thin, but tasty enough for a brewpub porter.
Medium to dark brown pour with tight off white head and lace. Astrigent coffee aroma. A large coffee flavor and a bit of a sour. A full bodied beer with good carbonation. Pretty damn good.
Draft at brewpub. Brown body, sweet caramel nose, smallish head. Sweet caramel with toasted notes, mild bitterness. Definitely a brown porter here.

Sampler @ Brewpub. Deep mahogany pour, very thin white head that disappeared almost immediately. Smells of roasted malts with pretty pungent alcohol aroma. Tastes dry, roasted malts, a little faintly of coffee and finishes a little hoppy for a porter. Decent.

Hmmm, this is one where, if they could make it consistent, it would be very good. As it is, it is just too hit and miss. Looks like a Coke in the glass, smells of chocolate and earth. Slightly bitter, but most sips alternate between chocolate and roasted barley to bland and watery. Just all over the place, and never hits its stride. Too bad.
Draft sampler at brewpub. Very dark brown color, aroma has some coffee notes, good malty flavor with some nuttty and chocolate elements.
Draft. Black in color with roasty aroma. Light/medium body with a somewhat nutty, roasted flavor.

Pours an almost black color with a compact dark beige head. Sparse, stringy lacing. The aroma is toasty with malt and a bit of chocolate. Medium-bodied and smooth but not very rich. Lightly smoked, with roasted coffee, malt and light chocolate flavors. The finish is creamy and sweet. Nothing really distinguished about this Stout but it is decent.
Good black color and odd aroma. Good malty taste, chalky mouthfeel and good to complement a desert, because it doesnt overpower like many a stout would.

Okay, first off, I know the brewmaster Vince Falcone. Since this is his newest venture, the beers here will only get better. I liked the color of it as well as the aroma. The tasted was pretty good, but it is a little bit on the light side for a stout in my opinion.

Pale lager de 5 % abv. Couleur blond mat, aux reflets ivoire et clarté pure. Mousse blanche à très gros flocons, et dessus informe. Arômes de malt pils et fruits blancs. Bouches de sciure de bois, poils de chèvre, cuir tanné. Jambes très collantes. CONCLUSION : l'antilope noire emblématique du pays, dénommée " hippotrague noir géant " ou en portuguais " palanca negra gigante " est obligée d'être sur ses gardes pour se préserver de l'extinction, mais elle ne doit surtout pas boire trop de pale lager !!

Puszka 330ml wypite w domu, dzięki ,,Sępie". Kolor złoty, klarowny, piana znika szybciej niż się pojawia, gruboziarnista. Aromat słodu, kukurydzy trochę gotowanych warzyw. W smaku wytrawne, mocno gazowane z warzywami, bardzo przeciętne z dziwną goryczką.

Shared 250 ml bottle, as Nocal Mini. Golden colour, small white head. Sweetish "industrial" aroma. The pale lager flavour is uninteresting, but not terrible - you could survive for a week in the jungle if you had an unlimited supply of well chilled Nocal.

Shared 25 cl bottle labelled Nocal Mini at RB/HD at Bjørnøy 26.01.18. Clear pale golden. Small white head and lacing. Aroma of canned fruit, wine gum, grass and citrus. Similar, and slightly artificial, taste. Not bad, though.
0,25 flaske på RBHD-samling, Bjørnøy jan-18: klar gylden med kort skum. OK citrus i tillegg til lys malt både i aroma og den slanke smaken. Overraskende friskhet og mild bitterhet men kort ettersmak.

3-3-2-2-4 Can, shared with BBGTC. Pours clear pale yellow, with a small creamy head. Aroma is pale malts, rice and cereals. Medium body, with average carbonation. Flavour is sweet pale malts with cereals.

11.12.2017, 0,33l can sampled @ BBGTC tasting: Small fizzy mediumlasting head, straw colored. Aroma is slightly dry sour-ish grassy, weeds, sour grass, wet hay, metal tank, corn, cereal, vegetables, paper, old wash cloth. Taste is harsh mineraly, weeds, paper, wet cardboard, cereal, corn, minerals, alcohol. Little bitterness, watery and harsh mineraly mouthfeel. Drainpour!

0.33l can shared with The Tasting Crew. No doubt, a lovely looking pale golden looking one with a small quickly fizzing away white lager head. Doesn't smell fantastic by any means. Corn and dusty hay. Cereal and a metallic undertone. Not lovely to smell at. It has a good carbonation level and a thin oily texture in the mouth. Quite on the sweet side in the taste. Minerallic and dusty in the taste also. No doubt highly drinkable in the hot Angolan heat. Not a fantastic thing in the cold December Bergen winter. 11.12.2017
Standard light lager. Crisp and dry. Slight fruitiness that may be slightly out of style but not at all unpleasant. Refreshing.
Can thanks to Wickedestman. Very malty and sweet taste. White sugar and honey. Paper and boiled vegetables.
Taste, Trade of Grumbo, Thanks you so much!!. 26/07/2018 Color amarillo claro, espuma blanca escasa,aromas rancios, floja.
Sample courtesy of fombe89. 26-07-2018. Dull cheap industrial pale lager. Boring, sweet, lots of adjuncts. Very poor.
Country #77, Golden beer, small head, aroma funk, grain, malt, taste is the same. Pale lager all over, meh

10/III/18 - 50cl bottle, shared @ RBBWG (Beer Lover's, Antwerp) - BB: n/a (2018-286) Clear blond beer, small creamy white head, little stable, adhesive, leaving some lacing in the glass. Aroma: very dirty, grains, hay, some cow fodder, pretty dirty, meh. MF: ok carbon, medium to light body. Taste: pretty metallic, grains, hay, cow fodder, bit sweet. Aftertaste: bit sugary, metallic, pleasant bitterness.
Taster, courtesy of CH-303, many thanks! Clear golden, almost flat. Glue, solubles, less body, thin, watery, grains. Oh boy.
01-05-18 // taster, many thanks to Anstei! Clear golden. Old grainy, mild muffy, pale watery. Country tick, nothin more.
Danke an anstei. Laffer, muffig herber Beginn. Wenig Getreide, wässrig, untrinkbar. 10/5/6/5//5
Bottle sample, thanks CH-303 & anstei! Clear golden color with no head. Aroma is solvents, cardnoard. Taste is solvents, water, sugar sirup, cardboard. Oily mouthfeel, low carbonation.
Bottle many thx to Grumbo etc 2018-04-25 Göteborg AR: dry cardboard, bread AP: pale golden, no head F: dry, cardboard, apple, wee pilsner

Many thanks for this sample to CH-303. It's my 132 new Country. Thanks Again Asbjorn for sharing this big bottle. Piwo ma prawie niewidoczna piane jest wielkosci pol centymetra, wyglada jak wino musujace, drobne babelki i jest bardzo jasne. Smakowo ten lager nieco, nieco lepszy od ostatnich egzotykow jakie testowalem, jest delikatne, moze lekko wodniste, ziarniste, ale malo slodkie, nie wyczulem tu tego taniego slodu kukurydzianego, a za to niewielka nutke goryczki, ktora szkoda ze nie potrafi zatrzymac sie na dluzej w przelyku.
I think the beer used to be good, but it is now almost impossible to find ABC, although there is still some old merchandising in many bars. Our bottle was fairly old too.

I had this beer while on a medical mission in Ghana a number of years ago, but I thought I’d rate it now (one more country to check off!). Obviously you are not going to find a brewing miracle in West Africa, but when its over 40 degrees Celcius with 90% humidity, if it even remotely tastes like beer and is cold, then it does the job just fine. This one is a poorly made pale lager that became a revered after-work treat, along with Star and the occasional Guiness. The atmosphere of Ghanaian hospitality, hot groundnut stew with fufu, and the contented feeling of having finished a hard days work are what elevate this rating to what it is.
In the can at the 2004 Crescent Moon Vintage Beer Tasting. A boring lager. Looks and tastes the same as just about any generic foreign lager.

Bottle coming from the Goutte d'Or area, Paris. Drinking and trying this bottle at Epalinges. Nothing outside of the common with this beer, a classical radler similar with the blizz of Feldschlosschen. The color is gold, clear, average carbonation, thin and whitr foam. The taste is sweet, lemonade that it is industrial, almost no hop, some malt, boring one but it is fully drinkable.

Appearance: Pale golden, clear. Small head. Aroma: Light fruits, wet cardboard, slight grains. Taste: Slight fruits, watery, palest of malts. Bought: Trade with Nisse666 - big thanks!, 50 ml sample Info: 13/3-2019

Sample many thx Mr Grumbo - super thx 2019-03-09 Göteborg AP: clear coppery wee amber, no head AR: honey? F: low carbonation honey, cardboard box, wee grainy - is it a bock, fairly low ABV?, soapy mouth feeling
24-11-18 // country tick share with Koelschtrinker and Beerhunter. 1000ml bottle thanks to Koelschtrinker. Senegal 🇸🇳 - clear golden. Nice name for a pale lager. Plörrig mit getreidiger süße.
Danke an Idiosynkrasie. Getreidig metallerner, plörrig herber Beginn. Dumpf getreidig, erhöhte Karbonisierung, laff. Bäh. 8/4/5/4/4/4
Taste, Trade of Grumbo, Thanks you so much!!. 26/07/2018 Color amarillo claro, espuma blanca escasa, aromas dulces, cereal, sabor cereal, floja.
Sample courtesy of fombe89. 26-07-2018. Very poor pale lager, with reminiscences of honey. Quite sweet, dull, flat.
Sample from Grumbo - pours gold white head - nose and taste of corn, old grain - light body

Bottle. [ As Solibra Bock ]. [ As my country rating # 171 on ratebeer ]. Clear light medium yellow colour with a small to average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly lasting to diminishing, white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, grain, pale malt, wet grain, cardboard. Flavor is light moderate sweet a average duration, sweet malt, grain, cardboard, wet grain. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20171001] 4-2-3-2-7
Many thanks for this beer to Erzengel. Pours clear golden with a creamy white head. Hay, bread and paper. Medium to thin body.
Overall: Sweet bread, syrup, bitter seeds, grass. Note: Bottle 750 ml at home. Reviewed 2015-10-22.

Bottle at the Cape Hotel bar in Monrovia. Very pale yellow color, huge fluffy white head. Aroma of white pepper and straw with a whiff of cardboard. Taste is bitter peppery straw. Actually not terrible.
RBESG Sheffield 2009 Grand Tasting @ Harlequin. Crappy corny lager, nothing really noticable about this belwo average pale lager.

Land #56. Leicht penetranter und hefiger Geruch. Leicht würziger, schnell wässriger Geschmack, leicht getreidig, milder, etwas saurer Abgang. Für diese Breiten ist das Bier sicherlich recht gut gelungen! Danke an den Doppelbock für das Teilen des Biere und an den Lieferanten Jevers Zeuge! Test vom 8.5.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 6,7,7,6,6,7 - 6,70
[bottle @ RBESG 2009, Grand Tasting] Rank hay aroma. Clear straw appearance. Watery water flavour with a touch of grain. Light body, medium carbonation.
From the Bottle at RBESG Harlequin, Sheffield 19/07/2009 Malty aroma. White head. Golden coloured and smooth on the palate with a crisp and slightly dry malt finish.
Bottle at RBESG 09 Sheffield. Pale gold Stale as xxxx. Toast. Really rancid.

Bottle @ RBESG 09 Grand Tasting @ [ The Harlequin, Sheffield, England. ] Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toffee, butter, sugar, cardboard, paper. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20090719]
Bottle @ RBESG Grand Tasting 2009... Bright yellow ... horrible graint hop ... again crap lager.
Bottle at the RBESG09, Grand tasting, sheffield. Alround rating: Quite light pale grainy and a little buttery malts, some bitterness but on the sweet side, but thin and drinkable enough. Clean.

The head is ok, the body very dark. It smells fruity and sweet. The taste is fresh, sweet, fruity, darkmalty, yeast is passiv. Good drinkable, refreshing but less aromen and a bit boring. 11/9/10/11/11/10
Bottle, 5.3%. Mild citric aroma. Hazy brown colour. Small stable off-white head. The flavour is a little citric, has some caramel, hint of bread. Not so interesting, but not horrible either.

50 cL bottle. Pours cloudy dark brown with a huge, light tan to off-white head. Aroma is roasted and slight phenolic to estery wheaty. Roasted malt flavoured, light fruity and vague spiced. Dry and estery finish.

Bottle 50cl. Close to clear medium to dark brown color with a large t ohuge, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, beige grey head. Aroma is light malty, caramel, light to moderate yeasty, banana. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery - creamy, carbonation is soft. [20091002]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours an almost clear deep amber with a firm, off-white head. Sweet aroma of overripe fruit and banana. Medium body, sweet caramel and overripe fruit with an edge of yeast. Finishes dry. 021009

Bottle: Almost clear, amber to deep amber coloured, smaller off-white head; solid dark-malty nose with traces of brown sugar, wheat and cloves; moderate sweet-sourish flavour, light to medium bodied; increasing, but still mild acidity in the fruity-dark-malty finish. Good........
Pale brown and very hazy. Toffee and banana aroma. Tart and refreshing. An outstanding dunkelweizen.
I have a half a dozen stubbies still in the cardboard pack if you are a collector ?
Bottle- a very nice beer. Good balance of malt and hops. a good version of an english pale ale.

Pale amber yellow white foamy head. Faint caramel when cold and a roasted malt toffee sweet aroma on glass swirl. Medium thin body with nice brit ale mouthfeel. Floral hoppy bitter flavoured start. Woody slightly malty sweeter middle and medium light bitter finish. The best boags beer brewed so far, clearly better than other australian beers

Comfortably Boags’ best beer. A commemorative ale released in 2002 to mark the brewer’s 120th birthday. Brewed in the style of one of the brewer’s original ales from 1881. Pours a deep amber colour with a fair lacy head. Inviting rich, hoppy nose, with some spice to it. Medium-bodied. Big malty flavours at first but it goes AWOL in the middle before a mild bitter finish. Quite a warming, flavoursome style by current Aussie mainstream standards. (Bottle)

Bottled, with Sats, in Sydney. Amber with a lacy grey head. Distant hope and malt aromas. The flavour arrives from a slightly sweet base and fails to go on from there. Shy and withdrawn the 1881 design is a little too much like alcohol in a glass for the more flavour seeking palates. Soft, jammy end notes fail to impress.
rich dark amber colour, huge white head, sweet malty aroma. better cold as it warmed up became very soapy. I think had been on the shelf since 1881. thanks Neil.

better than the honey porter i suppose. nasty, dirty hops with faint honey in the odour. nutty, bready, syruppy malt and an ugly, alcoholic, rough, bitter and astringent finish. at least it's not flavourless, just bad.
You can tell its a boags beer. Typical ale, fruity flavours, malty goodness - overall quite a smooth little drop. cheers
Wasn't overly impressed by this beer but could easily sit down and scoff three or four in a sitting without wincing too much. Not bad, not great

i was surprised by this beer. i had it at a nightclub, which is a strange place to sell this beer. i had to drink it out of the bottle, so i couldn't tell you what it looked like. it was malty slightly toffee like, and fruity and sweet. it has the same floral aroma and fruity taste that all of boags beers have.
Cask at SRAF 2010. Pours clear amber, nose is light spicy fruit, caramel, taste is sweet, fruity.
Light golden, honey coloured. Not much in way of aroma. Taste is quite hoppy initially leading onto slightly sweet orange. Slightly sweeter finish. Bit of dry biscuit. Finishes dry. Nice.
Cask by handpump at Hengler’s Circus, Glasgow - clear deep golden, thin off-white head, caramel malt and floral hop aroma and flavour with a hint of resin, thin bodied, very easy to drink

Cask @ The Golden Rule, Edinburgh 230812 Dark amber, dense frothy white head, good lacing Aroma - pale malts, cereal, light pale fruits Taste - caramel malts, touch of toasted malts, soft fruity malts, bitter bit earthy hops Palate - soft carb. light body, bit oily. Finish - lingering bitter bit toasted cereal malts, hint of citrus, bit astringent Overall - This had quite a lot of flavour for the abv. It’s all right.

First tasted this at the Waterside Inn, Seamill in July 2000. Cask hanpump dispense. Crystal clear pale amber in colour with a thin creamy white head. Expecting a malty nose but got English floral hops instead. Thin mouthfeel and poor lacing. Pale malts give a tanin flavour with raisin fruit evident. Hop resins give a dry edge to the aftertaste. Finish is well balanced and bitteer sweet. Reminded me of Timothy Taylor Landlord? A good session ale.

Cask@GBBF2011. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is wood, some caramel malts, mild floral notes as well as some slight toasted notes. Flavour is much the same with some mild earthy and grassy notes as well.
Cask at GBBF 2011. Cloudy orange coloured with a medium sized off-white head. Fruity aroma of hops, caramel and grass. Fruity flavour of hops, caramel and grass. Dry hoppy finish.

From cask. Pours hazy orange to brown with a small, off-white and lacing head. Aroma is yeasty, fruity and hoppy. Bitter, toasted malt, grassy, citrusy and light peachy flavoured. Bitter and dry finish.

On cask at the Ormidale Hotel, Arran. A deep golden ale with a thin white head. Some caramel, yeasty aromas and mild fruity hop notes. Tastes fresh and clean with nice hop bitterness that lingers. Nicely dry and bitter.
Cask @ Pot Still. Hazy copper colour, off-white head. Aroma is a bit malted, cooked vegetables, bit of fruits. Flavour is light malted, fruity. Slightly bitter finish.
Destijds gekocht voor het etiket, wel opgedronken, te hoog Spa Lemon gehalte, daar zitten ook tonen van citroen in en heb ook een hoog Co2 gehalte.
Nice lemons... tasted like Fanta Lemon. I think fruitbeer would almost be a better description. It''s a very weak beer in all directions possible.
I totally agree with jbrus. It's just fresh lemonjuice. The usual Gulpener Korenwolf is a nice refreshing wheat, but this lemon version is definitely not worth trying!
fresh sour lemon smell, typical witbier color. Refreshing, not too sweet. I like it.

Sharp lemon aroma, almost herbal. Yeasty. Swet, syrupy lemon taste, honeyish, bit herbal. Grape sugar and coreander. Bit watery, but refreshing. I like it! One of the most drinkable light beers on the market. The overall rate is lowered, because in my opinion it is more of a low alcohol soft drink than a beer.

Strong lemon aroma. Looks like fresh lemonjuice, rocky white head that diminshes fast. Sweet, lemon flavor, very watery. Short sweet finish. Could be nice refreshing if you're not expecting a beer. But I was.

I do not understand why this beer exists. For sure it tastes much better than a Cola but an Alt beer is much better than this. I would have understood when they mixed their NA alt with Cola but this makes no sense to me

Sampled from 0.33 l bottle from local ’trinkgut’, best before January 2018. Clear, very dark red with a thin, frothy, slowly diminishing, off-white head. Sweetish, a little sourish, sugary aroma of cola and some caramel. Very sweet, minimally sourish, sugary taste of cola, some caramel and hints of cardboard, followed by a short, minimally bitter, a little tart finish. Thin to medium body, slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Okay although no beer at all, definitely drinkable, the super low ratings surprise me a bit.
0,33l Flasche. Dunkelbraunes Getränk, dunkler Schaum. Sehr süsser Coladuft. Seltsamer Geschmack. Cola und Malzbier. Nicht mein Fall!

(Bottle, 0.33 l, at laiti’s, 20150613, thanks) The drink poured with Coca Cola colour. Its head was small and white. Aroma had sweetness and cola. Palate was light bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were sweetness, cola and sugar. Not a beer.

330ml bottle (Kaufland, Olpe) - fuck me! Sweet perfumey aroma. Yeah, this is just perfumey shitty cola. There’s some furniture polish in that, but furniture polish tastes better than this. Starchy paper hints - that must be the pretence of beer in the mix. Cinnamon too. Horror.
330ml bottle @laiti’s, thanks. Brown, Coca-cola color. Looks fizzy too. Sweet, cola in aroma and taste. As a soft drink it’s bad and as a beer it’s even worse. Baaaaaaaaaad! Never again!

33 cl bottle @ home, BBE 06/2015 Aroma is sweet with cola, some malty notes and some sweet licorice. Flavour has cardboard, starch, some cola and hints of wet paper. The beer and cola do not quite mix up here.
Bottle 0.33l at Laiti’s, Helsinki. Thanks to FatPhil! Colour is clear brown with almost no head. Aromas and flavours: Coke and sweetness. This is watery coke.

*Old rating, best before 18.12.04. Sehr leckeres Cola-Bier. Zwar schon sehr süß, aber die Cola harmoniert mit einer ganz leichten Altbier-Malzigkeit, die sich aber doch recht im Hintergrund hält. Der Nachgeschmack ist Cola-süß mit einem ganz leichten Altbier-Malz.
Dunkel rötlichbraun mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr süß nach Cola. Geschmack süß klebrig nach Cola, von Bier ist nichts zu schmecken.
Bottle 30cl. Pours a gold colour with normal size head, like most pilsener. Aroma is hoppy. Good taste, nice bitter taste and finish. Watery in the mouth. Nice pilsener.
Bottled. Pale yellow colour, big creamy white head. Aroma is earthy, dull and mouldy malty with some mild hints of hops. Flavour is mainly sweet malts. Not much else in it.
Bottled, pasteurised, 250ml, from Supermarket at Schin op Geul, NL Limburg. Yellow straw with white head. Sweetish but relatively tangy lemony lager. Nothing special, just not the worst.
Very clear, blond colour, white head. Pils aroma, very hoppy. Rather fresh and herby pilsener. Little bit sweet and drybitter, but the finish is rather flat.
Decent pilsener. hoppy aroma,.. not bad for 29 eurocents

(bottle) Clear and pale golden colour with a foamy white medium head. Floral hoppy nose with a touch of grainy malts. Smooth and refreshing Pilsener, also quite rounded initial maltiness and hopbitter finish.
This beer has a light yellow body - hue apperance and a coarse white scum collar. I have drunk the beer from the bottle and it had a lot of carbonic acid. The initial flavor taste is bitter.

Bottle, Hoppy and a bit soapy aroma. Flavour is a bit sweet fruity. I like the normal Alfa better. Label say’s Norbertiner brau in Beek, lived there for two years never saw that brewery.. the label is of Alfa design.
Hoppy, bit soapy aroma. Just a bit hoppy flavor with an underlying orange fruitiness. Maybe a bit sticky. One of the better supermarket brands available.

taste is not very explicite, but the taste after is pretty good it seems this could be the afterpartybeer! Easy drinkable, but leaving a good taste in your mouth It aint a very good beer, but it sure isn't bad
[Cask from The Three Judges] Fruity, peach notes, perfumed hops. Light fruity palate with a dry, perfumy finish.
Cask Stillage at the Metropolitan Cathedral Crypt, Liverpool 19/02/2003 Clear golden coloured and pale. Slightly dry lasting finish.

This was very hazy when poured, head non existent.The nose is quite pleasant, light, fruity and fresh, a lightly flavoured beer, not much to it to be honest. 39p from a dump bin in my local Morrison, BBE date is Dec 2005, two bottles only, they also had some Coopers sparkling ale, also at 39p!!!
Bottled. Golden amber beer with a smoothly caramel and hopped aroma. The flavour is quite grassy, slightly hopped and slightly fruity. Overall a good ale.

Pours cloudy light cold with a very small white head. Strange aroma, quite funky / musty. Reminds me of rotting oranges. Taste is just as strange, very musty/funky, feel is very very thin. I think this may be off, either that or very "unique".
Pale amber coloured. Sweet and weak aroma of hay. Very boring and watery. Not much hoppiness anywhere.

Bottled. A nice orange gold coloured beer with no head and little carbonation. The aroma is really hoppy, citrus notes especially oranges shine out. The taste too has good hop qualities and is quite thick in the mouth. There is a little off-putting sulphorous note hidden in there, but for a 4% hoppy British beer it’s really good.
From A Small Bottle.Sort of golden in colour,ok head,weak malt aroma,jif lemon and hop taste.
Golden, small head, soft carbonation. Cellery nose with some parfume notes. Not unpleasant. Medium bitter hops taste, medium long lasting. A bit spicey at the end.

Fruity, floral hop nose; hazy dark yellow; scumy head. Thin malt body - quick profile. Tangy broad hop bitter like rocket - lingers forever. Thin, scratchy texture. Kinda like a homebrew, but I like it.

Tasted this at the Three Judges, Glasgow in February 2003. Cask, handpump dispense. Dull jet black in colour with ruby tints around the edges and a thin buff head. Dusty black malt in the short aroma. Thin but creamy mouthfeel and good lacing throughout. Dark malts give a burnt toast note at the start which then gives way to milky coffee, molasses and dry drinking chocolate powder in a smooth mouthfeel. Dry hoppy bitter prickle noted in the short aftertaste. Finish is dry with a slight liquorice note present. A decent session stout.
Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 01/03/2003 Dark red colour. Poured lively. Lasting slight roast finish.

Very dark with little to no head. Roasted malts dominate the nose with a yummy hint of coffee bean. Thin and light, this could be the first "session stout"! Very smooth and enjoyable. At the tasting, I kept saying, "I haven't tried that stout yet..." Luckily someone handed me a full pint to shut me up for a while.

1. Cask Handpump at the Station Buffet, Stalybridge 01/05/2003 Amber coloured with a reddish hue. Slightly sweet. Some bitterness in a full malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 25/02/2004 Copper mid brown colour. Some sour fruit flavour. Bitter full malt finish.

Deep red/brown colour. Served too cold to get much of the aroma, A balance of malt and bitterness on the palate, but can't say I noticed the Oregon hops too much. A robust and rather rustic ale, but quite pleasant, if unexceptional. Cask (handpump), Lord Moon of the Mall (JDW), Whitehall, London SW1.

Cask Conditioned, at the Head of Steam, London. Amber with a lacy white head. Very well balanced. Sweet malts transition through to decent bitter finish. Very impressed with the condition of this beer. The Head of Steam is a top notch Free House with 8 hand pumps (7 beer + 1 cider).

JDW Maidstone. Good condition. Perfect temperature. Brown red colour. An initial malt sweetness is quickly balanced by dry almost tannic hops that lead into an earthy bitterness in the finish. Nice, but not my thing.
Deep ruby red with floral aroma. Some spice flavor at the beginning, nice sweet malty middles. Dry finish.

Normal pour, subpar head, ok lacing. The aroma was too strong on a coffee type slant, as was the flavor initially, strong bitter coffee in a brown ale with only bitter nuts detectable underneath. As it warmed, this thing improved, but it wasn’t smooth and was only average in the style.
Some milky chocolate, yeastyness, sweet and toasty malt flavors, it's filtered to a clear brown with amber hues, medium effervescence and some creaminess and light resins.

column1: Beaver Street R & R Oatmeal Stout
column5: Pours a deep chocolate brown. Perfectly roasty-chocolate with a slight sweetness. Pronounced chocolate roast aroma. Well rounded. Notes: on tap at the brew pub, summer '12

column1: Beaver Street R & R Oatmeal Stout
column5: Tap at Beaver Street Brewery, Flagstaff. Aromas and flavours: Coffee, dryness, chocolate and roasted malts.

column1: Beaver Street R & R Oatmeal Stout
column5: Stout and hops smell and taste. Medium to full body, medium carbonation, and heavy foam.

column1: Beaver Street R & R Oatmeal Stout
column5: Poured up on tap at the brewpub where it exhibits a deep dark body that supports a thin dark tan head. The aroma offers up chocolate malt balls, dark roasted malts, chocolate malts and a thin layer of burnt malts. The taste delivers chocolate malts, some dark roasted maltiness and then thin malt sweetened shards of bunt malts. It picks up a bit of sweet black licorice to sort of a cola sensation from time to time. The chocolate and dark roastiness run from front to back. Pretty nice.

column1: Beaver Street R & R Oatmeal Stout
column5: easily the best beer on the menu - nice roasted malt flavor. smooth with a good balanced flavor and finish.

column1: Beaver Street R & R Oatmeal Stout
column5: Dark pour with a brownish head. Flavor is a weak oatmeal and chocolate. Smooth finish.

column1: Beaver Street R & R Oatmeal Stout
column5: On tap @ Beaver St. Almost black in color with almost no head. Roasted malt, coffee, and licorice on the nose. Okay chocolate and cocoa. Slightly watery. Flavor is slightly bitter and very much roasted malt forward. Some vanilla, burnt sugar, and seltzer.

column1: Beaver Street R & R Oatmeal Stout
column5: Draft. Black. Fair beige head. Lighter body. Not really oatmealy. More like a stout or sweet stout. Some roast. Sweet but not too sweet. Really quite nice.

column1: Beaver Street R & R Oatmeal Stout
column5: On draft at the brewery a dark brown with a minimal tan headit has an orange and coffee aroma the taste is of oatmeal and coffee with bitterness on the palate.

column1: Beaver Street R & R Oatmeal Stout
column5: On draft at Beaver Street Brewery in Flagstaff AZ Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted grain. Flavors chocolate, roasted malt and oats. Medium mouthfeel. Smooth finish.
Amber pour. Citrus hop aroma, citrus and spicy hop flavor, but not too bitter.

I got this at the brewpub in Waltham. Was told by my server it was fresh. Absolute palate crusher. In a good way. Almost tasted like spicy licorice. One of the more extreme hop experiences I’ve had in a while. Had to switch up to water after the first pint. 63 ibus seems a bit modest. Or it could have just been the choice of hops or that I was drinking it new. This was a tough pint to drink, but as a hop lover, it was tough love. I could barely taste the bleu cheese on my burger that came out after I finished the pint.

(beer tasting @ Monty’s Krown - Rochester, NY: bottle - 22 oz) Hazy amber color with a thick white head. Grassy and hoppy citrus aroma, much like a good solid IPA. Flavor has a nice hop bite at the start with a dry and slightly astringent middle and a dry and slightly piney finish.
Draught) Pours a hazy orange body with a medium off-white head. Aroma of citrus, caramel, herbs, and grass. Flavor of herbs, grass, grapefruit, pine, and tobacco.

Pours a clear deep golden with a well-lacing white head. Has a sweet caramel and fresh grapefruity hoppy nose. Starts with a light sugary caramel maltiness with a good balance of fresh resiny hops before a crisp bittersweet finish. A pretty good IPA.
Pours light golden in color with a thin white head. Restrained hop aroma, not much of an explosion. Little caramel sweetness added on the tongue. Palate was thin. Decent enough.
Light orange smell. Clear amber, thin head. Light orange flavor. Not impressive at all.
Draught sample at the brewpub. Pours copper/gold with a nice white head. Aroma and flavor is bitter, citrussy, pineapple, resiny, spicy. Enjoyable.
Enjoyed at the brewpub. This batch came out 5.9% a.b.v. and IBU 68. Medium yellow, that leaves a lace trail. C-hop aroma. A good bitterness, like a 1.5 times IPA.

A golden amber ale with a thin off white head. A restrained floral hops and caramel malt. In mouth, a more British IPA with dry malt, astringent notes, and grapefruit. Medium bodied. On tap at brewpub, Oct. 12 2008.

plale Bronze pour with a filmy white head. Aroma is wheat and light fruitiness. Flavor is sweet wheat grain, light berry fruit. Overall uninspired, but then again, I cant think of a blueberry ale that is.
Pours amber into a tumbler. Head quickly recedes to sicken surface. Mild blueberry juice aromas. Slick with blueberry upfront and a sour finish.
Slightly hazed gold pour with white head and lace. Aroma of blueberries, bread, and wheat. Lighter blueberry flavor, perfumy, with spiced hops. Medium bodied with light carbonation.

12oz bottle-pours a white head and hazy pale yellow/yellow color. Aroma is blueberry, some light malt, hint of hops. Taste is blueberry, some light malt/grain, some lemon, spice/slightly metallic hops with a bite.
Beautiful blueberry smell. The taste is closer to a pale ale with a good blend of hop and blueberry in the finish. Modest head that dies out but leaves pieces of lace.

Bottled. Hazy golden, rich head. Blueberry pie aroma. Sweet and mkedium bodied with clean rounded mouthfeel. Like blueberry pie with vanilla custard. Low bitterness. I believe the brewmaster has succeeded in his ambitions, but I’m not sure I like where (s)he’s going.

(Bottle from Marcorelle’s) Pours hazy light coppery gold with a very slight pinkish tint. Thin off-white head. Aroma of berries but behind it it’s kind of sourish and dishraggy. Mouthfeel fairly smooth, light, fair bit of carbonation. Lots of light, patchy lacing. Flavor of berries mixed with that distinct soapiness I get with alot of the blueberry beers. Seems to have a bit of spice in the finish. A decent one - at least it seems "real".
A nice, clean, refreshing beer for berry season. Smells of blueberry muffins, though has a fairly weak blueberry flavor. Easy to drink, balanced.

I actually think this is a quite good beer. It’s not quite as well balanced as Sweetwater Blue and that’s its problem, but it is its rival. I could have sworn the ABV was higher...but I guess I was wrong. I really enjoyed this brew though. I had it from a bottle in Florida when I bought a six pack in Panama City.

October 2007. Tap. A generally weak blueberry brew. Smells lightly of berries and wheat. Looks a pale yellow with a little white head. Overall is fairly watery with a light flavor of blueberries. A decent summer beer, I suppose, but nothing compared to Sweetwater Blue.

Draught @ Holyoke Brewfest: All watermelon nose. Golden pale amber hue. Small white head. Pleasant and easy drinking. Sweet, all flavored watermelon. Obviously an extract...Definately drinkable, and fairly unique.

Boston Beer Summit 2003: This had a strong watermellon aroma, and I rated it really high because it was PLEASING to smell, but in retrospect, it wasn't pleasing in a beer way. It was pleasing in a Jolly Rancher way. The flavor, however had a very bitter, hoppy attack. I think it was almost TOO bitter for what they seemed to be trying to accomplish with the beer. Is it supposed to be sweet, or is is supposed to be bitter. Unfortunately the bitter overpowered the watermellon flavors until the very end, and you didn't quite get to enjoy it long enough.
Has a golden color and a nice watermellon smell. Taste is of watermellon, but it finishes pretty flat. Overall this was a pretty good fruit beer, but the watermellon flavor finished to quickly.

On tap Boston Beer Summit '02: Let me preface this by saying that I don't like fruit beers. This one I liked. Big watermelon aroma without smelling fake. Good malts back up the fruity taste. I do want to taste this again to make sure all the other beer I had that day isn't talking, but I think I found a unique solid fruity brew.

On tap. Golden red with small white head. Aroma grassy hops, some wood and bourbon. Medium body, slight alcohol, a little sticky then dries out. Flavors up front sweet caramel and warming presence, some spices, citrusy hop finish. Pretty good.

Keg at Moe’s, Lee, MA. Pours clear, rich gold with a foamy, white head. Floral hops in the nose, some yeast. Light to medium sweet flavor, nice and bitter. Tons of floral bitterness, light grass, dough, light candi sugar. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Dries lightly in the finish, with notes, with lightly toasted sugar, grass, flowers. Seems just slightly watery, but overall very nice.

On tap at Sunset Grill. Served in a tulip. Pours a moderately-hazy light golden color with a good white head and a bit of lacing as it makes its way down the glass. Thin cap nearly throughout. The nose brings forward some light banana, a bit of yeast, and a light grainy presence. Nothing too complex, but everything fits together quite well. The flavor falls along the same lines. The banana was light and carried the rear, while the more forward flavors were a bit of other yeastiness as well as a pervasive presence of grain. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Pretty decent. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 03-22-2011

On draft at The Ale House in Amesbury , MA. Poured a light orange with a white head. Nose of malts and other odd aromas. Medium body and light mouthfeel. Flavor is spicy with lots of malt. Kind of an odd tasting beer, but drinkable.
From tap at Sunset Grill. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is roasted malty and phenolic. Spiced and phenolic. Dry malty and slight yeasty. Dry phenolic finish.

In short: A inoffensively bland slightly citrusy golden ale. Meh How: Tap at Pour Farm, New Bedford, MA The look: Almost clear golden blonde body topped by a white ring of foam In long: The very light nose is a bit citrusy. In the mouth I got bready malts, some citrus fruits, some wet grass. A little tartness. No bitterness to speak of. Carbonation is very active. An inoffensive beer for the mass. I spent only one night in this beer wasteland, extremely boring and very ugly town called New Bedford, MA. And by the end of the night I wished I was running a business making ashtrays made out of human skulls.
Pint on draft - Pale red to golden, sweet, fruity, lighter flavor. Perhaps trying to emulate a Belgian style. Good session beer

Big City Allston tulip ($5.25): The bartender poured it without a head, so I can’t comment on that aspect. The beer is a translucent red color. Sweet malty and cherryish aroma. Some Belgian notes are there, but not in full force. Tastes kind of sweet. The high alcohol is covered by the sugar I would assume. Mild hop presence and some bitterness throughout. Pretty fruity tasting. Good, but as others have said, far from great.

Sampled at Sunset Grill Allston. Pours a hazy yellow with some frothy white head. Fruity aroma, lightly sweet, light citrus. Flavor is malty, citrus, bread, a little sugar. Finish is medium bodied. Nothing wrong, per se, but completely forgettable.

Was nice to have this on tap in Boston even though it is made in Western MA where I am from. This light orange beer had a slight head in my pint glass. The aroma was sweet but also a bit estery and like peptic. Fruity and smooth taste witha bit of hop bitter, Nice middle of the road beer

OLD NOTES NOV 3, 2004 Skuny kinda yeast aroma, with a bit of hop and wierd mustiness to it. Pours golden with foamy little head. The flavour itself is inoffensive and nothing complex. Bit of hops or something going on there. The carbonation feels a bit odd on the tough, and has an odd bit end to it. If you’re going to go cheap Boags, avoid this, the Draught shits all over it!
Bottle- I’m just updating my records- Another boring pale lager in their range.

Plain old gold beer with an average white head that stuck to my glass quite well. Got a good whiff of tasty fresh citrusy hops and the smallest hint of malt. The hops dominate what exists for flavour. Those same hops crinkled my tongue and left a nice bitter finish. Drank in under 5 minuites - sucker went down with amazing ease.

Another thin-bodied lager in Boags’ drab line-up. It poured the colour of Sunday morning piss, with slightly more head. Lots of citric hops and little else in the aroma. A skinny quenching palate and the faintest of dry finishes. So bland I’m struggling to keep my eyes open. (Bottle)
Meh. It’s a lager. There is nothing overtly good or bad about it. I keep forgetting I don’t like it so much and end up buying one or two every 6 months or so.
Bright clear gold colour with a medium-size fully lasting head. Hoppy aroma with a smooth flavour that is nothing too exciting but easily quaffable.
An all round inoffensive blandish beer. Doesn’t suffer form the chemical nastiness of most standard Aust lagers. Probbaly a good reguler quaffer.

Always a worry when you see something on special that hasn’t actually been in the shops for a long time here. Probably the rep said this was a good deal and thought it was worth an unload here. The description says it is a pale lager. It is. Beertalk synonyms for pale in my mind are bland, fleeting. lifeless and unexceptional. Put this in a blind tasting and it would truly be confused with a number of average Aussie lagers

Nice gold colour with good head retention and lacing. Very clean aroma, pretty much nothing going on, which is an advantage over most of its contemporaries. Flavour of crystal malt, pretty light on otherwise and not as bitter as I recall. Quite drinkable and without any real flaws but doesn’t really have anything all that great about it either really.

Well i am going to stick up for this beer. I really really like it. This beer is aggressive and has a nice level of bitterness with a bit of an aley character. Much more complex than strongarm and blows classic right out of its own water. Easily Boags best.

Deep amber with creamy head. Big, flowery hop aroma. Ful bodied, but dominated by the grassy/flowery Fuggles hops all the way through. Very bitter finish. The 3rd IPA from this brewery. Perhaps overly flowery, but still a really nice pint for a hop head.
Aromas of barley malt, herbal and grassy hops. Flavours are pine, grass and herbal hops, hints of citrus, balanced with some barley
Deep plum aroma. Caramel malt, peach, floral hops, bittersweet finish. Elegant and well-rounded amber ale with quite a Belgian character.
Pours dark, clear amber with a small beige head. Aroma is caramel, pine, spices, nuts. Taste is light sweet, caramel, resin, dried fruit. Mild bitter finish. Excellent.
Bottle sample at After Dark, Haifa. Hazy amber with an off-white head. Malty, toasted and caramel aromas. Sweet, toasted, honey, caramel, old hops, bitter finish. Medium-bodied.
Cereal, malt, barley on the nose. Very pleasurable aromas. Snappy, hoppy bite on the tongue at first sip. Not much depth or mouthfeel. Decent enough though. Smell makes up for the other shortcomings.

Bottle from LCBO. Pours an average size frothy beige head and has an amber appearance. Bubbly sticky lacing. Slightly excessive carbonation. Aromas of barley malt, herbal and grassy hops. Flavours are pine, grass and herbal hops, hints of citrus, balanced with some barley and light caramel malt.

Bottle (Mr Mama). Deep clear amber with a lasting pale beige head. Aroma of bread, singed toffee, grapefruit, pine. Creamy. Almost burnt toffee.The malt is not overwhelmed by resin but it's getting towards that. Brief finish with modest bitterness. Pretty good, not quite my sort of thing.
330ml bottle. Pours dark, clear amber with a small beige head. Aroma is caramel, pine, spices, nuts. Taste is light sweet, caramel, resin, dried fruit. Mild bitter finish. Excellent.

Bottle courtesy of Loz's boss Ele, cheers Ele. Consumed at home sat down the garden by the pond Friday 27th July 2018 in the company of Mum and Keith. Pours hazy brown with a thick off white head. Really good, nice hoppiness, a little rustic, some caramel, toffee a little toasty and malty. Very good. A7 A4 T8 P4 Ov16 3.9

On tap at Kiuchi brewery, Naka, Ibaraki, Japan. An amber coloured pour with a medium off white head on top. Malty, caramel aroma. Tastes vaguely hoppy, malty, caramel., slight sweetness. Easy drinker.

33 cl bottle (BBD 2019-10), bought from Trevs Bar (DH1 3LN) and drunk at home 2019-08-31. Appearance is a hazy deep gold, with a thick, densely formed beige head that lingers for a fair time. Slightly unusual but quite pleasant. Aroma has tropical notes, with some pine and citrus (orange) as well. It's not wildly strong, but noticeable and nice enough. Taste is pretty good. Sweeter than the aroma suggests, with some orchard fruit notes and perhaps some grassy hints. Not too much bitterness from the hops, but a little bit of drying bitterness comes through towards the finish. Palate is definitely the weakest aspect. Medium-bodied and juicy with a little in mouth carbonation, but there's basically no finish which is disappointing. Overall, this is pretty nice. Nothing revolutionary, but it's nicely fruity. I do want more finish, but it's not a deal breaker and certainly wouldn't stop me having another.

330ml bottle given to me by Stephen - cheers mate! Sampled on the 7th August 2019. Opaque straw in colour with a thin white head that quickly disappears. Light floral hoppy aroma with notes of lychees and warm bread. Thin resiny mouthfeel and poor lacing. Pale malt base gives a light biscuit base with soft citrus fruit notes of lychees and gooseberry coming through. Aftertaste is hoppy with lychee fruit becoming more dominant on the palate over the fading gooseberry flavour. Finish is again hoppy with juicy lychees to the fore, building light astringency in the mouth.
As of this moment, this is the hoppiest Japanese beer I've tasted (quite possibly the first). Mild bitterness and hops with a light dry finish.

I have found this bottle, at Biervana, in Munich, trying and enjoying this bottle, at home, in Epalinges. The color is copper and aorange bit orange, clear, regular carbonation, thin and white foam. This one is almost an IPA, good and smooth, side of resine, pine tree, strawberry, a pleasant bitterness and hop.
330ml bottle from Beru Vykhodnoy in Moscow. Pours opaque copper with a tall off-white head. Aroma is caramel malt, citrus. Taste is fruity, caramel, light to medium bitterness.
Online order @ LCBO, nice pale ale, nothing to envy to competition as a basic reference, well done from Japan.

Аромат хмелевой, весьма горький, легкие еловые нотки. Цвет немного темнее чем должен быть. Пена хорошая, большая, хотя и мыльная немного. Вкус питкий, сильно карбонизирован. Вкус по началу нравится, но вот послевкусие не очень. А точнее это лично мои пристрастия к именно этому хмелю и его еловые и лесные нотки мне не нравятся. Ну а так среднее пиво.
0.33 l bottle from K-Citymarket Ruoholahti, Helsinki. English School of Pale Ale, well, maybe a bit on the bitter side. No American Citrus, but pine trees.

Half pint of the cask condition version at the Hitachino Brewing Lab at Tokyo Station in Japan. Appearance is a clear coppery amber with no froth as it is not carbonated, which also meant that the aromas were muted, but there is no repressing the caramel notes in the brew. Taste is unusual, this seems to be a traditional English pale ale with few hops, so it is caramel, malty, some bitter piney notes, in a smooth medium bodied brew.

A light coppery colour, a head is medium and blond. Aroma has caramel malts, some citrus, also wood. Taste has caramel, wood, citrus, quite mild bitterness. More caramel in the end. Medium bodied. Quite lots of caramel.

A glassfull of used motor oil toped with a small light brown head. Roasted malts take center stage but this isn’t a "one trick pony" as other Japanese stouts that I’ve tried have been. There is sweetness from the malts and yet a bit of a tart follow. A tangy bitter aftertaste. A dangerously easy to drink beer. My only knock on it is that it’s a bit thin bodied for a stout.
Bottled. Amber colour, average head. Slightly acidic. Fruity, slightly rounded mouthfeel, citric finish.
amber colour with a big head, vinous, vinegar aroma, decent malt body, some sourness, aftertaste of boiled vegetables

Red amber ale, beautiful head. Very nice hop aroma, floreal, light banana. Good malt, good body, some sweetness, a very light sourness in the background, light caramel taste. Good palate, medium-strong bitterness, not really aromatic. Beers of Switzerland
Bottled. Brownish amber. Acidic nose, Light bodied and simple, slightly rounded. Lactic acid dominates.
cloudy amber colour with a big foam, vinegar aroma with some malts, quite sour and acidic, medium-bodied, malty sour finish - something's wrong here

Amber-orange ale, nice head, misty. Nice hop aroma, not floreal; subtile mix of light aromas: a bit fruity, spices (black pepper), very light sourness, grapefruit. Bitter dry, as first impression, tart, light sourness; the style is close to some dry Belgian Oud Bruin, interesting, but poor malt and hop. Same notes for the palate, bitter-dry, a bit astringent. Beers of Switzerland
На удивление оказалось вкусным пивом! Знакомый купил в Багдаде и передал его мне по прилету в Ирак
COUNTRY 182. Butelka 0,33l alk. 5% Prawie brak piany, lekko kwaskowe,bezsmakowe.Serdeczne dzięki Norbert.

I did not expect beer from Iraq at all, but the english labeled can gives a hint that the main customers might not be local people. It looks quite pale with only a hint of foam. The taste? ... well although beer from Baghdad is exotic it doesn’t taste exotic but simply bad. like water with something like hops, bitter, no body, sweet at some times. No wonder the prophet did not allow the drinking of beer ...
Resin and a bit citrusy hop aroma. Clear yellowhead disappears instantly. Medium sourness, light sweetness, umami taste. Fizzy, lively. Nice drinkable beer, nothing very special but a good beer.
Foam dissapears right away. Lot of bubbles by look of it. Lightly golder color. Light hop smell. Sour, suprisingly not watery. Lightly sweet aftertaste.
Drank it today was fabulous made my day the best in Iraq possibly the Middle East. It was very fresh.
Tasted great, the aroma was good as well and love the bottle. Doing a pretty good job even though it’s in iraq

50 cl can courtesy of Bierkrug. Cereal grains very evident, pours with thick silky head, slightly sour palate and taste, decent lacing, but not much else remarkable in the palate. Props to entrepreneurs in Iraq for providing some homebrew in probably less than ideal conditions.
Milder, abgestanden wirkender Getreidebeginn mitzunehmender Herbe, die aber wässrig bleibt. Hellmalzig, laffe Süße. Plörrig bitter-wässriger Abgang. 8/4/5/4/9/4

Courtesy of Bierkrug, thanx a lot, Michael!!! Shared with Cunningham!!! In the glass the beer is pale yellow, slightly cloudy and does not have a foam. It smells malty sweet, much grains and some corn. Starts spoiled fruity, pale malty and watery. The middle part is much more watery and lax, it tastes like flavored water. Goes into a sweet-grainy, very lax finish!

Draft at the Source. Somewhat murky deep yellow light golden color with a smallish quickly dissipating white head. Spicy yeast cereal grainy aroma and flavor with just a hint of lemon. Not my favorite style, but I could pound this if I had to.
A very traditional interpretation of the style. Sharp wheat bite. Exactly what it should be.

On tap at the source in the company of jcwattsrugger. Pours a cloudy pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is wheat, clove, coriander and orange peel. Flavor is the same with the addition of some light banana. Light in the mouth and quite easy drinking. Nice.
Cloudy. Bananas and fruit juice. Taste is also banana heavy. Yeasty and fruity. Wheat heavy probably my favorite of the bunch.

Draft. Nose is spot on for style, wheat, coriander and oranges. Flavor is a traditional Belgian Wit. Orange peel, coriander with a decent wheat yeast body. Coriander seed is light, thankfully. Medium body with a sweet citrus finish.

In short: A typical brewpub witbier (wheat, bananas, coriander, etc.). Inoffensively easy to drink How: Tap at brewpub The look: Almost clear dark blonde body topped by a small white head In long: The relatively strong note (for the style) has bananas, orange peels and coriander. Taste is more of the same. Wheat, bananas, orange peels and coriander. Finish is a little dry. Body was a little slim (even for the style) and the carbonation could have been more lively. As expected, nothing special. I don’t know if I’m more a beer geek or a computer geek. After carefully examining the beer menu at Marthas I wanted to drink everything and wondered what font they used.

En fût. Verre de dégustation directement à la brasserie. Arôme: Légère odeur d’agrumes et de clous de Girofles. Apparence: La couleur est blonde voilée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence d’une mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de blés et d’agrumes avec une pointe d’épices. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Présence de blés en arrière goût. (Rating #3151)

Part of an 8 beer sampler at the restaurant. Enjoyed the restaurant and all the beers I tasted were good though nothing really stood out. Their white beer was actually pretty good for what it is though I’m not really that into the style.
on tap-pours a thin white head and yellow color. Aroma is clove, perfumy. Taste is clove, light malt/grain, perfumy/slightly spice (saaz like) hops.
Doing this from memory. Very nice beer. nice aroma and flavor, citrus/orange. Very refreshing, great wheat beer. Definitely would have it again
hazy pale golden, Aroma is mild cracker malt with some light bitter hops. Mouthfeel is light, crisp. flavor is a bit bland, metallic. Meh, its crisp.
Straw gold pour with creamy white head and lace. Very light malt and medium papery aroma. Medium semi sweet malt with a decent light/medium bitter. Not bad but not special.
12oz bottle-pours a dissipating white head and hazy yellow/gold color. Aroma is light malt, hint of hops. Taste is light malt-some sweet, some hops bite. Easy.

Big, fluffy head; recedes with a center dome. Cloudy, but solid gold color. Nice soft floral hop aroma. Attractive in a mild way. Slightly sour which is distracting. Otherwise, this is a pleasant, if soft, beer with a light malt flavor. Good hop balance. A touch of fruitiness. Rich body for the style.
Another beer with a different look, a different name, and yet tastes the same as the rest of the bad pee hops used in the other beers. All metallic.
December 2008 Beer of the Month Club Overall Impression: This was a nice smooth Blonde Ale, not too unique, but it drinks well

Beer of the month club, Jan. Just all kinds of things going on with this beer, and not in a good way. Plenty of bizarre flavors, metallic, etc. This beer, and pretty much the whole style, is skippable.

Opaque straw with light white head. Sweet straw and citrussy orange and grapefruit aroma. LIght, crisp citrussy bite at the tip of the tongue. Very lightly roasted malt with a little sweetness and a light hop bite. The taste lasts with a bit of the sweetnes and a hop bitterness along the middle of the tongue. A nice session beer. The tasts is nothing special, but the flavor is nice enough to have a few and not get bored with it.

A cloudy, dark gold pourwith a large, tight bubbled, pure white head. The flavor was much lighter than the dark color would imply. The hops also had a light touch. It goes down quickly, a good session beer. The head held up well. Not much of an aftertaste.

This has got a nice aroma, something I should be able to place but can’t right now. Quite dark for a golden, almost orange. Fruity coriander maybe? I was quite impressed with this. The flavor is sharp, maybe a bit too fruity to be a true session beer, but mostly a solid beer. Quite surprised that I liked it so much and that others didn’t.

Bomber - Poured a dark amber in color with a small white head and low carbonation. Some nice lacing apparent. Aroma is is not strong, but has a citrusy hop character. Flavor is not strong either, but a nice citrus hop flavor along with medium bitterness make it quite pleasant. Some residual sweetness in the finish provides some balance. Finish is clean with a lingering bitterness. An ok bitter brew, but not outstanding.

Light and melony aroma with citrus tones waft from this amber brew. Lacing is ample from a small off-white head. Carbonation is minimal with tight bubbles. befitting a bitter. Nicely balanced with a lingering slightly sharp bitter finish. Well crafted, but not very exciting.

The Lure: Peaches, grapefruit and cantaloup fruitiness roam atop floral hoppiness. Sweetness appears butterscotch-like at times, and for now dominates the hops, surprising for a McNeill’s brew. The Festivities: The low but adequate carbonation seems to attempt an emulation of cask bitters. Wooden hop dryness gets a little chalky at times. Grapefruit juice and cantaloup slices sit strong, as flowers grow sparsely around. Fruit get relatively sweet as caramel emboldens them, all the while remaining very drinkable due to airy spaces between flavors. Transcendence: Getting your clothes dirty, but at a picnic.
Hazy orange body with thin offwhite head. Sweet orange citrus aroma. Hollow flavor that gives a sweet tangy palate and active carbonation. Crisp clean finish.

Poured a medium golden color with an averaged sized off white head. Some floaters. Aromas of light fruits, some citrus and light toffee. Tastes of citrus, caramel and some grass in the finish. Lively body. Starts out lightly sweetand ends on a light hoppy bitter finish.

Thanks to HopDog for this. Pours a cloudy peach with floaties and a small white head that laced the glass. Aroma is bitter with lighter fruits and some spicness. Fizzy feel a little lighter in taste than aroma. Not very bitter taste. Slight caramel and pine in the finish.

Poured a hazy golden color with a thin, off white head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of citrus hops, yeast, light banana, and caramel malt. Taste of grassy hops, some citrus, toffee malt, light pine, some yeast, and a bitter hoppy finish.

Cask conditioned. Clear amber pour with a thin bubbly white head. Appealing aroma of floral and citrusy hops. Flavor of floral and citrusy hops with caramel. Medium body, smooth, confortable texture, soft carbonation.
No real aroma. Smooth mouthfeel like velvet and very nice going down. Well balanced and very nice-a.
Light brown sugary color. Sweet fruity smell. Smooth. Easy and yummy to drink. Very good!

This beer definitely has it’s own flavor. Every once in a while I really get a craving for it, but alas, it is no longer available. THIS IS NOT A SUMMIT BREW. If you have had Summit’s Finnegan’s you are NOT drinking the same beer. James Page Brewing went out of business a few years back and their recipes were purchased by Steven’s Point Brewing co. Point actually sells a few of the recipes under the name James Page, just not this one.
The head was small and diminishing. There was not much aroma, but I liked the flavor. I will order this beer again!
light in tatste at first but taste lingers, must be the patatoes. hi-ho i’m from idaho, or am i?

Page used to have a Potato Ale under their own labeling,(you have to read the fine print at the bottom to learn that it is "brewed, bottled, and supported by the James Page Brewing Co in NE Minneapolis, MN) and I have to wonder if this isn't exactly the same. Actually, I wonder why you would want to make an ale with potatoes! In the mid'90's, the Augsburger Brewery had a billboard campaign featuring art by cartoonist Charles Burns. One featured a brewer in a field holding a spud, with the slogan "NEVER made with potatoes!" But these folks are right up front with it! "A charmingly smooth pale amber ale brewed with potatoes." Amber color is right, with a small, plain head, and no aroma to speak of. After that, it's alarmingly lame. Short finish, light body, no hops, little malt...I wasn't terribly pleased. Is it smooth? Yes, to a fault. Charming? Eh, I don't know... I still don't get the potatoes. Yesterday, I visisted a reputable local brewpub and tried their Potato Stout. They just don't belong in beer! What's next, radishes? Rutabaga? Rhubarb?

Brewed and bottled by Summit Brewing. Virtually no aroma at all, maybe a faint wet graininess if I try really hard. Some decent caramel malt flavor, some hop bitterness, clean and vaguely pleasant, but I'd like at least a little aroma.

Hmm...The "finnegans" i purchased was brewed by Summit, not James Page, but perhaps there are transactions i am not aware of. This beer is quite tasty. It's light, creamy, malty and easily surpasses other "Irish" beers on the market. This beer is rather thin but quite well-balanced and drinkable. A solid 6 pack buy.

Sparkling clear, deep golden ale with a small, fizzy, white head. The aroma is a touch bisquity with notes of chicken broth. Lightly floral. The flavor is well-balanced but fairly bland and thin. Light-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, crisp, clean finish. Brewed with potatoes? Novel, I guess... the whole Irish theme.

The first whif straight off the bottle reminds me of pot roast with those baby potatoes and gravy.Copper color,small head with the above for an aroma,with a malty side to it.The flavor is malty with a slight sweet taste and mild hops at best with maybe a hint of spuds.The after taste is sweet malt with a mild hop presence and maybe a starchy potatoe(maybe) this is a pretty decent brew and from the desc.goes for a good cause.Leave it to James Page to help the less fortunate when they themselves are a struggling craft brewer.

I'm not exactly sure this is the same Finnegans Irish Amber since the bottle says it is brewed by Summit, which of course is a local competitor to James Page. Just for the record the label on the bottle is brown and green and states it is brewed with potatoes. Also states "As Irish as it Gets!" However here is my humble opinion. Not much aroma at all. Very little almost non existant head. Poured amber color a bit darker than the picture with nowhere near that head. Flavor was very smooth and pleasant but not significant. Carbonation was not great but at least not entirely flat tasting. This at least warrants a try for a hot summer day. I'd drink it again but won't go out of my way to get any more.

Faint Aroma, nice amber color, but poor head retention. The head is even already dissapating in the photo on this page! However, this is a very pleasant brew, with a dry, subtle hoppy aftertaste with notes of creaminess. I could drink this all night.
2009 rating. Keg at the brewpub. Poured a clear amber color with a small head. Nice refreshing flavor slightly malty with a quick finish.
alla spina chiara poca schiuma non molto persistente debole aroma in bocca leggero malto e luppolo molto watery sia nel corpo che nel gusto
Bottle. No defects but no outstanding features, balanced but a bit too watery.

A very suprising beer full of a very unique taste. It’s almost a bit syrupy -- but at the same time very dry. Entirely different from the Anchor and quite refreshing. A nice change from the malt-heavy crap that most italian breweries spew out when they’e not making poor lager.
No aroma. Nice taste, most of all hoppy, some malt in the middle. Pleasant hoppy palate.
Light aroma and flavour of wheat beer. Simple, watery palate................
2009 rating. Keg at the brewpub. It pours a clear golden color with medium white head. Aroma with erbal notes. Taste is mostly bitter with some spicy notes. Dry finish. Quite thin bodied.

rossa buona schiuma mediamwente persistente sentori fruttati fragola leggermente aciduli non so se era voluta e cosa ma il mio bicchiera aveva un sentore netto di fragola ed era leggermente acidula errore o pregio
Poor aroma. Watery, with some caramel taste; no malt, no hop, a bit metallic. Poor final.
Gold ale, misty; thick head. Light, but nice hop aroma. Dry, good hop, not too much malt, weak body. Nice palate, bitter and aromatic, enough long

Amber ale, thick head. Light malt and hop aroma. Warm in the mouth, yet the body is weaken by some carbonation; good balance, strong hop, caramalt. Nice palate, strong bitterness. Very similar to a bitter ale.
Red ale. Very light roasted malt aroma. Pretty strong roasted malt taste, good hop balance, nice hop palate, strong bitterness.

2009 rating. Keg at the brewpub. Amber colour, not much head. Madeira-nose with lots of wood in it. Also slight alcohol noteable. Flavour is very much madeira along with malts, raising and a nice sting of alcohol. Also some fruityness.

Ehh, strong, yes, unique, no. It’s much like most "doppio malto" here, but I appreciated that lack of disturbing sweetness that I usually associate with beers of this type here. English strong ale? Ok.
Simple aroma, malt, candy sugar. Nice body, smooth, rather sweet, lightly malty, not enough balanced by the hop. Rather poor palate.
Tasted a vintage bottle 30cl from 2003. full brown beer with a malty nose and taste. Due to age, some notes of chocolate, sherry and alcohol. Too bad, i should have drunk it fresh in 2003.
Brown coloured. Nutty and malty with notes of chocolate. Smooth and mild mouthfeel.
Caramelly, yeasty,flavours dominate. Quite dry and mild, with some mild tartness, quite Belgian in character, enjoyable (Bottle-GBBF 03')

Bottled. GBBF2003. Muddy red brown, good thin white head and moderate condition. Low malty aromas, with hints of figs and roast barley. Slightly apple tangy in the mouth but with plenty of dark malt to counter it. Dry and roasty finish with some faint hoppiness lingering. Not a bad dubbel.

Dark brown color, with firm thick lacing, very nice. Aroma of roasted malts and caramel malts. Sweet taste, again a bit 'stouty' of the roasted malts, coffee, salami. Bitter palate. Decent dubbel, but somewhat too roasted for me.

Mmm i see i'm the first one to rate this beverage, so i guess i have to say more than just "good dubbel" ;-). Very dark brown appearance, initially large head, beautiful lacing, similar to La Trappe's dubbel. Aroma of roasted malts, raisins and liquorice perhaps? Nose is pretty nice but not very strong (perhaps gets better when warming up). Malty flavour, obvious sweetness, a bit of coffee and a hint of chocolate. Quite nice, but it could use some additional elements, perhaps aging could help. Palate is initially bitter, but then goes on to be more sweet and a bit coffee-ish. Overall quite nice. Likely to be one of the best beers of this brewer.

Draught. Clear pale gold with white head. A little limestone and corn in the nose, mild bitterness and a little dry in the mouth, very carbonated and light body underneath. A little corny aftertaste but not bad.

Dark golden color, no head. Strongly buttery aroma, sweetness too. Thin to medium bodied. Sweet start in flavor ends with tangy and biting hops, butter tones too. Lasting bitterness and butter in aftertaste.
Pale golden. Neutral aroma. Light bodied, very sweet, clean. Boring.........
28th May 2006. Warning! Early amateur rating! Bottle in Riga. Refreshing lager. Slightly fruity. Bitterish but with a clean finish. Respectable.

the curiously shaped bottle no doubt figured into my friends mind in picking an exotic latvian beer to bring home to me. it’s cool: kind of shaped like a baseball bat, tho my guess it that it’s been labeled as exhibit "A" in more than a few trials of assault and battery in riga bar fights. the beer is frightfully pale-- brewed with albino malt presumably-- but the head was adequate and virginal white, a cotton crown suitable for a family-sized aspirin bottle. the hops arrived aromatically intact, all the way from northern europe to just under my nose-- where they resembled saaz and were reasonably pleasing. alas, they were also handicapped by the smell of open manhole, and grapes of the disreputable sort that go into wines like boone’s farm. for all of those flaws, cesu is still quenching and drinkable, albeit thin as a vegetarian lion. there were notes of grain, sweet pound cake, and a bounce dryer sheet. noted was a tinkle of fading bitterness in the finish. the beer may have been designed once upon a time to be a serious pilsner; if so, the process has gotten just a little slack presently. perhaps the poor, jaded brewer lost faith in all mankind and just said "fuck it" and decided to design the bottle to look like a billy club. and then he threw his work-boots into the wort.

Nifty 300 ml octagonal A leCoq brown glass bottle, bought in Riga. ABV is 5.0%. Pale golden colour, large to moderate white head. Fruity and flowery aroma, quite nice. The flavour is also fruity and quite refreshing. Lemony finish. Some more malts and bittering hops might have been a good idea. Light bodied, soft mouthfeel. No masterpiece, but better than I feared.

Yellow colored, lively carbonation with medium sized white head. Surprisingly clean aroma with lemon and esters, some fruits also, still no very much in there. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is more unclean with mild cardboard, maybe some grainy tones also. Lemon lasts in aftertaste, which dries mildly. Nothing much.
This is my favorite beer. In my opinion Cesu alus is the best brevery in whole of Latvia
Canned. Yellow with minor white head. It has a flavour of sweet hops with a bitter twist.

Bottle, from Rhythm & Booze, Brigg. Pale gold, initial sudsy big bubbled head soon dropping but leaving a lasting thin white head, moderate condition. Good solid Bohemian hops and sweet honeyed maltiness in the nose, slight startchiness in the mouth with some tinny blood notes that soon disappear leaving gentle grainy malt. Estery/startchy in the finish with some bitterness. Starts well but goes downhill quickly.

Bottled Nice special bottle - of one Estonian A Le Coq beers, I wonder if beer is also basicly the same. Pale yellow, small white head. Grassy corn aroma. Malty, crisp and very watery. Like a "Light beer". Too light to be remembered.
Very pale yellow coloured. Some grassy notes in the aroma and in the flavour. Unpleasant plastic notes are there as well. Very thin.
Golden color with a white head. The taste is thin with a light citrus bitterness.
Bottle (thanks marduk). Tastes golden. Aroma is nasty, grainy, caramelly, cardboardy. Flavor follows the nose. Overall: horror.
500ml plastic bottle, thanks Marduk. Clear golden colour. Aroma is grainy, metallic, malty. Taste is metallic, bland, dusty. Bitterish finish, some booze. Very bad.
500ml bottle (Alko1000, Valka). Clear dark yellow color. Huge size, white head, stays. Sweet, malty, caramel, papery, husky in aroma. Husky, sweet, malty in taste. Fizzy carbonation. Nope.

500ml Bottle - Golden with a white head. Sweet and malty aroma with hints of corn. The taste is sweet and malty with a sweet and slightly bitter finish. Drinkable, but gets a bit sweet and sickly after a while.
Bottle. Clear golden. Short bubbly white head. Sweet siruppy alco malty aroma. The flavour is siruppy sweet with malt some bitter hops. Bitter finish.
Shared with fatphil, thanks! Small, almost no head, medium yellow colour. Not a great aroma, but the taste is almost balanced and has a good, clean, bitter finish.

500ml bottle. Shared with Tranquillity - sorry! (3:2:3:2:6=1.6) Yellow, brief head. Smells of nothing. No real taste, a bit of malt somewhere if I hunt for it. Not actually nasty in any way, but basically fall-over juice. Rerate: 500ml plastic bottle - Thanks Marduk! (4:2:4:2:9=2.1) "Better" this time. Grainier ESL aroma. More mainstream macro ESL taste, quite papery. Tastes like a 9%-er watered down to 7%. Bitter finish. Still fall-over juice. Averaging the scores, even though later is more relevant.
Yellow with medium head 500ml bottel a really flat beer with some bitternes has a sweer mouth felling but not really good.
Extremely pale coloured. Slightly sour aroma. Very sweet and very thin. A really foul strong lager.
Golden color with a white head. The taste sweet light malty with a metallic slight hoppy bitterness. Comes off a little thin.
Can on a terrace in Riga. Clear golden coloured with a small white head. Malty aroma of hay and bread. Malty flavour of hay, bread and hops. Hoppy finish.

Klar lys gylden med hvitt skum. Aroma malt epke humle korn. Smak humle eple. Fylde men kort, kjipt øl. Boks kjøpt på XLyngen mens Tottenham og Liverpool spiller fotball. Håper kampen blir bedre enn ølet
Orange color, middle foam size. Good beer, aroma and taste fit into the style.

Kolor: Jasnozłoty, klarowny. Piana: Biała, obfita, drobnopęcherzykowa, w miarę trwała, niezły lacing. Zapach: Zbożowy, całkiem czysty profil. Smak: Zbożowy, to zboże lekko mokre jak w wersji Amber ,ale ogólnie całkiem smacznie, choć goryczka minimalna. Wysycenie średnie w stronę wysokiego, treściwość charakterystyczna dla stylu. Piło się całkiem dobrze.
Pint can @ Riga, outdoors. Straight from the can. sweetish malty flavors, bulky with non existent finish. light bitterness.

Bottle 0,568L. Courtesy of Kita. Clear, pale golden color with a finger of frothy, white head. Aroma of grain and some very light caramel. Taste is light sweet with some weird cardboard/metallic notes and some light bitterness at the end of the sip. Not good at all and hardly drinkable.

Can. Light golden, small to average and mostly diminishing head. Light to moderate, malty - grainy and dryish - lightly sweetish aroma, faint herbal/vegetable hoppyness, light metal.
