Body is light to medium, malty - grainy anddryish - lightly sweetish flavor, faint herbal/vegetable hoppyness, light metal. Finish is short to average, malty - grainy and dryish, light herbal/vegetable hoppyness, light metal. Dryish lager with notes of sharp metal. Not really a "premium".

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega piirdun iga õlle juures selle tekstiga.

Can, 0.568l, courtesy of Danijel. Aroma is grainy, grassy, citrusy and vegetably. Pours clear pale golden color with large frothy white head, good lacing and sparkling appearance. Taste starts light sweet grainy with adjunct feel, following is vegetably and papery with really unpleasant bitter finish. Light body, slick texture and average carbonation in palate. Impossible to drink with pleasure...
On tap at the ferry. Slightly hazy with white head. Malty and a bit yeasty, slight banana notes.
0,5l fles op het strand bij pludmale in riga, goudoranje met een witte kraag. Smaak Is zoet graanachtig met grassig hop. Ik heb slechtere gehad.

Bottle, RB Århus tasting @ Christers. Pours very pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma of malt, grain, cardboard. Flavor is malt, grainy, cardboard, hint of fruity and grassy hops. Thin watery body, lively carbonation. 030413
Can @ Aarhus-Randers tasting. Clear very pale yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, light malty and bready. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. Watery. 040313
Can. Clear pale yellow with medium white head. Aroma is malt, straw, hop and grainy. Flavour is malt, straw, grainy, hop and watery.
Pale yellow, white head. Watery, fizzy, some vague maltiness-hoppiness with metallic-sweet notes.
500ml Bottle - Amber/gold with a small white head. Malty and slightly grainy aroma. Malty taste with grain and hints of bread. Refreshing to drink cold, but extremely bland and dull.
Bottle. Very watery. Probably after sauna? When you are thirsty? Some malty and hoppy tones, but it is all.
Amber lager. Pleasant malty/honey aroma but hoppy taste with hints of malt and fruit. Very drinkable.

Bottle. Pours a clear deep golden colour with a bubbly creamy well lasting white head. Aroma of hops and grains with a strange sour touch. Thin mouthfeel. Flavour of grains with some malt, some bitter hops and caramel.

Shared with fatphil, thanks! Quite golden, small white head. Smells like any Nordic lager. Doesn’t taste good either. No wait - actually it’s bad. The distinction between "not good" and "bad" is a line drawn in the water, as with this beer.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of fine to medium sized mostly diminishing white colored bubbles that left behind no lacing. The body contained average carbonation, was transparent and straw yellow in color. Its aroma contained notes of mild malt to no aroma. Its mouth feel is initially smooth flat with a lingering palate and a smooth aftertaste. Its flavor contained mild malt hop notes.
Dayton Draft. Clear amber color with small white head. Aroma was little to none. Flavor was smooth and refreshing with small sweet finish. Sorry, this is another moist air light.
(Dayton) Faint yellow pear cider body, white head. No discenible aroma. Taste is mild, medium sweet, some biscuit, no bitterness. Light body. Quite a waste of a tap.

Rated at TDBC. Small white head that mostly diminished, fine-small sized bubbles, good lacing, carbonated, transparent, and a yellow hue. Aroma was malty and sweet. Flavor was sweet, malty and smooth. Smooth mouthfeel and light body.
Obviously, this is Thirsty Dog's beer for the fizzie masses. Thin and yello. Malts are sweet, but not overly so. Try a sample and move on to some of their better beers.
Slightly foul nose, yellow pissy color, low tight head. Fresh from tap, but this just isn't a good beer. Sweet canned corn-like maltiness. Thin and watery.
thin, light. It gets points for not bing obnoctious or vile, but your standard light beer.
eeeh. Pretty much a typical light beer - but not quite as terrible..........
Not bad for a light beer, but it's a light beer so there are much better choices at a brewpub like this.
Dayton draft. Good combo of a friut beer and porter styles. Complex aroma and flavor of raspberry and chocolate malt that had balanced medium finish. Good brew that you can use to smoke a cigar.

Brown hue with ruby highlights, fading head and minimal lace. The nose was full raspberry juice with just a hint of roasted malts, nothing else. The taste is fruity and tart with the nutty buttery note. Some smoke upon the finish. Thin and lively feel. Arggh! Too fruity and not enough porter character.

So we are having dinner at the Dayton Brewpub and he orders the Nut Brown Ale. The waitress brings him this beer that smells and tastes distinctly of raspberrys. He complains, because he doesn't like many fruit beers, and she brings him another one. Same thing. Turns out neither the waitress not the bartender are allowed to taste anything, so they have no idea that they have the wrong keg tapped. Based on the color and flavor, we ended up drinking what we assumed to be the raspberry porter. Well, he drank most of it, I do not like fruit beers. I wanted the nut brown ale.

So we are having dinner at the Dayton Brewpub and I order the Nut Brown Ale. The waitress brings me this beer that smells and tastes distinctly of raspberrys. I complain, because I don't like many fruit beers, and she brings me another one. Same thing. Turns out neither the waitress not the bartender are allowed to taste anything, so they have no idea that they have the wrong keg tapped. Based on the color and flavor, I ended up drinking what I assume to be the raspberry porter. It was a deep mahogany color with a slightly medicinal raspberry nose. Not overpowering syrup taste for a fruit beer (like that awful Pete's Winter) but a nice infusion of raspberry tartness over a solid porter. I still don't prefer fruit beers.
Nose of what? raspberry? you guessed it. The raspberry and choclate blend well together, not overbearing. Clean at he finish. Bow wow!

This mixed breed of Poodle (raspberry ale) and Boxer (old leghumper porter) produces one of those dogs that's so ugly that it's cute. This is like a Chocolate/Raspberry truffle - save it for dessert - it doesn't go well with their tex-mex burrito! The strength of their porter is the only thing that saves this one from the kennel.
ugh. Amazingly this tastes just like the other Raspberry beer from Thirsty Dog, except it is darker and not quite as carbonated. For comments, see Thirsty Dog Raspberry Ale.

Great raspberry aroma that does not carry over to the flavor. I am guessing this is a blend of the Old Leghumper and Raspberry Ale, and it is a great breed. Roasted chocolate flavor and an excellent experience.

16 ounce draft at Winking Lizard Macedonia Ohio Floral scent with the hops. Deep golden in color. Medium white head with some film on glass. Really smooth with very little hop taste. Taste some malt Just a little citrus after taste. Overall I was surprised how drinkable this beer is. Pretty nice for the style. Cheers!
Pours a hazy honey golden with a loose white head.......aroma of bready malt, pine, citrus.......taste is crisp, clean, pine, citrus.
Tap @ Top Hops, NYC. Pours hazy amber with a white head. Aromas of grapefruit, malt and caramel. Flavours of caramel, pine, floral and grapefruit. Smooth texture, bitter finish. Very nice.

Cask @ Albion, dry-hopped with Mosaic. Murky brown with sediment floating down to the bottom of the glass, medium sized beige foamy head, faint citrus aroma, low carbonation, flat sweetish caramel taste with citrus bitterness and throat-irritating chili like effect kicking in later. longish mosaic flavored hoppy finish. Interesting brew, not sure whether I liked or not.
Excellent citrus malt aroma. Excellent balance between the two. Interesting seeing that their success with this one at the GABF goes back to 2001.

Pours bright clear gold, admirable head. Nose of sweet gently roasted malt, parfumy flowery hops, funky lemon rind. Flavor has a substantial malt body, a perceived ripe fruitiness from the malt/hop combo at first, then malts drop out to reveal a bright grapefruit rind and flowery hop finish/linger. This definitely is a hoppy American amber, yet hop profile is very rindy, bitter, and lacks a more ripe depth. Still a solid and choice offering if you’re looking for a little bit of a pale ale kick to an amber. Their hoppiest beer, though? I sure hope not.

Bottle. Pours hazy reddish gold with a fluffy white head. Aromas of sweet fruit--caramel and apricot--and citrus hops. Flavors of honey, ginger, stone fruit, caramel and bitter citrus. Crisp finish with a lingering hop bite. Somewhat oily mouthfeel. Very nice beer!
Cloudy, dark orange body with a medium-lasting white head. Very hoppy aroma with seaweed notes. Very hoppy bitter taste mixed with orange zest, short-lived. Medium body has a nice tangy feel.

This was poured into a pint glass. Bottle came from Batdorf, Annville PA. The appearance was a hazy red color with a slim bar pour’s kind of white head. The smell mainly had a malty sweet caramel malts with a subdued grassy/earthy hoppiness to it. The taste took all of those previously mentioned flavors to combine and give off a decent amount of light caramel notes in the aftertaste. The finish was quick. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was somewhat subdued. Overall, I say this was an okay American Amber ale that I could have again but nothing over the top.

Pours a nice amber color with a good two finger head..aroma is slightly citrus..kind of a disappointment when you have a name like this..I expected a hopps bomb..not the case..flavor is malty goodness with some roasted and toffee notes..all in all avg amber brew

Bottled. Dark brown colour, close to black, mediumsized brownish head. Aroma is caramel malts, some roasted malts as well as coffee and chocolate. Flavour is roasted malts, some burnt wood, chocolate and dark dry fruity notes as well.

Bottle, Ale Cellar, Darlington. Poured a deep dark brown, near enough black really. Not much of a head to speak of. Malty,chocolate orange aroma. Soft mouthfeel. Sweet, roasted malt flavour with good fruit notes. Dryish finish. A tidy porter for sure.
Bottle. Pours black with a brownish head. Aroma is sweet, malty with toffee. Flavour of roasted malt and toffee.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a decent creamy beige head. Rich aroma and taste of roasted malts, coffee and licorice. Sweetish finish.
From Voldby, DK. Bottled, 170608. Dark brown with reddish shine. Aroma of coffee. Flavor is dry from roasted barley but with some sweetness counteracting. Balanced bitterness

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a diminishing light brown head. Small lacing. Sweetish, roasted aroma. Notes of cooked vegetables appear as it warms, but it’s not that bad. Flavour is sweet and roasted as well, with a medium bitterness and liquorice notes. Metallic notes appear as it warms. Finish is coffee and bitter chocolate with a sweet touch. A decent porter. 05-06-08.

Bottled. Tasting @ Kolding Bryglaug. Aroma has roast, coffee and chocolate. Black coloured with an off-white head. Taste is sweet with roasted malts, coffee/chocolate, some fruits and hops. Dry finish. Good one.
Bottle. Very dark brown with a small off-white head. Fruity and malty aroma, with some molasses. Rich and fruity flavour, malty with a dry, roast finish.
Bottle @ thewolf-and-his-flock-of-sheep tasting session. Clear dark color, short head. Aroma of malt, brambles, ripe fruit. Dry fruity taste.
Dark brown with tiny beige head. Sweet with roasted malt, caramel, bitter coffee and hoppy notes.
Much too malty. I needed a water chaser.....................................
Interesting - but too malty for my taste....................................
Very, very malty! Amber color and minimal lacing. Rich texture and flavor, I will definitely get this one again.

12 ounce bottle at sissy’s house. smell the spices. Golden orange in color. Small white head. Taste the spices and some pumpkin. Not sweet. Light bodied with a nutmeg finish. Nice beer and local favorite. Cheers!
Pumpkin and allspice nose. Clear copper, thick head. Slight stewed tomato, allspice. Medium body, moderate carbonation.
Pretty decent pumpkin ale. Nice aroma with pumpkin and honey coming through. Would buy again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Drinking a little out of season but a pretty approachable beer. Copper colored, brown sugar and light cinnamon flavors - mesh nicely.

Bot. Late for punky, no? Smell is decent real mild pumpkin. Looks like a yuengy. Taste is sizzly biting co2 laced with an above average amount of pumpkin spice. Seems to have more alky than 5 fer sure. Rude malty medicinal finish.

Poured a clear amber colour with a thick frothy white head with good retention and left nice lacing. Aroma is of cinnamon, nutmeg, pumpkin, and a bit of graham cracker. Flavor is of pumpkin, bready malts, and holiday spice. Well balanced medium bodied brew with a slight bitter malt finish.

12 oz. bottle from ryanmcfly1985 - thanks again, Ryan! Pours a clear gold with a bit of an orange hue and a small off-white head that lasts as a thick ring and film and laces the glass unevenly. Notes of pumpkin spice up front - nutmeg, allspice, cinnamon, ginger - graham cracker, earth, lightly roasted pumpkin, and a surprisingly big bready malt finish. Moderate level of spice in this one. More in the nose, while the flavor is maltier. Light-bodied, with modest carbonation. Pretty smooth. Not bad.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a hazy orange color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute. There was some light lacing all along the glass. The smell had some pumpkin up front with a nice allocation of cinnamon, allspice and ginger. The taste was there as it took the previously mentioned flavors and combined them really nicely. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium with a slight sessionability about it. Carbonation was somewhat smooth. Overall, though I can’t get this beer where I currently live, I would love to have it again some day as when I was able to have it, it was always a go to pumpkin ale.

2013 12 oz bottle with a label that says "PUMPKIN ALE - ale brewed with pumpkin, honey & spices". Not emphasizing the spices anymore? In any case, the spicing level on this is excellent. Even though the aroma suggests a higher level of spicing, tasting reveals a balanced blend of caramelized pumpkin, malts and spices, with a hint of hops. Very mildly sweet. Mediumlight caro

Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Clear orange amber brew with steady white head. Aroma of pumpkin pie spice. Taste is sweet with pumpkin fruit hints, a little spice in the finish (glad that it was restrained) and a little bitter. Nice seasonal brew.
Dark amber colored pour with a thin tan head. Aroma is thick rich toffee. Taste is caramel malts, toffee, and a nutty flavor. Full and rich. Somewhat buttery, and a mild tart finish. Not bad.
Malty with plenty of toast and toffee and peat. Nice and earthy with a nip of tartness at the tail. Full body. Light carbonation. Medium brown with a small ring of tan head.

Pint at new Thirsty Dog Tap house. Draft. Not much aroma. Thin white head. No film on glass. Deep brown in color. Sweet, some malt flavor. Smooth and very drinkable. Above average for the style Cheers!

A fairly standard Scottish ale. Pours a beautiful ruby red with a thick soapy head. Smells good, caramel, malt, dark fruit and cucumber. Taste is more basic, malt and caramel, and not much in the finish. Had in the bottle. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours clear red has zero, small tan head, dissipates fairly quickly, decent lacing. Aroma is malty, nutty, a bit smoky, dark bread. Flavor is medium sweet, minimal bitterness, bland, water, hint of copper. Light body.
Bland aroma of grain, malt, and mild caramel. Deep dark brown with almost no head. Fairly bitter for the style. Odd note of fruitiness. Medium bodied.

12 ounce bottle - $2.49 at Total Wine & More in Greenville, South Carolina. Appearance: Pours a relatively clear, dark reddish-brown body with a slim, thin, light ecru head. Smell: Toasty, lightly nutty with a thin shaving of roast. A little fruitiness. Modest notes of cocoa and the brownest of sugars. Taste: A washed out, watered-down taste of heavily toasted bread given a bit of brown sugar sweetness and a hint of cocoa powder. Light raisiny fruitiness. A modest touch of spicy hops with a very low bitterness. Sweetish, toasty finish. Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium-low carbonation. Overall: So-so.
Fairly thin body, not overly malty. Slight swetness at the end but not too much. Very drinkable.
Pours a amber color. Sweet aroma with roasted malts and molasses. It is very highly carbonated. Tastes of roasted malts, hoppy grass and an off taste of seltzer.

Tallahassee, Fl - New Leaf Market - 12 oz bottle Deep dark brown pour, some reddish tints. Light bone colored head that clings to the edge of the glass. Toffee-like aroma, some light chocolate. Rich flavor, some toffee, caramel, a touch of molasses. Decently thick mouthfeel. Nice treat.
Nice blend of two of their beers - You get the chocolate/roast of the Old Leghumper, thinned out a bit and brightened by the ale's hops. This would be an o.k. session ale.
Not bad, but pretty bland. From the looks of it - I expected much more.....
A good mixture and a good balance of the two styles present in this beer. The hops in the Pale Ale complement the sweetness in the Stout. Well done.

California crisp has a light fruity aroma. The color is a light copper with an off white head. There is a fruity essence to the flavor with a caramel background. Crisp has a medium body and a quick clean finish.
Deep orange brown. Layered goodness. A bitter and perfumy quality to the flavor. Carbonation light. A few off flavors induced by malts. Overall, rather papery and bland/flat. Its alright.

Sampled from a fresh growler. I really think Thirsty Dog could have taken this in an interesting direction- instead, it is merely a watered-down version of their "stock" beer. Clear amber/copper appearance, thin off-white head. Aroma opens up with grassy hops that settle into a light fruity malt matrix. Light, fruity flavor with hints of caramel, touching on candy, with grassy hops tickling the palate. Light body and light in every aspect, but not very complex or interesting.
This was a hazy dark amber with a wisp of white head. It had a fruity, flowery aroma. Caramel and toast. It’s light and a bit sweet.

Smelled "fresh". Unlike the other hooligans at my table (Jsquire, BBB63, & Aracauna), my glass had fantastic lacing - it had to have something to do with me because this phenomonon continued throughout most of our day. Body was light, almost watery; taste had a citrusy zing down the center with (only) hints of bread. Finish was crisp and clean and left you wanting more. First brew of Drew’s Magical Mystery Tour 2004.
Hazy orange with a very thin white head that disappeared to a ring very quickly. Very little nose. Some faint hop notes with doughy yeast hints. Refreshing because of its watery body.

Amber hue with small head and no lace. The aroma hints of orange zest, apple, apricot, caramel, toffee, rye bread and floral hops. The taste has a mild bitterness with a fruity character, good malt balance. The mouthfeel is smooth, clean and crisp with some chalky aftertaste. A good session beer.
Clear amber color, nice white head, very mild flavor. It's not hoppy, but certainly not sweet. I don't taste Any rye. It's an OK session or lawnmower beer. Not bad, but not great.

This beer medaled at the GABF, not as a rye beer(which it is), but in sort of a miscellaneous category. Looks like a pale ale. Moderate white head, translusent gold color. Aroma of sweet carmel. As previously note little hops to speak of. Flavor is mostly sweet. Finish sweet and carmelly too! I liked this beer and think it would make a good session beer.
Light nose, pale amber color, sticky head. Pez candy-like taste. Odd mix of hops and malt - bac balance. Unsuccessful.

Beautiful straw-golden color, with excellent foam! Nose. Malt with grassy hops. Taste. The body of the beer is soft and very pleasant. On the palate is a malt base, sweetish. The aftertaste is slightly bitter hop with a hint of bread.
Lata 0,568 l Color dorada clara con espuma blanca,fina,alta,bastante resistente.Aroma malta,herbal.Sabor ligero amargor con notas dulces,malta,herbal

Kolor: Jasnozłoty, klarowny. Piana: Biała, dość obfita, drobnopęcherzykowa, żwawo opada. Zapach: Słodowy, słodki, lekko kukurydziany. Smak: Słodkawy, słodowy, ale bardzo subtelny z niską goryczką. Wysycenie średnie, treściwość dość niska. To piwo nie jest smaczne, ale też nie odrzuca.
17.03.2019. 0,5l Can. Bought in Riga. Thanks Eivind! Yellow colour with white head. Dry with grassy hops. Soft and neutral. Straw and hay in both aroma and flavours. Short and soft bitter aftertaste.

Can, 0.568l, courtesy of Danijel. Aroma is grassy, grainy, vegetably, papery and metallic. Pours clear straw color with medium sized soapy white head and sparkling appearance. Tastes medium sweet biscuity, bready, grassy, vegetably and skunky with unpleasantly bitter finish. Light body, creamy texture and average carbonation in palate. Misery...

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega piirdun iga õlle juures selle tekstiga.

Unter einem "Gaišais"-Bier versteht man in Lettland ein Helles. Dies ist ein klassischer Vertreter dieses Typs. Das einzige, dass ein bisschen auffällt, ist ein extra herber Nachgeschmack, der ein bisschen ins metallische geht. Man kann es schon trinken, aber es gibt bessere Biere (auch von dieser Brauerei).
Can: 568 ml, Price: 1,09 eur Latvian coast tour (Liepaja-Ventspils-Jurmala)
568 ml can. Clear pale yellow color with small white head. Smells grass and barley. Taste are barley with some brown sugar sweetness and and some flowers. Aftertaste short time barley and sweetcorn.
the aroma is malty and herbal with shades of grain, resin and straw... the taste is malty and herbal, rather clear, with notes of grain, hay, flowers and perfume... bitter and dry aftertaste...
Bottle. Dark brown colr with brown head. Caramel and malty aroma. Malty and caramel flavor and I feel something like oil? So common.

Bottle, 50cl - Dark red brown clear beer with a large beige head. Aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel and spices. Flavor is malty with notes of roasty malts, spices and caramel. Not too bad, but nothing special.
500ml Bottle - Dark brown with some red tinges. Fruity and malty aroma with some raisins. Fruity and slightly roasted taste with raisins and some liquorice notes. Not too bad.
500 ml bottle. Rīga, Latvia. Dark amber brown colour with fluffy white head. Nice. Quite light flavour. Oily, bit cola-like feel without the carbonation.
Deep amber brown pour. Rich roasted flavour with malt, caramel and liquorice. Light, but decent.
[Bottled at DØE-Ølfestival, Århus, 2008.] Not that bad for a beer with some low expects. Amber with sweet caramel aroflavors. Dry and some dunkelroast in the finish.
Bottle at ÅBF08. Grainy aroma. Clear, dark, beautiful chestnut colour. Roasted flavour, good maltiness. The roastedness gets a little bitter. Not too bad.

Bottle 50cl. Clear medium amber brown color with a average, frothy, good lancing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, chocolate, light brown sugar. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (170508)
Bottled at Ølfestival, Århus, 2008. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with strong notes of caramel, while the flavor is sweet with notes of both caramel and metal.
Dark red-brown and the aroma has sweetness and notes of candy sugar and caramel. The flavour has sweetness, notes of roasted malt, caramel, candy sugar and a slightly dry finish.
Bottled (BB 07/2005) Golden yellow, small white head. Grassy, plastic aroma. Medium-bodied. Some grassy hops, slightly unclean lager with some sourness.

(Bottled@HBF 2005) Pale golden color with a smallish head. Slightly buttery, stingy, quite original aroma (not very pleasant). Strangely chocolatey, low-malt, low-hop flavor. Light-bodied and quite carbonated palate. A light, quite unclean brew.

Hazy, honey light golden color. Not really characteristic of a lager. White, thin head. Not a whole bunch of carbonation. Light malty aroma with a little hop note. Light mouthfeel, almost like Fraoch, hints of heather maybe? Not a bad brew, refreshing.
Light yellow color with a small white head. A lighter less offensive version of their original.

After the last Kimmel I tried, I don''t know why I decided to try another, but the White cried out to me. I procede. Pours a cloudy light golden color with a head that turns into little wax islands floating on the top. Smells a bit like sourdough bread dough with a touch of light vinegar and goat cheese. Once again, rather complex. Tin, blood and a touch of caramel flavor, with a sharp bitterness in the finish that leads to a rather rusty vapid afterglow ending. I realy must stop my morosistic, masochistic, martyrdom with this brewery! My head hurts!
Golden coloured, rich head. Spicy aroma. Medium bodied, sweet, big funky cellar flavour.
A fairly decent selection, although very weak in all categories. Perhaps this beers best feature was its appearance, reminiscent of an amber ale.
Bottled (BB 08/2005) Pale yellow, mostly vanishing white head. Sour, grassy, malty aroma. Grassy, malty and slightly sweet flavor. Boring.
Amber honey with a decent 3/4" head. The aroma is fairly good with a balance of malt and hops. Taste is thin.

This bottled brew poured a small head of fine to medium sized white colored long lasting bubbles that left behind a good lace. The body is carbonated hazy and dark yellow brown in color. It had a sweet lager aroma and an odd metallic mouth feel that was somewhat off. The flavor was metallic and malty. It was not a good brew, but it was also not an awful brew. I'll not voluntarily buy this one again while there are so many better brews readily available.

Bottle. This beer formed a small sized white head that was creamy with fine-small sized bubbles that fully diminished. The body was semi-transparent with fast rising carbonation and a pale yellow hue. The nose was malty, lightly hoppy and sweet. The flavor was bitter and it had a lingering aftertaste that was unpleasant. The mouthfeel was fairly smooth. This was a light bodied beer with sparse lacing. I was unimpressed with this beer overall.

Pale yellow with clumps of 'wanna-be' head bubbles floating on top. Some corn in the nose, slight hint of grassy hop. Tastes surprisingly like Cheerios breakfast cereal, very dull. Some grassiness at the finish, as in the nose.
Sweet whole grain flavors. Fairly harmless all around, but overall pretty lame.
Nice pale tan white body, no real head. Smell is subtle yeast. The taste is very bland--not good, like the moment before you puke. The terrible taste lingers well after you are finished drinking it.
Clear gold color with a small white head. Pleasant grain aroma initially that turns more cornlike upon warming. The taste and aftertaste have an unpleasant grain taste and bitterness.

Not horrible, by any means. Too sugary for a lager of the type, I think, but the aroma contains some bitterness and so does the close of the flavor, but it is a little thick and indistinct. Hey, it's summer!
Very dark reddish brown. Big unpleasant apple and cellar aroma. Sweet, medium bodied, fatty and unclean. I'm afraid this is the worst porter I've tried.

0.5 l bottle. Sampled in Riga. Pours deep mahogany with khaki head. Bready malt aroma along with some light hop scent. Nice full mouthfeel, it is thick and malty. Some nutty, caramely flavors. Not much sweetness, which earns it points. Some off flavors/armoas like dirty dishwater, as well. And a little bitterness in the aftertaste. An ok Latvian dark.

Bottled as "Kimmel Rigas Tumsais" (BB 02/2007). Dark rubycolor, good tan head. Sweet caramelly aroma of fudge. Medium-bodied. Creamy mouthfeel. Caramelly with malty finish. Sort of "the brewery is not the most modern" -feeling here - some flavors are unclean.
Bottled dark red. Sweet malty caramel aroma. Malty slight sweet, quite good beer.

Bottled. Ruby red colour, small beige head. Aroma at first quite caramnellish and malty. Flavour at this point was caramellish malty too. Once it gets a bit warmer both flavour and aroma starts to live. Flavour gets a bit sweetness, fruitishness and plums in it. Flavour gets Sweet malts, caramel, a weak sting of alcohol and some hoppyness in it. So, I would say, good session beer both warm and cold. Oh well, it seems like a beer which is kind of divided, hate it or love it... I’ll compromise and like it.

Dark brown color, little vanishing head. Caramel and malty aroma, this seems to be common to these local "tumsais" beers. Differing from other local dunkels, this is not so full bodied and sweet flavored, this only has lots of carbonation and strong hops. Dark beer that tastes like bad pale one, absolutely NOT one of my favourites.

Horrible horrible beer. The Latvians I know wont even touch the stuff. Has to be ice cold to drink. I had a customer explain the taste. He said it was like eating browned hamburger. That's not really good.

Deep amber brown color with a foamy beige head. Nearly no aroma, perhaps a bit of celery. Light fruity flavors of the front, turning to a cheap cream sherry taste. A strange lager that tastes better as it gets warmer. Actually not as bad as the other Kimmel products I have tried, but certainly not a "quality" brew.
Man this was just a bad beer. Save yourself the trouble and buy a different dark beer. Just bad.
Not very good really. kind of nice color, but a taste that can only be descibed as bad. Tastes like something died inside and rotted a bit before I opened it. But it did look kind of tasty.

Sweet caramel aroma and even looks somewhat appetizing, but it has a very strange flavor profile. It does kinda taste spoiled. The aroma is actually more like used cooking oil. The bitterness is way off balance and the malt flavor tastes artificial. I kinda feel bad for the people of Latvia.
Bottled Kimmel Rigas Stiprais, golden with short malt aroma. Too sweet taste to be good.
Bottled. Grain aroma with a hint of citrus. Golden color, white head, good lace. Light sweet, light bitter, lemon flavor, medium body. Straightforward and very drinkable.

Bottled. Had it as Kimmel Rigas Stiprais, 7%. Golden colour, huge white bubbly/foamish head. Kiwifruitish aroma. Sweet caramellish fruity flavour. Also some hints of alcohol in the flavour. Gives a bit oily mouthfeel. Could do with a bit more bitterness, as I felt it was too sweet for me. 6363 12 Re-rated 17.12.2005 Kimmel Rigas stiprais (bottled.) 7%. Golden coloured, big foamy/bubbly head. Aroma is sweet caramel, fuit and alcohol. Flavour mainly sweet alcohol, fruit and caramel. Also some balancing hops, which makes the flavour quite good. Aftertaste is pleasant, but flavour while drinking not too good. 43539

Had this one labeled at "Riga’s stiprais", brewer is Kimmel so these must be same beers. Starts and ends with sweet malty taste, sweetness lasts very long in mouth. Hint of warming alcohol in palate. Too sweet for my taste, maybe some carbonation or hops would have done it.
Amber coloured. Apple and cellar aroma. Medium bodied, very sweet, clean finish.
Bottle: 500 ml, at Piejuras Kempings (Ventspils)Price: 0,87 eur

Smell - weak, hops, hard to tell. Foam - thin,, soft, weak bitterness to front sides of tongue, light, medium large, but disappears quick, white. Appearance - clear light, yellow, orange amber, carbonated. Taste - carbonated, hops, weak bitterness at start, weak lasting aftertaste, bitter. Not my type kind of.
Bottle. Pours golden with medium white head. Aroma is grainy, hay, some light roast, white bread,light dough. Taste is dough, some sweetness, rain, cereals, light vegetables, white bread. Nice beer!
Bottle, Golden with a small head.Quite pleasant fresh taste with some hops.What spoilt it was the thin body lacking any real character.
Clear yellow golden color with small head. Aroma is grainy. Flavor is malt. Basic ok lager.
Bottle 0.5l. Clear, straw colored. AROMA- malt, rice. FLAVOR- slightly sweet and bitter, malt, some off-flavors. Light bodied. Bad.
#710 Bottle 0.5l. Clear pale body, medium white head. Aroma of malts, rice. Taste is neutral to sweet, bitter finish. Flour, paper, artifical lemon hops, malts. Medium body and carbonation. Bad one.
Golden color, white head. Light malty nose, grass, earthy hops. Malty taste, light caramel, grass. Light body, average carbonation.
Eh, not terrible--decently rounded mouthfeel, crisp throughout, good CO2, nice darker amber appearance...but bitter and alkaline/grassy, so not that enjoyable either.
butelka 0,5, która podoba mi się średnio, ale piwo ogólnie dobre, niepasteryzowane, treściwe z dość mocną goryczą.
Kolor - złocisty klarowny. Piana - drobnobąblowa,utrzymała się 2 minuty i znikła. Zapach - chmielowo-miodowy sympatyczny. Smak - chmiel , słód i nuta miodu, wyraźna goryczka. Poprawne

Clear golden with medium white head, that disappears quite fast. Bit Lacing. Aroma.. grassy hops, bit malty, fruity. Quite well balanced with no unpleasant spikes. Sweet with quite bitter finish, hints of sour. Decent beer for price/performance

Keg (Riga Beer Festival 2010) 5 Initially almost nothing, as the keggy head smothered all the aroma. Getting close, there was some dusty hops, and perhaps some ginger. As it warms, there are lots of herby grassy hops 3 Rich gold, large light white head. 5 A full grassy and herby hoppy body. Packed full of grains, but also other vegetable matter too. Quite bizarre, but very much Piebalgas. 3+ Soft palate, decent carbonations. Finish very hoppy - a touch papery, but green too. Vegetal in places too. 9 A well crafted and interesting beer, but not to my taste so much. Anna adds "Only a little bit shit in the taste".

500 ml bottle. Pours light golden, pure white head. Light cereal grains and grassy hops in the aroma, flavor adds a corn like sweetness. Kind of blah, not much going on, but a totally unoffensive lager.

Bottle. Light malt aromas of grain, grass for the hops and a hint of apple. Head is large, fizzy, white and clumpy. It has no lacing and is mostly lasting. Flavor is lightly sweet and acidic to start and the finish is lightly acidic. Palate is light to medium, watery and has a fizzy carbonation. An average tasting Pale Lager with a little uniqueness.

(bottle - 500 ml) Slightly cloudy gold color with a soapy white head. Aroma is sweet and malty, almost with a hint of iced tea and biscuits. Not much hops in the aroma. Flavor is sweet and malty at the front that moves to a dry and grainy middle of hay, grass, earth, and hops. Finishes bitter and slightly sour with a light hint of sweet malts. Thin-bodied.
Bottle. I am thinking this has to be a new country. Pale lager, white lacing. Simple malt sweetness and breadiness. A light floral hop finish.

A hazy golden lager with a thick white head. In aroma, a stricking maple water aroma, woody, a bit of corn. In mouth, a crisp malt with sweet light vanilla, a bit cloying, with definite cardboard notes, signs of oxidation. Tasted Jan. 2007.
Bottle in Riga. A whiff of boiled veg her, but the beer is certainly not bad - cereals with grassy hops in the finish. Very decent for a lager of this strength!
Bottle. Pours a golden colour with a medium short lasting white head. Aroma of grains and malt. Thin mouthfeel. The flavour is a bit sweet with malt, grains and some bitter hops.

Well, it’s OK I suppose. It’s "flat", my term, for a beer that’s supposed to have at least some hop character. Not as much as an IPA, mind you, but definitely, not on par with other pale ales. Too much malt in the background for my taste. Glad I tried it, but wouldn’t repeat.

On-tap into a pint glass... This was suppose to be the best beer they had, probably was but still not saying a whole lot... Pours a totally clear dark orange with notes of copper, looks good. The head is a nice off white, good retention and lace... The aroma is also pretty good, mostly grassy on the front with a hint of caramel, pine hop finish... The taste is decent at first, light toffee and grass. The finish becomes way too bitter, hops are off, reminds me more of an ipa. Not terrible but I wouldn’t have this again unless my prison was Harrison’s and I was sentenced to life without parole.
This one was okay. Aroma of caramel and sweet. Brownish amber color red. Taste is hoppy, slightly sweet, low malt. Will not have again, but I’m not a fan of pale ales

Draft @ Harrisons, Orland Park, IL. Pours a pale amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy aroma. Has a fruity malty hoppy citrus flavor. Has a fruity malty hoppy finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.
From the Jug at the GABF Colorado Convention Center, Denver 11/10/2008 Fruity pine aroma. Amber coloured and hoppy with a slightly bitter fruity malt finish.
(Draught) Pours a clear deep amber body with a medium beige head. Aroma of toasted grain, caramel, and lemongrass. Flavor of caramel malt and hops (grass, floral).
Draught at the Great Taste of the Midwest 2008. Sweet resinous hops aroma. Amber off white head, floral. Nice lingering bitterness.

amber color, light tan head. nose of grapefruit hops and citrus sweetness. creamy, citrus flavor. medium bodied, moderately bitter. not bad, much better than i expected. a bit too mild overall for my tastes.

Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Orland Park, Illinois. Clear, dark red pour with an off-white head, a wonderfully hoppy, floral nose. Pronounced hoppiness thorughout, nice and dry with some red grape fruitiness. Clean and excellent.

Draft sampler.There are some hops at work here. A bit pine, grapefruit and even peach (the impression left over from the peach beer.). Malts are a little lacking for what the color suggests, but it does play nice and finish with a decent pale ale flourish.

On-tap into a pint glass... A medium but lightly murky straw, off looking. However, the head is great. A bright white that has great retention and totally thick and coating lacing that looks great... The aroma is really light and boring, a hint of grain... The taste is light skunk from start to finish, that’s it. A very HARSH bitter finish that really ruins a basically boring but unoffensive beer. Pass.
Aroma is corn, pilsner color, taste is light. tastes like miller lite with a tad bit more hops and malts. This light beer actually has taste. Aftertaste is crisp..

Draft @ Harrisons, Orland Park, IL. Pours a pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty aroma with some weak grassy hoppy hints. Sweetish malty weak hoppy flavor. Has a fruity malty weak hoppy finish.

clear yellow, slight white head, some lacing, too watery looking. grassy, wheaty aroma, a stronger nose than i expected for a light beer. creamy, corny flavor. full mouth-feel, fizzy. kind of a ’salty’ finish. not as bad as i feared, but in the end, the ’saltiness’ was ultimately distracting.
Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Orland Park, Illinois. Clear light yellow pour with a grassy nose, dry, a bit hoppy, well balanced. Kind of bland for the style, though. Not much going on.

Draft Sampler. Well, yes, a light beer, and what else could I expect. Very little taste, but does show a certain ale fruitiness. I would be hard pressed to guess what style this was based on. Suspect some rice was involved in keeping it so light. Hops were weak to me.

Clear, transparent and watery yellow in color with rising bubbles and a white wrung for the head. Lemons, cornflakes and starch spray provide the cleansing aroma. Yeasty and effervescent upon all quaffs. Flavor circumvents bready crescent rolls traits with a touch of stinging lemons. Definitely one of the hoppier "lite" beers (cascade, primarily) and well balanced, for what it’s worth.

Light golden bodied served with a white ring of a head. No aromas detected (which I suppose is better than detecting bad aromas). Very mild hop presence in flavor but weak overall with a slightly metallic finish. Harrison’s Brewing Company, Orland Park, IL

Nice try but no cigar. Please stop with the trend towrds "light" "lo-carb", "lo-calorie", "lo-alcohol" etc. Beer is not a diet drink. If you are trying to lose weight, please drink something else...somewhere else.

This is like am introductory ale for those who normally drink macro lagers. Pale yellow with a light head, it had little of any aroma. Kind of watery in the mouth. Little taste. Clean finish. Harrisons Brewing Company, Orland Park, IL

On-tap into a tasting glass... Pours an ugly dirty honey gold, ugly head, served with a lemon slice!... The aroma is dead, nothing going on at all... The taste is bad lemon and wheat, very chemical, terrible finish that is stale cloves and wheat. Big time pass.

orange/yellow color, cloudy and served with lemon. Smells lemon, light banana. Taste is light banana, but does not taste like typical hafeweizen with heavy banana and clove taste. I’m assuming a traditional Wyeast haffeweizen yeast was not used in this one. A light, tasty hafeweizen..

Draft @ Harrisons, Orland Park, IL. Pours a hazy yellow color with a small white head. Has a frity wheat malty aroma with some hints of citrus. Sweetish wheat malty fruity flavor. Has a sweetish wheat malty citrus finish.

hazy apricot body, slight white head. served with a slice of lemon??! i didn’t detect any aroma once i discarded the lemon. flavor of spices, and banana tones. the banana was not off-putting. the mouth feel was a bit effervescent, in a weird way. i don’t care for wheats, but this wasn’t too bad.

Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Orland Park, Illinois. Pours cloudy light orange color with a thick, white head that dissipated to a pervasive film, very faint citrus in the nose, light wheat, alcoholic finish. Meh.

Draft sampler. Well, yes it does have a cloudy wheat character and a sort of lacy foam. Can’t smell much beyond the lemon slice on the glass. Actually bears more of a resemblance to Belgian, with its cloudy pink-tinged yellow body. Just a touch of coriander, then a bit of sourness makes this a but more interesting than my rating might suggest.

Served with a lemon wedge (damn.) Dirty, murky and solid pale yellow-gold in color with a few bubble cloisters on the top, but fairly stagnant in appearance overall. Aroma is very subdued - banana, vanilla and lemons at best. Flavor is absolutely repulsive. Cat nip, pineapple, rutabaga and acorn squash. Hops are doing something unforgivable. I will forever remember this one.
One of the blandest wheats I ever had...no aroma, little flavor (watered down) and thin palate. Skip this one.
I’m not a wheat beer afficianado, but this beer wasn’t bad. I only took spare notes on it: murky-tan; no head/white ring; fizzy; mild; smooth. Harrison’s Brewing Company, Orland Park, IL

A fairly bland wheat with little discernable aroma. It looked nice in the glass, a cloudy yellow color with a frothy head. Not much in the flavor area. A bit watery... which leads to the very clean finish. Harrisons Brewing Company, Orland Park, IL
Wow, I pretty bad red in my opinion. A lot of malt with almost no hops. It seemed very "empty" to me. I’ve had way better amber ales. Thankfully this one was just a taster sample :)

On-tap into a taster... This one starts off really nice. A bright clear medium copper, hints of amber. The head is a nice tope color, great retention, looks good... The aroma is light with notes of rye and a hint of toffee; a little generic but unoffensive... The taste is horrible, fuesal alcohol finish with a bit of toffee. Was this the base beer for BA 1000 IBU? Tastes like burning.

This one was good. Red amber color. Sweet nose, caramel also. Sweet flavor. Chocolate/crystal malts used for sure. Maybe wilamette and liberty hops used. Mild hops, mild malts. The brew needs more malt though and make it a medium body opposed to a lighter body. My irish red was better that I brewed in November. Great beer to drink with a burger or steak.

Draft @ Harrisons, Orland Park, IL. Pours a reddish color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

pours an appealing purplish-brown color, slim tan head. aroma is slightly sweet air. the flavor is also slightly sweet with a touch of creaminess. medium bodied with a dry finish. not a bad attempt by harrissons.

Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Orland Park, Illinois. Pours a clear, deep copper tone, with a fluffy, off white head, faint citrus in the nose, very mild maltiness, would be a great session beer but lacks oomph. Finishes clean.

Transparent and magnifying amber with a tan wrung for the head. Caramel, honey roasted peanuts, hops and rye give it a snappy nose. Munich malts make their presence known, churning a whole wheat bread persona. Caramel, wheat, peat and rye provide the rest of the flavor fillers. Seemingly an Irish Red by all means except the ingredient list.
Also surprised at the improvement in this one from my last visit. Rich toffee maltiness nicely balanced by signifigant hop bitterness. Much better since my last review.

A clear, deep copper with an ecru head. Caramel malt aromas under piney hops. Rounded flavor, albeit a little weak. Fizzy mouthfeel with an astringent finish. Harrison’s Brewing Company, Orland Park, IL

Draft. Not quite the disaster I remember when I was last here 3 years ago. Think the current brewmaster has been trying to get management to care about what they had treated as a mere adjunct to yuppie steaks and cigars... Deep amber color under a thin, slightly lacy head. Clearly force carbonated, and therefore gassy. Still, some lightly roasted and crystal malts with a bit of fruity esters. A bit of hop spiceness to finish off.

On-tap at this place...Pours an ugly dark murky hone gold, just ugly. A light tope head, not much going on there... The aroma is asisnely sweet, generic tart raspberries, tons of sugar, yuck... The taste is one of the most chemically plastic beers I’ve ever had. Raspberry cough syrup barrel aged in plastic, barf... The mouthfeel is bad, acidic and biting. Needless to say this is terrible and should be avoided.

Raspberry reddish.yellow haze color, berry nose. tastes like wheat with infused slight raspberry taste. No extract in this brew. Great session beer and could definitely try again. If I had to take a growler home, this would be the brew..

Draft @ Harrisons, Orland Park, IL. Pours a hazy yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity and slightly sweetish raspberry aroma. Sweetish fruity raspberry flavor. Has a fruity sweetish raspberry finish.

hazy yellow, bubbly white head, some lacing. aroma of wow!! raspberries. flavor is raspberries, grains, mostly raspberries. palate is frizzy, sweet, fruity finish. i don’t like fruit beers and this one doesn’t disappoint.

Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Orland Park, Illinois. Pours a cloudy, dark yellow color with a pervasive thick white head, nose of baked bread and raspberry jam, lightly wheaty with lots of breadiness and fruitiness. Tart in the end. Pretty good.
The fruity flavor has been toned down from past years, but it doesn’t make it more enjoyable to drink.

Draft sampler. Well, there’s certainly raspberry here, but what else. A Belgian would be inherently fruity in taste, and just adding an overwhelming flavor like raspberry would just blow it away. Cloudy like a wit, no doubt, and as I go through the sampler while writing this, I am starting to pick a bit staled hops taste that I wouldn’t expect. Bland, but certainly no disaster.

Lightly hazy and pale yellow in color with some rising bubbles. Aroma consists of strawberries, raspberry jam and rose tea. Flavor ensues with a sugary charge. Lemon bite in a small sense and something suspiciously familiar with raspberry flavored seltzer water. Better than expected, for what it’s worth.

They have no business experimenting at this brewpub. Tastes like raspberry NEHI and has the same over-carbonation, but the tickling distracted me from the flavor, so I bumped up the palate a point in gratitude.

Cloudy and wheat-colored with a ring for a head. Raspberry aromas (go figure). Sour fruit flavors, with the berries tasting like an integral part of the beer (as opposed to their Blueberry Wheat). Dry finish. Refreshing. Harrison’s Brewing Company, Orland Park, IL

I have no idea what they were going for with this. My waitress even warned me it was bad. Has no resemblance even in appearance to a maibock: it's kind of a reddish amber, practically no head. Flavor is cloyingly sweet, and finishes with a gut-wrenching olive oil taste that required a lot of water to rinse away.
Brown and bubbling with no head or lace. Sweet malt aroma with a sugary sweet start. Watery and thin with slight drying finish but leaves sugary aftertaste.

cloudy yellow, frothy white head, nice lacing. aroma of blueberries and hint of grain. flavor of blueberries, malt, grain. kind of watery mouth-feel, with a bitter-tart finish. kind of frizzy. fruit beers are not an endeared variety to me.

On tap at the brewpub: This was a hazy dark straw in body with a bubbly head. Way too strong on the blueberry, one of the few fruits that I do not care for, and an artificial aroma and flavor to boot. It took quite a while to stop burping this stuff up.

Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Orland Park, Illinois. Hazy dark yellow pour with a great foamy head, pronounced nose of baked blueberry muffins, wheaty and sweet but the blueberries are not overpowering the flavor very quaffable and refreshing. ! I continue to be bewildered at the low ratings for this place by some of my collegues here.

some fella from indiana poured this for me at DLD. i dont even know why i’m bothering to rate it, except perhaps that i had it early and remember it well. it sucked. i remember pretending it was good and the blueberry wasn’t artificial tasting. it actually kinda was, and the beer was totally uninspired otherwise. hardly any flavor, probably 3-4% in alcohol. this is the closest thing to water I had that day.

Once you taste the obviously artificial blueberry syrup (and recoil from the heavy hand at work when adding it to the brew) you will have great difficulty finishing a pint of this stuff. I drank it to the last drop, but I’m a moron.

Looked nice enough, with a cloudy, wheat beer appearance. Aromas dominated by artificial blueberry (very similar to General Mills’ BooBerry® cereal). Fizzy mouthfeel begins a cream soda based flavor with that lingering artificial berriness. I actually rejected the second half of my sample. Sad. Harrison’s Brewing Company, Orland Park, IL
Bright fruity nose. I agree on the cough syrup flavor. Maybe sort of a spiced apple cake. Not too bad on the mouthfeel, but lacking overall.
Blueberry nose, very slight cloudiness with many carbonation bubbles. Taste is all blueberry, no beer...more like a blueberry soda.
dark, light fruit, hoppy. All Ipas taste the same to me, but this one was more fruity then most. Not a fan. F

hand pumped at cellar temperature at the brewpub bar. pours with the color of dark tea, with negligible head. aroma of bitter evergreen and citrus. flavor is bitter and evergreeny with no citrus notes. bitter without being exciting. medium bodied. the taste does grow on you, and i filled my growler with it. at $7 for 2 liters, i didnt think i could go all that wrong.
Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Orland Park, Illinois. Cask ale, hand pumped. Dark red, hazy pour, with a big, bubby foamy head, very bitter with notes of rose, lots of hops. Outstanding.

Cask. Semi-cloudy and ruby-amber-orange in color with a moon rock pocked head, resembling krausen in fine form. Grapefruit and grass stains instantly capture the nose for loving longevity, pursued by strawberry magic markers, freesia buds and lemon grass. It’s quite alluring at this stage of the game. Mild clover and mango bitterness creeps in with a waxy rhubarb drone. Flavor evolutions revolve around EKG hop pellets – sucking and absorbing the alpha acids as if it’s an oral prophylactic. Acidic and very green at the stems with a dry creeping bitterness that spans from the rooftop of the mouth and works its way down. Marigolds and ragweed tickle the tonsils with alcohol swab status, but it’s surprisingly enjoyable yet incorrigible. Pollinated hops spurge forth with post-gestational burps while buffed mango rinds and earthen chomped dandelions bring up the rear.

Served room temperature as an incredibly dense hazelnut/copper with a creamy head that laced in a solid sheet. Aromas are grapefruit with dishrag and acrid notes. Flavor holds thorough bitterness with citric notes but nothing too special. Mouth is sticky with a dry finish. On cask at Harrison’s Brewing Company, Orland Park, IL 60462

Nitro pint at Harrison’s. This may be improving under their new brewer, but still needs a long way to go. served properly "warm" and hand-pulled. A thin head that coats instead of lacing the glass. Cloudy orange color. Slight biscuity malt that’s overwhelmed by hop bitterness. A touch or earth, grapefruit and pine needles, but mostly just bitter. A perceptible alcohol burn, too. Yes, Mabel, there is an aftertaste, so I don’t see it being ordered by many of the cigar-smoking yuppies here. I think Harrison’s is slowly improving, but they need to learn more subtlety.

Cask-conditioned, served at room temperature...This cloudy brew had a slight grapefruit- hoppy aroma, and even knowing better, I hoped against hope for that slight promise to be fulfilled...but instead I got dishwater that made up for it with a slightly vinyl finish. Please, I’m begging you, just stop brewing beer before someone gets hurt!

Nitro version served at room temperature: Actually not a bad IPA, looking a murky orange/brown color with an off-white head. Nice pine & herbal hop aroma. I was told that this was "real hoppy," but the flavor didn’t strike this 3F drinker that way. Not too bad, with an earthy hop flavor and a very mild malting underneath. Lingering bitter pine finish. Harrisons Brewing Company, Orland Park, IL
Cask: Dark orange color with a nice head. The smell is terrific with hops. The taste is little to be desired. It tasted old and lacked something. Not a bad beer, but disappointing after the smell.
Cask: Perhaps the best of their beers. Murky golden color with a subtle hop nose. Some nutty textures. Not big at all, and really unassuming.

On draught at the brewpub, adjacent to the brewery in Cave Creek, AZ. Pours a clear caramel amber brew with a thick, creamy off-white head that has some good retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, some candi sugar, and a touch of honey. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonated with flavors of sweetened caramel malt, some candi sugar than its aroma and some cotton candy. Finish is semi-sweet, slightly metallic as the brewmaster told me it’s 8% alcohol, with some candi sugar aftertaste. It’s different.
GABF 2005: Orange color with no head or lacing. I usually enjoy all bocks but, this one was nothing special.
Cloudy yellow orange. Light fuzzy head. Sugary sweet but without distinctive character.
Drinkable, very plain, nothing too exciting. No head ad no lace at all. Very strange aftertaste.

Tap at Il Granaio, Premilcuore, Italy. Pours brilliant red, transparent, with minimum foam. Aroma is delicate malty. Body is average, like carbonation. Taste is medium-high sweet with low bitterness. Finish is slightly long with sweetness.

Birra rossa onesta, dal bel colore rosso intenso, e dal sapore dolce-amaro abbastanza piacevole dove emergono, anche se deboli, i malti tostati. Resta un prodotto commerciale ma comunque bevibile se ben fredda.
Si presenta anche bene con bel colore rosso porpora, ma poi in bocca è davvero scialba, e senza carattere...

Bottle. Pours clear dark tawny with a medium, frothy beige head, medium retention with some lacing. Aroma is rich caramel and toast malt with dark fruit notes and light earthy hops. Flavor is rich caramel and toast malt, nutty and dark fruit notes, light earthy hops and bitterness, clean and a medium dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Pours amber/deep orange without much of a head. Aroma is brown sugar, malt, caramelized malts. Taste is malty, caramel and slightly fruity. Slightly dry. Watery texture, soft carbonation, medium body.
Clear dark amber beer with white creamy head. Aroma is roast caramel. Taste is malty and caramelly and little bit sweetness also. Medium body. Descent beer to drink and enjoy.

CLear light brown/ruby with little beige head. Aroma of nuts, caramel, a little roast and raisins. Taste is malty sweet with some caramel/honey and roast in the finish. Smooth. Very low carbonation. Nice.
Ciekawa barwa, piwo przejrzyste, piana niska. Nasycenie średnie. W smaku nic specjalnego, stosunkowo mocna goryczka trochę ratuje piwo.

Bottle shared by Inoven. Clear dark amber to red-brown color, average sized off-white head. Smell and taste malts, sweetish, a hint of chestnut, slightly brown candy sugar. Average body and carbonation.
Flesje thuis gedeeld. Kleur is roodbruin. Weinig aroma, ietsje houtig. Smaak van hout, fruit , kastanje. Weinig nasmaak.

This bottled brew from the brewery poured a large sized head of of unnoted size quickly diminishing clear bubbles that left behind an unnoted lacing. The body contained average carbonation, was hazy and yellow in color. Its aroma contained notes of mild bready malts. Its flavor contained smooth mild astringent wheat notes. Very disappointing.
Draft at Dayton. Cloudy light amber with small rocky white head. Moderate sweet wheat aroma. Medium to full body with thick texture. Sweet wheat flavor with medium finish.

Rated at TDBC. A disappointing German Hefe IMMHO. Poured a very, very small off-white head that quickly dissipated, no lacing, fine-large sized bubbles, uncarbonated, cloudy, and a straw yellow hue. Aroma was malty, some banana and spicy. The flavor was sweet, malty, banana and some spicyness. Watery, thin mouthfeel. Light body. A real disappointment for a rater who truly likes this beer style.

I probably would not have bothered trying this beer if this T.D. location was not finally out of Siberian Night. Hazy dark yellowish-orange with a thin white head. Aroma is light wheat and citrus. Light-bodied with a slick yeasty flavor, along with a little citrus and hops. Finish is a little on the thin side, even for a Wheat. This would be a good brew as part of their 15 beer sampler but I would not get it again otherwise.
Yellow in color,slightly cloudy with little head. Yeasty aroma. Flavor of yeast and fruit. Good wheat beer, but missing something to make it more interesting.
on tap-pours a white head and yellow color. Aroma is sweet grain. Taste is sweet grain-honey, some lemon/herbal/grass hops.

On draft at the brewery. Pours a clear light gold with white head ring. Sweet and a little grainy, vanilla, reminiscent of a eurolager with a bit of a noble hop kick. Not bad with the poppyseed spinach salad.

From a sampler at the brewpub. Pours a golden amber color with a medium head. Honey-like grain aroma. Taste is primarily grainy with some honey-like notes and bitter and fruity hop notes. Medium bodied.

Sampler at brewery. Slight pale malt aroma. No hop aroma. Clear golden with fine white head. Light caramel and pale malt flavor. Medium body and mouthfeel. Low hop and fruitiness. Clean finish. Honey notes are hard to detect. Very clean refreshing sessionable beer.

Draft @ Cally’s. Very light yellow straw color with a slight honey aroma. Very grainy and quite unimpressive. There lightest beer that they had when i was there, certainly they have better things to drink.

On tap at Cally’s. Clear golden blond body with a medium creamy white head. Sweet grainy aroma with light honey. Very sweet honey flavor, light grainy ending. Fairly smooth body with medium high carbonation.

Draft at Cally’s. Probably wouldn’t have tried this in the first place other than another rating on ratebeer :-) Fairly lackluster, clear golden pour with a slim white head. Good carbonation, but that’s about it. Really have to stretch myself to find something in this one. Probably cally’s easiest drinking beer next to their american wheat.
Pretty nondistinct beer. Had to work to find the aroma and flavor. Calhouns weakest link of the beers available now. It could have been a Busch.

Draft at the brewpub, labeled Blonde Ale instead of Honey Blonde Ale. Medium golden color with white head. Aromas of light malt, copper, and faint floral hops. Flavor is very lager-like malt with a crisp, slightly bitter finish. Surprisingly good, and certainly heavier than I would think a macro-lite drinker would wish, especially at 5%.

Medium to deep gold, good head, no real aroma at all. Sort of an inoffensive "beer" flavor, touch of grain, predominate note is just a general sweetness. This is definitely the beer on tap for the Budmiloors crowd. Not my bag.

column1: Maplewood Farms The Intimidator Double Bock
column5: Sample at the brewpub. Clear very dark brown, no head. Absolutely huge malty gingerbread nose with whiffs if cinnamon and anise. Big sugary-sweet malty flavor, no hops to speak of; perhaps a bit too syrupy without the stronger hop foundation and heavier body. Still very very good; just a bit smoky near the finish.

column1: Maplewood Farms The Intimidator Double Bock
column5: On tap at the brewpub: Ruby orange with a thin head. Deep caramel and malts in the nose. Oily full body. Very sweet ending that is a bit too much. Otherwise a great brew.

column1: Maplewood Farms The Intimidator Double Bock
column5: Has a dark ruby color and a somewhat sweet malted smell. Taste is malted, but not as much as some of the other doppelbock I have tried and it finishes with a funny aftertaste. Actually all the beers in the sampler had a funny aftertaste, hmmmm... Overall this is one of my least favorite from this brewery. It didn't taste right...

column1: Maplewood Farms The Intimidator Double Bock
column5: They refer to it as a dopplebock, to me it tastes more like a Belgian Strong, and every bit as good as the ones highly rated here, but those dont particularly do it for me either.

Well I tried this beer in a sample platter with five others so tyake this with a grain of salt. Has a medium yellow color and a hop smell. Taste is of hops and finishes with a medium bitterness. Overall it is similar to an IPA, but smoother and not as bitter.
Tastes a lot like an IPA, with its rich hoppieness. A nice beautiful golden appearance and rich hoppy smell. A good beer.

On tap at the San Mateo Brewfest. Not sure why this is retired because I just had it on Sunday 6/10/07. This was a great pale ale. Nice big citrus aroma and flavor. Body was medium but still refreshing. Some caramel malt and alcohol to back everything up. Yum.

By far the worst beer I ever had. I have to assume this beer is bottled conditioned because the amount of yeast in the bottle was very surprising as was what I can only hope was grains floating around in the bottle. Everey single bottle was filled to a different amount. Some filled to the very top others have an inch and a half of space. The taste...well it was awful. The only explanation I can have is that this beer was sent to market prematurely because it tasted nothing like a pale ale or even beer for that matter.

(12 oz bottle: BevMo in La Jolla, CA) Pour the beer, smell the beer, taste the beer, rate the beer, dump what’s left. The nose of this beer is sweet and extremely grainy and corn-flavored. The flavor is similar; it’s lightly malty, strongly corn-flavored, and fairly sweet, but the sweetness just seems cheap tasting. The hops is mildy bitter, but doesn’t have much character. Light-to-medium bodied, but the sweet corn flavor quickly becomes tiring on the palate. Dark golden color seemed promising on the pour, but those hopes were dashed when the cheap aromas hit the nasal passages. Light tan head fades to a ring in a few minutes. Some patching lacing here and there. And just think, I bought a six pack of this crap. So sorry I sent a bottle of this to Bert. This is garbage, but it’s a rating I guess.

Small tan head, lasting. Clear coppper color. Subdued piney hop nose with a fair bit of malt. Light body. Light malt flavors, caramel and light piney hop notes with an unfortunate astringency/ Quick dry finish. Thanks Stephen!
Bottled: This is just a bad beer. Light tasting, not very hoppy, but had a horrible after taste. Won't buy it again.
Medium Brown color, large head. Very hoppy, nice maltyness. Finish is crisp, no bitterness in aftertaste. Doesn't really taste like a pale ale.
A modest pale ale, light, slightly worty, easy on the hops, crisp and solid

This one is very good. It does remind me of Hop Wallop and Ruination, although not as citrusy as Hop Wallop or as astringent as Ruination. Great hop presence, and great balance. Get some while you can.

I had this at the Michael Jackson beer tasting in Philadelphia in 2005 and I loved it. What a great surprise. Hopped with Centenial and Cascade like a Hop Devil, with great malt taste, bitterness, and orange and pine complexity, but with enough simcoe to give it a crisp almost miny taste like a Hop Wallop. A favorite now, along with Hop Wallop and Stone Ruination, though less grapefruity than either. May not be for everyone ... this is a real slam of hops.
A decent pale ale, not quite an IPA in my book. Not sure where the overpowering hops are. A touch of vanilla.

This beer reminds me of Stone's Arrogant Bastard and Victory's Hop Devil... and yet it is slightly more refined and truly unique. A Bronze medal winner at the 2002 World Beer Cup, this beer offers a uniquely fresh profile in that it is bottle conditioned! It pours a cream colored, 1/4" head that holds fairly well, and offers an incredibly intense hop aroma of both American and English hops; well backed by a sweet caramel maltiness. The moutheel is creamy and full with a medium level carbonation. The flavor is equally balanced between sharp hop flavor and sweet caramel maltiness. The finish is on the sweet side, turning dry, and finally revealing a ton of hop flavor. Unlike any beer I've ever had before; although the original brewer has left and this beer has not been even remotely the same in recent versions.
An okay wheat ale. Pale a very light. Lots of citrus. Sweetness lingers, but otherwise not much lasting character. Tried for the first time back in 2007 and only now adding the rating.
Dry Hopped Wheat-on cask-pours a white bubbly head and hazy yellow color. Aroma is lemon. Taste is lemon/lemon zest/tea/some spice hops, wheat. Light body.
On tap at the tap room. It’s fine, and plenty drinkable. There’s just not much to it.
Very clear and golden with a staying head. Crisp, clean, vaguely fruity. Nicely balanced with unique light grain flavors. Kolsch-like, refreshing.
Ugggghhh. THis was bad, macro bad. Wet cardboard flavors. Uhhhh. What a bad beer to have started the fest with.
Pale and clear. A typical American Wheat - which means I didn't like it much.
Light bodied wheat ale. For the American Standard drinkers. Better than anything AB makes.Since Saint Louis Brewery ( the tap room) does not sell any beer but their own.

As the description reads, this is the filtered version of the Schlafly Hefe. The flavor doesn't gain any extra "wheatiness", but loses some of the yeastiness, as is obviously to be expected. Light bodied, and a lighter mouthfeel as compared with the regular version. This is one of those "it'll please the non-beer connoisseur" types of brews, but it's not bad.

On tap @ Wynkoop Brewery. Deep dark black with a persistant dark tan head. Smells of chocolate, coffee grounds, and lightly roasted malt. Taste is wonderfully chocolatey and roasty. The chocolate is kinda bitter like bakers cocoa. Some espresso notes hit through the finish, as well as some subtle fruitiness. Not too bitter but pretty sweet. A fine dessert beer, and a fine stout.
Tap at Wynkoop. Pours a deeper brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, nuts and toasted malt. Flavor of chocolate, nuts, toffee. Nice chocolate character.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a black body with a finger-width, creamy, brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is rich chocolate, soft oats, and roasty coffee. A light earthy metallic and some caramel too. Flavor is the same. Rich, sweet, and smooth chocolate oats with a good amount of roasty coffee. Finishes smooth and rich with a light, earthy bitterness and dry roastiness. Aftertaste that lingers for a lengthy duration after a medium, somewhat watery at times, but creamy body. Overall, a tasty stout. The metallic hint in the aroma didn’t show up in the flavor which was nice. Serverd at a warmer temperature too, which I appreciate. Not bad.
Old review from 2000 I never posted. Well-made stout, good roasted aromas and flavors, smooth and flavorful with a nice finish.
On tap at brewery for GABF 08. Dark pour with tan head. Roasted malts, chocolate and oatmeal. Flavor is the same, with a bit of milkiness.
(Draught) Pours a dark brown body with a creamy tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, grain, and chocolate. Flavor of roasted malt, light lactose, oatmeal, and chocolate.

Sample at the brewpub. The beer pours a solid black color with a medium thin light brown head that diminishes slowly. Rings of lacing. Roasted malt and coffee aroma, with notes of chocolate and hops. Medium-bodied with a roasty character that is predominantly coffee and malt. Some milk chocolate is present as well. The finish is moderately bitter coffee and hops and it lingers awhile. Pretty solid overall.
Draught at Wynkoop. Black - light brown head. Licorice, roasted, berries, dryness, burned, red berries, caramel, butterscotch, high sweetness, a bit too much sweetness. Lovely burned.
Dark black with a brown head. Sort of tasted a little like a barley wine because you could taste the alcohol. Almost light-medium bodied. Decent choice, but they have better.

Pitch black color, with a sweet oatmeal cereal roasty malt, mochaish nose, with a light chocolatey icecream aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a smooth, roasted malt, toffeeish, winey character, with some dark dried fruits, maybe more plummy, with a light dark chocolate accent, leading towards a fruity, roasted, lingering bitternees finish.

An orange beer with a small disappearing off-white head. The aroma is lovely hoppy combined with sweet caramel notes. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel and oranges leading to a dry end - but before that the body seems weak in the begining.

Does this beer even have a flavor or taste? Nope. Does it have an aroma? Nope. I had this beer at the brewery in Denver and it had zero taste, zero flavor, zero aroma. I actually sent it back/dumped it for another fairly bland beer. I have never had such a crappy IPA in my life and suggest it be avoided.

Tasted in Colorado (Denver). Tasted at Wynkoop Brewing Company. Liver is going to quit - I am NOT. Must complete my mission. Who does number 2 work for? (oops, wrong movie - bad timing). Deep deep copper colour. Sooo deep. White fluffy cumulous head, I see angels dancing on the peaks. Again, such a fruity aroma - mother of pearl. Taste is an orchestra of subtlety and destruction.
pretty standard. some pine and lychee in aroma, but way too sticky, hint of mango nectar, lower bitterness than expected

Clear red appearance. Biscuity, hopy aroma. Low in carbonation (cask), sweet tropical fruit and biscuity malt with a good citric bite in the finish. Rated low because it’s my favorite style and I was not impressed.
On tap at the brewpub: Clear orange with a big white head. Citrus aroma, solid body. Starts and ends moderately bitter. If this beer had a high ABV, I didn't notice it.

When I first tasted this IPA my nose was kinda FUBAR, and I was kinda out of it too... West coast hops, a nice, lasting head, the IPA itself is slightly opaque. I liked it... I know thats not saying much but my notes are kinda crappy here... The bitterness is not too extreme, and it blends into a light sweetness. The palate is rather thin.

(cask) Slightly hazy dark gold. Flimsy white head, reasonably stable. very fruity nose (exotic fruit as passion) and yeasty - smelling like green beer. Well-bitter taste with both noble and bitter hops. Enough malts underneath to support, without sweetening. Well-bodied. Aftertaste turns out malt-sweet. Nice one. But Imperial?

Cask at the Appaloosa Grill in downtown Denver, owned by Wynkoop. Cascase hop aroma. Slightly murky, with some soft orange colors and a white head. A little thin, lacking the needed carbonation, even for a cask conditioned IPA. some chalcky and stale wheat flavors. Aroma sets it up, but the flavor is a let down.

Light amber colour with a thin white head. Served at cellar temperature. A pleasant english hop aroma comes from the beer. In addition to the hops, there is a bit of sweetness. The taste is almost purely of malt and english hops. Once again this is a tiny bit watery, but not as much as the others. Aftertaste is a subtle malt with prominent english hops. This was most closely related to a bitter, but possibly could be considered an EPA, but definately not an IPA! Overall, better than the average bitter, and one of my favourites from the brewpub. I had this on tap at the brewpub in Denver, Colorado on 12-August-2003.
Deep brown pour. A bit of light woodiness, but it basically just smells like sweet, wet malt. Flavour has a touch of weird chewy roastiness that I’m not a fan of at all.

On tap at the brewpub. Cask version. Pours a very dark brown with a large bubbled off-white head. Served at cellar temperature. Has a pronounced bourbon flavor and is very malty. The flavor is quickly fleeting and has a very low hop profile. A delicious beer but it deceptively feels like it is bigger in alcohol than it really is.

On tap at Wynkoop poured a clear reddish brown with a lingering ring of light tan foam. Aromas of carmel, fruittiness and light peat smoke. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, dried fruit, peat smoke and toffee with a smooth lingering peaty finish.

Cask - a fairly sweet scotch ale, with a bit of plumy character, some earthy/dms/boiled vegetable character (which is covered by the sweetness fairly well), and a peaty finish, followed by some alcohol warmth - a bit of vanilla, some toasted malt - sweetness washes out a lot of the other characteristics - okay.
From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 13/10/2007 Malt aroma. Dark red coloured strong in alcohol and rich on the palate with a slightly dry crisp whisky malt finish.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer is a dark brown color with a thin and rocky white head that burns away pretty quickly. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel and candied fruit as well as some malt. Flavors of caramel malt and toffee along with some sweet fruit. The finish is smooth and sweet with a caramel malt aftertaste, along with a touch of hops. Overall this is a unique take on the style, and it is a pretty good beer.
Now we are talking. This beer has a bold caramel aroma and flavor. Body is full and rich. Creamy smooth mouthfeel. Very nice and balanced beer with lots of flavor.
On cask at Wynkoop. Pours dark brown with tan head. Dissipates quickly. Malt forward. Sweet with caramel and chocolate notes. No hop presence.

tap at the brewpub. dark red brown body with a decent head of white. sweet caramel nose with a light hint of butter. flavor was outstanding. fruity with a big dose of toffee. light cherry flavor(or something similar) lingered in the finish.

Draft at Wynkoop. Coppery shimmer to this. Nose is malty, caramel, light spice notes and toffee. Taste is malt, fruits, light hops, and caramel. Body is light-medium with relaxed carbonation. Bit of dryness in spots. Finishes with more sweet maltiness, caramel, light hops and fruit notes.

Augustiner Brau München From the Tap. Drinking on May 5th so definitely in season and from the Voss. Quite Malty however prefer over the typical Helle’s as much more flavor. Never tried on the bottle however believe this would be best enjoyed in Munich/on Tap

Tap. Pours a clear amber orange color with a light head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, malty. Flavor also has sweet notes, caramel, malty and grainy. Slight hoppy flavor. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pint at the brewpub. This is a nice clear copper color with a creamy one finger light tan head. A nice nose of American hops and caramel. Some nice caramel, fruit, floral, and pine flavors. Well brewed.
Sampler at the brewpub. It poured a light brown color with small head. The aroma was of sweet malt. The flavor was carmel malt, with a hint of spices in the aftertaste. A very good Maibock.

At the 2010 Microfest in St. Louis. Pours a dark caramel color with a decent off white head. Very well balanced with a sweet toasted malt flavor along with caramel, maple syrup and a little hop bitterness.
full bodied and malty with a lot of carmel flavor and a bit of chocolate/roast with just a hint of hops.

On tap at the 2006 Best of the Midwest Brewers’ Festival. Chestnut in color with a tan head. Sweet malty aroma with the smell of bing cherries. Thick flavor with a lingering balance of malt sweetness and hop bitterness. Mellow ending. Very delicious.
copper/light brown color with small tan head. Aroma of sweet malt. Flavor is carmel malt, well balanced, with a hint of spices in the aftertaste.
Malty aroma, sweet malty taste. Not a bad Maibock. .........................

Dark copper/amber color. Malty aroma. Good fruity sweetness, nice hoppiness, too. Munich, Vienna and Caramel malts are what the brewer said was used. Very well balanced, in my opinion, and better than most maibocks in general!

64 oz growler. Pours a hazy amber with a nice foamy white head. Smell is initially peachy then some green pepper, some dank grassy herbal earth notes. The pepper sucks, but the rest is nice. Flavor is sweet up ront. Lots of bubblegum flavor, sweet herbs, very mild bitterness, caramel nougat malt but not too much.
Smells floral. Pretty tame ipa. Clear copper. Nothing special. Tasted in Hermann.
On tap at Augusta brewing company off the Katy trail. I was surprised at how good this is. Very refreshing. Great for after a long bike ride.

Tasted at St. Louis Brewer’s Guild Heritage Fest 2014 in a cool nonic sampler glass. It poured a mostly clear orange amber colour with weak white foam. LOADS of citrusy, flowery, earthy English hops: strong bitterness, flavour AND aroma. Nice biscuity malts underneath, with just a hint of residual caramel sweetness. True-to-style and very tasty. Very nicely done.
