Tap. Pours a clear orange color, copper with a foamy white head. Aroma has a big hoppy nose, citrus and sappy. Flavor is dry, hoppy, hop cones and bitter. Good finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A hazy copper pour with a white head. The aroma was mostly mild pine. The light body has lively carbonation with a semi-bitter flavor throughout.

Sample at beerfest. Pooured a darker orange color with a smaller head. Left some lacing on the side of the glass as it went. Aroma was grapefruit, citrus and floral. Hops in the flavor. Grass, pine and grapefruit. Hoppy aftertaste. Very sticky and oily. Good IPA.
Sampler at the brewpub. It poured a cloudy amber color with a small head. The aroma was of citrus, grapefruit and pine. The taste was similar, grapefruit , floral and citrus hops. Very enjoyable.
Tasted on tap at Augusta Brewing in Augusta, Missouri. Burnt orange appearance which is mostly clear. Sweet hop aroma with a sweet, creamy hopped IPA.

Sampled at the brewpub. Beautiful lacing over a copper colored beer. This IPA is, indeed, well hopped. Tart bitterness throughout. Citrus is grapefruit, a hint of pine, and some pleasant caramel that is almost over whelmed by the hops. Finish was slightly spicy. Nice beer.
6 oz draft sampler pours Amber with a off white head. Aroma of malts, earthy, floral and toast. Taste is caramel, grain and some citrus.
Mild pale ale that pours an ideal color. Doesn't knock your tongue off with hops. My wife even liked it. Refreshing.
Tap - good size foamy head, medium copper color, nice earthy hop aroma and flavor, well balanced by nutty malts ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap. Pours a clear amber orange color. Light ring of bubbles. Aroma is hoppy, mash, and old hops. Flavor also tastes like hops beyond their time. Bitter finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Amber, cream head. Leather and horseblanket in the aroma, with clean hops. Start is assertive, toast, followed by solid malt, followed by a long, bitter finish. Clean, fresh on the palate.
Sampler at the brewpub. It poured a copper color with a small head. The aroma was hops and more hops, very tasty. The flavor was also dominated by hops and a little bitterness. A very decent brew.
Tasted on tap at Augusta Brewing in Augusta, Missouri. Medium orange body with a bit of cloudiness. Medium hoppy aroma. Hoppy yet amber-like malts can be tasted.
GABF 2010, lighter caramel colored pour, grassy hops & medium biterness. balanced but flavor was a bit light. decent EPA & sessionable

Sample from a growler poured by the brewer. He was calling it an APA, though, so I think the style might be incorrectly listed here. Anyway, it pours a clear amber color with a two-finger off-white head. Notes of floral hops, orange citrus, caramel malts, pine, yeast, and grass. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a leafy mouthfeel. Whether its an EPA or APA, it’s a nice, sessionable ale.
Fairly decent EPA, with a fairly strong malt beginning finishing with a slight hop taste and bitterness at the end.

Draft: Cloudy, dark yellow with a small white head. Grain malt, honey aroma. Slight grassy bitter over sweet grain malt taste... Leans more along the lines of a blonde ale, rather than a Pils... Solidly drinkable, though.
Draft at the brewery during RBSG. From notes. Fruity with tropical and citrus notes. Bready wheat backbone.
12 oz can pours golden with a white head. Aroma of malts, grain and grass. Taste is grain, malts, hay and caramel.

Feint hint of hops and grain. Very light yellow, though not totally translucent. Lace is small and easily dissipates. Refreshing grains and rice, light hints of hops here and there. Beer is very clean and refreshing. Most refreshing beer with flavor in a while. Overall this is a great pilsner. Could use more hops but pilsners aren’t known for that.

Draft... RBSG 2014… Hazy yellow lager with a mid-sized, wispy, white head that diminishes to a small, creamy, white cap. The bouquet is reserved and tough to pull, but I’m picking up rumors of pale malts and spicy hops. Medium-bodied with stinging carbonation. The flavor is bittersweet – pale grains, honey and spicy, peppery hops. Well-balanced, but it does trend toward the sweet side. Bright, crisp, lightly sweet finish.
Deep yellow pour with creamy white head and lace. Aroma is sweet pilsner malt. Sweet malt with a nice floral hop bitter finish. Medium bodied with good carbonation. nice pils
On tap at the brewpub during SRBG Bus Tour. Comes golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma of malt and grain. Taste is sweet malt, grass, and honey. OK.

Draft during RBSG 2014 Bus Tour at Morgan Street. Clear yellow with off-white head. Aromas of tropical fruit, mangoes, apples. Tastes of citrus, tropical fruit, wheat, light skunk. Medium-light body with a dry finish. Medium carbonation.
Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a hazy yellow color with a white head. Has a fruity malty grainy weak grassy aroma. Fruity malty grainy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy weak grassy finish.

Taster on tap at the brewpub during RBSG. Clear golden color. Thin ring of white head. Medium body. Smooth, crisp, lighter carbonation. More dry finish. Moderate bitter, light metallic note. Bready peppery flavor. Smooth pils, but just OK flavor for me.

On tap at La Forge in Tremblant, Quebec. Opaque, near-black with a small, creamy "cafe au lait" head and very good lacing. Aroma of roasted coffee, roasted malt and cocoa. Taste of chocolate, cocoa, coffee, oatmeal, roasted malt and caramel. Medium body and medium/low carbonation with a smooth mouthfeel.
It poured a copper color with a small white head. The aroma was of hops. The taste was of hops as well. A medium-bodied brew and very easy to drink.
Tap. Poured a light cooper color with no head on it. Aroma was light citrus, corn and grass. Flavor was malts, earthy flavors, dough and metallic. Very thin and watery body. Not the best.

sample at brewpub poured a rich amber color with a huge, frothy white head. Aroma of belgian yeast, spice, vanilla and a hint of fruitiness. Pretty straightforward and not overly tasty of a beer. Some caramel, yeast, earthy/herbal elements with a slightly tart flavor. Just ok

Draft sample at the brewpub. Pours a cloudy, pale amber color with a small white head that laves some lace in the glass. Aroma of butter, pale and sweet malts, copper, and minerals. Flavor follows the same lines, with butter, toffee, and sweet malts early, ending with a more mineral, metallic note. Dry finish. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation. Not bad, but for a better locally-made common, you could head to Pi for the Schlafly Pi Common.
Clear amber color/ off white head. Yeasty bready aromas with spicy hops. frothy light mouthfeel. Bready honey biscuit malty flavors with spicy, citrus hops, crisp clean finish, not bad.

Date: February 27, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear copper, fine off white head, thick patterned lace Aroma: light sweet malt aroma, touch of fruity character Flavor: sweet and fruity flavor, light earthyness Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4

(On tap, named Steam Lager) This beer seems subdued upon first sip, smooth for a second, but quickly the hops kick in and you realize that it is more like an American pale ale than a typical (blander) "steam beer". The hops are very fresh and cool tasting, and the malt is fairly complex and blends and balances extremely well with the hops. This is one of the better beers to come out of Morgan street brewing. I wish they made more beers like this because I think this beer is not only well-executed, but unique and has character and complexity. It’s also largely without objectionable qualities, although perhaps it is a bit flat, like most of Morgan street’s brews. I would recommend this one for anyone who likes American pale ales and more bitter beers.

On tap at the Parkville Microbrew Festival. This is a very well-balanced beer and just a pleasure to drink. A dark gold pour with a ginormous white head. This tastes like a steam beer. Has a goodmalt graininess, but ends up being surprisingly smooth to drink. Great finishing lacing.

Sample #3 from the brew pub. Golden amber. Off white Saturn head. Medium malt caramel nose. Smooth. Little soapy. Nice citrus hop finish. Floral. Medium bodied. Malty and a little bitter. Solid. Best of Show!

On tap: pours an opaque black with a creamy nitro head. Has a lightly sweet roasty coffee nose with a hint of dark chocolate. Body starts with decent fullness and a bittersweet roasty maltiness with a touch of black licorice and coffee grounds before a drier lingering roasty finish. A pretty true to style and drinkable Irish stout.

Sampler @ the brewpub. A very good dry stout, no flaws. A bit heavier than I like my Dry Stouts but full of roast and some chocolate at the end. Well attenuated, sweetness not coming off the sugars. I would drink this anytime.

Sampled at the 2009 Parkville microbrew festival. Pours black with a beige head. This is a semi-decent beer. For the style it seems a little too sweet but not lactose sweet. I just don’t find the beer to be dry enough. It’s ok though.

[tap at brewery] This beer is delicious, the aroma is roasted coffee and chocolate, the taste has a nice slightly bitter coffee/chocolate dominating that assaults your olfactory as you drink, I love what this beer did while I was drinking it. Simple enough to enjoy, but just complex enough to keep you sipping and pondering.

(On tap) The commercial description of this beer modestly compares it to Guinness, which in my opinion, does not do this beer justice as I think this beer is much better: more flavorful overall and certainly more complex. A little less smooth than is typical for an Irish stout, this beer has a bit of roast, a bit of bitterness, and a rich, coarse texture and a coarse sourness that I like. My main complaints is that, as you drink more of it, it comes across as a bit watery (without being smooth), and a funky quality emerges to the roast, reminiscent of stale coffee. Still, these negative qualities are not particularly dominant, and not nearly as bad as in many microbreweries attempt at a stout, so I have to give them credit for it. Overall, I like this beer and would drink it again, although I think it could be improved somewhat, mainly by making it have a richer body, be smoother, and lose the funkiness in the roast aroma.

Pours a creamy dark brown with a small tan head. Roasty aroma of coffee and chocolate, and a few hints of dark fruits here and there. The palate is quite thin borderlining on watery. Not much going on with this one.

Draught at Morgan St. Pours black with a small, creamy, light brown head, somewhat lasting with good lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (chocolate, coffee, burnt), light hops (grass), average yeast (leather) with notes of prune, date, and tar. Medium bodied, thin texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish. Average duration, light sweetness and acidity, moderate bitterness.

From the brewery on 12/4/07. I liked this one, apparently more than others on here. Coffee and malt aroma, nice balance of malts and just a hint of hops. Poured dark brown with light tan head and nice lacing.

Part of a sample bunch, prior to the Packers/Rams game ( GO PACK!) Normal stout pour, aroma seemed almost close to the dopple I had. Plus coffee. Taste was way thinner than most any stout I have had. Not much there but a coffee & malt.
Of the sampler this was my favorite of the five. Not amuch aroma but some roastiness. The beer was mostly sweet malt. It started out with a full bodied feel but that seemed to thin a bit.
Pite w domu, ciemnobrązowy mętnawy kolor, piana średnia trzyma się słabo. Aromat niezbyt intensywny, słodowy. W smaku lekko karmelowe, nie pozostawia śladów w pamięci, przeciętne.
Dunkelbraunes Bier mit feinporigem Schaum. Milder Malzduft. Antrunk getreidig schaumig. Erfrischend, aber noch nicht zu wässrig. Dennoch wenig Aroma. Im Nachgeschmack leichte Bitterkeit.
Bottle from Blau Weiss. Copper with a full head. Aroma of malty grain. Flavour of citrus, bread, sweet malt. Finish is oily citrus.

On tap at Bamberger Weissbierhaus. I thought it was Maisel Landbier we had but I can’t find that beer on Ratebeer so I assume this is what we got. Malty smell, light metallic with some butter. Malty taste, bready with caramel and light metallic. I also got some butter in the taste. Malt focused. Not that clean.

500 ml bottle. BB 26/03/15. From bierzwerg.de. Clear copper golden colour with a big foamy off-white head. Sweetish malt, some grainy dryness, grassy hops, mild bitterness and some metallic notes in the aroma. The flavour is dry graininess, metallic notes, honey sweetness, malt and mild hops. Low carbonation. Drinkable but there’s some cloying honey sweetness I don’t quite like.
Draught at Berlin Bierfestival 2014. Low fluffy white lasting head. Clear dark brown body. Sweet roasted malt caramel aroma & Flavor. High carbonation, short sweet finish.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig. Geschmack malzig fruchtig, getreidig, leichte Bitterkeit.
bottle from mein-biershop. Deep golden colour, white head. Malty with grassy-resiny hops - well-balanced.

(bottle) Clear, deep golden to amber colour with a medium-sized off-white foamy head. Doughy cara-malty aroma with a touch of metal. Moderately sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a quite soft carbonation. Slightly bready cara-malty taste with shy herbal accents; rather slim and sweet malty finish with restrained hoppy notes and a tinge of metal. Bland. 06.XII.13

Bottle. Golden, small to average and fully diminishing head. Light to moderate, malty - lightly grainy and sweetish aroma, some caramel and some bread with faint hoppyness. Body is light to medium, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish flavor, some caramel and light bread. Finish is average, malty - lightly grainy and sweetish, light caramel and light bread, faint hoppyness. Caramel sweetish and bready lager - really nothing special.
A solid german wheat. Not the best, but i’d be extremely happy with this in north america. D&S dresden
bottle bb 20/6/18 oro velata biona scjmhiima piuttosto persistente piuttosto fenolica babana delicata in bocca cereale un leggero maltato

Bought in Bamberg's Getränkemarkt near Train station. Quite a stable, very soft bubbly foam, pretty long lasting though. Color between brown and yellow. Fruity aroma (lemons and mostly banana). Pretty strong, bubblegum, very yeasty and soapy taste. Low carbonation, quite along finish. Hmmm... Strong taste.
From bottle. Transfer of an earlier rating without text recorded, rating only.
500ml bottle courtesy of Lisa in Viereck. Aroma is light banana, light yeast. Appearance is cloudy orange with a white foam. Taste is light sweet. Dry. Very nice.

Hazy orange golden beer with a big white, medium-lasting head. Aromas of banana, yeast, wheat, malt, citrus and floral hops. Moderate sweet malty and yeasty in taste with light sour and refreshing citrus, some pepperiness. Banana and lemon juice in finish. Creamy texture, light body, fizzy carbonation. Good and refreshing. Different from your typical heavier Upper Bavarian Hefeweizen.
Troebel geel bier met schuim. Smaak is fris fruitig banaan en citrus, licht zuur. Goed voor een warme zomerdag.
Rating from 2005. Sehr schönes Weißbier, aber etwas säuerlich im Abgang. Schön hefig-mild mit leichter Herbe. --> 11

Bottle at Berlin Bierfestival 2014. High creamy and lasting white head. Hazy light yellow green body. Mild banana dominated fruity aroma.with apples and pears as well. Very sweet smooth and creamy fruity flavor with a bit of sour lemon notes. Low carbonation, long sweet finish.
bottled. murky yellow with a lingering head; aroma of banana and bread and bitter pudding; mellow, some caramelised banana flavours, dull finish
Poors golden yellow, white lacing foam. Barley aroma and sweet in taste. A good beer with this heat. (Bamberg 201808) ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Alla spina. Bellissimo colore dorato, schiuma bianca e persistente, finissima. Lieve aroma erbaceo, lievissimo sentore di miele. Secchissima, abbastanza amaro che prevale sulle note maltate. Birra che si fa bere in gran quantità, senza però lasciare grandi segni
At Berliner Internationales Bierfestival 2016. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma of bread, light fruit and some grass. Similar taste. Soft and easy to drink.

Draft at Bamberger Weissbierhaus during the Bamberg Jolly. Pours perfectly clear yellow with a foamy white head. Really nice pils, good dry cereal character, with a bit of crunchy straw giving bitterness. Light bodied with average carbonation. Lightly hoppy in the finish, with great crunchy cereal, straw, white bread. Solid, super drinkable, lovely.
On tap at the Bamberger Weissbierhaus (under the name Pils Püls-Bräu). Fruity smell with pale bread. Similar taste with a light herbal hop aroma. Medium bitterness.

500ml vom fass at Bamberger Weissbierhaus. Crystal clear golden coloured body. Low, but lasting white head. Grass and pale malty nose. Pale malty flavours and a touch of lemon. Harsh bitter endnotes. Accepted, not so bad with the food (Bamberg 10.10.2014).

Draught at Berlin Bierfestival 2014. Low fluffy white lasting head. Clear yellow golden body. Mild malt straw aroma and flavor with little hops bitterness, pretty sweet in fact. High carbonation. Short finish.

Bamberg jolly day 1 24/1/14. On tap at the Maisels Weissehaus Bamberg. Crystal clear yelow straw colour with a big ol frothy white head. Aroma is clean pils grain and earthy hop. Flavour is clean cereal, green nobel hop. Grassy hop bitterness. Average / high carbonation. Tasty enough.

How: Draught. Where: Bamberger Weissbierhaus, Bamberg. Appearance: Pale yellow colour with a small white head. Aroma: Sweet malt, hops, citrus. Body: Medium body, heavy carbonation. Flavour: Mild caramel, hops, yeast.

Day 1 of the post Xmas Bamberg Jolly, from tap split at Maisels Bamberg, 24/01/14. Clear golden with a moderate white head that dissipates to pondwork. Nose is clean, straw, citruc, grass laden, pale malts/ Taste comprises hay, light caramel, lemon sherbet. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, crisp clear closure. Decent pils.
Es steht nicht Dunkel drauf aber es ist dunkel drin, braunes Bier schaum is etwas schwach, im Geruch kräftig malzig, im Geschmack malzig süß Karamell holzig säuerlich herb im Abgang

“Schwanenbräu Lager“, vom Faß im Schwanenbräu, Ebermannstadt. - Kastanienrotbraun, klar. - Nase ähnlich ländlich wie beim Pilsener, aber mit ein wenig säuerlichem Kakao und Frucht. - Antrunk weich dunkelmalzig und mild fruchtig-säuerlich mit Kakao. Weiche dunkle Malzbittere. Mild rezent, vollmundig. Im Abgang dunkle Malzbittere und milde Hopfenherbe. - Ungewöhnliches aber durchaus überzeugendes Dunkles.

Many thanks to bobinlondon for the bottle!! Pours a clear brown with orange highlights and a loose tan head. The smell is roasted malt, brown sugar, brown bread, a touch of coconut. The taste is delightful roasted malt, brown sugar, brown breads bit of fruit while ending dry and a bit roasty. Light+ oil body with silky carbonation. Very drinkable.

Draft at Schwanen Brau in Ebermannstadt. Called dunkel Lagerbier. Clear brown with a frothy white head. Aroma of plenty of nuts, walnut peel. Bitter, a little bit metallic and nutty taste, light body, fine carbonation and nutty finish - delicate though.
Frisch vom Hahn im Hahn im Hotel Schwanenbräu getrunken. Mild salzig, aber keine Größter.
Draught at SMÖF cons 2015-10-24 Söderbärke AR: bready, wee syrup AP: clear brown, no head F: bready, wee carbonation, soft mouthfeel
Lichtbruin helder bier met schuim. Gedronken in het restaurunt van de brouwerij. Smaak is licht bitter en iets zoet met sporen van zoethout. Goed bier.
Klares bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit einer geringen beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht röstmalzig, fruchtig, Karamell. Geschmack malzig, reife Früchte, nussig, Karamell.

My Bottom Line: Metallic nodes grow on this Dunkel’s toasted toffee, clashing with the brew’s lean and fluffy feel. Further Personal Perceptions: -A sliver of foam rests atop the misty brown. -This isn’t too sugary, but it’s sadly clunky. -Light caramel appears in the finish. -The mouthfeel is actually pleasant. On tap at the brewpub.

Draft at Schwanen Brau in Ebermannstadt. Called dunkel Lagerbier. Clear amber copper body; short but tight off-white head. Clean first impression of the aroma. Nutty and sweet and bready Munich malt. Crunchy grains, red apples, some caramel. Good mineral quality, quenching and smacking. Flavor shows some pleasant toasted malt expression, but not rich. Semi-sweet chestnut flavor lingering with some candy sugar and light herb / spice. Simple but well-executed.
Aroma has caramel and tropical fruit. A sweetish, malty taste. Very fruity (pineapple, banana, pear). Yeasty and fruity finish. Refreshing beer, in spite of its maltiness.
Gold pilsner. Nice malt aroma, honeyish. Dry, good body. Simple finish, only a few hops.
Dark ale. Roasted malt aroma, really strong. Good body, sweet, only partially equilibrated by the hop. Palate more balanced then the other beers sampled, just due to the presence of roasted barley.

Gold-amber cloudy wheat ale. Yeast in the aroma; then a strong fruity aroma (green apple, apple, grape). Sweet, a little malty, candy sugar, fruity. Sweet and fruity final; absolutely no hop character. The brewer uses some addictions to give those subtile aroma and flavour: apple, grape, ananas, banana, Grand Marnier.

It’s golden with a white head and the aroma has notes of malt, light cabbage and straw. The flavour has a light sweetness and the same notes as the aroma. The finish is dry. It’s not one to remember...

Bottled, "Premium Pils", alc. 4.9% (BB 03/2006) Pale yellow, decent creamy white head. Mild flowery, malty nose, hints of cardboard. Malty, fruity with woody hops. Basic clean German pilsener with dry a bit buttery and late hoppy aftertaste.
Hop- and barnyardaroma. Hoppy and malty taste, relatively dry. Bitter, herbal finish. Good pilsener from a very small brewery.
Barnyard aroma, hops and hay. Hopbitter taste, medium bodied, relativerly dry and firm. Hopbitter, grassy finish. Drunk at the brewery.

"Pottensteiner Bio-Dunkel", Flasche (50 cl) aus dem Hufeisen-Getränkekeller, Pottenstein. - Dunkles Rotbraun, trüb. - In der Nase mildes dunkles Malz, Vollkornbrot und eine eigentümliche krautige Note (Moos?), kräftige Röstnoten. - Antrunk weich dunkelmalzig mit Brotkruste, Bitterkakao und Mokka. Kaum süß. Tiefe dunkle Röstnoten verbinden sich mit brotiger Trockenheit und moosiger Hopfenherbe zu einem wuchtig trocken-bitteren Abgang. Mild rezent, zart hefig. Sehr langer Nachtrunk. - Ungewöhnlich malzbitter-herbes, trockenes Dunkles, individuell und urtümlich. Unbedingt probierenswert! Eine würdige Konkurrenz für das ebenso fulminante, doch etwas traditioneller aufgefaßte Dunkel vom Mager im gleichen Ort.
Brown. Aroma is lightstruck, peas, slight roast, treber. Taste is sweetich malt with lots of nut oils and alcoholic nothingness. Sharp not balanced. Bad.

(bottle) opalescent ruby-brown colour with a frothy light-beige head. aroma of liquorice and peppermint, with some notes of toasted grain, rose oil and earth. flavour is mostly earth and roasted malts, rather twiggy, with a hint of sesame seeds and a slightly toasty bitter finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Bottle. Red dark chestnut, brown lace. Farty roast, sulphur, grilled veggies, DMS. Medium light body, mellow mouthfeel. Bandaid, old veggies, roast, bitter finish. meh.
Bottle. Amber-brown color with beige head. Aroma is chocolate, earthy. Taste is chocolate, roasted, some veggies. Silky mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Not convincing.

Bottle best by June 1, 2016, consumed Nov. 2015: Clear garnet. Fine but broken off-white head. Papery and waxy nose, with underlying prune juice, brown sugar, pumpernickel bread, chocolate, caramel and wet carpet. Discordant leaves a foamy residue on the palate. Opens with notes of overripe plums and medicinal characteristics. Poorly extracted malt predominates with paper and soggy cereal notes. Incessant gritty sugars greatly hamper drinkability. Finishes cola sugary with some cardboard and unwelcome raisiny flavors lingering. Zero discernible hops to help with balance. A fairly dirty and underattenuated (semi-worty, in this case) Franconian dark lager. Unpleasant.

Bottle: Unclear, deep amber coloured, unclear, big creamy and lacy off-white head; moderate clean caramelly-fruity nose with a slight herbal bitterness in the background;moderate bitter-sweet flavour, creamy MF; lingering fruity-malty and herbal-hoppy finish. Well rounded, well balanced franconian Dunk’l...

50cl bottle. Pours clear orange brown colour with a mid-sized most good lasting beige head. Aroma of toasted dark malt, caramel, some chocolate. Taste of mild roasted malt, floral hops, some chocolate, good one!

Bottle best by June 2016. Lightly hazed dark maroon-brown body with a short tan colored head. Aroma is malt-dominant with notes of roasted grain, peanuts, dirty dish water, compost / soil, autolyzed yeast. Medium-light bodied, sweet and sharp with low bitterness and noticeable burnt grain astringency on the palate that tastes like burnt pancake batter, finishing slightly sour.
Lichtbruin bier met weinig schuim. Scmaak is licht rokig en licht caramel en zoethout, niet zoet. Erg goed bier. Gedronken op terras bij Schöngroundsee Pottenstein.
Klares goldgelbes Bier mit einer ordentlichen weißen Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr hopfig, grasig, leicht floral, malzig. Geschmack hopfig, grasig, getreidig, spritzig und süffig, gut!
Bottle, picked up at landbierparadies. Pale and yellowish with a slim head; dull grassy aroma; light bitterness with hints of self raising flour and dried apricots.pretty unexciting
A pretty average German style Pilsner,a bit too sweet and salty for my taste..Pale yellow,small white head with a strong malty aroma.lots of grain and not so fresh tasting hops..Enough said..
Grassy straw notes. Heavily carbonated. Slightly sweet. Nice color, pours smooth with little head.

Der Herbe Antrunk bietet von Anfang an eine hopfige Umgebung, zwischenzeitlich auch einen feinen Zitrushauch. Ab dem Mittelteil etwas zurückhaltend, dafür aber gleichmäßig grasig. Das Bier ist hier weniger aromatisch und wirkt etwas langweilig. Dazu in Teilen trocken und etwas muffig-bitter. Fast schon laffer Abgang, unstimmig. Danke an den Doppelbock. 8/9/9/7/8/9
It’s golden with a grey hue and a small head. The aroma has notes of malt and fruit. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of caramel, fruit, straw, and the finish is dry.
Bottled. Yellowish golden colour, small white head. Aroma is bready malts, grass, mild hay and some saltwatery notes. Flavour is bready malts, caramel, some grass, mild hay and earth.

Bottle picked up from the Brauerei Andreas Sauer, Gunzendorf, during Fin and Loz’s cycle ride around villages to the South and South East of Bamberg, Germany 19-06-10 consumed 11.08.10 Pours light gold, very pale almost straw coloured in fact. Soft, with cereal and a touch of metallicness going on, sweet and malty but not bad. A6 A4 F6 P3 Ov12 3.1
Bottle. Corn syrup malt and light grass hops aroma. Golden yellow color with minimal head. Syrupy sweet light malt flavor with bitter weedy finish. Pretty basic and not so great.

(bottle) Clear, golden colour with a blond medium-sized foamy head. Moderately sweet and slightly milky pale malty aroma with a tinge of herbal hops, accompanied by shades of citrus. Sweet-bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a crisp mouthfeel. Rather a malt-accented Pilsener with a mild grainy touch and shy herbal hops towards the slightly bitter finish. Clean but not world-shaking. 27.IV.10
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig, bananig. Geschmack hefig, bananig fruchtig, minimal würzig.

Das Bier ist insgesamt sehr laff, ganz leicht hefig und in Anklängen frisch-süffig. Der Abgang ist ziemlich kurz und trocken, erinnert an Apfelwein… --> gibt bessere... Test vom 22.1.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,9,10,6,12,7 - 8,35

There are many words in German that use pig or sow (connoting "extremely") to denote great taste or greatness of any sort, so maybe that explains the pig on the label? Schweinegut (pig-great), sau-lecker (pig-delicious) are 2 I can think of, but there’s also saumäßig (lousy, or beastly, or rotten). Maybe that’s what they could be hinting at with this picture. Besides the fun picture of a pig drinking a Weissbier on the label, the label on the top states "Yeasty, Drinkable, Top-Fermenting" and on the side or (bottom) part I find the best, "Bottle-fermented," which for me says live yeast to possibly harvest for my homebrew. On the back label is a bigger surprise for me. Besides the normal BS about RHG, it states it uses Aroma hops. However, that might just mean "aroma hops" were used instead of "bittering hops" as the main hop additions. After drinking so many fränkische Biere without a leaf of aroma hops and lots of Noble hop bitterness, it should be nice to get variety. It opened with a bang, yes, it’s bottle fermented, and I had to close the flip top immediately to avoid a minor mess. The beer pours like a regular Weisse, with a light orangish tinge to a nice deep, dark yellow. Foam is huge of course, but dissipated and laid down by the time these last 2 sentences were typed. It’s not see-through clear, but not of a hefe-weizen thickness. It looks like a normal protein haze of some of my homebrews that are a signature of bottle fermentation with some yeast in suspension. It’s not bubbling up CO2 like many Weissbiere, but that may be because I’m drinking it out of a Pils glass. The aroma is wheat full-bore with orange marmelade lemon and a hint of bubblegum, yet no trace of aroma hops :(. The initial tastes is has a hint of sourness, spritzy but not overly so like a Hefeweizen. The wheat is as noticable as the Pils malt is. The taste has very, very light bubblegum but more in the direction of citrus, but not lemon, and finally, more of a sweet aftertaste. Basically, it’s a sweet and sour taste that lingers without any hint of hops. In summer, I can imagine it to be a great thirst quencher of a warm, sunny day. The mouthfeel is not think nor thin, really a happy medium. Overall, I think I would’ve like it better sitting in the shade of tree with a little sweat from a nice warm day. Normally, I wouldn’t expect sourness in a Weissbier but with the Eber-Weisse, it fits in nicely. I would give it a 4 out of 5.

(bottle) pours a murky golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of heavy caramel, wheat and burnt toffee, with a hint of kiwi fruit. flavour is mostly the same, wheat and caramel, slightly meaty. watery body with lively carbonation.
banana, Exotic fruits, dough, bread, bubblegum, amber-orange, cloudy, frothy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation,
Hazy golden color with huge frothy white head. Aroma of red fruit, banana, yeast. Taste, fruity with yeast, banana, clove.
Bottle @ Brewery. Pours hazy golden with a white head. nose is extremely phenolic. Herbs, cabbage and mint. Flavor is wheat and yeast. Slightly tart. Medium bodied.

Bottle @ Mega Bavarian Beer Tasting in Schlitz. Lightly, whitish yellow golden appearance with a white head. Moderately spicy, banana, light citrusy aroma. A bit tangy, lemon/orange citrusy, creamy, fairly yeasty flavor. Pretty decent but nothing special.
The head is ok, the body cloudy. It tastes sweet and a bit sour, yeasty, nice. It is refreshing and a bit fruity-citrus, light and sweet. Ok! 12/11/11/10/12/11
bread, toast, spruce, earthy, banana, cooked vegetables, vanilla, amber, sparkling, frothy, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, creamy, soft carbonation, oily feel, astringent,
Had at the brewpub on tab and somehow smelled like a skunked beer. Tasted ok but nothing special and hard to concentrate on taste when aroma is like a skunk.

Dark golden foamy head. Clear, lots of light, a bit hazy. Some spidery lace. Flowery malt aroma. Smell is not distinct, not strong. Has a heavy spicy / Saison / maibock flavor. Spicy and a bit sour like a saison; hints of dark grape. Some honey to smooth it out. Some white wine. Feels bubbly; sharp and fizzy. Improves with warmth. Actually a solid brew, much better once you let it breathe a bit.

12oz Handbottle. Labeled 6/08. Slightly estery and rubbery nose, backed with some slightly old malt. Pours a crystal clear burnt orange, with a soft soap up in lacey whitish. Flavor is shocking. There’s some really ugly flaming tire, hexane cleaning chemicals, and residue. Rubbery. Bitter. Alcoholic. Ahh. This is, unfortunately, not drinkable. Some bitter almond close the smack, but ugh, this has some serious problems.
On tap at the brewery. The stronger alcohol content has a bit of a bite. Good overall flavors with good hops on a solid malt. I found the bitterness a bit more than I cared for.

12oz bottle, courtesy of ryan. Thanks! Pours a bright, clear golden-orange color; light, creamy khaki head with solid, fine-bubbled lacing. Light aroma showing candy sugar, basic cereal malts, and some orange-tinged fruitiness; a bit bland overall, with a touch of alcohol poking through. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: candy sugar, sweet basic maltiness, and some light citrus and mineral bitterness; slightly relaxed carbonation, making this seem a touch flabby overall; still, decent amounts of balancing mineral bitterness and a solid, if not overly complex, malty core. Lengthy, dry finish: toasted malts, breadiness, and some minerals.

Draft at new brewpub. Poured clear dark amber color with an average creamy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate toasted nutty malty aroma. Medium body with soft carbonation. Medium balanced flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Drinkable brew that met my expectations.

Tap at Spuyten Duyvil. Pale amber beer with a thick white head. Pale malts with light honeyish character. Acetaldehyde and DMS stink. After the last two quality brews, this nastiness just doesn’t cut it.

Draft at Spuyten Duyvil. Vegetal, dry earthy. As it warms there is a kind of glue taste that makes it near undrinkable. Doesn’t have much to separate it from other maibocks, and doesn’t really live up to its brothers, either.

A little lighter in color than many mai bocks I've tried in the past. Wonderful malt sweetness ... some citus flavors. More hops than many mai bocks. I really enjoyed the lingering aftertaste. This is the beer to drink while munching peanuts outside on an overcast afternoon. MBC's mai bock is a beautifully balanced beer and could become a favorite.

Nice malty inhale redolent of peaches and cinnamon - deceptively soft, as is the first smooth rich taste. The thing just has more than hops than are usual in a bock and they fire up the close significantly. Good stuff.
On tap. Dark cooper color with white head. Malty taste with a slight biscuit taste. Dry aftertaste. Nothing special, but drinkable.
12 oz bottle. Aroma of malt and faint caramel. Nice even, surprisingly full taste of malt, caramel and grass.

A brew with clear high and low points. Highs? The lovely appearance, with a nice medium copper color and off white head. The aroma, with a nice sweetness and some alcohol notes. Lows? The flavor, sadly. It’s thin and lacks much depth. A bit of malt and caramel sweetness, but it can’t live up to the aroma...not even close, really.

Retired? Guess it’s a good thing I found a bottle when I did! Aroma is strong, malty and fruity. It pours a clear golden amber with a thick off-white head that does not stick around too long. Flavor does not quite match the aroma, being malty with a hint of fruit and a touch of hops but mostly unremarkable; still, it satisfies. Texture is smooth and tingly, rather typical.

Bottle Pours a hazy amber with an off white head. The head leaves quickly. Lacing is okay. Aroma is malty. Mostly caramel and grass. Has an okay cabonation. The mouthfeel is alright. Theflavor is spicy grass. Which really works for tis beer. Has a good malty endiing. Has a medium body. A thickier texture. The finish is good with a good aftertaste. Not a bad beer from a brewer who makes good beer.

12oz bottle. Pours pretty hazy, light golden color with a very small white head with poor retention. Aroma shows fresh barley, cracker, intensely malty. Very grainy, like barley husks. No hops to be found. Flavor is dry, malty, very low bitterness. Tastes the same as it smelled, crackers and barley. Could use a tad more hops. This is all right, not exactly what I think of when I think of Viennas though.
POured a light straw yellow color with a white head. Aroma was grassy some caramel and thats about it. Flavor was much the same, really bland, some hints of hop bitterness detected as well.

12 oz. botle. Pours a hazy dark golden/light amber color with a small off white head. There is some sediment that comes with the pour. The aroma is light caramel, toasted bread, and a hint of bitterness. The flavor has caramel malt, honey sweetness, a light amount of fruit, and some bitterness in the finish. Medium bodied at best, slightly watery and thin. Not bad, maybe better than I expected.

Light haze on this copper brew. Sweet caramel malt, light grass, toasty malts, and some floral as well in the aroma. Full bodied and smooth. Nice toasted malt, caramel, and some earth/floral hops in the flavor. Refreshing and flavorful- this brew is well underrated.

Date: 12 oz. bottle on 8/30/08 Aroma - toasted grain , biscuit, some floral hops Appearance - Clear orange, medium white head, reasonably durable Flavor - Solid malt base of light sweetness with a gentle bitterness as it finishes Palate - Light to medium body, smooht, clean Overall - Refreshing, nice balanced flavors. Seems underrated to me.

Sampled from the beer engine at the brewpub: Poured a surprisingly transparent dark brown with a thin, short-lived, light tan head. Aroma is subtle and malty, but with a noticeable brandy quality. Lightly sweet and filled with brandy oak, it’s body was also kinda thin and not very interesting. Would’ve much rather seen the Siberian Night on the beer engine.

On tap (nitro tap...no!) at the Dayton location. Quite the variety of opinions here on this beer; I am in the "liked it" camp. Poured like your average nitro stout, dark chocolate-brown (with red tinges) and a thick, creamy, dense tan head. While this beer is probably offered to the general public as "Guinness-like," I was pleasantly surprised by how un-Guinnessy (dontcha love Ratebeer English?) the flavor was; instead of rather acidic roasts dominating the palate, this beer offered loads of chocolate balanced by toasty notes and a bit of caramel. Aroma was very light at first (and roasty) but some caramely elements appeared as the glass warmed a bit. Nice complexity for a rather thin-bodied beer. Goes down so smooth...and so fast.
Dark brown color with a small tan head. Roasted aroma and flavor. It is somewhat thin and watery for a stout. Very smooth and drinkable. Thanks to Dogbrick for the growler.
and on to the stouts. This was very light for a stout. lighter and less creamy then guiness. Still a very good stout and i'd have again (if they were out of siberian).
water + stout = watery stout with no head or taste. Couldn't teach an old dog new tricks in this one.

This poor, tired old dog has gone soft and thin. The body was so watery - thinner than a nitro-canned Guinness. It looked so tasty - deep black body, creamy head. Even the roasted malts were affected by the watery taste. It did have enough hops to dry out the finish. This dog may need to be put down.
Definitely the best offering from Thirsty Dog. I'm glad I tried this one last. Thick and dark, incredibly smooth.

Rerate 05/05/03:Tried this again from a growler and I am adjusting my rating slightly lower because the thinness was more noticeable this time. However it is still an easy-drinking Stout and I like the roasted coffee flavor very much. I mostly wanted to amend my statement of this being my favorite Thirsty Dog beer. Nothing will ever top Siberian Night now that I have tried that. 05/21/02 (4.3): Unbelievably smooth, yet with a bubbly appearance. Excellent roasted quality to the armoma and flavor. Probably my favorite Thirsty Dog offering.
(Bottle 33 cl) Nice, fully golden beer - almost amber - with a delicate and stable head. Pleasant, malty nose and a very nice, malty flavour - quite sweet. A surprisingly good beer. 150500

An amber beer with a fine light orange head. The aroma is sweet malty, but with clear sour notes from brewing cereal. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel, and sour notes from the brewing cereal, leading up to an OK bitter, slightly dry end.

OK white head on an orange golden body. Sweet aroma with tones of fruit and hops. Also quite sweet in the flavor, surprisingly fruity with some bitterness to the finish. Actually a quite nice beer and better than expected!
Bitter taste. A boring and cheap beer.......................................

17/7/2019. Bottle shared at the South West tour bottle share. Bought at the brewery. Pours dark gold with a bubbly white head. Aroma of hops, malt, fruit, light caramel and straw. Moderate sweetness and bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, average to soft carbonation.
Bottle: Poured a coppery golden with white head. Aroma is toffee and roasted malt. Taste is nice grain, malt, soft toffee.
Bottle from the brewery. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, nuts, fruits, hops and malt. Sweet nutty finish.

1Jul2018 Sweet grain and cereal malts, molasses, biscuit, straw, hay, grass. Clear, dark gold, small, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More straw and cereal malts, hay, grass, bitter citrus fruits, orange and lemon peel, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Alright, yet unremarkable. Bottle from Rog - thanks!

Bottle at home, 26/06/18. Clear golden copper with a well presented lasting off white head. Nose is dusty fruits, brown bread, almond, grains, malty, biscuit. Taste comprises fruit slice, airy malts, biscuit, caramel, dried fruits, ligh breads, hint of orange. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with balanced bitterness. Decent enough ESB.
Bottle conditioned. Pours a amber colour with with a tight white head, plenty of fruit especially orange in the aroma, the taste is medium bitterness and fruity with a dry bitter finish.

Bottle as a Christmas present from my brother and drunk at home a few months later. Clear amber colour lasting thin beige head. Certainly a tasty premium bitter, lots of fruity malt and biscuit here. Very drinkable. Earthy, brown malts, earthy hops. It’s a premium bitter. Some blackcurrant and hedgerow. Fine.

500ml bottle as ’Old Luxters Farmhouse Barn Ale’, 5.4%, BB July 2017. ’By appointment to Her Majesty the Queen’. Consumed in Blaendulais. Clear dark amber, lightly sparkling, small thin white head, light lacing. Aroma is almond, touch yeasty, cheap cookies. Body is medium, soft carbonation, a little foamy. Taste is spicy, bready malt, tangy metallics, dried tangerine peel, soft peppery bitterness. An interesting beer. Definitely not your average bitter.
Bottle - Golden amber with large white head. Heavy initial carbonation. Hoppy aroma slight ting on tongue and back of mouth. Pleasant hoppy taste with bitter finish - very drinkable.
Pours dark amber with a frothy white head. Aromas of orange, rye bread, honey, citrus, earthy musky notes. Taste is orange, citrus, honey, rye bread. Mouthfeel is quite smooth with low carbonation.
Bottle from the brewery shop. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are rich caramel, fruits, little nuts, hops and has a nice nutty finish.
Bottle at Pre-GBBF: Poured a Brown with tan head. Aroma is sweet malts and dark fruits. Taste is malty sweet toffee, some fruit.

Bottle split at the pre GBBF Shindig '18, picked upat the Brewery shop, 04/08/18. Mahogany brown with a decent beige cap. Nose is nutty, roasted notes, bitter fruits, toffee. Taste comprises dried fruits, brown bread, grains, toffee, light charr, spice. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. So so.

Bottle shared at Chris and Ruth shindig 04/08/2018. Many thanks. A mostly clear nut brown copper coloured pour with a beige head. Aroma is grassy, weed, toasted malts, brown bread. Flavour is composed of dry toasted malts, liquorice, apple, grass,. Palate is dry tannin, meh.

Clear bottle thanks to Colin. It pours clear brown with a small white head. The aroma is earthy roast, wood, bark, damp soil, spicy and burnt grass. The taste is dry, bitter, earthy, tannin, leather, coffee grounds, spice and dirt with a chewy, tannic finish.. Medium body and fine carbonation. Pretty shit overall. Like licking coffee grounds. Meh.
Bottle from the brewer's own stall at Feast at Waddesdon Manor. Brown-red with no head. Thin and lightly sour with chocolate and a light roast. Tastes like low-grade homebrew.

Bottle from a farm shop somewhere near Windsor. Poured a hazy dark amber colour with a moderate off-white head. Aroma of malt, bread, caramel, a slightly nutty. Moderate sweetness and roasted bitterness. Medium body, slight oily texture, soft to average carbonation.
Bottle as a present bought at a National Trust location. Clear brown coloured with a very thin head. Has sweetened dark malts with bursts of chocolate that do linger in the palate.

Bottle - dark red / brown with no head. Burnt roast chocolate aroma - slight vanilla. Ting on tongue, slight fizz aftertaste. Thin tasting - no real depth to flavour. Nothing special. 1st 5-3-5-3-11 2nd Clear reddy brown with large frothy head .High carbonation. Decent roast aroma. Ok mouthfeel - much better tasting than 1st and easy drinking with good finish. What was wrong with1st?

50cl bottle from the brewery. Pours very dark brown with a low tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, rye bread, chocolate, brown sugar. Taste is rye bread, roasted malts, brown sugar. Mouthfeel s somewhat thin with low carbonation. Well made but lacking some depth.
Cask at cloisters... Golden amber.. thin white lacing... Soft dry herbal fruit nose... Ligh dry honey fruits
Cask at the cask and barrel southside. Pours pale golden, nose is light fruit, buttery toffee, taste is similar.

Cask timepiece dewsbury. Golden thin head. Aroma is buttery malts taste same nice sweetness some fruits nice hoppy bitter finish well balanced. Nice mouthfeel. Good session stuff tasty. Very up and down ratings for this I liked!
Cask at the Kidbrooke Beer Festival, 2014. Gold pour with a white head. Vanilla, honey and citrus aroma. Caramel, honey and vanilla flavour. Tasty

Well..... Say no more.... For paler ale lovers this one is a masterstroke of excellence. Superb from start to finish, this is simply awe inspiring. It’s palatability belies it’s strength. A sure stunner, everything about this must-sample gorgeous drink is perfection in a glass!
Clear yellow with next to no head. It is very malty and slightly overbearing in this respect.
Cask (5.2%) by handpump at Bon Accord, Glasgow on 1 Sep 2012: clear golden, thin white head, toffee / caramel malt aroma and flavour, sweet, smooth, very well balanced, easy to drink.

First tasted this at the Waterside Inn, Seamill in August 1995. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear pale straw in colour with a thin white head. Dusty hop flowers in the short aroma. Thin refreshing mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt gives a slight digestive biscuit note with gooseberry, kiwi and lime notes coming through. Hops give a light citric taint to the resiny aftertaste. Finish is lightly edged with dry hops to give a sharp citric bite to accompany the golden syrup laden malty finish. An excellent ESB session beer and well recommended.

What I imagine Harry Potters butterbeer to taste like! Poured a hazy golde with good tight head. aroma is hoppy/grapefruit and the taste was very buttery with a smack of toffee! leaves a silky mouth coating with a bitter finish. very drinkable, but a strange taste Cask from Town Street Tavern, Horsforth, Leeds

Cask at the Myrtle Grove (JDW), Bingley, West Yorks’, 03-05-07. Golden in colour, nice floral aroma with a hint of alcohol. Taste was very smooth with hints of vanilla, some grapefruit flavours also coming through after with a dry finish, great beer, suprised at the ratings of others as I felt this was an excellent beer.

Bottled. A slightly hazy golden beer with a lazing thin beige head. The aroma has strong notes of flowery hops as well as light notes of malt. The flavor is sweet malty combined with flowery notes of hops and light notes of citrus, leading to a dry and lightly bitter finish. The body is light.Thanks fonefan for sharing.

Bottle 50cl. Light unclear light to medium yellow color with a small to average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, dry malt, dusty,light to moderate hoppy, lemonish notes, light to moderate yeasty. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. (220808)

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of fonefan. Slightly hazy golden with a white head. Lightly citrusy nose with a whiff of ginger. Light body with a dry maltiness, some fruit and a dry and bitter finish. 220808

Bottle, shared by fonefan. It pours an almost clear, golden body with a minimal off-white head. Sllightly sour and citrusy, with fruity and flowery hops. Faint malty note. Too sour flavor, but with a pleasant citrusy and piney hoppy bitterness, leading to a piney, citrusy finish with a pleasant bitterness. Medium body. Quite quaffable and quenching, pity it’s going bad. (080822)

50 cL bottle. Pours cloudy golden yellow with a lacing white head. Orange fruity dense hops aroma, seems dry. Light lemonish note to a more dense and almost grapefruity accent in the flavour. Crisp lemon hoppy and vaguely spiced too. Light malt base if any. Lingering citrus fruity hops finish.

Bottle Conditioned. Light brown/yellow with a small off-white head. Aromas are citrus and bitter hops with some sweet malts. Flavours are light sweet malts with hints of caramel. Next are fairly bitter pine hops followed by citrus bite. Dry on the finish with quite a prickly mouthfeel. Pretty thin on the palate, but as a session bitter its pretty decent.
From A Bottle.Light brown in colour with no head,aroma is of leather and hops, taste is thin and watery with some grass and hops and a light bitter finish.
Tested cask conditioned. A good bitter, pleasent balance of bitterness and sweetness. Would have again.

Bottle 50cl. Clear light to medium amber orange color with a average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, moderate yeasty. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (220808)
(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of fonefan. Slightly hazy golden with a rough, off-white head. Lightly citrusy nose. Light-bodied with fruity accents and a fairly bitter finish. 220808

Bottled. A light amber beer with a huge cream colored head. The aroma is sweet wíth an acidic edge and notes of elderflowers. The flavor is sweet and acidic with light notes of malt and caramel. Thanks to fonefan and Brugmansia for sharing.

Bottle, thx to fonefan. A hazy golden-orange beer with an off-white head. Dusty, a bit sourish and citric nose with some maltyness. Quite decent flavor, with a malty caramel and hoppy bitterness, but there’s also some dusty, citric sourness. Medium body. Decent bitter and fruity finish, with some sourness. Luckily the flavor is much better than the aroma. Still, there’s obvious signs of the beer going bad. (080822)

50 cL bottle. Pours slight cloudy orange with a lacing white head. Mild spiced and yeasty aroma. Flavour is quite dry hops with a light spice to herbal note yet light and not too dominant. Mild fruity accent and caramel malt showing through. Light citric touch and bitterness into the far finish.

Bottle conditioned, from Beer cellar in Lincoln. Amber gold, thin rocky white head and moderate condition. Gentle citrus hops and background sweet maltiness with some suggestions of chocolate in the nose. Quite dry and hoppy in the mouth with some citric notes and more chocolate sweetness underpinning it and a delicate yeastiness emerging with time. Short finish, beginning sweet but becoming chalky and slightly yeast bitter at the end.
Although describing itself on the bootle as a typical IPA this is really a brown coloures bitter. Bottle conditioned and slightly smokey with traces of burnt toast. Not very impressive.
From A Bottle.Light brown in colour,no head,malty aroma,good hoppy bitterness in the taste.Another good session for me.
Bottled. Reddish brown, creamy head. Citric acid up front. Clean mouthfeel, traces of pine needles and a lot of lemon juice. This beer has obviously gone bad long before it’s supposed too...

See Beer Elsie Bub for some general comments on Bartrams beers. I had expected this to be a "red ale" from the name, but it was, in fact, a pale copper colour. Malt and hops in the aroma. Malt continues into the flavour, but there is a lot, and I mean a lot, of hoppy bitterness here too. Very bitter finish. Drinks above its abv. Very nice. Bottle-conditioned, October 2003.
Tap. Light pinkish gold in color. Aroma is grains and light raspberry. Taste is grains with spicy raspberry.
Pours a reddish color. Aromas of berries and wheat bread. Flavor of light berries and a sweetness. Medium body with a berry aftertaste.
On tap at Mcguires. Aroma is pure raspberry and Triscuits. This one had a nice garnet hue almost, in the light. Flavor was raspberry with bitter wheat. Not bad.
Draft: Poured a golden color with a white head. Aroma was subtle raspberry and grain. Taste was nice raspberry with light bitter wheat to keep it balanced.

On draft at McGuire’s. Pours a hazy pink with a white head. Nose is light wheat, raspberry puree, and some light tartness. Flavor is similar with light berries and wheat. As for fruited wheats, this one will do fine. Light in body and ok overall.
Tap at the Destin brewpub. Light orange pour. Simple wheat beer with sweet raspberry in the aroma and taste. Easy drinker.

Tap. Pours clear light pink gold with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is raspberry, wheat malt and light earthy hops. Flavor is raspberry, wheat malt, light hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Light body and carbonation.
Tap. Pours clear pink amber with a medium creamy off-white head and good lacing. Aroma is all raspberry. Taste is wheat, raspberry and lemon with only light sweetness.
Surprisingly good raspberry wheat beer. It’s not overpowering or too sweet which is a plus.

2/3/11. On tap at the Destin location. Clear red pour with no head at all. Burnt charcoal aroma with wheat malt and corn. Sweet raspberry flavor with a hint of fresh sour raspberry and sweet wheat malt. The flavor really isn’t bad.

Draft in Destin post-PMR with the fam. Dark brown color with a tan ring. Nice aroma of sweet dark malt and a hint of chocolate. Pleasant flavor with a hint of earthy minerals, burnt malt and a touch of hops. Nice.

Rated based on notes taken 29 Dec 2013 -- Seasonal offering at the Destin establishment. This is a pretty decent Scotch ale, I would definitely drink more of. Lacks the extra caramel/toffee or peat or depth that would make this truly awesome.

On draft at McGuire’s. Pours a clear orange-brown with an off-white head. Nose is maple, some sweet malt, some light smoke, and some mild bitterness. Flavor follows: sweet malt, some light smoke, and a hint of earthy bitterness. I am ok with it; light to medium in body and lingering sweet malt and smoke in the finish.
Tap at the Destin brewpub. Clear golden pour with a small spotty white head. Peat and buttery sweetness in this. Maybe a bit of butterscotch.

Tap at the Pensacola establishment. Pours a moderately dark tan with minimal white head. Bourbon barrel aroma with notes of oak, butterscotch, and bready malt. Flavor has lots of sweet qualities (caramel, butterscotch) but is not very sweet itself. Smooth and well balanced. Quite a treat. A favorite of mine from McGuires.

The aroma is peaty with malt, yeast, and a touch of smoke. The appearance is mahogany with a medium sized sudsy head. The flavor is like the aroma with plenty of peat and a touch of butterscotch. The palate is average. Overall it’s an interesting beer and worth a try. It’s alright.

Tap FBGF. Pours dark brown with beige head, and nice golden lacing. Aroma got plenty of caramel malts and toffee light roastiness adds a small coffee touch to the aroma. Taste, roasted malts, lots of candi sugar, licorice, and a ton of of sweetness for an almost butterscotch/strong toffee palate. Liked this one a lot.
Draft at Florida Brewers Guild Beer Fest 2008. Full rating updated as soon as I am more coherent.

Draft at Destin location. Copper color in the glass with an off-white, creamy head that left some lacing. The aroma found malts, wood, and a hint of alcohol. The flavor was of barrel wood and fruits. Medium to full body with a slight warming feeling. A nice after dinner sipper.

Seasonal brew from McGuire’s in Destin. Nice deep mahogany color with an extremely small white lace head. Very pleasant aroma - Very malty with some brown sugar and coffee. Full bodied flavor - Light sweetness continues with more coffee and some dark chocolate notes. Finishes with a bitter "twinge" of hops. Very tasty stuff. If only I could bring some home with me! Cheers!
8/6/03: on tap in Destin. hazy pale yellow body. coriander, lemon and wheat nose and taste. clean, crisp and fresh.
Walnut wood color. Good mouthfeel, but a syrupy odor and mediciney sweet...
Really just a slightly hoppier version of their Irish ale. Average with a moderate hoppy bite.

Appearance: Medium golden. Slightly Hazy. Finger of white foam. Nose: Slight pine hops with a touch of herbal. Lightly malty. Taste: Faint herbal hops. Lightly roasted malt. Light bitters Body: fluid with soft carbonation. Parting thoughts: Very mild IPA. As if someone made an IPA for the middle of the road crowd.
Tap. Gold, slightly cloudy. Aroma and taste is typical weak American IPA. Didn’t really care for it.
Pours a medium amber. Floral hop aroma with some caramel malts. Flavor is citrusy, could use more hops.
On draft at the pub -- Pretty solid IPA. Not going to win many awards but it went amazing with my Burger. I’ll have another.
Had this poured from draft at McGuires in Pensacola. Golden and clear. White head. Bitter and citrus flavor. A little off in some way but overall enjoyable

1/21/14. On tap at the Destin location. Amber pour with a small khaki head. Plain aroma, grainy, very light fruitiness, virtually no hop. Hardly any bitterness in the flavor, mostly plain biscuity malts, caramel, and no hop character to be found. Very bland, unimpressive. Either they don’t know what an IPA is or they’re dumbing it down for the public. Either way, I shall scroll past from now on.

Date: 3/24/2010 Source:Other Sampler at the Destin Pub. Floral hop nose with moderate fruit notes. Clear golden with small white head. Very floral hop flavor with enough caramel to back. Medium body and mouth feel. Residual is a bit minerally with moderate residual bitterness.

Draft @ FBGBF ’010. Pours light copper with thin off white head. The aroma is vaguely sweet with a touch of caramel. The taste starts with a thin pulse of sweetness before a modest note of vague bitter hops sway themselves into grapefruit like acidity and then moving toward slight graininess. It ends pretty dry with a bit of hop resin and a touch of roast. Very drinkable and fairly refreshing.

I (Irish) PA @FBGBF-on tap–pours a dissipating white head and hazy gold color. Aroma is sweet medium malt, secondary spice/pine hops. Taste is spice/citrus-lemon/pine hops bite, secondary sweet medium malt.
Tap. Pours cloudy yellow with a medium white head and some lacing. Aroma is strong banana, wheat and a bit of lemon. Taste is the same, mildly sweet. Refreshing light hefe overall.

On tap at the Pensacola McGuire’s. Pours cloudy yellow with medium white head. Aroma and flavor are surprisingly rich of roasted malt that gives a nice background to the banana and wheat. This is a very good hefeweizen. I’d like to have more of this.
The best hefeweizen I have had to date. A citrus, wheat taste, cloudy, with a light sweetness, that has a good after taste. On tap in Pensacola,FL.

Faded yellow color. Minimal head. Had an overripe fruit aroma to it. Strong bannana cream pie flavor with a good bit of cereal flavor in the after taste. Suprisingly that works. Decent little hefe that isn’t watery like most of McGuires other beers. On draft at the Destin location.

Yet again I have to wonder why mcguires keeps there average offerings on the menu hen they have it within their means to make such quality seasonal brews. The hefeweizen was smoothly cloudy with a white head. Clean but not watery mouthfeel with a fruity and acidic taste. Stronger hoppiiness than most wheats. Great beer all around. Second only to mcguires millinium belgian as far as their offerings go.

Draught, pint glass. Has a fizzy, white head which is fairly lasting. Murky body is mostly orange. Clove and bananas dominate the aroma. Dought yeast. Wheaty, strawy malts. Really a great smelling yeast. Nice moderate citric acidity. Warm yeast and banana flavors throughout. Nice spicey kick to the finish. Banana flavors do turn bubblegum-ish after a while (in the after taste). Watery texture, medium body, lively carbonation. The bottom line is: this is a great hefe to try if you're ever in Pensacola or Destin.

I was told this was a pale ale, but apparently from the description on the webpage, this appears to be the ESB. Nice hop selection, seem to be goldings. I didn’t see the recipe on the chalk boards in the brewery section. I thought this could use a little more amber color. Still, this was my favorite of the five I tried tonight.

Draft. Very small tan head that mostly diminished, no lacing, no carbonation observed, transparent, and an orange hue. Nose was malty, caramel, hoppy, and crisp. Flavor was sweet, lightly bitter, malty, caramel, hoppy, citrus, and a hint of pine. Mouthfeel was smooth and light in body. Not super bitter tasting and IMO could use more bitterness to make it taste even better.

This draft brew from a beer festival poured a small sized head of foamy fine to medium sized white colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a transparent uncarbonated brown colored body. The mild aroma was malty sweet and nutmeg. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish with a mellow hoppy aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of malt hops and mild caramel. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Date: 09/01/1996 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clean amber, thick creamy head producing bealtiful lace, crisp hop aroma, great hop flavor (too much for an english esb, but tasty), great lasting bitter finish pale, munich, chocolate, cara pils, chinook, willimenette Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.5/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Sampled at Brewgrass Fest. This one had a beautiful creamy tan head and nice lacing (porbably partially due to the serving method...but I still liked it) on a really dark brown body. Aroma was of toasty malts. I had a hard time picking out much hops in the bouquet, but then again I also had a hard time getting upwind of all the damn smokers! I really enjoyed this beer, although for some reason it reminded me more of a scotch ale than an ESB.

Clear, bright copper with a dense, creamy head (nitro pour). Rich bready, toasty aroma. Notes of biscuit and black pepper at first, then a really "English" hop finish. Not bad - Sampled at the 2005 Asheville Brewer’s Jam.

12/19/13. On tap at the Destin location. Amber pour with a small khaki head. Spiced aroma and flavor... as you could have guessed. Some caramel and maltiness in there, with loads of nutmeg, cinnamon, allspice, et. al. Some citrus if you search for it. Could be worse, honestly. Not bad.
Draft: Poured a brown translucent with an off white colored head. Aroma is huge spices. Taste is very warming spices with lots of nutmeg.

On tap at the Pensacola location pouring up clear deep copper with thin white head. It has a big spicy aroma with notes of citrus, some sweet malts and faint dark fruity esters. The taste is predictably spicy winter spice additions of cinnamon, nutmeg, coriander and possibly all spice. The non spice notes are sweet crystal malts, some caramel malts and faint citrus hop flavor imparting a just noticeable hop bitterness.
Pours a hazy amber color with a light tan head. Has an aroma of cinnamon and honey with a flavor of ginger and nutmeg. Strong palate and great flavor

Draught into pint glass in Destin. Clear golden and amber hued colour. just a thin film on top. Aroma was a little spice and candied fruit. Flavour was light, slightly sweet with just a hint of spice. Almost oily mouthfeel. Pleasant beer.

Mcguire’s - Pensacola, FL Poured a clear golden color with a thin white head. The nose and flavor was pure christmas spice, orange and cloves reminiscent of a wassail. Mouthfeel was watery. Flavor was spicy with mild hops. No maltiness but the christmas aroma and flavor really feels festive. I’d drink it again, but only to get into the holiday spirit.
Orange hazy beer. Fruity, a bit dry beer with bitter finish................

Bottled. Orange colured and really cloudy with rich head. Fruity (apple & apricot) aroma. Malty and flowery, medium bodied and medium bitter. The very light mouthfeel makes it dangerously drinkable for a strong ale. Delicious!
Quite nice, peachy-brown colour with decent head. Hoppy and a bit malty aroma, malty first up, and then a hoppy finish, my only problem was the slight metallic finish, but otherwise pretty good.
It looks like the name were not complete when I got them at the bar. Anyway it was not so graspy but it gave me the feeling of more an ale than a Pilsner.
From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is grassy and light straw. Crisp grassy and bitter. Grassy and bitter into a dry finish.
Clear white yellow with a white cover. Aroma is sweet malt, corn. Taste is light corn, sweet, lightly grassy.
Pale yellow, slight head. On tap at brewpub. Cracker aroma with hay and grass hops. Flavor matches. Quite a nice brew.
Straw colour. Bright and sparkling. Straw-like pale malt nose with herbal hops underneath. Soft malt - nice bready character. Not much bitterness, but a pleasing herbal hop character.
Straw gold, lots of rising bubbles and a small white head. Fresh grain and lemony aroma. Medium carbonation but fizzy. Moderately sweet and has some lemon flavors with a dry finish.

On-tap at the park’s brewpub. Lots of lacing, fresh with creaminess in mouth. Above average carbonation as their entire product line. Decent effort. A mild amount of hops and probably best on a hot summer day.

Pours typical pale golden with non-existent head. Aroma of corn, grassy hops, pale malts. Way too sweet for the style, somewhat sticky, finished with noble hops. Not very palatable in large quantities.

Date: 03/05/2005 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear yellow, scant head, light hop aroma, light sweet malt flavor with a touch of fresh hops -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 10/27/2007 clear yellow, fine white head, lots of patterened lace, sweet grain aroma with light floral hops, rich sweet malt flavor, nice grainy character, light balancing bitterness, improving Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 9/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

Pours light golden with a fully receding off white head. Aroma is bready, with notes of diacetyl and herbal hoppiness. Taste is bready and yeasty but also hindered by diacetyl and acetaldehyde. Mouthfeel is meidum bodied with moderate carbonation. Easily drinkable, but this needs a more full boil and an extended diacetyl rest!

Pours a slightly odd goldish hue with a small head but an excellent carbonation, still bubbling as the glass empties. Carbonation complements an excellent malt mouthfeel, though there is a odd note to the aroma that detracts from the experience of the sip. The taste is a great balance of malt and hops, a much more true example of an American pale ale than many in the over-IPAed craft beer moment of today. While not an excellent beer, it is superb for a house brewed ale at a local restaurant.

Pint at the brewpub. This is a deep gold hue with a small white head. Aroma is grassy with wood undertones. The hops are pretty strong but have a British smell. Everything is balanced and pretty clean. The finish is pleasing, dryish.
Faint caramel malt and floral hop aroma... Flavor is overly watery, slight hint of caramel malts, very minimal bitter palate... The bud light of pales, too watery for my taste... Skip this one...
Gold pour with white head and lace. Aroma of light caramel. Paper, dry malt with a hint of bitter. Thin and watery with aggressive carbonation.
Light orange-yellow, sticky white cover. Lightly floral aroma, caramel. Taste is lightly metallic, caramel, floral hop bitterness.

Pale orange, just didn’t look quite right, little head. Lightly floral and citric nose, some caramel. Flavor is hoppy, mostly floral, with the faintest hint of infection present. Sediment floating happily in the bottom of the glass, almost like proteins. From a draft??? Disconcerting.

I made three visits to the tavern this month and each time have had the pale ale and it has been right on the money. True to style, with a very similar feel to what you can get in british pubs, albeit not cask. But the mouthfeel and carbonation is right, contrary to most US ales. In the past I have been disappointed with their ales but something has definitely improved here. I know they are brewing these cause I can smell it sometimes!

Comes out of the tap a clear golden amber - not remarkable, but at least appetizing. Malty aroma has some fruity and spicy hints. Solid flavor is mainly malty and surprisingly hoppy, and only mildly bitter. Texture is smooth, tingly, and satisfyingly sassy. Nothing spectacular, but worthy.

Hazy dark blonde. The aroma is fruity with some brett. There’s a definite infection, but mostly it’s brett, maybe a little pedio. At this point, it’s at a nice, happy level. A week later and this will probably be terrible. But at this particular moment, the infection is going well with the fruity hop character.

Hazy peach-orange color with small off-white head. Smells like Brett, and the bacteria blends well with the hops even though it is unintentional. Medium-high carbonation is prickly. Dry, thin finish. The hops almost come across as being those in a Belgian IPA because of the nuance added by the bacteria. An accidentally good brew.

On tap. It poured a golden color with a white head. The aroma was of malts, caramel, toast and hops. It tasted similar to the aroma with more malts, caramel, toast, hops with a nice aftertaste. Not bad.
Nice, somewhat bitter and quite ambe rin appearance. NOt so smooth but nice floral aroma.
From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild butterish, toasted malty. Light caramelish, butterish and toasted. Mild bitter to medium sweet finish.
Nothing special but definitely can enjoy sitting and sipping this amber, highlighted by a subdued sweet malt flavor complemented by hops.

Pint at the brewpub. Clear amber with a tiny head. This one smells sweet, lots of caramel and toffee hints. It’s a medium bodied ale with bunches of sticky malt flavor and a butterscotch finish. Hops are very mild. One glass is more than enough.

Only got this because the pale ale was bad and the ipa hasnt been on for months. Amber? It was really dark and I would have guessed it was a brown ale only I have had their brown ale and this isnt it. It was flat, and the taste was predominantly licorice. It only cost a dollar because it rained that day. Overpriced.
Dark red-brown, off white cover. Taste is apple, fruity, caramel. Aroma is malty, caramel, light citrus and fruit.

This one pours a dark, clear, slightly orangy amber. Rich aroma is malty, a little yeasty, and has hints of spices. Flavor is malty and quite yeasty with undertones of orange and caramel, and is slightly sweet and spicy. Hard, edgy, jazzy texture leaves a malty, yeasty and slightly sweet finish.
On-tap at the park’s brewpub. Aggressive carbonation, a bit of toasted malt, a moderate amber colour, some hops and a bit of creaminess and lace.

Date: March 05, 2005 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear amber Aroma: light sweet carmel malt aroma Body: light body Flavor: mild malt flavor well balanced with enough hops to keep it interesting, light bitter finish Date: October 27, 2007 Appearance: clear amber, fine beige head, specks of lace Aroma: light sweet caramel malt aroma Flavor: rich malt flavor, light bready character, touch of caramel sweetness, well balanced light, earthy hops Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4

On tap at the brewpub for lawschool prom. Nice color and head. Cocoa aroma and roasted coffee malt flavors. Pretty decent porter with a lot more flavor than many I have had recently. A little overpowering with the roasted malt but decent drink nonetheless.

Appearance: Near black body with reddish edges and capped by a small, off-white head. Smell: Mild aroma of unsweetened chocolate and sweaty dark grains. Taste: Dark malts with some hints of semi-sweet chocolate. Herbal hops. Earthy bitterness at the tailend. Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Mild carbonation. Creamy mouthfeel. Drinkability: Well, I’m sold. A decent porter.

Fresh batch just tapped. The rating is of the second sample, as the first one was poured into an appropriate but soapy tasting glass. Choclate and coffee nose. Dark brown with soapy mocha head and good lacing. Better as warmed to room temperature from the cellar. A lively carbonation. Creamy bove-average mouthfeel. A bit like an imperial porter.
Cask Ale tasting at Sweetwater. Very nice porter with great malty taste and finishing "snick" of bitterness. I would have this one again
Atlanta Cask Ale tasting at Sweetwater. Aroma of chocolate. Taste is very malty with plenty of chocolate. Finish is bitter. Mouthfeel is nice and creamy. Good roastey porter.

Date: 09/05/1996 Source: Brewpub very dark amber, headless, roasted chocolate aroma with a hint of hops, tasty chocolate flavor with hints of roastiness, dryy finish -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 03/05/2005 Words: Draft Words: Brewpub dark brown, scant head, sweet malt aroma with a hint of butterscotch, rich malt flavor with a sweet edge, good chocolate character, little to no bitterness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Robust Porter Date: 01/27/2007 Mode: Firkin Source: Brewfest, Atlanta Cask dark with ruby edges, frothy tan head, sweet milk chocolate aroma, lots of rich sweet chocolate flavor, almost enough bitterness to balance, caramel and butterscotch sweetness, right or wrong I still like chocolate and butterscotch as a combination, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4

On cask at the 1/27/07 Atlanta Cask Ale Tasting listed as Robust Porter: Pours a barely transparent dark mahogany with an airy coating of dark tan bubbles. Aroma of lightly sweet earthy malt with a touch of dark chocolate. Body starts fairly sweet and caramely malty with a touch of black cherries before a toasty dark malty finish. A nice porter.

Pours black with a mostly receding tan head. Aroma of roast malt: predominantly chocolate but ventures towards coffee and spice. Taste is lightly sweet, with notes of chocolate and crystal malt. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with moderate. Enjoyable, the best beer I had at my recent visit.
This dark brown beer seems to be struggling a bit. It’s thin in flavor, but sugary. It may have some quality control issues much like the beers at Park Tavern the last time I visited.
Best beer by far from these guys. Deep brown color with good head. Chocolate malt flavor and it stayed with me. Nice caramel hint as well. Good beer not the best porter but a good one.
Don’t quite remember this one but it was tasty & easy on the palate. Good stuff!

On draft at Max Lagers in downtown Atlanta. Pours light brownish red with no head. Aroma of some Belgian funk and something I don’t recognize. Flavor is a bit weird, with some cough syrup flavors, maybe some spice, and a little bit of yeast. Lighter bodied with plus carbonation. This was the only real miss for me on my visit.

growler. clear copper with no head. malty, brown sugar, caramel, coins aroma. caramel, fruity esters, banana, belgian yeast flavors. mild to moderate sweetness, sort-of dry finish, medium body. lightly warming.

On tap at the brewpub. Handsome pour, gleaming deep brown with moderate carbonation and nice sticky lacing. It’s a pretty game effort at a dubbel. Soft and inviting nose. Not exactly obvious that there’s Trappist yeast involved, but the aroma is still a nice blend of nutty malts, caramel, and esters. Body is a bit on the thin side, slightly slick in the finish. But it tastes nice, on point even if not "wow."

Beautiful brownish, amber pour, thin head. Moderate dark fruit aroma. Flavors were similar, dark fruits, candied sugar, some cloves and the obvious yeastiness. The big knock was that it was undercarbonated, to put it kindly (it was flat). Still, not bad and avoids the pitfalls of many american attempts (candied sugar bombs). Worth trying.

Tap. Amber color, white head. Aroma of buttered popcorn. .. Not a Good sign. Flavor is very sweet. Finishes with a lot of cinnamon, for a beer. It has an old (A.B.C.) Big Red not to it. Medium bodied.
Lightly hazy amber, decent head. Aroma was caramel and clove accented Belgian yeast. Flavor essentially matched. A bit off from a true dubbel, but not a bad belgianish beer.
Red-orange, off white head. Aroma is sweet, sugar, little else. Taste is sweet candy sugar, fruity esters, light clove, alcohol.

Appearance: Clear, amber-golden body with a thin, short-lived, white head. Already, the widespread carbonation problem, which has plagued the other pints I’ve tried, seems to be present here, too. What gives?! Smell: Spicy and sweet on the nose with a notable bready character and fruity notes of golden raisins and semi-ripened apricots.
