Taste: Bready, lightly toasty maltiness lightly brushed with sweet caramel. Moderate amount of sweetness throughout. Background hint of finely-ground spices. Light fruitiness splashed with honey liqueur. Max Abbey has a warming finish that’s a tad on the sweet side. Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Lightly carbonated. Touch of stickiness to the mouthfeel, no doubt facilitated by the sheer lack of effervescence. Drinkability: A decent abbey ale, but, like Max Lager’s other beers, seems to be hampered by a surprising lack of carbonation. Which, don’t get me wrong, I’m not a proponent of highly carbonated beers with all their ghastly tongue-prickling fizziness, but that doesn’t mean flat is the way to go.

Color is a beautiful dark honey-golden, cloudy and opaque, with a decent white head. Aroma is strong, malty, with fruity undertones. Flavor is rich, mainly malty with a touch of apple, and just a whisper of hoppy bitterness. Velvety smooth and mouth-filling, this is a beer to sip and appreciate.
Golden color, little foam, a bit hoppy aroma, but also metallic. Has a mildly sweet malty taste. A good drinkable average beer.

Can at Rossatzbach camping. Straight from the can, so appearance score is random. Nose is nonexistent, light maltyness maybe. Taste is low sweetness, no bitternes at all, only in the aftertaste. Low carbonation. Not a very good beer with a very good background.

Clear straw yellow, tall soapy head. Average retention. Aroma: grains, straw, distant dusty hop. Light to medium body. Lively carbonation. Taste: grains, bread, light minerals, hop. Light bitterness. Mediocre.
0.5l can. Pours clear golden with a medium foam. Aroma of malts and grass. Taste of malts, corn, cardboard. Medium carbonation. Light bitter aftertaste
Uit blik. Ruikt zoet mout. Smaakt zoetig, mout. Weinig hop. Doorsnee pilsner.
Clear golden pour with a fine head. Ok lacing. Ok bitternes. Crisp. Usual malty and herbal flavor. [Can from Merkur Hoher Markt in Vienna, Austria]
06.02.2019. 0,5l Can. Grassy hops. Light grassy hops. Medium body. Nuce freshness. Busstrip fron Munich to Val Gardena.

Das Schwechater Bier kommt von einer der größen Brauereien des Landes und hat schon eine lange Tradition. Das heißt noch lange nicht, dass es gut ist. Es ist ein typisches Industriebier im unterern Preissegment. Daher war und ist es bei den unteren Bevölkerungsschichten und den Obdachlosen Wiens sehr beliebt. Geschmacklich gibt es nicht viel her, aber es reicht, um sich zu betrinken.
500ml can Golden pour with decent white head. Solvent/grain aroma. Clean, sweet grainy taste. Standard Euro lager.
0,5l can. Lagerish golden appearance with strong white head. Sweet aromas like apple and malty flavours and a bit metallic as in the end. Highly carbonated. Not my style too sweet for me.

Clear golden color with thick lasting off-white head. Aroma has citrus, spices, yeast and fruits. Taste is malty sweet with long somewhat bitter aftertaste. Flavors of citrus, yeast, sweet fruity notes and caramel.

330ml bottle. Hazy, orangey, bright golden colour with average to huge, thick, firm, creamy, moderately lasting and lacing, white head. Sweet-ish muesli aroma, notes of yellow stone fruit, dried yellow stone fruit, a cereal touch, predominating apricot flavours. Taste is slightly dry hoppy, yeasty fruity, minimally grainy malty with a muesli / cereal touch, hints of yellow stone fruit, especially apricot, a touch of mandarine; well hidden alcohol, slightly prickly carbonation. Good.

30 April 2019. At Dirk's First Home-made Beer Tasting. Cheers to all! Pours clear golden with a lasting, thick, frothy, white head. Aroma of pineapple, apple peel, yeast, grass, herbs, perfume, clove. Taste is medium fruity sweet, notes of apple & pineapple with perfumey & honeyish touches, bready & yeasty character, spicy bitter clove & grass leading to a dryish, earthy hoppy finish where yeast, spices, perfume & warming gin-like alcohol linger. Medium body, creamy texture, fizzy carbonation. Agreeable in all aspects.
(levure-malt-hop, onctuo-ronde, petites épices, ampleur du malt, bien rafraîchissante, bonne triple en général, sucre nickel)
Blond or sombre, légèrement trouble. Mousse très abondante. Nez de levure et d'alcool. En bouche, gros malt et levure. L'alcool se sent. Fait penser à une chouffe en un peu plus complexe.

33cl-fles. Wazig goudblond bier met wand klevende witte schuimkraag. Geur: licht moutzoetig, ietwat gistkarakter, licht kruidig, licht fruitig, zoete appel . Smaak: moutzoetig, licht kruidig, licht fruitig, zoete appel, ietwat hopbitterheid, lichte oxidatie. Redelijk volmondig. Medium koolzuurprikkel. Afdronk: lichte hopbitterheid, ietwat droog.
33cl Bottle @ Saveur-Biere, Lille, France. Hazy golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma is malt, yeast, spices, fruits. Taste follows the aroma. Medium body, average carbonation.

A golden beer, a head is big and blond. Aroma has fruitness of perry, spicyness. Simple but good aroma. Taste has fruitness, perry, some sweetness of honey and peppery spicyness. Medium bodied, high carbonation. Basic and succesfully brewing, good beer.
33 cl. bottle. A hazy yellow coloured beer with a white head. Aroma and flavour of yeast, malt, spice, hops, bread, fruit and with a dry finish.
Bitterzoete blonde tripel met rijkelijke schuimkraag. Vrij zoet, doch ook een bitterheid door de citrustoetsen. Beetje mout, lichte kruiding. Niet slecht.
Soapy aroma. Malty, neutral taste. Slight bitter finish. Hint of fruitiness (apple). Bit thin. Bit disappointing after the good pilsener from this brewery.
Gebaseerd op Middeleeuwse gruit. Geen idee wat dat is, maar het smaakt heel zacht, het proeft eerder als een licht biertje dan wel het 7,5 ° als op het flesje staat.
Mętne, bez zapachu. Smak ziołowy, trochę medyczny. Goryczki brak ale ziołowość całkiem dobrze ja zastępuje
Lekker bier, tripelachtig. Licht bittertje, wat zuidvruchten en graan en gist. Schuimlaagje blijft aanwezig.
Fles 33cl thuis. Gagel, zoeten, drogig, kruidig, ook zacht, bloemig. Redelijk complex. (4-2015).
Bottle at pandekagehuset, kvie sø. Aroma of malty hay, citrus hops, Yeasty notes. Light sweet and bitter. Light and Waters.
Bottle. It pours hazy golden with a creamy white head. The aroma is spicy and herbal with malty notes. The flavor is malty with herbal notes. Refreshing.
A small taste from wiosna (bottle) @ One Pint Pub. Pours cloudy golden with a low head. Aroma is slightly herbal malts. Flavor is slightly herbal malts with some hops. Decent.
Bottle from Ekoplaza. Clear golden with thick white head. Moderate carb. Earthy nose with strong planty palate. Some honey notes and spicy-bitterness aftertaste. Differ'nt

Bottle @ No5, DØE tasting. Clear pale yellow with a large white head. Aroma light to medium bog myrtle, herbs, spices. Flavor medium sweet, bog myrtle, herbs, spices, ending bitter. Medium body, lively carbonated.

33cl flesje via Mans, Margraten Alcoholpercentage van 7,5% Uitgeschonken in Leffe glas Uiterlijk: goudoranje met volle witte schuimkraag Aroma en smaak: neus is citrusschil, smaak is kruidig van de gagel, richting anijs licht, bittertje Conclusie: apart, niet verkeerd

330ml bottle. Slightly hazy pale amber, effervescent bubbles and a foamy white head. Flavors are yeast, pear, orange and coriander with spicy notes. Light to medium body, lively carbonation, slick texture.
Яркий и вдохновляющий поначалу аромат, затем начинает приносить мыльные нотки. Пиво хорошее, но кроме аромата особенностей нет.
Bottle. Cloudy yellow pour, with a large white head. Bread, yeast, biscuit, wheat, hay, light, spice.
Flaska på La Trappiste, Brugge. Disig ljusorange med vitt skum. Jäst, vete, honung, parfym, koriander. Lätt.
Troebel goudgeel bier met ruime witte schuimkraag. Goed gebalanceerd: niet bitter noch zoet. Prima alternatief voor een pils

W zapachu przyprawowość, pomarańcze i brzoskwinie. Czyli Belgia pełną gębą. W smaku tez przyprawy, białe dojrzałe winogrona, brzoskwinia i słaba pomarańcza, dość wytrawne, lekko goryczkowe, pijalne i smaczne.

Barwa złota, klarowne, piana biała, dość obfita, dość trwała. W aromacie słodowe, białe winogrono, chlebowe. W smaku półwytrawne, sporo nut soku z białych winogron, trochę chlebowości, mało estrów. Goryczka niska, wysycenie do średniego, ciała nieco brakuje. Nieco monotonne, szału nie ma.
de doordrinker (bier van de paters) van Chimay, een lichte versie met het alcoholpercentage van een pils, fris, licht

Belle bière dorée et trouble. Un nez très fleuri avec j'oserai dire une note de miel. Elle est beaucoup plus légère en bouche qu'au nez et les céréales y prennent la place des fleurs. Avec ses 4,8% et ça légèreté en bouche c'est bien le genre de bière que je prendrai en terrasse.
330ml bottle. Pours slightly hazy dull gold with a large head. Aroma is dusty, yeasty lemon and straw. Taste is yeasty, grainy, spicy lemon. Gassy straw.

Bue à la pression. Couleur dorée légèrement cuivrée et un peu voilée. Mousse faiblarde. Nez un peu sur le miel. Plutôt ronde en bouche, là encore avec des notes de miel, mais finale plutôt métallique. Carbo assez forte, faible amertume. Avec le temps ça vire davantage sur les grains et ça devient plutôt aqueux. Donc oui mais non...
Sampled at the brewery. Deep corn colored gold with a little white foam. Very clean and easy to drink. Malt forward with a hint of hops. Sulfur and gentle fruit. Nice beer. Citrus after taste.

Draught @ Magnolia Pub and Brewery, SF. Pours golden with an offwhite head. Aroma of malt, little grain, grass. Flavor is light sweet, malt, grain, grass, light fruity. Medium body, average to lively carbonation. 180718
Clear amber color with a thin head. Aromas of caramel and pear. Flavor is kind of bland. Could be better.
On tap at Gabf. Pours a hazy orange gold with small white head that lasts. The aroma is grass and yeast. Thin body, earth, grass, light citrus, decent.

From tap at Magnolia, San Francisco. Aroma is nicely grainy with bready and biscuity malt notes, including some hay and a hint of grassy/floral hops. Flavour is light sweet and bitter. Body is medium. Very likeable Kölsh, nailed it.
The second of two Kolsch’s tonight. Tastes just about the same as the last one.
Tasty Kölsch brewed in America. Smooth and creamy with cautious hopping. Very refreshing.
Much too bitter for a kolsch. Probably not true to style. A decent beer, but some slight astringency creeping. Magnolia SF.
@CBF Straw yellow Surprised at the low scores as this was a surprisingly well put together and refreshing kolsch (had a couple of those, as well as a couple average ones).

On tap @ "Al Gambero", Palmanova (UD), Italy. Hazy amber body with an average, frothy, tan head, mostly diminishing with some lacing, though. Moderate malty (caramel, bread) and light-to-moderate hoppy (citrus) aroma with some fruity notes. Moderate sweet and light bitter flavour; long-lasting sweet finish with notes of bread. Light-to-medium body with watery-to-oily texture; soft carbonation.

16 oz swingtop bottle 4/00-Pours a medium golden with a nice white head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Taste of sweetness, wheat, and caramel. This light to medium bodied brew was not my cup of tea but still rather tasty.

My username reflects my undying devotion to this most interesting creation. Like a beautiful woman hiding behind cats eye glasses. The glasses (appearance)are interesting but are masking the real beauty. The light haze draws you into a complex palate that starts smooth and slightly sweet but finishes pleasantly dry and clean. Its true beauty is the sum of it parts. Enjoy. My regret is that access is limited.
Nice light color good aroma. Somewhat metallic tasting. Not terribly good lasting flavor. Finishes a bit sharp. Disappointing.

Interesting surprise packgage from Davhgbrew and I had no idea what to expect. Looks like a Krystall or Kolsch, smells like a Bock, finishes like a Pilsner. Light straw color, slight wheat haze, weak head. Fruity malt aroma, a little winey. A little fizz on the palate, but pretty smooth verging on syrupy. Sweet full maltiness, (agree with honey below) but crispens a little mid-palate, finishing with a nice dryness. Works well as the sweeter front does linger through striking a fine balance with the the drier finish. Still not sure of the style but not a bad brew.

Strong malty aroma, cloudy yellow appearance, little to no head retention. Palate is smooth and creamy. It has an almost candylike sweetness which is not too sweet. The middle is a little watery and it finishes kind of like a Michaelob with honey in it. NOt a great beer, but an interesting find nontheless.

A light brown color with a moderate tan head. Aroma of biscuit and munich malt, very alt characteristic. Feel and flavor of wheat. Flavor mostly nutty. Fairly light bodied. Nothing to special but very drinkable.

Mix of lager beer and white sweet wine. Light muscatel aroma, predominant sweet taste, balanced by some beer dryness in the palate; very poor beer characteristics. The production has been discontinued, and the bottles withdrawn from the market when the French Champagne organization complained for the improper use of the name. Beers of Switzerland

Pivo u flaši. Kupljeno u Hoppiness dućanu u Kopru. Najbolje kotirani Imperial Stout ns Rate Beeru do sada koji sam uspio nabaviti.... pa da vidimo šta je to za jedan vrhunski Imp. Stout... Fina aroma kave , čokolade i lješnjaka koja se osjeti na metar od čaše... Tijelo je nešto tanje , ali to sam već naučio od ovih nekoliko američkih primjeraka koje sam probao do sada... Moj je zaključak za sada da ameri očito rade tanja tijela od evropljana , šta ne mora značiti da je to lošije , jer se takva piva lakše piju.. Okus je ko i aroma , i naročito mi se sviđa taj miris "bajadere" koji ide u nos kad ga promućkaš u ustima.. I tako... nije to najbolji Imperial Flavored Stout koji sam probao , ali je sasvim pristojan , i takvu sam mu dao i ocjenu..

Aromat: czekolada, kawa i likier w tym klimacie, przyjemny nienachalny alkohol, sos sojowy, trufle, trochę spalenizny popiołu; Wygląd: ładna ale szybko redukująca się piana, brunatne klarowne; Smak: mocna kawa, paloność, gorzka czekolada, wytrawne, goryczka czekoladowa długa przyjemna, długie przyjemne posmaki gorzkiej czekolady; Podniebienie: ciało średnie, gładkie, nisko nasycone;

Tap at Hopa. Oily black pour, beige head. Nose is big booze, coffee, roasted malts, molasses. Taste is thick sweet notes of booze, malts, chocolate, a touch of coffee. Medium to heavy body, soft carbonation. Very nice with a superb balance but somehow I expected somewhat more.

Pours an opaque midnight brown with a nice thick tan head. Roasted malt and coffee aroma. Taste is sweet roasted malt, molasses, coffee, and some mild bitterness near the end from the roasted grains. Some alcohol warmth after the swallow, but not in the taste. Excellent impy stout!
An american, black, Imperial Coffee Stout with low brown head. Aroma is coffee, prune, light chocolate, light liqourice, light caramel, light hazel nuts. Taste is bitter and light sweet.
Black with off white head. Coffee and malt aroma. Malty body with a taste that takes over your mouth. Long lasting finish

Aroma of coffee, chocolate, caramel, nuts, wood, dried fruits, liquorice and a hint of soy sauce. Black with a tan head. Medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter. Full body with average carbonation. Dry and bitter finish. Overall a very nice Imperial Stout. A Well balanced, warming and creamy brew.
Wspomnienia z degustacji podczas epickiego panelu który odbył się 14.09.2019 r. :)

Oily black with thin white head. Aroma rich with coffee and chocolate. Taste is a delicious blend of coffee, chocolate, hints of liquorice, underlying alcohol. Smooth mouthfeel, makes this deliciously drinkable. Excellent.

Aroma: Dark chocolate, strong coffee, licorice and malt Appearance: Black color with a small brown head Taste: Moderate sweet and bitter, strong coffee, licorice, chocolate ending in a light alcoholic finish Mouthfeel: Creamy texture with soft carbonation Overall: A masterpiece from AleSmith Brewing Company ;)

column1: Town Hall Bright Spot Golden Ale
column5: On tap at Town Hall. Pours a mostly translucent golden with a medium creamy white head that left lacing. Aroma of malty sweetness, orange zest, grassy, floral, ginger and tea. Flavor was a mix of the same. The hops were giving off some interesting spicy notes...ginger and a few other ingredients used in Chinese food.

column1: Town Hall Bright Spot Golden Ale
column5: On draught at the brewpub near downtown Minneapolis, Minnesota. Pours a clear golden pale blonde brew with an average white head that slowly dissipates to a fine film and white ring, with some nice lacing Aroma of golden grain malt, some citrus zest, grassy hops and a touch of lemon. Taste is light to medium bodied, lightly carbonated, crisp clean cut with some golden grain malt and grassy hop flavors. Finish is semi-dry, mild bitterness with a crisp citrus zest aftertaste that quickly disappears.

column1: Town Hall Bright Spot Golden Ale
column5: Draft @ Brewpub. Golden pour with a white head. Aroma of earthy, grassy hops, pale malt. and light lemon. Flavors of lemon/lemon zest, grassy hops, and pale malt. Light body bitter/dry finish.

column1: Town Hall Bright Spot Golden Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub on 6/22/07: Pours a clear bright golden with a small frothy, well-lacing white head. Aroma of lightly sweet pale malt and earthy noble hops. Body starts lightly pale malty sweet with a decent earthy noble hoppy bitterness toward a thinner, drier bittersweet finish. A ok golden ale.

column1: Town Hall Bright Spot Golden Ale
column5: Draft @ Brewpub: Pale yellow, light head and lacing. Nose of nice pale malt and clean, grassy hops. Subtle metal. The flavor has a nice body and a malty finish. Citrusy, clean. Ok.

column1: Town Hall Bright Spot Golden Ale
column5: Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear yellow, dense white head, lots of lace, light sweet malt aroma, sweet malt flavor, touch of corn sweetness, light bitterness Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 7/20 Rating: 1.9/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *+/4

column1: Town Hall Bright Spot Golden Ale
column5: Draft on 8/2/07. Clear amber/yellow. Light malt sweetness with some fruit (apricot and pear). Grassy hops make the finish bitter. Not too bad on a hot summer day.

column1: Town Hall Bright Spot Golden Ale
column5: (Draft) Pours a clear pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma of soap and grain. Flavor of sweet malt and hops.

column1: Town Hall Bright Spot Golden Ale
column5: On tap RBSG. A clean golden pour wth a thick white lacing and light head. A flavor that is malty but changes to a bit of a papery flavor and a tad of hop bitter at the finish. An aroma of light malt, corn. Nothing bad on the nose just not much there. The palate was all you could expect from the style. It was crisp and clean but a tad fizzy. Very good offering for the style.

column1: Town Hall Bright Spot Golden Ale
column5: Out of a sampler at the pub during 07 RBSG. Pale straw gold color with a thin white head and a light nose with some citrus. This is a light, crispy beer with light caramel sweetness and some grassy hops in the finish. Inoffensive golden ale.
It was as if they mixed their bitter and IPA together. It was difficult to finish even the sample.

Draught at the brewery. Pours brilliantly clear golden orange with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with excellent lacing. Aroma is moderate rich bready, grainy and lightly caramelized malt with light earthy hops. Flavor is moderate rich grainy and bready malt, light alcohol notes, light earthy hops and bitterness with a medium sweet finish. Medium-full body and medium carbonation.

Minnesota Trip Beer #2. Keg at the brewpub, 5/7/16. Clear dark amber, thin fizzy off-white head, good retention. Aroma of caramel, toasted malts, noble hops. The taste is toasted malts, caramel, raisin, bits of cherry, noble hops. Medium bodied, refreshing, well balanced.

Keg @ Town Hall. Deep golden pour with a small white head. Aroma of fresh baked bread. Caramel-dipped Apple. Light grassy hop. Flavor is nicely balanced. Sweet, somewhat nutty malt. Caramel. Mild pepper hoppy bite on the finish. Somewhat chewy. Easy drinking. Strong carb. Solid.
Super light gold brew that doesn’t have much character on the nose other than grains and some straw but a clean bacon-y smoke come in the flavor. Almost rauch beer esk... Strange but tasty!

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear gold with a white head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has a lot of earthy grains and a bit of caramel as well as a bit of dirt. Flavor has sweet grain with a touch of caramel and a surprising bit of smoke.
Caramel notes with a fairly solid malty backbone. Light body with mild carbonation. Pretty decent overall!
Tap at Town Hall. Clear rich yellow pour wih a clingy white head. Caramel malt nose and taste. Floral elements present as well. Good brew.
Had a rather feint spice scent, rather light taste, smooth pleasant bitter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Growler. Clear light amber colored pour, plenty of continuous carbonation and a thick lasting head with an aroma of sweet malt & honey. Flavor is bready malt, more sweet honey, slightly vegetal and finished with a little noticeable alcohol. Enjoyable Maibock.
Pours orange/amber with white head, aroma is fruit, biscuit, and some caramel. Slight hoppy start biscuity middle and a slightly dry malty finish. Not too bad, really tasty and still drinkable.
Growler. Dark brown pour, thin carbonation and an aroma of light chocolate. Flavor is light peaty chocolate, slight hints of soy & smoke and finished with a bit more bittersweet chocolate.

Sampled at an esbls tasting. At 4 Hands. From a growler. Almost black but with red. A nice long lasting tan head. This is ashand just a bit thin. Chocolate is a sub note. A nice beer. Glad I got to try it.
Tap at the brewery. Garnet color with beige head. Not as dark as I would expect a porter to be. Sweet maltiness with barely any roast flavor. Would be better labeled as a brown ale than a porter.

At brewpub: Pours a medium depth brown, much lighter than expected, with a modest tan head. Mild aroma is roasty and sweet. Flavor is heavily roasted chocolate malt, vanilla, and caramel. Some seemingly artificial sweetness. A little on the thin side. I have much higher expectations for their brews by now.
Tap. Dark cola colored pour with a slightly off-white head. Aroma of nut and mild chocolate. Thin body. Taste is fig, muted chocolate, and some funk. Just okay.
Pours dark brown with tan head, aroma is chocolate and a bit of roasted character. Taste is chocolate and roasted notes throughout, a bit watery and thin but well balanced.

Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Slight aromas of chocalate, sweet roasted grain. Light taste of the same with a touch of coffee, with a touch of astringency. A little light and watery on the pallete, but ok overall.

Growler: pours a steady brown to settle nearly black and stays black. A very tawny deep chestnut can be detected up to a strong light. Capping is medium in stature with a nice sandy brown evenly foamed froth. Eventually slips away to a ghostly skim and a thin collar. Some spotty lace with a few tiny strands are flung about and sticking to the glass. Aroma is light and sweet with a fair amount of cocoa and a smidgeon of roasted malt and a tiny note of grain husk dryness. Flavors are mild and set in tone with a moderate base of easy going, smooth cocoa sweetness. Touches a bit of roasted malt and a sliver of coffee noting the finish as it flecks at the hint of char and burnt toast even later. Light to medium body, smooth and fairly slick with a budge just past the middle area bringing in a brief build up on the palate as it tenderizes the flavors a bit and floats off the finish with a ever so faint and lovely cocoa dryness. A pretty decent porter. A subtle delight of a beer. Perhaps not a stand out in impactful punch in flavor as some of the other mighty brews that have graced the taps of Town Hall. But if you don’t mind a simple, subtle little sit down porter. This will suit you just fine.

Dark Brown with Red Hues and Tan Head. Subtle Malt Aroma. Sweet Malt...Followed by a Toasted Nutty Flavor and Dry Aftertate. Starts off Sweet and Thin Bodied...Nutty Flavors Come Out and Leave with a Dry Finish.

Dark brown with quarter inch head. Aroma is chocolate, which comes out immediately in the flavor, too. Some hazelnut like flavor as well, with a slightly tart, well balanced finish. I wish the alcohol was 1% lower, I’d drink five or six of them at a time. I think there are some people rating different beers here from a couple of years ago.

column1: Great Waters Golden Prairie Blond Ale
column5: Minnesota Trip Beer #69. Keg at the brewpub, 5/9/16. Golden colored, large creamy white head, good retention. Aroma of doughy malt,mild floral and citrus notes. The taste is citrus hops and bready malt.

column1: Great Waters Golden Prairie Blond Ale
column5: Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a near clear light gold with a white head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has a light bread note with a bit of straw and a hint of grass. Flavor is full of bread and straw with a hint of biscuit underlying.

column1: Great Waters Golden Prairie Blond Ale
column5: Good blond ale at the brewpub during a Pedal Pub ride. Light and crisp but really nothing too special. Good to chug.

column1: Great Waters Golden Prairie Blond Ale
column5: Date: November 5, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Great Waters Translucent golden, grainy, drinkable just not much to it.

column1: Great Waters Golden Prairie Blond Ale
column5: Tap. Light orange pour with minimal head. Nice mild biscuit and grain nose. Lighter palate. Taste is grain with some slightly sweet malts. Pretty nice.

column1: Great Waters Golden Prairie Blond Ale
column5: On tap @ Great Waters. Light yellow appearance with a pearl white head. Clean golden ale nose that’s fairly grainy. Grainy, bland golden ale flavor.

column1: Great Waters Golden Prairie Blond Ale
column5: Sampled via growler pour thanks to Doug H at the 29th Annual ABA Meeting in Bloomington, MN. Pours a clear golden yellow pale colored brew with a thin off-white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of golden grain malt, some citrus and lemon zest hops, plus some grassy hops. Taste is light bodied, with flavors of golden grain malt, grassy hops and a hint of lemon. Finish is light, clean cut with a crisp aftertaste. Bring on the summer sessions!

column1: Great Waters Golden Prairie Blond Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub on 05/31/2009. Very clear golden body with a medium creamy off-white head. Sweet honey, pilsener malt and light grain aroma. Sweet honey flavor, some grainess with a bit of pilsener malt and a light grassy hop hint. Very clean. Medium light body with moderately high carbonation.

column1: Great Waters Golden Prairie Blond Ale
column5: Draft @ Brewpub: Clear yellow, light white head and lacing. Nose of light husky malt, some light lemon and faint hops. Malty flavor, thin mouthfeel and a dry dusty finish. Lotion and lemon in the tail. Ok.

column1: Great Waters Golden Prairie Blond Ale
column5: Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub pale yellow, fine white head, lots of spidery lace, light sweet malt aroma, sweet malt flavor, lots of corn sweetness, light bitterness but it’s the sweetness that lingers into the finish, Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 6/20 Rating: 1.8/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: */4

Pours slightly hazy golden amber color with a couple inches of white foam. Good lacing. Mild sweet malt in the aroma. Light honeymalt flavor with a medium floral hop finish. Mellow, light body, smooth drinking, and very softly carbonated.

Cask. Semi-translucent and lovely nectary orange in color with a grey glacial sheaf topping it off. Aroma is well derived from chestnuts, mild marmalade mixed with light molasses and brown sugar, ginger chews rolled in amber rock candi, and a rustic, edible dust at the cuffs. Delicate flavor pulls with a spruce accented bitterness, transitioning to an orange toffee crème body. Supple carbonation gives a mild life to the light cocoa, hazelnut and caramel-like concoction. Moderate orange candied grahams make for a medium-bodied simplicity, but it’s fairly well done. Caramelized willow wheat plucked from the fields is met with a mild English hop bitterness for a charmingly clean finish.

Terribly bland, timid and BORING. No head, no bitterness, no substantial mouthfeel that I can remember and again, that watered down texture. But I did taste that strong floral hoppiness that I find in almost everyone of their beers.
Clear copper. Fruity, citric nose, no real hops. Flavor is a bit woody and nutty, some lemon. Toasty at the end. Could use some more depth.

In the cask at the Brewpub. ABSOLUTELY BEAUTIFUL POUR!!! Gorgeous golden-colored cascading ripples undulate down to the bottom of the pint glass. Truly a spectacular site to see this in yellow. Caramel aroma. Smooth palate. Rich complex tasting beer with lots of esters. The bitterness is flavorful and mild. The tongue coating from this is delightful.
faint aroma (barely) of floral hops and light grains. No taste on front of palate. Creamy mouthfeel, long sweet quiet finish. Good with food.

Clear, light amber color, substantial white head. Amiable aroma, light, slightly hoppy. Taste: sweetish, smooth, perfectly tasty, mild, but not without it’s rewards. Slight fruitiness, little bitterness, a quite adequate ESB, an able take on the style. A medium body, crisp finish. Nice drinkability, a good session brew. When you need a solid, if unchallenging brew at the pub, this one will do.

Cask sample. Clear dark honey, with sour berries and wet grass dominating the nose. Honey’d, slightly alcoholic (surprising but gratifying in this case) mild flavor, moderately sweet; light hops late, apple juice with pepper. Interesting bitter.
Amber Coloring. No Head. Hops...not very flavorful....expecting more punch...or ’bitter’ ...pretty watery on the flavor end.
Cask. Dark gold with zero head. A little bit of hops on the nose and taste. Very little bitter taste to it. Seemed pretty bland to me.

column1: Great Waters Saint Peter Pale Ale
column5: Amber with minimal head. Malty rye aroma. Taste - like a hoppy amber ale. Caramel malt and spicy green hops. Well balanced. Pretty good. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Great Waters Saint Peter Pale Ale
column5: Minnesota Trip Beer #74. Keg at the brewpub, 5/9/16. Hazy golden, large creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of lemony hop and pale malt. The taste matches. Medium bodied.

column1: Great Waters Saint Peter Pale Ale
column5: Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear orange gold with a white head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has notes of earthy grass and earthy grain with hints of pine and citrus. Flavor ha earthy grains and bitter citrus with a hint of pine and an earthy grain backbone.

column1: Great Waters Saint Peter Pale Ale
column5: Tap at brewpub pours a copper/orange with s medium khaki head. Sweet caramel and toffee aroma with some berry. Sweet malt with a pleasent drying hop. Not bad, drinkable.

column1: Great Waters Saint Peter Pale Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Standard visuals for an EPA, perhaps a bit darker than some. This is tasty, but drinks with a fruity, almost berry aspect that I’d expect more in a beer labeled an American amber than an "English" pale. Sturdy flagship. (#5689, 8/30/2014)

column1: Great Waters Saint Peter Pale Ale
column5: I liked that this wasn’t overly bitter as some APAs are. This had a nice aroma and flavour.

column1: Great Waters Saint Peter Pale Ale
column5: Sweet money, some hops. I found this to be a very sessionable and drinkable beer. Not crazy amounts of flavour but quaffable.

column1: Great Waters Saint Peter Pale Ale
column5: Date: November 5, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Great Waters Golden orange pour, fruity/citrus aroma and caramel/malty taste.

column1: Great Waters Saint Peter Pale Ale
column5: This was our first stop while on our Minneapolis trip. The St Paul brewery is downtown near the St Paul Hotel. This APA was one of the best tasted for the trip. The clear amber color and frothy head were impressive. The bitter floral flavors of the hops were well balanced with the malts. The finish was smooth with some bitterness. The APA had an IBU of 50 and 14 Plato and served at 38 degrees. We also had Bac-n-Beer nuts that was spicy.

column1: Great Waters Saint Peter Pale Ale
column5: On tap @ Great Waters. Burnt orange appearance with a light off white head. Good caramel malty, somewhat hoppy nose. Caramel, slightly nutty malty flavor with light hops. Almost more like a light brown ale.

Claims to be brewed with six different kinds of hops, one for each year they've been open, hence the 6th Anniversary Amber. Color is light brownish amber, kinda hazy, very little head, about 1/8 of an inch that faded fast and left some lace. Faint spicy hop and malt aroma, very soft and light on the nose. Taste is good, a little empty at the start, but the middle gets some malt tones and finishes with very nice sweet, bitter hop bite, slightly dry. Has a bit of spicyness. Is light to medium bodied and resembles an IPA style in the overall taste. They serve it a little to cold. But it mellows out as it sits. Pretty decent stuff. Next years Anniversary is to have another kind of hop added. That should make it even more interesting I'm sure.
Not bad. Hints of nutmeg, sweetness, candy. Somewhat complex. Nice!......
Black Coloring with Tan Bubbly Head. Coffee Aroma.. Light Rich Malt, Light Coffee Roasts.. Hints of Chocolate. Think Mouthfeel and Overall Subtle Flavor. Session Stout to be Sure.

Aroma is better than the GW Pothole porter I had before it. Dignified, subtle roasted malt aroma. Tiny bubble, tan head. Black opaque body. Decent lace. Missing sweetness. Some flaws. Lactose. After a lackluster Pothole Porter, and then this beer, I have pretty much lost faith in this brewer.
Black color with a thin, almost cask-head head. Smells and tastes like coffee. Pretty thin body. Borderline average.

Push beer sampled on 2/13/2004 at Great Waters. The aroma was roasty. Appearance was dark and rich with a tan head and good lace. The flavor was nice as a Dry Stout, roasty and dry with a decent body. It was served way too cold. However, this was the best of the three beers that night.

On cask: Color is awesome with the huge cascade of dull yellow making its way up the sides of the glass, finally settling to a very, very dark brown, nearly black with ruby red highlights around the edges, head is creamy and frothy tight about a finger high, creamy/tan in color and leaves large sheets of lace. Aroma is mild roastyness and milk chocolate with a slight tang of bitterness from hops in the back. Taste is more of the same with a solid dose of mild but bittering milk-like chocolate with a sweet roasty nut-like note darting in late in the finish with a touch of burnt coffee as well. Feel could be smoother, its a bit textured in a uneven sense, but the serving on cask makes for a nice milding effect. The dryness is nice and mild as well, very calming and easy with a nice light cottony feel fading into the mouth making you want another sip; if this was cold it would probably be disturbingly astringent and unpleasant alot like some of the other brews offered here. The cask does help it out alot I think. Even with that said, it has pretty good drinkability. Reminded me alot of the Pot Hole Porter with a bit of a different finish.

Not much aroma. Rough, extremely dry finish. Didn't seem malted enough. But to their credit, the owner was talking to me and he told me that the particular batch wasn't quite up to par. (He said that before I drank it :)

column1: Great Waters Brown Trout Brown Ale
column5: Minnesota Trip Beer #71. Keg at the brewpub, 5/9/16. Clear copper, large creamy tan head, poor retention. Faint chocolate aroma. The taste is chocolate, soy, cherries. Thin.

column1: Great Waters Brown Trout Brown Ale
column5: Samplesd from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear brown with a slight amber hue and a grayish tan head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has notes of bread and grain with a bit of nuttiness and a touch of sweetness. Flavor has sweet grains and bread note with hints of chocolate and toffee.

column1: Great Waters Brown Trout Brown Ale
column5: Sample at APN. Pour is dark brown with beige head. Roasted malts, nuts and caramel flavors.

column1: Great Waters Brown Trout Brown Ale
column5: On tap at GW. A nice deep brown color with a healthy tan head. Roasty aromas. Flavor is smooth and malty with just enough hop bite. Well made.

column1: Great Waters Brown Trout Brown Ale
column5: This was tasted on our 3M trip in St paul. The Reddish brown color of the ale was perfect. The ale had coffee notes and some tannic flavors. The ale is rated at 5.8% alcohol, 35 IBU and 15 Plato. I also detected some yeasty notes as well. The waiter at another brewpub was very high on this ale.

column1: Great Waters Brown Trout Brown Ale
column5: On tap @ Great Waters. Very dark red/brown body with a light tan head. Toasty, slightly nutty, somewhat alcoholic brown malty nose. Dark caramel malty flavor that’s slightly alcoholic. A little unbalanced.

column1: Great Waters Brown Trout Brown Ale
column5: Sampled via growler pour thanks to Doug H at the 29th Annual ABA Meeting in Bloomington, MN. Pours a semi-clear dark brown colored brew with a thin beige head that quickly dissipates to a thin ring. Aroma of toasted dark malt, some roasted nuts, and floral hops. Taste is medium bodied, burnt and toasted dark Munich malts, a hint of chocolate and floral hops. Finish has a toasty dark malt aftertaste, some bread crust aftertaste that reminds me why I enjoy getting the "heel" portion of the fresh roasted bread at excellent restaurants. Most excellent.

column1: Great Waters Brown Trout Brown Ale
column5: Tap. Very dark brown pour with a small fluffy tan head. Aroma of light roasted malt, chocolate, and nut. Taste is similar, thin yet creamy, and moderately carbonated.

column1: Great Waters Brown Trout Brown Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub on 05/31/2009. Clear very dark brown body with ruby highlights and a large creamy light brown head. Chocolate and light nutty aroma with a bit of molassas. Sweet chocolate flavor some roasty hints with light molassas and a bit of nuttiness. Medium light body with moderately low carbonation. Not sure it’s really a brown ale, but it’s certainly tasty. 7/4/8/4/15 - 3.8 On handpump at the brewpub on 05/31/2009. Clear dark black body with ruby highlights and a medium frothy light brown head. Sweet chocolate aroma, light roast, a smokey hint and some light molassas. Chocolate, roast, and molassas flavor with a bit of light bitter in the finish. Very light body with low carbonation. 7/4/8/5/16 - 4.0

column1: Great Waters Brown Trout Brown Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Slightly clear, but very dark brown pour with little head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and nut. Sweet malty flavor with some nut and a slightly bitter finish.

Date: 11/08/1997 Source: Brewfest, Real Ale Festival roasted malt aroma, watery and sour Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 1/10; Flavor: 1/10; Palate: 1/10; Overall: 3/20 Rating: 1.1/5.0 Score: -/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Mahogany with a cap of nice fine bubbles. This actually smells like an oatmeal stout. Toasty, buttery, warm brown sugar. Nice soft palate, but kind of clumsy chocolate flavor and a bit of stale smoke. Not bad, but also not stellar.

On cask, served at 52°F in an 8oz serving. Rich, chocolate and nutty, roasted coffee aroma with a hint of roasted oats. Dark, dark brown with ruby tints and a thick, off-white head filled with tiny little bubbles. Sweet chocolate with roasted barley and what I refer to as toasted sesame seeds in the flavor. Medium-light bodied, very soft carbination with a slightly dry finish. Reminds me of a lighter, sweet stout because of the roasted notes I taste.
Very thin bodied, especially for a porter, with a distinctly watered down feeling. Weird floral aftertaste that I don’t expect in the style. Not very satisfying.

Very dark, faint hint of red, absolutely no head. Nose has toffee, and something akin to bourbon, but it’s light in the smelling department. Molasses bitter, not any coffee or chocolate, just basically tastes like watered-down molasses. Watery, and not because of the cask, just not a good mouthfeel.

Cask. Very faint aroma, but somehow pleasant. Hint of sweet roasted malt. Cascading opaque body as one would expect from a cask Porter. Average sized tan head. I really didn’t like the color of the head. It wasn’t quite tan, and it wasn’t quite a smooth creamy off-white like in a Guinness. It was dirty looking. Some lace. Not bad, not great. I warmed up to it a little bit at mid glass. Some sweetness.

In the cask at the Brewpub. Very black with a brown head. In fact, a phenomenal head. This was a good-looking beer. I could not get much of an aroma out of this one. Surprising taste like chocolate mint. Smooth going down, but a sour aftertaste. Slightly disapointing for a cask-conditioned ale.
Guinness wannabe mugshot. Fearless head standing tall throughout all opposition. No aroma, but body is creamy without overburdening or stickiness. Finish is tannic, oaky, and creamy.

Appearance: deep, dark brown, with a fuzzy, light tan head. Aroma: smooth, mellow, creamy, with nutty hints. Taste: mild and mellow, medium bodied, with a sweetness in the finish. Missing a lot of flavors I yearn for in a good porter, actually, not much in the coffee’n’cocoa department, lacks a fullness I prefer. Drinks down nice enough, but in my book, just passable as a porter. Afterthought: I look at the notes from my St. Paul comrades and clearly we tasted different beers, for they tasted the things I missed. Perhaps I owe it to Great Waters to try this again, next time. After-after-thought: I’m all for alliteration, but why did they name it after something you like to avoid, that’s what I wonder...

Cask sample. Very dark brown, with a bit of gold at the edge. Chocolate-caramel nose, hints of vanilla. Smooth, vinous, moderately sweet body with a bit of robustness to finish, but far too watery in the mouth.

Dark Red/Brown with Light Tan Head. Light Dusty Malt Aroma. Very Light Bourbon Notes. Very Subtle Tasting Brew and Easy to Drink. Very Subtle Notes that it was in fact Aged in a Bourbon Barrell. Overall a Solidly Average Brew, if you Accept the Extreme Low-Key Atmosphere of this Beer.

In the cask at the Brewpub. Dark amber-brown in color with a beige head. This beer was kind of a disappointment. There’s not much here. It’s very smooth and easy to drink. Very good malt content. If this was ever in a bourbon barrel, it has no evidence of it.
Dark copper. Sweek malt aroma. Single brown-ale-colored flavor. Light caramel notes. Empty finish. Not fantastic, but a reasonably pleasant session beer.

Rich head, clinging to the glass above a chestnut brown beer. Light bourbon touch, moderate nutty and woody. Very thin (typical brown ale) at cask temperature, smooth, and dangerously easy drinking. Such an easy finish, too bad it is only a brown ale to start with before going into the barrels. Excellent. (cask conditioned, handpull, at brewpub)
Tap @ brewpub. A dark brown color with a creamy brown head. A musty aroma. Smooth malty flavors with a slight hint of the bourbon barrel. A pleasant sweetness and a touch of fruit. A great brown ale.

Cask. Very lovely dark brown color (reminded me of a nice oak table) with a thick head. Kind of a dead aroma, but slight malts are there. Taste is a tasty mix of toasty malts and raw barley, but none of the heavy hitting nuts that I would expect from a Brown Ale. The bourbon is slightly detectable as an alcoholic zing at the front, but doesn’t appear too much in the beer. The cask definitely rounds out the body and makes it insanely smooth. A very tasty brew, but not as stellar as I was looking for.

"Cask"ading action is short lived but impressive gold tones flurry then settling to a nice dark amber walnut color with a steady finger high head of ivory creamyness, continent shaped lacing sticks well. Smell is faint sweetness of fruit, peach and lightly lemony. Unique soft taste of sweet bourbon, an interesting mix of tenderness and rigid ripeness, malts and fruits dance lightly together with a twinge of bitterness, sour-like grapefruit notes. It goes right through and down as far as feel, lightly astringent and velvety textured, smokey and limpid. A wee bit lighter then I was expecting, has a sour drying of lemonyness into the finish thats nice. Worth a try, quite interesting, on cask makes it worth while.

Nice dark appearance, pretty head. Whiskey hints in the nose, and I thought that I was in for a treat (a la Happy Jack Stout from The Bitter End in Austin, TX). However, the bourbon didn't follow through in the taste and I was a bit disappointed.
Another addition to the already overcrowded macro lager market in Japan. Has one distinguishing feature, a bit of a spicy aftertaste. I wonder what hops they use?

Tastes much like any other American Standard lager. Unlike most Japanese beers, this one's not particularly dry. I like the cobalt blue metallic can, however, it imparts a hint of metallic taste to the beer.
Crisp, refreshing. Slightly sweet. Hoppy. A good beer.......................

500 ml bottle at home, bb. 3.3.2020. Pours a clear very dark golden to amber with a white head. The aroma is medium malty with lots of dried fruits, dried apples, raisins, honey, toasted bread, some metallic notes and hints of butter. Medium body with a soft carbonation, a light to medium sweetness and a light bitterness. The flavor starts with sweetish malt, sweet grains, hints of honey, biscuit, dried fruits and some hay and finishes with a light earthy, hoppy bitterness. Overall a nice malt dominated lager. Aroma: 6 Appearance: 4 Taste: 6 Palate: 4 Overall: 12
500ml Bottle - Light amber with a foamy head. Rye bread, sultanas and orange in the aroma. Sultanas, orange peel, aniseed and rye in the taste. Nicely balanced and enjoyable.
In der Nase malzig, im Trunk süß, dazu eine etwas unrunde Bittere. Nicht so der Hit.

(bottle) clear deep golden-amber colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of rotten fruit and spent grain, quite metallic, with some notes of caramelized popcorn and strawberry syrup. flavour is mostly caramelized malts and cooked asparagus, slightly earthy, with a touch of yeast and a grassy popcorn finish. full-bodied with lively carbonation. avoid.

floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, light sweetness, medium sweetness, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, very bitter, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium sourness, heavily sour, salty, umami,
Bottle (50 cl) from Landbierparadies, Germany. Clear amber, large off-white head. Bready malt, herbal hops. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Dry, low to medium bitterness,a tad metallic.
Orange-goldene Farbe, wenig Schaum. Metallisch malziger Duft. Im Antrunk malzig schaumig prickelnd, aber auch leicht ölig. Weicher Charakter, ganz leichte Bitterkeit, sonst wenig Aroma.
Sehr malzbetonter Antrunk, brotig und leicht röstiger Körper mit einer gewissen Süsse. Der Hopfen kommt langsam im Abgang und ist gut nachwirkend.
Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of buttersotch, bready malts, herbal-earthy, grains, fruity. Taste is heavy diactyl, light bready malts, grains, earth. blah
Bottle. Orange Amber, low carbonated, low offwhite head. Light Bready malt nose. Medium full body, mellow chewy mouthfeel, light mineral, iodine, grassy finish. Serviceable

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Keg. Clear deep gold, generous head. Malty aroma. Clean taste, slightly sweet. Not much else to it but very good with food. Decent

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: this is a pretty good examples of style, has some fragrance, nice clean hops. but of course a little thin. no head or lacing

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: The most interesting thing about this beer is the can. The rest is really a standard Helles lager. Certainly drinkable, not really bitter, okay flavor.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Lemon and a little funk in the aroma, a little off. Standard (and good) flavor, with lots of cereal-like pilsner malt and more grassy hops than usual. Pretty good.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Can. I'm getting pretty noticeable lemon notes in this. They differentiate it from other helles lagers, but don't really fit. Beyond that, bready malt backbone and crisp hop bite.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Nice golden color. Clean malty flavor. Nice noble hop flavor and aroma. Great summer beer, especially on hot days. ---Rated via Beer Buddy

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Blind tasted with 4 other helles/dortmunder lagers. Lagers were: 1. Sly Fox Helles Golden Lager 2. Lakefront My Turn #023 Dylan 3. Benediktiner Original / Hell 4. Schloßbrauerei Fattigau Schloß-Export 5. Key Helles. Both raters rated the beers 21534. 355ml can. Gold pour. Fruity aroma, mixed popsicle aroma. Falvor is grainy and hoppy, fresh, refreshing, bit bittersweet. Post tasting thoughts: This delivered but was a bit odd in a few ways.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Drank this on a hot day after doing yard work so this got a higher rating than I probably would’ve given it. Aroma was weak. Lager smells with a hint of boiled egg. Pour was a light clear gold with no head. Taste was offensive at first but then as I got hotter it tasted better. Fresh baked bread and crust were the main flavors but there was little carbonation to help them. The sulfur hurt and there was a wet doughy finish. Im not a huge fan of the style to begin with, but this is one of the rare German styles that I think Americans just haven’t figured out yet

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Bright clear yellow gold with slight rimmimg head Aroma is rich grainy malty Flava is rich sweet honeyish malt Feels light yet creamy with lively fizz Finishes dry grainy mildly bitter

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: light malt aroma. pale and clear in color with decent head. taste is malty, notes of euro-lager

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: This poured a clear.golden.color with a white head. Aroma was of a blegian yeast, light fruit and light spice. Flavor similar, a little overly sweet and lacking in the body, but decent.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at station tap room. Pours clear orange with a small white head that quickly dissipates. The aroma Is very sweet with some fruity notes, light biscuit. The taste is very sweet with banana, raisin, pure sugar, yeast. Pretty nice.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours a clear with a thin white head. Aroma has a hint of grass and some nice hoppy spice. Flavor has hints of fruit and candy sugar with nice grassy spice. Mouthfeel is medium/full...very silky...nice grassy/dry pils like finish.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at the bocktown. Taste is alittle mild for a strong ale but a medical buikds thru the session. Fairly flat, I don’t detect any co2 at all. Not sure what to think of this bitter medicine. Needs some manners, even for a strong ale. I must say tho, it does try to fool you on the initial taste, comes across rather friendly then bites you inthe ass.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: transparent gold, lacing white head. Dusty yeast and citrus nose becomes heavy bubblegum, ethanol, and peppery yeast finish in flavor. Soft carbonation leaves it oppressive.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at phoenixville. Golden pour. Candy sugar flavors dominate. Sweet and medium bodied. Low Carb.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours golden yellow with a white head. Aroma of yeast and candii sugar with hint of citrus. Belgian yeast, spice, and candii sugar dominate the flavor with hints of citrus. Good beer!

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Poured hazy yellow with little head. Aroma of spice and some citrus. Lots of spice flavor with some citus background. Had some sweet character here and there. More spice than anything.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: &#40BCTC, 2007 3L bottle, thanks Eugene&#41 Medium off-white head atop murky orange body. Aroma is medium sweet, orange, yeast, some candi sugar. Taste is moderately sweet, candi sugar, yeast, some orange. Sofy medium body, low carbonation.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Big ol’ bottle courtesy of Eugene I think, at BCTC. Pours a hazy apricot gold with a thin white head. Citrus and honey on the nose. Thin to medium bodied, light sweetness. Ends with a large bitter, and slightly acrid finish.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: 5/7/2016 -- from notes: Sample on tap at Whiskey Village during CBC. Orange juice appearance. Bready wheat malt, kind of peppery and spicy. Hint of citrus. Medium body. Light dry, lighter, crisp carbonation. Mild dry finish. Light sour. Moderate sweet. OK berliner. Not interesting nor particularly flavorful, but refreshing enough. If you told a layman that this was OJ they'd probably think it was too watered-down.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at brewery. Hazy golden, tiny head. Body about right, light weizen aromas, taste too. Nearly there, but not quite.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Canned. Cluloudy yellow pour. Bursting with bananas and cloves. Rather well done Imo.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Cloudy gold thin white Lacy head; aroma is sweet fruity notes of bananna; flava is bananna and dry graininess subtle hop notes; feels medium with a soft fizz; finishes tangy sweet notes of banana and hints licorice/anise

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: 4 oz pour on draft at Spacebar. Clear golden yellow with off-white head. Aromas of light citrus, herbs. Tastes of wheat, light citrus, herbs. Medium-light body with a semi-dry finish. Decent hefe.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours cloudy golden orange with soapy white head that doesn’t last long but leaves some skim. Nose is wheat, dough, tangerine, very light banana. The palate is bread and lemon rind. After a few minutes, the banana and clove notes of the traditional weisse show up, though fairly subdued. It’s uncomplicated but refreshing. Sometimes on a warm day, you just want a cold one. This is for those times.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Decent weizen. Nice and cloudy with a nice head. Puckering palate but a fruity finish.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Bottle shared at Leighton’s. Many thanks to Colin for this one. Clouded golden orange coloured pour with a thin sticky white head. Aroma is big doughy wheaty grains, light banana note, light citrus. Flavour is doughy bread grains, light banana bread, yeasty, wheat with background lemon rind. Palate is flabby grains, highish carbonation, ok.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Can share at Leighton’s flat, thanks to Colin. Hazy orange, lightly sparkling, small foamy white head, light lacing. Aroma is wheaty, tangerine, a little banana. Body is medium, soft carbonation, smooth. Taste is buttery, soft citrus, wheaty banana and clove. Has the classic hefe characteristics but just a little toned down.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Can split at LKS high up place, from Beer merchants. Com i think, 20/10/15. Hazed orange with a moderate off White covering. Nose is light nana, yeast, bitter orange, straw. Taste comprises yeast esters, clove, banana bread, light spice, orange. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Decent enough hefe.
* Old rating, 0,5l crown-top bottle, best before 04.2003. Bought in October 2002 in Hamburg. Malzig-dunkles Bier. Moderat bitter, moderat süß. Nicht zu klebrig, dunkelmalzig, nett.

(Bottle 50 cl) Apparently brewed from the devils own recipe... Nothing diabolic about it though. The malt provides a pretty, reddish brown colour. Flavour is dominated by the roasted malt. But mainly dry and bitter with a weak, underlying sweetness. Full-bodied and quite nice. 300600
Dusty malt nose, candy sugar like nose and color. Medium head. Strong medium sweet and malty taste.
A red-brown beer with a fine white head. The aroma is sour malty with notes of caramel. The flavor though is sweet malty with notes of caramel and straw.
Bottled: Amber coloured. Beige head. Malt with notes of choco. Malty and watery flavour with notes of caramel. Is watery in the aftertaste.
Weak brew with a rather watery start and middle. Slightly malty in finish. Boring and uninteresting palate. Some watery aftertaste.
Brown coloured. Very bready aroma with notes of cookies.Malty and rather sweet flavour with some bitterness in the metallic finish. Slightly thin.

Bitter and very dry. Aromas of musty hops. Alcoholic aroma even though it's only 4.9% and not very dark -- a medium brown. I've got good creamy foam. Not a whole lot there. It's brewed with hop extract -- no hops.

A relatively strong aroma, but a little foul somehow. Dusty too. The color is clear carmel. A mild, sweet taste predominates. Slightly bitter and woody finish. Very thin body - too thin. Large bubbles and no head. Enjoyable, but this is a cheap beer posing a something special. Just above average.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: WOW. Can’t believe I never got around to rating this. Thanks again to Skyhand. Bottled in 1995. Drank around 2007ish. An absolutely brilliant perfection once again from Alan. The man really can do no wrong. Big and fairly boozey but it only compliments the raisin, toffee, candy, and bits of awesome burnt cocoa. SO GOOD.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Nice dark pour with no real head. Flavor is aweome. Sean9689 mentioned that this was the best bottle he had ever tried, and it was really good. Sweet, tobacco, port, leather, hints of dark fruit.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Served in a Hair of the Dog stemmed taster. Nose is similar to Dave but without being as heavy on the smoke. Blackberry jam, booze, tobacco, and mild spice notes. Bit of booze.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Thanks to Richard for the share. Paired with Hair of the Dog Dave. The beer appears virtually still and is dark brown in color. The aroma brings molasses, a touch of soy sauce, though certainly not off putting. Additional notes of leather, maple. The flavor brings more spice than the aroma indicated. A bit of pepper with moderate booze. Void of carbonation and really smooth in the palate. A once in a lifetime experience and certainly an enjoyable experience pairing this with Dave.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Sampled at the CCB/RateBeer/Pre-Hunah Tasting (Tampa, FL). Pours a nice deep black pour, coal with good haziness, dark and opaque. Frothy brownish head atop laces ok as a thicker ring. Aromas are cocoa, toffee, and a bit roasty. Chocolate, some roast, mellow growing earthy hop bitterness. Initial is roasty, dry and bitter, some pretzel, cocoa, and more toast and roast as we press on. Toasty, dry. Middle is cocoa, dark black malts, and toffee. Still firmly dry, roasty, and cocoa. nice bigger flavors, backend is dry, toasty, rich coffee and dry bakers chocolate. Finish is dry, a bit bitter and cocoa laden, shavings, gentle dark fruit. Solid fun beer.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Bottle. Pours dark brown with a small brown head. Aroma is fruity malty raisins fidges dark fruits. Flavor is fullbodied peppery fruity raisiny malty slightly roasted velvety smooth and a bit bitter. Very well kept, excellent.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Forgot I had this with Jeremy and Chris. Still plum body. Soft cardboard elements hint at severity of oxidation, behind which hides some chocolate, soy, and a bit of paper. Thin oily body, short bitter finish. Drank against ten vintages of Adam ranging 1-8 years of age, and none of complexity of those remains in Eve. Feel bad ticking such an old beer this low, especially when Adam is consistently 4.4+. This rating is intended as a cold bucket of water for all the Captain Ahabs out there still hoping the hunt is worthwhile.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Pour is a clear dark wine like red with no head. The nose is different, some sweet notes of berry, lightly oxidized, notes of chocolate, strange soy sauce. The taste is rough, salty, chocolate, boozy, vanilla, and a large amount of soy sauce. The Adam characteristics may be there, the body is lightly creamy with low carbonation if any.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Dark mahogany, mostly clear and a slight impression of lacing at certain moments. Nose is umami, soy sauce, old malt, rasins, seaweed. Ocean-like. Mouth is weirdly blank at first, then a pretty heavy seaweed, prune, raisin. Mostly still in the mouth, slick, oily feel. Interesting beer, probably past its prime.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Bottle shared by Ryan at the Philly tasting. Roasty caramel nose. Clear dark brown pour with no head. Lots of caramel, dark fruits, and a hint of sherry. Medium in body with nice balance.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Keg at borefts. Pours golden, nose is toffee, spice,lemon, taste is similar, grassy. 3.1

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Borefts 2019 day 2. As "Greg ***********" 5.5%. Hazy golden with white head. Sweet and dry grainy. Grassy and somewhat plasticcy. Moderate sweet and bitter. Medium body and soft carbonation.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Tap @ BBF 2019. Blonde. Vinous aroma and flavor. Sweet, gummibears. Floral notes.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Sampled at Borefts 2019, Friday. A clear golden beer. Aroma of moderate sweet dry grainy malt. Taste of sweet grainy malt, straw, mild bitterness. Earlier Rating: 3/4/2017 Total Score: 3.1 Sampled @ ACBF Vichte 2017. Fast klare goldene Farbe. Geruch leicht würzig malzig, Kräuter, helles Malz. Geschmack mild würzig, Kräuter, helle Früchte, helles Malz.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Edwin Z. is drinking a Greg by Hair of the Dog Brewing Company @Bbf’19, Lichte alE, vrij rechttoe rechtaan, best ok

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Tap. Hazy golden color with white head. Aroma is flowery, blossomy, cookie dough. Taste is flowery, some spices, blossomy. Oily mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Lovely!

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: From tap at Borefts 2019. Curious aroma of what I suppose is pumpkin squash. Sweetish flavour with low bitterness. Medium body. Not bad though.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: 28th September 2019 Borefts XI Day 2 . Keg. Hazy yellowish gold beer, small white head. Thin crisp dry palate, decent minerally carbonation. Thin malts. Minerally tangy flinty mid. Some dry floral fruits. Dry finish. Okay.

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Keg at Borefts2019. M hazy amber.. Thin white lacing.. Light dry grassy fruits nose.. Soft herbal grain.. Oily fruits.. Very grainy

column4: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
column5: Draught @ Borefts 2019 Aroma has quite nothing, just faint traces of citrus. Flavour has soapy notes, apricot and fruit juice. Very mild and easy-going. Earlier Rating: 7/12/2012 Total Score: 3.2 Draught @ the brewpub Aroma is slightly sweet and tart with grapefruit, apricot and hay. Flavour is sweet with grapefruit, some peaches, pineapple juice and fruit sugar. Warming alcohol in the finish. Sticky and somewhat leathery palate. A bit odd.
Utseende klar lus gul med hvitt skum. Aroma og smak korn malt noe eple. God fylde, maltpreg, moderat bitter. Boks kjøpt på Joker engenes.

Blehh alkaline chalky cream-fizzy nothingness. Solely a box-checking exercise with some pointless carbonation. Not enjoyable, i imagine it's consumed only in large quantities by Norwegians that live far from a Vinmonopolet outlet (16.9 oz can, Kiwi supermarket, Oslo)

Can (Kirkenes) Pale golden color, small white head. Aroma is rubbery and worty and even a bit grainy. Light-bodied, watery palate. Grainy flavor, a a bit rubbery. Harsh finish. Quite typical industrial NOR/SWE-type lettöl. Meh.

Canned@AIH66 Beer Session (from Rema 1000 or Kiwi in Kirkenes). Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is grains, herbs, mild cardboard and some malts. Flavour is grainy, herbal, grassy and some wooden notes.

50cl can from Coop Extra, Sandefjord. Pours pale yellow with a white head. Grainy aroma with notes of cooked vegetables and hints of fruits. Sweet and grainy with slightly unpleasant vegetable flavours. Null was better and more refreshing in my opinion. This one was rather unpleasant.
Ok lettøl, men selvsagt ikke all verdens kategorien tatt i betraktning. Helt grei tørsteslukker.

As with most other light lagers, this beer has a fantastic appearance in the glass, light yellow golden, thick foamy head. Looks far more refreshing than it really is. Not much aroma, even less taste, just a short sting from the carbonation and/or bittering hops. If you’re really very thirsty, go for it if it’s cold. If you want a glass of delicious beer to enjoy, leave it where it is.

From can on board Fridtjofen 08.09.15. Very clear and very pale straw colour. White head. Harsh aroma with some grass and grains. Similar taste, with a low - but harsh - bitterness continuing into aftertaste. Slightly metallic.

Appearance: Clear pale golden color with a fine white head. Some lacing. Aroma: Mild malty, mild herbal and some wort. Palate: Light body. Moderate sweet and a moderate bitterness. Average carbonation. Taste: Mild malty, mild herbal and some wort. Overall impression: Drinkable. Personal stats: Bottle from a local grocery store.
Gulbrun klar med lavt hvitt skum. Malt og korn. Søtlig med noe bitterhet. Lett. Med medium kullsyre.

Cask-conditioned at Colston’s Yard, Bristol 16/05/09. Deep amber with a slight, white head. Orange fruit and caramel aroma, with a touch of earthiness. Flavour started with sweet malts, more fruit, leafy hops and a decent bitter finish. Good.
Cask at Ealing beer fest. Aroma is sulphury and yeasty, theres some apply character too. Taste is similar, reminisant of green king yeast.
gravi @ ealing bf 08. sweet malty aroma, hop notes of grass and nettles. dark amber colour. farmy, herbal flavour, quite citric bitter finish. dry and tart, quaffable.
Cask conditioned @ South Western Arms Beer Festival. Tangy citrus and grainy malts. Light bodied but not excessivly so. Unexciting quaffer.

A reddish, copper coloured beer with a weak white head. Zesty, citrus fruit nose, a little like that is a Sauvignon Blanc, with a hint of hop. The taste is light, and dry, a little malty, then the zesty lemony, white wine flavour comes through to a crisp, citrusy finish. (Cask - The Ouse Amateur Sailing Club, King’s Lynn, Norfolk).
Very nice, a little sweet, not really a bitter but nice in aroma. A little dark, and bubbling foam.
Cask Handpump at the Great Western Hotel, Exeter 11/06/2003 Amber golden colour with some alcohol. Fruity and dry with a crisp full malt finish.
Cask Conditioned, at the Market Porter, London. Crimson body with fruity, sweet nose. Colourful and lively, it delivers sweet excitement on a lively Friday night at the porter.
Sampled cask conditioned. Amber coloured. Neutral nose. Fruity, remarkably light bodied, medium sweetness, fruity. Some bitterness in the finish. Not an attention grabber.
Cask @ the brewery. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, malt, fruits snd hops. Light bitter finish.

Hand-pulled half-pint in The Nags Head, Shrewsbury on 11th May 2019. Clear and clean golden amber body, thin head of white foam. Decent enough blend without getting my senses excited too greatly. A little more malty sweetness than hop bitterness, but a nice balance overall.

5/4/2019. Cask at the Rebellion brewery shop, Marlow Bottom. Pours golden amber with an average sized off-white head. Aroma of citrus, hops, light caramel, malt and grass. Moderate sweetness with medium bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation.
500ml on tap. Pours murky gold with a small white head. Aroma is peach, biscuit, malt. Taste is fruity, toasted malt, light bitterness.

Just bought a large bottle of this from the brewery's shop. First impressions: it's a traditional bitter, with excellent, subtle, flowery aromas that develop. I can understand why some may consider this a bit watery, but the fact is, it has it all. Starts off with a hint of fresh hoppiness, vaguely cannabis-like, which immediately rounds out to a light toffee/malt aroma, without a tarry lingering aftertaste. There are no roasted-malt notes punching through. Seems very refreshing and tempting to quaff, with absolutely nothing unpleasant about it at all. As an infrequent but keen drinker of bitters, I find this very much to my taste. Exactly what I hoped it would be.
On tap at the hotel bar Pours deep amber. Sweetish aroma. Taste is medium bitter, low carbonation, not really amazed.
The best IPA I've tasted in a long time. If it's on it's my first choice.

Egham Beer Fest (one of the standard beers from the bar), 30/03/18. Vague malty sour aroma. Medium brown. Thick off-white head. Sweet caramel malty. Light-medium bodied. Soft carb. Abrupt finish. Whoever branded this an IPA is a delusional madman. Low ABV bitter. Nice enough.
Pendle Beer Festival 2018. Amber-brown in colour with a gentle and appealing caramel sweetness.

[9358-20170701] Tap. Mild sweaty citrus aroma. Murky, light tan body with a long-lasting foamy white head and some thick lacing. Bitter evergreen resin hops flavour has some citrus peel oil. Medium body is quite bitter. Good, a little rough. (7/4/7/3/15) 3.5 (@ Rebellion brewpub, Regina, SK)

Oddly curious and refreshing aroma, suggestive of suntan lotion and mosquito repellant. Light but luninescent copper color. Flavor gives a hint of malt and more of alcohol. Really not as deep as it might have achieved.
decent bock, dark golden color with a decent taste with a slight malt flavor. My favorite of the evening.
golden yellow with a firm white head. aroma of toffee and malt. nice light taste of malt with notes of butterscotch and vanilla. very drinkable for a strong bock.
Decent brown ale. Was one of the best of the samplers, but I'll stick to the back forest.
Of all the brewpubs in Pittsburgh, Valhalla is my favorite. This beer is one of the reasons, however, I give them much more credit for the lagers that they brew. Cheers!

a nice brown ale. dark brown color with a beige head. big malt nose with a vague nutty flavour. very smooth drink would be a great session beer. has a surprisingly bitter hoppy finish with a long lasting aftertaste
Country tick #187. Thanks Grumbo. Pours yellow gold - slightly dirty - nose/taste of grain, apple and varnish - med body

Bottle 330ml. [ As Castel Beer (Mali) ]. [ Courtesy of Grumbo ]. [ As my country rating # 181 on ratebeer ].Clear medium yellow colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, straw, pale malt, sweet malt, corn, light grass - green apple. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, pale malt, sweet malt, corn, grass, light fruity hops - green apple. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20190529] 4-2-4-2-7

330ml bottle [thanks to Aziz iterum]. Clear, orangey golden colour with small, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Rather weak, sweet-ish, grainy, minimally bready aroma. Taste is sweet-ish, bready and minimally grainy, pale malty, moderately bitter hoppy; slightly oily texture. Clean, refreshing, drinkable.
Frothy white fair mostly diminishing head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. light bitter flavor. Short light bitter finish. Watery palate.

Bottle @ Johns, courtesy of Grumbo, thanks Graham! Pours light yellow with a small white head. Aroma of malt, corn, little grass. Flavor is sweet, malty, corn, grass. Thin body, average carbonation, sweet finish. 240419
Sample courtesy Grumbo. Small head with short duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are rich malt, corn and hops. Sweet bready finish.
Sample courtesy of Grumbo. Thanks. Clear yellow with a small white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and corn. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. Watery. 240419

Sample courtesy of Grumbo, cheers Graham! Pale gold colour, thin white head and aroma of malt, grain, corn, grass. Taste is malt, grainy, cardboard, papery, with some straw and grassy bitterness. Light bodied, medum carbonation, cardboardy finish. Quite standard pale lager.
33cl Bottle. Gift from a friend. Golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma is grain, straw. Taste is grain, sweet, watery. Light to medium body, average carbonation.

23/3/2019. Bottle courtesy of mtitov, huge thanks for arranging this. My country #196. Pours clear bright gold with a small white head. Aroma of grain, sweet fruit and straw. Medium sweetness with moderate bitterness. Light body, sticky texture, average carbonation. Sweet and slightly metallic finish. Great country tick. Fair beer.

On draught at 69 Taps in Akron. Hazy reddish amber color with a thick and foamy beige head. Thin and sticky lacing. The aroma is both sweet and tart, with malt and sour fruit. Medium-bodied and pretty smooth, with far less sourness than expected for the style. The flavor leans more toward a straight up Amber Ale. Sweet malt and caramel flavors with light sour fruit undertones. There is also a nip of hops here and there. The finish is fruity, tart and short. I am not convinced that a Flemish Sour is the style they were going for. On its own merits the beer is pretty tasty though.

Hey, I gotta give Barrelhouse points for attempting to brew a Belgian Style Red Ale, but they missed the mark here. The Barrelhouse brew is too light, without the richness and "wine-ness" that one expects from the Flemish brews... it's still very drinkable, though.

it's tough to say how I really felt about this beer. I was thrilled that anyone would attempt a flanders red ale in a beer starved town like Cincinnati. The beer was indeed a red color altough more amber than red. The aroma was a soft malty aroma. The biggest knock on the flavor was the lack of sourness and bite. It had a slight vinious character that reminded me of fresh grape skins and maybe even a bit of the bubblegum flavor I found in the hefe they have. I think this is a beer that would be great to lay down for awhile a let mature. It just seemed to young.

Van de tap als zomerbock bij de NRC in Rotterdam. aangenaam verfrissende Bock. Goudgeel met een witte kraag, licht troebel. De geur is ingetogen, de smaak begint volzoet maar al snel komt daar een aangenaam bitter bij.
On tap @ brewpub. Not bad but I’m just not a big fan of this type of beer. Balanced too much to the sweet aromas, away from more interesting directions.

Keg at Broewerij De Pelgrim, Rotterdam as Zomerbock. Amber to brown with white head. Initially a buttery caramel dominated proceedings, but eventually a fruity, soft berry note came through with some bitterness. Decent.
On tap at the brewpub. Hazy amber. Sweetish fruit and caramel aroma. Fruity toffee flavours. Quite good.

Draught @ Brouwerij de Pelgrim Brewpub, Aelbrechtskolk 12, 3024 Rotterdam-Delftshaven, Netherlands. Clear medium orange amber color with a average, creamy, good lacing, mostly - fully lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate to light light heavy malty, caramel, light to moderate hoppy, orange, moderate yeasty, overripped plum. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet, light to moderate acidic apple - malt sour, and moderate roasted coffe bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily - sticky, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light to moderate alcoholic. [20090601]

Huge lasting yellowy head tops the cloudy light copper hue. Very malty, almost with a wheaty hint underneath. It is an kinda earthy rendition where sandy and gentle leafy bitterness never quite cuts through the cerealic and grainy sweetness. A bit simple as far as its toasty or caramelly subtleties go. More fruitiness would also give it a sense of purpose. A it is, a sweet, honeyed and fizzy bock.
On tap@Pelgrim. Cheesy aroma at first, later on a hint of smoke and caramel. Hazy, orange color, citric, several spices, caramel malts. Sticky and full.
Pretty dark for a spring bock. Clear dark orange/brown color. Smelled like salami or 'leverworst'. Dry malty taste and a dry palate.
On tap. Red-coloured, small head, thin lacing. Malty aroma. Soft, malty, sweet and a bit fruity flavour. Bittersweet finish. By the way my Pelgrim Meibock had 6.8% ABV.
Good tasting Rotterdam beer. Pretty hoppy tasting beer, hoppier than most bock beers.
CBC2016S03, pours brown with a small head, aroma of chocolate, bread, flavor of chocolate, bread, medium bodied

Draught@CBC2016. Copper colour, small brown head. Aroma is fruity, floral, mildly tart notes with liquorice, alcohol and some toffee. Flavour is liquorice, some wood, toffee, mild alcohol as well as some slight tobacco notes to it.
Tap @ Copenhagen Beer Celebration, 2016. Cloudy dark brown body with a small offwhite head. Malt, caramel, light hops, raisins, plums. Good.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.

Draught @ CBC 2016 [ Red Session ]. - Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2016, Oksnehallen Vesterbro, Halmtorvet 11, 1700 Copenhagen, Denmark. [ As Bells Batch 3000 Ale ]. Clear medium to dark red brown color with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, dark malt, caramel, bread, sweet malt, dried fruit. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, sweet malt, caramel, dark malt, dried fruit. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finidh feel is light alcoholic. [20160514]
