Draft @ CBC 2016. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and caramel aroma with weak hints of dark fruit. Roasted ,malty chocolate and caramel flavor. Has a roasted malty caramel and chocolate finish with hints of dark fruit.
Draught at Mikkeller & Friends. Black colored with a medium sized beige head. Roasted aroma of caramel and chocolate. Roasted flavor of caramel and chocolate. Roasted finish.
From tap at CBC 2016. Black with a beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, caramel, bread, chocolate, vanilla and a mild bitter finish.

Enjoyed on tap at Slows BBQ in Detroit, MI while having some lunch with good friends. Very excited to see this on the menu. I didn’t take tasting notes, but remember this being a very unique and complex dark ale with rich vanilla, raisin, plum, chocolate, and coffee profile. Would definitely have this again if that was a possibility, very much enjoyable.

Tap@Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2016, Copenhagen - black pour with a tan head. Dark roasted malty aroma and taste with chocolate, caramel, dark dried fruit, nutty, vanilla, some burnt malty notes, roasted finish.
330ml can from some supermarket. Somewhere in time. In short: another crap lager. Corn, sweet, dull, boring. Just another poor mainstream beer.
Can. Malt with a hint of citrus in aroma. Clear yellow colour with soft white head. Quite ordinary pilsener.
Can bought in some store some where in Madrid. Clear yellow, short lasting white bubbly head. Aroma is grainy and bit maltish. Grainy grassy lightly malty flavour with a light bitterness.

33 cL can. Pours clear yellow with a diminishing white head. Malty and slight mouldy aroma with notes of corn. Dry and almost breadish malt flavour, medium dry. Has a faint bit of bitterness in the far finish - otherwise just plain malt.
(can) Label says since 1857. Found in Barcelona. Poured yellow with an artificial head. Very thin with little malt or hops. I would guess a good amount of corn is used. Not recommended.
Skunky aroma. Pale golden, white rocky head, few lace. Light, sweet, malty pilsener.

Thank you Chris for sharing the bottle - Dark amber with off white head - Malt and some hops in the aroma - Malt body with some dark fruity tones and caramel - The caramel malt goes into the finish - With some fruity tones - This was nice
Bottle From Vinmonopolet Stavanger. Shared with Bergstaden. Dark amber with little head. Malts, hops, Caramel.
Bottle at home. Pours clear copper with off-white head. Aroma of toffee, dried fruits, herbs, spices, caramel. Tastes a bit sweet with balancing bitterness. Medium bodied, slightly bitter finish.
OKT 17 oppsaml. Rødbrun med beige skum. Dufter lett maltsødme. Doven munnfølelse. Søtklissen smak. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Mahognifarget klar med fingerhøyt beige skum. Lukter brent karamell, maltekstrakt og kandis. Fyldig. Kraftig søtlighet, brent karamell og brunt sukker. Noe bitterhet og alkohol. Kort.

33cl bottle from Vinmonpolet Storo, Oslo. Pours clear copper coloured with a modest, off-white head. Aroma is dominated by malt and caramel with hints of dark fruits and herbs. Sweet and caramelly and neither very pleasant nor interesting. Fair enough, but the same boring caramel as the others.

33 cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. Pours dark amber with a thin beige head. Aromas of fruits and malts. Sweet taste. Warm alcoholic aftertaste. Nice christmasbeer from CB. New design on label and bottle.
Dark amber, clear, medium off-white head. Aroma barnyard, dried fruits and alcohol. Some dried fruits in taste, hint of spices. Alcohol is sensible and gives warmth in aftertaste.

Bottle from Risør Vinmonopol. Copper. Above average amount of brown head, with some red tones. The head quickly disappears. Caramel, some malt, wort and some hop flavour. Quite thin body. Average carbonation. Low sweet and bitterness.
Caramel, dried fruits, brown sugar and malts i the aroma. Dark brown with a tan head. Medium + sweet and medium bitter. Medium body with a average carbonation. Overall totally OK, but not much more.

Christmas beer sampled in May(!). Reddish brown colour, head disappears quickly, lovely spicy aroma (to some degree reminiscent of a Belgian strong ale, but less complex), mouthfeel is rather thin, flavour dominated by spices and caramel sweetness. Acceptable aftertaste that could have lasted longer. Not a bad brew, but several other Norwegian strong version Christmas beers are better.
Sampled cask conditioned. Golden coloured. Flowery nose. Light bodied, dry, slightly salty, really flowery. Really bitter finish. A pleasant golden cask ale, but it doesn't stand out.
Bottle at White Winter Winery on Nov. 18, 2011. Amber pour, taste was caramel and earthiness. Wasn’t my favorite on this stop, but it was okay.

First time mead, sharing with my bro. Thanks to my co-worker for picking this up from the brewery. Pours an amber color with a thin bubbly off-white head. Aroma is caramel malts, aged wood, and some earthy peat. Taste is much like a barley wine with some peat and earthy characteristics. Quite enjoyable.

First time with a mead. Pours a clear, dark ruddish-brown. Aroma is somewhat like a barley wine but with some vinuous aspects. Taste is some caramel, wood flavors, light vinuous flavors. Pretty close to barley wine with more wine aspects. Pretty drinkable and enjoyable.

I didn’t really get the honey aspect of this, but if someone had raved about this as a great dopplebock, I would agree with them. Pours a deep clear red-brown, with a little bit of sediment and an ongoing effervescence. A large, rocky tan head deposits ring after ring of lace. Aroma is decidedly vinous, with port-wine elements. Cider and caramel also present. Flavor is rich and malty, raisins dominate. Gets spicy and slightly fusel in the middle, but here that’s somehow not a flaw. Cloves, citrus zest detectable. Finishes somewhat dry. Medium bodied, very lively mouthfeel.

Bottle. Dark amber with a large off white head. Lots of lacing. Sweet aroma of carmalized barley and hops. Thick palate. Flavor is a nice sweet start with a malty middle and a bitter sweet finish. This is by far the best mead I’ve ever had.

Name: Traditional Brackett Date: 02/01/2006 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting clear amber, whispy off white head, spicy sweet honey aroma, huge dry honey flavor followed by an assult of bitter floral hops, tons of spicy character, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ***/4

The first beverage sampled at the RBSG ’07 Grand Tasting. From 12-oz bottle, pours a clear burnt amber colro beverage with no head or lacing. Aroma of dry wood, caramel malt and some dark cherries. Taste is light carbonated, dry with a slight sour aftertaste. Not much honey in flavor or scent.
RBSG 06. This was a mead I was looking forward too. Unfortunately it was bad. Dry and chalky. No honey or other sweetness at all. Orange color. it was still, like a mead should be.

Sampled at the RBSG 07 Grand Tasting. This is my first Brackett and I can’t say it’s my favorite mead style. Honey and malt in the aroma but and the malt flavor, while not overpowering, did seem to dominate the honey.

Approximately 1.5 oz. sample at the Grand Tasting of the RateBeer Summer Gathering 2007 in the Twin Cities, MN on July 23, 2007. This was the third of 26 "beers" that I sampled and rated during the tasting. I’m about to confess something that is going to make me look pretty stupid: I did not know this was a mead when I tried this. I just thought it was a honey-flavored beer. Please take that into account when you read the review. If I had any clue I was drinking a mead, I might well have reacted differently to it. It’s funny that, as far as I know, this was my first mead ever, and I didn’t even know it. Anyway... Honey dominates the aroma. One dimensional, but nice. Pours a clear, gold-tinted amber/bronze with a small amount of near white head. Surprisingly bitter base. Tastes almost like a honey-flavored pale ale. If I didn’t know better, and I didn’t at the time I tried it, I would have called it hoppy. Too sweet for me. Odd, almost sour finish. Light to medium body. Smooth and frothy in the palate.
Dorada, tirando a ambar, de muy abundante espuma. Aroma ligeramente frutal y lupulado. En boca es muy refrescante y bebible. Ligera, de base malteada y frutal, con contrapunto lupulado cítrico.
Very smooth Blonde Ale from Pyramid brewing. Can’t go wrong with this Summer Ale, even in the Winter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From Jun 2007 Purchased at Poplar Wine & Spirits in Casper This pours from 12oz bottle(best by 09082007) a clear light gold with a very large billowy head of foam that finally settles down after a few minutes to a fine broken layer with good lacing. The smell is pretty nice. I'm getting notes of spice and a good mix of malt and bitter hops. The taste has some biscuit malt up front and some grassy hop bitterness about midway through. The finish ends on a bitter and then slightly sour note. Interesting. It's pretty flavourful(I'm drinking it at room temp) but I don't think I could call this a session brew for me despite it's low abv. One bottle and I'm done with it for now. Bottom line: Interesting example of the style and is worth a try.

On tap at Portland Brewing, pours a clear pale blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out crisp crackery malt, not much else really. Flavour is along the same lines, with cereal malts and crackery malt. Light sweetness in there. Pleasant but not interesting. It’s fine.
Bottle in Seattle. Pale straw gold, creamy head. Malty sweet body, creamy grain. Mild sweet hop note but muted in front of creamy, touch lactic malt. Solid but not for me.
Typical blonde ale here. Pours a clear golden color with white head. Cereal grains with just a slight herbal tone on the nose; follows onto the palate. Light bodied. Finishes with grains.

Served on tap in a pint glass Appearance – The beer is served a golden orange color with a one finger head of white foam. The head of the brew has a good level of retention, slowly fading over time to leave a decent level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass. Smell – The aroma of the beer is heaviest of a bready and light caramel smell with a moderate showing of citrus and a little bit of a yeast. Along with these aromas comes some light hop smells of a floral and citrus nature. Taste – The taste begins with a rather clean malt flavor, being mainly of a doughty and caramel nature. With these flavors comes some other lighter fruit tastes of a peach and citrus nature, which grow slightly stronger as the taste moves on further. All the while the doughty takes on hints of a grainy nature with some hop flavors of a floral and citrus nature. A little bit of a yeast and a light loss of some of the sweet comes at the very end of the taste, leaving one with a rather easy going, but enjoyable flavor to linger on the tongue. Mouthfeel- The body of the beer is on the average to slightly thinner side for a kolsch with a carbonation level that is rather average. The feel is rather nice for the mix of flavors and makes for a rather enjoyable brew overall. Overall- This was a very easy drinking and quite enjoyable brew overall. Nothing super out of the world, but a nice easy drinker that is great for the summer months.

On tap at Pyramid. Served in a plastic cup in the Beer Garden. Clear golden color with medium white head. Slight citrus aroma. Grainy flavor with a slight citrus finish. Med-light body. Too much grain and not enough citrus. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

the first one i had was good enough, but in subsequent tastings, there was an unpleasant, almost skunky quality to it. i’d have thought i got a bad one if it only happened once...and it didn’t taste quite spoiled. just boring and not very good."
had this beer at Shileds tavern in anice colonial glass. It was a fair ale though nothing special but the atmosphere made it great

To look on the bright side of things, I’m 4 beers into my mixed sixer of Williamsburg. Only 2 more to go until I can move on to something else. The Stock Ale wasn’t bad, but was a pretty mediocre beer...a tad on the bitter side. I’ll say this, it poured beautifully with a really nice head that lasted the entire glass. The flavor was very average, though.

(12 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with jasonp, thanks Jason!) This bottle has aged in my cellar for awhile and when I wasn’t impressed at all by my first sip, and I was worried that I let it sit too long, but after a few more sips, it’s kind of grown on me. I just think my taster needed an adjustment as this isn’t tasting bad at all now that I’ve knocked down 4-5 ounces. Okay, now that my palate is in order, this beer tastes quite roasty, almost ashy, mildly bitter, only lightly sweet, with a mild note of sour cherries shadowing over the flavor and a mild smokiness in the finish. Aroma of roast, molasses, and again, that slight sour cherry aroma. Medium bodied and lightly carbonated, but the flavor sticks to the palate for a long-lasting finish. Ruddy brown in color and fairly cloudy to boot, so this beer has kind of a murky translucence. Small, off-white head settles quickly to a filmy layer. A pretty decent beer once I was actually ready for it.

Bottle. Aroma of soured malt, very nasty. Taste, not as bad as the aroma would suggest. This brew actually grew on me as I drank it, but only a little bit. My first impression was to pour it down the sink, but I actually drank over half the bottle before doing this. Flavour: too sweet, and a weak but ever-present sourness that I wish would go away. A slight metallic tinge. Not much complexity in the malt flavour, and barely any hops. Quite a disappointment to me. And I did not finish it, which says a lot.

Not as impressed with this Williamsburg than I am of the other beverages in this line, though I did enjoy it. A very sweet smell that is followed by an equally sweet taste. Smooth, and a very nice finish.

Hazy chestnut brown. Aroma suggestive of caramel, tea, and a bit of metal. Tea more prominent in the flavor, along with some clearly roasted, even smoke notes. There’s a sour edge in there too, someplace. Moderate body, slightly astringent finish. Not very pleasing, all told.
Very much like an alt, sweet malts with some toffee, a handful of spices in the brightly hopped finish. Very smooth palate. I really liked this, could easily drink it all day long.

Weird, I really don’t understand the low ratings here. I found this to be a quaffable, sweetish beer. Despite the brown ale labelings, anything called stock ale is going to make me expect altbier - and that’s basically what I found in this one. Its basically a softened up version of alt. A nice well rounded melanoidiny malt is the main feature here. Some slight hops in the nose, but mainly just the toffee/cookie character. The finish is balanced, and this is where it departs from being a true alt, lacking that big long bitter finish. But still, regardless of how to interpret it stylistically, I found it to be a well balanced melanoidin based ale. I would pronounce it distinctly potable. Attractive copper color, too.

Yech -- very bland -- for some reason, I expected this to be like Sam Adams Boston Stock Ale (which I personally like) but it didn’t come close. Did they use any hops at all?? Low/no carbonation -- I was very disappointed in this and I bought a whole Sixer!!!! Maybe the dog will like it, or if not the drain. Thumbs down.

Heavy cherry buttery smell, diacetyl. Some sweet maltiness. Brownish dark red, slight haze. Supposed to be bottle conditioned, but no sediment. Medium watery body, medium carbonation. Starts with sweetness, sugar, and a Jelly Belly Buttered Popcorn taste. Mild acidity toward finish. Sweetness sticks around, with some biscuit. Finish is buttery and stale, with dry cherrywood after.
Typical mass produced low alcohol pub bitter, it's ok if the pub you happen to find yourself in have nothing else
Cask at Hare and Hounds, Appleby. Clear amber appearance with medium sized lasting white head. Aroma is malty and roasted. Flavour is nutty, roasted and smooth.

Cask at the Fox & Hounds, West Burton. I've always detested this in keg and can so was interested to see what it was like in cask. Lookswise, it's much the same -amber-brown with a white head and a light sparkle (it was served in very good condition). The taste though is massively better - a decent malty flavour with sweet toffee, nuts and a dry woodiness, followed by a pleasant balancing bitterness. It is, admittedly, rather thin and watery, but that almost makes it more drinkable, and thus more suited to it's role as a session bitter. I was pleasantly surprised by this (especially the woodiness); it's such a shame that its reputation has been so badly tarnished by the godawful keg version.

Dark amber to chestnut colour, moderate sized slightly amberish white head; aroma of toasted rye bread, some floral, toasted nutty and butterscotch notes; taste of dried fruity, roasted nutty, butterscotch and floral notes; surprisingly good ale...or maybe it is just because of the atmosphere ( tasted in a pub in England during the semi-final of Englad vs. Croatia at 1:0) :)
Liverpool 2018, light brown, white head. aroma of caramel, toffee, creamy head, thin, dry, malts, ok-ish
not has this in many years but I can't say i have missed it. Low quality English ale
Cask @ The Board Inn, Howden, East Yorkshire. Chestnut brown. Clear body, malt and a touch of sweetness, bit dull really. A favourite with traditional older British bitter drinkers.
Cask at the Blue Post in North Frodingham. Dry, earthy, malty and biscuity. Better than I remembered to be fair, certainly better than the canned bitter.

Seems to be the go to pint when all the bar has is Fosters and Corona. Where do you start? It looks good, it is full bodied and the taste is creamy, malty and inoffensive (which scores it 80% of its points), but beyond that its an English old man?s session beer, sorry. A bit like silky dish water. Without sounding snobish, people buy this simply because pubs they frequent sell it and that?s what they remember getting merry on last time. Still, its not the worst beer I’ve ever had.

I was really surprised to find I had never reviewed/rated this beer having drank it thinking I have over a number of years. Anyway I had two hand-pulled pints in two different pubs while in Filey, Yorkshire on 21st Aug 2016. Bog standard, but decent UK Bitter, brown bodied, full off-white head. More maltys notes in both the nose and taste than whatever hops are used, easy drinking session Bitter than looked after correctly can (and was on the 21st Aug) be well worth trying.

This one confused five tasters at the brewpub in Seattle. Unanimous choice for the worst drainpour of the evening, completely flavorless, like drinking a glass of suds. What confused us is, why would you serve a beer like this.
Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is full of grain and nothing else. Flavor is full of grain, malty sweetness and a hint of lemon and grass. Thin mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very bland.
Sampler at Arlington brewpub. Comes as Juan Moore. Pale gold with thin white head. Mild aroma of malt and grain. Taste is weak grain and malt. Very watery.
Sold to me as Juan More Light in Dallas, Tx. Very light bitter aroma. Malty corn sweet taste. Refreshing bite. Malty sugary finish.
Pours pale yellow with very little head. Aroma is hay, light malt, pretty much just smells like a lager. Taste is a hint of watered down malt. Pretty much what you’d expect.

draft... at Humperdrinks still called the Juan Moore... piss water colored, no head... the nose has a weird peanut butter infection note, terribly off... tastes is sweet water, not much flavor, skunked finish, is what is expected
(draft 7/20/11 at CB & Potts Highlands Ranch). Clear gold color. Small white head. Light malt aroma and flavor. Short duration. Light dry finish. Thin texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

Draft. had as Humperdinks Juan Moore .. . light stuff here .. . light gold, light foam .. . good non cloying sweetness, clean .. . medium fizz.. . you know, for a light pale lager- quite well made .. . That’s impossible! How would I have gotten all four necessary drops into her cereal?
tap. water with a slight yellow tint, white head. sweet malts, and fruit overtone. thin, bland, boring.
(draught) water yellow no head. Nose of apple, butter and not much else. Taste of water, grains, old wet corn husks. This is very watery. Who the hell drinks what is essentially water?
Nice hoppy nose but a maltiness too reminiscent of American standard lagers, when it shows up.

Far more hops than the usual blonde ale and a fine soft mouthfeel that is a good vehicle for the hops. The malt action is subdued, gentled into simplicity, but there's enough character in this to make it worth consideration.
This is the beer they usually have on tap for people who aren't into drinking beer. It's OK - pretty light, but has some flavor.

Real cherry? Hey, count me in as a fan of Sam Adams Cherry Wheat, but the real thing is even better. Aroma is strong sweet/sour cherry, and emanates from an appropriately red body (including a pink-tinged head!). Flavor is a medley of typical cherry aspects: some sours, some sweets, some bitters, and some woody hints (note: some woodies was edited). I agree with hoppygrrrl that cinnamon plays a role here. I also have a hard time finding the "ale" beneath the cherry, but this is still good brew, although a notch or two below the Ichabod.
Lovely, rich, cherry color with dense bubbles, and a crisp cherry aroma (I even get some cinnamon in the nose - scent's a bit like a cherry candle). Fizzy, hoppy, bitter, and sweet. Quite good!

The aroma is sweet, flavor is rich with cherries but its also kinda skunky, Amber/red color, pink foamy head, the palate is a little on the thin side, the finish begins sweet with a slight alcohol bite and ends with a tart aftertaste, I didn't really like the tart aftertaste, but its an interesting ale that deserves a try

Very suprised at the mediocre ratings of this brew. I thought it one of the most successful pairings of fruit and ale I've tried. Beautiful deep garnet color with loads of suspended yeast when held to a bright light, a sustaining white head with a pink tinge (which may be just reflective of the brew.) The aroma is fantastic: loads of cherry, ginger, cinnamon, and some clove qualities. Full maltiness complimented by the tart cherry mouthfeel. This buries Unibroue in my opinion. A fantastic brew to bring in the summer and should cellar beautifully.

Well, there's an ale under there somewhere, it's just darn hard to find. Not impossible, though; there's some hop action that survives the tart, acidic, also slightly sweet cherry onslaught. It's made with cherry juice. I like it, but I think I like fruit stouts better. And this is way more beery than, say, New Glarus's Raspberry, IMO.
Whooa, I don''t like this.The cherry taste didnt sit well with me. I just wanted to finish it quick and get it over with.

Deep inhale of cherry brandy, looks like tart cherry juice, the taste is sharp with cherry soda action and ... soap. I'm not kidding. Might be a Cherry Ale to rival the one in Pontiac (at King's) were it not for the unmistakable soapy presence. That, combined with the cherry intensity, helps diminishing the feeling that you're actually drinking beer.
Interesting beer, dark rose colour. Not tart and not sweet. I don't quite know how to describe it, a bit acidic?

Tart and sweet at the same time. Medicinal for sure, and I liked this more than Sam Adam's Cherry wheat, for example. Refreshing but I would ease off the cherry a bit and allow the body of the beer to show through. Overall well done.

Red color. Cinnamon, spicy, sort of cough medicinish nose. Spicy, tart, some cherry flavor, quite dry. Finally a cherry beer that isn't just a lager with concentrated fruit juice and sugar added. Nice work on this one.
Not bad, but I don’t know if I would buy it. I’d be better off buying a packet of Kool-Aid. It’s a hell of a lot cheaper.

Hazy light yellowish body, thin off-white head. The aroma and flavor are essentially that of lemonade, the kind one makes using lemon concentrate (purchased in those little yellow plastic "lemons" at the grocery store), sugar, and several ounces of water. The only hint of beer is a slightly bitter aftertaste. The finish becomes cloying after awhile. If this wasn’t classified as beer I’d enjoy it more, but there is little in the world of beerdom to remark on here.

Pale gold like a belgian white. No head. Smells like a hard lemonade. Tastes like Mikes Hard Lemonade except not as sour. A little bit like lemon peel too. If you make a shandy with regular beer it tastes a heck of a lot better than this. This stuff really sucks. I have to pour out the rest of this. This is one of the worst beers I have ever had in my life. I give it a 2 in flavor simply because yes it does have some flavor even if it is horrible horrible stuff. Even my wife thinks this stuff really sucks.
I like lemonade, i don’t like shandy. I will niether recommend nor drink this beer again.
An assault on the senses: cloying, cheap, lemon drop pop. Ugh..............

Fuckin awful. I would rather toss a 80 year old's salad than suffer through this terrrible swill. The iceman, funk, and myself had a sixer of this at least 5 years ago and its shittiness still sticks out in my mind.

If you take the sh from shit , and the andy from candy then you have this sick ass product. If you've ever heard of ass in a can then this is fruit flavored ass in a can, and its 2.5 percent. Maybe I'll have one after i finish my odoul's.
Well, it's not bad, but it's not beer. Does what's required of it, I guess.

Sparkles in the glass (didn't know until I saw soemone else's). Slight grain tannins, mildly spritzy but that's welcome, a little more deeply roasted than my favorite browns and yet there's some good cocoa in there along with some interesting esters. This was another happy accident in brewing -- a creative mixture of two beers to come up with something different. Another reason to rate outside of styles.

Pours dirty and murky into a British tulip imperial pint glass. The rusty chestnut tint is a lovely sight for traditional Olde English style Bitter ale enthusiasts. The aroma is bit underwhelming for such malty beer, but a pleasant roasted coffee smell prevails. This Ale is full flavored and hearty, revealing hints of walnut and roast malts. Definitely more suited to cold weather, but I'm slurping it down in 80 plus degree Pittsburg, CA and it's devilishly satisfying. The finish is long for a non barrel aged beer, caramel and boozy heat makes it a great dessert. Over all this is a solid representation of the style. Cheers EJ Phair!
Amber in color. Lots of toffee and caramel in the nose and flavor with hints of chocolate malt and roast. Good.

On tap @ EJ Phair - Concord. Ruby colored beer with a small off-white head. Big time sweetness of table sugar, caramel, and toffee. Light pine hop character to go with it. Has some fruity ester qualities to it as well. Maybe a light nuttiness to the flavor? It’s just very sweet and intensely sugary for me. Not a fan.

Draft. Red/orange color small head. Sweet hops, citrus and toasted almond aroma. Medium body with a long dry nutty finish. I wouldn’t say its an amazing Belgian Strong, it feels more like a really nice hoppy brown. Either way it’s definitely pintworthy.

A decent red, but something weird about it. Pours a great amber color with a tan head. Smells fruity. Taste is fruity too, but a strange aftertaste. Had at tap at the Bay Area Craft Beer Festival ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A - Served a clear copper-red color with a thin layer of white head. The head fades down slowly leaving behind some good lacing. S - Aroma is a mix of rich tasted caramel malts with some light dark fruit sweetness and a hint of booze. T - Starts off with sweet rich caramel malts with a touch of spice. Through the middle some more malt flavor comes through with a bit of hop and some light booze. The finish is a mix of rich malts with some light spice and a touch of booze. M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a mellowing warming and a sweet finish. D - Very drinkable. Pretty good balance of flavors but just maybe a touch thin bodied.

Glad to see E.J. Phair brewing again, although they have have been hit or miss in the past. This had a strong and clean malt, muted hop flavor but overly bitter. Still worked out okay, but not quite there.
Only house beer on tap, guess they’re not brewing until November probably. Clear golden with a fluffy white head. Good strong fruity and grainy aroma and taste with a crisp finish.

On tap at EJ Phair Appearance: Slightly cloudy amber with a off-white head and nice amount of lacing in the glass Aroma: Caramel, biscuity and sweet malts Taste: Caramel, sweet malts and a medicinal bitterness in the finish OK.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours dark copper with a sllight off-white head. Aroma is very mild and indistinct. Flavor is smooth darkly roasted caramel. Except for a mild fruitiness it hasn’t got all that much flavor and is something of a clone of Newcastle Brown, though better. It does drink really well. Ends more fruity than anything. Quite smooth.
On tap at RateBeer Best. Pours copper with small off white head that lasts. The aroma is citrus and pine. Medium body, grass, earth, pine, bitter finish, good.

Draft @ RateBeer Best 2017. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty spicy hoppy aroma. Fruity malty spicy hoppy flavor with weak hints of citrus. Has a fruity malty spicy hoppy finish.
Sample at RateBeer Best. Clear dark gold, white head. Aroma of grain, fruit. Taste similar to aroma with pine and citrus notes. Fairly bland overall.

On tap @ RBWG 2016. Gold colored beer with a white head. Not my kind of beer. A lot of cracker, popcorn, and cereal. Very grainy bitterness. Some grass, citrus, and old hops. Kind of musty. Moderate sweetness, some potpourri, and dried grass. Just was’t a big fan of this.

[1/30/16] Draught sample at RateBeer Best awards ceremony at Hyatt Vineyard Creek Hotel in Santa Rosa. Hazy golden. Grainy aroma with some hops. Flavor is quite dry, grainy, with bitter floral hops. Medium-bodied.

Good beer. Was surprised at the hop bill and how well it worked. Crisp fresh and tasty, with hop balls. Almost IPA but nicer and easy going. Pale gold amber. Palate was right on. I liked the brew, get some.
Had on tap from the brewpub. Pours ambery colour, skunky aroma, highly carbonated. Nothing special.
Blond colour. Flavour of pale malts and fruity hop. Simple and easy to drink beer.

Returning from redwood state park and stopped in at the dump of a pub that is stumptown. The three brews they had were nondescript or skunked. This was the best of the: pale malt, caramel. grass maybe. musty. 6.6

A golden ale with a thin white head. In aroma, a very herbal malt with light floral hops, with fresh grasy notes. In mouth, a crisp malt with a more British hops, clean and crisp. Medium bodied. On tap at brewpub, August 16 2009.

Bomber poured a clear reddish brown woth a small lasting tan head. Aromas of toffee, brown sugar, caramel, oak, vanilla and dried fruit. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of toffee, brown sugar, oak, light vanilla and a hint of dried fruit with a smooth dry lingering toffee finish.

"next to Bourbon aged Olde Bluehair, there was no vanilla to speak of in this beer. not a bad beer, but it was the first letdown from previously dependable Mammoth Brewing. Aroma was a nice balance of sweet musty malts and hops, but was a little flat. Dark, almost black ruby tinged body. The flavor was ok as well...for a porter. NOT a big beer worthy of a Brewer’s Reserve label. The body was the weakest link...10%? Really? Olde blue hair at 8.75 had twice the body. Mammoth’s weakest offering to date. Average beer overall, subpar for the style."

A hazy red/brown coloredbeer, with a thick beige hed. The aroma of some fruits, ike orange, with vanilla notes and some hop. The taste is fruity sweet. Red fruit and notes of hop. The aftertaste is sweet with some bitter notes.

(22oz bottle thanks to ericandersnavy at RBWG) clearish ruby-brown with soapy tan bubbles. Nose of rich caramel, honey, grain mash, faded hops. Taste of watery grain, honey, medium sweetness, well carbonated, creamy, and light alcohol presence.

Bottle. Clear dark amber, with a Fizzy off white head. Not terribly pretty. Caramel, vanilla, sweet malt, and notes of oak. The body is very light for the style. Very easy drinking, but the lack of body is a major downside.
Bottle shared during RBWG Clear dark amber with a small off-white head and some lacing. Toasted malts, woody, vanilla and sweet caramel. A nice beer, smooth.

2/25/12. Bottle shared during RBWG 2012. Slightly hazed red pour with a small khaki head. Chocolate in the aroma with a bit of dark fruits. Somewhat light flavor with a ton of chocolate and malty aspects. Interesting.
Bottle as shown. Pours a dark amber with an of white head. Vanilla oak malt aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a sweet vanilla and oak woth sweet finish.
Bottle shared with Timfoolery. We’ve had this one for awhile so decided to crack it. Not as big as I thought it would be, but still had a nice full flavor. Good brew!!
Bottle from 2009. Listed as an old ale, but is a barleywine on the bottle? It had that typical hint of bubble gum and a nice caramel malt flavor. Very good beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had on tap.This had a somewhat fragrant aroma of malt and barley.Color was orange-amber.I was very disappointed by the taste.I was expecting that "bock" taste.What was dominating was that crappy golden beer flavor.Had a very light malt flavor.I thought this beer sucked pretty hard.I gave it away to someone who apparently didn’t know a good from a bad beer.

Medium orange color. Small head. Aroma is fruity and sweet. A medium bodied Bock. Malts are fruity, slightly sweet and a touch nutty. Hops are floral and slightly bitter. Nicely balanced, mildly flavored bock. The fruitiness of the malts is well balance by the hops. No alcohol bite at 7.8%. Nice dry finish. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
Rich carmel color, with a small amount of head. Nice fruity nose. Malty sweet goodness with a wine-like taste.
Light carmel with a thick round feel, off-crisp, semi-dry and cookie flavors.
[2/3/16] Draught at The Good Hop in Oakland. Clear golden. Strong sage aroma. Flavor has sweetish malt, a bit of fruitiness, a tart note, and lots of sage. Medium-bodied.

After the rain in the high desert...that’s what this beer smells like. A refined but rich take on white sage that compares favorably to Crooked Stave’s Colorado Sage Wild Saison, which also uses white sage (and lemongrass).

One of my favorite beers hands down. Suprisingly spiked with a delicious sage flavor which takes it over the top. The tripel wheat flavor is solid and a perfect baseline to allow the amazing sage flavor to shine through. Will always be one of my holy grails and i wish they bottled it *hint hint*

On tap at Hog’s Apothecary. It pours a nice golden color with a tall white head. The aroma is very fragrant with sage, rosemary, spruce and a little background dried fruit. The flavor is full with ripe fruits and a perfect blend of spices and yeast derived phenolics. Aromatic with some nice sage in the aftertaste. Balanced and super tasty. Awesome.

This is one of my favorite, if not my favorite, triples in the world. The sage works in wonderfully with the classical triple aromas: banana, shortbread, vanilla,lots of belgian yeast. Pours a majestic clear hazy yellow, with prominent head, taste is very sweet and aromatic. Just delightful stuff by Craftsman which is, again, THE most underrated brewery I know of! Amazing!

Tap at Neighborhood. Full haze light golden. Thick white foam. Excellent lacing. Nose is bright sage, white pepper. Taste is thicker than, spicy white pepper, sage, mint, chamomile. Similar to Cellar Door order Cuvee des Fleurs. Abv is higher for being normal saison buy comes across similar to Dupont Avec les bon Voeux. Nice albeit stickier and heavier.

On tap. Pours a golden orange with a small white head with some lacing. Aroma is of sage, Belgian yeast, candied sugar, some banana, and some caramel malt. Taste is similar with unique earthy spicy sage notes, Belgian yeast, banana, candi sugar, some cloves, and some caramel malts. Has a medium body with a semi creamy mouthfeel and a dry, spicy, sweet finish. Overall, a pretty tasty and interesting herb beer that was much better then I thought it would be.
On tap at Monk’s Kettle for a Craftsman dinner. Sensory overload on all aspects of this great beer. The sage is so unique and pronounced. You can even tell the base beer is top notch.

Draft. Rich amber beer with a dark cream colored head. Yeast and sage aroma with malt. Fruity, yeasty flavor with earth, spice,and sage. Medium bodied. Fruitiness and yeastiness lingers with spice and sage.
On tap at Monks Kettle. Pours copper with a decent off-white head and an herbal aroma. There is a a sweet caramel malt flavor with some heavy duty sage and some banana ester.
750ml bottle. Poured an orange color with a smaller sized head. Spices, citrus, yeast, and caramel. Spices where there but somewhat muted. Overall this one held up decently.

Bottle at Woodshop 6. Pours with hazy golden hue and a large white head. That slowly fades. Aromas are estery, light phenol, honey, bready and mint. Light citrus notes. Flavors are fruity, honey, pear, peach, bready. Estery. Lavender and dried apricot. Medium spice. Dry finish, lively bubbles. Seems to have held up quite well.

Bottle (from the november 2005 RB-tasting at Dixens place - notes have been damaged by flooding of my basement, but this was such an insane tasting for me as I was new to such massive tastings, so I gave up on the detailed notes quite early). Hazy, clinging head. Citrus, peach, hops, nuts and velvet.
Maltzilla!!! Honey colored. Smells and tastes of an herbal mead mixed with a saison. Pretty crazy flavor!!!

A: The pour is a goldenrod sort of color with a large white head that displays some pretty good retention. S: The nose offers up some good spice notes/yeast esters along with bready malts and a moderate sweetness. The citrus notes are pretty much gone on this one, but there is a hint of lemon and lemon zest. T: A fair amount of spice notes opens up the palate: pepper, ginger, and citrus rind. Mildly sweet and bready malts round things out. M: The body is medium with a lively carbonation to it and a really long finish. D: This beer does show some signs of decay, but it has actually held up quite well. That said, I wouldn’t necessarily advise hanging on to this much longer.

In short: A (probably once excellent) spicy rustic Saison that is past its prime How: Bottle 750ml. Exact age unknown but obviously a few years (too many) old. Tasting session with Montreal crew The look: Cloudy dark golden body topped by an off-white ring of foam In long: The nose is spicy and with a nice Saison character that is more rustic (old dusty attic, rusty) than wild. Taste shows decay. Oxidation, minerals, cookies, herbs, pepper, rust, ginger. Mild tartness. Dry finish with minerals and spices. Body is rather thin. The oxidation sadly overwhelms the Saison yeast character. Age has not been good to this beer. This was probably once an amazing beer because I still enjoyed it despite being obviously past its prime. I wish I could have had it a few years ago but sadly I came too late. Usually my problem is that I come too soon.

2005 bottle shared by CaptainCougar at the DC Local Gathering. Pours a pale, orange amber with a thin, cloudy white head. Smells like a good oatmeal cookie, spices, ginger, sweet dough. Flavor has a slight sour pucker, spice, ginger, slight pepper, oranges, candied lemon peel. Finish is slightly salty, slightly sweet and slightly sour.

750ml aged bottle shared by CaptainCougar. Murky orange-brwon color. Crazy unique gingerbread aroma. Lots of ginger and herbal sweetness in the flavor. Very soft on the palate, with some black pepper as well. Fluffy and light. GIngerbread really comes through solidly to me, with some brown sugar smooth out by the funky, at times tart, herbs. Unique and quite enjoyable.

750ml bottle - Pours a very cloudy deep amber color with a medium sized thin off white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma has notes of basswood honey, apple cider, bay leaves, orange zest, candied giner, light caramel and mildly toasted oak. Flavor has continental malts, light caramel, seville oranges, tart apples, grains of paradise, apple cider vinegar. Finish is mildly tart and fairly dry. Overall a very interesting beer. Although I’m not that experienced with saisons, this doesn’t seem very traditional. Nevertheless, it is very unusual and fairly good.

Thank you Guy! for this treasure. This aged (unlabeled) 750 ml bottle poured murky like unfiltered cider with aroma of coconut and currants. Tastes like coconut oil and raisin paste, and I have to agree with Brad that this one tastes also like marzapan. Medium bodied and multi-layered; remarkable for undetectable hops or alcohol, while still not cloying and still balanced.

Bottle @ Hotel. Thanks, Alex. Black pour with only mild carbonation and a khaki head that doesn’t last long. Sort of a musty, oxidized nose. A lot of soy sauce and herbs. Licorice, some cocoa powder, and chocolate syrup. The flavor is a touch ashy and is fairly roasty. A really heavy dose of soy sauce and old herbs makes this sort of weirdly savory. A lot of old milk chocolate. Some caramel and grass. Just kind of stale.
Bottle shared at the Woodshop Quad. Flavors of caramel and sweet fruits. Very good and thanks to who ever donated this bottle.
Pours golden orange with a decent off white head. Nose is sweet citrus fruit, yeast and caramel. Quite interesting.
750mL bottle at Woodshop Quad. Amber color. Lightly sweet. Easy to drink. Excellent. Surprized at how well this has kept.
Bottle at Woodshop Quad! Pours orange with a bright white ring. Nose is sweet and tart. Taste is sweet , rich and malty, great!
Thanks to Chris! Caramel, spice, citrus, soft malts, fruits, some sweets...age is apparent. Badass beer...for which I’ll probably never get to try again
(sample from chis c.)ruby red with a light brown head.malty body with apples and spices.its held up well..

Bottle shared at Cleveland tasting. Pours a cloudy brown color with a decent beige colored head. Aroma is caramel, light citrus, yeast. Flavor is spicy, orange, malt, raisin, I get this spice, however not the rosemary it says was in the boil. Palate is smooth, medium bodied, medium carbonation, finsihed spicy and a tad warming, with a touch of tartness. Nice!

Tasted at Cleveland tasting on 8-23-08. Thanks!! Bottle pours a dark brown color with off white head. I surprised this was a saison. Considering its been aging a while this may be normal. Has a nice sweet aroma consisting of sweet malt and some slight citrus. Taste is smooth tart flavors, but it isn’t really tart. Sweetness and some spice on the finish round out this brew. I was pleasantly surprised by this brew. Overall it was a nice aged brew.

Dr. Bill’s tasting. Poured a hazy light brown color with a thin off-white head. Sweet aroma with a mild tartness and light oxidation to the malt. Some notes of cola and spice. Mild alcohol. The flavor had a mildly sweet start with a long spicy finish. The flavor dried out quickly. Medium body with alcohol warmth.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Rating #400. Paso Robles location. Nice looking stout. Deep dark color with good head. Nose of chocolate and espresso. Taste was much more subtle than the nose, and not as creamy as the description would have you believe...but an okay beer.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Smooth creamy and sweet with roastiness in the toffee range. Packs a mild hop punch. Delicious.

A: The pour is a dark amber color with a tan head. S: The nose is quite smokey and salty with a big of a woody/bacon/nut aroma to it. T: A ton of smoke, wood, and salt flavor to this that is somewhat astringent and not all that pleasant. M: The body is medium with a moderate level of carbonation. D: Not the most intense of the smoked beers I’ve had, but you still have to really enjoy the smoke to want to drink too much of this one.
Clear amber with a medium beige and creamy head. Aroma had toasted malt, smoke and caramel. Flavour had plenty of smoke, roasted malt, caramel and hints of hops. Finished dry and smoked. Nice.

On tap at Blue Palms. What an odd beer... Pours with an amber-orange pour with a large off-white head with great lace. Aroma is leathery, chocolate, cherry and toffee. Taste is celery, leather, berry, chocolate, herbs and a spice I cannot pinpoint. Quite odd and unique, but pleasant. Lively carbonation, some pine needles, medium bodied.
Had on cask at the York. Strong and smooth. A bit of tartness. Some cherry notes followed by a traditional old ale base. Good and complex.

<!-- i -->Draught at Lucky Baldwins, Pasadena<!-- /i --><!-- br -->Deep ruby brown in color. The taps were quite warm this day so the beer initially poured almost entirely foam which took nearly seven minutes to settle. Rather lactic smelling, almost gueze like. Quite smooth on the palate with a bit of a spicy finish.

Medium orange color. Medium white foamy head. Aroma is fruit, orange and malt. A medium bodied American Strong Ale. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are spicy. Orange flavors throughout this beer. Nicely balanced. Very smooth. No alcohol bite at 8%. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
clear golden ale, some bitterness up front with a smooth finish. Lots of orange notes in the flavor throughout

Dark orange beer that builds a huge tan head with the consistency of whipped cream. Citrus nose.Medium body. I get slightly bitter orange coming at me when I taste this. One of the highlights of the fest for me.

Good hoppy & creamy aroma permeating from deep dark bronz..Light tan head..hops are up front with a very nice fruity malt background...Some licorice root w/ fresh mint leaves and a big ass can of Fresh
Herbal, earthy, some mineral saltyness, like an APA gone wild, peppery finish.

On tap at Eagle Rock. Really an odd beer. Pours with a hazy golden body and a white head. Aroma of orange blossom, honey, spice, lavender and banana esters. Taste is herbal, banana pancakes, syrup, spice and mandarin orange infused butter. Lively bubbles.
Like and orange crush in glass! Orangish red in color, with almost no noticeable hops. Good but not great.

On tap at Toronado San Diego. Pours with an amber body with little head or lacing. It’s slightly sweet and spicy wtih a hint of orange. The spicyness is a little much...I think this could have been a much better beer if the spice fit with the orange a little better. Light to medium bodied, tingly from the carbonation and a touch warming.

I remember when I moved to CA in August they were out of this at Lucky Baldwin’s. Now that I see the cycle of a year I know when they are in stock. Warms my heart. ANYWAY... a nice fruit beer, though not as fruity as some might like. I had to search a little too hard for the orange, and even then came up with mostly orange peel.

Lightly malty aroma with a little light orange. Orange amber color. More beer than oranges in the initial flavor. Nice malt profile. Finish is a very nice natural orange flavor - like orange juice. A nice fruit beer.

Ninth sample Stone Anniversary Fest XI. Pours amber with a bright white ring of a head. Nose has a bit of orange in it. Taste is sweet oranges with the taste of an amber ale. Sweet overall not bad, a little to much like Iced Tea.
Tasted at Stone XI Party. Clear red copper with no head. Honey and orange aroma and taste with a bready finish.

Is this an amber ale with some orange or a fruit beer that has an amber ale basis? Whatever... The orange flavor nicely complements the beer. Wish I’d see this on tap more often. Had this at the stone 11th.

Facinating beer - maybe the first orange fruit beer I’ve ever tried. Big sweet juicy orange aroma, bitter smooth flavour, and subtle maltiness made this an interesting offering. I’d definitely try this again, its not like other fruit beers that just taste like sparkling fruit juice.

Sampled on tap at Lucky Baldwin’s, June 2007 The beer is lightly hazy with a darkish honey amber color. The head is frothy, tan colored and starts out about a finger and a half thick and even leaves some lacing on the sides of my glass. The aroma is not as orange smelling as I was expecting; soft notes of oranges zest, some pith aromatics (which could be a malt contribution). There is a touch of biscuit like malt, but all in all the aroma is quite muted overall. The taste is lightly sweet and citrus flavors accentuate a light tartness. This almost has a creamy mouthfeel to it, though it is quite light bodied. There is something here that reminds me of watered down orange juice (I would hope that actual juice was not used for this, but you never know). This is not bad, but it seems a bit washed out. It makes me wonder if they in fact did use orange juice instead of orange peel (which is actually were a lot of the flavor is).
Tap at the brewpub. Pours Amber with a creamy white head. Aroma seems floral pine with nice caramel. The malt is fairly strong, but the is bitter enough to handle it. Sturdy IPA.
Sampler at the brewpub. Mild floral hop aroma. Flavor is mostly floral hops as well. Fairly earthy.

on tap-pours a light tan head that laces and slight hazy gold color. Aroma is sweet citrus-grapefruit/lemon/pine, some malt. Taste is sweet citrus-grapefruit/lemon/pine with some bite, secondary sweet light/medium malt. Nice gentle IPA.

Pours a chill hazed, rusty amber body, with a creamy, tightknit, offwhite head that floats two fingers above the body. Exceptional head retention eventually drops into fluffy clumps of sticky lace. Lots of minute bubbles are apparent in the body, madly rushing upward. Very nice to behold. Aroma is inviting and heavy handed. Fresh, leafy, hops lead off with citrusy grapefruit, orangerind, and spruce. Some toffee and caramel notes become more apparent as it warms. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a velvety carbonation and a tingly bite of fresh hops resin. Taste is surprisingly, well balanced. Hoppy bitterness is dry and assertive, with grapefruit, citrus rind, and spruce. Sweet/Tart tangerine and a dollop of clover honey emerge after a few minutes of warming. A solid malt backbone of toffee and caramel becomes prominent at room temperature and provides a superlative balance to the bitter, leafy, hoppiness. A note of clover honey chimes in, as well, as the citrusy aspect veers toward a sweeter tangerine and pink grapefruit presence. Some mild alcohol warmth adds to the complexity near the finish.
Light yellow, very light for an IPA. Sweet hopped nose with vanilla, peaches, grapes... really nice. Good bitterness, like chinook hops... crisp.
Tap. Dark golden color with a tan head. Good hop aroma. Bitter flavor yet rather generic.
Cascade and Yakima Chief hops all over this one. Huge pine, pepper and juniper in the nose and finish. This is nearly 100% organic to boot. Excellent and packs a whallop.

Draft. Nice pine/citrus hopped nose. Slight smoked malts in the aroma as well. Transparent copper with a whitish head. Extrememly grapefruit bitter to start. Mellows but remains hoppy throughout. Quite one-dimensional.
Hoppy aroma. Copper color with a nice creamy head. Hoppy, but not too bitter. Easy drink. One of my fav. beer in college.
Aroma is sweet and hoppy. Flavor is intensely hoppy -- floral and slight grapefruit. Still, the hops don''t oppress, overwhelm or leave it with a one-dimensionality. Nice beer.

Uhh...it''s actually "naughty fish", but I''m sure someone''s already mentioned that. A good pale ale, with that american twist. Lots of cascade and maybe columbus hops, with a light malty background. A good drink, especially after busting your ass doing some chore your wife tells you to do. Please believe it!
A good beer from the former head brewer at Trout Brook. Good amount of hops. Very drinkable.

Nice copper colored beer, the head is generous, creamy, beige and lace last forever. Nose is malt, a hint of citrus, the front is lightly sweet, the top is light. The beer has an acidic finish, dry, decent hop presence an a fine "Session" beer. Ranks #646 on my current master beer list.

Clear gold. Foamy white head. Light carbonation. Hoppy aroma, dominated by citrus notes. Crisp and clean and hoppy. Very dry, lacks malt depth and balance. Remains drinkable and hoppy enough to keep your attention despite the lack of balance. A good session brew, that doesn't require much effort.

Bottle. Cloudy, orange with small white head. Aroma is sour lemon, slightly sweet, citrus. Flavor is very sour lemon, sweeter, wheat. Body has a pretty intense sourness with big bubbled carbonation. Sour lemon all around.

Murky dark gold yellow color with great two finger head. Explosively carbonated, no joke. Just about lost an eye when I popped off the cap. It burst off and ricocheted off my ceiling. Needless to say, this was one of the most aggressively carbonated beers ive had, which actually worked very well with the beer. Lots of citrus and some banana flavors. Some tartness and spices too, but not a ton. Medium light bodied. I had a hoegaarden after this one, and much to my surprise because of the kings carbonation, the hoegaarden tasted flat.
bottle. has an aroma of wheat and grapes.pours a golden yellow with lots of carbonation and little head.bit of an orange flavor with a bitter finish. good but not as good as expected.
Clear pale body with a tiny white head. The aroma is banana, bread and light clove. The flavor is banana, metallic and cotton candy. Medium/light body with soft carbonation.

Cloudy straw gold with a couple inches of sudsy off white foam. Very good head retention, sparse foamy lacing. Sweetish wheat and clove in the aroma. Sweet bready wheat flavor with some pungeant spice and yeast character. A touch of white pepper. Green hop and tangerine bitterness in the finish and into the aftertaste. Medium body, solid carbonation. A nice Americanized version.

12 oz bottle pretty fresh. Poures a dark orangish with a little haze no head whatsoever. Aroma were slightly wheaty with some yeasty spice. Flavors were mild with some clove and wheat light citrus as well Not a big beer but not bad

King Weissbier ("Bavarian Style Wheat Beer"). I assume this rating belongs here. Hazy orange-yellow body, thin off-white head. Banana, clove, and bubblegum aroma. Typical hefeweizen flavors of banana and clove, pretty potent on those notes, with a slightly tart, spicy finish. Creamy, somewhat heavy-feeling body. A bit undercarbonated. Decent.
On tap: Yeasty banana aroma. Dark cloudy orangish-yellow with a small white head. Yeast and banana up front with a light citrus finish. A little watery.

Tap. Wow, the other guys must have had a bad batch. I had this one at Kings. It was a pleasure to watch. Poured into the proper glass, this one was just a flurry of bubbles, with a great head and beautiful golden color. The bubbles just kept coming. Great aromas, fruit and malt. This one roils around in your mouth, the flavors are on the sweet side, very good.

Draft at 2004 MBG Summer Festival. Poured a very, very small white head with fine sized bubbles. Uncarbonated, cloudy and a yellow hue. Malty, banana, spicy and clove aroma. Malty, sweet, banana, spices and clove flavor from start to finish. Smooth palate. Medium bodied beer with fair lacing.
Decent tasting amber. Not worth the cost though. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Fruity aroma (cranberry like), amber ale isn't a way to describe this beer, super fruity and an alcholic kick in the finish..this super strong ale weighs in at 9% alcohol
fruity, mainly from dried cranberries, and blessed with a floral/spicy aroma. very Belgian in character, warming and unique
Touch of cranberries, honey, cinnamon, curacao and coriander. Light medium bodied but full aroma and flavor.

The head is ok, the body brown. It smells malty, bit alcoholic, darkmalty, grain. The taste is malty, bit dry bit alcoholic-dry, maltaromatic, less hoppy. Nice, not that sweet like the most Dopppelbock in Germany but on his dry way very tasty.

Draft at Bel-Aire, recommended by Ray, thank you sir! Nice variegated amber brown color, small beige head with good retention. Aroma of lightly toasted caramel and nuts. Taste is sweet and malty with a bit of roasted nuts. Very nice.

Bottled. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel as well as lighter notes of pumpernicle bread, alcohol, and honey. The flavor is sweet with notes of cardboard, dusty hops, caramel, and alcohol, that makes its mark felt on the tongue. The finish contains a bit of strored fruit. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

Chocolatey with allspice and candied fruit aromas and flavours. A pleasant drop made well but not as forceful as authentic doppelbocks that I have tasted in the past. But credit where it is due, at least it is within style guidelines unlike a certain mainstream NZ brewery’s doppelbock down to the -ator name.

Bottle. Pours a deep mahogany brown with a brief medium brown head. Aroma is very nice-- sweet brown bread, molasses, chocolate. Oddly, these all fade before the glass is half consumed, leaving a woody caramel aroma behind. Flavours of bread crusts, treacle, chocolate, and hints of coffee are all nice. Medium bodied, and despite the ABV there is no trace of booziness or alcohol. Finish is mildly bitter. Nice.

Bottle 33cl. Clear medium red - brown amber color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, bread - grainy. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. (220808)

(Bottle 33 cl) Clear, deep amber golden with a small, off-white head. Sweetish aroma of hard roasted malt and pumpernickel. Solid and full body with notes of sweetish roasted malt and pumpernickel. Finishes dry. 220808

Bottle, shared by papsoe. It pours an amber, clear body with a decent beige head. Malty nose with caramel and beefstock. The flavor is on the malty side too, with a little fruity touch. Caramel, beefstock and some roasted notes. Caramel-malty finish. Medium body with a pleasant cabonation. Far from my favorite doppelbock, but a decent beer. (080822)

12 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden hazzlenut brown with a lacing off-white head. Barley and malty roasted aroma. Sweet flavour of barley, caramel and mild breadish. Lingering malty and slight breadish. Light alcohol presence and warmth into the finish.

Bottle, pours a deep brown colour with a large foamy off white head. A malty aroma, sweet and a little grainy, with noticeable alcohol and vinous hops. A full malty palate, chocolately, with the finish interestingly mellow but short. Can’t put my finger on exactly why, but I like this.

column1: Mussel Inn Captain Cooker Manuka Beer
column5: Amber-brown, really nice bright fruity tip note. That manuka tip note is bright, the base amber is ok, and that.

column1: Mussel Inn Captain Cooker Manuka Beer
column5: Bottle. Huge spiy, resinous nose. Sweet and spicy with resins from the manuka tips. Wax, chocolate, caramel, soft body, cinnamon spice. Not my thing. Too strong in the resins.

column1: Mussel Inn Captain Cooker Manuka Beer
column5: On tap. Pours orange brown. Peach, honey, sage, little synthetic grape, lemon. Decent body. Good stuff.

column1: Mussel Inn Captain Cooker Manuka Beer
column5: On tap at Brew Craft Beer Pub Tauranga. Slight hop aroma with pine and sulfur notes. Dark amber brown with OK head which dissipates quickly. Mild bitterness with smooth malt body and lingering hop bitterness. Also a slight astringency perhaps from the Manuka. Not bad by any stretch.

column1: Mussel Inn Captain Cooker Manuka Beer
column5: Draft at Hashigo Zake in Wellington. Clear reddish amber color with a small head. Aroma is very herbal, wood, berries. Flavor is medium sweet, herbal slight bitterness, stone fruits. Medium bodied, well carbonated. Interesting.

column1: Mussel Inn Captain Cooker Manuka Beer
column5: [8223-20160510] Tap. Floral taffy and herbal wildflower cleaner and nail polish remover aroma. Clear, dark amber body with a quick foamy white head and some light lacy lacing. Bitter floral evergreen taffy flavour has a floral sweet cleaner-like finish. Medium body. Interesting but strange as a beer. (7/3/6/3-/11) 3.0 (@ Brew, Rotorua, NZ)

column1: Mussel Inn Captain Cooker Manuka Beer
column5: 2016-05-10. Crisp dark amber body, modest off white head. Aroma has an interesting almost spicy green herbaceous vegetation character that reminds me a bit of Anchor OSA. Flavour is interesting, green herbaceous character, moderate bitterness throughout. Average bodied palate, good carbonation. Tasty, fairly different. 7/3/6-7/3/15-16 On tap at Brew, Rotorua, NZ.

column1: Mussel Inn Captain Cooker Manuka Beer
column5: On tap. Artificial drug store shampoo aroma with a bit of roasted caramel. This is just an experiment which went wrong.

column1: Mussel Inn Captain Cooker Manuka Beer
column5: Pours a deep mahogany, not quite bright, with sparse, fine carbonation. Head settles to a thin pad of tight beige bubbles and manages a thin lace weave. Strange aniseedy, herbal, almost medicinal nose that also shows hints of spruce, stewed rhubarb and mushrooms, Benadryl cough medicine and paperbark. Similar on the palate; medicinal and woody with a complex herbal flavour not dissimilar to Unterberg aperitif. Dowdy, astringent berry finish with licks of aniseed, paperbark and rhubarb. Fades off quickly. Body is medium light with soft carbonation and an oily finish. Not altogether tasty or appetising. Would love to try a fresh sample; this one seems a little beyond its used by. One for a re-rate! (33cL, no date stamp, Cellarbrations Carlisle)

column1: Mussel Inn Captain Cooker Manuka Beer
column5: (On tap) Clear copper with slight white head. Nice floral aroma - rather reminiscent of rose petals.Light body and medium carbonation. Taste is light, refreshing and elegant. Slightly honey sweet, floral with a hint of stone fruit and negligible bitterness. Nice easy drinking beer.

A hint of hop smell but not much. Gold colour and average carbonation. Tastes OK, but the company makes much better than this. This beer is a carry on from the previous owners and not a Kraft bier. Definately drinakable on a hot sunny East Coast day. Would go great with prawns.

Tap pour. Pours a light gold with slight white head. Strong lager nose. Medium body with the clear lager front flavours and a hidden sweetness at the end. Would take a 12 pack of this over any mainstream lager.
330ml bottle BB 3/5/2017 Fruity aroma with a touch of malt. Pale gold color with OK head. Medium bitterness with a understated malt finish. OK for this style but nothing special.
For a lager this one is not that back - more sweet malts than expected give this a bit of flavour to at least make it interesting.

Light malt and hops. A little grass, a touch of honey, a bit of metal and a bit of plastic. Good carbonation pushes the decent level of bitterness (decent for this kind of beer) forward a tad and tingles the tongue. Better than green-bottle macro slosh.
Pale gold color with an everlasting bright white head. Pale malt flavor and aroma. Not much else. Light body.
500ml bottle pours pale & frothy, light malt grassy aroma with a bitter mildly hoppy taste that finishes quite dry, very refreshing

It’s probably about time I reviewed this beer given its long standing, but you just don’t get it in the South Island of New Zealand. It is as it says on the label, a golden lager that also has a white head and large bubbly carbonation. It looks like a classic lager in the glass and has a very light malt aroma and subtle metallic hopping. It isn’t the most complex beer - mild maltiness and little else to commend it to beer snobs. It tasted to me like Mack’s Gold used to taste prior to Lion’s takeover. An aperitif beer? I bet it has never been described as that before, but that’s how and why I had it and it fit its purpose well.
Draft at Beervana. Crystal clear pale yellow color, fluffy white head. Aroma of whitenpepper and hay. Taste is peppery straw. Light body.

The first sip reminded me of opening a bag of hops. Great drinker, interesting and unintrusive hop profile. It’s not trying to new a highly hoped pils, that is the green’s job. Instead it is an easy drinking yet satisfying pale lager. I would order this over a steinlager, stella or carona any day.
This is just a wonderful beer. Tastes great and doesn't have a bad after taste.
Based on the name and this breweries other products, I was sure that this beer would suck. But it was better than expected. A somewhat acceptable pils with a bit of hop flavour.

column1: Roosters Brew House Black Cockerels Stout
column5: Dark black in colour with thick creamy head that bar tender wiped off. Thin body but lave thin hoppy residue on roof of mouth. More of a schwartzbier than a stout. Bonus point for hand pump.

column1: Roosters Brew House Black Cockerels Stout
column5: Mellow and chocoltey to start with a hop bitterness developing late, accompanied by some decent hop flavour. Silky smooth mouthfeel.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: The head is impressive on this red/brown ale The flavour has initial light sweetness and hints of licorice, and then mostly malt and a brief hint of smoke. There is a very low bitterness in the short finish.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: 50 cl bottle. Yeast at the bottom. Reddish bown colour with a nice head. Malty aroma with notes of oak, sugar and hints toffee. Nice sweet flavour with notes of roastedness, chocolate and some hoppy finish. Ends up dry and very little bitter. Very drinkable.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Hop malt aroma and nor much else. Murky brown caramel colour with great head and lacing. Sweet malt flavour. Not expecting a sweet beer. Fizzy palate.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Pours a hazy brown with a substantial tanned head. Sweet and quite dry. Dusty with brown sugar, some caramel and roasted malts and fine tones of flowery hops. A hint of coffee in the dry finish. Wish I´d had this and other Emerson beers instead of Speight´s when I was in Dunedin.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: 12 Feb 06 - LIght fruit malt aroma. Cloudy brown colour, nice head retention. Light sweet roasted malt flavour. Tangy hop finish.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Hazy amber colour with a dense tan head. Malty aroma with hints of caramel and nuts. Malty, light roasted flavor with a faint caramel sweetness and a dry buttery finish.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Fluffy golden tan head, hazy brownreddish body. Dry and dusty aroma with lots of spices and malt. Rather sweet with tones of brown sugar. Dry sourish flavor with bready and spicy notes. Thin in the body with a bitter spicy end. An atypical brown ale and not very balanced.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Bottle. Fruity hop aroma. Cloudy chestnut colour. Malty flavour. Mouthfeel is quite swelling, too much for my liking.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: (Bottle 50 cl) In a blind tasting I would never ever have guessed this to be a brown ale. The beer has a dry, sourish tone that rather takes after a Flemish Oud Bruin. Amber coloured with some impurities. Very lively and bubbly carbonation that really fills the mouth. Very unusual. 211204

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: A hazy red-brown beer with a disappearing orange head - the haze disappears after a while. The aroma is sweet with notes of roasted bread and prunes. The flavor is sweet with notes of prunes, wood, roasted bread, and a nicely hoppy end.

column4: Malt Shovel Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Very rich and malty, almost reminded me of a belgium dubbel, could have been the use of sugar. Overall a pleasant brew.

column4: Malt Shovel Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Now i must admit I have been quite harsh towards Lion Nathan but this is quite a great beer, I enjoy all the Malt Shovel brews....They do have a habit of giving me a headache while drinking them, might be quite a high sugar content.

column4: Malt Shovel Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Sweeter, maltier, and less smoky than their other porter. Chocolate is the predominant flavour here and perhaps a bit of roasted malt once it warms up. But overall, I'm getting a sugary sweetness.

This beer has an interesting yeasty flavour similar to what is found in their wheat beers. The flavour is citric overall (from hops) but somewhat sour (from yeast). I'd prefer some more crispness, bite, and malt flavour. The yeasty flavours that work in their wheats are definitely out of place in this beer.
only upon memory from a visit there but I do remember it being one exquisite brew.

Pours a clear light yellow with a white head. No sweetness just bitterness. Does have a light caramel maltyness. Quite hoppy with aromas of pine and a bit of resin. Medium bodied. Lively carbonation. Bitter finish.

One of the last ones that I could find after the announcement that this beer is now defunct. Pours a light brown with no head, it’s never really ever looked good in the glass since they stopped bottle conditioning. Has a rather prickly carbonation to it but a lovely passion fruit nose which is probably due to it now being brewed by the hop king at steam breweries. It’s unfair to judge this bottle because it’s an old on and a wee bit dusty but I have drunk many pints of this and it’s a great beer. One of the only decent beers to be found on tap in Hamilton in the early part of this century so I owe it a huge debt!
Bottle 33cl. Clear amber body with normal size off white head. Nose dominated by hops and fruit/citrus. Flavour with bitter sweet hops.

(Bottle 33 cl) Pours a clear, deep golden with a creamy, lacing, off-white head. Very pleasant, peachy hop aroma. Medium-bodied with lightly sweet notes of caramel malt and then otherwise completely dominated by the rather sophisticated hop blend that leaves lots of flavour but not so much bitterness. A fantastic session beer. This may be based on an English style but with the Kiwi twist it certainly came out as a brilliant APA. 240108

Bottle courtesy of beer_ledgend. Pours copper white with a rocky white head. Smells of citrus, pine, some caramel, spice. Tastes earthy with some peppery splashes and elements of biscuits. Mouthfeel is full with a peppery finish.

A deliciously juicy example of New Zealand brewing. They do a fine line in pale ales brewed with local hops, and this seems to be one of the best. There’s no longer any mention of Fuggles on the label, instead referring to NZ Saaz and "other New World hops", which tends to confirm my impression that this is now closer to an APA than an EPA. It’s a cracking beer, whatever the style. There’s very little to fault, from the towering head with lashings of lace to the gloriously fresh and zesty aroma and the exquisitely balanced flavours. Loverly stuff. Gives off big drafts of lychee, passionfruit, orange Fruit Gums, gooseberry greenness and Curacao. Soft carbonation. Tart, juicy tropical fruit with some US APA-style toffee malts and pine. All very restrained and balanced. After starting an NZ holiday with a few duds, this one lifted my whole mood because I knew I had something really good to drink for the rest of the week. (330ml bottle from Scenic Cellars, Taupo)
Love this beer, this years batch of hops have a great passionfruit aroma. Such a clean taste, it’s such a pleasure to drink. Beautiful looking, beautiful tasting!
On tap @ Rosies Hastings 19/10/06. Slightly cloudy, big fruity citrus floral nose. Stonefruits, grassy & passionfruit. Big thru to the finish - love it. Nice to meet Chris too...

I was very happy to have been served this beer when I asked for a recommendation from the barman. I was served from the bottle which gave the beer lingering carbonation which lasted to the very bottom of the glass. It had boatloads of hoppy character and a lingering after-taste matched only by the beers from The Twisted Hop brewery in Christchurch. The orange and coriander complimented the weather outside (dismal) making it very much a comfort beer. The purchase price was justified by the aroma alone, which made me look forward to the next bottle.
Medium amber-orqange, almost red colour. Mild, tart cherry aroma. Initial flavour is malty with a subtle tart cherry fruit flavour and developing bitterness late.
Sampled cask conditioned. Brownish amber and slightly hazy. Neutral nose. Medium bodied. Salty, sulphuric, dry and bitter.
Fairly sweet and simple Hellas with some cereal notes, but lacks body and overall very uneventful, even very fresh.
From Hipercor. In Bavaria glass. Playing Darksiders 2. Very malty, with a bit of dank and good body. Its taste and aroma may not stand out, but its really crushable and feels very good in mouth

Muy clara y limpia, dorada. Escasa espuma, poco duradera. Aromas cereal. En boca entra ligera, con predominio dulce, cereal y contrapunto de ligero amargor. Bebible y refrescante si está bien fría. Si no debe cansar.

Clear straw color with white head. Aroma is clean, slightly lemony and grainy. Taste starts grainy with a slight honey sweetness but balances out on the finish with some clean hop bitterness. Body is medium with medium to low carbonation. Clean is the best word to describe this beer. It’s also balanced and easy to drink but it doesn’t stand out with anything.
0,33l Flasche "Drittelgold". Goldene klare Farbe mit weissem Schaum. Duft nach Grass und Stroh. Wenig Kohlensäure. Leicht säuerlich im Antrunk, herb im Abgang.

Flasche 0,5l: Golden, klar, feinperlig, kräftiger feinporiger Schaum; leichte Süße in der Nase, malzig, Getreide, leichte Würze, Mischbrot, ganz leichte trockene Hopfennoten; im Körper leichte Süße, malzig, spritzig-cremig, deutliche Kohlensäure, leichte Fruchtigkeit; angenehmer milder recht süßer Nachgang

A slight haze on this otherwise golden clear brew. Medium white head. Lightly sweet fruity aroma with some hay. Medium bodied. Flavor is simple but nice. Much like the aroma it is lightly sweet, some hay notes, and some background bread dough. Clean and refreshing. Good beer.
Bottle from Rehills, Newcastle. Hazy, very pale golden coloured with a sweet fruity and malty flavour, slight grassy notes and a slight sugary sweet fruity finish.

500ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours clear pale gold, thin white head. Aromas of light lemon, grassy hops, chalky, near-metallic note. Taste is more of the same, with some corn, which builds on the astringent finish.
Bottle leggermente dorata non molta schiuma cereale leggero maltato buona beva discreto amarob discreta secchezza nota erbacea
Hazy amber with a small white head. Nutty malt aroma with a fruity touch, a bit dusty. Dry and fruity flavour with nutty malt, some toffee and a dusty feel
500ml bottle (ChrisO’s, post-RBESG2011 Sunday) Nutty aroma. Anna gets liquorice, christ knows why. Sweet and nutty. Survived aging fairly well. Nicely dry and nutty.
Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of metal and over ripe fruits. The flavor is sweet with notes of matl, metal, and over ripe fruits.
Bottle @ Chris O’s. Thanks guys. Pours cloudy golden with a small off white head. Tart, fruit, toffee alcohol and cellar. Oxidized. Medium bodied.

Bottle 500ml.@ ChrisOs. [ Vintage ]. Clear medium red amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, oxidide, toffee, raisin - plum notes. Flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, oxidide. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20110807]
Unusual dry taste with a medium head. Doesn’t resemble any other Batemans beers I have tried. If only all bottle conditioned beers where as nice as this.

Bottle Conditioned, bought from Booth’s, Clitheroe, 500ml. Reddish amber beer with chunky white head. Wow, I don’t usually rate British bottled beers that highly, but this is a bit special. Full impact bitter with a tangy citrusy hop note and a good resinous bitter finish. This is a real belter, so why don’t Batemans make more Bottle Conditioned beers for us to enjoy. Yummy.
Brewed for a supermarket chain. Lucky supermarket. This is a russet coloured beer that is big on biscuity malts. To finish there is a slightly "oaky" aftertaste. A good bottle conditioned beer.

Cask: A little better than on the regular tap, most of the same features, although a little more of the bitterness could be tasted at the warmer temperature, great creamy head that stuck on the side of the glass throughout the pint. Keg: Kept a very nice head throughout the pint, a nice hoppy aroma & flavor, a little short on the bitterness, but a good IPA. Keg score 3.4

Thanks to Erzengel for sharing! Looks good in the glass, deep golden, nice head. Malty-spicy aroma. Starts strong, malty, spicy, light alcoholic notes. Woody hints. Finish with a sweetish-fruity touch. Not bad.

Many thanks to Erzengel for sharing! A clear deep golden beer with a small white head. Aroma of grainy malt, strong pale malt, straw. Taste of mid sweet strong pale malt, straw, hints of honey and grains.

Many thanks to Peter (pdog555) for this bottle! Nice Heller Bock nose. The beer starts mild smooth with sweetish hints. Very soft and mild, the body is moderate sweetish and easy to drink, caramel, nice Heller Bock flavour with nice malts. Not much bitterness in the back, easy to drink and very sessionable! Fantastic Maibock.

Pours a reddish-amber with a very slight yeast smell. More carbonation that I had expected. Interesting taste with a complex palate. Getting distinct hints of nuts and perhaps a slight toasted flavor. Hard to describe, I have no experience with this style. Very good beer though.
22oz bottle. Poured a golden color with an off white head. Fruity, toasted nuttiness, some earth, and caramel.

Sweet and sour malt aroma. Deep golden haze body. with only a thin head. A mixture sweet fruitiness, nuts and caramel malt. Hard to wrap my taste buds around this one. It’s not bad but it isn’t great either.
