Pale bronze/amber colour. A good, clean, straightforward bitter. Tasty and well balanced. Enough said. Would make an excellent session beer. Cask, GBBF 2004.
Tested cask conditioned. Starts off with biscuty malt flavours. Through the pint the hop flavours come through, ending with a very bitter, but pleasent finish.

Manneken Pils é produzida pela micro cervejaria belga Brasserie Lefebvre e utiliza em sua receita uma porcentagem de milho. De coloração dourada clara e translúcida, sua espuma é de média formação com bolhas e boa persistência. No nariz um bom equilíbrio entre o dulçor do malte, com um toque que lembrou açúcar mascavo sendo completados pelo aroma floral de lúpulo. No sabor tudo se repete, cereais, grãos, lúpulo floral e herbáceo. Possuindo um corpo leve e carbonatação média baixa, o final traz baixo amargor, com residual de malte. Uma cerveja leve, equilibrada, de sabor fugaz e perfeita para dias quentes!

25cl bottle as “Manneken Pils” from Rob the Gourmets’ Market in Brussels. F: medium, white, not long lasting. C: gold, light hazy. A: malty, bit herbal, bready. T: light sweet malty base, sweet malty, oxidized, bit bready, bit mineral water, medium carbonation, quite bad for the style, not good balanced at all.
Helder goudgeel bier met beperkte schuimkraag. Zeer vlak van smaak en afdronk
Bottle at Beerselse Kasteelfeesten 2019-06-28 AR: dry bready AP: clear coppery, white head F: crisp hard bread, cardboard, super dry
Gedronken als manneken pils. Goed en smaakvol pils bier. smaken van graan en een bittertje. -backlog de BierApp-
Fles Manneken Pils. Geel bier met mooie schuimkraag. Smaak is helaas erg licht en waterig, ietwat bitter maar niet echt een pilsener.Teleurstellend.
You could as well drink water. No taste there, at all. Weak aroma, no taste, no palate. Is this beer?
-On tap Røør, Oslo- Malty and cereal. Light, fresh and clean finish. Well done.
Standard lager. Not terrible. Some bittering hops, not much body. Medium carbonation.

@ Brussels, Belgium Beer Trip. Pours a golden colour with a fair white head. Aroma of corn, caramel, bready yeast and alcohol. Similar flavours with lingering corn. <><> Beeroda.hu - Beer Tasting Sessions @ Budapest, Hungary <><>

column1: Rugenbräu Mountain Twister Crazy Apple Bier
column5: Bottled 33cl. It pours an extremely pale yellow beer with no head. Fizzy. The nose is mainly of apple juice. Cloying taste. Sweet. Apple juice accompanied by beer and lemon juice. Useless.

column1: Rugenbräu Mountain Twister Crazy Apple Bier
column5: bottle. Golden yellow, thin head, aroma of apples. Tastes like carbonated apple juice, no hints of beer present. If drunk as refreshing lemonade rather than beer it is not bad.

column1: Rugenbräu Mountain Twister Crazy Apple Bier
column5: Bottled. Pale yellow in colour. Minor white head.. It has an apple like aroma, kinda like a cider. The flavour is applelike and you can taste some malt in this mix.. It has sweet and dry aftertaste. Thanks to "Dorqui" for this one.

column1: Rugenbräu Mountain Twister Crazy Apple Bier
column5: Bottled (1.5%). Pale yellow colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma of sour apple and sugar. Flavour is apple and sugar. Artificial. Extremely close to finnish ciders... "Applejuice rating #1".

column1: Rugenbräu Mountain Twister Crazy Apple Bier
column5: Bottled, alc. 1.5% (BB 09/2006). Very pale yellow, small white head. A bit artifical aroma of green apples. Basicly decent apple juice drink, sweet and slightly sourish apple flavors. Maybe notes of malts in the finish. Not really a beer.

column1: Rugenbräu Mountain Twister Crazy Apple Bier
column5: Crazy Bottle: Very light yellow, almost clear. Nose is full of fructose, sweet apple cider. The flavor is sweet, lightly tart, no hint of alcohol. Zesty, snappy finish and lightly tart mouthfeel. Good cider for drinking from a jug at the family reunion after the cobler meal. It’s just hard to consider this real cider. Thanks to Dirk for this bottle.

column1: Rugenbräu Mountain Twister Crazy Apple Bier
column5: 33 cl Bottle. Pours out a very very light almost clear. Topped with a white head. The aroma of Green apple is GREAT. The tast is just like apple juice. Thanks Dirk for this sweet little bottle

column1: Rugenbräu Mountain Twister Crazy Apple Bier
column5: 33 cl Bottle: Pale color, almost no color at all. Sweet apple aromas just like Sparkling apple cider. Coke should get this recipe - it would easily sell as an apple soda. The tastes are all apple Jolly Ranchers with a hint of malt in the aftertaste. Very tasty, just not beer. I imagine that desperate Swiss moms put this in their babies bottles when they run out of apple juice. I give this a higher rating for a fruit beer. Thanks BuckeyeBoy!

column1: Rugenbräu Mountain Twister Crazy Apple Bier
column5: Bottle pours a pelucid clear effervecent pale pale pale pale pale yellow. Very sweet apple aroma. Motts apple juice I’m thinking. Flavor is apple, marshmalow, and papery. Pallete is a bit dusty and unfiltered. Strange feel. Hides the ABV rather well. granted it’s only 1.2% (incorrect info listed) Thanks to buckeyeboy for this liquid Jolly Rancher

column1: Rugenbräu Mountain Twister Crazy Apple Bier
column5: Bottle in Hotel Alpina, Murren, Switzerland Pours a champagne-like yellow with the effervescence to match. A hint of apple is evident throughout the sip, with the carbonation really toying with the back of the throat. Palate is watery, but that’s to be excpected with the style. Maybe it was the Alps in the window in front of me, but I enjoyed the heck outta this.

Bottle, from Rhythm & Booze in Brigg. Amber gold, good fluffy white head and moderate condition. Initial peppery hop in the nose then a building worty maltiness with hints of horlicks. Thin and malty sweet in the mouth with some gentle hop floweriness, low hop and soft malt in the finish.
Cask Handpump. Clear orange color, short head. Aroma is moderately hoppy, grainy. Bitter taste and palate.

1. Cask Handpump at the Station Buffet, Stalybridge 16/11/2001 Golden coloured with citurs aroma. Poured lively. Full hop finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Unicorn, Altrincham (JDW) 24/06/2003 Golden coloured slightly pale and hoppy. Some dryness in a malt finish.
I just had it last night. It was a little sweet in smell, but bitter in taste. The colour is interesting, and cloudy before settling. Strange beer.
Cask at County Hotel (JDW) Ashford. Amber in colour, some perfumed hops on nose. Acidic in mouth and on end. Bit ordinary until you get a smack of tangy hops on the end.

Hand pulled at the British Oak, Stirchley, Birmingham. Bright yellow/orange with a foamy top. Caramel mainly, with a some slight pepper dryness. Fairly bitter, but not interesting enough and nothing like an IPA.
Clear orange color, short head. Aroma is moderately hoppy, grainy. Bitter taste and palate. (tnx caesar for notes)
Clear orange color, short head. Aroma is moderately hoppy, grainy. Bitter taste and palate.
Draught. Nice lacing left on the glass. This is a nice hoppy beer, with some sweet notes, perhaps caramel and toffee. Dry and bitter finish.
An amber beer with a huge off-white head. The aroma is nicely hoppy. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel, toffee, and aroma as well as bitter hops. A fine IPA.

On tap at Newark brewpub. Poured a dark honey brown amber color with a creamy two finger off white foamy head and nice lacing. The aroma was plain and simple, toasted malts, a touch of sweet caramel, and a lite hoppiness. The taste followed the aroma, which started off malty with toastiness and sugary caramel. Light bodied with medium carbonation. Very middle of the road, a sessional beer.

20100926 tap at Wilmington. Dark cola brown with sheeting beige head of even medium foam. Aroma is full of burnt vegetal notes, tar, burnt toast, and some floral hints as it warms. Flavor is primarily toasty malts with dark bread, walnut, mint, pine. Interesting, tasty,clean. Yum.

(cask @ GBBF). A nice meaty, chocolty ,roasty SChwarz amid all those alcoholic US beers , i though this was a decent take on a style I like. A bit minty hopped and chalky in the finish . Not bad rendition.

GABF 09. Pours a deep clear woody brown almost black- nice light beige head. Aroma is nutty, herbal, modest roast, choocolate and coffee, some black malt acrid- and burnt notes, toffee and light sweetness. Flavor is full bready toasted malt, then some nice herbal floral hops to balance and a modest sweetness, and just hints of roast and chocolate- Clean and easy drinking will more flavor than 4.4% would lead you to believe. Nice.
I liked this very much. Very nice creamy head that lasted til the end. Dark amber pour with a fruity malty aroma. Nice malty sweet taste with a hop finish. Dry at the end. Very good.

On tap at GABF 2009. Dark brown in color with reddish hues and a small tan head that leaves nice lacing. Aroma is well-balanced with roast, coffee, and grassy hops. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, nuts, and crisp grassy hops. Described as a "black pilsner," but it’s roastier than others of that style that I’ve tried. Palate is clean and crisp with medium-light body and average carbonation. Overall a very good schwarzbier.
10/2/09 notes: GABF Saturday. Nice toasty, ash chocolate nose, with dry, somewhat grassy and chocolatey body. Very flavorful for the style. Palate is clean, without being watery. Enjoyable.

Draught at BrewPub: Aroma of roasted malts, light chocolate, light coffee, and a hint of wood. Poured very dark brown/very deep amber in color with a small, creamy, tan head, that lasted throughout. Clear. Not sparkling. Good lacing. Flavor is lightly sweet. Tastes of roasted malts, light chocolate, light bitter coffee, slight wood, and a hint of nuts. Medium body. Dry, lightly chalky texture. Soft to average carbonation. Roasted malt, chocolate finish is chalky and dry. I initially mistook this for the Pig Iron Porter, but upon comparing the two, the lager characteristics of the Schwarz were very clear. Earlier Rating: 11/2/2003 Total Score: 2.2 Not as good as the porter from which it is derived. Not enough taste, though quite dry.

On tap at Iron Hill Lancaster...I hope this is the same beer...was just listed on the specialty beer menu as Schwarzbier...poured root-beer in color, off-white head...light roasty aroma with caramel, malts...flavor was somewhat light but malty, with molassas, walnut, weak coffee...not a bad beer...went down fast.
(11/8/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in North Wales. Clear reddish-amber color. Weak aroma of malt and light toastiness. Sweetish flavor with some caramel. Light-bodied.

I initially had this in Queenstown in 2005, but that location has now closed. Apparently Aukland has closed as well? The website seems to promote only Wellington and Christchurch locations. Anyway, it doesn’t matter all that much, as the beers were not very good. This was served with rather low carbonation and was very cold. A low apple-fruit aroma with a hint of caramel malt led the way, and the flavour was pretty much the same. Thin and minimally carbonated.
Dark black in colour with thin white head. Biscut and malt aroma. Thin watery body with hint of burt coffee. Dry finish.

On tap at the Hog in Queenstown. Pours a clear dark brown with a small cappuchino head. Slightly sour with a twist of burnt malts and a hint of band aid. Thinnish and kind of watery with some oilyness. Low to medium carbonation.
Not a beer I would ever go back for seconds. It smelt like a turd covered in burnt hair and tasted like a shot of coffee in a pint of coke. The shame.

Draught at Loaded Hog, Auckland. So, with 5999 Ratebeer ratings in my luggage I walked in to this brewpub, aiming to find a beer worthy to celebrate 6000 with. I knew it wouldn’t be great the second Iopened the door. To get to the bar I had to wade across the dance floor where drunk middle aged couples were falling around to the sound of the lousiest cover band north of the Antartica, with a noise level that could wake up the dead. Luckily I managed to make it to the bar without my feet getting stuck on the messy floor, and somehow managed to get the bartenders attention through pointing at two beer taps. The beer came out dark brown with near no head. It had an appley nose and uit was appley, sweetish and thin. The mouthfeel was sharp and clean, and I could sense no hops. Why, oh why did I pick this, the lousiest brewpub in the southern hemisphere to have my 6000th rating?

Dark brown-orange colour. Slightly vegetal aroma. Faint maltiness, and a touch of nuttiness. Flavour is quite non-descript, faint malt and herbs. Light toasty finish, but way to thin-bodied to be any good.

Tasted 15/07/2005. 400ml tumbler’s (the old Tupelo "bookie" glass) from Loaded Hog, Wellington. Calls itself full-bodied but tastes like a shot of espresso in a pint of sparkling mineral water. It’s fresh, the pipes are clean, the glass is clean-ish and it goes down easy while you’re having a chat with friends but I’d never choose to drink here myself. And, it’s a lager.
pretty terrible beer from a terrible beer franchise. sickly sweet with the only other flavours being compost and vegetable stock
maybe this was too cold but it was heinously sweet. tasted like a malzbier - raw malt extract, brown sugar and water. plenty of water.

I only asked for a half pint but was served the full one. By the looks of this amber/copper ale and the creme caramel head I think this mignt not have been a bad thing. The nose is a cross between coffee and toffee in the place of any aroma of hops. The flavour is rich and suitably mouthfilling with an obvious hit of crystal malt and burnt black malt character. Like a lot of these styles the bitterness is not so much provided by the hops as the malt. A good beer that is served too cold.
Bright red in colour with thin white head. Interesting candy floss ad honey flavours. crisp clean finish. Interesting style.

Hazy orange-amber beer with mossy shine; small whitish head. Diacetyl, butterscotch, buttertoffees!! Less diacetyl in the taste, but still enough - as with the water. Bit of old, oily hazelnuts. Even a bit end-sourishness. Very ligfht body, only the buttery diacetyl filling in to a very slick feel. Oh well, interesting enough to have this rare thing. Thanks, Stef!

There is no incentive whatsoever to have a second one of these, in fact after tasting some of the others out of this range I was similarly disappointed. It looks inviting enough but tastes like the stainless steel it was brewed in. It seems like the product of the manufactured franchise that I drank it in, so at least that’s a good fit.
Rich golden colour. Fairly sweet toffeeish aroma. Flavour is also quite malty, toffee, caramel, honey with a touch of spiciness. Their best beer, but that’s not saying all that much.

Tasted 15/07/2005. 400ml tumbler (the old Tupelo "bookie" glass) from Loaded Hog, Wellington. Another bantamweight from the Loaded Hog. I must confess there is nothing bad going on with these beers but, most importantly, there doesn’t appear to be an attempt to actually make anything with any character - and that’s worse in my book. As a money making venture, these guys are probably killing it ($1 litre to make, $12+ over the bar). This one has more going on than the others - I can taste an unpleasant caramelised sugar - but other than that it’s basically the same old blandness. Ale my ass.

after a couple of awful beers at the christchurch loaded hog franchise, i resolved to avoid the rest of them. a couple of days later i ended up tasting the loaded hog wheat and made this resolution again. another day later i ended up in a loaded hog franchise in hamilton and the cricket was on and i drank this and barely noticed it as steve waugh slog-swept his way to retirement. typical nutty nz lager with some bonus nasty aluminium flavour
Dark golden colour. Buttery malt aroma. Flavour is rather mediocre. .....
Gold straw colour with thin white head. Weak malt aroma. Thin body and very watery mouthfeel.
I dared myself to try this beer just to see if the Loaded Hog set of franchises had any redeeming features. I shouldn’t have bothered.

Clear, pale golden beer with a thin white head. Pale malt aroma, some hay and bread. Flavour of bread and crackers. Light spicy/grassy hops. Decently quaffable, and it doesn’t have any faults, but its nothing very interesting either.

Tasted 15/07/2005. 400ml tumbler (the old Tupelo "bookie" glass) from Loaded Hog, Wellington. Light gold with a pathetic looking head that vanishes quickly, possibly from embarrasment. Crisp, dry, watery... actually it’s pretty tasteless. A hint of bitterness but it’s too cold to tell if there’s anything else going on. Mouthfeel is beyond lightweight - let’s call this one bantamweight. The taxman is probably gettting more revenue out of this beer than the maltsters. One gets the felling it’s all about money...

Bottle from Beers Of Europe. Hazy ruby body with a thin off-white head. Lively carbonation. No lacing. Aroma of prune, raisin and treacle. Flavour of caramel and fruit loaf with a peppery finish. Medium body with a slightly sticky mouthfeel. Soft fizz. Sweet and slightly spicy.
A really top notch beer. Not super strong for the style, but super flavorful and spot on. The definition of a great eisbock. Online belgian beer factory
0,33 litre Bottle from Pizza Port Bottleshop, Carlsbad, Ca. Dark amber with beige head. Malts, Caramel, sweetness, strong.
33cl bottle. Pours black, thin tan head. Heavy malt, Strong dried fruit, mild fruit, liquorous, Porto spirit, caramelish. Light bitter, mild sweet. What a good Eisbeer!
Pours a very dark brown with a khaki head. British porter and circus peanut nose. Sorghum, plum, and chocolate flavors.
Sweet slightly boozy aroma. Darker than expected with a tan head. Tastes sweet with a light roast and booze aftertaste.
Dark brown color with sweet aroma. Taste is malty sweet without coffee bitterness. Some woody flavor, almost a slight whisky flavor.

Backlog, on tap in Philly a good 7-8 years ago. Pours a brown color with a thin ring of head and not a whole lot of lace. Nose and flavor are clove, banana bread, yeast, fruity malt, and light hops. Boozy and warming in the finish. Medium bodied.

Pour une Eisbock, les 9,2 % pourraient paraître décevants. Mais cela est trompeur car la brasserie Kulmbacher a su tirer entièrement profit de ce titrage avec un alcool qui est juste bien présent pour donner force et caractère sans taper dur et ce titrage permet également de ne pas avoir besoin d'avoir une bière sursucrée ce qui est parfois nécessaire pour équilibrer l'alcool. L'amertume joue également très bien son rôle afin de conférer ce petit plus de fraîcheur qui n'est pas toujours présent pour le genre. Côté équilibre on est donc proche de la perfection. Du côté des arômes, on ne peut qu'apprécier une belle tension en bouche avec un cocktail riche et puissant sur le caramel, la prune, la banane, le caramel, le raisin, une pointe de chocolat et des épices. On retrouve cette alliance gourmande tout en étant de caractère sur l'attaque et la seconde bouche. L’arrière-bouche et le final sont plus épurés avec un alcool s'affirmant davantage mais qui couplée à l'amertume permet à la bière de conserver son équilibre tout en étant racée. Certains auront peut-être une préférence pour des Eisbock plus riches, tant en alcool, qu'en densité, personnellement je trouve qu'on y retrouve dans cette Kulmbacher tout l'esprit des Eisbocks tout en étant plus élancée.

Flaska från hopt.se. Mörkbrunfärgad med ett beständigt smutsvitt skum. Dofter av russin, malt och karamell. Smakinslag av russin, ljus choklad, karamell, honung och färska fikon. Alkoholen döljs helt och hållet i smaken. Det här är gott.
on tap as light dorata limpida buona schiuma cereale un filo di agrume amaro medio

On tap- Served a black color with a nice tan head that fades to some lacing. Aroma of malt with a trace of caramel. There is also a bit of coffee and nut in the background. Taste of malt, coffee and some bittersweet chocolate. There is a nice bitterness throughout and a dry finish. Medium body, crisp and smooth. Nice balance. Easy drinker, nice beer for the style. I think having this on tap at an Irish pub enhances the character of this beer.

Draft at McSorleys, where I think this is what the "light" beer is. Deep clear amber pour with a lasting two finger off-white head. Caramel and cereal grain aroma with mild earthy hoppiness. The flavor is big on caramel, grain, and bready notes. A little herbal too, not bad. Medium-bodied and slightly crisp with soft carbonation. A reasonable but not excitig beer.
Black color, with only a bit of light coming through. Light head and medium body. Modest aroma, but lots of roasted malt flavor---especially for a lager.
12 oz bottle. Aroma was mellow, smooth. Notes of hops and malts. Flavor was good, though pretty standard.
veyr smooth, very sweet. Not much character at all. I could drink this beer again but I probably won’t....unless its free. Worth a try though.

Draft at McSorley’s (NYC). Not a lot of flavor or aroma to the beer, but the surrounding environment somehow help to make it enjoyable. There are some grassy hop notes and a slight green apple flavor to it, but not much else I can remember.
Hmmm. Fairly typical Irish lager. Malty nose. Malty taste. A bit thin on the palate. Meh. Not great, but not bad.

Easy drinking malt driven beer. Aroma is sweet malts, appearence is dark amber, bordering on copper. Flavour is relatively straightforward sweet malts followed by a slight bitterness. On tap at McSorleys NYC.
Light herbal hops, malty, and a touch of roasted notes lead this boring brew. Easy to drink all night long, though.

500ml bottle. Cloudy amber colour with small to average, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, off-white head. Minimally husky and grainy, caramel malty aroma, fruity hoppy hints of mandarine and orange. Taste is mellow malty and slightly grassy and fruity hoppy, hints of caramel, husk, mandarine, orange.

Bottle. Pours deep golden with a white head. Aroma of spices, fruity, light paper, lightly toasted, slight leafy. Taste is malty, fruity, light paper, bready, light bitter, mostly sweet with some malts.

Summer Sunday @ Dolle. Dark golden with a small white head. Malty aroma with bread and grain, along with a fruity touch and a hint of alcohol. Sweet malty flavour with a fruity touch. Herbal hops and a nice bitter finish.
Bottle @ Oberfranken Neuheiten, Summer Bottleshare Odense, Summer 2018. Pours amber copper with a creamy white head. Caramel and bready. Good malty. A touch of alcohol. Clean.
500ml Bottle - Amber in colour. Biscuity aroma with hints of nuts and toffee. Malty, biscuity and slightly nutty taste with peanuts, sultanas and caramel detected.
Bottle from Landbierparadies24.de Pours golden orange with a flat head. Aroma has sweet grain, caramel and a hint of smoke. Taste has caramel, nuts and some smoke. Sweet caramel in the finish!
50 cl bottle. Small white head.Small lasting.Malt and caramel with some other element that I could not precise.Malt and some other cereals flavor. Average carbo. Interesting
Pours clear dark golden colour with a small white head. Aroma of grain, bread, sweet malt. Taste of caramel, sweet malt, grain
Klare sehr dunkel goldgelbe Farbe, ordentliche weiße Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, nussig, Karamell. Geschmack kräftig malzig, leicht hopfig, Karamell, minimal rauchig.
Bottled. Deep gold, with next to no head and slight carbonation. Full bodied, predominantly malty, with a touch of summer fruit and hay, leading to a gently bitter finish. Fine.

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Bottle Conditioned Ale
column5: Bottle at Automata. Pours a near clear yellow gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has earthy grain, light bread and a bit of wet grass underlying. Flavor is similar with wet grass, bread and a touch of sweet grain backing.

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Bottle Conditioned Ale
column5: 500ml bottle thanks to Shingo. Pours a clear Amber color with a small white head. A light fruity nose. The flavor is light toast, watery, melon. Very light. OK.

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Bottle Conditioned Ale
column5: Bottle shared. Thanks TimE. Very old school nose with caramel and grassy notes dominating. Body is balanced but kind of simple. Mostly chewy caramel and some light hop character. Bitter finish. Simple.

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Bottle Conditioned Ale
column5: Bottle. Clear golden amber color, medium white head. Aroma of grassy citrus, light caramel. Taste has toffee, caramel.

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Bottle Conditioned Ale
column5: The nose is basically non-existent, and the beer looks murky, with an off-white head that faded quickly. Very high carbonation on the palate, making for a fairly crisp finish. The flavours that push through aren't very... Authentic. They seem artificial and not alluring in the slightest.

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Bottle Conditioned Ale
column5: 330 ml bottle at Izakaya Seki in DC. 2013.11 stamped on the lower left side of the label. Mostly clear yellow with just a hint of haziness, big rapid forming off-white head. Aromas of lemon lime, floral notes, light funk, Brett, caramel. Tastes of lemon citrus, floral notes, citrus peel, light Brett. Medium body with a dry finish. Pretty enjoyable.

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Bottle Conditioned Ale
column5: Pours a clean and clear yellow color. Aroma of rice and yeast. Taste is simple with a tint of honey and malt. Slight metallic flavor in he aftertaste. Overall, a simple beer that was not very flavorful or complex.

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Bottle Conditioned Ale
column5: Bottle from local Yamaya. Grain, yeast, and honey aromas, with a very light cardboard note. Hazy amber/strae color, thin head, and good lace. Caramel, honey, apples, peaches, and light spicy hopping. Thin-medium body, a bit soapy with the somewhat over-the-top bottle conditioning carbonation, slightly dry finish. Okay. The carbonation does interfere a bit.

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Bottle Conditioned Ale
column5: Bread, mild caramel aroma.Caramel malt, quite fizzy, cake, touch of orange, floral hops, clean finish. Nothing too exciting but ok malty caramel ale.

column1: Tama no Megumi (Ishikawa) Bottle Conditioned Ale
column5: Bottle 330ml "Tokyo Beer" 5.5 % (sampled in Kyoto) Hazy amber color, small steady white head. Grainy, bready, hoppy aroma. Medium-bodied. Grainy, fruity flavor, some yeastyness. Mango, very light pine touch, sweetish. Really gives quite "bottle conditioned" feeling.

I'm not much of a style guy - ordinarily I could care less about how "true" a beer is to style and I hardly ever rate that way. But this beer gave me pause. It looks, tastes, and smells so much like an English pale that I had to ask the very friendly bartender if she'd poured me the right brew. She assured me and I have to say, it's one strange dortmunder!

column1: Hair of the Frog Deep Doppelbock
column5: light very sweet caramel on the nose. Dark ruby burgundy with no head. sweet sweet caramell bockishness that finishes in an intense cherry sugary sweetness. very sweet example of the style

column1: Hair of the Frog Deep Doppelbock
column5: Bright dark brown color. Slightly sweet organic malty presence in the nose with a touch of light chocolate present. Body starts with a short malty sweetness and quickly moves to overriding piney hops. Not a great example, needs a thicker, more robust maltiness to stand up to the big boys of the style. Never noticed that alcohol presence now that I see what it is.

column1: Hair of the Frog Deep Doppelbock
column5: Weird. But I'd come to expect that at this point. The brewery is in a hot tub rental place, of all things, with a thick, humid, chlorine feel and a very fun crowd. Anyway, this is a strange, burnt belgian sugar of a bock.

column1: Hair of the Frog Frogger Vienna
column5: His dad, who was the chief brewer, recently suffered a fall, so the current brewer kind of has free rein and he is using it to full chaotic creative advantage. This thing has the grassiest, most awkwardly herbal hops I've ever tasted. Pure alfalfa and only a touch of sweet maltiness. Yikes. Maybe the bartender accidently switched the dortmunder and this ...

column1: Hair of the Frog Lily Pad Pale
column5: Hazy amber body. As hennes said it, this was a little weak on the hops. A little sweet. But, the atmosphere of the brewery is nice, so I guess that makes up for it, if only a little.

column1: Hair of the Frog Lily Pad Pale
column5: Slightly hazy gold. Light sweetish malt in the nose and just a touch of light fruity hops. Body is spritzy and one-sidedly bitter towards the end.

column1: Hair of the Frog Lily Pad Pale
Hair of the Frog Cut River IPA
column5: Golden color. Citrusy hoppiness and a light fruitiness in the nose. Big chewy hops in the body with a touch of fruit. Finishes long and sticky with not enough malt to balance things.

column1: Hair of the Frog Cut River IPA
column5: I have to say I was impressed with the tap room of this little brewery, with the beefcake bulldog, Jake running around to the fish tank in the wall. The beer was pretty good. Hazy amber color, mostly diminishing head. Quite a bit of apparent Cascade hops, but there''s never enough of those in my opinion. This brewery should start distributing, but from the comments of others, they may need to make consistency a priority before they do that.

column1: Hair of the Frog Cut River IPA
column5: Hoppiest standard beer sold here. Decent amount of hops. ..................

column1: Hair of the Frog Cut River IPA
column5: Now we're getting somewhere, but I'm not sure how far. One local, Tom, a regular, claims that inconsistency is the hallmark of this eccentric little brewery, with no beer tasting the same way twice. This is one they might try to emulate, or improve on a bit. Not much substance, and a touch of skunk flavour, but decent and very real hops.

column1: Hair of the Frog Brown Porter
column5: nose of unsweetened chocolate, light black with light red hues. light in body, chocolate, caramel. sweet, very light bitterness, nearly no hops. rather mellow

column1: Hair of the Frog Brown Porter
column5: Dark brown color. Light chocolate, good roast and a touch of sweetness in the nose. A touch of smoke in the body, lightly roasted and slightly oily. Finishes slightly hoppy but overall is affected by it''s spritzyness.

column1: Hair of the Frog Brown Porter
column5: a nice dark brown with medium sized head, good roasted chocolate malt flavor, but unfortunately way to thin and watery.

column1: Hair of the Frog Brown Porter
column5: Too watery, but a nice roasty, sweet, chocolate flavor. ....................

column1: Hair of the Frog Brown Porter
column5: If it wasn't so damn thin, it might be a superior brew. Very nice roast and, especially, chocolate flavours. A touch sweet like all HOTF brews.

column1: Hair of the Frog Imperial Stout
column5: dark black with a small but long lasting head. coffee, mild chocolate and dark fruit, moderate alcohol on the nose. Round body with notes of toffee, loads of chocolate, minimal to no hops, very sweet. late alcohol, very sweet as most of the beers at this bar were

column1: Hair of the Frog Imperial Stout
column5: Black with a dark tan head. Nose is nuts, light chocolate and roast with a touch of fruity hops towards the end. The body is creamy and quite roasted, ends up coming across milky. Comes up sweet and organic in the malt area. Finishes with an alcohol shot. A nice imperial stout, although it seems to be a bit sweet which is not unpleasant but maybe a bit unexpected.

column1: Hair of the Frog Imperial Stout
column5: By far the winner of my evening at HOTF, poured a deep dark brown with a bigger head than usual for an imperial, aroma of chocolate malt with a hint of vanilla, alcohol started to show through about midway, had a nice rich chewy mouthfeel, a nice imperial

column1: Hair of the Frog Imperial Stout
column5: Ok. Maybe it was the fact that I sampled a lot of lackluster beers yesterday. Maybe it was the fact that the company was awesome. But I simply loved this beer. Crystal, the novice beer drinker sitting next to me, even liked this and she's been drinking beer only a few months (a convert, brothers?). It comes on huge with vanilla, chocolate, and spicy alcohol. Enough vanilla in fact, that Crystal claimed it similar to taking a hit of vanilla while making chocolate chip cookies. Why she does that, I don't know, but she's a great woman and fellow lit lover I hope to share a brew with her later this year in Seattle ... Anyway, this is a thick, classy, rich, real beer, a hidden gem on the outskirts of Grand Rapids.

column1: Hair of the Frog Irish Stout
column5: loads of caramell to start off, roasty with real roasty caramell bitterness. very light in body but quite flavorful. dark dark brown with no head vinous flavors. lasting roasty bitterness

column1: Hair of the Frog Irish Stout
column5: Dark brown appearance with a little red shining through underneath a tan head. Aroma is reminiscent of Guinness with the light smokey, burnt wood impressions. This beer falls apart in the body though, comes across thin and light and dries quickly towards the end. A touch of roastiness, but nothing that keeps moving into the finish.

column1: Hair of the Frog Irish Stout
column5: Vaguely reminiscent of DFH Chicory, in fact - that stands out through the decent roast and pleasant bitters. One of two beers at HOTF with a real head and some substance.

column1: Hair of the Frog Copper Frog
column5: Dark red appearance. Slightly sweet malty nose with candyish/fruity hops coming through. The body is lightly bitter and organic with a light maltiness that materializes into an irony finish. Mine was called Copper Lager.

column1: Hair of the Frog Copper Frog
column5: Now this is the protype HOTF brew, reddish, sweetish, mild, not much body to speak of. It has more smokey, spicy flavours than most, though, so it gets more points.

This is a serious hole in the wall sort of place with a great small pub atmosphere and very friendly folks. The brewer is wildly creative and cares very little for style guidelines, so be warned! This wheat beer hardly seems wheaty at all. It's a weird orange colorwith no head, bright tasting with a very sweet malty, bocky taste and almost zero traditional wheat flavours.

I second Hennes comment regarding this beer being so thin. I have come to expect more body in a stout. I also detected something "rusty" in the flavor; as if the silos were oxidizing during brewing. neither Hennes or Inveigler mentioned this phenomenon, but I’m sure Hennes excuse would be the ten previous samples. It is for what they obviously tried to achieve with this beer that I gave it a 16 overall. Cheers!

Nice pillowy head and very rich ebony appearance. Second Hennes comments about the nose, spectacularly rich roasted and coffee aromas. Java notes throughout the first sips, but it recedes into rich malts and nice bitter background. This is a well-balanced stout, and one of the best beers I have sampled at MBC.

I was getting up to leave after sampling ten MBC brews but the bartender stopped me, giving me this one more. I'm glad she did, if only for the nose, with is absolutely huge and gorgeous with roastiness. The flavour is good too, not as big as I hoped, but definite in its admixture of coffee and smokey chocolate that finishes pleasantly long and bitter. The only knock on this seasonal is that its so thin - it gave out so much of its heart in the aroma, leaving it a bit empty inside.

I have to a gree with daboskasbouter that this was too hoppy for the style. Burnt peach to orange in color with a thin fizzy head. Hops and malt blended pretty well in the aroma. But, man, did the hops come out in the flavor. It was suprising. Not the MBC's best effort.

Slightly hazy dark orange appearance. Light chocolate and citrusy hops in the nose. Body is spritzy with a firm sweet malt presence. Finishes lightly tart and too hoppy for the style. Not much of an old ale if you ask me.

Yet another MBC brew with nice aroma and weak body - that seems to be a distinguishing feature of the brewery. Some citrus, nuts, and cinamon to lend a little complexity but this is more a dressed up American style pale than an old ale, leaning hard with hops.

Pours a light golden with a 1.5 inch white head. The nose is light and sweet. Light body, some floral and bitter hop notes, lingers well. Some residual sweetness and notes of mixed grain (more towards corn flakes than grape nuts). Lace does form. This is a light, pleasant, if not overly impressive beer. Easy to drink. Thirst quencher! It is not moreish.

In the bottle from a quickie mart in Mackinaw City. This brew pours amber with a thick yellow-beige head. Very malty aroma. Flavor has good notes of caramel and roastedness to the finish. Nice body, not a thin beer. I think this is under rated.

Bottle, has a very clear medium to deep gold pour with a hint of amber and brown colors, has a short lived white head that hangs around as a ring and cover, obviously, this has more color than the typical macro beer, leaves little lacing on the sides of the glass, light malt aromas of bread with faint hops, grain and sweetness, some faint peas aroma in the background, flavor of malt and bread with a very present hop bitterness, there is a touch of honey sweetness but this sweetness is minute on the palate, also, a touch of off flavor in this beer, mouth feel is good, this beer could have been a great beer but the nose and flavor have some off-ness, which is unfortunate, I would have given this drink a better grade if it was not for the off fragrance and taste.

From a 12 bottle obtained in a trade with Erik of indiana, this pouerd a clear an light honey yellow with a small white head and virtually no lacing. Nose of sweatsocks and rotten apples. Watery and fizzy mouthfeel. Flavor is malty with a touch of fruit. Finish dry and bland. This is simply a very ordinary beer.
12oz plastic bottle-A clear golden body with a decent head and an aroma of nothing. Taste of a typical Helles with nothing to write home about. I’ve had worse.
Not sure where I had this. Pours a weak tea brown with sour vegetables and flat sugar in the nose. Flavor is a mixture of corn malt and stale flowers. Watery mouthfeel. No mac attack here.

Pours a honey yellow with a filmy white head despite the vigorous pour. Low key aroma of grains and malt. Taste is mostly inoffensive malt and light hop spiciness. Sour finish with a not entirely pleasant aftertaste. A poor attempt at a mass appeal beer by a brewer who can do much better.
On tap @ Coles in buffalo NY. Pours a medium golden color. Aroma has some malty sweetness but rather non descript. Flavor is lacking: some malts sweeter & pilsner. Nothing special

Goodbar Beer Club. Rich gold, thin white head. Nose is herbal hops, minty/spicy notes, light to medium toffee malts. Flavor is rich malt, herbal & spicy hops, huge malt finish - almost meaty. On the verge of being cloying.

Pours honey yellow with a white head. Very little aroma, maybe a light touch of grain, but not much. Smooth, lightly malted, almost a hint of skunk (even though it probably never say much light in its life), and a touch of soap and hops.Nothing outstanding, yet nothing horrible, either.

column1: Michigan Brewing Renaissance Brand Spelt Pale Ale
column5: Hazy light yellow, nose is sweet grainy malt, but hints of diacytol present (low). Buttery first sip is disappointing, grainy and wheaty, small amount of grassy hops in the finish, but something has gone wrong along the way. (on-tap @ brewery)

column1: Michigan Brewing Renaissance Brand Spelt Pale Ale
column5: Draft, at taphouse. The folks at MBC also tell me it’s an organic grain bill, too. A different taste, not as hoppy as expected (and they certainly are pushing it to have three different pale ales on tap). It's a cloudy yellow in color as expected from a wheat-type beer, and slightly spicy more than bitter, at least to me.

column1: Michigan Brewing Renaissance Brand Spelt Pale Ale
column5: I was always thinking about brewing a spelt beer and well here it is a SPELT beer. I can taste the spelt just like the bread to me. I'll give them credit for trying something different. Full tasty enjoyable. Anyways this was nice.

column1: Michigan Brewing Renaissance Brand Spelt Pale Ale
column5: Light golden color, light lace. The aroma is grassy, the body sweet malty and spritzy. The sweetness is rather syruppy sweet, kind of like maple syrup sweet without the maple. Light hops in the finish. The one I had was called Spelt Pale. That''s funny, my beer wasn''t moldy. I don''t think I''ve ever had a moldy beer.

column1: Michigan Brewing Renaissance Brand Spelt Pale Ale
column5: Moldy Moldy Moldy dog crap. Did I mention this beer was moldy?..............

column1: Michigan Brewing Renaissance Brand Spelt Pale Ale
column5: Most unique. Several hard to discribe flavors...all good. Nice hops character and nice finish. Still don''t know what the aftertase was but will drink this again and again.

column1: Michigan Brewing Renaissance Brand Spelt Pale Ale
column5: This is quite good, and very different. I've never had anything quite like it. Extremely smooth, some bitterness and sourness. The aftertaste is very strange, sort of citrusy, but hard to describe. I definately recommend giving this a try.

column1: Michigan Brewing Renaissance Brand Spelt Pale Ale
column5: As Hennes mentioned this beer is brewed using spelt which makes describing it difficult. The style os reminiscent of a pale ale. Fairly hoppy, but those malt tones! ... like nothing I have ever tried before. This beer is well worth a try, and I think that it could really grow on me with time.

column1: Michigan Brewing Renaissance Brand Spelt Pale Ale
column5: They are full out experimeting in Webberville! This one's malt is entirely Michigan grown Spelt, a wheat like grain pushed delightfully by the 12th century nun, Hildegaard, who was also an early proponent of the hop. The beer is, as one might expect, very different. It's transcendently sour and citric, really lemony, with an amazingly soft mouth feel.
Draft at the brewery. Pretty basic lager. Light with a faint hops and barley grain taste. Very light straw color. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Golden foam. Had a draft at their brewery. Super foamy as the title. Very fruity and wet. Hard to describe. God

tap at the brewpub last summer - Pours clear gold with a white head. There’s a mild malt aroma. It tastes of light pils malt and is a bit grainy. The hops is crisp, the brew light bodied, and the finish has lingering bitterness.

On tap at Grand Rapids Brewing Company. Straw yellow with no head. Aroma of corn and light hops akin to an American macro. Taste of mild honey, lemon and light hops. Grainy body finishes up corny and astringent. Not very good.

Draft. A pale yellow pour with a one finger white head.Aroma of grain,corn and bread,some faint hop notes of citrus and spice.Light body with some sour/bitter notes,very little in the way of malt flavor.Smooth mouthfeel,dry slightly tart finish.I am not sure if I really liked this or not,I will go back before long and retry,not bad but nothing special.

(Sampled 7-5-08 at brewery from sampler) Transparent like water in appearance with some yellow food coloring added, white ring for a head, aroma of bread, corn, and a small hop note. Hits the mouth with a thin watery body, malt is too weak in the mouth, a single hop flash on the finish. Almost every brewery has to have a BMC clone I guess...
Tasted 4/27/08. Sampler from the brewpub. Filtered with a golden hue. Trace white head. Grainy bready nose. Light bodied and crisp. Smooth malts. Mild dryness and a touch tart. Solid interpretation.
Pours gold with light white head. Smells of wheat and grain. It is a plain pils with a metallic finish and bready taste. It goes down smooth though.

Draft sampler at brewpub. Poured clear pale color with an average frothy white head that mostly diminished with fair lacing. Moderate sour citrus aroma. Light to medium body. Light bitter flavor with a light smooth bitter finish of moderate duration.
from the tap. poureda golden color, with white head and some nice lacing. aroma hops, malts, a touch of sourness. aroma, malts, hops, dry very easy to drink, could of had a few of these.

Pint on tap at brewpub. It was pale with white head, moderate carbonation. Reminded me a little of the rice brewed macro’s but with a good sweetness, rather than a cheap hangover sweetness. It was refreshing and its quality beer but just not enough flavor.

Tasted 4/27/08. Sampler from the brewpub. Filtered and pale golden. Honey floral nose. Grainy aspect. Light bodied with a tart honey sweetness. Bright yet mild. Smooth and easy. Nothing offensive, yet nothing extraordinary.

GRBC at its finest.....actually im kidding; hazy yellow appearance with aroma of honey, wheat, and mild ctrus hops...flavor was okay (a typical wheat beer with a touch of honey)...pass this one up if u can
One of two GRBC beers that I'd have again, if I were to revist the brewery (unlikely). It has nice, sharp wheat flavours just touched by the honey and some spicy hop action on close.
On tap at brewpub. Dark brown with a nice off white head. Bland aroma, some malts come through, nothing unique. Light body for a porter, reminds me of a red. Not much flavor, decent.

On tap at Grand Rapids Brewing Company. Brown with red highlights and a thin tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel and toffee. Taste of roasted malts, smoke, peat and light caramel. A bad sourness hovers over this one and it finishes astringent.

From what I remember they were selling this as a stout, maybe I am incorrect though. A nice black pour with a whitish head. Roasted malt and some coffee. Aroma does not lie, tastes similarly with some slight chocolate tones. Pretty dry clean finish. Far and away the best of their regular offerings.

Draft.A dark brown color,with a thin light tan head,Aroma of chocolate and maybe butterscotch,tastes pretty much the same as it smells. This and the Octoberfest were the only thing I tried here that I would order again.

(Sampled 7-5-08 at brewery from sampler) Midnight black in color, non transparent when held to the sun. Roasted malt with coffee and dark molasses in the background according to my old sniffer. Hits the mouth with a medium body, malt comes through nicely in translation, very light on the tongue, some caramel and walnuts on the finish. The wife had a snort and compared it to a Guinness Light- I would have to concure with her observations. To be honest, that’s not a bad thing either...

Tasted 4/27/08. Sampler from the brewpub. Dark as pitch with a brown hue. Toffee and coffee in the nose. Touch burnt. Medium bodied with a nice roasty grainy fruity flavor. Sticky and bitter. Dry finish. Nutty with a hint of molassis. Tasty.
Pours black with a cream head. Roasted caramel is most noticeable in the aroma. It tastes sickly sweet followed by a dark roast aftertaste.
Pretty dark brown color, good roasted malt flavor, but light on hops. Part of 5 brew sampler for $4.95!

Draft at brewpub. Poured dark brown color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Medium body with a smooth texture. Medium balanced bittersweet flavor with a medium bitter finish of moderate duration.

On Tap at GR Brewpub -- Rich aroma of coffe and chocolate. Appearance is an apealing black/brown with a minimal amount of carbonation and light head. Fllavor has a strong hoppy malt with roasted coffe and some fruitiness
Decent goldings flavour accentuates a beer that comes on a tad more aggressively in hops and malt than is usual at GRBC. At least I noticed the action. Far more interesting than most beers here.
Tap at the pub. Clear light spicy color. White head. Grainy aroma, light floral hops. Flavor is grainy, spicy hops. Bitter and crisp finish.

An excellent Czech -styled pilsner with a mildy nutty malt backing and crisp continental hop character. Great balance. Love the mild malty fade. Pours crystal clear light amber with a sticky large white head. Oodles of lace.

Pours a typical golden yellow color with a malt corn aroma. Taste is light, crisp, with a very minimal malt backbone. A crisp, easy drinking beer, true to the style. Nice low ABV that lends to a nice smooth drinking pilsener.
Can. On a United flight. This is a decent little brew and the best you are going to find on a plane.

On tap, poured into a shaker. The aroma is rocky with some pastry dough and a light toffee touch. The appearance is clear and pale-gold with a mild, soft head that has okay retention and mild lace. The flavor is a muted, medium sweet and a medium light bitter. The texture is thin with a fuzzy carbonation and a medium light body. The profile is buttery with notes of bread and a mild, bitter spice. The finish is spicy and has a rock-like note to it - like a dry, muted mineral tone. The aftertaste has a light tone of minerals and bread toast.

On tap at GI (late 2011) described as a Czech style pils. Pours a hazy golden color with a white head. The aroma has grassy hop notes pale malts with some herbal character. The flavor is grassy, light citrus, pale malt., lightly herbal, clean, crisp, and decent for what it is.
On draft at brewpub, poured a light golden yellow color, aromas of hay, light sweet malt, and some grass. Flavors are the same, light on the palate, decent beer overall.

Enjoyed on tap at Goose Island Wrigleyville while hanging out with some friends before going to see the band Afghan Whigs. I didn’t take notes on this one, but remember it being pretty good and well balanced between crisp malts and very lightly bitter hops. Nothing re-inventing the wheel but great for the style.

Draft in sampler at the Clybourn brewpub. Pours a clear gold color with a small white head. Notes of grass, straw, and sweet and pils malts. Light-bodied, with a malty mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Crisp all the way through, but not as clean as a better pils because the malt lingers for so long.
Sampled at Clybourn brewpub. Clear gold. Definite eastern european hops are forward. Light sulphur effects help make for a dry beer. Light fruit adds nicely. Authentic.

i think the hops were so late they got missed altogether, well there is some hopiness, but just a big brewer using inferior ingredients jumping on the "hop" "craft" bandwagon but failing miserably, not undrinkable but very disappointing and extremely bland
Bottle 04/10/2004 Golden amber coloured and hoppy. Some dryness in a bitter lasting finish.
Bottled. Ooh no, didn’t like this one. Sickly sweet and unrelentingly artificial tasting. Glazes the tongue, but not in a pleasant way. Quite bad.

One of Marstons better bottled beers, great summer drinking. Poured a marmalade colour with a thin white head. The floral nose is deliciously zesty, with some limey hop characters. Light bodied and quenching. Has that wonderful Marstons green apple crispness. Here it’s coupled with a citric hop tang and a lingering bitterness. In bottled form, this comes up much better than some of the brewer’s better ales. (Bottle)

I respect Marstons, though I wouldn’t say that there are many differences between their session bitters. This is sold together with Pedigree, Single Malt and Double Drop. Maybe the hoppiest of them. Clear bottle, copper colour, thin head, malty and fruity aroma, hoppy, malty and ironish taste. Dry finish.
Bottled.Deep golden colour, quite a nice looking white head. Very bitter aroma and flavour. Long bitter palate.

There are two enjoyable aspects of reviewing beers. Being the first is great and then there is being the tenth which gives rise to the percentile. Ok now to the beer. This is a good amber with the promised nose of hops, The head is thin but still presentable all the way down. The flavour is good but not brilliant. This is the sort of beer that you would expect to see in an English pub, which fom my perspective is not a bad thing, but it isn't a 'wow' beer either.

Bottled. Filtered and pasteurised. 5.0% April, 2003:I’m not a fan of Marston’s bottled products - though Owd Rodger is a decent ale. This is a typical Marston brew, with the trademark Marston’s malt aroma. I tried this alongside Marston’s Strong Pale Ale. Not a lot of difference. The colour is slightly paler - more sunflower oil than burnt orange. The steady rise of thin bubbles is similar, just less of them. It has the same monk’s head of foam. There is the usual gentle hop bitterness, though well integrated with the malt. Not as sweet, nor quite as fruity as the Strong Pale. Indeed, there is a tobacco quality about the taste. Not a great beer, but certainly drinkable. [2.5] Dec, 2004: In the Marston line up with the Drouble Drop and the Single Malt. Not much between them. This was the driest with the most hop awareness in the finish. Not great quality, but drinkable. [2.3]

A reasonable beer. Has a good nose full of refreshing hoppy aromas. Pours with vitually no head. The taste dissapointing, it is watery slightly soapy and has a metallic after taste. Certainly not Marstons best work.
From old tasting notes. Bright brassy gold color. Bubbly white head. Tart fruity malt nose is clean and crisp. Zesty sweet malt flavor. Dry hop finish. A clean crisp ale. It’s a clean machine.
12oz bottle (Old Notes)-Pours amber with a small head. Aroma of malt and grains. Taste of the same. This light bodied brew is not very tasty.

Had this in a central PA strip bar. Decent malty taste. This one seemed to taste very alcoholic. Decent finish. I probably wouldn't buy this again, but it was somewhat complex in flavor. A stripper even drank one with me.
Weak undertones with thin flavor, but rich color. Overall, not the best ale to find, but will do in a pinch.
Feel for the advertising. Light on flavor, did not sit well. Still better then most of their stuff

column1: J.J. Wainwrights First Brewing Select Lager Beer
column5: (Bottle 35,5 cl) Nice amber colur, almost no head. Soft, lightly sweet malty notes of caramel making this a bit more interesting than the average American lager. Not that bad.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights First Brewing Select Lager Beer
column5: [bottle] Pours a dark golden brown with a decent sized white head. Very oddly sweet aroma; reminds me a bit of applesauce. Slightly sweet flavor that goes away quickly and leaves no aftertaste. Extremely watery for a lager. Tastes like a light beer.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights First Brewing Select Lager Beer
column5: This has "CHEAP BEER" written all over it... and I should have known by the price! I guess it's "You get what you pay for." This beer is watery yellow, smells cheap, tastes cheaper, feels cruddy going down, and makes you hand these out when someone comes to visit (either that our pour it into a glass and tell them it's something else). Not gonna retry this one!

column1: J.J. Wainwrights First Brewing Select Lager Beer
column5: Golden brown color much darker than most American-style lagers. Very thin head. Light to medium bodied. Nose is slightly sweet. What would be light, refreshing flavor is weighed down by a slightly earthy, metallic bitterness in the finish.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights First Brewing Select Lager Beer
column5: The use of roasted barley really does make this lager amber-colored, which comes as a surprise. It lacks much hop bite but rather is fairly sweet and watery. Not complex at all.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights First Brewing Select Lager Beer
column5: uhhh. This was not that good. Decent color, but either too much going on, or not enough going on with the taste.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights First Brewing Select Lager Beer
column5: Tea-colored with a decent head. This beer managed to be malty-sweet and sour at the same time, which I didn't really like.

22 oz bottle 8/17/19 (Tops Liquors-Tempe) 46° in Shaker. Pours a light amber with a small white head. Aroma of grapefruit, citrus, and slight malt. Taste of the same with more hops and a bitterness on the back end. This medium to full bodied brew is well balanced and downright tasty.

J'ai donc fini par trouver cette référence dans l'ipa. Et c'est vrai elle est excellente, la canette de 35 cl était trop petite. Des arômes de résineux et de fruits (exotiques, agrumes). Belle amertume et surtout un équilibre parfait et une longueur infinie. Une autre!

Bottle from AleSmith, SD - I had this not knowing that it was No 1 in IPAs. but the moment I drank it I knew you could hardly make a better prototype IPA. so round and smooth, so moreish and exceptional. it's the great beers when they come so easy, as if it was nothing to brew a master IPA. no more to say, I tip my hat.

0,65l bottle. Aroma of citrus, spruce, pineapple, mango, a blast of tropical fruits, caramel. Taste is citrus, pineapple, a little bit of maltiness, herbs. Medium mouthfeel, the perfect amount of carbonation.

Draft at Artisan Burgers in Bangkok. Appearance is a hazy golden hue, with a finger of white froth which recedes to a thin layer. Aromas muted, especially when cold, hoppy citrus and grapefruit. Taste is different, tropical fruit sweetness, piney bitter. Medium bodied, average carbonation. Well made, but not exciting.

From the bottle. Hazy copper with an off-white head. Tropical and citrus fruit aroma. Aggressive hop bitterness. A bit of biscuit and slightly toasted malt in the background, but predominantly hop forward. Excellent.

Tight white head left s good cover on a hazy dark copper coloured still body. Pine, stewed fruit, sweaty socks, peach & caramel. Medium bodied with a slight tickle over the tongue & softer cloying back. Well balanced tastes of malt, biscuit, pine, grapefruit, hops, resin & caramel with long tangy pithy finish
Hazy golden color with white head, aroma of tropical fruits, citrus, hops, biscuits and caramel, taste is lightly sweet / medium bitter, medium body, average carbonation.
Small white head. Clear copper color. Slight malt nose. Light bodied. Slightly sour malt flavors, no hops. Dry almost puckering finish.
Bright orange (I'm glad it's not silver); light malt character, with hints of bread crust and caramel. Watery finish.
I had this beer a while back and from what I can remember I enjoyed it. I’ve had this at the pub/brewery so it was fresh. Nothing special about it is popping into my head at the moment.
Golden color, easy to drink, would make an excellent session beer. DFH did a fine job with this German Wheat.
Drink this fine brew after spending a day at the beach or mowing the lawn. Not many wheat beers beat this one.
Refreshing, balanced, subtle foresty hops, crisp wheatiness. Understated fruitiness would be the only drawback to this summer sessional.
Not sure hoe this is a cream ale... 9 ibu and 4%. nothing wrong with this one, it’s actually quite nice for what it is, but in the end it’s still a "light" beer."

Review from memory. Summer 2011. My first DFH beer, and first visit to DFH Alehouse. Light in every way. Not unpleasant, and serves its purpose, but nowhere the bold and interesting ales we come to expect from DFH.
On tap at brewpub. Pours a pale yellow color with a small amount of white head. Aroma is light malt with a touch of corn. Flavor is pale malts with some earthy hops.
This is def. a starter beer, little flavor and pretty watery, not as bad as mass produced but nothing like any other dogfish brew.

"My girlfriend ordered this at the Ale house in Fairfax VA. I had to try a bit and she loves making fun of me as I jot down notes of beers. A - No head, very light pilsner colored beers. It’s just a wattery looking beer like a Coors or Miller High Life with far less carbonation. S - Lots of wheat with some lemon and fresh cut grass. Very summery smell. T - Tastes like a weak hefeweizen but there’s still flavor here..but it’s very hard to find. M - Very light beer, no carbonation when swishing it around. O - This isn’t a bad beer. DFH took a style of beer that isn’t too represented in craft (with good reason) and made it tasty. I’d drink this over a Budweiser for sure and pick it easily in a blind taste test but it’s just not a beer I’d drink day to day. This beer would go GREAT with burgers and bacon!"
On tap at DFH. Yep, a light beer to please the masses. Was at the brewpub, never had it, so had to try it at least once!
Definitely one of the lightest beers I’ve had from Dogfish Head. Light color, aroma and flavor. A great beer for the summer and very sessionable. A really good anytime beer.
Pretty much what you’d expect. Actually remind me of a sweaty betty. Grassy flavor, clean and crisp. Good for what it is.

On Tap at the DFH brew pub. Pours pale straw hue with a thin white head. Very fruity, malty aroma has a hint of hops. Light-medium, crisp body. Light, pleasant hops are balanced on the palate by biscuit malt and lemon fruit. Very pleasant, light session beer.

11 Aug 2011, tap at the brewpub. yellow, clear some steady bubbles. smells a bit like a slightly sweet, faintly crisp, hoppy lager. thin/med body, a bit fizzy. slightly heavy if it was meant to be a lager (which it’s not). faint toast notes, w/ main flavor of lemon pith, but not much citrus. a sessionable light ale but a bit heavy for a thirst quencher in the summer sun.

Calling this beer nice is like calling it amiable and well meaning. It doesn’t truly do justice to the Oud Bruin style of my ancestors but had the rich spice and tart aftertaste that I quite enjoy. A good session beer for those who enjoy it, but not the most special oud bruin I have ever had. In saying that though, can I have another?

Dark ruby-tinged brown with tan head that didn’t last long. Solid roasted malt aromas with some sweet toffee. Same on the palate with the proper amount of carbonation made this very enjoyable. Got even better as it warmed.

This was actually a nice beer, but calling it an Oud Bruin can be seen as an insult to the traditional Flanders brewers who have mastered this Indigenous style over the last few centuries. On it’s own, though, this would be a great beer worthy of some praise. Poured into a Tulip glass, an island of off-white foam sat atop a deep cola brown body, with ruby sides. Generous toffee sweet and tart hop aroma, with an underlying mixture of grain husks and acidity. In the mouth rich dark chocolate was pronounced throughout, with a sweet but husky front, aniseed mid palate and a pleasant roasted grain finish. A small amount of spice balances the sweet dark malts. Light bodied, lightly carbonated and rather smooth, this one impressed me and is a step up for this brewery. If they would just reassess the name then they would be on a winner. Very nice!!

Deep mahogany brown almost opaque with a medium size shortish lasting beige head. Medium bandaid and light biscuity malt aroma. Medium smooth body with low carbonation. One dimensional medium low sweetness roasted malt flavours. Soft roasted bitter malt finish. Mullet reports a plastic twang, yeah I get that like a bottle of cola left too long in a plastic bottle in the sun? Apart from the appearance I Can’t find anything oud briun or Belgian about this one.

Deep brown, red highlights, head OK but not by Belgian standards. Distinct aroma of mint peas!!! Also chocolate (not the malt) and other spices - perhaps cardamom and lemongrass. Thin body. A touch of choc malt, a bit of a roasty finish with a tiny bit of hop. Some weird plastic twang. Smells quite interesting but really doesn’t have much flavour. As noted by others, this is clearly not a sour beer.

Very dark brown to black, with some red hues. LIghtly carbonated, with a thin, light brown head. Smokey, slighty sour, fruity aroma. Hint of sour/dryness and mild malt flavours. A nice drop, but a little thin and bland.

As I was pouring this brew into the glass I was impressed by the appearance. Dark cola brown colour with a medium sized light tan head that hung around for the journey. Pleasant mix of hops and malt on the aroma. Initial taste of chocolate and cocoa, some spice but not a lot showing, smooth texture, a touch of smoke hiding in there, pepper and a medium body. I think this is a bloody good drop! Cheers!

interesting, not really an oud bruin but a good beer anyway. it’s closer to something like Daleside Moroccan Ale than Liefmans Odnar - a spiced old ale or porter. Extremely dark brown with red highlights - could pass for a stout. Really odd fuggles + fennel seed + toffee aroma. Plenty of chocolate malt and a reasonable malt body, along with a very strong aniseed/fennel seed flavour that is a spicy sort of fennel-ouzo flavour rather than a fat licorice root taste. There’s also some sweet cake spice like cinnamon or allspice in there. Bewildering aftertaste of pepper, blackberry and fennel. Quite dry and light. Plenty of flavour certainly, and not totally similar to any other beer I’ve had. Just not an oud bruin. But pisses all over every other Monteiths beer.

Dark brown colour. Belgian yeast aroma. Fruity yeast notes in the initial flavour, followed by Belgian malts (slightly chocolatey), and slight cinnamon notes on the finish. All in all, it's well rounded and fairly smooth. Easily Monteith's best effort to date.
Golden colour. Hemp seed aroma and slight hemp flavour. Clean and crisp. Overall though, it is fairly light and lacking in flavour.

Got this in a trade a while back but I do not know who sent it, but thank you. poured a amber color with a white head. aroma, some malts and toffee, yeast, grassy. flavor, about the same as aroma but with a hint of alcohol

I’m kinda liking these Maibocks when I try them. Appearance and aroma were unnoteworthy. But this had a good taste balance. Sweet but not too sweet. Hoppy but not too hoppy. Tasted like apples. I’d try this again and give some patronage to my fellow Delawarians.

From a 12 oz. bottle with a blurb on the back label, no freshness date, sampled at cellar temperature in a pilsener glass. Poured a clear golden hued tarnished orange with a frothy, rocky white head, good retention, settled in a thin sudsy lacing, minimal amount of ringed sticking. A grape and red plum fruity aroma with a light amount of spiciness and sweet bready malts. Tiny bubbles at the top, moderate carbonation overall, and a crisp, dry, smooth medium-light bodied mouthfeel. Pleasant. but average tasting, sour grapes and dates, the fruitiness meshes with the alcohol to give the taste a mild acidity, grain bready with a hidden touch of sweet caramel, an soft earthy spice, herbal bitterness, and a dry sour fruity, grainy finish. Not a bad Maibock, I know my score reflects having tasted a much better Maibock at a brewpub last week, didn’t have the overall malty sweetness one would expect from a Maibock.
12 oz. bottle. Pours golden with white head that quickly diminishes with slight lace. Wheat aroma. Clean mellow taste that fills mouth with malt and slight bitter hops.
On draft at the Newtown Brewfest with Stegosaurus and The Mad Indian. Pours gold with a white head. Aroma of hops and grains. The flavor is sweet upfront and finishes bitter. Good beer.

bottle @ Newtown brewfest. Bottle was warm (as noted by other raters). Amber pour with heavy malt aroma. Very rough on the palate with a wide variety of flavors from herbs to grass to hops that didn’t seem to meld together very well. Should have been much better.

bottle at Newtown Brewfest. Chilled on ice, but still was kinda warm when served. Pours a clear light amber with a fluffy white head which fades a bit. Aroma is a bit sugary sweet, almost artificial, caramel and light toasted malts but the intense nutty and bready malts werent there. Herbal hops in the flavor with more sugary sweetness and even apparent alcohol towards the end. This wasnt very good.
Sampled with Stegosaurus and Beerded_one at Newtown Beerfest. Pours a hazy gold with fizzy head. Sweet and grassy aroma. Same as in taste. Ehh it is what it is.

On draft at the Newtown Brewfest with Beerded_one and the Mad Indian. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of grassy hops and grains. The flavor is slight ly sweet upfront followed by bitter grassy hops, and grains.
Sweet floral aroma. Pours golden with a slight white head. sweet caramel and fruit taste with a slightly hoppy finish. I was suprised to see that it had such a high alcohol content.
En engelsk ipa med en god afdæmpet humle der anes i eftersmagen. Der er også en god maltsødme.
Beautiful light red colour with a thin head. Mild but deep hop flavour. Supremely drinkable. Definitely worth a buy.
Aug 2012 Bottle. I recorded a number-only rating at the time unfortunately. I may rate it properly another time.

Bottle at home. Light reddish gold like a Star Wars moon, thin off white head. Aroma of hops, chocolate and caramel hints. Flavour some toffee, soy sauce, a bit of spice, some oaty malty stuff, got better as it warmed up. Not bad.
Clear copper, slight off white head. Nose is earthy hops. Bittersweet. Middle is caramel and earth, slight spice. Finish is medium spruce bitterness. Something seems to be not in the right place.
Pivni, York 26 Jan 13. Gyldenbrun. Litt uklar. Lavt skum med litt lacing. God fruktaroma. Smaken er bringebær. Svakt syrlig bitter ettersmak. Bra - men litt kjedelig.

Pours a slightly cloudy and bubbly orange copper colored beer with a large off-white head. Aroma is a very green hop with some citrus grapefruit and pine notes. Taste has a very hoppy tang to it dry with some malt in the background. Finishes with earth type flavors along dry hop finish.
From a 22 oz bottle shared at home. Pours a clear copper with an off white head. Light floral hop nose. Light citrus flavors. Clean bitter finish.
on tap pours copper, mini head. wet grains,,slightly bitter. pine. solid body. pretty boring of a beer.

Flaska. Guldfärgad med vitt skum som snart lägger sig. Arom: Smörkola, sura frukter och kräftspad (!?). Gräs, krusbär, karamell och (åter) kräftspad i smaken. Mycket märklig APA. Mycket märklig öl överlag. Gott? Tja, jag vet faktiskt inte.
Looks just like the IPA, but the smell and flavor differ. Light fruit on the notes with a thin caramel in the flavor, but perhaps a little hoppy by the style standards. Clean malt in the finish.
Clear golden with a creamy white head. Caramel and grain aroma and taste with earthy citrus notes.
Pour was lager brown no head, little lacing. No aroma...I tried. Flavor was malty but with a crisp lager bite. Smooth, rich mouthfeel. Not bad.
Sample. Amber/orange with off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, dry, fruit and hops.

Amber yellow with an okay head and medium body. Fruity, nutty, and carmel aroma. Good balance between malt and hops. Not overly hoppy which is a good thing with this beer. Clean aftertaste. Not like an Anchor Steam (the beer menu compares this brew to those steam beers in California). A good beer.
Aroma was an interesting mix of whiskey, rock candy and must. Very smooth, somewhat wood/nutty, and not hoppy compared to the other heavily-hopped brews that Max Lagers serves up. A very bronze brew.
Deep golden colour with a small white head. Malty, grainy and light sweet aroma. Malty, sweet flavor with a light grassy finish.

12oz Bottle: Clear orangey golden pour with a vanishing white head. Aroma isn’t bad, smells like apple juice with a distant skunk background. Thin and mild beer. Sweet applish notes and a light hint of caramel. Light pale malt hint in the finish. A decent Pale Lager (as far as Latin Pale Lagers go)

A orange beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet with primary notes of caramel and alcohol, but also hints of metal. The flavor is sweet and very bready, combined with notes of caramel, and with a metallic end.

Bottled. Orange coloured. Clear. Off white fluffy head. Aroma of light grass, sugar and fruits. Flavour is fruity as well. Very, very sweet and sugary. Almost cloying. Thin bodied and quite unbalanced. Dies quickly leaving a sugary rest on the palate. Quite unpleasant.
Bottle, thanks to Jeppe. Golden colour with a white head. Fruity, corn aroma and taste, sweet. Light body with a sweet finish.
Bottle, thanks to Jeppe. Clear yellow coloured with a white head. Aroma of malts and fruits with notes of corn. Sweet flavour of malts, fruits and corn. Very watery.

Snow white head, orange golden body. Maize and grain aroma, rather sickening and not very pleasant. Thin sweet grainy flavor with a sugary touch. Hint of bitterness shows in the finish. Not very good at all.

Yawn... I almost fell asleep in my glass. Ironically I have lived in PR for 3 years and have never seen this beer available locally. The only place I have ever seen it was a CUBAN restaurant in PHILADELPHIA.
Nothing really memorable about this beer...an easy drinking lager, very "grainy."
This is drinkable and that is about it. Only when it is ice cold, when this stuff warms up slightly it take terrible.
Ottima kellerbier!!! Bevuta dalla botte al Whynot Alassio... Profumo di pane erba e tutte le migliori caratteristiche di una stupenda keller della franconia... Super!

Bottle. Another clean German Kellerbier. Wholemeal bready characters. Some grassy hope in thew finish. Pretty straight forward, but i thought the balance was there and its something i could drink a lot of, no problems. Sweetish, and mildly bitter in the finish.

(bottle, a gift from pivnizub) Hazy mahogany colour with a foamy tanned medium head, lacing with crackling sounds. Slightly sweet toastmalty and cararmelly aroma with chocolate, slightly yeasty and herbal. Strong malty body with caramel and chocolate, dry, moderately bitter and slightly fizzy finish. Nice unfiltered Dunkel.
Malty and fruity (pear) aroma. Also malt in the taste, as usual in those Franconian beers. I found chocolate, caramel and tropical fruit.

Pours thanks to Grumbo. Country tick #119 - Pours gold white head - nose and taste of apple, sweet grain, marzipan, grass and vegetal notes - lighter medium body. Really wish this brewery was called Vandalay so it had two Seinfeld references.

Bottle 640ml. @ [ The Stat Improver Tasting ] - Saxo, Højbjerg - Aarhus, Denmark. [ As Mandalay Strong Ale ]. ABV: 6.5%. Clear medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, sweet malt, marzipan malt, vegetables, light grass. Flavor is light moderate sweet with a average duration, sweet malt, marzipan malt, vegetables, light grass. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20170617] 3-3-3-3-6

Bottle at Højbjerg tasting. Country #164. Pours pale gold with a bubbly white head. Aroma of hop, malt, grass and grain. Medium sweetness, light bitterness. Light body, slight oily texture, average carbonation.

Bottle @ Johns. Pours yellow with a white head. Aroma of malt, grain, vegetables, little grass. Flavor is sweet, malt, corn, sugar, light grass. Medium body, average to lively carbonation, sweet finish. 4-2-4-2-8. 170617
Bottle, 6.5%. Clear golden with small white head. Aroma is malt, grainy, corn, hop and a little marzipan. Flavour is malt, grainy, corn, little marzipan, medium sweet and a little bitter.
Bottle @ Saxo tasting. 6.5 % ABV. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, light fruity and vegetables. Flavor is quite sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 170617
Bottle @ Højbjerg tasting. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are bread, malt, fruits and hops. More of a malt liqour.
Bottle. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Week citrus notes. Light bitter flavor. Short light bitter finish. watery palate.

660ml bottle in Bagan, Myanmar. Pours a a pale copper gold with minimal white head. Aroma: Malt, grain, corn notes. Taste: Malts dominate the flavour balance. Mild corn, earthy flavours. Mild sweetness. Moderate bitterness. Not particularly hoppy. Watery texture. Light bodied. High carbonation. A decent beer (better than most other beers available in Myanmar).

Tasted 31/12/2016. Bottle in Mandalay. Poured a crystal clear golden amber with a one-finger bright white foamy head that diminished slowly to a very thin collar that laced OK. Carbonation moderate, slow and fine to medium. Aroma of slightly sweet malt which is slightly sweeter than other Myanmar lagers; no obvious hops. Taste of slightly sweet malt that is slightly stronger than other Myanmar lagers; no real bitterness. Light body. Crisp and smooth with a short, sweet finish.

I really wasn't into this stuff. I guess it's good, but I think you really have to want to like it. I'm not much for lagers in general, although I do like a good pilsener. This didn't really do it for me.

Great head and lace. The beer is naturally hazy. I detect a little bit of dyacetyl in the nose and on the palate. The butterscotch becomes much more noticeable as the beer warms. I guess having a summer brew a few days into fall is probably not a good idea, but the bottle does not have an age statement. Who knows when it was packaged.
The more I drink this beer, the more I appreciate it.Fruity,spicy,and quite refreshing.
A good summer brew. Light, but still has character.........................
Nice lemon flavor but a little watery. Had some aftertaste but overall a decent beer.

Clear straw. Foamy white head. Moderate carbonation. Toasted white bread aroma, grassy hops. Crisp yet full bodied with a toasted malt aspect, fresh mown hay and spicy hops. Clean and dry. Slight fruity yeastiness appears as it warms. Finishes well balanced with a touch more malt sweetness and increase in hop spiciness. A very good, non American Wheat, Summer brew.
INteresting, not so bitter but quite amber. Cloudy and with a graspy aftertaste. Strong and nice too.
Dark amber color. Malty and hops aroma. Malt flavors with some roasted flavors. Hop finish. Great label. Please bring this beer back to bottles!!

On Nitro A: pours a yellowish copper color, with a great creamy white head that leads to outstanding lacing. S: big draws of citrus brought on by the hops. Small hints of sweetness, almost like butterscotch. Very clean and crisp. T: very smooth and very creamy. hints of oranges with subtle hop flavors. great sweetness delivered from the malts. Light flavor of creamy butterscotch. Absolutely delicious. M: Very creamy and smooth leaves the mouth craving for more. so many complex flavors, but it doesn’t shock the palate, it pleases it. extremely well-balanced. D: Warning: you can easily drink 8 pints of this rather quickly. It is so smooth. Great job Alan Pugsley

On tap. Pours a medium brown. The hops are overpowering for my tastes and make the beer pretty bitter overall. It mellowed a little bit as I worked my way through it, but the initial taste was very hoppy.

Tap. Aromas of roasted, pine and some dried fruit with spices. Head is small, frothy, white with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is clear reddish amber. Flavor starts faintly sweet and a little acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is light to medium,watery with a lively carbonation and a lightly dry finish. A pretty good amber, but just about them same as every other middle of the road amber.

Nitrogen draft at redlight redlight. I had this one as the Shipyard Nitro. Not a bad session beer. Pours amber with a tight white creamy head.
