Notes of caramel and very subtle hints of hop in the background. The flavor is smooth. Not very complex but a nice balance of sweet and bitter. Great creamy mouth-feel.
Pours reddish brown with a tan head. Smells of sweet malt, some sweet citrus, earthy tea. Tastes earthy and tea like with some spicy hints on the finish.

Medium brown head. Opaque black body with dark brown edges. Roasty licorice and coke aroma. Dry licorice, chocolate, and coffee taste with soy notes. Light body. Dry roasty soy and burnt grain aftertaste. It’s OK, I guess. (0.65l bottle, Systembolaget, Charlottenberg.)
Bottle. Pours a dark amber body with a white head. Some berry, toffee, and butter malty character with some earth and caramel. Gone before you knew it.

Bottle, with Tommy at his Winter Six Pack tasting. Warm ruby, persistent fine tan head. Bright toasty cake aroma, a little lemon. Toffee, grape sweetness, some apparent alcohol. Butter, a touch of resiny hops in the finish. A very nice little wintery amber.

Bottle. Poured clear amber color with a medium frothy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate sweet grainy aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.
bottle at Our House in Allston. Best deal in Boston but not a particularly good beer. Some corn in the taste but nothing to write home about. SOlid cheap brew

Like the previous rater I got this at Our House in Allston. I drank this out of the bottle because this is how Boston Bars like to do it. It is pretty much a crappy pale lager if you want to find the cheapest beer in the bar. It isn’t offensive; it is better than Lionshead; it is obviously not too good.

Bottle @ Our House in Allston. Like the review below, great deal at @ $2 for a half liter. Better than most American macros, but not by much. Corn & barley tastes that do not excite but also do not repulse.

$2 bottle at Our House in Allston. Great value for $2. I’ve had this lager with and without a lime. Why? Because I’ve had it a million times so I need to change it up once in a while. This is a good drinking beer, not chugable because of its rich flavor. Certainly not the best beer available but certainly worth a try if you don’t want to spend a lot.

Only a dollar at Colonial Spirits, in Acton. I was slighly scared to try this, especially considering the pencil-shaving aroma. I was pleasantly surprised. It’s more than drinkable. Tastes like it cost a dollar, but it wasn’t a dollar wasted.

Ah, this takes me back to college. Nothing like a $2 Brubaker "pounder." Drinkable and not too light, fairly basic tasting. Wouldn’t go so far as to call it "good," but it’s good for a night out and your wallet.

Bottle. I was not given a glass for this magnificent beer, so I can not rate the color. I’ll just assume it looks like Coors Light. Aroma from the bottle is of skunky malt. Kind of like malt that had rotted in my gym socks (this could of course be the bottle and the nasty ice water it was soaking in). Taste is light and sweet with a little malt to be found. The greatest thing about this beer is it’s $2 for a 16oz bottle. I even got it for that price in downtown boston where a Bud will cost you $4. This is way better than Bud, and I’m kicking up it’s overall rating based on the price.

Pours with a light white head that fades slowly, leaving a some lace. Light-medium carbonation. Clear light amber color, light-medium bodied, starts malty and sweet, finishes mellow with some crispness, good session beer. $1.05 for a 16 oz bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA.
16oz bottle. for $3... smells like macro swill, looks like macro swill...*takes sip*... tastes like macro swill...but hey, its cheap and the label is ghetto and I need it for my BU Pub Quest.

column1: Golden City Clear Creek Gold Pale Ale
column5: Sample at the taproom. Clear golden color with a thin white head that evaporates quickly to a wispy film. Spotty lacing. Grassy hops, fruit and malt in the nose. Light-bodied with flavors of floral hops, citrus and biscuit malt. The finish is mildly bitter with a grassy hop aftertaste. Decent overall.

column1: Golden City Clear Creek Gold Pale Ale
column5: Tap@ Golden. Clear golden with white head. Mild floral, white bread, peppery aromas. Medium body.  Lagered pale malt dry ish base brew with light fruits, black pepper--not bad

column1: Golden City Clear Creek Gold Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery. Yellow, golden and clear with a small white head. Sweet and light bitter flavor with light floral hops. Light body with a smooth crisp feel and a sweet, clean finish. OK.

column1: Golden City Clear Creek Gold Pale Ale
column5: Clear light golden with a clean kolsch aroma of earthy pale cereal grains and leafy un-bitter hops. Taste of the same, boring and grainy.

column1: Golden City Clear Creek Gold Pale Ale
column5: Tap @ Golden City Brewery. Clear, very light yellow appearance with a white head. Grainy, husky, straw aroma. Fairly sweet, husky, grainy, pale malty, straw flavor. Actually not horrible.

column1: Golden City Clear Creek Gold Pale Ale
column5: Bottle 22fl.oz. Clear light medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, toasted notes, light hoppy, leather - grass notes. Flavour is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, pale malt, fruity, herbal. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120529]

column1: Golden City Clear Creek Gold Pale Ale
column5: Bottled. A golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of malt and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw, leading to a dry finish. The body is light. Thanks pinball for sharing.

column1: Golden City Clear Creek Gold Pale Ale
column5: 22 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is cornish and light grassy. Cornish, grassy and straw. Cornish and light grassy finish.

column1: Golden City Clear Creek Gold Pale Ale
column5: Bottle, courtesy of Pinball. Clear light golden with a small white head. Herbal, skunky hop aroma, quite fresh, quite dry. Taste is orangey sweetness, herbal hops, dry bitter finish, ligh metallic note, cabbage water. Much better than the not above suggests.

column1: Golden City Clear Creek Gold Pale Ale
column5: Bottled. Golden coloured. Fluffy off white head. Aroma of herbs, fruits and a touch of sweetness. Flavour of fruits, sweetness, vague flowers. Medium bodied. Ends on a light bitter note.

can as a gift. This is a really clear beer with a bold color and a firm white head. Quite good looking. The aroma is nutty with caramel, a touch of wet hay/wet dog, and subtle hints at berries. The body is medium with carbonation levels right in the middle too. Sweet flavors of bread and toffee almonds come through. I was expecting an American red ale when I cracked this, but this is clearly European leaning. I get big Munich malt impressions. It finishes clean and semi-sweet. Not much hop character to speak of. It's all about the malt with flavors of nuts, biscuits, puffed rice, and toffee.
Draft at the brewery. Poured reddish amber with an off white head. Aroma was caramel, sweet malt. Taste was bittersweet, caramel, toasted malt.

Sample at the taproom. Clear reddish-amber color with a medium thin off-white head that recedes quickly to a wispy film. Short strings of lace. Roast malt, fruit and hops in the nose. Light-bodied with flavors of caramel malt, earthy hop and fruit. The finish is sweet with a short malty aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.
Tap@ GCB. Clear dark amber with ivory head. Toast, caramel, earthy lagered malt aromas. Smooth medium body. Lagered toasted caramel base brew with subtle herbal hoppage ---smooth finish___ not bad

On tap at the brewery, GABF week 2014. I did not know exactly what kind of beer this was while drinking it, but i did not think altbier. Mild malt aroma and flavor. Low carbonation, not too heavy on the palate making it easy to drink, but I thought more of a red ale than an alt.
Cool looking can. Pours a hazy reddish brown with hardly any head. Got a bit of a green apple aroma/flavor problem. Ick. Pretty malty with a lingering bitter finish. Flawed.

Bottle from the brewery. Pours a clear, deep ruby color with little to no head. Light aroma of some malt. But not much after that. Light roasted malt and caramel taste. Both flavor and aroma are kind of lacking. Not that great of a beer.
Draft at Woodys pizza in Golden. Good refreshing red, subtle hop build, smooth bitterness, satisfying finish.

On tap at the brewery. Amber and clear with an off-white head. Light to medium body with a smooth, crisp feel. Light bitterness and medium sweetness with bread, toasted malts and light caramel. Not bad.
On tap at brewery. Excellent beer. Great red, great color, not much nose though. Still a good beer.

On tap at GCB as "Cherry Bomber Inspired Ale". A Kölsch + Cherries. Cloudy amber appearance with a small white head and light lacing. Fruity and sweet cherry flavor with light malts and a fruity finish. Not bad, just a fairly one-dimensional fruit beer.

Head is initially small, fizzy, off-white, fully diminishing. Body is dark reddish brown, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (light bread, caramel), with a light note of cherry. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic. Finish is moderately acidic, lightly bitter, slightly unclean/dull. Light to medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation, lightly astringent.
dark orange/amber in colour. small fluffy head. strong malty nose with swet malty tatse
Light amber-orange colour. Fruity aroma and fairly bland fruity malt flavour. Slightly buttery.
Black in colour, small fluffy head. soft aroma of coffee. bitter coffe tatse but has no bdy or bite.
Malted chocolate aroma. Sweet oatie/chocolate flavour. Relatively thin bodied for a stout, but still well rounded with a coating mouthfeel. Quick, clean finish.
have to agree with eczy that this just tastes like speights gold with extra alcohol. no hops, hint of toffee and metho

called just "extra strong ale" when i had it? dunno if a beer this useless justifies the hassle of entering a new beer. tastes of bland nutty malt and nought else apart from formaldehyde, like Speights with 2% more alc. bland. short on the palate, monotone on the palette, should be minimal stocks on the pallet.
nice gold colour with big spritzy head. little or no aroma. sweet almost brnady tatse

Pale, slightly cloudy, golden-yellow colour. Candy malt aroma. Sweet, sugary, Belgian-type malt flavour. I'm told by the brewer that this beer is lagered and it is reflected in its smoothness and rounded flavour. Basically a lagered tripel. Interesting concept, which I rather like.
On tap. Pours gold. Lemon, plum, sweet, sharp vinegar. Extremely clean and pretty tasty.

Pours a crystal clear, almost neon gold with no head even when forced. Moderate aromas of honey and wild flowers with a mild grain bite and an unidentifiable dank note. Flavours bring more of the savoury, basement dankness forward, accented by the honey floral notes from the aroma. Somewhat sweet and medium-full bodied. The sweetness lingers in the finish.

On tap in the beer garden at the brewpub. 4% ABV Deep golden with excellent clarity and a decent head. Feel: Crisp, with medium+ carbonation and a dry finish. Quite aromatic and fruity for style, and with high quality at that. The flavor is more average but certainly satisfying. Lasting, mildly bitter, hoppy aftertaste. O: Recommended, although not the most interesting beer from Mussel Inn.

New World Kiwi hops give it a citrus character that’s reminiscent of Cascade and Hallertau (orange gelatin candy, apricot nectar, lemon balm, pepper / spice, a little bit of cheese rind mustiness) while a quieter intrusion of Nelson / Motueka give it that burnt pineapple / papaya and green onion character. Malt sits in the background with a soft honey succulence. Body is savory and rich but malt texture is brash, which the rough carbonation amplifies. Medium+ bitterness, medium sweetness, prickly acids which combined with the harsh texture make a half-glass about all I can stand. Flavor and aroma-wise this might be a high 3 if the body were smoothed out. From draft.
The head is ok, body blond. It smells malty, sweet. The taste is malty, sweet, spicy. Sweet, less sour. Ok…
Appears to be a well made lager. Clear yellow poor with slight white head that disappears quickly. Slightly sweet. Refreshing.

Pours golden and clear, thin dissipating head. Aromas of gooseberry, grass, tangelo and meringue. Initially full with loads of carbonation. Light, soft and slow to develop flavour. A tinge of bitterness and dries on the palate. Tails off herbally (roemary and chives) with freshly buttered toast. Not a full on flavour attack but pleasant. "An easy drinking lawnmower beer" quoth the brewer. Bang on.

The colour was golden amber with a moderate head. There was a crisp green hoppy aroma. The flavour had smooth ginger and biscuity malt, and medium bitter hops and dry yeasty finish. This beer had nicely balanced flavours with a crisp light bitter finish. A very pleasant beer without being outstanding.

330ml bottle. Doesn’t look too bad compared to most pale lagers. Thick merengue of white foam that leaves a good bead of lacing on the glass. Deep golden amber colour with a citrus hop aroma. A bit dry in the finish with some mild bitterness in the flavour. Overall this is pretty good for a pale lager.

330 ml bottle Aroma: Hoppy, floral; Appearance: golden brown with large head dissipating quickly leaving minimal lacing; Taste: surprisingly mild yeast with very little bitterness; Palate; medium to light body, trace of astringency, finishes quickly to a yeasty aftertaste; Overall: Not all the remarkable but a nice drop.
On tap at the brewery. Pours black. Chocolate, coffee, plum and fig, bit of toast, some bitter roast but not too much. Medium body. A well balanced easy to drink dark ale.
Dark brown, really nice dark malt complexity, dry finish with a toasty, chocolate note.

Small beige head dark pour aromas mild roast coffee chocolate hint of caramel flavours roast coffee liquorice note chocolate medium bitter milky note has some richness in it a fair sweetness finish a little down in taste but drinkable some okay bitter sweet backing but needed more oomph

On tap in the beer garden at the brewpub. Deep and dark mahogany; clear with a decent head. Feel: Lightly crisp, with low (too low) carbonation and a semi-dry finish. A bit watery Aroma: a mix of lager and schwarzbier. The flavor is more average but certainly satisfying. Lasting, mildly bitter, hoppy aftertaste lacks dark roasted malt flavor. O: Not bad, but disappointing.

As others have said, and as it says on the bottle, it’s not a porter it’s a dark beer and it is very nice... until the metallic/ tinny aftertaste kicks in. And if you let it sit, after a while the aroma changes from malt to malt-with-a-hint-of-vinyl, but if you give it a swirl, it’s back to malt again. That drags it down from "very good" to "better than a macro". Maybe my bottle wasn’t fresh.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a lazing tan head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, soy sauce, and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, soy sauce, and caramel, leading to a dry roasted finish.
The Mussel Inn are producing a bunch of competent beers, but they are not leaders, or trend setters, or making their own path, they’re just making a beer. I cried.

So fitting to call it a Dark Horse! First of all I wound never chose it out of the shelf if not with the specific intention to try it. Not an appealing presentation. But surprise: this is bloody good! This Dark Horse makes it ahead! Nice dark chocolate nose, so dark that it gets bitterer by the minute. Good sign. Hardly any mocha or coffee notes. That’s another point. I’d say this is much more of a chocolate stout, so strong the cocoa notes are, but never a sweet stout. Bitter and sweet are well balanced on the flavour. It is full bodied, taste is round and well packed with a chalky feel, perhaps the char having turned to ashes. Not bad at all! Extremely pleasant to drink. The Mussel Inn boys gave their recipe to the right people to brew it.
Bottled from South City New World, Christchurch, NZ. Sark colour, with big head. Chocolate nutty flavour. Medium-strong bitter finish.

You can’t see through it and it has a mocha head that subsides slowly. Chocolate malt aromas, nutty roastiness. Similar in aroma to just about every other microbrew dark ale and a similar taste too. Could easily be mistaken for Invercargill Pitch Black. Nice enough, but not outstanding.
(Bottle) Average stout. Unfortunately alcohol is showing little too much in the taste and aroma could be stronger.

as below, the alcohol is so overwhelming on this one that it strangles everything else. it’s a little hard to see beyond the alcohol, although there certainly was a fairly nice stout below there. oh well.

Blood red black, with no noticeable head, but a lovely aroma of plums, chocolates, and alcohol. The flavour is dry bitter, nice to start, in spite of the coffee notes, but the 7% takes over everything, smothering the roasts and the licorish, feeling like there’s a lot more alcohol in the beer. I would have liked to see it more subtle and taste the stout better.

Pours very dark with rosy port-like notes. Little apparent head and is a sort of off-white. Smells of port, flowers, molasss, fresh coffee ad has flavour of that same port, toffee, pumpernickel and medicinal alcohol. The bitterness isn’t overpowering, rather complimentary to the lush winey flavours. It ought to have been served slightly warmer than it was, but that’s not a fault of the beer.
Sampled at Beervana. No tasting notes I’m afraid, and it was too long ago to remember specific details. I do remeber being reasonable Impressed though.

Bottle, available only at the brewery. Oily black pour, brief head with no lace. Sweet aroma of treacle, chocolate, and fig jam. Rich figgy flavour, sweet and fruity with some chocolate liqueur. I couldn’t find any burnt malt here. Sweet, full bodied, warm finish.

(Bottle 33 cl) Comes in a Danish beer bottle! Pours very dark brown with a vague tint of orange and a rough, beige head. Big aroma of nuts, wood and alcohol. Good, full, body, very low in carbonation with plenty of accents of dried fruit, nuts, wood and alcohol. Slightly burned in the finish. As most Mussel Inn beers this defies category, but I find Old Ale to be the closest style. 310108

Tasted 31/01/2008. Bottle direct from the brewery, courtesy of Papsoe. I see a garnet highlighted dark brown beer that’s so lowly carbonated it borders on lifeless. Looks like it would love to go through a beer engine, to turn the airy disappearing head into a thick foamy collar. Chocolate, sweet espresso, cola, liquer and a little lacquer greet the nose. In the mouth it is much of the same, like a chocolate liquer with coke. The finish is a little overwhelmingly lacquer-like. Great cask style carbonation and full weighty mouthfeel. Very nice strong mild recipe that hasn’t quite been executed right.

330 ml bottle from the pub. Pours afine black with warm brown tinges. Sweet aroma almost bourbon tinged with char notes. Beautiful full whipped cream head, almost like a cappichino. Lovely body, warm toffee with coffee & slightiest touch hop dry finish. Almost like caramello but with dark chocolate. Suprisingly easy to drink given it’s abv. Beautiful beer from a fine establishment

Bottled. Near black, no head. Roasty and lightly grainy. Very dry and salty with medium body. The mouthfeel is a little bit coarse, but when it warms some coffee and chocolate shows up and covers that. Surprisingly low bitterness.

Bottle at the Jester’s House. I thought I had rated this already. Anyway, it is a nice and simple beer, cloudy golden colour, aroma of lemon, fruits and something sweet. Flavour is grassy but fresh, not too sharp, with lemon, grapefruit, some type of citrus sorbet, and a background of malt. Beer is crisp and full-bodied.

Bottle in Nelson, 11/6/2014. Listed at 7%. Pours a copper color, thin fizzy head, decent lacing. Aroma is straw malts, light honey caramel, nice citrus, tropical notes with slightly vinous hoppy grass notes. Taste is moderately bright citrus, spicy pine and grass, light toasted straw. Light, crisp body. Decent pale ale.
rating from backlog, sugary sweetness dominates, not an awful lot of flavour beyond that. okay.

Similar golden colour and head to the Golden Goose. Aroma is summery, coase grass, lemon meringue and spices. Flavours of ornage lobes, lemon twist that brins a twang of acid and then very softly bitter. The aftertaste is strong, spicy and lingering. It makes the act of drinking this beer secondary to the arrival of the flavour.
Pours a hazy amber with a small white diminishing head. Nice lacings. Sweet and very bitter. Heavy malt aromas of grain. Some alcohol notes. Bitter finish.

(Bottle 50 cl) Pours a slightly hazy golden with a creamy, off-whitehead leaving a neat, broad lacework. Aroma of fruit, diacetyl and alcohol. Quite full-bodied with a very soft and velvety mouthfeel, lots of fruit and a whiff of Belgian yeast. The finish is astringent and alcoholic. 310108

Tasted 31/01/2008. Direct from the brewery, courtesy of Papsoe. Cheers! Pours a brilliant pale rose gold with a just off-lacy white head. Sea spray dry hop character and spice on the nose. Some alcohol and ripe stonefruit in behind. Lucious malt sweetness in the mouth, carried by velvety full weight and soft carbonation. Justa little hop flavour anda very mild bitterness. Becomes a little too warming and phenolic in the finish. More Belgian than English, for me.
Tasted Jan 07 @ Brewpub. Bottle cond - Mid golden colour, slightly cloudy. Sweet butterscotch start with a mild hop dry finish. Soft carbonation - nice beer

Bottled. Cloudy amber, very small head. Hoppy aroma of melon and mango. Medium sweet and near full bodied with soft mouthfeel. The bitterness is surprisingly low after all the hop aroma. A full sized ale displaying NZ hops, but perhaps not the most complex of their beers. Mussel Inn however rank as one of the most charming locations to have a beer anywhere.
On tap at the brewery. Pours slightly hazy light yellow. Bubblegum, peach, pepper, cereal, minerals. Spritzy body. Quaffable.
Draft. A yellow beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of straw and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, straw, and fruit, leading to a bitter finish.

What strikes me first and foremost is that it is clear. Not cloudy or with generous amounts of banana or clove. Instead you get a nosefull of sharp malt and aromatic lager if anything. Such an odd beer because there was no indication of the wheat malt unless this was a kristalweizen. Easily drinkable though.

(On tap) In their own beer menu description this is called a "Crystal Weizen". Almost clear, pale golden with a small, white head leaving some lacing. Very delicate and sophisticated aroma from the Sauvin hops - I think I can actually smell some Sauvignon Blanc here - is that where the hops got their name from? Medium body with a dry malt base and a fairly bitter finish. 290108
500ml bottle @ the bar. Bottle conditioned. Pale straw gold. Marmalade and a touch of wheat on the nose. The flavours are balanced & very subtle. Buttery, vanilla with the wheat not too pushy. Deft.

column1: Mussel Inn Heat Rash Chilli Beer
column5: I was extremely lucky to have got a bottle where the chilli hadn’t been in for a long time, otherwise I would have handed my mouth back to its maker for a new one*. In ddition to the standard aromas there is a rush of capsicum and cayenne on the nose. It smells dangerous. It tastes dangerous too. There’s a rickly heat that starts on the tongue and speads downward. The aftertaste of the piquancy lasts for a good twenty minutes. Wow, just wow. *When I was five, my father was dryin cayenne peppers in his lounge and I was told not to touch them and so I was left alone in the house with orders not to touch something. Well, I touched them. And my face and my eyes and my mouth. In hindsight it was my first self-inflicted learning opportunity and it is only now that I’m at law school that I’m asking what father leaes a five year old in a house by himself all afternoon? Bastard.

column1: Mussel Inn Heat Rash Chilli Beer
column5: Bottle tasting at Beervana 2008. I got the chilli in my glass, which looks awesome! Poured golden, with a white diminishing head and a chilli on top! Aromas of chilli, thats about it. Strong capsicum flavour, warming the mouth with a slight spicyness. Some hops are present with a malty background. Wierd but nice!

column1: Mussel Inn Heat Rash Chilli Beer
column5: Tasted 31/01/2008. Bottle direct from the brewery, courtesy of Papsoe. Pours gold with a slight haze, a disappearing head and a light lace. Green chilli and a little ginger dominate the nose, with an underlying note of lolly-like malt. Sweet malt and hot chilli dominate the mouth, and a low carbonation level really allows the chilli to really show its hand. My sinus tickles just reminiscing about this one. The best commercial chilli beer I’ve had thus far - but that’s not even close to saying I’d buy it for anything other than a laugh.

column1: Mussel Inn Heat Rash Chilli Beer
column5: (Bottle 33 cl) Pours a hazy golden with a small, off-white head. Very peppery aroma. Rather light in body completely dominated by the spicy and HOT chili that completely numbs your palate. Oh dear - why? 310108
330ml bottle. Pours dark orange brown. Biscuit, caramel, plum, bubblegum, synthetic grape, honey, booze, cheap wine, lots of synthetic candy fruits. Smells much better than it tastes.

International IPA day train tasting with Kenny, all aboard the 15.50 from Waterloo to Sirenville, 01/08/14. Mahogany brown with a good sized tan covering. Nose is malty, dark fruit, spice, raisens, fruit cake tones. Taste comprises dark fruits, raisens, light booze, fruit cake mix, spice, currants. Medium + body, fine carbonation, lightly warming booze in the close with a little hop presence. Ok Belgian strong, drinks fine for 10% not too hot.

1st August 2014 Micro train tasting with Colin on the way to Siren. Chesnut brown beer, good pale tan head. Palate is light and semi dry, good fine carbonation. Bitterish malts with bitter dark toffee. Little dry cream. Bitter dried fruits. Light airy finish. Warning linger.
Thick body, nonexistent head, 330ml, enjoyable but not something I would buy regularly. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

An interesting beer that tasted like a cross between the advertised Belgian strong ale and a regular double/imperial IPA. Well balanced with enough bite to leave you in no doubt you’d be walking home if you had another.

Weak head misty deep brown pour medium carbonation aromas grape floral yeast sweet caramel dried fruit cinnamon clove wine the flavours fruit sweet sugar cinnamon clove dried fruit rich grapes caramel sticky note smooth red wine taste the finish enjoyable ale best tastes spice red wine good on palate fruity lingering taste

On tap at Meow in Wellington. A big 10% beer like we brew in America. Finally found a big beer in New Zealand. This beer has a rather mild aroma but in all fairness it should have been served in a snifter instead of a half pint. Flavor is malty with a nice sweetness balance. Alcohol is present and almost has a barrel aged bourbon flavor even though I don’t believe it us barrel aged. Color is deep amber and poured clear and not hazed. Enjoyable!

Monkey Puzzle? More like muddle puddle to look at. Not that I wish to denigrate the efforts of the fine people at the Mussel Inn, but this was not a good looking beer. It was good smelling though with aromas of marmalade, carob (I hate carob), cocoa and stewed apricots. This was evident in the flavour, of which there was shitloads, along with the distinct warming alcohols that let you know that you’d better not be contemplating driving after this one. The lingering finish was interrupted by my learned off-sider who wanted me to try their heat rash chilli beer. Ah well, I’ll just have to try again tomorrow.
Bottle from beerstore.co.nz. Bright orange in colour with thin white head, which disappeared quickly. Big malt aroma. Spicey nutmeg/honey flavour that lingers in mouth for ages.

On tap at Beervana 2008. Pours cloudy amber. Aroma is yeasty with some hop & sweetness. Explodes with flavours, sweet beginnings, then some milk chocolate leading into caramel, hops remain throughout in the background. The bitterness breaks through the sweetness to make this a really balanced strong flavoured dangerously drinkable beer.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Pretty good beer. Color of marmelade with a small white head. Nose of fruit, taste of sugar and a little spice, harsh finish of rice pudding.
Strong fruit aroma, notes of apricot. Big white head, half clear gold color. Medium sweet, some sour, not bitter at all. Light body with medium carbonation.

Tap at the brewery. A: Apricot in color with a thin white foamy head and lacing. N: Apricots, peaches, cracker, heather, some lemon zest, grapefruit, touch of pine, wheat, and grist. T: Tart, sweet, juicy. Apricot buoyed up by the base beer. M: Light body, no alcohol, foamy carbonation. O: Bit of a lifesaver fruit beer. Not too shabby, but nothing to pine for.

Draft at Bru Craft. Hazy gold pour. Moderately tart wheat beer with stone fruit flavors. Apricot. Peach. Tangerine. Caramel malts. Toasted puffed wheat. Somewhat fizzy. Balanced, but more like a soft drink.
Vom Fass in Eureka. Trüb oranges Vier, hoher heller Schaum. Fruchtiger Duft. Antrunk herb vergohrene Aprikose und Hefe. Süffig und damals absolut neu!
Draft sample at Dominion Wine & Beer. Clear orange with off-white head. Aromas of apricots, stone fruit, light wheat. Tastes of light apricots, wheat, malt. Medium body with a dry finish.

5oz draft pour at Whole Foods Old Town Alexandria. I’m pretty sure I’ve had this before, but never got around to rating it, so here it is. Poured a hazy yellow color with a small white head. Aroma was a pleasant character of apricots, light wheat notes.
Draught from whole foods old town. Cloudy pale yellow pour. Fruity apricot and acidic wheat.

Tap to glass @ Lost Coast tap room@ Eureka,CA Look: Dark/yellow orange, medium head goes away quickly, hazy cloudy Aroma: more aromatic that other wheat beers from this brewery, grains Taste: low bitterness, not a lot of taste Feel: fizzy, abrupt, no follow through Overall: fair beer free ok, not to repeat, but not to look for April 11, 2016

Une mousse d’épaisseur respectable et très nuageuse se pose sur une bière dorée à peine voilée. Une touche très discrète de blé est envahie par des arômes de jus de pêche de marque Fruité. Disons que ça sent un peu "artificiel". La céréale est plus présente en bouche, surtout en finale, et les saveurs d’abricots semblent moins fausses. Ce n’est pas une très grande réussite, mais ça se boit très bien à 30 degrés Celsius. Quand tu n’as pas d’autres alternatives.

On tap at the Library Alehouse in Santa Monica. Clear golden appearance with a lacy white head. Artificial fruity aroma with hints of bread and light herbal hops. Sugary and sweet with a light body. Meh, OK.

This was called Morans dunkelweizen at the Alpharetta location (10/30/08). Very dark pour, barely any head. Aroma is rich and fruity. Nice malt profile on the nose and that leads to a pretty nice sweet malt tongue with some dark fruit and syrup. No bitterness that I detected. Spicy and pretty full mouthfeel. Nice beer.
Best beer of the lot. Strong malt flavors with lots of bubble gummy esters. A friend says ripe bananas, I get more Dubble Bubble. A bit watery, but not as bad as their other beers.
Schönes filtriertes goldgelbes Bier mit idealer Schaumkrone. Für ein Pils nur wenig hopfig, aber für den fränkischen Gaumen gerade richtig. Sehr lecker.
bottle bb 18/4 oro leggera velatura buona schiuma media persistenza diacetile leggero erbaceo media secchezza amaro medio diacetile un po troppo invasivo

Slightly hazy golden body with a medium, foamy white head. Aroma is cereals, grass, noble hops. Taste is cereals, mild grassy, lots of mineral. Mineral and mild sour finish. Medium body, average natural carbonation, thin texture
Clear golden. Aroma is malt forward with herbal and bready hops. Taste is bready and sweet malt. Incredibly drinkable. I love it.
Bottle, thanks hubi. Nose is citrus, grains, citrus, bread. Palate is sweet buttery bread, citrus, bitter finish. Nice lager

Bottle from Biervana, bottled 53 hours ago, many thanks hawanna for bringing this back! Clear golden color with fluffy white head. Aroma is malty, grassy, cereals. Taste is cereals, medium sweet maltiness, a bit rural, sugar icing, noble hop finish. Fatty oily Landbier mouthfeel with natural carbonation. Very drinkable and balanced, very well-made, but definitely not on par with the unfiltered version.
Bottle. Lightly hazy golden, white foam. Hay, grassy, light rural and mineral. Medium body, chewy, light sparkly, a hint bubblegum, broad land Bier, but fresh! Quite moreish.

0,5 l bottle from Biervana bread, cereal, herbs, golden, hazy, white foam, frothy, medium sweetness, lightly-medium bitter, medium body, oily feel, slick feel, average carbonation, very nice franconian Pilsner
On tap @ Café Klatsch Ansbach - Nice round franconian pilsner. Medium body with gentle bitterness surrounded by thin pale malts.
Old rating. Best before 06.02.11. Nice malty round beer with a nice bitterness. Fresh, hints of grain and a moderate sweetness. Nice stuff!

500ml bottle in 2012. Deep amber with an offwhite head. Aroma of toasted malt, candied peal and raisins. Big malty flavours with crisp notes and a lovely dried fruit edge. Sweetness is well measured and there’s a small amount of spice in the mix.

500ml bottle from Dan Murphy’s. Poured a deep mahogany with a lasting and lacing off-white to light tan head. Chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruits, some dried fruit aromas. Mid-weight, medium carbonation and a moderate length and intensity roasted malt bitterness to finish with hints of coffee.

19/10/2019. Bottle from Cotswold Vintners, Chipping Sodbury. Pours mid brown with a towards beige head. Aroma of dried fruit, malt, Christmas cake, orange truffle, dates and toffee. Medium plus sweetness and light to moderate bitterness. Medium body, slight sticky texture, soft carbonation. Pretty decent.
Stout-like with coffee and prunes on the nose. Good char, with long hop finish and creaminess for balance.

10Feb2019 Dark toasted malts, burnt toast, dark chocolate, cacao, toasted straw. Clear, very dark brown, small, creamy, beige head. Light bitter. More dark, sweet, toasted malts, burnt toast, cacao, chocolate cake, soft carbonation, medium to full bodied. Decent. Bottle from Ocado.

500ml bottle. Bottle calls it a porter, rb calls it an ESA. Very dark brown colour with tan head. Bit lighter than usual for a porter. Dark malt, black coffee, soy sauce, gravy granules, brown bread, light dark fruit, weird light herbal, weird light medicinal.

Bottle from The Beerhive. Clear ruby body with a thin off-white head. Faint lacing. Aroma of fruit cake and toffee. Flavour of caramel, toast and cherry. Medium body with a slick texture. Soft fizz. Rich and warming. Decent.
500ml bottle from Good Spirits Co. Dark Reddish brown with a thin off white head. Toffee and fruit aroma, flavour is berries and caramel. Tasty

the aroma is caramel and fruity with hints of prunes, dried apple, raisin, toffee and berries... the taste is fruity and floral with notes of dried plum, toffee, raisin, dried apple and some sweet berries... the aftertaste is sweet, dry and bitter...
Reddish brown with a glint. Caramel treacle well rounded and tasty bottle from ocado

Bottiglia. Il gusto al naso è indirizzato verso l'orzo tostato. L'olfatto viene stimolato in maniera normale e il modo in cui permane è sufficiente. Il cappello di schiuma resiste abbastanza. La grandezza delle bollicine è medio-fine. Il liquido è di aspetto velato. Il colore è giallo dorato carico. Il corpo è medio. L'amaro non è invadente. La forza gustativa è normale e permane in maniera sufficiente. Il finale è amarognolo. L'aroma in bocca porta i segni di miele, amaretto, frutta secca, resina, agrumi e arancia amara.

500ml bottle from Dan Murphy’s. Poured clear golden amber with a one finger, lasting and lacing off-white head. Citrus, tangerine and peach aromas with some grain, citrus peel, and caramel and biscuit malts. Mid-weight, medium carbonation and a moderate length and intensity bittersweet finish.
Bottle - clear light amber, initial very decent white head. Pleasant fruity aroma. Good mouthfeel. Clean, pleasant tasting. Good all round beer.
A: Clear gold with a small white head. N: Citrus and fruity notes. T: Slightly sweet with lemon peel notes P: Medium O: Quite enjoyable.
Appearance: clear golden, medium head Aroma: light hay and malt Palate: medium mouthfeel, low carbonation Taste: light malt, low hops, slightly tart

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Appearance - orange to copper. Neat white head. Nose - toffee and spiced biscuit. Taste - burnt toffee and brown spiced bread. Palate - medium bodied at least. Rich and roasty texture. Dry, crunchy, bitter finish. Overall - slightly challenging but good ESB.

500ml bottle. Light amber colour with white head. Pale malt, tangerine, citrus, bready, grassy, light green apple, weird light herbal, weird light medicinal, weird light chlorine, orange peel, light grassy hop finish. Solid
The bitterness is a little rustic and barnyard-like. Not the most pleasant aroma. Decent, not one to keep coming back to. D&S Dresden

Amber and slightly cloudy, with very little head. The aroma is pretty powerful: deep and sweet and malty, with notes of red apple and whiskey, along with a hint of brown bread. Bitterness is (just about) assertive enough, lingering nicely in the finish and aftertaste. There is also a neat little dry edge to the flavour. All in all, this beer could be close to fantastic and I'm hard pushed to tell what's missing and why I'm not uber-excited - probably something to do with overall balance. But it's not a huge gripe and I would certainly buy this one again.

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega piirdun iga õlle juures selle tekstiga.

Gravicask (HBF2014, Friday) Honey and dry hops in the aroma. Soft palate, carbonation low. Similar soft sweet malts in the taste. Finish excellent - beautiful hops, some zesty aromatics, a nice bitter hint, and some rich earthiness. Rerate: Gravicask(HBF2014, Saturday) Sweet soft real ale aroma - classic modern pale bitter. Soft palate, carbonation low. Sweet malts, a little biscuity, a little starchy. Resiny dry hops, leaves a pucker and your tongue curled up. Not quite as good as yesterday’s.
Cask at Kitty’s, Helsinki. Colour is clear golden with thick small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, hay, grain, some hops and malts.
0,5l from cask @ St. Urho’s Pub. Pours clear golden with a medium soapy head. Aroma is malts with some fruits. Flavor is malts, fruits and hops. Good balance. Not bad.

Cask (gravity) @ The 18th Reading Beer and Cider Festival 2012, Reading, Berkshire England. Clear medium yellow orange colour with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, moderate hoppy, grass, tea. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, acrid tea bitter, malty, dry frass. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120505]
Draught. This is a nice refreshing golden ale that goes down smooth. Perfect spring beer.
Cask@Reading Beer Festival 2012. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is floral, citrusy, herbal and mildly wooden. Flavour is caramel, fruits, nectar and some mild vanillaish notes.

Cask, gravity dispensed, at the beer festival at the Marlow Donkey, Marlow, Bucks. Poured brilliant amber with traces of a scummy white head; grainy aroma; crisp fruity body; then a slightly more complex finish with resinous and peepery hops contributing to a prolonged clean bitterness.

Cask conditioned handpump Brunswick Derby. A light orange coloured beer with a white head. Fruity and hoppy. House yeast works well in this. Good citrus flavours from the hops and a nice balancing body providing malt base. Nice bitterness. Tasty. Score 3.5 Subsequent rating scored 3.4 Score unaltered

Cask at Bishop Arms, Malmö. A light amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and straw as well as lighter notes of flowery hops. The flavor is sweet with light notes of malt, toffee, hops, flowers, and spices, leading to a dry finish.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Gold with a small white head. Slightly sulphurous note in the malty aroma. Taste was a good deal better; some citrus and grain and a mid bitter finish. Rather liked it.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Pours a clear orange amber with a large foamy white head that leaves ample lacing. The aroma is stone fruit and malt. Taste is malty up front with s nice full hop presence throughout the finish.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle from Lunardi’s in San Jose, CA. Aroma is dank nugs, earthy citrus. Taste is bitter orange peels, earthy dank ness and some dry pine. 🤙

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: The can says best by next month but it doesn't taste that fresh at all. The aromas are musty, dry grain, a little pale malt and a hint of hops. Flavors are like Nose, some bitterness yes but little to no hop flavor.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Partagée à Chaussan. Couleur jaune orangé, nez parfumé. En bouche l'équilibre est grand : une certaine douceur, bon fruité, un peu de pin. Amertume présente et belle longueur. Alcool à 7.5% inaperçu. Très bonne IPA!

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Rich aroma of malt, citrus and tropical fruits Taste: sweet malt, pineapple, grapefruit and hints of honey. Solid piny flavor in the aftertaste

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Appearance is amber and quite clear, a 1-finger off-white head. Aroma- pithy fruit, hop resin, big grapefruit and orange, stewed pineapple, tropical fruit. Caramel ‘sweetness’ is detectable. Taste- bitter hops, toasty malt undertones, pithy fruit, grapefruit, orange juice, pineapple, some sticky treacle in the finish. Good stuff.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Das Bier in der sportlich gestalteten Flasche hat eine schöne rote Farbe und überzeugt durch seine fein angestimmte Hopfung mit allerlei amerikanischen Aromahopfen wie Amarillo und Simcoe. Dadurch ist es recht bitter, behält aber trotzdem eine gute Süffigkeit.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Golden color with a big, white head that diminishes slowly, poor lacing.Light aroma of cereals and flowers, but that's it. Mild taste of flowery hops and some herbs with medium bitterness of medium-long duration. Generic texture and body. A quite disappointing beer for the brewery's renown, too mild aroma and simple taste.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Color anaranjado translúcido, dos dedos de espuma, excelente retención. Aroma a pino. Gusto bastante maltoso, caramelo, resina y toques cítricos, amargor final media, cuerpo acuoso, muy buen comportamiento. Estoy seguro que esta birra en EEUU es la bomba pero la que yo probé estaba muy justa de aroma y habiendo probado otros pepinos de Port Brewing me extraña, seguramente no estaría en su mejor punto de frescor. Me esperaba mucho más.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bomber. Grapefruit citrus aroma with notes of pine, floral and a bit of tropical fruit. Pours clear copper colored with a large off white head that has excellent retention and good, soapy lacing. Starts with grapefruit citrus and a little bit of tropical fruit flavors. Finishes dry and quite bitter with pine and floral hop flavors. Good to start but quite bitter at the end.

column1: Pizza Port Ale Nino Old Ale
column5: crisp and malty, vaguely belgian, but something lacking.....................

column1: Pizza Port Ale Nino Old Ale
column5: Blend of aged and fresh beer, more or less in the Flemish style, and the results are quite impressive - very complex, with malt and fruit richness. I would like to see this again.
Had a bottle from Adam. Absolutely outstanding IIPA. Nice mellow flavor without overly hoppy aftertaste.

Originally reviewed: 10/20/09. Poured into my conical pint glass. Pours a very cloudy copper gold with a big 2-finger off-white head resting on top. This sticks around a good bit, and leaves plenty of sticky lace. Smells of peppery spices mixed with a sharp twang. Not a big citrus or piney scent, very subtle. The feel of this one is crisp and clean, but it sips well. Slight creamy quality to it makes it a pleasure to drink. The spices I got in the nose come out in the flavor as well. Definitely some big time bitterness going on here, but it’s of the spicy variety. Dull black pepper start to this, that finishes more mellow and grainy. The semi-sweet citrus that I enjoy in IPAs is absent in this beer, but it’s still decent. It’s a different take on the style, and I commend them for it. I wouldn’t want many of these at a time as the spicy nature would wear on me, but I’d have it again.

aroma is lemon, lighty grainy sweetness, clean pale malt. appearance is full head that reduces to near belgian cotton candy, with absolutely huge lacing, good carb, lightly hazed gold. flavor is buried pine and balanced lemon/clean pale malts. light maltiness without even bare caramel and equally as simple but powerful enough hopping.

12 oz bottle. Is this really a winter seasonal? If so, I probably should not be rating this because it does taste a bit stale. What is interesting about this beer is I really can’t detect an aroma or flavor profile to write about. It is pretty much without either. There is a malt backbone and maybe some hints of citrus. But, even though it is a light bodied beer with some lively carbonation, there is a hop bitterness in the finish that I am able to give props to. Another than that, not a very good IPA.

12oz bottle. Thick, cloudy orange-tan color with a respectable head on it. Lots of earthy hoppy citrus flavor up front, followed by a nice toasty malt balanced, watery finish. Solid soapy/astringent bitterness. Walking the line between medium and full bodied, it remains pretty sessionable while still being quite flavorful. A respectable IPA.

12 oz. bottle at Lunar Brewing Co.. Poured a hazy, orange/amber with a light orange tint to the off white, foamy head, leaving some nice ribbons of lacing. The aroma was light with floral and citrus notes. The flavor added an astringent bitterness that over shadowed any good malt presence. Light bodied, drinkable, but unimpressive.

Hazy pour, light amber or dark gold, large white head, abundant sticky lace. Soapy hops bitterness, way more bitterness than aromatic qualities, malts have a worty, fresh oatmeal quality to them, but also a lactic staleness. There are some nice fruit qualities, citrus, apricot. Medium body, palate is both soft and lively. Disappointed: there’s a good beer trying to get out of here, but it didn’t make it.
12oz bottle. yike this is bad. rarely if ever say that but this one’s a mess. smells like hop extract, no hop flavor just bitterness, and it tastes like crap. pass on it.
Had on tap at a restaurant in Madison. The beer was okay, but the aroma was all pee and the flavor was much too bitter.
Cloudy copper color with a thin off white head. Extremely mild for an IPA. Light caramel aroma. Slightly malty with a dash of hops.
Probably the best real ESB I’ve had outside of England. Crisp, caramel color and just the right aroma. Do I sense Styrian Goldings? Perhaps a bit of EKG in the nose?
medium to light brown color. nice, slightly thick body. this started off well, the malt and hop were battling it out, but at the end, i was left with an odd, somewhat metallic hop flavor.

From my long lost notes. On tap at the Quarryman, July, 2003. Served in a pint glass. Arrived at the table gold with a thin white head. Moderate carbonation. Light indistinct aroma. Flavor was pretty standard fare for a pale ale. Nothing special.

This is an amazingly palatable beer with just-right bitterness, citrus notes, and a soft, quenching mouthfeel. Finish is dry and bitter just like it should be. This is an iconic beer and a damn good one, at that.
very good & tasty! Nice body & authority. sweet but not too. Good with pizza!
yum. thick and oh, so sweet. the maple syrup really comes thru strong. just enough hops at the end to keep it from getting cloying, but I probably still wouldn't want more than 2 of these in a row.

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Bottle from old backlog notes. Pours a clear amber color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have a basic malt profile, caramel, doughy bread, light fruit, herbal, thin and watery.

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Aroma and flavor is sweetish malts, mild tea and not quite enough hops/bitterness.

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: A bit of a milestone beer for me since this is the 1500 beer rating from the US. I picked this beer because it isn’t the first beer I ever tried, but it is the first beer I ever truly enjoyed, when I had my first experiences with beer at the age of 21. I know. I started the beer thing late. Pours a clear copper color. Appropriately. Super smooth, easy drinking. Light body. I’ve always enjoyed this beer, and after a 2 year hiatus of trying this, I still enjoy it. Probably my favorite Red Hook brew, though a lot of that is owed to sentimental value.

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass and a mug at different times and there was barely any difference between the two glasses. The appearance was a nice hazy but clear amber color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated gently into the beer leaving some light slightly clingy lacing. The smell had some light sweet caramel malts. The taste took those malts and added a gentle crisp hop bitterness. On the palate, this one sat about a light on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was somewhat smooth. Overall, not a bad beer just not generally a go to for me.

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: The body has a dark golden almost coppery color with good clarity. On top an aggressive pour produced a tall foamy white head. It has good retention and makes some sticky lacing on the glass. There is a sweet candy like malts with notes of brown sugar and some herbal hops of in the distance. It has a candy like character with hints of caramel, brown sugar and white bread. Hop bitterness is mild and adds some spicy/herbal notes to the mix. The hops come out a little more towards the finish and give some more balance to the sweet malt up front. It has a medium body, soft carbonation and a smooth texture.

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Appearance: no surprise, it is a copper colored ale. Pours about a 1 1/2" head that dissipates rapidly leaving moderate lacing. Moderate carbonation. Aroma: mild aroma, smell of toasted grains and sweet malt Mouthfeel: mouthfeel is watery and carbonated. Sweetness predominates but there is some mild hop to balance it. Finish is semi-dry. Flavor: flavor is consistent throughout with a blend of malt and hops. Overall: I really enjoy Copperhook and recommend it if you like session ales, Copper/Red ales, or if your palate runs more towards malt than hops.

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: 355ml bottle. Pretty standard fare, this. Went down easy, pleasant taste, refreshing. Much like their pils, this was a good mealtime table beverage, rather than a sensory experience. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Starts tasty and finishes to weakness. Easily drinkable in the heat, but there are better options. I Luke the variety pack as a crowd friendly mix/match. Good, but far from great. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Bottle. This is a pretty generic amber ale without a lot going for it. Fine for partys and cookouts.

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Pours a decent medium amber I wouldn’t call it copper. Aroma is that of cooked tomatoes barely registers and aroma. Taste has a slight bubblegum aspect if you really cycle some air through it while in your mouth. All around almost flavourless with a hint of bitter aftertaste... but not much. Fades to nothing after swallowing. Overall would be good to chug after a hard days work. Nothing offensive, but nothing worth praise either.

Draft at the Keg Liquors Fest of Ale. I was really pleased that David, the brewmaster at BBC brought this beer back out again. Pours a cloudy yellow with a full white head. Excellent lacing. The aroma is full of yeast and wheat. The flavor is excellent, with the coriander really coming through. A truly authentic version of this style.
A nice flavorful light wheat beer. Good head and nice cloudy pale color. A really nice summer session beer.
Very enjoyable and quite refreshing belgian wit. Spices are well balanced with the wheat flavors.
It has light malt in the flavoring. The flavor is sweet and well malted. No hoppy bitterness at all.

0.3 l bottle from Spar, Odense... Clear black color, looks like a cold coffee... Very sweet malt aroma of caramel and sugar... Tastes like real sugar, but quite refreshing... Sugar ending... Mixed with sugar, therefore minus points for not acting within the German purity...
Bottle @ Super Best, Odense. Pours dark amber with a small off white head. Sweet nose with rye, bread, sugar, syrup and metal. Flavor likewise. A bit thin. Drain . .
Bottle. Nice head with medium duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are rich malt and candy sugar, but not too sweet.
Black with a brown head. Malty aroma: caramel and brown sugar. Very sweet malty flavours and almost no bitterness. Refreshing, though.

Bottle, bought @ LIVA, Kolding. Pours clear deep brown with a small, creamy, cappucino head. Sweet aroma, some roasted notes, rye bread and quite a lots of toasted caramel. Medium carbonation, thin mouthfeel. Flavour is sickenly sweet, caramel, metallic, sugars. Yuk!

Bottle at home. Clear red brown coloured with a medium sized beige head. Very sweet aroma of molasses and caramel with notes of rye bread. Sweet flavour of molasses, caramel and rye bread with notes of dried fruits and hops. Sweet finish. A bit watery.
bottle. Dark red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malt, sugar, toffee. Flavour is sweet, malt, sugar, toffee. Very sugary beer.

Bottle. A dark brown beverage with a ruby touch, topped by a small, beige head. Malty-sweet nose with toffee, molasses, some dried fruits and hints of red wine. Too sweet on the palate, quite sticky and full-bodied with flavors of dark sugars, molassess, prunes and dried dades. Long sweet finish with some dried fruits and molasses. Maybe a touch of bitterness in the far back. It probably has it’s use, but I can’t see what it is. Still, it’s a flavorful one, but almost sickingly sweet. (081213)
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma and flavour of caramle, and sugar.
Strictly from memory. This was a decent shot at a light lager, but fell short on everything as usual. However, it had street credit from that kayaker on the label.
A carbon copy of almost every other American light beer. Flavorless, watery and thin.

Lightly hazed gold colour with a nice creamy white head. Slighlty cardboardy malt arima. In mouth, stronger signs of oxidation occurs, with corny adjunct malt definetely noted.Body of mineral water. Bought at CJs in Potsdam.

Appearance: clear, honey gold color, kind of pretty and appealing, head is a treat for the eye, too, bubbly, snow white, leaving a little lace, slowly simmering. After that, it’s all downhill. Nose is nothing, though I searched and searched, my nostril aflared...nothing bad, anyway... As for taste; a tiny hop drizzle appears for 1/1,000,000th of 1 second that fades away...body doesn’t exist...in fact, it stands as the very hallmark of negligibility! There are small specs of flavor here and there, very small, and not enough to merit the term "flavorful" as it appears on the label. I don’t understand the existence of this type of beer, though the majority of Americans seem to take them to their collective bosom. It’s even more mysterious when a small brewery or a craft brewer farts one of these things out.

Bottle: Light straw colored with a large white head. Almost no aroma, and a barely discernable malt flavoring in the taste. Very watered down....just like I’d expect from a pale lager. I guess it’s better than coors or bud.
why would anyone really make a LIGHT beer, or, for that matter, and why would they rate it?? It is ok, much better then standard lights, but, maybe next week it will low carb crap also.
Pours straw colored, with good head. Flavor is watery, with some sweetness. Finish is slightly astringent. Not bad for a light. This light is far better than Bud, Coors, and Millers regular beers.
Decent for a light but way too watered down. Not all that offensive but there's nothing there to be offensive.
Pretty straightforward. Not too much flavor but still beats most of the macros. Almost no aftertaste.

Not too bad of a light beer, but still watery. There is some actual malt flavor in there, and there are no foul off-flavors that are so common in many of the macro-brewed lites. Still pales in comparison to Sam Adams Light.
typical bland koelsch. the best you could say is that it tasted quite fresh. lemonade and detergent

Clean & carbonated, with a slight fruitiness; just below average for this style, IMO. Dry finish with a little bit of bitterness in the finish. These light styles are hard to make, so I give them credit for making a "clean product," but I wish it had more personality.

Draught. Light yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (light bread), lightly hoppy (flowers, perfume), with a note of DMS. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic. Finish is moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Too sour for the style (could be an old keg or infected, who knows), and unpleasant cooked corn aroma.
Hazy yellow, bright and clean. Lots of banana and clove. More watery than expected, but otherwise an impressive hefe.
Translucent yellow color. Aroma of citrus, clove, wheat. Light banana - more in the flavor. A touch lite, but pleasant overall.

Tap at the pub. Cloudy light yellow. White bubbly head. Wheat grainy aroma. Soft nose. Light earthy hops. Wheat flavor, low sweetness, grainy finish. Light bitterness with low grassy notes. Refreshing.
Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a hazy yellow color with a white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy banana aroma. Fruity wheat malty spicy banana flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy banana finish.

On tap @ Wynkoop. Hazy light straw pour with a white head. Nose is banana, clove, and wheat. Some grass, orange peel, and doughy sweetness. Flavor is sweet dough, banana, and clove. Bread, a touch of grass, orange, and a mild lemon zest note on the finish.
Sweet wheat beer. Aftertaste has hints of banana and the cloves give it some bitterness.

On tap at Wynkoop. Pour is hazy lemon peel with a small white head. Big clove, bubblegum, banana, somewhat musty, biscuity, citrusy, and grassy aroma. Taste is clove, light banana, bubblegum, straw, light biscuit, grassy, lightly sweet, and citrusy with a medium spicy finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Damn decent Hefeweizen.

Draught at Wynkoop as part of a flight, visited on October 7, 2012 Murky yellow color, white head. Sweet, phenolic, yeast, citrus taste. Spritzy mouthfeel, medium low bitterness. Acidic, citrus scent.

On draft at Wynkoop in Denver. Pours a hazy yellow with a white head. Nose is big banana, light wheat, bread, clove, and lemon. Flavor is similar with banana, lemon, and lingering cloves into the finish. Light in body and a nice wit.
Weird. I wish it was fuller bodied. Had on tap at the historic brewpub. Wasn’t very cloudy for an unfiltered wheat.

Bottle from Au Grain D’Orge / Pale Hazy yellow color withe fast disappearing white head / Aroma of honig, flowery, pale malt, ester from yeast / same flavor as aroma / Medium body, flat carbonation, sweet, sweet honig finish

Bottle in a train in Switzerland. Muddy yellow coloured with a small white head. Sweet and fruity aroma of malts and honey with notes of berries. Fruity flavour of caramel and honey with notes of berries. Berryish finish.

33cl bottle from Au Grain d’Orge, Switzerland. lot# LG073 Pours golden, fizzy sparly and quickly disappearing white head. aroma of honey sweetness, lots of blossom, possibly some esters, some bready malts peeking through, floral and tangy. flavors, lots of nice lingering honey meshed with some dark sugar and a light yeasty mouthfeel, some notes of caramel malts, hops add a mild bitterness to the finish. Overall the beer is sweet and I really enjoyed how the honey blends with all other ingredients, especially the sugar that directly follows every touch of the honey.

33 cL bottle, courtesy of Bov. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is phenolic, light yeasty and orange to citrus fruity. Mild floral and yeasty flavoured. Subdued sweetness and crisp bitterness. Smooth and mellow flavour, rather high carbonation mouthfeel. Lasting phenolic and citrusy flavoured into the finish.

Dark yellow colored, hazy appearance. Medium sized white head. Big parts of yeast in the bottom of the glass. Aroma is weird with sweet and sour touch, some vinegar also with lemony touch. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is also weird with this same vinegar and glue tones, sweet and bitter lemon also there. Aftertaste lasts with sour lemon and some yeast.

Bottled. Hazy yellow, steady cloudy white head. Very witbier-like outlook. Sweet strawberry aroma, slightly sour. Very sour, Vuuve-like beer. Almost like drinking some kind of lambic. Very difficult beer to rate, it has lemony sourness with fruity background.

Bottled (thanks Bov!). Hazy yellow colour, small white head. Sour fruits and cinegar in nose. Flavour is super bitter and sour fruits. Quite unpleasantly balanced. Quite artifical fruity notes (atleast when it comes to the lemon).
(Bottle 33 cl) Hazy, pale golden with a tall, white and dissipating head. Lightly tart, fruity nose. Rather light body with both tart and malty accents. 211006
Bottled. Pale golden coloured with a huge but very fast disappearing head. Some sour fruity aroma and flavour. A bit thin mouthfeel.
Bottle. Hazy yellow colour with a big white head. Light sour fruity aroma and taste, citrus. Medium body with a light sour finish.
Bottle in a park in Bern. Hazy orange coloured with a medium sized off-white ehad. Fruity aroma of caramel, spices, hops and soap. Fruity flavour of hops, caramel and spices. Hoppy finish.

33cl bottle from Au Grain d’Orge, Switzerland. Lot# LG074 pours amber, white with nice white head that for once goes beyond the usual fizzy head. aromas, hoppy, sweet and malty, earthly and bready nose with strong yeast presence. flavors, tropical fruits with some brown sugar quickly followed by malts. The whole mouthfeel is overly fizzy and bubbly, carbonation level is too high to really enjoy much of the beer. Touch of caramel, grainy and cereal presence. Once again, this one finishes overly yeasty leaving much of the beers’ elements to come through.

Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a cloudy and opaque pale amber with a solid off-white head. Unclean fruity nose. Medium body, sweet fruity and phenollic, with a tart and astringent finish. 230909

33 cL bottle, courtesy of Bov. Pours hazy dark orange with a small tan head. Aroma is mild spiced, wheaty and yeasty. Smooth fruity, yeasty and mild floral flavoured. Light phenolic and fruity flavoured into a lingering finish.

Bottled 33cl. It pours a murky copper beer with a huge rocky off white head. The aroma is of yeast, wood, hops, leather, blue cheese, crackers, lemon peel and cork. Quite a lot of leather in the taste too which is accompanied by blue cheese, lemon peel, sage and wood. Acidic. Light bodied. Smooth. Beautiful lacework. Decent bitterness. Peculiar finish. Interesting and distinct. Thanks bov!

Bottled. Hazy amber with a rich lively white foam. Vanilla and nuts in the aroma with dryish undertones of yeast and grass. Starts malty sweet of vanilla, fudge and cookies with a growing grassy bitterness. Finishes bitter of crisp grassy hops.
Bottled. Amber colour, rich head. Dry and light bodied. Flavours of roasty malt, hay and orange marmelade. Crisp and drinkable with resiny bitter finsish.

Bottled (BB 07/2008) hazy orange color, small steady white head. Light herbal, slightly sour, spicey aroma. Herbal, odd flavor - bitterish long ashy and herbal aftertaste. Interesting but one bottle is enough.

Bottled. Hazy pale nutbrown colour with white foamy head. Aroma is hops, malts and yeast with some mild berryish notes. Flavour is yeast, sweet malts and hops. Quite grassy and hayish aftertaste. Wellbalanced.
Light amber color with a beige head. The taste is sweet with slight sour fruity notes. Has some acidic and citrusy notes on the palate.
Bottle. brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is alcohol, spices, dried fruit. Flavour is sweet, alcohol, malt, berries, dried fruits, spices. OK beer.

Bottle in a park in Basel. Muddy orange red coloured with a small off-white head. Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, dried fruits and alcohol. Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, dried fruits, alcohol and marzipan with notes of nuts. Sweet finish.

Bottle, from trade with Papsoe. 9% ABV. A flat, dark amber beer, almost clear, and with some bubbles around the rim. Roasted, spiced nose with jam and dried fruits. Alcohol too, in a pleasant way. Some sourish notes too. Full body, sweetish and sticky, and slightly warming. Dried fruits, caramel, sugar, alcohol and a touch of spices in the flavor. Lasting finish. Overall, a bit heavy on the alcohol, at least when considering the body fullness. Not bad, but I suspect a bottle on my own would be demanding. 110304

Bottle.Pours golden orange with a small off-white head.Aroma of bready malts, caramel, alcohol and licorice.Flavor is sweet and warming with some alcohol, caramel and licorice.Medium to full body, soft carbonation.Slightly meaty beer , not quite "there".

Bottle 330ml. ABV. 9.0%. Light unclear medium orange amber color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, chocolate, honey - overripped fruit notes. Flavor is heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, caramel - candy sweet. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light to moderate alcoholic. [20100908]
Hazy amber with a small of white head. Sweet aroma with toasted malt, fruit, caramel and alcohol. Sweet flavor with toasted malt, caramel, dark fruits and rubber. Slightly off. Cloying sweet.

33 cL bottle. Pours hazy brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is yeasty, fruity and phenolic. Slight spiced too. Sweet malty, caramelish and candy like. Slight fruity phenolic. Quite sweet caramelish. Toasted malty into the finish.

Bouteille de 33 cl de chez Grain d’Orge à Crissier (CH). Bière rousse-ambrée foncée, sans mousse et faible pétillement. Odeur maltée, caramel au beurre, malt roti, touche d’orange et de soufre. Goût très doux, très caramélisé. Texture huileuse, coprs plein, candi XL, note d’alcool, de rhum, d’orange et de raisin. La douceur sucrée poursuit jusque dans l’étalement avec une pointe d’amertume et d’acidité. Un peu lourde et sirupeuse.

Bottled ((9.4 % ABV) Thanks Bov! Bottle cap mentions Oct 2006). Hazy ambery brown colour with mediumsized head, that turns into a small one quite quickly. Aroma is strong plum, toffee, fruits, alcohol and mild woodenness. As it turns warmer the aroma goes a bit oxidized. Flavour is wood, bread, spices, yeast and ends in a very smooth toffeeish raisiny way. Warming up it turns toffeeish all the way through. The finish is quite much plumpudding mixed with wood, nectar and raisins. Quite crisp carbonation makes this one a rather slow-to-drink beer.

Hazy amber colored, ultra fast dying head. Sharp in the aroma. Malt, toffee, fruit and some alcohol present. Fruit and anise flavor with a sharp citrus note and some orange and pineapple also. Good taste but not very balanced. Hides the high ABV well.

Date: 05/16/1997 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: cloudy amber, thin head leaving thick dripping lace from nowhere, Aroma: strong sweet banana aroma, Flavor: strong sweet malt flavor with lots of clove and banana esters, just a touch of bitterness Aroma: 9/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Strong aroma of esthers (banana). Fuller bodied then typical. No detectable hops and very wheaty. Interesting beer but not for me.

This was one of the first hefes I ever tried, and it gave me my first experience with the banana flavor the style carries. Unfortunately, this one's so strong on the banana that i've never had any desire for a refill. Nevertheless, it's a beer I've certainly enjoyed in a single serving.
argo0 sums it up perfectly, a "repro of a standard american macro". Need I say more?

Good repro of a standard american macro. I've never understood why microbreweries have felt any compulsion to attempt to duplicate that which the regular swill-drinker can find anywhere. Guess it's so the beer snobs don't have to leave their friends behind when they go out for the good stuff. Bleah!
Average and watery, with some berry and big chunks of yeast. hazy red pour with puffy head and lacing. Light tangy finish. Tap at waterfront palace.

Ahh, it was the best of times, it was the worst of times. My wife and I went on one of our first dates at Bardo back in 1997. Only weeks before that, however, that’s where I watched my Jayhawks take a beat down from Arizona, the eventual tournament winner. I was devastated. I also vaguely remember drinking beer there. This one, though, I remember quite well. Partially because the name was so damn brilliant. Partially because the beer was gloriously delicious the first time I had it. Partially because when I went back for the next batch it was so disgustingly awful. I guess that’s what happens when you play with wild yeast -- sometimes you win and sometimes you lose, particularly when the people involved probably had no idea what they were doing. The first batch -- the delicious one -- was a God’s-honest-truth lambic: earthy, complex, yeasty, tart. And with just the right amount of fruit. The second time, well, who knows what they had done. It basically tasted like alcoholic Kool-Aid -- no tasty, tarty funk, just sweet fake fruit. Maybe this is why Bardo didn’t make it? Seemed like they had some serious quality control issues. My ratings are for the good version. That’s how I want to remember Marion Berry.
It seems as if they had trouble with this one. The beer was almost like an 'ade'. Too fruity with no other flavors detected. It smelled kind of nice though.

Date: 08/11/2000 Mode: Draft Source: chamdo funky Aroma: 2/10; Appearance: 2/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.1/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

A forgettable ESB. Bardo did much better with the american style ales. Very weak aroma and flavor. Low carbonation but not pulled from a firkins as it should be. Of course back in the days when this was available it was impossible to find beer on cask in the states.

Draft at Dremo’s. Poured out a reddish brown, with red highlights at the edges. Off white head, somewhat soapy. Aromas are of roasted malts, more a weak stout than a brown ale. Flavors are of roasted malts, yeasty bread, some biscuit malts. Hops are present, but subdued. Thin body and mouthfeel. Hid the alcohol well.

Name: James Brown Ale Date: 08/11/2000 Mode: Draft Source: chamdo dark brown, whispy head, sweet malt aroma with a hint of floral hops, thin body, slightly sweet malt flavor with well balanced north west hops, hint of alcohol, touch of bitterness in the finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Draft at Dremos. Dark brownish color, with small creamy head. Aromas of roasted nuts with a hint of chocolate. Perhaps like most SBC beers they can be hit or miss, I thought this one was really great.

Bottle... Cloudy, burnt orange ale with a small, frothy, off-white head. Good retention. Roasted notes of pecans, chocolate and maple syrup in the nose. Also, a bit phenolic (bandage). Thin, lightly acidic, gently bitter flavor. Terrific balance, but bland. Light-bodied with a fairly crisp finish. Thanks to growler for sharing the bottle!

Tap at SB Co. - Rusty brown, thin white creamy head. Soft floral nose with roasty, nutty, and chocolate undertones. Flavor was similar with earthy hop notes to boot. Light to medium bodied, light carbonation, drying, nutty, mild chocolate finish. Drinkable, but nothing special...

Gosh, I’m going to go against the grain. Hazy, moderate nut brown color, another beer of theirs that comes out undercarbonated, though it just so happens that I don’t think that’s a problem--it’s nice relief from most American beers in bars (including brewpubs) that are way too overcarbonated. I liked the basic flavor components, nutty, some suggestion of hops peeking through, caramel, and candy. Quite satisfying. (on tap at Dr. Dremos, Arlington, VA)
Brown. Nose is quite sweet. Good malts, caramel and peat, some molasses as well. Mildly hoppy at the end.
Light brown and opaque. Aroma is very sweet molasses. Flavor is molasses, raisins, and a hint of chocolate.

Setting: Served on tap at Dr. Dremo’s in a pint glass. Appearance: Clear medium brown topped by a smallish light tan head that dissipates to a scanty film and wee ring after a few sips. No lacing at all. Aroma: Light bready malts, faint whiffs of anise and candi sugars. Flavor: Sweetish caramel malts with a modicum of hoppy bitterness. Mild toasted malt flavors, too. Palate: Light to medium in body with short-lived aftertastes. Overall: Eh, this ain’t too bad, but there are better beers available at the place where you can get this, among them Brooklyn’s Brown Ale.

Slightly hazy brown colour with a thin tan head! Aroma of soap, strong nuts and a fair amount of malt! Tastes of malt, nuts and a fair amount of sugars. Aftertaste shows some bananas and subtle maltiness with predominiant malt. Overall, a better than average brown-impressive for someone who doesn't like the style! I bought this twelve ounce bottle at Shenandoah Brewing Company in Alexandria, Virginia and sampled it on 21-November-2003.
Not a bad wit, considering some of the other rubbish that comes from this brand. Light with lingering coriander.

Oczy: złoty kolor z mnóstwem białych "fusów", Piana niewysoka, biała, drobna. Nos: lekko cytrusy ale takie stęchłe, zborze Paszcza: smak delikatny, niska kwaśność, wysycenie wysokie ale miękkie, delikatna słodycz,
Keg at Huis, Portsmouth. As Huis Wit. Spicey aroma. Slightly hazy pale gold. Creamy white head. Sour. An almost off sour. Light. Sticky mouthfeel. Soft carbonation. Sour aftertaste. OK, perhaps.

Bottle at Delirium Cafe Brussels. Pours hazy pale yellow with some white sediment floating around. Aroma is surprisingly fruity. Taste is nice wheat and spicy wit with a tropical fruit character to it. Classic wit beer with an interesting berry fruitiness. Not bad.

At the Delirium Cafe Kuala Lumpur on draft. Pours pale hazy yellow with a nice head. Pleasant fresh aroma. Taste of fresh wheat and herbs. A but dry but light and refreshing. Perfect easy drinking white beer.
Het is een troebel witgeel bier met een wit schuim. Het heeft een moutige wat stoffige geur. De smaak is slap, waterig en beetje zeepig.

0.33l bottle. Hazy yellow color with white head. Aroma is malty, citrusy and spicy with some coriander and orange peel notes. Taste is sweet and spicy with orange and coriander notes. Overall it's nice Wit.
Tap @ Delirium. Hazy yellow with a white head, nice lacings. Aroma light malty (wheat, orange peel, coriander). Flavor light sweet, medium sour and spicy, light bitter. Medium body.
Bottle, 330 ml at Svijet Piva. shared with JFK10000. Pours light golden with medium white head. Citrus, coriander, some light banana, yeast. Sweet, some light tartness. Light bodied.
From Delirium in Brussels. Light, hazy thin yellow. A refreshing wheat beer, typical of the type. Not bad

Date: 05/16/1997 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear light amber, thin head leaving thick lace, strong chinook hop aroma, strong malt flavor with slight sweetness well balanced with strong chinook hop flavor and leaving only a slight bitterness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
A very good beer. I lost my notes for this one and it has been years since it was available but it was one of the better Bardo beers.

Date: 06/30/1996 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub amber ale, wnispy head, no aroma, good malt flavor -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 08/07/2000 Score: ii to iii rich carmel malt aroma, rich sweet malt flavor, hint of peat - or smoke - or something, a bit strange at first, but grows on you Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Not enough of anything to stand-out. I expected much more malt for a scotch ale. The lack of malt dealt a serious blow to the body, much to thin. One of Bardo's weaker efforts.
Fairly bland -- kind of just sits there.....................................
