Had on 8/18/2000. Aroma is a lightly roasted malt scent. Color is a deep golden brown with good carbonation and head. Taste is crisp and nutty. Starting with a light body that goes down with a crisp feel. Finish is a clean roasted malt flavor backed by a light bitterness. Its a nice little Brown Ale.

Name: Brown Ale Date: 03/09/1996 malty aroma, good sweet malt flavor with a touch of hop and a dry aftertaste Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
this is an outstanding beer. Goes right to the top of my favorite Brown Ales. Excellent flavor. No bad aftertaste. Not too weak. Not too strong. I will buy this one regularly.

Clear copper, thin white head. Graham cracker aroma, pus some mild understated hints of plum. The Bride called it "Bland, but kind of a good bland", and that actually makes sense here. Hints of rasin in the finish. OK. Thanks to Springslicker for this one.
Thin brown color with a small, fleeting head. Yeasty aroma. Flavor is cola-like sweet carbonic acid tang, thin body. Below average.

Not too great. Poured dark brown with minimal head which evaporated almost as fast as I could pour the bottle. Slight lacing along the way. Aroma was just barely there. I thought it was lacking in carbonation. Flavors which included some maltiness were very slight and a watery body. I don't like this anywhere near as much as Aspen's Red or Pale Ale. A dissappointment to say the least. I'll drink the rest of the sixpack, but won't buy another of this one
Deep brown with a very light tan head. Malty caramel aromas with a nuttiness. Flavors of caramel and a little nutty. A bad metallic flavor and grainy. I would not drink this one again.
Tastes slightly nutty with a very noticable sweet, vanilla-like flavor. It's not bad but really doesn't seem enough like a beer to me.
Aroma of walnuts and almonds. Light brown color with minimal head. Very light malt and nutty flavor. Very thin and watery. A beginners brown beer.
Dusted chocolate aroma. Dark chocolate on palate. Well balanced. Very impressed. Beer has obviously improved since 2005.

Bottle -- Small, creamy light brown head with a bit of retention and lacing. Vary dark brew with active carconation when seen with a strong light behind it. Aroma of caramel and dark chocolate with a bit of a roasted edge. Palate is fairly thin but with a bit of creaminess and quite a lot of carbonation. More roasted, if not burnt, flavours in the taste. Almost really good.

Dark, but not opaque, with a reasonably sized, frothy, lasting head that left some lace. Aroma contains some roasted grain notes rounded out with atouch of toffee. Very dry roasted bitterness which isn’t well integrated at all, but is otherwise ok. The palate is where all of Holgate’s beer have let me down so far (all in bottle). This one is fizzy like soda water, and it froths up as soon as it hits the mouth. It’s thin bodied, and the fizz creates an overly aggressive bite on the tongue. Admittedly it’s probably the worst time of the year to drink this beer, but it took a bit of an effort. Maybe they don’t bottle well, or they were too hot during travel - maybe I’ll give them another chance one day ;-)

Reading some of the ratings I was prepared for a gusher and that is what I got. Poured into a large chalice to take the exorbitant flurry of bubbles that rose a 2" dense tan head that formed, lasted and laced rings down the glass. The body of beer a deep cola brown and almost opaque. Overall an impressive looking beer once it settled. Dry chocolate and vinous red-wine aroma with a little herbal and grassy hops. A little biting in carbonation in the mouth at first but this waned quickly and became quite smooth once it warmed to room temperature. Cocoa powder, roasted grain and the doughy, bready yeast found in most Holgate beers, with a light vinous and almost puckering note in the back that borderlined on astringent, Finish is reasonably long and dry with a mix of cocoa and dark malts. Very simple, and yet easily sessionable winter ale. It would be nice if the amps were turned up a little but otherwise it wasn’t that bad a drop. Quite nice. (33cL, age unknown)

330 ml bottle. Very dark brown, almost black beer. Deep herbal and musty aroma. Coffee and chocolate mingle with dusty yeast. Flavour is quite thin though, toffee, coffee, and chicory. Slightly herbal.

A pretty good beer. I was surprised to find it scored so low. Poured out a dark brown with a small white head. Great roasted aroma and flavour. With some coacoa and a nice hit of hops on the finish. I got faint hints of dark frutiness as well. One fo the better beers I’ve had since arriving in Australia.

A nice little winter warmer. Dark brown with a very large foamy head (had to break up the pour into quarters while waiting for the head to settle). Cozy aromas of roasted malt, woodsmoke, and coffee. The palate delivers the same. Looking at other reviewers comments, there seems to be a problem with overcarbonation, but I didn’t find this to be the case-- probably because I "deflated" it during the pour.

Bottled. Opening this bottle was a mess. It sprayed itself all over my room and my computer, leaving less than half the beer in the bottle. What was left poured hazily nut browned and very lively. It was roasty and nutty with some Belgian style almondy yeast characetr. It was well balanced with medium sweetenss and medium bitterness. Besides the fiasco upon opening the beer, it was a quite enjoyable experience.

Hopelessly over-carbonated Australian strong ale. Shame because there may be a decent beer lurking under those suds. Poured a cloudy bottle-conditioned teak colour with a surging tan head. Looks extremely frisky for a winter ale, which raises doubts before I’ve sniffed or tasted. Clumpy lace. Porter-like sweet aroma of dry cocoa powder and chocolate. God this is fizzy. First mouthful is all foam. I guess you’d call the mouthfeel lively and it’s all wrong for the style. Flavour also porter-like - dominated by dark malt, with a dry chocolatey finish.
Lovely alcohol/smoky/coffee aroma promised so much. Kind of tasted like a thin porter, bit of chocolate maltyness but not a lot else, has a slight warming effect but there really is nothing special.
Dull copper coloured body with a small head and some lacing. Cascade hops very light in taste and a little bit oily. Decent looking brewbar now they just need some decent brews to go along with it.
Slightly cloudy gold colour, pineapple aroma, with resiny, pine flavour, dry malt, with a thin finish. Seems like consistency is a problem for this brewer.

Draught at AIBA, Melbourne. Clear deep golden, small creamy head. Grapefruit aroma. Dry, really hoppy and salty with clean, hard, primitive malt profile and a strikingly bitter, near inky finish. A brave but rather unrefined example of the style.

I had this with a great steak at the Gunn Island Pub. It was great and I feel that it will impress some of you beer afficinados if you can get to it. It had good colour, aroma and palate and tasted a little bit too hoppy. I will buy it again definately.

I’ve had this a few times previously and it was never very good (including one phenolic infection), but this time it was pretty good. Aroma is malty like vanilla ice cream with caramel topping. Flavour is caramel malty, with quite a solid bitterness. Certainly not enough hop flavour or aroma to be an IPA but pretty nice nonetheless. (7/4/7/3/13) RR: Has dropped the "Cut Snake" from its name. Vaguely like an APA but mostly just thin, metallic and soulless. Vague lambic quality. My mate asked why a beer like this would taste so much like VB - I couldn’t really answer him. Nothing like the last time I had it. Looking at my previous rating I’d say the time it was good was the anomaly, so I’m adjusting the numbers accordingly.
Dryish. Pleasant cow manure aroma. Perhaps too watery with some adjuncts. Typical Aussie pale.
every brewery seems to be trying to make one of these nowadays - little creatures more or less. plenty of cascade in there and soft in a dull way. still, a pleasant antidote to metallic lagers

Consumed at Kiribilli hotel (under the Sydney Harbour Bridge on the north side). A good IPA with presentable hop presence. The aroma was slightly cardboardy and agreeably herbaceaous on warming. At least they are trying to brew a traditional beer.
At AIBA 2003. Nice amber body with floral hop aroma. Thick and sweet with a sour citrus finish in which some alcohol was evident. Not much real bitterness but I liked it.
I would have to agree with duff on all his points. This beer could be anyone of 100 run of the mill beers out there at the moment

column1: Gunn Island Ducks Nuts Amber Ale
column5: Proper amber body with a poor head. Boring caramel once again also grainy but nothing in it to really turn you on.

column1: Gunn Island Ducks Nuts Amber Ale
column5: Draught at AIBA, Melbourne. Brownish amber, small head. Peach is obviuos in the nose. Sweet with clean, straightforward mouthfeel and low hop rate. A pretty mediocre ale that passes by unnoticed at a beer festival.

column1: Gunn Island Ducks Nuts Amber Ale
column5: Now known as simply Gunn Island Amber Ale. Fairly dark with decent head retention. Berries and toast aroma - quite plain. Burnt toast flavour and not much of anything else. A touch of roast. Boring as batshit. Pale ale with food colouring? (I must’ve been in a bad mood when I rated these)

column1: Gunn Island Ducks Nuts Amber Ale
column5: Not bad. A hint of smoked malt and beef. Englishy hops, decent balance. One of the better beers at nfob.

column1: Gunn Island Ducks Nuts Amber Ale
column5: nfob03. this had the orange mango cordial aroma that i like in amber ales. quite a dark amber, thin body, sweet aftertaste

column1: Gunn Island Ducks Nuts Amber Ale
column5: This ABV is always a bit of an enigma. It is great as a basis for a good beer provided the beer is going to have a fine balance of hops and malt. I agree with the commercial description but for the lack of comment on bitterness. Look, in Australia we need to support this effort.

column1: Gunn Island Ducks Nuts Amber Ale
column5: At AIBA 2003. A darker brow brew lacking aroma, mallty, nutty and fairly bitter in flavour. Quite watery though.

column1: Gunn Island Ducks Nuts Amber Ale
column5: Beautiful color and pour. Tastes of toffee and malts, with subtle floral notes. Excellent micro brewery drop!

column1: Gunn Island Ducks Nuts Amber Ale
column5: This is a beer made better by the fantastic brewpub it comes from. Lots of malt, unsurprisingly.

column1: Gunn Island Ducks Nuts Amber Ale
column5: Had a nice flowery to fruity aroma, flavour was malty but not bitter in aftertaste. Wish they bottled the stuff.

column1: Gunn Island Shot Fox Red Beer
column5: Red and orange in body with an off-white head. Much better head poured but hardly lasting and less lacing, some caramel in the taste followed by light lemon hops, none of the advertised spice. Not lager offensive.

column1: Gunn Island Shot Fox Red Beer
column5: Draught at AIBA, Melbourne. Amber colour, small head. Strawberry aroma. The mouthfeel is primitively clean and hard. There’s notes of peach and only low bitterness. I couldn’t find much that caught my interest in this beer.

column1: Gunn Island Shot Fox Red Beer
column5: Now known simply as "Red Lager". Nice fiery red colour. Head retention is OK. Sweaty yeast aroma with a fair dose of fruitiness and grassy hop. Seems like a couple more weeks of lagering would clear it up nicely. Firm Melanoidin maltiness, not sweet, with hop flavour at the end. Firm bitterness. Alcohol is evident. Seems quite bock-like. A bit rough but actually quite likeable.

column1: Gunn Island Shot Fox Red Beer
column5: On tap, aroma was just noticeable floral hop and a tiny amount of roastiness. Looks clear red/orange, nothing wrong with how it looks. Fairly mild toffee & a bit grainy giving way to a bitter aftertaste. Quite watery though refreshing.

column1: Gunn Island Shot Fox Red Beer
column5: Very polite Ale. To me it was little Belhaven-y. Some tartan underpants: I don't understand what style this is.

column1: Gunn Island Shot Fox Red Beer
column5: nfob03. looks pretty orange for a red beer. for all the effort that the commercial description suggests that they put in, this still tastes very extracty, it's unfizzy and dull and tastes of porridge. but it is smooth and drinkable

column1: Gunn Island Shot Fox Red Beer
column5: At AIBA 2003. A dark amber beer. Very swwet aroma and flavour without much hop contribution. I must agree with the others though, extra points for quick drinkability.

column1: Gunn Island Shot Fox Red Beer
column5: Sweet and Peachy is the best way to describe this beer. Very easy to drink, low on the hops as well.

column1: Gunn Island Shot Fox Red Beer
column5: I found this to be my favorite of the lot in their stable. Nice full flavour and I agree with duff, easy to drink....by the pint.

column1: Gunn Island Shot Fox Red Beer
column5: Pretty tame. Not much aroma (perhaps a bit of sweetish malt aroma), a bit sweet at the start, and finishes very quickly, little or no hop presence, easy to drink.
Pretty flavourless and edgy, bit of spice, but pretty below average. probably my least favourite of there brews.

Bottle- Pours a dark amber color with a decent tan head that fades to some lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, nuts and a hint of caramel sweetness. Taste of roasted malt with some caramel sweetness and a bit of nut flavor in the background. Mild bitterness and a clean finish. Medium body, smooth with a decent balance. Fairly average brown ale but still good for a couple.

From a 330ml bottle on 14/8/2011.Pours a very cloudly dark amber with almost no head. Has quite a distinct caramel toffee malt aroma. More caramel and toffee sweetness is evident in the flavour, but the most prominent feature is a strong almost burnt, roasty bitterness. Reading the other reviews on here makes me wonder whether I’m drinking the same beer. A good ale with quite a bit of character.
Tap. Nutty, brown sugar on the nose. Thin to medium mouth feel. Good caramal/ nut body with a soft finish. Good easy drinker.

Bottle from Warners at the Bay. Pours a clear copper/brown with a small beige head. Aroma was a light roasted caramel and toffee. Taste was a slightly hop and nut combo, with a light roasted flavour. Not very impressive, but drinkable i suppose.
Thick brown colour, with a small beige head that dissapears quickly. Roasted toffee elements to the aroma, which follow through to the flavour. Roasted flavour lasts to the after taste. Plesant beer.

Bottle. Pours copper with a large fluffy beige head that settles to an inch. High bead. Very modest aroma of a little cereal and caramel. Taste has some crystal malt sweetness and a fair bit of spicy hop bitterness. Spicy finish. The malt’s a little simple and subdued and there’s too much carbonation, but it’s OK.

Lovely mahogony color. Huge head. Filled the whole glass very quickly. Not much on the aroma front. Perhaps a little malt but not much else. Tasted of a little malt and a little yeast though overall very bland. Good mouthfell. A little fizzy and some malt sweetness. OK . A bit lacking with not much happening at all.

Big frothy head tinge of fawn in it decent carbonation red brown colour ale,aroma caramel,toffee fruit hoppy.Flavour caramel mild toffee hoppy bitter fruity taste of pear and apple,well put together ale finish good malt and hop tastes,bitter sweet.
Melbourne, Australia Bottled Brown sugar malltiness - some roast notes but mostly sweet Bitterness too low
Little aroma at all. Minimal head that dissipated almost immediately. Strong malty flavours which are balanced well by the bitterness. A decent session beer.

Good on them for doing a beer of this style. Wouldn’t it ihave been great if it actually tasted like the style. murky, mudy stagnant, this has more in commmon with a pond than beer. Evrything about the beer is unexciting

Wow, people really beat the crap out of this beer! I quite liked it, thought it my favourite out of the Jamieson selections that I tried. Pours a dark brown with medium head that doesn’t last very long. Roasty malt aroma with some fruity tones, all of which carry over on the palate. No real criticism from me, I quite liked it. I agree that it doesn’t really fit what I might expect of a "dark wheat", but good nontheless.
I don’t know why they bother to make this beer and a brown ale, very similar they are. Sweet malt, aroma of carbon dioxide (overcarbonated). No character.
apart from a slightly flat mouth feel, this beer is quite nice with great burnt malts and enough bitternes to balance but not overpower.

I think this is now called the Mountain Ale? Medium chocolate brown, pours a good fizzy head early but settles fairly quickly. Sweet chocolate malt on the nose. Pretty good in the mouth; more chocolate malts round the profile out nicely. Fizzy finish. Lacks a bit of seriousness but a fairly decent effort. A much lighter beer than the ’old’ version and IMHO a better drink.
I normally like wheat beers, but I wouldn’t classify this as such. Very little taste and head retention was extremnely poor. Not bad, but not great.

Bottled whilst at Paddy’s Brewpub, Flemington, Australia. Thoughts on this beer retained for rating purposes…[Thought to self] Spiesy what do you think of this beer? [Noted replies to self] ‘Not much, it sucked’ The gathering: duff, eczematic, motelpogo, Spiesy, Sully and late arrival Linc.

awful. clear brown. syruppy, incredibly sweet and not wheaty at all, with a thin, dirty extract tang. ugh. rer8: this was under the name of "jamieson mountain ale" but i think is the same beer cause it said it was a "dark wheat beer" in the label blurb. so i didnt even get a new rating out of this, damn. the best i can say about this beer is that it’s not infected. murky red-brown, almost completely aroma-less but what there is is dust, POR, thin toast. taste is strawberry jam on burnt toast then an extremely quick nothing-dry finish with some sourness.
Dark brown colour with a light brown head, retention low and little lacing. Smooth chocolate taste but not real full flavours. Aroma is malty caramel.

Pours clear brown with amber tinges. Sudsy off white head, ok retention. Med-high carbonation. Caramel dominates aroma, with some roast malt there too. Medium mouthfeel, reasonably smooth start though finish a little thin. Pretty bland and innofensive taste. Sweet malty start with a clean choc malt finish. No yeastiness, no flavours I normally associate with a hefe. Alright beer though.
like an aussie attempt at a south-east asian lager. quite ricy and dry and golden. some sulphur in the aroma is a bit of a worry
like a bad heineken attempt. odd sulfur stench like it hasnt been lagered enough, or at all. yellow, very sweet, slightly grainy.
Pretty bland lager, i guess this one is meant to appeal to a wide range of people, not a stand out, no real malt or hop character, no body.
Light passionfruity aroma. Tea red coloured. Lots of hoppy notes but I think their was some malt showing through.
At AIBA 2003. Cloudy bronze with fresh hoppy aroma. Some malt at first but mostly has a big bitter hoppy kick at the end.
Big hoppy and malty nose, very zesty, citrusy and fruity, nice malt middle, and very satisfying hop finish, this beer really agreed with me.
a closer approximation to a bitter than their other one. slightly funny metallic/citric tang but drinkable enough
syruppy, fruity like one of those cream cheeses with chunks of apricot in em. showed some promise but was too tangy.
A nice little bitter, very nice bitterness and maltiness, not as goo as their real ale, but still a decent little brew. Thumbs up.

There is a real need for the brew team to lok at the definition of a stout. No hint of roastiness in the flavour and there is such a soft mouthfeel that it is merely a dark beer of questionable substance.
not very stout like. dark purple, not particularly roasty and quite thin. had a decent lingering thin head. otherwise pretty funny - hints of orange and garbage juice

damn, i hate disagreeing with duff but i'm going to have to again. this wasn't even close to black, more like dark red. watery, flabby, thin mouthfeel, with vague burnt flavour overwhelmed by banana/celery/DMS with off cordial aftertaste. tasted a bit off, like another of their beers. maybe after the grand final wasn't the best time to try em.

I actually had this again about 6 months ago and totally forgot to re-rate it. It was definitley not as good as i had remembered. Much thinner this time. Sweetish, with some burnt roastyness in the finish, still not totally bad. Drinkable.

Pours dark amber with a quickly fading head. Nose shows DMS, soft sweet malt, cidery notes and faint nutty malt. Better flavours. More prominent nutty malt and some spicy hops. Still a faint cidery note though. Body feels a bit watery.
330 ml bottle Nice golden colors good aroma can taste hoppy flavour although not overpowering ok not great

From a 330ml bottle on 16/4/2011. Pours a murky golden orange colour, with lots of yeast sediment floating about. The aroma is fruity and yeasty. Goes down quite nicely, with citrus fruits combining with caramel malt. Has a pretty decent dash of hops at the end. A pretty good English pale.

330ml bottle. Big fluffy dirty san dcoloured head a top a hazy light copper base. Floral hop aromas and a big bang of flavour hits the mouth, hops again. Balance is spot on and the finish is how you want it.
Bottle 330ml. Not bad. Aroma is floral, with a hint of caramel. Sweet taste, with light bitterness. Oily palate, and thin-to-medium body. Yellow, with a frothy white head.
My favourite of the buckleys variety, deep gold appearance with residual cloudyness present. Fruity ale displaying some tart in the finish. Decent.

Original?- maybe ordinary.Straw coloured body, poor head, fruity hop taste but still pretty boring, it is an ale but that is about all, doughy aroma, sour soft grapefruit taste. Looking at previous ratings I must have got a crook batch.

Looks great in the glass, big white head with very good retention and lacing. Small floral aroma. As said before, carbonation is spot on, the dry malty flavours come though nicely, combined with a light bitterness and a very very clean finish. Great hop profile, one of the best Victorian beers i’ve tasted.

Amber colour, light malty aroma with some orange character. Orange zest and grapefruit flavours compliment a light malty palate, a distinct acidity makes for an unusually clean, refreshing finish. A little light on the body but not bad overall.

Much better than previous efforts. Genuine english pale ale / bitter traits here with a very good creamy structure. Indeed, had I only smelt and not tasted I would have unreservedly picked this as English. Slighlt metallic ping in the back palate. The best of the house.
330 mil bottle malty aroma dark amber sort of a malty beer its ok but would not buy again

Pours dark amber with a small off-white head. Nose shows spices, some nutty malt, subtle sweet malt and corn-like DMS notes. Pretty restrained. Restrained flavours too. Some bready malt and grainy notes alongside faint spicy hops. Body feels watery.

Bottle 330ml, present from my gf. Interesting malty nose. Aroma is vinous, with nuts, and floral hints. Taste is sweet, with average length. Palate is oily, and medium bodied. Amber, with a frothy head.

330ml bottle. Deep fluffy dirty white head that rises like bread in an oven. Ruby copper flecked cloudy beer that looks good. Biscuity caramel aroma that gets your attention. Full of flavour and fills the mouth and then leaves a lingering warmth on the palate. Yet another good effort from the boys at Yarra Flats.

Like the worst kind of home brew. Rancid in such a familiarly unsettling and seemingly unsterile way that as you grimace with displeasure, it makes you think "oh well, at least it’s free", and then you remember that amazingly it so isn’t.

Bottled, Amber colouring throughout the body, fizzy light head. Bitterness strongly felt through the palate along with a slight nutty flavour reminiscent of a heavier beer variety (ie. Amber Ale). Decent locally grown beer, still slightly rough though.

Medium amber body with a slight off-white head, hardly lasting. Caramel aroma along with hops, fuggles & tettnanger show up in the taste, resin, like it better than the bells hotel bitter but it is still one-dimensional, almost like an IPA.

Pours a deep cloudy copper, with a large fluffy off white head. Poor lacing. Pretty typical aroma, but a bit yeasty. Fuggles are evident in the palate, plenty of earthy flavours and a hint of friutiness. Also some nice (slightly sweet) maltiness. Not too bad really

Pours a pretty good foam head with good form and decent lacing. Dark orange, almost light brown in colour. Good aroma lift but a fraction too citric and metallic for my liking. A little sweet citrus in the palate and does firm up at the back with some bitterness, but that citrus does thins out the flavour out somewhat.. Better than previous bottles &#402.3&#41.

Aroma: hoppy, some sweetness and a bit lagery. Appearance: cloudy brown with a hint of orange. Small bubbly head. Flavour: some sweet malt with strong hop bitterness. A touch of grapefruit also noticeable.
Looks pretty good like most dark beers but that's about it. Sugary aroma, faint simple burnt malt taste & a dry finish.

Nice looking dark amber ale, a bit reddish, smells nicely malty, slightly roasted nice foamy head. Tastes is very roasted, almost too roasted for my taste. Still it's a good beer that i'll be drinking again when i can. Not great, but drinkable.

Dark amber-red clear with medium size lasting pale beige head and some sporadic lace. Faint light roast malt aroma becoming sweeter as it warms. Medium sweet roast malt flavours with hint of toffee and coffee. Mild dry faint bitter finish. A touch on the thin side otherwise quite drinkable.
According to my beer stained tasting notes this is 5.2%. Fairly malty,reasonable flavour. I'd drink it again.
Ok, but a tad bit sugary like the rest of their brews, probably the best though.
12-Nov05 (Scottish Chiefs Brewery) - Very light fruit malt aroma. Clear amber colour with lowish head but good sheet lacing. Nice easy fruit flavour. Hoppy malt fruit finish but a bit thin.
Hop malt aroma with a hint of flowers. Clear amber colour with poor head and lacing. Light malt flavour with hops.

pretty much identical to the pale ale in appearance. its a lot sweeter though which equals i liked it better. not too interesting but some nice golden syrup flavour and minimal hops. quite ok. on tap at the labour in vain in melbourne.
Sampled AIBA 2004. Golden colour rather than amber. Light malt aroma and only slightly bitter. A beer to appeal to the mainstream palate that, as you see by my numbers, is decidedly average.
malty aroma, light golden amber colouration, malty with fruity hop sweetness, light bitterness.

Easily my least favourite Steampacket beer, and quite inconsistent, though there was one time I really enjoyed it. Caramelly, fruity aroma. Caramel malt sweetness, then a bit of metal, sourness and bitterness. Similar to Squire's Amber which I really don't like.
Not too interesting. An attempt at a flat inoffensive english ale that succeeded.
nfob03. pretty boring, bright orange, faint toffee, watery, not very exciting
A decent little amber ale, well balanced, lightish, caramelly, slightly roasted, pretty good.

12-Nov05 (Scottish Chiefs Brewery) - This beer was also known as ’Stoker Ale’ - Light brown roasted malt aroma. Dark brown colour, nice brown head and sheet lacing. Nutty light sweet malt flavour. A bit thin but smooth.
Burnt bitter nutty aroma. Dark brown chocolate colour with good head and lacing. Smooth malt flavour with nuts. Smooth palate.
Kiwifruit! What an odd aroma for a porter. Chocolatey flavour balanced by a distinct acidic cleanliness. Very odd but very tasty nonetheless.
Served too cold at the nfob. Fruit salad and some seasame seeds hidden under cold water like shower water on menopause and don't think that isn't related to a pause with the men.
nfob03. i tasted a lot of tamarind in this. pitch black, pretty fruity, some instant coffee

(Also known as Stoker Ale) Tasted at the Cornish Arms in Brunswick, Vic. Quite clear, dark brown colour with thin, white head. Beautiful dark fruit (cherry/sultana), dark malt aroma with malty, chocolate flavour. Not much hop character but enough balancing bitterness.
Pretty good little porter, lots of flavour, roasty chocolate and coffee flavours with a hints of berries.

On cask at The Postal Order, Worcester 27-06-09 at their Wem Beer Festival showcasing six of the range Pours golden with good clarity a white rim of bubbles for a head. Reasonably hoppy with traces of grapefruit, refreshing and ending dry. Citrus on the nose. A6 A3 F7 P3 Ov13 3.2
A Mes rate: cask at The Market Porter.Clean gold with a thin white film top. Very bland aroma. Reasonable fruity malt flavour with a faint citric bitterness in the finish. Dull as hell.
Cask at the Old Manor (JDW), Bracknell. Amber with a thin cream head; citrus aroma; creamy citrus flavour, rather sweet; with a gentle bitter finish. Rather ordinary.

Cask at The Moon Under Water, Leicester Sq. Hazy amber color with a good white head. Light hoppy aroma. Fresh fruity flavors with a hint of citrus. Finishes mildy bitter. Medium body with creamy carbonation.
Very enjoyable pint. Generously hopped and well balanced. Served in perfect nick (hand pump) at JDW Hatch End, Harrow.
Cask conditioned at The Briar Rose, Birmingham. Amber with slight white head. Straigh caramel malt, tea like hop bitter, decidedly average, slightly sweet on the finish with a touch of fruit.

Cask in Blackfriars. Aroma is biscuity sweet malts, notes of cascade lime character, grassy and gets floural as it growns. Taste is similar almost a slight candy sugar hint from the sweetness. Could do with double the cascade hops to be honest.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Brunswick Derby. A copper coloured beer with an off-white head. The aroma is orangey but there’s a disturbing phemolic edge. The taste is fruity and hoppy but a bit sweet. Certainly not much notes of cascade. A bit disappointing but manageable.

Cask handpull at Ship & Mitre, Liverpool. Copper/gold colour with thin beige head. I was expecting this to have lots of Cascade hops. Well it doesn’t. It might have a sprinkling though as it has some earhty citrus hops. These combine with a pleasant golden malty base beer. It’s fine, quite attractive, subtle hop finish. Quite good really as it had to win over my desire for huge Cascade hops.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. This was quite unusual: a dark golden beer with a small, off-white head. A curious sweet, spicy aroma, perhaps honeysuckle. Taste not so good: very sweet, slightly artificial cough candy taste with some incense wafting around somewhere. Virtually no bitterness.
A wonderful full flavored beer that left me thinking of ma home. Truly a Scottish Gem. -- rated via 'Find A Beer' for Blackberry 10
Cask Stillage at the Metropolitan Cathedral Crypt, Liverpool 21/02/2002 Black and fully roasted. Bitter smooth finish.
Sampled cask conditioned. Near black. Heavy burnt, roasty aroma. Softly malty, very dry. Mealy mouthfeel. Filling. Finishes salty with hints of licorice. A really nice cask porter!

Sampled cask conditioned. Beautiful pale amber, hazy appearance. Very flowery aroma. Fairly light bodied, and dryish. Really dominated by flowery (fuggle?) hop aroma. Finishes with balanced bitterness.
Bottle from Tuckers Maltings. Pale Amber colour with a small white head. Aroma is sweet and malty, taste has only a slight hoppy bitterness.

Cask @ the Speaker, Westminster SW1. Pours a pale amber color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty weak hoppy aroma. Fruity malty hoppy weak citrus flavor. Has a fruity malty hoppy bitter finish.

Cask (gravity dispense) at Reading Beer Festival on 28 April 2011. Another clean and quite restrained golden ale. By which I mean it could benefit from upping the Cascade levels and reducing the good old Fuggles and Goldings. This sort of beer really needs a bit more zing than Fuggles & Goldings provide.

Cask (gravity) @ The 17th Reading Beer and Cider Festival 2011, Reading, Berkshire England. Clear medium to light yellow orange colour with a small to average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, medicine, vomit notes. Flavor is light moderate sweet with a average duration, medicine. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20110428]
Cask handpump at FFTMC Oxford, 17-04-10 Pours dark gold, fruity aroma. Not particularly zesty or springlike, although moderately refreshing, fruity, lacking in hops, its ok. A6 A4 F6 P4 Ov12 3.1
Cask Handpump at the Railway Inn, Stockport 31/05/2003 Golden colour slightly fruity and hoppy. Full malt finish.
Sampeld cask conditioned. Pale golden. Fruity aroma, Rather sweet, really clean. Some spicy hop aroma, dry, reasonablt bitter finish. Lagerlike.

Cask-conditioned at the Portcullis, Clifton, Bristol 20/04/2011 as "Harvey’s Special Brew". Dark amber with a slight, off-white head. Malty aroma of barley sugar and fruit with a touch of dusty hop. Flavour had the same, malty character with a decent, bitter finish. Fine.
bottle, labelled Havrey’s Special Brew, 4.6%. Nearly clear golden colour with an orangue hue, large white head. Malty, hints of walnut, slightly fruity. An easy-going bitter.
Bottle. Light brown appearance with a small head. Low carbonation with a gentle maltiness.Quite pleasant with edges towards blandness.

Bottle conditioned, 500ml, from Happy Apple, Totnes, Devon. Bronze with white head. Darker fuller malt flavours, some roastiness with a touch of caramel. Decent hoppy bitterness, a good Teignworthy trait, sharp and flowery. Some sweetness on the close. Pretty reasonable.
BCA picked up from the brewery 30-12-06 in a mixed case, and drunk that evening. Dark Red/Brown colour, good, hoppy and malty tasty beer which I thoroughly enjoyed.

Bottle conditioned. Amber bronze, moderate head and condition. Slight caramel and fruit nose, good hop flavour develops in the mouth along with some banana and caramel, and a sweet finish with some hoppiness. If I were Harvey I would be slightly disappointed.
Sampled cask conditioned. Deep reddish amber. Neutral aroma. Medium body, grassy hop flavour, medium dry. Clean salty finish.
The best off my sampler. Not an A+ but a solid B which is more than I can say than the IPAs. Pours a light yellow. Decent cereal taste to it. Could have been a bit more bubbly
Draught at Wynkoop as part of a flight, visited on October 7, 2012 Light hazy golden color, white head. Perfume, hoppy, bitter taste. Spritzy mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Fresh malty, hoppy scent.

On draft at Wynkoop. Pours a clear yellow with a white head. Nose is bready with light lemon and citrus with big floral and noble hop bitterness. Flavor is similar with lemon, some malt, and floral hops. Light to medium in body and lingering hops in the finish.
Tap @ Wynkoop, Denver. Pours clear golden with a small white head. Aroma of malt, biscuit, grass, apples. Taste is malt, biscuit, grassy, peach, apples. Thin body, lively carbonation. 040312
Draught. Spicy and biscuity malt aroma. Clear amber with no head. Dull flavor. Wet malt and a below-style hop presence. Fairly clean but not a great example of the style.

Pours clear yellow, fizzy white head, aroma has notes of slight corn, biscuit, touch of spicy noble hops, very slight touch of earth. Taste is pretty simple, with slight notes of grain, corn, touch of biscuit, some spice and pepper notes in there as well. Average, with a bit too much corn.

Had this on tap during 2011 Denver Brew at the Zoo. Clear transparent gold with a peppery hop aroma with pale light biscuit. Taste was also biscuity but also with a slight touch of corn alongside some peppery hops. Not bad, just not good.
On tap at Wynkoop. Pours a piss yellow with minimal white foam. smells light and crisp with hints of hops. Tastes simple and crisp with light hops flavors.
Tasted at the Wynkoop Brewery in Denver, Colorado. Very light Pilsner appearance. Little aroma with a malty sweet flavor. Body is quite grainy with a sweet kick in the finish. Below average Pils.
Tap at the brewpub. Pours clear gold. Mild hoppy aroma. Tastes of light bread and noble hop. Nice.

Bottle, from historic notes. Source not recorded. Poured dull amber with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel, sweet malt, fruit and light hop. Medium sweetness, light bitterness. moderate body, average carbonation. Fair.

Aug 2008: Clear 500ml bottle drank at my brother-in-laws house well before the Best before date. Poured into a handled half litre glass mug from the JW Augustiner Munich tap house. Amber, copper colour with a white head that tried to stay around but failed and fell away to a wispy covering after about a minute. The aroma wasn’t very heavy, some sweet malted barley and hops, but not a great deal of either. Typical English Ale flavours, nothing to get excited about, even if it is ’Double Dropped’. The mouthfeel and texture of the beer was again ordinary and just like most British Bitters you can get cheap in any supermarket.

Bottle. Light amber with a thick lasting frothy white head. Smells of sweet malt and caramel, light hops and sour malt. Medium smooth frothy, flat body. Medium sweet with a smooth bitter finish. Soft fruit sweetness, nuts and brown bread and a touch of spice. Has elements of a common bitter but more developed. I like it.
5.0% pale golden colour with a thin head, sweet malt and hop aroma, citrus hop taste, not a bad drink.
Bottle. Amber colour with am off white head. Malty and light fruity aroma. Flavour of oderate malty sweetness and some cirtic hoppy notes. Also light fruity flavour.
11th May 2009 Clear amber beer. Crisp palate. Light malt runs through to a semi dry finish and aftertaste. In the middle is a bright sharp splash of bitterish hop. Refreshing.
50cl bottle from Netto. Clear bottle. Not good. Amber colour. Quite a decent beer.
Bottle, pint glass. Orange/dark yellow colour. Aroma is very strange.... mayonaise and chicken?? Boring taste, bitter and metallic. Boring beer.

Light amber-orange color. Quite heavily carbonated, with a nice, fine head. Strong aroma of hops and sulfur comes out immediately upon pouring-it is fruity, citrusy, a touch sweet. Very malty flavor, caramel. Quite sweet. But there is good hops in the taste from the beginning, and they come to predominate towards the finish and after. It is highly carbonated, light bodied. Lots of hops indeed. The finish has a touch or caramel malt but is mostly hoppy, and last a pretty long time. A nice beer, not completely original, but good.

Bottle 500ml. clear glass. Clear medium amber color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, sweet caramel, sour malt, cabbage water, light hoppy, light orange. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20100118]

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Tried at the three horseshoes Waddington. Colour is red brown wi a white head. Fruity citrus hop aroma with caramel, taste light sweet to bitter finish.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask, half pint at Vernon Arms. A creamy white head dissipating over a near-clear golden brown coloured body. Brown malts and dusty hops on the nose. Toffee and fruity flavours. Smooth bittersweet finish. Natural soft carbonated. Decent enough (Liverpool 01.02.2015).

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Pale bitter with little aroma but an odd ever so slightly cidery flavour. Medium finish. Not bad.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: On cask at Glyn Valley, Glyn Ceiriog. Pours red brown with foam head. About as interesting as a pint of water! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask at Cloisters. Amber with a white head. Earthy hop flavour with a quite strong bitterness. A pretty standard fair bitter.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask @ Cloisters, Edinburgh 170612 Golden brown, clear, thin white head. Little on the nose apart from vague malt and hops. Taste of soft caramel, bitter bit hedgerow hops, boring. Thin body, finish as main flavour, light bitter rapid finish. Nothing bad about this, just ordinary, plain and boring.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: cask at cloisters ... copper ... thin tan head ... soft toffee malt nose... light toffee ... little insipid ... but inoffensive ...

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: On cask at Cloisters. Pours a dark golden colour with a decent white head. Aroma of yeast, grassy hops and caramel. Similar flavours and fairly bitter with moderate carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask handpull, The Plough, St Asaph. Bronze with a persistent lid and lace spots. Labrador and sweet grain aroma. Biscuit linger, some hop bitterness. Very soggy and caramel-soaked, but hints of character shining through.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: BItter enough to not be on my favourites, but being fair to the beer, it had a good taste. And nice colour.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask (backlog). Ambery brown colour with a small white head. Aroma is floral, some wooden notes as well as mild nutty and some toffeeish notes. Flavour is somewhat bitter, with a nice toffeeish, but biscuity maltiness along with some nuttiness. Pleasant and refreshing.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask gravity at Kent & East Sussex Railway BF 2016. Clear golden amber colour lasting white head. Not too sure about the aroma touch of wort maybe. Earthy. Worty. Hmmm. Some vague hop on the finish. Not convinced by this. A little honey sweetness. Otherwise just a little rough around the edges. Didn’t finish a third pint. Hmmmm. Sickly. Raw.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Hand-pulled pint in the excellent ’Cock Hotel’, Wellington Shropshire on 7th Sep 2013. Golden amber body with a full white crown that gave off some good lacing. Lightly malted, with a sweet, almost honey flavoured smell and taste. Makes a change to find a golden beer in the UK that isn’t citrus oriented in flavour. Easy to drink and more complex than my notes suggest: overall a very good beer that is worth finding.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask Stillage at the RUFC, Chester 15/05/2003 Amber coloured with some fruit and wheat flavours. Dry malt finish.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask (gravity dispense), GBBF, August 2005. Mid brown colour. More fruity than malty I’d say. Soft and slightly sweet. Bitterness builds on the finish. Drinks easily for a strong bitter. Perfectly respectable but doesn’t really impose its personality.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask conditioned. Deep amber coloured. Fruity aroma. Light and slightly grassy flavour. Dry finish.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: [Cask at GBBF 2005] An amber beer with a fine orange head. The aroma is nutty and slightly roasted. The flavor is somewhat sour with notes of nuts and roasted malt - I don’t like the sourness - is it the hops?

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask @ GBBF 2005: Amber coloured. Clear. Fruity and chocolatish aroma. Herbal and fruity flavour. Is fresh and has a good fullness. Ends on a quite bitter note.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Review from 20/05/2014. A bottle I picked up from the brewery itself on my recent trip to Wales.. Pours nicely with a good head, the body is light amber in colour. Smells of a ginger and caramel aroma. Tastes of a sweet caramel flavour with a mild ginger sharpness and full malt finish. Overall a good Premium Bitter/ ESB

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask gravity at Bexley BF 2014. Bottled and drunk on the train home. Clear deep amber lasting beige head. Slightly farty aroma. Rich malt as well. Settles down into an esb with some white pepper hop on the finish. It’s ok. Decent mouthfeel from the strength. Decent.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: 10th July 2012 Chelmsford Beer Festival. Clear amber beer, residual white head. A little malt, candy fruits and citrus buried under massive detergent and soap. Dry finish. I can’t believe this is anything other then badly infected but I was unable to get the Camra guys to take this off although they all agreed it didn’t taste good. Grim!

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: cask in cloisters ... copper brown ... thinest tan ... soft dark berries ... urggggg ... huge medicinal sandle wood ... yeuch ... reallyy WHY ... i cant drink this ...

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: On cask at Cloisters. Pours a dark golden brown colour with a thick beige head. A very yeasty aroma with a floral character reminiscent of violets and dandelion. Similar yeasty flavour with Weetabix malt and a dry finish. A little sweet and fairly bitter. Moderate carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. Alcohol quite prominent.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask, The University Arms, Sheffield. Dense amber, ginger and caramel aroma. Sweet flavour, milder than expected with a ginger sharpness.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask-conditioned at the Seven Stars, Bristol 3/11/10. Ruddy-brown with a decent, off-white head. Sweetish, caramel and berry fruit aroma. Malty, fruit aroma with a thin, alcoholic finish. Didn’t pack much for 6% ABV.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel, Northampton. A light amber coloured beer with no head. The aroma is malty and fruity with notable alcohol warmth. A fruity taste with alcohol again. Lacking body really though for its strength. No more than ok.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Malty, lightly fruity aroma. Taste is similar alcohol having a wee say too. Not really my style of beer.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: 1. Cask Stillage at the Metropolitan Cathedral Crypt, Liverpool 22/02/2001 Smooth on the palate and malty. 2. Cask Handpump at the Bar Fringe, Manchester 09/04/2004 Mid brown amber coloured and strong in alcohol. Slightly bitter full malt finish.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask pint in the Cock Hotel, Wellington Shropshire on 29th April 2015. Clear amber pour with a lasting white head. Fruity and malty, semi-sweet with a slight caramel feel. My sweet tooth liked it.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel, Northampton. A golden beer with off white head and lacing. The aroma is sweet with some light fruity berry. The taste is too sweet with a flowery character. Wishy washy dull with flaws.

column4: Magic Dragon Brewing (prev New Plassey and also Plassey)
column5: Cask Handpump at the Old Harkers Arms, Chester 21/03/2001 Strong in alcohol. Poured lively. Caramel malt flavours dominate.

<!-- i -->Cask Conditioned, at the Market Porter, Borough, London.<!-- /I --><!-- br --> Amber beer with almost no head. Just above tank water, had to give the better of the 2 beers to my good buddy Harps. Bottom line, 6 other rates go unrealized because I was being silly.

Hand-pulled at The Wellington, Birmingham. Good amber colour with a decently-sized, slowly-clearing foamy head. Orange hops in smell, bitter roasted hops in the taste. Very nice. Slight perfume in the aftertaste.
Hand pulled at the Wellington, Birmingham. Orange gold colour. Light, but nicely balanced hoppy beer. Some orange and zest, a buzz of fizz and an almost sour dryness to finish.
Cask Handpump at the Bar Fringe, Manchester 20/07/2002 Golden amber coloured with some sour fruit flavour. Dry malty finish.

Pale gold colour. faint aroma, with just a touch of grassy hop. The mouthfeel is dry and fresh, but hop presence is restrained. Not enough zing here. Overall, a passable, but unexceptional beer. Cask (handpump) at the Victory brewpub in Hereford

Cask conditioned - handpump - Shepherd & Flock Farnham. Another English golden coloured ale good for the Summer. Has some hops in the aroma and taste just a little thin and boring and like so many other beers out there.
Gravity, Frog & Toad Body Parts Beer festival. Yellow colour. Floral citric aroma. Soft and watery. A poor attempt at a Golden Summer Ale.

Golden Syrup clear colour with small short lasting head - nice veil on glass. Aroma - nothing discernable except maybe wood shavings. Creamy soft slightly bitter palate. Weak short flavour of burnt grape vine prunings and slight bitter. Not pleasant! (Rated 9/5/02: Llangollen, Wales)
Hmm. Weak head some lacing. Golden yellow color, I was not able to pick up on the Rye. Thin mouthfeel with little aroma. Bit sour aftertaste. Vacation 03

Draught. Medium amber. Aroma is very lightly malty (caramel). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic. Almost zero aroma, sour finish.

On tap at the brewpub. Purs dark gold to light amber in color with a big white head. The aroma is filled with lots of aromatic ring structures- diacetyl perhaps? The flavor contains lots of smooth rich tea flavors. Pretty good.

Draught at the brewery. Pours bronze with a medium off-white head and good creamy lacing. Malt (husky, smoke, nutty) aroma, light fruit and citrus hop notes. Yeast and malt flavor, low acidity, fruit and citrus hop throughout, somewhat cardboard flavor as well. Meidum bodied and creamy palate.

Had this at the brewery. The beer poured a clear, medium-brown color with a large, creamy, off-white, fully lasting head that left behind thick chunks of lacing. The aroma wasn’t very vivid. No malty aromas; moderate apricot and black tea hop notes, heavy resin / pine hop note; no yeast. Miscellaneous esters of diacetyl, vanilla and strawberry. The flavor was lightly sweet, moderately bitter with a long, moderately bitter, lingering finish. There were some odd Nestea instant tea-like retros here that weren’t that nice, along with plenty of botterscotchy diacetyl. The body was medium, the texture was creamy and the carbonation was soft. A light astringency in the finish as well.
Orange. Fresh nose of oranges and hops, chilis, spruce and fruit. Flavor is a flat wood and stale cardboard combination. Good bitterness, but not an appealing flavor.

Off the cask. Very fine, creamy head with small bubbles. Leads to great lacing. Taste is full and malty, quite smooth. Bitter hops come in so late, I think it’s about a minute after you swallow. Very nice stuff.
Good head with good lacing. Slight citrus aroma to the top, but a bit of aftertaste that lingered too long for me. Vacation 03

Two notes seemed to take precedence: sour and musty. Other than that, somewhat sweet up front, light- to medium-bodied, not very aromatic, and somewhat bitter in the finish. Overall, very drinkable, but a little on the one-dimensional side.

Draught. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is light amber. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie), lightly hoppy (apricot), with a strong note of diacetyl. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter, unclean. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. This batch was a butter bomb, unfortunately.

Taster at the brewpub. Clear, yellow color, with a medium, white head. The nose is honey, rosewater, and hay. Sweet, with just a bit of bitterness. Very light body, with a crisp, clean finish. This is a refreshing, simple, and true to style kolsch. Nice.

From May 2008 From my notes of April 19, 2008 I was in the mood for something light yet tasty so I ordered one, let's see how it fares: Nice clear golden colour with a 2 finger head of foam. Some lacing and the head retention was good. The nose is very light but I did get a malty smell but not much more. The taste had notes of grain and malt and though it was delicate, it was pretty tasty and very smooth and drinkable. It had a lightish mouthfeel and it finished with just a touch of citrus hops that lasted through the aftertaste. This one is really easy to put away and though I only had the 1 glass, I could easily have sessioned on it. Imho, it is pretty true to style. Recommended when you're looking for something on the lighter side.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy yellow gold with small white head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is grass and lemon zest. Thin body, grass, lemon, wheat, crisp, decent.
Easy to drink but pretty boring. Faint lager aroma. Too pale and unattractive. Taste was bland and ineffective. Light and crisp palate.

On tap at the brewery. Dark gold and clear appearance with an off-white head and light lacing. Pretty bland and forgettable with a light malt sweetness and a touch of hop bitterness. Light body with a touch of floral and fruity notes in the finish.
Clear straw, no head. The nose is a bit appley with a light crisp German malt. Blandish flavor with golden toast/cracker with very little hop and a wee little fruity tone.
A milder than usual Kolsch. Lots of water in this beer with hints of beer. Grassy hops, small amounts of honied sweetness. Tried at the brewery with the parents in 2013.
(Backlog) On tap at the brewpub. Clear pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is lightly floral, fresh, and doughy. Taste is of sweet malts, light florals, and crisp.
On tap @ Coopersmiths. Pale golden pour with a white head. Buttered popcorn aroma, cream soda, and apple. Not good. Flavor is all buttered popcorn and cream soda. Butterscotch, grape, and apple.
Tap. The smell is floral, light, fresh, and bread. The look is clear, light straw colored, and has a light white head. The taste is sweet, florals, malt, and just ok.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy gold with no head. The aroma is strong chili peppers and grass. Thin body, wheat, nice heat from peppers, good.
Had it on tap at CooperSmith’s brewery! Aroma: Dammit, this smells like green chili Color: murky yellow Appearance: thin white head Taste: Crisp ale with a green chili aftertaste
Tap. Clear golden beer with a small white head. Aroma is spicy with notes of caramel, peppers, hay and flowers. Flavor is spicy with notes of caramel, citrus, hay, grass and peppers. Well balanced.

On tap at the brewery, haven’t had this in years. Gold and clear appearance with a white head. Mild aroma of mostly chili peppers. Similar flavor, moderate spiciness but still pretty easy to drink. Pretty decent chili beer.
Clear hay hue with a thin ring of foam. Large jalapeño and Anaheim pepper nose. The flavor is quite green with no spice. Just green earthy pepper and bland blonde malt.
On tap at the brewery Clear straw golden with a small white ring, no lacing. Aroma and flavor of green peppers Clean but a little too hot to drink and enjoy it.
This is a surprisingly good chili beer. It brings the heat but it isn’t overwhelming and there is a solid beer beneath it. Tried at the brewery with the parents in 2013.

Draft at Coopersmith’s. pours light orang with some yellow. Aroma is big chili spice with a little spicy hops. Taste is chili spice that burns in a good way. Has that same raunchy note from dirty lines; can’t get past it.

On tap @ Coopersmiths. Clear golden pour with a small white head. Green pepper, chilies, and water. Spicy, some fruit, and earth. Flavor is decently spicy. Lots of green, pepper flavor. Vegetal, light fruit, earth, and some grass.
Pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is of fresh chiles. Taste is of chile peppers, grass, grain with a slight burn in the finish.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear orange with thick frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is biscuit and floral. Thin body, bready malt, wheat, light finish.
On tap at the brewery. Light amber and clear appearance with a white head and thick lacing. Dirty hop resin, light toffee and caramel malts. Meh.

Clear deep gold with a lasting bubbly white head. Deep musty nose with a surprising pear and sweet passion fruit notes amidst English golden malt. A bit flat and creamy on the texture with light toast and light pear notes. Not piquing me in any direction. Pretty whatever.
Mediocre and mild, even for a bitter. Watery and light, golden colored beer. Grassy hops are non descript. Tried at the brewery with the parents in 2013.
On tap. Needs more carbonation. More hops for bitters. Tastes a little like good tea more than beer.

Draft at Coopersmith’s. pours golden bronze. Aroma is thin some earthy hops and boring. Taste is pretty bad. Starts with a light flat earthy hop then goes bad to a harsh malt note. Finish is medium length and not good.
Gold with a decent sized dense off-white head. Aroma is of caramel, biscuit, honey. Taste is of caramel, toffee, biscuit, honey.

Pour on tap at the brewery, hazy red pour with thin white head, aroma brought notes of caramel hints of grass and earth, slight biscuit notes, slight nuts as well. Taste is slight grain, lemon, biscuit, earth, hints of caramel and grassy notes, finishing fairly bitter but a bit clean.

Tap @ CooperSmiths Pub & brewing. A stop on grand tour of Fort Collins breweries and bars with Tim, Aaron and Armin, Thanks !! Pours golden with a creamy white head. Aroma of malt, toast, grassy hops, apples. Taste is malt, toast, grassy hops, green apples. Medium body, soft carbonation. 250212

On tap at Coopersmith poured a clear amber with a small lasting creamy amber head. Aromas of biscuit, earthiness and toasted malt. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bread, toasted malt and light earthiness with a smooth finish.

From Dec 2006 2004 Vintage Poured from 12oz bottle(room temp) a clear reddish gold with a large head of foam that eases back some but remains as a solid layer throughout the session. Oh, and there's plenty of lacing. The smell has a huge nose of caramel malt with some hoppiness in the background. The taste is very sweet up front. Nice caramel and butterscotch followed closely by some some hop bitterness and a good sour fruit bitterness. Very complex and very warming! A good one to drink on this cold snowy day. The finish is semi sweet and something that ends the flavours in a positive way. A great sipper, I doubt I could drink another one of these right away but that's not saying anything negative about it. I want to stretch this glass out. ;^) Bottom line: I've held on to this bottle for a while now and it's quite the treat. I got a 2005 bottle waiting for me..maybe later today. Thanks to Nutbrown for providing both bottles in a past trade!
Bottle, rated February 2016. Hazy red with off white head. Roma of raisins and dates. Sweet flavour of Daim chocolate. Ummmm....

Bottled in 2005, embibed 2014.(bottle #42 of 500). Exquisite. Pours hazy chestnut with visible particulate. Probably could have been decanted. Bottle foamed on opening. Big fluffy head that subsided to thin layer of what looked like cream. Nose - big but soft, complex; chocolate, dried dark fruit, plum pudding. Flavor - follows the aroma and add licorice, the real licorice, and cream. Palate - beautifully textured on the tongue without being syrupy. Flavors start creamy and builds to the more robust flavors, then becomes an ethereal but lingering reminder of what came before. Phenomenal that a nine - ten year old brew has so much character.

Bottle at a tasting in 2011 from notes. Pours a hazy orange/golden color with a small white head. The aroma and flavor has sweet caramel and brown sugar, a hint of tobacco, earthy notes and a slight hint of oxidation that promoted sherry notes. The alcohol is very well hidden which adds a point. This is the only time I’ve seen this beer, but would be interested in another taste.

2011 vintage, 12 oz. bottle, sent from javit (thanks a lot, Adam). Pours a beautiful dark mahogany with a small beige head. Nose is very malty, with dark fruits, caramel malts, some mild candied sugar, and an herbal note. Flavour has lots of caramel malt sweetness, some toffee, feint dark fruits and loads of booze - there is definitely a big boozy burn on the finish, along with lots of sweetness. Somehow the sweetness is contained by the intense heat, almost making two wrongs a right, except that the heat is too much. Low complexity, dominated mostly by caramel sweetness and booze. Perhaps age would settle this, though older reviews seemed to indicate the same thing, so I couldn’t be bothered waiting. Decent sipper.

Unclear amber body with a small offwhite head. Aroma is hops, fruit, caramel, spices. Flavor is caramel, fruit, dried fruit like apricots and pineapples, hops, pine needles, light alcohol. Nice lacings, well balanced. More like an iipa!

Tiny sample from bottle after a long tasting. This one had a reputation of being past it’s prime but It was still worth a go. Pours hazy brown orange. Small beige head and light lace. Aromas and taste were strong vanilla, slight oxidized rust, bread, apples, and spice. Plenty of carbonation. Not bad just overshadowed by the others brews that night.

Pours unclear amber in color with a decent light tan head. The aroma is light sweet malts typical of the style with a bit of the booziness there at the end. The flavor is not as huge as expected overwhelming in booze or sweet malts, the alcohol may have settled a bit over the year. It is palatable for sure with an ABV of 11.

Jeff pulled this beauty out of his cellar late night. 2006 vintage poured into a Stone IRS tulip. Pours a flat honey brown. It is completely translucent in clarity. Nose is hops, honey, and malt. Taste is rather pleasant, perfumery hops, smooth malts, and some caramel. Smooth mouthfeel, light booze, and a moderate finish. Nice barley wine for the age, would like to see what this guy tastes like fresh.

2011 bottle, 250/500 from hbmason...thanks Tim! Pours chestnut brown with a thin tan head. Mild nuttiness, nice mild herbal maltiness. Touch of floral hoppiness. Alcohol is present, but not overbearing. Taste is fruity--lots of plums and raisins with a big overlay of nuttiness, dry grainy malt, and a lightly spicy finish. Big fluffy carbonation with a soft body.

column1: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouché Brut de Normandie
column5: Clear golden with a small white head. Aroma of sour apple, lighter fruit, barnyard, citrus. Medium to light bodied, unrefined by design, tasty regardless.

column1: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouché Brut de Normandie
column5: 27/III/19 - on tap @ DOK Brewing Company (Gent), BB: n/a - (2019-416) Clear bright yellow beer, small creamy off-white head, pretty stable, non adhesive. Aroma: lots of apples, ripe to overripe apples, pretty yeasty, apple juice, lots of fermentation going on here, little chemical. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: lots of sweet apple juice up front, a pretty sourish touch as well, bit lemony, turning quickly to more bitter notes. Aftertaste: bitter, metallic touch, tannins, lots of apple skin.

column1: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouché Brut de Normandie
column5: 75 cl bottle vintage 2017 @ home. Batch #1172 Aroma has ripe-ish apples, apple peel and mild acidic tones. Flavour has sweetish apples, apple peel, mild milky and acidic elements. Too sweet to be enjoyable in large amounts, otherwise quite nice.

column1: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouché Brut de Normandie
column5: Draft @ Dok Brewing company. Very complex nose of tart apples, wood, calvados. Taste is tart, sweet apples, complex nice bitter notes. Very nice cider!

column1: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouché Brut de Normandie
column5: Bottle, as Bouche 2015. Lovely funky apple orchard and stable aroma, light almond. Hazy deep golden, fine sparkles. Medium body, sparkly chewy fruity. Almond, fresh fruity sweet dry apple balanced by apple cores and funk, broad flower and dried apple finish. Great drink.

column1: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouché Brut de Normandie
column5: Bottle, as Dupont Cidre Bouché 2015. Clear golden color with white head. Aroma is funky custard, very rustic, barnyard, leather. Taste is apple skin, rustic, leathery, vanilla, dry rustic finish. Dry finish, champenoise mouthfeel. Great dry and rustic cidre!

column1: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouché Brut de Normandie
column5: 2009 bottle - pours yellow - nose/taste of gold white head - nose/taste of apple, oak. Fritzy. Medium bodied.

column1: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouché Brut de Normandie
column5: Tap @ Pigalle, Sangenjaya. Nice golden pour, relatively flat. Nose has some beautiful funk and farmhouse character going on. Some tart acidity but that's pretty light. Drinks smooth, good tangy apple cider, drinks easy and yes, this funky addition really defines this cider. Super drinkable, fulfilling and beautiful.

column1: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouché Brut de Normandie
column5: 2008 vintage bottle pours out clear crisp golden with a small fizzy head. Nose is big funky goat cheese crazy barn yard. Taste is more of the big funky tart cheese crazy.

column1: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouché Brut de Normandie
column5: Bottle at home. It pours clear golden with just a few bubbles on top. The aroma is soft, sweet, juicy, tangy apple, apple pie, pie crust, earth and hay. The taste is dry, crisp, clean, sweet apple, apple tango, tangy, zingy sherbet note and dull hay with a dry, clean apple finish. Medium body and fine, prickly carbonation. Not a huge amount to it, just clean and balanced. Drinks easy.

This is one of my favorite wheat beers. The aroma is one of sweet malt and bananas. The flavor is all wheat with hints of fruit. But it is by no means a fruit type beer. I ty to stop in and have one when I'm in downtown Pittsburgh during the summer months. It is a very refreshing and very enjoyable beer. If you like wheats, this is a must try if you're in Pittsburgh.
Nice wheat aroma, with banana and citrus. Cloudy gold with foamy white head. Creamy palate, watery. Banana, wheat, and citrus flavor. A nice wheat beer, but just a bit weak.
Weak, worty aroma. Golden with nice head. Smooth, oily palate. Malty in flavor with nice finish. Ok Vienna.
(Tap) clear, bright yellow colour with a small white head; aroma of burnt rubber, noble hops; balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish
On tap at brewery. Pours clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is light malt, citrus, floral hops, and spicy, herbal yeast. Flavor is light sweet malt with crisp citrus and herbal yeastiness .

Dark golden colored body, thin white head, sparse lacing. Lightly sweet crackery malts, moderate grassy and citric hop notes, modest sweetness. Medium to light bodied, lively carbonation, mild bitterness.
Terrific beer. Smooth start with a crisp taste and light finish. Good for a long day of drinking.
Draft. Crystal clear light yellow color, white head, solid lacing. Aroma of white pepper and hay. Taste is light lemon and straw, lingering lemony finish.

Pours clear gold with a medium white head. Aroma is slightly sweet for the style...malty. Flavor has lots of cereal and a bit of grass and spice. Mouthfeel is light/medium and creamy with a crisp, dry finish. Decent but a bit malty for my taste.

Tap. Pours pale gold with thin, fizzy white head; short retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is straw, corn, grassy hops, lemon, and light barnyard notes. Flavor is balanced dry bready malts and grassy hops with some light fruit esters and faint woody notes; dry finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Tap. Pours clear dark gold with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is Pils malt, spicy and earthy hops. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and bitterness and a clean lager character with a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

Wife ordered this on a recent trip to LBC brewpub so I grabbed a few sips. Golden yellow color in a English pint glass, thin white head. Aroma of cereal and a little bit of grass hops. Taste is dry and crisp, typical of the style. Finish has a nice hop note. Decent.
Golden yellow pour with aroma of grain, citrus, and floral notes. Cereal flavor with some citrus sweetness and a quick hop ending. Clean dry finish. Good taste for the style.

Cloudy gold pour, small white head, no lace. Faint honey aroma. Flavor begins with a honeyed sweetness. The cereal backbone is very husky, and taste could go either way on whether that’s a good thing or not, a bit of an off sourness on the finish. Medium bodied, somewhat coarse mouthfeel from the carbonation.

Date: August 09, 2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Madison Appearance: clear gold, scant off white head, drippy lace Aroma: sweet malt aroma with a touch of spicyness Flavor: sweet malt flavor, touch of candy malt, light spicyness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4
Clear gold. No carbonation visible. Honey aroma with wheat. Flavor similar to the aroma. It is light, sweet and easy to drink. A nice summer time beer. Very smooth feel.
On tap at the brewpub. Pale yellow with next to no head. Aroma of honey, corn and light wheat. Taste of honey, rye and light citrus wrapped up in an astringent body.

A little dissapointing feature from J.T. Whitney: pours a straw yellow colour with a small, thin white head. Aroma is a little odd- aromas of corn, stale hops and grain. Taste is off dry, tart midpalate finishes slightly watery.

Served on draught at the Wisconsin Micro-brewers Beerfest in Chilton, Wisconsin. Pours a clear golden pale blonde brew with a fast dissolving white head that dissipates clean. Aroma is very light with just a hint of crystal grain malt, a touch of citrus hops and some dry herbs. Taste is light bodied, a multi-personality grain flavor with some carbonation and citrus zest character. Finish is semi-dry, crisp and then disappears to a clean cut flavor. I would not mind trying this as a trivial beer, for a "What am I?" drinking session.

Sample @ brewery. Grainy aroma pale to say the least. Yellow body to the beer. Odd flavor for this one couldn’t even decide what it was. Well they had it on the beer list as a beer so you have to try it.

On tap It was hard to pick up anything from the golden colored body other than a vague sense of grains. There was a light carbonation but otherwise not much was happening in my glass. The taste was a bit more active with a combination of grains (primarily the barley), malt and not much else. A slight bitterness left itself on my tongue for a second before leaving virtually no trace. Overall this was decent and enjoyable but there was nothing about it that either stood out or made me want to try it again.

On tap at the brewpub. Poured a Vitamin B-fueled fluorescent urine yellow with a little bit of white head. Funky veggies, random sweet malt, and corn in the nose. Flavor was of about the same stuff add some grains and a light bitterness. Tacky and unsatisfying on the palate... kinda felt like garbage juice slowly working its way over the tongue. This just wasn’t good on any front. Blech.
Very light yellow color, no aroma to speak of light malt taste,slighter sweeter than a macro,but not bold enough to be anything more than a refresher. wheat and rye didn’t come through at all

On tap at Khyber Pass in Philly, pours a clear dark orange with some creamy white head. Nose has vinous airs, lemon rind, mild soap, herbs. Flavor has orange and lemon, light candy, soap. Crisp finish with a touch of sweetness. Pays the bills because everyone can drink this. Earlier Rating: 12/2/2009 Total Score: 3.3 On tap at the brewpub. Transparent gold with a frothy white head. Nice floral, spicy aroma, all hops. Flavor was nice too, spice, soap, earthy. Finish was bitter and dry.

Draft at Khyber Pass. Cloudy orange copper with a slim fizzy/foamy off-white lace that left a few splatters of lace. Juicy malty earthy citrus hop brew. Blood oranges. Passionfruit. Chanterelles. Mangos. Autumn leaves. Tangerine peels. Oak resins. Green tomatoes. Starfruit. Medium caramel malts are paired quite well here with the Cascade hops. Missed this when it was made at the original brewery years ago. I think it is brewed out of PBC at the moment.
Well-balanced and nice enough. Amber pour with ok head and lacing. Soft citrus, lots of surprising roast for something so light in colour. Light florals. Tap at brewpub.

Amber with lasting foamy lacy offwhite head; aroma is sweet spicy hoppy and notes of tea; Flava is richly complex with blended notes of sweet fruity spicy tea; feels medium with just enough fizz to tantalize the tongue; finishes dry and slightly bitter
I Truly love this pale ale. Easily quaffable yet with plenty of aromatic hops. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at the source. Pours clear orange with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is earthy yeast, biscuit malt, farmhouse notes, floral and earthy hops. Flavor is medium hops and bitterness, light supporting malt and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Deep amber body, moderate off-white head, spotty lacing. Pine, orange, caramel malts. Simple but pleasant. A little sweet in the finish, moderate bitterness, appropriate carbonation.

Pint on tap pours a heathy amber with a full off-white head. Aromas are very floral and bright some citrus and pine and slight caramel. Flavor is bitter but balanced very well. Body is medium and has a good bitter bite at the finish

Cask at the Nodding Head Brewpub, Philadelphia, PA. Clear bronze colour with small creamy light tan head. Very nice fruity hoppy aroma with some malty balance and mild bitterness. Flavour is also bitterish hoppy, fruity, grapefruity and piney. Balanced. Nice one. Bitterness stays. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught at brewpub. Probably the best of what we tasted. Nicely hopped IPA closer to English in body color. But good overall taste and presence.

Golden color with a small white head. Rather bland aroma, but flowery hops were noticed. Overall the taste was balanced with sweet malts, and nice grassy hops. An overhopped, though enjoyable pilsener.

Yuck. Clear yellow with a ring of head. Musty, dirty, Saaz aroma, with some hints of grape fruitiness. Aggressive attack on the palate. When I put it in the mouth I didn't want to swallow because I could sense what would come next: a hint of hops, lingering bitterness, and a mildly astringent aftereffect that sapped enjoyment from it. Nicely carbonated, at least. (on tap at brewpub)
Light gold. Gives up its head fairly quickly. Fresh aroma. Nice spiciness. Usually I like a soft mouth feel but for a pilsener I could use something a bit more crisp.
Light golden with a nice Saaz-type nose. Fruity and malty, much fruitier than I expect from a pilsner. Decent.
Not nuts about this. It''s got a sweet bready flavor, and it''s nowhere near clean enough.
quite a quaffable beer nice saaz presence medium body the way it is meant to be
Hoppy, almost fruity nose. Nice light yellow with good head. Light carb, with nice body. Nicely hopped, bit sweet, clean finish. A bit too sweet for a pils, but very good.
Golden color with a small head and not much carbonation. Some hop spiciness in the finish, but otherwise malty in taste. Clean aftertaste as a ca common should have. Nice steam beer.

This was not one of the better offerings at the Red Star. Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a pale golden color with a medium sized white head. The aroma was light, dry and vaguely hoppy. The texture was a bit thin and the flavor dry with a sharp hop bite that was vaguely spicy. There was a dry sharp hop aftertaste as well.
Weak malty aroma. Golden amber color with small head. Moderate carb, watery. Hoppy and somewhat sweet with bitter after. It was OK, but I don't care if I have it again.

column1: Rocky River Oompa Loompa Chocolate Stout
column5: Tap. Ours deep clear chestnut, small creamy tan head, great lacing. Aroma is chocolate, chocolate, more chocolate. Flavor is heavy chocolate, cocoa puffs, a bit of roast. Medium sweet, medium bitter, a bit of saccharine. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel.

column1: Rocky River Oompa Loompa Chocolate Stout
column5: Aroma: Lots of chocolate aromas, but little else. Appearance: Clear, dark amber with rich tan head. Taste: Heavy sweetness with hints of bitterness at the edges. Very rich. Palate: Full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, long finish. Overall: A nice strong chocolate flavor, but there’s little else here. Not disappointing, but not mind blowing, either.

column1: Rocky River Oompa Loompa Chocolate Stout
column5: On tap during Ohio Brew Week 2013, taster from The Pub. Dark brown color. Thin lighter brown head. Leaves pretty good lace. Medium-plus body. Smooth, king of soft carbonation. Lightly dry in the finish. I know it’s a chocolate stout, but this is just too sweet for me. Would prefer more bitter dark chocolate. Good cocoa flavor, though. Light roast malt. Solid chocolate stout.

column1: Rocky River Oompa Loompa Chocolate Stout
column5: Draft. Dark brown, khaki head. Sweet roasty aroma. Sweet, nutty, roasty taste. Medium mouthfeel.

column1: Rocky River Oompa Loompa Chocolate Stout
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Finally, a beer from these guys that’s worth drinking. Deep brown pour with a frothy head. Chocolate and coffee are featured on the aroma and taste. Smooth palate. Nice.

column1: Rocky River Oompa Loompa Chocolate Stout
column5: on tap at RRBC, this one had me the most excited without doing any prior research, its your average stout color but its ligther body coupled with very good carbonation makes this a treat, not much chocolate flavor mostly coffee dominated but i suspect the addition of the chocolate aids in the smooth taste.

column1: Rocky River Oompa Loompa Chocolate Stout
column5: Note: I got this beer on tap during Brew Week in Athens, Ohio. Pours a very dark brown with a caramel head. Smells more of a coffee roast than chocolate. It has a medium sweetness with a carbonated soda feel. I like that this stout has a refreshing quality due to the soda-like palate but it loses it’s complexity in doing so I think.

column1: Rocky River Oompa Loompa Chocolate Stout
