column5: Draught Little head left, reddish cola-coloured beer. Nutty, indeed, hazelnut chocolade, and dark green leaves. Cola light? Sweetish and again green leaves. Light, rather watery. Too sweet and too light really.

column1: San Diego Old Town Nut Brown
column5: Poured from a tap into a pint glass at San Diego Brewing Company in San Diego, Calif. Color was dark brown. Light on the film on the sides of the glass, heavy on the lacing on top of the beer. Smelled with hints of nuts, malts, coffee, caramel and chocolate. Decent taste. Flavors included nuts, caramel and toffee. Fairly smooth beer. High carbonation. Small feel of cream soda on the tongue. Not a bad beer overall. I’d order it again. Nutty would best describe the beer.

column1: San Diego Old Town Nut Brown
column5: Draft @ San Diego Brewing Company: Part of a 7 sampler set. Food Pairing: Reuben Sandwich.

column1: San Diego Old Town Nut Brown
column5: Draft. A deep red beer with at thin off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and nuts as well as lighter notes of caramel.

column1: San Diego Old Town Nut Brown
column5: On tap at SDBC. Clear light brown pour, almost amber, off-white head. Lightly roasted malt, caramel, kind of sweet, light in the nut department. Just a light brown ale, nothing special.

column1: San Diego Old Town Nut Brown
column5: A: The pour is a dark amber color bordering on brown with very little in terms of head. S: The nose is sweet with a bit of nuttiness, but not quite as much as you might expect. Good caramel notes along with some toffee. T: The flavor seems a bit off, perhaps a touch sour. Otherwise, however, mediocre brown ale flavors at best: bit of caramel, toasted malt, nuts, and toffee. M: The body is medium and there’s a slightly creamy feel on the tongue. D: The sourness in the flavor really threw me off and sort of drug the overall impression of the beer down. I don’t think this would be an amazing brown ale either way, but certainly a bit better.

column1: San Diego Old Town Nut Brown
column5: On tap at the SD Brewing Co. No head, light lace. Nose is very light. Nuts and roast malt. Taste is very light too. Sweet with bitterness of roasted malt behind.

column1: San Diego Paddle Out Pale Ale
column5: Draft at SDBC. amber pour with average head. Aromas were some citrus, but mostly Apricot. The Apricot was so strong, I was sure I was going to get some in the flavor. I almost did. Just as the Apricot was starting to come through, the soapy hops took over. Very hoppy on the finish. Somewhat grassy, but mostly soapy. Decent

column1: San Diego Paddle Out Pale Ale
column5: A light brown orange color. Not much aroma. This is their only brew that actually has some flavor. Taste bitter hops.

column1: San Diego Paddle Out Pale Ale
column5: An amber color with no head. The aroma is of grapefruit and some hops. The flavor is of grapefruit and a touch of hops and a bit bitter. An average pale ale.

column1: San Diego Paddle Out Pale Ale
column5: Amber with lasting off white head.Faintly floral hop nose.Decenly hoped throughout

column1: San Diego Paddle Out Pale Ale
column5: Slightly floral aroma. Strong cascade hops. Pretty much like every brewpub pale out there. I haven't looked, but I'll bet I have like 8 pale ales rated 6-4-6-4-12 by now.

Draft sample at the source. The beer is a very pale yellow with a white head that dissipates quickly. The aroma has corny and mild bready notes. Medium sweetness and very moderate bitterness. Light in body and medium carbonation.

5oz sample from honeymoon. This one must be used for client who want a BMC offering. I don’t mind the low alcohol, but the light corn flavor is not pleasant. Low alcohol and low calorie beers can be so much more than this.
Macro-inspired pale yellow lager with a wispy white head. Dry with a bit of sweet corniness throughout. Aqueous with just a hint of grassy hops. Pretty bad.

5oz on tap at Smoky Mountain in Gatlinburg. Poured a clear yellow color, light fizzy yellow beer, a lot like the macros it’s going for in terms of not only visual, but also flavor and aroma. Light corn notes, some very light sweet notes, not super crisp. Kind of bland and a touch sweeter than a standard macro. I’d avoid this in the future, but a pitcher of this would be a lot easier to stomach than any Bud, Miller or Coors product.

5oz on tap at Smoky Mountain in Gatlinburg. Mild bready flavor. Not as sweet as the helles I just tried, a bit more dry. Some pale lager type funk similar to what you find in a macro, but not nearly as harsh. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter, and just a mild bite. Clear pale yellow color, with virtually no head. Pale "Light" Lager. What you might expect. Beats the macros.

Keg at Smoky Mountain Turkey Creek, 16/02/15. Clear pale golden/yellow with a minimal white covering. Nose is cereal, grain, light piss, floral notes. Taste comprises cereala, grassy tones, lemon rind, straw, grain. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. So so affair but ok for style.
Very pale yellow. Very little color. Nice straw malt, slightly peppery hops. Lightly sweet finish.
Given my low expectations I was pleasantly surprised by this one. Slightly sour, smooth. Pretty good, really.

Draft: Clear, light gold, white head. Lemon and grain aroma. Taste is weak grain malt, honey, lemon, water. Very light....mild pils bittering. Not bad for a chain-brewed light beer.....but not a lot of character.... It is what it is.
Draft at Pigeon Forge. Very pale yellow color. Aroma of light straw. Taste is similar.

Pint on tap. Clear, shiny darkish copper with a small spit of bubbles. Mild aroma is dark bread and molasses. Tastes of toast, dark toffee, lightly tart apple, and dry grass. Medium body has a smooth medium carbonation and a delicate balance. Decent example of the style.
Tap at the Gatlinburg location. Nice color and aroma. Decent bock. I had no idea this was 6.3.

Pint at the Turkey Creek location. Clear reddish brown pour with a thick tan head. Malty and caramelly nose with some earthy hop. Flavor of caramel, nuts and cherry with some slight noble hops before a sweet malt finish.

Pours a clear copper brown color with slight manilla head. Aroma is slightly dark cherries - almost medicinal smelling. Flavor has medium body, sweet medicinal dark cherry burn. Nice boozy undertone. Overall, pretty typical bock.
Draft at brewpub in PF. Pours reddish brown with thin tan head. All malt and nothing else. Not good.

On tap. A typical amber/orange pour with off white head. Malty sweet nose, some raisin and biscuit. Flavor pretty similar, nothing overpowering however, with some slight red fruits. Good drinkability. Descent enough I think, I don’t try too many Dunklers.

On draft at calhoun’s with suttree before heading to asheville. Reddish clear amber pour with slight alcohol on the nose. Caramel and toasty. Very sweet all around. Pretty average though as far as brews go.
Red-orange with a thin off white head. Caramel and light sweet coca aroma. Taste is nutty, toasty, sweet caramel malts, more light coca. One of their best.

Draft in Gatlinburg. Brown in the glass with a frothy off-white head that somewhat lasted and left think lacing. Light aromas of sweet malts. The flavor continued with the sweet malts and a light roast noted. Medium body. Ok but needs a little more in the flavor and a big push in the aroma. (Rating from 29 May 07)
Pretty decent little brew here... Good example of the style... Dark and malty with a nice sweetness, it went well with my patty melt..
Dark stout smell, so dark NO light gets through....chocolaty, some coffee bitterness, a bit too much for me...bold flavor though, not watery...
Bitter stout. Creamy on nitro. Okay beer. Aroma is chocolate. Dark. Thick head. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

5oz on tap at Smoky Mountain in Gatlinburg. Nice dark chocolate aroma. Coffee. Moderate roast malt. Satisfying moderate bitterness -- the most bitter beer of the 8 so far that I’ve tried in my flight here. Light to moderate sweet, a touch cloying, mildly astringent. Medium body. Kind of chewy. Very dry finish Light carbonation. Black color, with a tan head leaving good lace. Solid, flavorful, very bitter dry stout. I dig the black coffee character. Was easier to sip at than the other beers.

Keg at Smoky Mountain Turkey Creek, 16/02/15. Black with a decent tan covering - a good looking beer. Nose is light roast, dark toffee, liquorice, hint of coffee. Taste comprises chocolate, toffee, nice roast profile, dark maltings, liquorice. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Well rounded easy drinking stout.
This is an awesome beer. Great looking dark brew with a nice tan/white head. Boozy... Yes! But, this is the best beer that smoky mountain makes by far. Enjoy.
Black and long lasting head. Roasty, anise, a little boozy. Not as rich in the finish as expected from the start.
Draft at Pigeon Forge. Brown color, tan head. Aroma of cocoa and coffee. Taste is similar.

Draught at the Smoky Mountain Brewery, Pigeon Forge, TN. Black colour with a small light tan head. Roasted malt, coffee, mild sweetness and mild hops in the aroma. Coffee, roasted malt, dry hops and mild bitterness in the flavour. Watery.
Not a lot of roast character. Lightly hopped. Smooth carbonation. Nothing exciting.
Black with tan head. Aroma is coffee with sweet cream and dark chocolate. Taste is the same. Nice dark chocolate bitter bite.

column1: Westons Oak Conditioned Strong Medium Dry Cider
column5: Bottle. Pours golden. Aroma and flavor are sour, fruity, apples, sweet, caramel, watery. Overall: ok.

column1: Westons Oak Conditioned Strong Medium Dry Cider
column5: Bottle. Clear golden color. No head. Sweet, apples, fruity, caramel in aroma/taste. Fizzy carbonation. Drinkable brew.

column1: Westons Oak Conditioned Strong Medium Dry Cider
column5: 500ml bottle. 2016 vintage. Pale yellow gold colour, short-lived fizzy white foam head and aroma of mellow apple, barnyard, oak. Taste is sweetish fruity apple, some funk with vanilla, caramel, oak. Medium bodied, low to medium carbonation, semi-dry tangy finish. Quite OK.

column1: Westons Oak Conditioned Strong Medium Dry Cider
column5: 500ml bottle. 2015 vintage. Pours clear pale yellow, minimal head stays as ring for seconds. Looks almost flat, no bubbles. Sweet ripe apple, hints of apple vinegar in aroma. Bit tannin, sweet apple, medium soursweet, apple skins in taste. Long aftertaste. Medium bodied, below average carbo, rather well covered alco. Easily drinkable, tastefull everyday cider.

column1: Westons Oak Conditioned Strong Medium Dry Cider
column5: Bottle from Lidl, Mirfield. Paler yellow coloured cider. Its strength is hidden somewhat, with its apple dryish tasting, but also with a small sweetness to it. Its aroma also contains the sweetness found in the apple.

column1: Westons Oak Conditioned Strong Medium Dry Cider
column5: 500 ml bottle as "Westons Oak Aged Medium Dry Cider" bought at Market Place by Jason’s in K11, Tsim Sha Tsui. Very light golden yellow colour; Near zero head with residual soapy white foam which fades in 10 seconds; Fair sticky lacing with active, sparing slow carbonation; Fragrant aroma of apple wine and juice, with strong barrel, fair mustiness, strong yoghurt tartness, oxidized apple flesh, alcohol, light sugar and light tannic; Mid to light sweet taste of apple wine, with moderate alcohol, light apple juice, yoghurt tartness, wood barrel, sugar and fair tannic; Light body. Watery palate; Mouth feel is pretty winey in a watery background. More alcoholic, sweeter and dryer than “Westons Medium Sweet”, and with fairly good tartness, much less carbo, lighter barrel and tannin. The emphasis is on the booze, pleasant enough and not too dry. Okay... Quite dry after taste. Sweet, quite boozy and tart to mouth. Comments: This is the boozier version of “Westons Medium Sweet Cider” – body is thin, lesser influence on barrels and tannins, but the nice apple core aroma and basic sweetness is still there. The dryness lend a welcome crispyness for enjoyment. Not the best but enjoyable enough.

column1: Westons Oak Conditioned Strong Medium Dry Cider
column5: Golden colour. Aroma of apples. Sweet apple flavour, hint of wood. Finish light wood, apple, cigar box. Not bad - just not great either. (from 50cL bottle @ Chris and Ruth’s place, post-RBESG ’14 tasting)

column1: Westons Oak Conditioned Strong Medium Dry Cider
column5: Bottle from Lidl and drunk on a train. As Oak Aged Medium Dry Cider. Like all Westons ciders very drinkable. Apple juice but with some character. Some sweetness but not too much. Not particularly dry either. Fine.

column1: Westons Oak Conditioned Strong Medium Dry Cider
column5: 50cl. Last years crop. Full of flavour, not acidic, not too sweet and not to dry. Beautiful golden, fith soft carbonation. A go to cider on my list.

column1: Westons Oak Conditioned Strong Medium Dry Cider
column5: Bottle shared at ChrisO. Clear orange golden color, no head. Smell and taste apple, quite sweet, lightly apple pie, moderately dry.

Bottle: Golden coloured, medium-sized fluffy head; herbal, grassy hoppy aroma, some malty notes; low carbonated, sweetish-malty taste; very light hoppiness in the lasting caramelly, malty aftertaste. Quaffable, not overwhelming.
Bottled. Clear pale golden colour. Medium head. Dusty hops aroma with yeasty notes. Slightly fruity, bready and with a little maltiness in the background. Mild finish. Quite okay.
Only slight maltaroma. Malty, only slightly hoppy and fruity (pear) taste. Thin bodied. Very clean and crisp taste. Well made light lager.

Ah yes, but is it better than a slap in the face with a wet fish? On the brownish side of amber with a persistent collar of off-white head. I didn’t get a great deal of smoke on the nose but I did get redwood, a faint whisp of aromatic woodsmoke, biscuity amber malt and lashings of dehydrated apricots and guavas. The more it sat, the more smoke started to make itself known - cunning blighter. The smoke became more prevalent in the mouth among the initially prickly carbonation and smooth oily texture. It’s like sticking your head in the chimney of a fireplace once you’ve been burning copper beech or native timbers (not that I countenance burning New Zealand native timber when there’s perfectly good furniture to be made and obviously once the fire has died out). This beer wasn’t an overt smoky monster but was subtle, elegant and heartwarming. This is a beer to enjoy beside a fire while the elements rage outside and your labrador lies with his chin on your sock-clad feet. I’d even venture there may be a pipe involved somehow. By the way, it is better than a slap in the face with a wet fish.
Deep golden-amber colour. Moderate smoked malt aroma. Light smoky flavour to match. Clean, well rounded. Fairly light bodied.
Deep golden-yellow colour. Not bad, but not great. Some hop flavours, but relatively bland compared to others.
Chocolate notes in the aroma. Light roasted flavour getting sweeter towards the finish.
Light copper coloured. Yeasty aromas. Warming flavour that becomes slightly bitter in the finish.
Bottled. Golden colour, firm head. Medium sweet with papery malt flavour and clean rounded mouthfeel. Very low bitterness.
was a relief to have a hop-accented nz beer, even if the hops were as generic as they come. grassy aroma, crisp but not particularly bitter
Pale golden yellow colour. Ordinary continental-type lager. ..............
Slowbeer Richmond tap - Pale clear yellow colour big frothy head and good lacing. Sour citrus lemon aroma. Sour lemon hop flavour and thin palate.
The head is good, the body malty. It smells malty, bit bitter, hoppy, The taste is maltintensive, bit hoparomatic, bit bitter, Ok

From rumaging through my old tasting notes: pours clear yellow-gold with a white top that sank into the glass. Aromas tend toward citrus with a whiff of classic German hops giving a rounded almost musty basement aroma. Tastes lemon citrus and almost creamy, quenching but not memorable. Perfect hot weather beer.

Very highly carbonated large head frothy,straw coloured pour aroma hops fruit lemon flavour citrus taste bitter lemon some malt comes through hint of grapefruit has a sourness more than bitter not much sweetness finish sour not really like a pils.

(Bottle 50 cl) Clear, pale golden with a small, rough head. Very fresh, floral aroma. Medium body with a good and clean malt nose and dry, floral hop accents leaving a short bitterness. Lovely and well composed. 010208
Enjoyed in New Zealand. Light and clear body. Aftertaste with a lot of hops. Bitter. Yellow.
2l rigger from brewery. Clear gold, with thick creamy head. Dry, dusty aroma. Dry, citrus & slightly at the bitter end. Clean & refreshing.

Bottled. Clear pale yellow, really firm head. Light orangey nose. Dryish with soft, creamy mouthfeel and a gentle, lightly buttery malt character. There’s a touch of mango, but it’s fairly lightly hopped, and doesn’t have much bitterness. A well made lager beer, more a fresh, juicy variety of a dortmunder than a pilsener.

Tasted 18/06/2005. 500ml bottle from Regional’s, Wellington. Pale gold. Bright. Thin, pure white, head. Nice aroma of honey-like malt and fruity hops that hint guava and melon underneath the lemon dominance. Flavour is definitely hop-driven - dry, lemony and slight pepper notes. Strong bitterness. A very nice palate cleanser, not my type of session beer.
High hoppy aroma, clear gold colour, big white head, nice bitter taste. A classic bitter Pilsner.
Spice malt chocolate aroma. Dark brown colour great head and lacing. Chocolate malt roast flavour. Smooth palate.
Taster at Belaire Tavern, Nelson. Black beer with thin head. Chocolate malt nose. Zingy in the mouth, good body. Chocolate taste with slightly sour fruit finish. Solid stout.

This was a pint enjoyed in the excellent company of Geoff, Pip, Jeremy, Hazel and Mike at the Old Bank Tavern in Redwood among a few other pints and a few other luminaries. In such a situation it was hard not to enjoy this beer. It appeared as dark as proverbial with a collar of temporary cocoa coloured head. I think it would probably gain a great deal from handpull, but gas-flow was was the way it came. Once it had sat for a while to come up to temperature, the aroma was of ground cocoa beans, some plummy dark fruits and freshly ground coffee. These aromas are all winners in my book and were prominent in the flavour profile along with some darker grains. This contributed to a lengthy finish that is still undergoing changes on my tongue around forty five minutes after the last of my glass was drained. Still dusty cocoa and dehydrated coffee: this is a pint worth paying attention to and stood up well after the hoppy pale ales that had preceded it. Even if I hadn’t been in such good company, I think this beer would have kept me appropriately occupied.
The head is robust and beige. The body is black. It smells coffee, roasty, stouty, bit chocolate. The taste is bit bitter, chocolate-bitter, roasty, darkmalty, Good

Dark pour biege head good size aroma coffee caramel cocoa flavour coffee cartamel malty chocolate not rich vanilla smoothness chocolate and caramel give a goog taste finish very malty and a lasting bitter slightly sry

Bottle. Pours almost black with a creamy brown head. Light roasted aroma of toast, coffee and dark chocolate. The flavour is toast, coffee and dark chocolate. There’s great balance here with a full bodied maltiness and enough hop bitterness and hint of licorice. Smooth and bitter finish. A top stout...very nice!

Tap at Bar Edward. Pours black, thin tan head. A smooth aroma, vanilla and coffee with a bit of caramel sweetness. A robust flavour, plenty of coffee - espresso like bitterness. A wee bit of dark fruit on the finish which is long and roasty. A very tasty, classic robust Stout. This beer is on good form at the moment.

dark chestnut brown pour with a light brown bubbly head that collapses into a rim-hugging halo. Nice aromas of coffee and chocolate, slightly sweet with hints of molasses. No ash or vegetation. Semi-sweet palate, medium bodied leaning toward heavy. Classic stout flavours of burnt roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate with a solid bitter finish. Truly classic in profile, with good balance and generous flavour. Very nice.

(Bottle 50 cl) Very deep, dark brown - almost black - with an orange hue and a fine, rough, beige head. Burned aroma with a whiff of licorice. Solid body with burned coffee notes and again some licorice. Some malt astringency. Very neat. 200208
Tasted in New Zealand. Pretty dark with small head. Tastes of licorice. Bitter aftertaste. Oily.
500ml bottle in 2017. Clear light amber with a thin head. Aroma of digestive biscuits, wet grass and a slightly plasticy note. Some light grassy hops in the flavour.
Bottle from Liquor Land in Tauranga on 17 November 2019. Mildly bitter with some caramel maltiness throughout.

500ml bottle. Pours burnished golden colour with medium sized head. Subtle aroma of sweet malts. Tastes like a great English bitter, clean and well balanced with a nice crisp bite. Nice body for a reasonably light beer. I could easily drink a few of these on a Sunday afternoon. Very nice.

500ml bottle. 4.2%. Gluten Free. Golden amber colour, white foam head leaving lacing and malty, metallic hop aroma. Taste is malt, grain, fruity and nutty, with earthy hop bitterness. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry tangy dusty bitter finish. Quite OK.
500ml bottle Light amber pour with OK head. Grainy aroma with malt and toffee notes. Grainy taste too - mild bitterness. Thin malty palate. Average.
500ml bottle. Pours clear amber with a small white head. Aroma is floral hops, caramel, malt. Taste is toffee, bitter citrusy hops, malt.
Bottle. Clear liggt amber, weak head. Biscuit malts, solid butterscotch and grassy hops on nose. Light body. The taste has the same notes yet the hops dominate and save the show. Medium bitterness.

Clear deep golden color with almost no head. Do not look that inviting. Ok intensity in the aroma. Medium body and a soft to flat carbonation level. Tad sweet and a moderate bitterness. Caramel malty, mild crystal malt, herbal and mild buttery flavor. Not in that good condition this one. [Cask at United Brethren in Chelmsford, England]
Bottle. Gold in colour. Hoppy; earthy and grassy hops. Fruity; citrus. Malty; buttery caramel. Bitter hoppy throughout with quite a hoppy bite. Dry finish. Drinkable. OK. (2009-06)

Served in a pint glass from a 500ml bottle. Pours clear golden colour with a medium white head. Aroma is caramel, grass, floral, elderflower, malt, toffee. Taste is citrus, grass, floral notes, slightly bitter aftertaste. Medium body with medium carbonation. Nice, refreshing and thirst quenching golden ale.
Bottle. Bronze with no carbonation.Initial impression is of bitterness that lingers well after drinking.Reasonable although the rather tatty label doesn’t impress.

Bottle. Amber colour with a small off-white head. Malty slightly dusty aroma with some hints of hops. Sweet malty flavor with some hints of caramel. Also some thin hoppy hints. Malty finish some bitter aftertste.
Bottle. Reddish brown beer with a strongish head. The aroma is toffee and hopped, and the flavour is quite weak but well hopped with a dry toffee finish. Overall an average beer.

500ml clear bottle 4.5% ABV. Poured a clear lightly carbonated red chestnut with white gold frothy quickly diminishing head. Disappointing cereal aroma. Well balanced malt/ hopflavour with biscuit overtones & good bitterness. Well rounded mouthfeel with long bitter finish.

Amber with a good head. Malty aroma. The taste has citric sourness, a little sweetness, and plenty of malt. The fizz spoils it for me, but no doubt it will go down a treat with its intended constituency.
Bottled. Gingered amber body, with soft nutty looking head. Sharp, lifting, bitterness rises from the bottle. Nutty, bisquity bitterness, strong and unmistakably Wychwood.
Bottle, picked up in Morrisons Tewksbury (about a week or two back) Amber coloured beer, with malty nose, bit citrusy in the flavour department but otherwise a bit ordinary.
Bottle (from sainsburys, BBE Mar 07). A little citric hop, suprisingly strong caramel biscuity malts. A bit sweet in the mouth with the hops fading.

Bottle. Amber coloured with a slim off-white head. Aroma of malts, caramel and nuts. Some citrus in the taste along with a nutty malty flavour. Dry and lightly bitter. Nothing exceptional, but a drinkable bitter, that was better than I was expecting.

Bottle. Dark amber with a small head. Aromas are light caramel malts with some nuttiness. Some citrus notes with butter. Flavours are sweet malts with corn, butter and a light roast character. Sweet and acidic lemon comes through with a non-bitter, quite flat finish. Very average.

column1: Port Townsend Chets Gold Golden Ale
column5: Draft. Clear straw body topped by white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, bread, some hay, melon. Taste is moderately sweet, bread, cantaloupe, light spicy. Light body, light effervescence.

column1: Port Townsend Chets Gold Golden Ale
column5: Draft - Light grains and vegetal notes. Clear gold with a decent white head. Light grains and not much else.

column1: Port Townsend Chets Gold Golden Ale
column5: On draft at the brewery. Golden pour, slightly hazy, with a white head. Grain, crackers, floral hops, and notes of citrus. Fairly watery, but pretty standard for a golden ale. It is what it is.

column1: Port Townsend Chets Gold Golden Ale
column5: On tap at Port Townsend, pours a hazy blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out crackery malts, along some sweeter cereal. Flavour is dry and thirst-quenching with crackery malt and not much else. Dry and drinkable. Decent.

column1: Port Townsend Chets Gold Golden Ale
column5: 22 Oz bottle at a restaurant while in Port Townsend. Pours a thin see through yellow with no head on this one. Mild bready aroma. Not a whole lot of flavor going on. Super light corn flavor. The flavor that is there is t really good, and as a result, I enjoyed this beer. Light and refreshing. Pretty good.

column1: Port Townsend Chets Gold Golden Ale
column5: Bottle. Pours a mostly clear golden color with a moderate white head on there. Nose has some corn on there, but very little else. Taste is light and easy to drink though devoid of much taste.

column1: Port Townsend Chets Gold Golden Ale
column5: Bottl. Pours a golden color with white head. Malty, bread, earthy flavors. Very blah.

column1: Port Townsend Chets Gold Golden Ale
column5: Bottle @ Jon’s place on the 4th. Pours a hazy golden appearance with an off white head. Lemon zest, soda, dull sweetness, and herbal notes in the nose. Dull carbonation and flavor. Lightly sweet. Lemon and bread. A bit of celery. Bland and not good.

column1: Port Townsend Chets Gold Golden Ale
column5: A decent, if a little boring golden. Pours a very light grey yellow. Smells of ginger. Ginger in the taste too, with a bitter finish. Had on tap at the brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Port Townsend Chets Gold Golden Ale
column5: Pours golden yellow with a milky haze towards the top. Corn, light caramel aroma. Taste is semi sweet. Light bodied and thin.

column1: Port Townsend Bitter End India Pale Ale
column5: On draft at the brewery in Port Townsend. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Aroma of dank hay. Flavors are moderate bitter citrus with some malt sweetness. Easy drinking IPA.

column1: Port Townsend Bitter End India Pale Ale
column5: Draft - Caramel and pine. Clear gold with a decent white head. Biscuit and battering hops. Nice.

column1: Port Townsend Bitter End India Pale Ale
column5: On draft at the brewery. Hazy yellow pour, with a white head. Citrus, light bread malt, notes of caramel, not too intense of an IPA. Ok, nothing exciting.

column1: Port Townsend Bitter End India Pale Ale
column5: Draught at The Lazy Moon Craft Tavern, Port Angeles Hazy golden golden color with creamy head. A nice Pale Ale, with lean body, toffeish flavor, nice resiny hopping, strong bitterness and some fruity touch.

column1: Port Townsend Bitter End India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle. Orange pour with white head. Aroma is rather restrained, malty rather than hoppy. Very hoppy flavour, citrus and pine. Long bitter finish.

column1: Port Townsend Bitter End India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle. Bitter and fruity IPA. Nice and drinkable with medium body and medium carbonation.

column1: Port Townsend Bitter End India Pale Ale
column5: Vacation 2011 - Seattle and Olympic National Park 8/15/2011: Port Townsend Bitter End... Light and airy palate, but didn’t taste like much after the Hop Diggity! Draught at Port Townsend Brewing Company in Port Townsend, WA. Rating #58 for this beer.

column1: Port Townsend Bitter End India Pale Ale
column5: Crisp copper coloured body with a one centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of pale malt, a bit of floral hops, some citrus and a hint of alcohol. Light-bodied; Sharp metallic malty note with a twang of citrus and pine, a little earthy flavour and a lot of bitterness at the end. Aftertaste shows not much hops at all, some malt, a little fruit flavours and mostly bitter metal flavours. Overall, not such a great IPA, and not good for a west coast IPA. Decent to try at least given that I’m not from around there, but not worth the space in my suitcase. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Bottleworks in Seattle, Washington on 11-January-2013 for US$4.19 sampled at home in the real Washington on 07-February-2013 a day before leaving back for Seattle.

column1: Port Townsend Bitter End India Pale Ale
column5: Poured a golden orange with a nice head showing the same colors in the bubbles. The nose was pine and floral hops on a caramel malt base. Medium body. Smooth mouthfeel. Flavor is classic IPA, with citrus, pine, and flowers leading to a long dry bitter finish. Well done.

column1: Port Townsend Bitter End India Pale Ale
column5: 22 oz. bottle from Hayduke. We shared it via facebook chat. We had difficulty identifying it. Our bottles don’t say "Bitter End" but neither does the bottle in the photo here. This bottle had a little yeast in the bottom so I rolled it some. Due to the yeast it was hazy and golden orange with a nice lightly orange hued foam that never quite left. The nose was light with pine and floral hops and caramel. Nice but bigger would have been better. I get a powdery feel which is rare for an IPA. There are citrus, pine, and floral hop notes. That caramel, too. This is generally understated and quite pleasant. The hops didn’t taste real fresh so this bottle might have a bit of age on it. I like it
On draft at the brewery. Pours a hazy golden color, with a white head. Grain, watery, fruity, and light floral bitterness. Easily drinkable, but boring.

On tap at Port Townsend, pours a hazy golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is very light, with maybe a touch of English hops. Flavour is extremely bland, with English hops and biscuity notes. Very unambitious beer, not really tasting like much. Meh.

Bottled: unk Pours a golden raisin with etched whites atop a near excellently clarified brew. Smells oddly like skunked Heineken with a dash of cinnamon, plastic and oxidation. Poor nose. Flavor is bitter up front with some chemical sharpness. Followed up with some sweet crystal malt and a healthy serving of oxidation. Medium bodied with early eager but fleeting hi carb. This beer speaks of elderly characteristics, but I can’t really tell. This serving was subpar. Serving type: bottle 07-17-2012

English pales are becoming some of my favorites, and this one is archetypical of the style. I look for smoothness in mouthfeel, maltiness that is reminiscent of but so different than soapiness (if that makes any sense), and a twinge of bitterness to round things off. This one has all three in the right amounts. Very good. B+/A- ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Vacation 2011 - Seattle and Olympic National Park 8/15/2011: Port Townsend English Bitter... Barley hulls, good bitterness level; very sessionable, but lacks character. Draught at Port Townsend Brewing Company in Port Townsend, WA. Rating #39 for this beer.

April 2012, tap. Smells like a sweet fruit - mango/cantaloupe(just want to keep breathing it in). Same fruit on a palate, noticeable bitterness in the aftertaste. Very light and smooth - I could drink a lot of this beer. Fruity for a bitter, but super enjoyable.

This beer poured a slightly cloudy dark gold with a big foamy white head and decent lacing Nose of caramel malts, nuts, and spice. Flavor reminds me very much of English bitter and the mouthfeel was almost as smooth as a hand puled cask ale. Overall it was nice and easy to drink, and left me wanting more, always a good sign.

22 oz. bottle from Hayduke. We had it together via facebook chat. This beer pours hazy golden orange with a very small off white head. Ron reported that his had a big head but was poured at a warmer temp. Fairly hazy after rolling the bottle. Not a big nose but I got fruit and light spice. The flavor was very much to style. Nice gentle fruit, cinnamon, malt, grain, and cinnamon. At the finish some buttery caramel emerged. Call it toffee. This was quite nice and authentic. Ron has been to the UK and had many bitters there. While a bitter, this was not bitter at all. It was gently subtle and simple. I liked it.
On tap at the brewery. Unpleasant aroma but ok flavor. Slightly sour finish--kind of strange for being at the brewery (as if the line isn’t clean).
(Draught) Sampled at GCBF 2010 on September 11, 2010. Orange body without a head. Cloudy. Nose is very fruity. Flavour is bitter and somewhat metallic. A fairly average bitter.
Draft at PT Taproom. Amber-gold, small foam. Soapy aroma, butterscotch. Creamy sip, good alc warmth. Warm and fruity. Mulled wine hints. Amber malt, a little metallic. Alright.
Draft. Clear amber body with minimal off-white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some bread, light honey, faint peat. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, bread, faint seltzer. Medium body.
Draft - Rich caramel notes. Clearish copper with a rich beige head. Sweet caramel with a bit of hop bitterness. Not bad.
On draft at the brewery. Dark amber pour, with an off white head. Bready, caramel, herbal spiciness, and fairly sweet. Uninteresting and not that good.

On tap at Port Townsend, pours an opaque dark amber with a small white head. Aroma brings out light Christmas spices and bready caramel malts. Flavour is very earthy and spicy, with notes of feet. This isn’t very pleasant to me. Too much feet in this.

Bottle from CoOp Bellingham Cloudy dark amber color with small creamy head. Aroma of caramel, a bit cheesy. Sweetish and smooth mouthfeel, strong caramel flavor with a nutty accent, light Parmigiano Reggiano impression, some roasted nuts in the final. Strong bitterness. Old tasting (it’s about 1 years old), and not impressive anyway.

22 fl oz bottle. Cloudy orange with a small off white head. Aroma is thick maæty, caramelish and light breadish. Wooden, breadish. Dry and herbal. Toasted malty, bitter, herbal and dry. Bitter and bone dry finish.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel aroma with weak hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel hoppy bitter flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel spicy bitter finish.

Bomber. Pours a coppery amber color with a small amount of sudsy off-white head. In the nose, there’s hints of brown sugar, raisins, figs and cinnamon bread. The flavor starts out with lots of caramel, toffee, butterscotch and dried apricot notes supported by a toasted malt backbone. Just a tiny bit of a sweet citrus hops presence in the background. The body is adequately carbonated with a dry, sugary finish. In the end, it’s a little too sweet and one-dimensional.

Winter Ale--2008 22 oz. Bottle. 7.40% ABV. 45 IBU’s? (3.9 / 5.0) Mild lacy off white head. Clear bright dark amber color hazes ruby orange with mild sediment. Mild hop malt spice toasted fruit front. Mild sweet rich mild creamy toasted toffee caramel malty fruit hint rich Amber Ale body. Mild hop smooth crusty malt spice end 7/30/2009 2 $3.99 0

Had a bottle of this a week back and kept the bottle around to remind myself to write some positive notes. I've had a lot of barleywines and this one is very tasty, full bodied, moderately strong with a quite enjoyable balance overall.
Draft at PT Taproom. 2013 version. Dense copper-brown, small ring foam. Astringent butterscotch. Rough alcohol, sharp and hot, butterscotch heat. Nice sharp body. Not my flavor but not bad.

Copper/chestnut with a thin layer of off-white foam. Aroma is caramel, toffee, nuts, butterscotch, bourbon, bread, and slight citrus. Taste is toffee, brown sugar, candied orange, slight vanilla, alcohol, bread, wood, medium-high bitterness.

Draft. Minimal off-white head atop hazy dark amber body. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, orange, some cherry, light grapefruit. Taste is moderately sweet, earthy, cherry, some grapefruit, light alcohol. Full body, some stickiness.
Draft - Caramel, buttery Woody notes. Clear copper with a small white head. Sweet butterscotch, caramel and Woody bitterness. Not bad.
On draft at the brewery. Somewhat murky dark orange pour, with a thin off white head. Sweet sugary, caramel, rotting fruit, and harsh bitterness. No thanks.

Vacation 2011 - Seattle and Olympic National Park 8/15/2011: Port Townsend Barleywine... Malty and rich; a bit underattenuated, but I prefer barleywine that way. Draught at Port Townsend Brewing Company in Port Townsend, WA. Rating #121 for this beer.
Amber in color with a small off-white head. Aroma is of brown sugar and toffee. Taste is the same.

Drank from a bottle at the 20th Mondial de la Bière, June 1, 2013. Dark amber, no head. Light aroma of barley sugar, hints of herbs. Herbs dry taste and a little spicy, a little malted barley, dry bitterness. Strong but not the intensity of its style!

bottle at mondial de la bière, mtl. pours hazy light brown-reddish with a minimal light beige head. cherries (!), nice caramel and toffee, even more butterscotch, booze, grassy, earthy. average carbonation, medium body - oily. medium complexity but most definitely what you would expect from a bw. good balance.
On draft at the brewery. Cloudy golden amber pour, with a white head. Caramel, citrus, grain, and notes of pine. Ok, nothing really stands out.

On tap at Port Townsend, pours a hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma is quite hoppy in the floral hop department with a good crispness to it. Flavour matches, with a great floral hop robustness to it, with a citrusy finish. Really nice flavours and quite strong for a pale. Good stuff.

Draught at Lockspot Fish & Chips Bar, Seattle Hazy light amber color, creamy head. Light malt aroma. Malt flavor, pleasant, some toffee; the mouthfeel is smooth, the bitterness strong, with some resins. Pleasant Ale.

Draft at the tasting room. Pours a cloudy burnished medium golden amber. Dense creamy white head. Gorgeous. Toast, caramel, pine, and, alas, a bit of butter on the nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Toast caramel pine and slight butter mid palate. Long rein finish. Fix the butter and this is a b+/a- apa.

2010-06-29. Crisp golden body, small white head. Pleasant bitterness throughout, modest resin and green hops with just a bit of citrus. Modest aroma is lightly fruit, mild hops. Average plus palate suits it. 3+ Simple but pleasant. On tap at the brewery, Port Townsend

[3032-20100629] Tap. Fresh doughy bread yeast aroma has mild petrol toast notes. Slightly hazy, medium orange brown body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Light bitter bready yeast flavour has a hint of sourdough. Medium body. Quite drinkable, lovely hops profile. (@ brewery, Port Townsend, WA)

Pale Ale--2009 22 oz. Bottle. 4.50% ABV. 25 IBU’s? (4.0 / 5.0) Sediment hint. Dense rocky off white mild lace head. Clear rich bright orange gold color. Mild hop front. Doughy mild sweet soft caramel fruit mild creamy crusty biscuit cloying body. Refreshing smooth clean light hop end. Flavorful light mild hop NW Pale. Sampled 7/11/2009. 2 @ $3.99 Each.
Bottle from Bottleworks. Aroma is bland even for a pale ale. It is golden with a slight haze and a white head. Light with a weak almost sickly sweet flavor.
Bottle from Bottleworks. Pours golden with a light haze and white head. Very sweet aroma with hints of dough. Very light with a weak sweet flavor and not much going on except a long finish.
On tap at some place in Port Angeles, WA. Color was dull gold with a creamy white head. Aroma of apple, bread and fruit. Flavor was pretty sweet for style. Sweet malt, fruit and apple.
Draft. Minimal off-white head atop clear amber body. Aroma is orange, some spicy, light bread. Taste is moderately sweet, orange, some spicy, light grass. Light-medium body, light acidity.
Draft - Bitter and caramel notes, clear copper with a decent beige head. Caramel notes, toffee and nutty notes. Twiggy, sweet and nice.
On draft at the brewery. Slightly hazy amber pour, with an off white head. Caramel, some bread, mild hops, floral notes, and some sugar. Ok, drinkable.

On tap at Port Townsend, pours hazy dark amber with a small white head. Aroma brings out light floral hops, and a tequila-like fragrance. Flavour brings out lots of caramel malts, some sugar, and a light hop balance. Pretty ordinary amber that is decently balanced.
Cloudy dark amber. Slightly nutty. Creamy. Sweet. Semi crisp but also a little messy. Very flavorful.
Draft pour at the brewery. Pours a dark copper color with a mild bready aroma. Medium body with a malty caramel flavor to it. A nutty finish. Decent, drinkable beer. Will have again for sure.

Bottle. Pours a mostly clear amber color with a moderate off-white head on there. Nose is fairly bready with just a bit of caramel to sweeten it up. Taste is slightly toasty with just a hint of caramel. OK, but nothing special at all.

A very nice amber. Pours a beautiful amber with a thick white head. Smells sweet and creamy. Taste is very thick and creamy, with a bitter finish. Good stuff! Had on tap at he brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
tap@brouwer’s cafe amber colored, white head. crystal malts in the aroma. sweet, caramel flavor
Pours a deep amber, white head, heavy lacing. Earthy aroma. Sweet. Medium-light bodied.

Deep brown with a creamy tan head. Chocolate, roasted malts, a bit of earth notes, light cocoa powder. Roasted and bittersweet in the lingering finish. Medium bodied. A simple porter with a heftier dose of roasted malts. Nice.
On draft at the brewery. Dark brown pour, with a tan head. Roasted malt, notes of chocolate, earthy, mild nuttiness, and some raisin. Pretty nice actually, one of their better offerings.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown color with a moderate light tan head on there. Nose is roasty with a bit of chocolate in there, but just a hint of sourness to it. Taste is roasty and a tad sweet, though that odd sourness does hit.
Dark brown. Rustic coco nose with some molasses and dark berry. Dark sweet flavor with a touch of cherry and earthy bittersweet dark cocoa

April 16th, 2010 - Port Townsend is another one of those small breweries that works with a skilled distributor. Amongst the big boys, my QFC always had room for the little guys, which gave me the opportunity to enjoy a surprisingly well brewed porter. Their version doesn’t prop up any foam, and has all the trappings of your typical dark brown beer, but the aroma is sweet, creamy and has that agricultural smell of rich, dark soil, still clinging to vegetables at the farmer’s market. Delving into the flavor reveals even more - sweet yet savory, with dried raisins and plums, a brief aftertaste, and a little but of a dusty, dry grainy finish. Solid, well weighted on the tongue and balanced, this is an excellent porter, and one where I really have to...go against the grain...of the Ratebeer community.

This was a dark red pour with a robust tan head and a lot of lacing. Nose of roast malts with coffee aromas. Medium body. Flavor was on the mild side but was very tasty and the finish shows some nuts. Quite drinkable brew.

From Hayduke. We shared it via facebook chat. 22 oz. bottle. This poured dark with plenty of red and a nice thick tan head that never quite left. A bit of lacing. The nose was soft coffee. This was poured right out of the refrigerator and was too cold. Warmer temperatures did nice things to it. In the end this was much like a Pale Ale but with some nuts and coffee. The commercial description uses the word intense but that is not the case. There are subtle notes, though. Vanilla among them. If this is a porter it is a very light one. It is quite different and enjoyable.

Black with woody brown lacing. Aroma of chocolate, smoke, watery coffee, slight butter, slight lime, peanut brittle. Taste is roasty and a bit sour- lemonlime, smoky. I don’t imagine this is intentionally sour but it’s not terrible as a sour beer- adds to the smoky aspect really well.

(22oz bottle thanks to zdk9) clearish deep brown with few tan bubbles. Nose of cocoa, peanut brittle, lightly vinous. Taste is obviously infected but still liking this! Taste of lemon, cocoa, tangy fruits, and tangerine. Soft carbonation, medium to light on body. Interesting.

22 oz bottle my Mom brought back for me from the brewery in Port Townsend. Pour is hazy brown, with a smallish loose khaki head. Head minimal, despite an aggressive pour. Aroma has a soft coffee roastiness, along with warm chestnuts. Decent, though subdued nose. Taste is the roast coffee up front, along with some nutty bitterness, and finishing with a malty chemical grassiness. Palate is medium bodied, lower carbonation levels and a dry chalky finish. Thanks for lugging this back for me, Mom!
On nitro draft at the brewery in Port Townsend. Pours a clear dark cola with a creamy tan head. Aroma of raisin and toffee. Flavors are mild bitter roast and moderately sweet milk chocolate.

Draft pour pint at Hop and Hound. Missed this one during my visit to the brewery a while back. Glad it made it's way over here. Midnight pour with a ton of thick tan foam head. Toasty, metallic, chocolate forward aroma. Flavor is really the seller in this. Delicious stout full of roasted malt, coffee roast, semi sweet caramel and cream, and milk chocolate. A dessert beer, without being too sweet. A morning time beer, id say, with all the coffee and chocolate that come through. A flavorful dry stout here. Very impressed with this.

22 oz bottle shared. Black appearance with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate malt, coffee and roasted grain. Similar flavor, with a medium body, a smooth creamy feel and a dry, bittersweet finish. Pretty straight up stout overall. Solid.

Draft at PT Taproom. Ruby-tinged dark brown with pretty, clean-thick tan foam. Guinness character. Creamy roast aroma, a bit of alc bite and smooth creamy roast body. Cool cocoa, a little coffee roast. Delicious.

Draft at Central Cinema in July. Classic nitro pour: creamy dense khaki head that takes its time to settle. Smooth chocolate, sweetened with caramel. Gentle roast, creamy smooth texture. Overall: this is a pleasant surprise -- this is darned good. No idea if it’s changed over the years or if I just got lucky, but this was way better than the average would suggest.

Nitro. Medium beige head atop red-black body. Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, roast, some bittersweet chocolate, light oat. Taste is moderately sweet, milk chocolate, some roast, coffee, light earthy. Creamy light-medium body.
Draft - Dark roast and molasses. Jet black with a rich light brown head. Dark roast and a light sweetness. Pretty basic.
On nitro at the brewery. Dark brown pour, with a light tan nitro head. Roasted malt, light chocolate, mild bitterness, and toast. Watery, not bad, but not interesting.

On tap at Port Townsend, pours a deep dark mahogany with a medium beige head. Aroma brings out notes of chocolate, cocoa nibs and a little roast. Flavour is very light for a 6.6% stout, with notes of roast and cocoa. Smooth and creamy on the palate. Very drinkable but not overly thrilling. Decent stout.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown color with a slightly thick light brown head on there. Nose is roasty with just a hint of chocolate and sour in there. Taste is a tad sweet and quite roasty, and not as dry as i would have guessed. OK.

Bottiglia. Il gusto al naso è indirizzato verso lo speziato. La finezza olfattiva è normale e il modo in cui permane è sufficiente. Il cappello di schiuma ha una buona tenuta. La grandezza delle bollicine è medio-fine. La parte liquida si presenta limpida. La frizzantezza si presenta sotto forma di perlage dalle poche bollicine medio-fini. Il colore è giallo ambrato. Il corpo è pieno. L'amaro è deciso. La forza gustativa è elevata e la durata è buona. Il gusto è piacevole. Le sensazioni boccali finali risultano di pronta beva. Il retrogusto è intenso. L'aroma in bocca porta i segni di miele, nocciole tostate, frutta secca, pane cotto di recente, arrostito e agrumi.

W aromacie oregano, miód, przyprawy. Średnio intensywny i przyjemny. Barwa ciemnozlota, plywa w nim niezbyt ladny osad, piana ładna. W smaku cytrusowe, chlebowe, przyprawowe. Goryczka niska, alkohol dobrze ukryty. Nic ciekawego.

F: medium, white, quick gone to thin film. C: gold, almost clear. A: sweet candy, sugary fruity, bit caramel lemon, metallic. T: sweet malty, candy, fruity, bit bready, very thin body for the style, bit lemon, medium carbonation, this is not good it tastes almost like cheap imperial lager, bit spicy aftertaste, 33cl bottle from Beerwulf webshop.

Robe dorée et limpide, mousse et carbonation faible. Nez malté, sucré, bouche très corpulente avec des arômes fleuris et maltés, présence d'amertume dûe au houblon en fond. Ensemble riche et légèrement alcooleux.

color giallo tendente all'oro, cappello bianco a grana abbastanza fine, l'aroma è dominato dal lievito, puntina di agrume, spezie. al palato particolarmente dolce con poco amaro di contrasto, miele caramello, carbo bassa, alcol medio non risalta troppo.

Robuste et surprenante, la Yéti est une bière forte pour les amateurs de grandes sensations gustatives. Généreuse et savoureuse, elle est brassée avec le plus grand soin pour lui conférer une richesse aromatique hors du commun. Ses notes épicées et florales contribuent à vous offrir un instant de dégustation privilégié, loin des sentiers battus, sur les cimes du plaisir... Le nez réserve de surprenants arômes qui s'associent en un torrent de saveurs maltées et houblonnées. La subtilité et la complexité de son bouquet d'arômes et de céréales se disputent à la finesse des houblons. Elle offre une sensation unique de robustesse et de délicatesse.

Couleur blonde légèrement ambrée, un peu trouble. Mousse légère et pas très tenace. Nez agréable sur les malts cara, le miel et le sucre candy. Bonne rondeur en bouche, on retrouve un peu ces mêmes arômes sans que ce soit écoeurant. On sent aussi que l'alcool fait son effet. Not bad.

Goudblond bier met witte schuimkraag. Geur: moutzoetig, licht kruidig. Smaak: licht zoet, granen, fruitig, wit fruit, ietwat zurig en licht kruidig. Medium koolzuurprikkel. Afdronk: licht bitter droog en terug licht fruitig zurig.
Bouteille 33 cl - couleur blonde, légérement ambrée, goût sur les céréales, le houblon, c’est frais, sucrée, ça se laisse boire

ASPETTO: biondo oro, limpida, schiuma bianca, fine, abbondante e abbastanza persistente. AROMA: frutta gialla, speziato. GUSTO: come al naso. Carbonizzazione alta, corpo medio/strutturato. Buona, ma manca di carattere.

Keg at PP SB, 14/11/14. Light black with a decent tan covering. Nose is roast malt, dark toffee, hint of coffee, cocoa rub. Taste comprises subtle roast, toffee, brown sugar, nutty tones. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close, light hoppy backpangs. Ok porter.
Tap at PP Bressi Ranch. Nitro, deep red brown pour with good nitro lace. Nose is muted, some odd dairy. Taste is chalky, milk chocolate. Pretty bland overall.
Smokey chocolate. A nice light porter. On tap at pizza port solana beach.

On tap at Port Solana. Pours dark brown/black with a medium sized, offwhite head and good lace. Smells roasty overall with some sweet malts and pretty watery. Tastes the same roasty and watery overall with a bit of dark chocolate and chalk. Thin, watery body with good carbonation.

Name: Port’s Porter Date: 12/01/2005 Mode: Draft, Nitro Source: Brewpub, Solana Beach, CA black, thin fine brown head, nice roasted malt aroma, velvet body, rich roasted malt flavor, light malt biterness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 9/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4
On tap at Solana Beach (cheers again fordest). Dark brown in colour with a small head. Malty and sweet with notes of chocolate and coffee.
On nitro draft at Solana Beach Pizza Port. Dark brown with lots of bubbles from the nitro. Toasted flavor with some hop taste. Flavor and the nitro pouring beauty are this beer’s strengths.

On tap at Solana Beach. Deep brown, tannic acid colored pour with a thick layer of cream beige nitrogenated head. Innocent aroma of slightly sour Guinness water, a touch of cream, and a dash of maple woodiness. Rich, medium-full bodied mouthfeel with the trademark nitrogenated creaminess. Fairly typical porter flavors of dark malts combined with a light beechwood dryness. Very malty, lightly dry creamy porter with subtle hints of chocolate. Typical creamy porter.

Aroma of roast chocolate, but not prominent enough. Appears a dark mahogany with a huge head. Flavor is roasty with some light residual sweetness. Palate is creamy but with a light palate. Overall, just a bit less than the sum of its parts.

On Tap, Solana Beach. Dark color, with a super creamy tan head. First taste is fairly malty, with hints of chocolate and coffee. Kind of watery, with a mouthfeel of many british stouts. Very little carbonation. Good, but not up to par with many of PP’s other beers.
Big creamy head, cloudy bronz color, creamy and slightly hoppy flavor but not too much going on...
On tap at Capone’s. Poured a brown color with an off white head. Nice hoppy brown ale - pine, citrus, with nuttiness and chocolate.
On tap at brewery. Dark brown with a fizzy white head. Nice sweet almost molasses like aroma and taste with a light nutty and roasted grain finish.
Dark brown and headless. Aroma and flavour is malty and nutty. Alcohol is well hidden.
Color is brown as the name implies. Excellent nutty flavors, tastes like the essence of fresh roasted nuts. Very creamy and warming. Would be great on a chilly night.

Reddish brown looks, decent head formation and retention. Distinct nuttiness in the aroma. Well emhasized hot chocolate and hazelnut flavor, the latter certainly addds quite a bit of dryness to the prominent sweetness, while there's also a mild hop bitterness in the finish. Almost porter like in some ways, this is a great creative touch on an under appreciated style.

A great color scheme to it, a deep brown with a nice moderate tanish head. Little aroma, with a small toasted nut feel. Tasted very creamy and smooth, but more creamy with a subtle almond/walnut feel to it. Very nice,l and as smooth as a criminal. One to have when taking the ladies out, though that never ends up happening, well for sean at least.
Dark brown w/ no head, nutty aroma and an extremely smooth nutty & malty flavor, delicate roasted nut finish, superb brown ale

From the bottle. Dirty brown with a foamy head that proves to be fleeting. Mild aroma of toasted grains. Taste is mildly sweet with mineral notes and a light roasted bitterness at the end. Light to medium body wit a watery texture. Blah.
Bottle, Beers of Europe. Dark brown rather than truly black, big off white bubbly foam. Sweetish malts, malt loaf, not too rich, hint of spice, clean. Low perceived bitterness. Pleasant enough.
Black/schwarz indeed, off white short lasting foam head. Smoked barley aroma, quite nice ful taste/flavor. Good beer. (Velp 201604)

Bottled, 500ml at Alter Kranen, Wurzburg, Bavaria. Black(ish) with cream head. This was surprisingly light on the palate, fairly thin and watery, not sure why. There is a dusty note to the roasted malts, carbonation again, some caramel then fruitiness. It’s ok.

Der Antrunk ist vollmundig-malzig, leicht röstmalzig-herb, vor allem zum Mittelteil werdend. Insgesamt aber eher etwas flacher. Die Röstmalztöne bleiben doch etwas im Hintergrund, auch die herbe Note könnte ausgeprägter sein. Auf der Zunge bleibt eine leicht-malzig-röstmalzige Note. --> Netter Versuch, aber für ein gutes Schwarzbier viel zu flach. Die Aromenkomposition gefällt mir – müsste aber um einiges intensiver sein! Test vom 18.7.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,8,10,8,12,9 - 9,30

Thanks for the gift Lajos! While I really enjoyed drinking this, it was much lighter and milder than I had anticipated (expected Kostritzer). Nevertheless it was tasty. Sweet and maybe even a hint of chocolate. Too light on alcohol in the end for me.
0.5l bottle. Dark ruby body, light brown head. Aroma of caramel and some sweet dried fruits. Taste of caramel, minimal roastyness and some red berries. One of the sweeter schwarzbiers.
bottle, delivered by pivnizub! Deep brown, almost black, with a creamy beige head. Dry malty base, roasted malts, coffee, shy hints of caramel.

Dobre piwo choć jak dla mnie nie rewelacyjne i nawet w swojej kategorii. Rubinowo-czerwone odcienie i gożki finisz są jak najbardziej porządane. Piwo lekko gryzie i zbyt głębokich łyków nie da się robić.

Bottle @ bar in Würzburg. Pours a dark brownish with a large, latte-colored head. Aroma is light roast, some coffee, caramel, herbal notes. Taste is lightly metallic in the beginning, light roast, some coffee, lots of light caramel notes, light butter. Grassy finish. Palate is light and refreshing.
el hondra dispoliso van dista westi gelusas nelda destistas gernis del solista
500ml Bottle - Amber with a foamy head. Biscuity malt, sultanas and dried apricot in the aroma. Nicely balanced taste with caramel, sultanas, rye bread and dried apricot.

Bottle to mug at Landbierparadies, Wodanstr. Nuremberg, 8.10.17. No appearance. Malty aroma with some cold coffee, a little bit of chocolate. Sweet and coffee and slightly roasty and nutty taste. Full body, medium fizz, nutty and bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours hazy amber with a white head. Aroma of loads of grains, light vetagbles, earthy-pheonlic, dusty/paper, dried fruits. Taste is heavy dusty, loads og grains and earthy charater. Old and dusty

Big bubbled spritely pour but severely lacking head. Aroma of rust, black currants, and cellar dust. Interesting. Taste is of red fruit compote and straw. A bittersweet brew which has character but not very well balanced: initial sweetness is too soon overwhelmed by the hopped bitterness. However the dark fruit taste which is rare to find in a Landbier is excellent. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, best by May 7, 2016: Hazed amber. Quick eggshell head. Dirty nose of peanuts, paint, hay, fennel seed, wax and floral hops. Pointy carbonation and flimsy in body. Caramelly and sweet with papery malt and chalky yeast bitterness. Quite unclean, as its considerably dough and fruity. DMS also finds its way into the mix alongside a gummy candy slickness and stewed peach character which exacerbates the excessive level of sugars. Despite the poor attenuation, the center is somehow stark and hollow. Generic papery malt finish shows wet hay, chalk, and faint nuttiness. A very generic and dirty lager. Nein danke!
Bottle. Amber, with a thin, off-white, head. Very similar to the Vollbier drunk immediately before, with malts to the fore and perhaps a slightly more bitter finish. Good.

Thanks to kevnic2008 for that one! Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts mild but not washy, fine malty, more and more spicy. Light sourish background. Finish grasy-spicy, well balanced and quite drinkable. Not bad!
Recht malzig und nüssig mit ein paar süffigen Momenten. Etwas zu dunkel für mich in der Seele - die Malzigkeit wird etwas übertrieben. Dann aber ganz ok.

Bottle from Getränke Kistner in Forchheim. The beer pours out in a hazy brown colour with steady head and medium body. Aroma of lots of malt and peat. Taste of roasted malt, roast, leaves, woods, barley, bread and torf. Earthy.

12 oz bottle pours a muddy reddish brown color with small vanishing off-white head. Aroma has peat, smoke, roasted malts and band-aids. Taste is sweet with a bit of plastic in the finish. Body is medium to full with average carbonation. This would have been a great Scotch Ale if it weren't for the plastic/band-aids.

12 oz bottle from Beer of the Month club. Seems to be the same beer: now labeled as Scotch Ale / 8%, but the description is the same. Reddish to light brown color with a creamy tan head. Smokey, almost burnt taste. Some sweetness as well. Kind of odd and didn't quite work for me.

Not as hearty and bready as some of the true Scotch Ales I had. On the thinner side as far as caramel malt and flavor...though I tasted a decent amount of liquid smoke. Seemed only about 5-6%, so was surprised it was over 8% ABV. A nice enjoyable beer...which I used as a dinner pairing.
One of Sprechers better beers. good body and no lingering aftertaste, Smokey and rich. But nothing impressive.
Fruity esters of smokiness. Apple like flavors with lots of smokiness. Nose carrries all these parts as well. Lots of body. Overall this doesn't work together. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Shared 12 oz. bottle. Pours a brownish copper with a beige head. Head was initially fizzy. Aroma is quite malty with some sweet caramel notes.. Taste is plastic, malt, light smoke, and alcohol with a strong medicinal quality. Drain pour.

Aroma: heavy malt and sickly sweet; Appearance: dark ruby red with fizzy white head that dissipates quickly; Taste: overwhelming malty with a bizarre note of band-aids; Palate: heavy body with long, plastic finish; Overall: very disappointing.

Quite surprised that the ratings are so low. This beer stands with Robert the Bruce, Dirty Bastard and Bellhavens Wee Heavy. It’s terrific! I will guess that this is the base for Commando. Thanks to Jerry in Minnesota for making my afternoon just a Wee bit better.
Draft at Sprechers. Pours brown with no head. Nose is caramel, toffee and a strange bandaid aroma. Taste has some smoky flavor. Overall not that good.
A pretty solid scotch ale. Creamy, rich, with a sweet malty backbone. Tried with Brandon in 2015.
On tap at Slim Pign’s Redlands. Cloudy yellow with a slight creamy white head. Bready aroma. Orange and bready taste with a clean finish.
Not heavily yeasty or flavored but a decent fruitiness and citrus, albeit a little clean. Some tropical fruit in the aftertaste.

Draft at the brewery The ale poured a straw color with a smallish white head. The aroma had honey and caramel malts. The ale had a light body with soft carbonation. The taste did have a some honey sweetness. The finish was clean and dry with no bitterness.
Tap at brewpub. Nose is sweet honey and cereal. Flavours of Cheerios some peach and a bit of dough. Light sweet light bitter. Lightish body.

A: The pour is a rather light golden/yellow color with a short lived white head. S: A somewhat mild nose, but at least it’s not offensive. Floral and grassy hops with some nice pale malts and a light breadiness. There is definitely some corn and a hint of honey. T: Overall, this is a pretty sweet beer. Pale and lightly bready malts with a nice hint of honey flavor. Some corn notes, but they’re subdued, and a moderate floral and citrus quality. M: Light to medium in body with a medium level of carbonation. O: Easily one of the highlights of the Babe’s lineup (that’s somewhat facetious).
Off Tap@babes, Strong Honey flavor(note: orange blossom honey),smooth texture,light body, minimal white head, Average c02,I usually dont like honey beers but this was surprising good.

On tap at Babes Bar-B-Que Grill & Brewhouse 1/8/10. Pours a clear golden orange color. Thin white head that dissipates quickly. Very little aroma. Nice sweet citrusy flavor. Orange and honey. Crisp, clean mouthfeel. Nice.

Part of the tasting platter at Babe’s BBQ & Brewhouse in Rancho Mirage. Clear golden, white foamy cap. Aroma of sweet honey and orange blossom. Clean grainy palate with a very nice perfumey honey sweetness. Finish is crisp and dry. I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this!
Clear yellow with a creamy white head. Wheat bread aroma. Sweet honey bread taste.

For what this beer is trying to be, a thirst quenching ale as an alternative to BMC, it does a good job. It pours clear golden with little head. The flavor has a nice honey sweetness. It’s a very enjoyable session beer.
Golden body, honey and lighter fruits are in the aroma. Not a lot here. Bah
Not usually a fan of this style but I liked this beer. Pours nice yellow with nice carbonation. Very enjoyable.
On tap at Slim Pign’s Redlands. Clear golden amber with a slight creamy head. Faint caramel malt aroma. Bready caramel taste with a bitter finish.

Rerate: 11/12/02 Managed to snag a bottel from the GABF batch and this is good stuff. I get much higher emphasis in the woodiness, both in flavor and aroma. Could do with being beefed up a little but decent character overall. 6/8/02 Citrusy throughout, but balanced with some pale sweet and nutty maltiness. Light in flavor but pretty refreshing.
Black ale medium body. Hints of coffee flavor. A bit of coco. Easy to drink. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at the brewery This one of their beers that won a tasting competition in California. The lager poured a black color with tan head and lacing. Roasted caramel malt is detected on the nose. The taste had chocolate and hints of coffee. The lager had a medium body with average carbonation. This is nice lager that is very smooth and drinkable. You can see why it did well in a competition.
Pours cola with limited head and lacing. Nose is sweet and some roasted. Flavours of cola, bitter coffee and light brown sugar. Taste med sweet light bitter. Light body. Tap at brewpub.

On tap @ Babe’s. Dark brown with a small, dense off white head. Aroma of rich, dark, bready malt, with some coffee and chocolate. Flavor is more dark, bread and some dry cocoa with a light hop bitterness. Medium body with average carbonation and a dry, clean finish. I really like this, lots of malt flavor but not sweet at all, goes down very smooth.

A: The beer pours a very dark brown with a rather creamy tan head. S: Starts off a little buttery, but that seems to diminish with time. Moderate roastiness with some nice toasted malt and an earthy and floral hop profile. A little bit of bread and toffee sweetness. T: The flavor also shows some butter. Sweet with a big creamy caramel flavor. Some roast, but not all that intense. A mild bitterness to go along with some light earthy hop notes. M: Light to medium in body with a medium level of carbonation. O: One of the least awful beers at Babe’s, but that’s not saying much.
Off a Tap@Babes,white head ,Dark Red in color,light body,crisp, caramel and a lite roasty malt taste,4.8% abv.Also noted it’s called Blackfin now

On tap at Babes Bar-B-Que Grill & Brewhouse 1/8/10. Now marketed as Blackfin Lager. Pours a dark brown with moderate tan head. Aroma is biscut malt and caramel. Flavor is very sweet and not smoky for a supposed schwarzbier. Lots of caramel and toffee flavors and just a hint of light coffee malt.

Growler that my brother brought over. I had this about a year ago and enjoyed it - and am enjoying it again today. I haven’t had that many schwarzbiers, but this was as good as any that I have had. Malt and smoke are present, but don’t overkill the base beer, which is a nice flavorful lager. If you’re ever in Rancho Mirage/Palm Springs, stop at Babes for some good BBQ and beer.

Part of the tasting platter at Babe’s BBQ & Brewhouse in Rancho Mirage. Now called "Blackfin Lager" with an ABV of 4.8%. Deep clear mahogany. Burnt malt entry, followed by a surprising fruity sweetness (cooked berries). Finish is dry with low bitterness. Very nice.
Blackfin Lager On tap at Slim Pign’s Redlands. Dark brown with a slight creamy white head. Faint malty aroma. Caramel and roasty taste with a hint of chocolate and a clean crisp finish.
Muy buena cerveza estilo IPA, con un pelin de sabor alcoholico y dulce de amargor moderado
Bottle pour, they say you remember your first and this heavy IPA is no exception. Really intense pine tar and sap notes, thick, almost chewy. A bat to the mouth bitter.

Draft 0.5l at Samo Pivo Belgrade, Serbia. 08.05.2017. Pour it hazy orange color with big white head. Aroma candy, old orange rotten feel. Taste odd, orange, old batch, tingling in my throat, slick feel, light body, average carbonation, abrupt finish, not so fresh unfotunately.

From Sept 2008 I got this bottle in a trade with NutBrown. Thanks Alan! Served at cellar temp: It pours a clear gold with a 2 finger head of billowy foam. The smell is a big dose of grapefruit and piney hops with some caramel malt lingering in the background. Nice nose indeed. The taste has the big notes of grapefruit and pine up front but the caramel malt I noted in the nose has an even more solid presence in the taste. Is it perfectly balanced? No, but it certainly isn't one dimensional and that's a plus when it comes to how drinkable this DIPA is for me and the alcohol *does* give me some warming for sure but it isn't all encompassing and doesn't stop me from enjoying this drop. I can also taste some other fruit, maybe mango and tangerine? Nice. Mouthfeel is on the thick side..very substantial and I'm liking that muchly. The carbonation is on the low side of medium and it finishes pleasingly bitter. Btw, head retention is great and there's plenty of sticky lacing. Also, with the second pour, the brew became hazy. Bottom line: A very good DIPA here that doesn't go overboard with the hops thanks to a good malt backbone. I enjoyed my session with this bottle and I think you will too.

interesante ipa en la que se nota mucho un lupulo diferente y el malteado con un punto dulce muy agradable y puntito a madera en el retrogusto. nada citrica conngran densidasnen boca y poco carbonico. muy interesante no beber demasiada fria ya quempos aromasmmejoean un rato en copa.

Vierte naranja turbio con pequeña corona de espuma de larga retención; aromas a fruta tropical, piña, mango, maracuyá, flores, miel y hojas de pino; en boca entrada potente, licorosa pero con el alcohol bien integrado, amargor medio, cuerpo pleno y carbónico medio, largo retrogusto, maltoso y amargo con final dulce, compleja y excelente cerveza de estilo bien conseguido.
Bottle, 500 ml, courtesy of Max. Shared with JFK10000 and Tomi. Pours cloudy golden, white head. Light to moderate hoppiness. Fruity, sweetish, apricot, soft carbonation, medium bodied.
Aromas citricos y frutales y un poco resinoso Buen aspecto carbonatacion media, espuma persistente En boca fruta madura y final frutal
Bonito color naranja turbio con escasa espuma pero cremosa. Aroma muy resinoso y pinoso. En boca es amarga pero maltosa con los mismos sabores a pino y resina.

Botella 33 cl en el Lupulo 05..10..2016. Lote ES01524 hasta 07..2018 (r1090). Color dorado casi transparente con espuma blanca. Aromas y sabores maltosos algo dulces con lupulos maduros. Suave amargo final no muy duradero. Cuerpo medio algo pastoso. No está mal.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte La Vulcan
column5: Name: Volcano; ABV:8.2; .33 bottle; hazy amber colour, minimal off white head, which disappears promptly leaving back only some very minimal lacing (or rather nothing); aroma of honeycomb toffee, dried fruits (berries, raisins and apricot, as well), some caramel, biscuits and floral (honey notes); taste of malty sweetness with honey notes, dried apricot, grape-seeds/juice/etc like and earthy-yeasty notes, as well as decent hoppyness; good one!

column1: Brasserie de la Côte La Vulcan
column5: I bought this bottle at la ferme du terroir. I drank it tonight at home. In my opinion, it is a correct beer, original for the style. The body is brown/orange, regular carbonation, a little bit sparkling, thin foam. The taste is a bit crazy, for example, there is a sensation to drink gun powder at the end. Overall, the taste is a bit sour, typical from this brewery, brown yeast, pepper side, apricot, plum, malt, some hop, some alcohol at the end, winning a good taste at the end of the bottle, good experience.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte La Vulcan
column5: Amber pour with a large tannish head that semi-quickly fizzes away. Smell is dark fruits, spice, hint of hte malt billl. The carbonation is zippy. Flavor is caramel, tobacco, dark raisin, and spice. A nice brew.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte La Vulcan
column5: Bottle 330ml. @ home. [ Trade by fiulijn ]. ABV: 8.0%. Unclear medium orange - red brown colour with a large to huge, frothy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, dried fruit, moderate hoppy, grass, light alcohol. Flavour is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, caramel, dried fruit, light tobacco, soft wood notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20120627]

column1: Brasserie de la Côte La Vulcan
column5: 33 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden deep amber with a small tan head. Aroma is mild fruity, toasted breadish malty and light alcohol. Dense dark malty, roasted, caramelish yet dry. Light alcohol presence. Dry and roasted malty finish.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte La Vulcan
column5: Nose of yeast and some spices. Hazy amber body, small white head. Flavor of yeast and some alcohol, quite unpleasant.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte La Vulcan
column5: Hazy amber with golden head. Yeasty spicy aroma. Taste is sour, spicy and sweet.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte La Vulcan
column5: Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a small off-white head. Sweet fruity yeasty light sour aroma and a sweet fruity sour taste. Medium body and a light sour finish.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte La Vulcan
column5: An unclear amber beer with a disappearing orange head. The aroma is sweet yeasty with notes of oranges as well as hints of alcohol. The flavor is slightly sour with notes of oranges and alcohol. Maybe a bit over the top - 6 months over best before date. Thanks Alex (fiulijn) for bringing this to Denmark.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte La Vulcan
column5: Muddy amber to brown color. Nice aroma: malt, liquorice, fruits, esters (the yeast…). Quite good malty taste, but too yeasty, too evident homebrew touch.
*Old rating, best before 17.04.03. Malzig-caramell, fein-herb mit moderater Süße. Nett.
Bottle @ Bamberg. Pours dark amber with a frothy creamy white head. Nose is grass, grain and caramel. Medium bodies. Sweet malty flavor with a mild grassy hoppyness. Medium bodied. Decent.

Bottled swing top (BB 10/2010) Courtesy of bierkoning, tu Edo! Dark nut brown color, small steady beige head. Strong, strong aroma of toffee and diacetyl. Medium-bodied. Flavor has also diacetyl but it is not sweet brew. Some caramel, bready malts, balsamico. Strange dark kellerbier.

Bottled. Ambery brown colour with mediumsized beigeish brown head. Aroma is bigtime diacetyl along with toffee and sweet malts. Flavour is dry wood, some sweet malts, diacetyl as well as some slight bitterness.

It’s dark brown with a huge, creamy head. The aroma has notes of butter, roasted malt, caramel and the flavour is moderately sweet with notes of butter, caramel, slightly harsh citrus and the finish is slightly dry. Although I love the butter note in a beer, this is too much, and it’s far from being too old.

Swing-top bottle. Sweet molasses malt aroma. Dark brown color with large head and nice lacing. Sweet molasses malt flavor with a metallic aftertaste. Unique - a dark and pretty sweet Kellerbier - just wish it had more flavor.

Bottle 50cl. w. swing top. Clear medium amber color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, toffee. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20091004]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours a clear, warm orangey brown with a firm off-white head leaving some laces. Sweet aroma oc roasted malt and caramel. Medium body, roasted malts and a little nuttiness - a whiff of metal also. Little bitterness but some alcohol shining through. 041009
500 ml flip top bottle in Germany.Not really a true keller and not gold but a very good mild beer. A surprise for sure. Dark brown with a nice aroma.
Bottle, 5.2%. Clear dark brown colour. Small stable head. Mild flavour with low bitterness. A little maltiness and brown sugar to the flavour. Mild carbonation. A quite mild beer, but very pleasant.
Bella schiuma. In bocca piacevole e dissetante ma non particolarmente aromatica.

Flasche 0,5l (as "Schinner Urstoff", ABV: 4.9%): Kräftiges Gold, glasklar, kräftiger stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; frische Nase, kräftig Malz, Getreide, dezente trockene Hopfennoten, Hefearomen, leicht, Brot, Brotteig, dezente trockene Bitterkeit; frischer Körper, malzige Süße, dezente Fruchtigkeit, Malz, etwas Malzzucker, Getreide, cremig, deutliche Kohlensäure, leicht, sehr dezente Hopfennoten, leichte Hefearomen; angenehmer süßlich-malziger Nachgang
bestis dentra zatulis deris geldos onda resumas ferri usterus fendilas, hui costa

0,5 l swing top bottle. Clear golden with a two finger frothy white head in the glass. Grassy smell with some metallic elements. Taste is sweet grainy, some caramell, short apple fruity in the second row. Above average carbonation. Low bitterness. Mediocre stuff.

Bottle. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aorma of earth - veggies, malty - slight grains, fruity. Loads of hay, rather sweet, some slight earthy taste to it. Quite plain, loads of paper, with a sweet touch to it.
Clear, golden, focus on grainy flavors, lacking additional features such as some hoppy bitter notes etc. to be somewhat outstanding.

A: Golden, clear, lots of bubbles, medium sized head which hung around for a bit. S: Grassy, malty and also had notes of sugar beat. T: Apples, sweet malts with a slight grainy finish. M: Medium body, moderate carbonation. O: Refreshing Helles, not really a Zwickel, could have been a bit crisper.
Clear pale yellow, white foam head. Typical aroma and taste - barley - for this style, nothing special. Just a beer. (Velp 201612)

- klare gold-gelbe Farbe mit leichter Schaumbildung - Aromen nach Getreide, etwas Malz und Honig - gute Carbonisierung - geschmacklich kommt das Bier dann in einem undefinierbaren herb-süßlichem Gemisch daher - der Abgang zieht das ganze dann endgültig ins wässerliche Fazit: Ein weiteres Bier, welches die Welt nicht braucht
0,5l Bügelflasche. Hellgelb und klar, weisser Schaum. Frischer Kräuterduft mit etwas Zitrone. Citrus Antrunk, dann Honig und sanft bitter im Abgang.
Sourdouch and vinegar nose. Orange yellow, creamy white head. Dough and citrus flavors. Lightbodied - anonymous aftertaste.
A hazy amber beer with an OK head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and berries. The flavor contains notes of yeast and spices on a sour background before a dry end sets in.
