Bottled. Hazy yellow. Yeast and cheese in the nose. Fruity in flavour with a sourish background. Dry, sour, short finish.
Bottled: Orange coloured. Unclear. Off white dense head. Yeast, light spices and malt in the aroma. Light sour, malty and yeasty flavour. Is dry and acidic in the end.
cloudy amber-brown colour with a giant creamy head, malt and caramelwith notes of ginger, creamy mouthfeel, overcarbonated, sour and acidic, very dry and sourish finish - a failure

Bottled. Deep golden and extremely lively with enormous head. Concentrated orangey apple bubble gum aroma. Sweet and malty with notes of caramel and yeast. Some hop bitterness. Didn't get any of that marinated herring though. A pity...

Orange-amber, slight cold haze. Very little (white) head. Something sourish in the nose, wheat-like; chalk; orange peel. At times whiff of vinegar. Taste has sourish character again, even more outspoken - gets citrussy aspect as kumquats (bitter oranges). Luckily no acetic acid in the taste. Light bodied, very little malt. Aftertaste is a bit tart (sourish & bitterish at the same time). After warming even becomes soapy ?! OUCH... I cannot believe this is meant to be as it presents itself. I fear for infection. Especially the nose is off : I get a mental picture of "Schweden happen", marinated herring Scandinavian style. "Needs more ratings", I'd say.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch intensiv malzig, würzig, getreidig. Geschmack sehr malzig, leicht fruchtig süß, getreidig.

Der Antrunk ist sehr wässrig. Im Hauptteil wird es schlagartig herb-bitter-komisch. Der Nachgeschmack ist sehr langsam herber werdend, mit penetrantem, anhängendem Nachgeschmack, dabei auch irgendwie scharf. Dieser "Nachgeschmack-Mix" bleibt auch ziemlich lange auf der Zunge zurück. Insgesamt nicht so mein Fall! (Test vom 22.4.2008) --> 12,4,10,2,12,4 - 5,80

Poured into half liter Bitburger glass.Lightly clouded golden hue with minimal carbonation. Short head faded fast leaving almost no lacing and slight skin on top. Mild bitterness, but goes down very soft and watery. Smooth and drinkable. This could almost be passed off as a pilsener, except for the high ABV.

50cl bottle. Pours golden with a slight hint of haze and some head. The nose has flowers, fresh herbs, maybe urine (sorry). The taste has meadow flowers and more herbs on the head. The palate is medium bodied, with a tangy middle texture which leads into a dry finish which is more like a pale ale. Overall, really good!
Clear golden yellow colour, small white head. Full-bodied, malty with a fruity touch and some nice flowery, perfumy hoppy flavours.

Draught in Bensheim Golden color; small sized compact head. It’s one more simple Bock, low power, with some sweetish malt, but also an unnecessary alcohol presence. On draught it benefits from low carbonation and freshness, and it’s slightly better than a few other bottles.
The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass also. Starts dry, not very strong. The alcohol is well hidden. Very hoppy for a bock. Should be a little bit more spicy, but still not bad!
bottle. Clear golden colour, medium-sized head. Full-bodied, very malty but with some intensive hoppy flavours, hints of grass and hay.
Bottle. Barley malt and moderate astringent aroma. Golden yellow color with moderate head. Sweet barley malt flavor with very light astringency. Very smooth, easy drinking bock.
Clear golden with medium white head. Sweet fruity aroma wtih caramel malt notes. Sweet flavor with fruity and caramel notes. Ends mild bitter.
Dark brown color, aroma is more roasted and herbal. Taste is malty, bitter and a bit caramel. Worth to try.
The foam stability is good. the Aroma is darkmalty, a bit dark fruits, maltaromatic. The taste is darkmalty, a bit toasted, not much about hops. More on the malty side, ok.
Medium dark brown color. Nice off sweet chocolatey malty nose. Malty with big carbonation, slightly tart, slightly seeet with ok chocolate malt character. Ok

Bottle from getranke Hausler, Regensburg. Amber color minimal head. Cocacola and malts aroma. Nice bitterness and toasted malts, satisfying on a cold day in Belgium. Decent, but nothing to write home about.
Bottle at Nuremburg Youth Hostel. A decent Dunkel, dark and flavourful but still light.
Karamelliger, trocken dunkelmalziger Antrunk. Geringe Herbe, aromatisch malzig mit leichter Röstigkeit. Angedeutet bitter. Langer herb malziger Nachhall. 10/9/10/10/9/10

50cl bottle from the brewery, thanks to Matteo for this one. It pours a clean amber color with a medium beige head. Aroma is sweet malty with notes of toffee and caramel, raisins and biscuit. Taste is also sweet malty with notes of raisins and toffee and light nuts and cream. Lightly tangy finish. Medium bodied with lively carbonation. Overall, ok

Dark red with ruby hue, small off white head, not very lasting. Aroma is malty, caramel and Munich, lightly toasted bread and some honey. Taste is medium sweet caramel, Munich malt, honey, quite bready finish and aftertaste. Medium to light bodied, soft to flat carbonation.
Aus der Flasche. Schöne braune Farbe mit beigem Schaum. Röstmalzaroma. Geschmack Karamell und Röstmalz.

Tapped. Appears ruby-brown sunny and light brown body with stable head. Aroma contains some caramel, coffee and chocolate notes. Although the taste is quite clear, refreshing, rather medium with some roasted beans.
Bottle. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aromas of wort and grass. Flavours of malt, grass and apple. Light bitterness, high sweetness.

Pierwsza azjatycka pozycja co ekscytujące. Smak już nie tak bardzo. Żaden rzyg jednak nic nadzwyczajnego. Aroma jak to szwagier się śmiał nie czuję, taste pilza którego kupisz w Polscez Czechach, Niemczech, Grecji.
On tap at Sherep in Yerevan. Poured almost frozen (-), hazy dark golden color with a decent foam. Nose: smells rotten and tastes even worst. No no

Color: Straw, with beautiful, good foam. Nose. Malt, caramel and flower-grass hops. Pleasant. Taste: Malt, beer body is quite dense. The aftertaste is quite a bit of delicate bitterness. Great balance, very good taste.
Just barely enjoyable. Too malty no hops. Wierd skunky flavors. No really a fan.
Bottle. Hazy gold, white head. Skunk, light malt, mild hops. Yeah, this is crap beer, but it's an Armenian tick.

De botella y de lata de 50cl, servida en su propia jarra. Muy filtrada, como es habitual en este estilo. Rubia cristalina con abundante espuma jabonosa con retención aceptable. Cuerpo ligero, aguada y con mucho gas. Aroma escaso a cereal y sabor en la línea, aunque con matices de mantequilla, maíz y un toque metálico algo artificial. Postgusto ligeramente amargo y seco. No está mal como curiosidad.
50 cl fles. Helder blond bier met wit schuim. Geur: mout, granen. Smaak: pilsmout, licht zoet, licht bitter. Goede koolzuurprikkel.

33cl bottle at home, as a gift from a generous study friend. Appearance: clear light straw with medium sized white head. Aroma: malts, weird buttery, some cereal/cornflakes. Taste: medium sweetness and medium bitterness. Notes of malts, buttery, some porridge even. Palate: light bodied, watery texture and medium carbonation. Aroma: pretty weird stuff, but good to see that not all lagers and pilseners taste the same. Not my favorite though.

33cl bottle split with SimonBlok. Pours clear pale golden colour with a small soapy white head. Aroma of hops, slight butter, slight cherry sweet, pale malt. Taste is medium sweet, medium bitter with a moderate dry finish. Notes of pale malt, hops, slight grassy. Texture is oily to watery, light bodied with moderate carbonation
Cask Handpump at the Old Market Tavern, Altrincham 17/05/2001 Sweet on the palate with some malt flavour. Creamy aftertaste.
Cask Conditioned at The North Arms, Wroxton, Oxon. Pale brown with no head. Flat as a pancake, no condition whatsoever and this was a fresh barrel. Thin watery insipid beer, an absolute stinker.

Light color and consistency. Large bubbles forming on side of glass made it look like 7-Up. Not a bad bitter flavor, but a bit weak. Similarly, rather watery but not bad by comparison to many beers in this style. Some sweetness, for one moment it reminded me of taffy. (on tap, Bookbinders Arms, Jericho, Oxford)

Tasted this in the Saltcot, Saltcoats (JDW) in June 2007. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear reddish amber in colour with a thick white head. Slight malt note in the short aroma. Thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt gives a digestive biscuit note with boiled redcurrant jam in the mouth. Strong metallic tang of bitter hop resins impart a dry note to the aftertaste. Finish is slightly malty with tart redcurrant fruit present in the mouth. An ok session bitter.
April 2008 Amber beer. Light palate. Hoppy and a little bit fruity. Dry finish.

bottle, bought at a shop in Winchester. Hazy amber colour, large and persistent off-white head. Fruity nose. Light-bodied but full-flavoured. Slightly malty with hints of caramel and some very nice hoppy flavours to round it off.

Handpulled cask at Crosse Keys(JDW) Monument, London, during recent International beer fest. Orange with a good lasting white head, in very lively condition. Good body and well balanced with juicy malts and citric hop notes. Decent.

[on cask at Nag’s Head, Reading] Deep amber/orange with a slight but lasting white head. Surprisingly rich - flavours are malt, leaves, some earthiness, a bit of sweet rhubarb crumble and maybe a hint of honey leaving a rather sweet, almost sticky palatte - there’s not a lot of bitterness here. The stickiness made it taste like a stronger beer than its ABV suggested - in fact, reminded me a little of Fullers ESB. Not bad at all for a bitter.

Bottle 500ml from Tesco’s, New Milton. Bottle conditioned. Pours a slightly hazy amber colour with a small white head. Not a heavy aroma, but what there was was a kind of fruity/hoppy. Medium bodied; quite bitter in taste, with some fruits coming through as well. The bitterness lingers on for a while – can’t say I particularly noticed the dryness.
Cask (Market Porter, London) Another traditional English bitter. Decent malty body, and reasonable noble hop component.
Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm. Amber color with a small head. Aroma: Fruity and sweet, a bit of citrus and flowers. Flavor: Sweet malt, fruit, banana, citrus and floral hops.

Cask-conditioned at the Crosse Keys (JDW), City of London 3/4/08. Pale amber with a moderate white head. Aroma of strawberries, apricots and floral hops. Flavour had some sweet malt, plenty of fruit and A citrus hop finish. Good.
Fun to try it at the Standing Order (Edinburgh) during their Ale Festival - cheap. What a deal. A bitter, but not too bitter at all. Easy to drink. Can see how it won an award.
Dark brown in colour, big toffy coloured head.Fruity apple aroma and in taste. Mild bitter after taste.
Fruity, vinous aroma. Near black colour, nice lacing head. Bittersweet flavour: sweet and chocolatey to start with a roast finish. Fairly thin bodied.
From old tasting notes. Amber red color. Small bubbly beige head. Soft toasted malt aroma. Bittersweet toasted malt flavor. Chewy malt finish is spicy and dry.
WARNING, Not one of the 12 GREATEST BREW! I have to sample all 12, as my wife got this for me and with her not liking ratebeer as it is, I want her to think she did good. The thought counts.
As with the rest of the beers from this sampler pack - this was terrible. More orange beer, slight aroma of rotten fruit.

Part of the "12 Greatest Brews of the World" sampler pack found at my local Wal-Mart. I really hope that a typical macro drinker does not use this package as their first foray into trying new beers, because these brews will surely send them screaming back to the comforts of BudMillerCoors. Pours a murky orange (again) color with a thin off-white head. Vague aroma of sour apples. Flavor is bitingly sour with a dry, slightly hoppy finish. I am hoping these beers are at least doing some good in cleaning our my drainpipes.
I must agree with my fellow beer raters. This does taste like shit. Compared to all the European beers i have tried this is not even close to an old european beer.

Alright, So your actually telling me that this stuff goes by the name of gusatv. So already I've checked my sack at the door, and now I'M supposed to tell all the people round the world how i really enjoyed the texture of this paste like brew, and how I really thought that it had a robust, old european flavor, well fuck no, this was some shit, Brock tried to plead his case that this one was , actually no he didn;t, we were in complet compliance that this was shit. period..

Absolute shee-ot!!! I can not believe that this swill is actually considered beer! This beer puts the suc in sucks balls! The icemane and myself JUST suffered through this beer and were bitter, very bitter. It had no taste and was strangely reminiscent of Scholz beer, hmmmm...almost as if scholz was made by the same brewer. Anyway before bying this beer just lick a random guy's sweaty nut sack and it will taste better!
From old tasting notes. Just read the previous reviews. They speak the truth. A horribly tasteless mess.
WARNING, Not one of the 12 GREATEST BREW! I have to sample all 12, as my wife got this for me and with her not liking ratebeer as it is, I want her to think she did good. The thought counts.

A novel idea. "12 greatest beers of the world". But, no, let's make a batch of amber, a batch of pale, a batch of brown and bottle it and put different labels on it. OK, not quite true, but The differences between these beers, even though said to be different styles was scary. Yellow color with a white fizzy head. Acidic and bland.

The straw that broke the camels back! I could not finish the 18 beers from the two Gluek Sams Club gift packs. This was pure chemical water collected at the runoff spout of a chemical and biological weapons storage plant. It actually burned going down, erupting an old volcano of acid reflux. I, honestly, have to take several days off from drinking because of this. It's nearly midnight on a Sunday night and I'm drinking "Wurch & Warnke" sitting 6 feet away from a freshly tapped keg of 2003 Oberon. They have meetings for this type of behavior.
As with the rest of the beers from this sampler pack - this was terrible. Again - just plain bad. I don''t particularly like pilsners anyway - but this might be teh worst one ever.

Part of the "12 Greatest Brews of the World" sampler pack found at my local Wal-Mart. I am not usually a fan of this style anyway, so having a pale imitation like this didn''t help much. Pours an orangish-yellow color (I have noticed all the Old European brews have been some type of orange so far) with a thin off-white head. Mild hops aroma. Flavor is both watered-down and sour, with a somewhat dry finish. Avoid.

This beer isn't the worst I have had. In fact I think it is much better than other dirt cheap competitors such as pabst or busch, or something of the like. I don't necessarily reccomend this beer, but I would prefer it to other generic beers for the monetarily challenged.

Well, for starters yall could change the name from wurch and warnke to fuck and fucking suck. This was a ruthless voyage, seroiusly. Here's the worst part, It was 16 onces , not twelve. Well hot damn, someone had to finish this shit so it would actually show up as a rating, so i split a 16 with brock, and no that is not a sexual reference.

Well to almost any veteran beer drinker a pilsner is shit. This beer stands out in its shittiness but hey. Its overpriced, terrible, and if you see OLD EUROPEAN BREWING you know its the same as Scholz. And it does lick asss!!!

Chocolate malty aroma with vanilla bourbon notes Pours black with small wispy off white head Vanilla bourbon flavor with caramel milk chocolate Medium full bodied with medium CO2, lingering sweet roastiness. Very good bourbon stout. Extremely smooth. Taste like a quality caramel chocolate bar with a bourbon bite

Oily poured, all black with a short brown and pretext foam. Toasted and delicate aromas of Bourbon, vanilla and wood-oak. With a taste roasted and soft, rich of Bourbon, vanilla and notes of cocoa, hints of licorice, leather, coco probably due to vanilla and alcohol. Balance sweetness-bitterness. Bitter of roasted braided hop.
35.5 cl fles. Helder donker bruin van kleur, fijne romige bruine schuimkraag. De geur is whisky en chocolade. Smaak is zoet, whisky, citrus en melk chocolade. Medium body, veel koolzuur.

Appearance: Bottled 26/3-2019. Very dark brown, near black. Good size, dark tan head. Aroma: Dark malt, roasted, wood. Some barrel. Taste: Dark malt, lightly roasted, dark chocolate, dark ripe fruits. Slight alcohol, barrel. Bought: Drinks of the World (Bern), 355 ml, CHF 8.50 Info: 23/10-2019, BB: ??/??-????

Bottle. From November, 2018. Black. Brown head, two fingers, decent retention. Difficult to see the carbonation through the darkness. Almost creamy texture with delicate fizz. Aroma is strange: vanilla -but not bourbon-, barrel -strange, maybe old barrel but does not have a lot of character, altough it's tasty-, background of caramel. Taste is the same. Soft sweetness. Soft bitterness at the end. Alcohol is well integrated. Feels like a 8% Stout. But also feels like a Strong Ale. Anyway, it's good.
By far this is my favorite beer. Goes great with wasabi or anything spicey.
One of the most overrated drinks I've ever been recommended. It's extremely bitter and sour.

New to craft beer and saw this was a must get in the stout category. Unfortunately I was not a fan of the bourbon aspect and couldn't get past the heavy alcohol taste. Maybe after trying more stouts I'll gain an appreciation, but for now I wouldn't say this a great beer.

(Bottle) Dark brown colour, almost black, with brief frothy beige head. Malty nose with chocolate, toffee, vanilla, oak wood, dark bread, roasted nuts and hints of bourbon. Malty, sweet taste with notes of chocolate, oak wood, toffee, coffee, nuts, vanilla, bourbon and a mild roasty bitterness in the finish. More than medium body, sweet. Tasty, mellow and well rounded with a good bourbon wood character. Very nice.

Initial taste of vanilla, coffee and a strong overtone of whiskey from the barrel aging. The immediate after taste is that of bourbon, followed by a light flavor of espresso. An excellent slow sipper.

Bottle many times. Pours a clear amber with a finger of foam that dissipates. Clean malt and caramel nose, some light peppery hops as it warms. Balanced but a touch sweet on the palate, more caramel. Clean finish with some lingering caramel malt. Kind of old school at this point though.
Bottle from bradley...nose is malt and some caramel....pours is light amber....taste is all biscuit malt caramel and a nuttiness....taste is off...not that great.
Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. The appearance is an amber color with a medium sized tan head. The aroma is a very nice blend of hops, citrus and caramel. The taste matches the smell.

12oz bottle at O’Connors. Clear brownish amber with off white head. Aroma is malty, bread, biscuit, some burnt sugar, grass, herbs. Taste is similar; bread, biscuit, dark caramel, burnt sugar, brit hops, grass, herbs. Ok.

Taps clear, dark honey-golden with a nice golden-tinged light tan head. Aroma features malty and fruity tones, not strong but inviting. Flavor features malty, woody hoppy, and subtle fruity notes. Mouthfeel is a little thin but fairly fizzy. Howl for one.
Bottled. Pours fairly light amber. Slightly dark white head. Aroma is malty caramel, roasted malt. Flavor is malty, sweet caramel, fairly light. Standard.

12oz bottle. Attractive thick burgundy red-brown body, unfiltered. Respectably steady, foamy, off-white head. Big doughy malt tones. Not unlike a brown ale in some respects. Nutty. Kind of has an English feel to it. On the lighter side of full bodied. Pretty good.
Bottle. Clear amber brown. Nice mild hop bite paired woth a subtle almost rye quality. Slightly sweet malt. Easy drinking.

Light brown/ copper pour with beige head. Nose is toasted malt, coffee, earthy hop, molasses. Light mouthfeel. Roasty flavors, rye bread, coffee, very slight piney hop. Finishes lightly bitter and earthy. Not bad.

Dark copper pour with a long lasting tan head. Aroma is toasted malts and metal. Nice body, slightly creamy. Toasted malt flavor, bisquit and vegetable. Creamy, toasty finish. Very pleasant body and mouthfeel, some off/weird flavors but it’s good.

column1: Dunham Castle Limited London Nutty Brown Ale
column5: From old tasting notes. Reddish brown color topped by a rocky beige head. Sweet caramel malt nose hints at nuts and brown sugar. Spicy roasted malt flavor is balanced nicely by a bittersweet hoppy finish. Good body and flavor.

column1: Dunham Castle Limited London Nutty Brown Ale
column5: WARNING, Not one of the 12 GREATEST BREW! I have to sample all 12, as my wife got this for me and with her not liking ratebeer as it is, I want her to think she did good. The thought counts.

column1: Dunham Castle Limited London Nutty Brown Ale
column5: A novel idea. "12 greatest beers of the world". But, no, let's make a batch of amber, bottle it and put different labels on it. OK, not quite true, but The differences between these beers, even though said to be different styles was scary. All would have done well in a amber ale competition.

column1: Dunham Castle Limited London Nutty Brown Ale
column5: Apparently this company just renames it's beer every few months and keeps selling the same crap over and over...

column1: Dunham Castle Limited London Nutty Brown Ale
column5: "is well hopped with fuggles and bullion hops"?????? This is B.S., this is so far from a brown ale. Brock and iceman have summed this experience up nicely for me. This would actually taste better with a pepper floating in it!

column1: Dunham Castle Limited London Nutty Brown Ale
column5: As with the rest of the beers from this sampler pack - this was terrible. This is not nutty! Who is making these? This is terrible! I mean you can''t just call your beer a nutty brown ale if it tastes like freaking bud light.

column1: Dunham Castle Limited London Nutty Brown Ale
column5: Part of the "12 Greatest Brews of the World" sampler pack found at my local Wal-Mart. This sampler has made my average sink like a stone over the weekend, and I am realizing it has been awhile since I have had so many bad beers in a row. It''s a nice change from the pursuit of good beer all the time to just sit back some weekend and drink an assload of subpar beer. Anyway this brew scores points for being the first Old European that wasn''t orange. Other "red" and "brown" beers in this line have been thoroughly orange. It''s still not a good beer but it is progress. Pours and amber color with minimal head. Weak malt aroma. Back to the sour flavor, this one particularly tannic. Another drain pour.

column1: Dunham Castle Limited London Nutty Brown Ale
column5: So once again, the mo, fo's from the scholz brewery make their presence. And now, their tryin to be all hip and call this shit dunham castle, i mean what the fuck. There is no dunham castle, there is no nutty london, and there certainly is no me enjoying this shit ass wannabe beer, all i can say about london is gimmie the s club 7 girls and we'll call it even. Brock is in total agreance, i mean, fuckin A, Dunham Castle,... Is this a fucking mini golf course or what?

column1: Dunham Castle Limited London Nutty Brown Ale
column5: Fuckin ridiculously terrible. I mean scholz can not let up in its pursuit of shitty beer. The iceman and i jUST drank this bee-otch and it is totally uninspired and absolutely lacking in taste and style. In fact the only thing this beer has going for it is it is brewed by frederick scholz and can be recognized immediately as the equivalent of licking a sweaty asshole after a cardio workout and without a shower. God damn this fuckin SUCKS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
From old tasting notes. Reddish brown color topped by a creamy beige head. Faint toasted malt nose. Light toasted malt flavor hints at caramel and Cocoa Puffs.

WARNING, Not one of the 12 GREATEST BREW! I have to sample all 12, as my wife got this for me and with her not liking ratebeer as it is, I want her to think she did good. The thought counts. Watery murky bland crap. No porter here

Notes from ’98. Straight from the bottle. Good porter for the price. Slight roasted flavor. This was purchased in a 16oz. bottle I believe. It was not from the Beers of the world thing. I picked this up at Vons on Aero Dr.

A novel idea. "12 greatest beers of the world". But, no, let's make a batch of amber, a batch of pale, a batch of brown and bottle it and put different labels on it. OK, not quite true, but The differences between these beers, even though said to be different styles was scary. Brownish color with a small fizzy head. Bland and quite disturbing that it was given any form of saintly name.
This is not a porter. This looks and tastes suspiciously like every other beer by this company...
As with the rest of the beers from this sampler pack - this was terrible. This is not a porter - it is orange like just about every other beer in this pack and it tastes disgusting.

Part of the "12 Greatest Brews of the World" sampler pack found at my local Wal-Mart. This beer is absolutely heinous. It was even lighter in color than the "Stout" I had before it. It looked like I was pouring a glass of Killian''s. Now that my "12 Greatest Brews" experience is over, what have I learned? I have learned that it is possible to make 12 different "styles" of beers look and taste startlingly similar. I have learned that I can pour out 180 out of 192 ounces of beer and not feel guilty. I always try to find the good in any non0-macro beer, but in this case Old Eurpoean needs to take one for the team and just go out of business already.
Since when does a porter look like a miller lite? This has no taste and barely an aroma. Crap. Cheap. I'd consider budweiser closer to a porter than this.

So they call this one st johnsbury, So all i can say after having this one is that st john's bury his face in my ass, cause this was fucking horrible. Seriosly, does anyone actually think that anything from the old eouropean brewery is actually any good. Dear lord, does history not repeat it self, is dust not dust, is shit not shit, is old european not the worst shit ever imaginable, i mean serousiouly, if they all told me back in the day to make a product that resembled shit and creeped the hell out of everyone I would have just said, Fuck, here's the recipe for st johnsbury. Brock and Funk, I know that yall have a taste for this flavor, but every once and a while we all take one for the team, we all make a SACracife, we all actually enjoy what were doin.

This is supposed to be a porter? I agree the old european brewery somehow found a way to make absolute shit shittier. But hey the iceman and I took one for the team and drank this swill. It tasted like a draft macro that someone poured dirty dish water in. If you drink this prepare yourself for one nasty beer shit come morning.
Big hop nose with subtle fruit tones(cherries?) and a red brown color. A sweetish roasted maltiness up front bursts into a huge hop bitterness. Full-bodied and smooth.
Big hoppy aroma, vine, herbal, grassy. Deep malts lightly roasty with caramel and hints of honey. Delicious!

From old tasting notes. Brewed by Colonial Brewing Company in Evansville, Indiana. Bright yellow gold color. Creamy white head. Mild sweet malt aroma. Soft, dryish malt flavor is lacking any wheat malt character. Light flavor and body leave you wanting something more.
WARNING, Not one of the 12 GREATEST BREW! I have to sample all 12, as my wife got this for me and with her not liking ratebeer as it is, I want her to think she did good. The thought counts. Worse

I think i made a mistake buying so many brews from these guys.Nice golden color small white head that faded quickly leaving little behind.The aroma was not great,Mildly wheaty with a slight fruit presence maybe some hops.The taste was nasty with the flavor emulating the aroma for the most part with a nasty sort of off taste coming through.Just not a good brew at all.I guess if you need a rating here it is but if your shooting for taste forget it,it’s just not there at all.Shame on ya Glueks for going where you shouldn’t.

A novel idea. "12 greatest beers of the world". But, no, let's make a batch of amber, a batch of pale, a batch of brown and bottle it and put different labels on it. OK, not quite true, but The differences between these beers, even though said to be different styles was scary. Yellow color with a white fizzy head. Acidic and bland.

Dogbrick's rating is great. This should be banned from beer section at Sams Club. It would go better with the 60lb bags of dog food because that is what it smells like. You have to love the description about wheat beer need not be cloudy. I just drank about 6 ounces of this shit and I'm startring to get a little bit of heartburn and really annoyed.
As with the rest of the beers from this sampler pack - this was terrible. Terrible macro tasting piss fizz. Really really bad.

Part of the "12 Greatest Brews of the World" sampler pack found at my local Wal-Mart. You just know you are getting into trouble with a claim like that. Sure enough, not only was this not the best Wheat beer in the world, I doubt it was even the best Wheat beer at Wal-Mart. Pours an ugly fizzy yellow with a thin white head. A little hops in the aroma. Flavor was mostly sour with just enough hops to keep me from dumping the whole thing. As it stands I only dumped half.
I had this with the iceman and it was total shit. Totally macro-like swill that sucks from start to finish.

So first off we have to address the fact that the word bison is used. In the world of the dead, the word bison is God. So is this gods beer, well , thats up for the bison to decide. So as i wait for his decision, i realize that a bison can not speak and therefore i will never know if i am set free, so lets all take this leftover donation money, buy some forties , get fucked up and pretend that this shit all makes some sort of sense, or not and just buy some 7 11 chilli dogs.
(Draught) Pours a cloudy maize body with a small white head. Aroma of orange peel, clove, vanilla, and banana. Flavor of clove, grapefruit, banana bread, and grass with a dry, bitter finish.
Clouded orange color. Lemon slice that was dropped into this overpowers the aroma. Expected flavors of lemon with some edginess of wheat grain. Would have liked to try it without the fruit first.

6-1-08 tap Super cloudy thick glowing orange with a nice little white head. It has a hefeweizen funk to it in the nose but it is muted and a bit more balanced than some. Flavor is funky and wheaty and a hint of bananas are in there too. Nice thick mouthfeel with a medium carbonation. Overall, a nice beer.

Pours yellowish orange and hazy with a small head. Smell is lighty spiced, yeasty and wheaty. Taste is bubble gummy, wheat and nice, with mild spicing. Actual, strong and noticeable hop presence really makes this unique. Semi rich body, tasty and refreshing. Great summer brew.

Pours cloudy bright/straw yellow, small head. Smels like leather. Is this a recurring theme with Draught House? Flavor is of light wheat, and is naturally sweet. It tastes really good. Aftertaste is thick wheat and leathery. Good though.

Hazy dark amber, creamy white head. Light nose of lemon, clove, and hints of bubblegum. Flavor was soft and fruity with more spiced bubblegum tones that round into a light bitterness. Light to medium bodied, light carbonation, fruity spiced finish. It was aiiight, but nothing special...

On tap at pub. The pour is cloudy gold/orange with a white head and good lacing. Banana, clove, bread, and vanilla in the nose. Clove and vanilla in the flavor with banana and hints of bubblegum. Medium body and slightly dry finish. Nice beer.
Pour is hzy glowing golden orange with a thin white head...smell is yeast, banana, vanilla...lively mouthfeel, but quite strangely dry...spicy yeast flavors with a medium amount of banana....

Well, from what others have said I would say the body issue has been addressed as I felt it not to be watery in the least and also had quite a lot of flavor. The unfortunate aspect for me was that there seemed to be a slight tannic twinge in the finish that was stron enough to throw it off from being much more enjoyable. Still, not bad.
This is back on tap...and who cares. Not all that great...ion fact watery,weak and only slightly wheaty. Like bad micro hefe’s G-rat
0,33 l swing top bottle. Clear golden, big off white head. Grainy smell little bit citrus. Taste is more flat grainy, dry bitterness. Cardboardy in the aftertaste. Can not convince.
Clear golden with a thick white head. Citrus aroma. Taste has elements of fruit, some flower, a gentleman bitterness. Overall a standard Pils but with a little twist.

Lübeck 16/4 2019. 33 cl bottle with a swing cap like other beers from Flensburger Brewery. Figure from Werner Comics “fumping” a bottle on the label. Looks quite irritating (but my daughter thought the beer looked “cute” - not a guarantee for anything). Pours clear pale yellow with a big white head. Settles as frothy layer of foam clinging to the sides of the glass. Substantial Lacing. Aroma is sweet malts in abundance. Sweet, Bready, grainy malts. Light grassy notes with an acerbic touch. Light carbonation. Thin, watery texture with a Soft, foamy touch. Flavor is medium sweet followed by a stronger sour bitterness. Aftertaste bitter with a rough touch. Lingers for a bit. Not the most sophisticated of beers bi’ut not without it’s own rough charm.
Can. Pours clear yellow. Aroma is grains, müesli, lactic. Body is light, bitter, and not much else besides carbonation. Some malt body, with off flavours. Ugh.
A quite nice and easy drinkable pilsner. Nothing special, but nothing wrong either. Refreshing with some pork. Malty and herbal flavor. [Can from Sune – Holevannet 2018]

Sampled from 0.33 l bottle from local 'toom', best before August 2019. Clear, golden with a medium large, frothy, almost stable, white head. Sweetish, slightly grassy-spicy aroma of grains and some straw. Just slightly sweet, moderately bitter, gently grassy-spicy taste of grains and straw, followed by a short, quite bitter, grassy-spicy and slightly metallic finish. Thin to medium body, slightly effervescent mouthfeel, average carbonation. Not very good, as expected.

Aroma; greens, fruit, sour grass, wort herbs. Look; green 0.33 swingtop with embossed bölkstoff, off white head, pale golden body. Taste; fruit, mash, hops, grain. Finish; hoppy-fruity. Feel; ok body n co2. Overall; pilsner with some hops. [btl@Melfar2018]
Fles 33cl thuis. Fris bitter, kruidig, zomers, grassmaakje. (10-2013).-----.

0.33l green flip-top bottle from hieber's. pours a clear pale golden with a frothy head. aroma of sulphuric hops, grass, a hint of flowers. flavour of grass, citrus. oily mouthfeel, somewhat metallic bitter finish.
0,33 l Bügelflasche. goldgelbes Bier, viel, stabiler, grobporiger, weißer Schaum. Riecht leicht grasig, erdig. Schmeckt laff, leicht süßlich, unangenehm bitter.
Drank at Brewery 2001. Always, always a bit too hot. High alcohol, and probably due to their space constraints a bit young.

They aimed for the middle and hit with amazing accuracy. Everything about this beer screams half-assed, from the weak aroma to the faint amber tint to the slippery palate, and ending up with the so-so flavor. This is a baseline for the style. It has no pizazz whatsoever.
2002 Vintage- amazingly smooth and well aged. All of the edges are removed- completely smoothed out. Almost too drinkable- all malt up front and the alochol is scarily removed. A teaser for sure.

Tap at Bitter End. Batch 2002. Murky medium copper with some head and lacing. Smooth as silk. The hop bitterness has mellowed very nicel. Very balanced malt profile. Lots of body. Very warming as well. I’m glad they brought this out to try!

2003 Batch Aroma: dull, grain alcohol, some fruit and dirty socks Appearance: dark, woody brown, white head, some lacing Flavor: lots of dark wood, some peat/moss, earthiness, sweet berry flavor, cherry cough syrup Palate: smooth and bubbly, crisp, slightly dry bite, woody aftertaste

2003 vintage - sampled in Feb 2005. Plum colored with a very small head. Sharp aroma of plastic, dull grain alcohol and bleach? Metallic and full of chemical flavors... but there is a strong showing of decent plum and dark, sour cherries... abrasive and foul tasting at times with an acetone quality. Something happened to this one since 2003, and that something wasn’t good.

Had on tap at the B-Sides - Dark orange to amber colored pour with a generous amount of mocha colored foam - leads to good thick lacing. The aroma has a bit of a brandy essences to it with some molasses accents. Has some caramel, dates and raisins in the flavor with a bit of underlying smokiness. Not as much hops as I would expect in a Barley Wine though. Nice thick mouthfeel, overall, very decent.

2003 version. Medium brown color with excellent head of very small bubbles. The aroma is malty with some hops coming through. The flavor is incredible with oak, must, vanilla, fruit, and candy sweetness. Wow! Thanks for saving a keg guys.

2003: Poured hazy amber...smell is dark fruit and alcohol...taste is simple and delicate with light taste of dark fruits...finish is crisp and sweet with some alcohol...I never tried it before but I guess 2 years did it well...

Agree that this tastes a bit under the alcohol strength for a BW, but for a bar, maybe that''s not such a bad idea. Not sure what the actual strength is, but it has all the other fine character needed. Malt and hops and a FINE mouth feel and nice aroma even for a stuffy head.

Had it on tap a few days after the fire, very sad indeed. Nice rich amber color. Had a refreshing citrusy smooth taste. Carbonation was on the low side, but I dont think that detracted from anything. A pleasant beer, especially after walking around in 100 degree Austin heat.

On draught. Amber color with nice head & lacing. The aroma has a nice balanced hop and malt profile going. The flavor is very balanced as well. This batch might have more malt than I remember in the past but it is quite nice with the hops balancing nicely. Not your average pale ale. Quite drinkable. Great beer.
Tap. Smooth malty body with a thick velvet like mouthfeel. Very, very clean with a dry apple like finish. Slight cherry aftertaste. Excellent and enjoyable.
Pours amber with a small head of clinging lace. Taste is hops and a rush of citrus, with a bit of sweet cucumber in the finish. Pleasant beer.

Pour is golden amber with a thin off white head...smell is grassy and perfumey with lots of floral hops and malt accenting the whole aroma...taste is sweet at first and lots of pepper and hops going on toward the finish...nice...

This was a very good brew. At first I didn’t think there wa sa whole lot going on with this one. However as I sunk in I realized all the smoke in the bar was clogging out my olfactory senses. Great brew. Rich thick coper color. Head dissipates. Smells like fresh ground black pepper and fresh vegetables. I know kind of strange but excellent smelling. BRew tastes like ground pepper and lemon. Aftertaste is nice and dry like a good californie common. Excellent brew. grat
Deep copper color and a lightly sweet aroma. Candy-like, floral lager yeast profile. Body has a nice subtle caramel sweetness. A very nice steam beer.

What style WON'T these guys at Bitter End tackle. A "steam" beer is truly uncommon, especially down in Austin, where everyone drinks a so-called "bock" called Shiner. This Mopac steam beer is true to style and is a reasonable facsimile of the famous Bay Area Anchor Steam. Hoppy and enjoyable.

MoPac is short for Missouri-Pacific, and it represents a highway in Austin that has a railroad running along it. MoPac looks cool because of the "Green Belt", a nice wooded area with all kinds of parks and trails and stuff. Unfortunately Mopac Steam Engine beer didn't look as good. It has almost no head and I deducted another point because of the fact that despite it being served in an awesome looking Bitter End glass, it still looked kind of bad. I'm not sure what it was supposed to be, but it smelled and tasted just like a pale ale.
This beer reminded me of an average pale ale. Very little head, amber color. Somewhat hoppy with a decent malt balance. Very effervescent.
Is it "force-ale" or is it "for-cale"? Hoppy, nice smell but off-balance flavor. Pale and bitter, blah.
Pale orange color, little head. Reminded me a lot of a redhook IPA....tons of floral hops with little malt to back it up. Very bitter and a not very refreshing finish.
En øl der desværre ikke når samme højder som Jever pilsneren. Den mangler lidt skarphed som pilsneren og lidt fylde som mørk øl.

Northern German but otherwise quite typical Schwarzbier with light beige, moussy head and deep black-brownish colour with ruby hue. Roasted coffee and caramel aroma with some leafy hops and a hint of leather. Bit one-dimensional taste, mostly roasted bitterness, warming and enjoyable but I did have a few Schwarzbiers with more complexity.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein dunkel rötlichbraunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, nussig, Karamell. Geschmack röstmalzig, leicht schokoladig, nussig, leicht würzig.
Bottle in China. This a pretty lack luster schwartzbier. Nothing worth seeking out.
Dark brown and cloudy. Hoppy and malt aroma. Malty caramel chocolate flavour. Test of 27.03.2005.

on tap at Jever Brewery, Jever in 2004. Pours almost black, impenetrable against light, clear with creamy big beige head with lacing. Aromas sweet malts, little caramel. Palate is sweet grains, roasted malts. Texture medium bodies, little thin watery, sticky with smooth carbonation. After taste light bitter dryness with short finish.
floral, roasty, bubblegum, brown, minimal head, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, thin feel, astringent,
Brown color with medium size off-white head. Caramel aroma. Slightly metallic taste behind the hops.

Röstmalzig im Geruch - etwas metallisch. Geschmacklich eine kräftige Malz-Kaffeenote untermalt mit leichter Herbe. Im Abgang steigert sich die Herbe und hält lange vor. Gut gemachtes Dunkel. Leider auch von einer gewissen Wässrigkeit. Trotzdem noch ganz gut.Test vom 17.8.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche
Pours clear pale golden with a white head. Aroma of grain, light dough and light bitter.
Bottled 330ml. -Yellow coloured, small white head, weak dusty vegetables nose. Malty, grainy and vegetables with flowery and salty notes. Low carbonation. Dry bitterish finish. (Below) average pils.
Bottle. Clear yellow colour with small creamy white mostly lasting head. Malty aroma with grainy notes. Sweet flavor. Bitter finish. Watery palate.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, grain, toasted, light vegetables, light hoppy, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20100904]
Bottle. Frothy white good mostly deminishing head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Light sweet and bitter flavor. Average m oderate bitter finish. Oily palate. Strange CGP.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is pale golden. Aroma and taste are butter, malt, grass and hops.

It’s golden with a creamy, white head and an aroma of malt, light flower and a touch of straw. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of malt, floral hops and the finish is slightly dry with notes of straw and it has a light and refreshing bitterness.

Hochstiftliches Brauhaus--Will-Brau Pils--2000 16.9 oz. Bottle. 5.00% ABV? (3.25 / 5.0) Clear light bright straw golden color. Delicate floral front with Bavarian tinge. Light nicely sweet body with crisp creamy buttery malty flavor. Smooth creamy mild spice end. Light but good flavor. Sampled 8/23/2000.
Bottle. Pale blonde. Soft malty flowery citric aroma. Medium bodied. Malty sweetish flowery citric flavor with a hint of perfume. Apple. Typical southern German pilsener.
Bottle, 4.6%. Mild dusty aroma. Clear golden colour. Small white head. The flavour is nicely malty, very pleasant. Low bitterness, some good chalk. Nice and well-rounded.
Canned, 355 ml at Teton VAlley, Provisions. Cloudy orange, white head. Citrus, some caramel, sweetish, some light bitterness. Light bodied.
(355ml bottle) Pours a hazy golden body with a medium white head. Aroma of grapefruit, orange, caramel, and grass. Flavor of caramel, citrus, earth, and peach with a dry, bitter finish.

From bottle, pour is cloudy with yeast suspended in the beer, the color is blond with a tan head that is creamy and lingers. The taste is sweet initially, notes of green apple and good presence of hops. The mouthfeel is medium with a sweetened finish.
Tap, ADT. Hazy golden orange with a thin off-white head. Orange nose and flavors, with floral and grassy hops, light sweetness. Medium body. Juicy, spicy finish.
(En fût à la source): Entre les fines herbes et le gazon frais coupé dans un décor teinté par la fraise et les céréales miellées. Très gruitesque.
12 oz bottle bright gold pour with medium off-white head Aroma and taste is citrus grass and a mild hoppy bitterness

355ml bottle. Pours a hazy yellow-orange with a medium, frothy, long lasting, off-white head that leaves curtains of lace. Sweet aroma of biscuit malt, caramel, orange, tangerine, grass and pine. Sweet flavour of caramel malt, biscuit, peach, orange peel, lemon grass and light pine with a dry, bitter hoppy finish. Medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Ok.
Wow! Buddy bought a 6-pack of this beer at Smiley Creek Store, near Stanley, ID. There to watch 100% solar eclipse. This ale is the real deal...!

Had this from the bottle in Laramie WY. Our first night out on the 60th motorcycle trip with Marc Caron. Nice citrusy hops balanced with light malt and 6% alcohol. I really enjoyed this. F Avey---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours orange. Head is white, creamy, and the brew retains a visible lacing. Aroma is a mix of caramel and blood orange. Tart, with a citric bitterness. Finishes the same. Body is medium, and the beer leaves a rich, smooth feel in the mouth. Good.

Bottle with 4% ABV. Golden clear body with nice white head. Aroma is grains malts bread with hints of citrus. Taste is bread with hints of malts. Aftertaste is nice bitter with hints of malt sweetness. Nice for the low ABV.
50 cl bottle bought at Merkur,Vienna.Golden colour with small head. Malty flavour. Light body.
0,5l bottle. Quite good. Tasty with a refreshing bitterness............................ ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nettes Lager ohne grosse Hoehepunkte. Mild im Geschmack, mit etwas Hopfen, Malz unz Gras im Aroma. Recht sueffig ohne gross aufzutrumpfen.Ganz ok halt und eine ordentliche Wahl fue einen Fussballabend.

Bottle from local Merkur in Austria. The beer pours out in a clear golden colour with low head and medium body. Aroma of mild hops, barley and grass. Taste of mild bitter hops, malt, barley, citrus and grass. Easy drinkable,yet nothign special.
Flaska från brorsan, tack! Guldfärgad vätska med vitt skum. Smakar och doftar som en klassisk eurolager... Bra med en Lätt efter kräftor och snaps.
Clear yellow appearance with medium head. Malty aroma with some hops. Decent pale lager.

On draft into a liter Maß. Pours a deep gold with a frothy white head. Smells of sweet grains and light fruit. Clean mouthfeel. Tastes of pilsner malt, lighter non-citrus fruits, with a bit of a metallic finishs. A good, easy to drink lager.
Nice crisp beer. Light flavor and smooth aftertaste. Good to have a few on a sunny day
(Flasche) Es ist zitronengelb, klar filtriert mit einer weißen Schumkrone. Das Aroma ist sehr würzig und malzig. Der Geschmack ist etwas wässrig, süß und würzig.

Name: Earthquake Pale Date: 06/06/2002 Mode: Bottle Source: Ale Atlanta Sweet alcoholic funky aroma, sweet corn flavor, touch of bitterness, no Aroma: 2/10; Appearance: 2/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.1/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

First of all, the color is way too light. I've had many brown ales this color...transparent medium brown. The aroma was of burnt peanuts, and slight hops bitterness. The flavor was exactly like a Butterfinger's candy bar (sweet peanut butter and chocolate)...it was actually quite enjoyable. The feel was watery and too thin.
Yes its better on tap. Great burnt nose nad taste, but way too thin.........
I don't know if my bottle was old, but this tasted like a watered down guiness. Stay away from this beer, unless the brewery is next to your house.
Nice looking, fairly unassming, but I don’t assume or presume to like brown ales much and the lean to being too sweet did nothing to win me over.

This used to be a decent brew. The last time I had it though i wanted to barf! EVERYWHERE!! On nitrogen in a weizen glass. Look lovely. Deep brown. Looks like really thick beef stock...ohh wait it even smells like really thick beef stock....no it couldn’t be it tastes like really thick beef stock as well. Gross. Strangely salty on the uptake and disgustingly so going down. Not a good brew as of late. grat
Brown ale, nothing really wrong nor right here.............................
Creamy but a complete lack of flavor. Red appearance, nice head. Overall very very forgetable. My brother-in-law didn''t drink the half of it.
A lot better the second time I had it. Still nothing spectacular though. Caramel-chocolate aroma, medium bodied taste, clean malty finish.
Beautiful head, exceptionally nice looking in the glass. Slightly sweet smell. Disappointing taste and thin mouthfeel; very smooth but weak and watery.
From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center Denver 17/09/2010 Big fruit aroma. Bronze coloured fruity cherry flavour with a hint of dryness in an oak flavoured finish.

(Draught at GABF) clearish orange with few bubbles. Nose of tart cherry, honey, rainier cherries and lactic. Taste is very acidic, maple, cherries, acetic and lactic. Awesome apple cider vinegar notes, and pipe tobacco. Very tart finish, a bit thin and uncarbonated.

Sampled at GABF on 9/18/2010. This fruit beer/kriek pours a medium gold color from the tap. Medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity, cherry and tart. A medium bodied fruit beer/kriek. The malts are cherry and fruity, slightly tart. Slighlty funky. Nice carbonation. Good balanced. A nice American kriek. Mouthfeel si full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is fruity and tart. Earlier Rating: 4/10/2010 Total Score: 3.7 Tasted at the Triple Rock Sour Fest on 2/8/10. This sour beer pours a medium reddish color from a 750ml bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is cheery, tart and funky. A medium bodied kriek. The malts are fruity, tart and sweet. The cherries are semi sweet. Nice carbonation. Very smooth tasting. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly tart.
Super job on this. Funk aroma. Cherry flavor with funk aftertaste. Very well done!!!
(Sour Monday - Triple Rock) Bottled. Slight sour cherry-ness. Almost like a juice consistency. Very lightweight body. Red color. Just didn’t care for it.
Lactic sour light body light fruit light effervesence tang. No obvious flaws

OK, I really wanted to taste their cask conditioned peanut butter stout, but this was the funkiest that they had at the beer tasting. And funky it was, too. Great amber apricot color, not the brown or brownish red I expected from a kriek. Not as funky stinky as a lambic, but nicely sour, with a dry fruit offset, slighlt barnyard smell, good lambic finish. Lewis Thomas their brewer is very proud of the beer, and rightly so. But no one is allowed to like the smell of a lambic!
They did a great job getting the cranky nuance of a Belgian kriek. both sweet and sour notes are prominent.
Good stuff. Sour cherry and Belgian funk predominate. Solid cloudy red/orange, rocky tan head.

From old tasting notes. Translucent black, brown color. Creamy tan head. Sweet burnt caramel, cappuccino aroma. Bittersweet chocolate malt flavor. There is a hint of licorice and smokiness that lends to its complexity.creamy mouthfeel. A very good American stout.

17-Apr-14 (12-oz bottle, 2005 release: Obtained in trade with hopscotch, thanks Eric!) Drank a lot of Steeple Stout in the 90s when I lived in DC, one of my favorites back then. It’s still pretty solid. The beer pours a black body with a short, dark-tan head, fading to a ring. The roasty, chocolaty aromas are very pleasant and enticing, smelling moderately sweet. It’s really tasty on the palate, with prominent flavors of dark chocolate bar and cocoa, with lesser notes of coffee, tobacco, grilled meat, and cola. Light-medium sweetness is nicely balanced by mild, roasty, cacao-like bitterness. The beer is full bodied, medium in carbonation, and soft, smooth, and creamy in mouthfeel. Overall, this is such a perfect stout for me. It’s a little sweet, a little bitter, and a lot delicious. And talk about beautiful cellaring capability, wow!
Pours dark brown with a light brown head. Smells of roasted malt, spice, some sweet chocolate hints. Tastes dry and earthy with a roasty finish.

Deep dark brown coloured body with a subtle light brown head. Aroma of grapes, chocolate and light coffee. Medium to Full-bodied; Deep chocolate, coffee and roasted malt flavours throughout the taste. Aftertaste shorly follows with a pleasant sweetness, a good chocolate kick and somewhat of a bitter coffee taste. Overall, a damn good stout - no horrible tastes at all, just good ones! I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Norm’s in Vienna, Virginia on 04-September-2005 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.
Nice aroma, good color, ok taste. Full body with malt and a hint of caramel flavor. A bit on the tart side of things when it comes to taste.

Dec 2005 - Beer poured dark color with next to no head and lacing. Aroma of roasted malts. Taste was rich and full...roasty, sweet and even a nice, slightly bitter finish. Well done, esp. for the money.
Had on 9/15/1999. Aroma is a sweet malt scent. Color is deep and dark. Taste is a rich malty body with a roasted malt finish and good bitterness.

Name: Blue Ridge Steeple Stout Date: 07/23/1996 Mode: Bottle Source: Chevy Chase, DC black, no head, not much carbonation, rich sweet chocolate aroma, roasted chocolate flavor, roasted aftertaste Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Pours a medium black with a small head of tan bubbles. Smells or earthy malts, chocolate and coffee. Nothing out of the ordinary, just a very straight forward, drinking stout. Flavors are also of chocolate, balanced nicely with roasted malts and hops. Alcohol is just right, solid.
Good stout. Not too much alcohol, reminds me of an Australian stout like Sheaf, but with less molasses flavor. A very light body for such a nutty, chocolatey beer.

column1: Jacob Rosenberger & Son Germanic Style Dark
column5: From old tasting notes. Deep reddish brown. Tan head. Toasted malt nose . Malt flavor is thin and watery. Little hops to speak of. Nothing like the brews of Munich.

column1: Jacob Rosenberger & Son Germanic Style Dark
column5: WARNING, Not one of the 12 GREATEST BREW! I have to sample all 12, as my wife got this for me and with her not liking ratebeer as it is, I want her to think she did good. The thought counts.

column1: Jacob Rosenberger & Son Germanic Style Dark
column5: A novel idea. "12 greatest beers of the world". But, no, let's make a batch of amber, a batch of pale, a batch of brown and bottle it and put different labels on it. OK, not quite true, but The differences between these beers, even though said to be different styles was scary. Light amber color with an off white fizzy head. Acidic and bland.

column1: Jacob Rosenberger & Son Germanic Style Dark
column5: As with the rest of the beers from this sampler pack - this was terrible. The first thing I noticed about this beer while pouring it was the dead gnat that poured into the glass. I wasn''t going to drink it, but Dogbrick insisted that I try it. yuck. Absolutely terrible. More orange crap.

column1: Jacob Rosenberger & Son Germanic Style Dark
column5: Part of the "12 Greatest Brews of the World" sampler pack found at my local Wal-Mart. No matter what the label says, they refuse to be any other color than orange. This beer poured a dark orange with minimal head and lace (+ one insect). The gnat was the most interesting thing about this beer. Practically no aroma (maybe some malt) and I actually thought about putting more insects in the beer so it would actually taste different than all the other Old European brews I have tried so far. No such luck.

column1: Jacob Rosenberger & Son Germanic Style Dark
column5: Wet cardboard, and again dark as 7-up!!! this isn't even beer!.............

column1: Jacob Rosenberger & Son Germanic Style Dark
column5: Probably the best of the self proclaimed 12 greatest beers. They are all absolutely horrible. I suppose i knew that when brock picked it up from of all places, Sams club. The thing about all 12 of these brews is that they all are supposed to be different flavors, but they all taste the same. And really, would the 12 greatest beers actually have twist off caps. The only good thing is that we were hammered when we rated them, so at least our ratings are interesting.

Aroma; cellulose, malts, straw, grain. Look; off white head, clear pale straw golden body. Taste; mild malts, grain, paper, straw, and finishes thin. Feel; light body, normal co². Overall; as pale macro lager. [can @im hauslicher Umgebung] 33427
Bottle, golden with a fast-settling head and a corny and malty-sweet nose. Pleasantly dry-sweet with a light crisp-dry bitterness. Sehr typisch!

500ml bottle, BBE Sep 2018. Drank in my hotel room in Lauenau on 31st July 2018. Clear and bright golden pour, Snow White head on top. Nice hop based aroma and taste, dry and semi-bitter finish/aftertaste. Not to sure where the 'Spezial" comes in, but an easy drinking beer with nothing to offend anyone.
0,33l Flasche. Goldenes Bier mit kleiner Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht malzig, wird im Geschmack bestätigt.

Bottle: Golden, clear, medium-sized creamy white head; moderate grainy-strawy nose; mild to moderate sweet-bitter flavour, almost medium bodied, quite soft; slightly lingering sweetish-grainy finish with a slight tartness in the mildly bitter aftertaste. Down to earth Helles...
Bottle from Hannover hbf. Light gold with a frothy head. Aroma of fruity grain. Flavour is citrus hopand grainy malt, dry bitter finish.

500ml bottle. Clear, yellow-ish, golden colour with average, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Grainy and strawy aroma. Taste is minimally sweet, pale malty, minimally grainy, strawy and malt-spicy, slightly bitter hoppy counterpart; oily texture.
Eisgekühlt trinkbar. Wobei nicht zum Genießen, sondern eher als 5-6 Bier. Trotz Wässrigkeit eine unangenehm bitter, herbe, aber geschmacklose Note...

(bottle) clear golden colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of doughy malts and physalis, with some light notes of tobacco and some caramel. flavour is mostly floral hops and candle wax, with a light hint of dimethyl sulfide, some chalk and a light-bitter herbal-hoppy finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.

(Flasche) Es hat eine hellgelbe Farbe, ist blank filtriert mit einer weißen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist süß, getreidig, leicht würzig und etwas spelzig. Der Geschmack ist fast wässrig, spelzig, etwas harzig, kaum süß, prickelnd und ein klein bisschen bitter im Nachgeschmack

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Tap at the Del Mar race track. Pours a deep chestnut brown almost no head. Roasted malt, light bitterness, oatmeal, and 2 hour old Folgers coffee.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Tasted at the San Diego International Beer Festival. Dark brown with no head. Faint malty aroma. Sweet, chewy, sugary, chocolate taste with a roasty finish.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: On tap at Hamiltons. Pours with a black body topped by a thick brown head wtih a good amount of lacing. It’s sweet and full of coffee, vanilla and an artificial chocolate note (reminds me of Cocoa powder). Light bodied for a stout and smooth.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Tap @ La Jolla location. Pours dark brown with a nice cascading tan head. Caramel, cocoa, oatmeal, and hot fudge in the aroma. Sticky on the tongue, but overall more of a dry stout mouthfeel. Chocolate milkshake with malt, and some espresso in the taste. Dry finish. A nice, silky smooth stout.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: (Draft: Rock Bottom in Irvine, CA) Competent, but not outstanding, this beer is balanced, flavorful, pleasant, but still seems lighter in flavor than other oatmeal stouts; Strong dark roasted maltiness with only a moderate oatmeal flavor; Mildly sweet; Fairly bitter, but the bitterness is in balance and complementary to the maltiness; Hardly anything in the nose; Black and opaque, even at the edges; Huge, tall, tan head has great retention and good lacing

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Delectably delectable...i think! It pours a mean black hue with a thin scattering of orangey head which dissipates mighty quick. The aroma is choco-cocoa...! The taste...is more choco-cocoa, but it is just beautifully put together. Mocha, chocolate, cocoa and a hint of sweet coffee mixed in with more chocolate malt finish this dry beer. Nicely done indeed. I want more!

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: A voyage into the deepest blackness occurs upon visual inspection of this brew. Big ass chocolate in the araoma and continutues into the body of the beer, Damn impressive, just like a nice piece of dark chocolate. Most impressive.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Cask-conditioned draught: Dark brown, head bigger than the beer, nice nutty/chocolatey aroma, HUGE chocolate flavor and very sweet...The closest a beer can come to pure milk-chocolate

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Toasty bitter chocolate flavor with a hint of coffee. Sweet but with a thin mouthfeel. A solid stout.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Right on! Good to see this beer on the boards! My wife actually discovered and fell in love with this beer - we order it by the pitcher at the Irvine, CA location. Very tasty & smooth stout. Heavily leans towards roasted/burnt malts, bakers/bitter chocolate and cofee. BIG FLAVORS. Wouldn't exactly call it sweet, but certainly smoother than hoppy stouts and is bitterSWEET. When visiting SoCal - give this a try - its my fav local brewpub micro draught stout.
GABF '03. Golden color with mellow floral hop aroma. Sweet and sticky with nice bitter finish. Too light for my taste.
Good, hoppy/grassy aroma, cloudy bronz color with a nice creamy off-white head...HOPPY from start to finish, bitter aftertaste

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Pelican Red
column5: 7th Feb 2017: tasted on a flight at the source, then had a 20 oz pour as I thought it was their best beer (not difficult to be honest). Anyway it is a red beer and although it had a mild Rye aroma and taste I enjoyed it’s flavourings. Malty with a good hop bitterness late in the mouth. Cheap too (was Happy Hour).

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Pelican Red
column5: On tap at the brewery. Mild aroma, bit of hops and grist, caramel. Medium clear amber with thin lacing head. Medium body and carbonation. Starts medium sweet with nice caramel and crystal malt flavor. Strong hop character. Finishes nutty with medium bitterness - like an Irish pale ale. Bitter after.

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Pelican Red
column5: Appearance is medium darker head with a deep amber color. Aroma is caramel malt. Taste is malty, but with a floral hop punch. Overall pretty decent.

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Pelican Red
column5: A: The beer pours amber in color with an off-white head. S: Fairly citrusy up front. However, the hops quickly fade away and the malt takes over. Toffee and caramel malt notes with a decent breadiness. Just a little bit of grass aroma in there as well. T: Flavor starts off fairly hoppy, too. Orange and tangerine provide some nice citrus and there is a little bit of pine and grass. Toffee, bread, and caramel provide the sweetness, which is the bulk of the flavor of this beer. M: Medium in body with a moderate level of carbonation. O: Pretty good amber/red ale. Nice array of flavors and easy to drink.

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Pelican Red
column5: Clear copper color/ beige head. Leafy hop, caramel aromas. medium body. Fresh floral hop flavor with caramel, mild roasted nuts. not bad.

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Pelican Red
column5: On tap. Pours with a fully lasting off-white head and a hazy amber body. Aroma is sweet with caramel and light fruit. Taste is fruity, light rye and caramel. Lively bubbles.

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Pelican Red
column5: On tap a few weeks back. Color was a reddish/orange/brown. Aroma wasn’t too strong; some caramel and earthy/citrus hops. Flavor of brown/red malt, cocoa, and earth. An ok beer.

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Pelican Red
column5: The pour was a nice ruby color with a solid, two-finger off white head that created good lacing. The aroma was malt, spice, light hops. The flavor was light tart fruit, malt, spice and some dry hops. The mouthfeel was nice and the finish didn’t linger. Not bad.

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Pelican Red
column5: Very clear malt aroma a nice light red brew a tad dry on the finish may be due to the rye.

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Pelican Red
column5: on draft at brewery, consumed on 11/12/07. Crystal clear golden brown with no active carbonation. Head is thin skin of foam. No aroma to speak of. Tingly mouthfeel, but only a little generic "malt" flavor and some sweetness. No hops detected. Disappointing.

Keg at SBBC, 01/05/14. Black with moderate tan spotting and edgework. Nose is bitter roastings, light smoke, dark fruit rinds, light charr, liqourice. Taste comprises roast malt, tobacco, earthy cocoa, dark malts, toffee. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, drying close. Adequate stout, nothing worth returning to.
28 July 2013, tap at Santa Barbara Brewing. Black with thick frothy head. Nose is burnt malt. Thin body and creamy, moderately fizzy. Dark roasted malt, dark chocolate bitterness. Pretty good.
Draft. Pours almost black with tan head some coffee aroma. Taste quite bitter. Roasted malts. Hint of coffee. Medium carbonation. Just ok. Manta better examples around.
Pours brown black with no head Aromas of black malts, coffee Taste has coffee beans, tar, dark malts ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of their best ones in the sampler. Nice coffee and chocolate aroma, and dark black body. Good!
Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and caramel aroma. Roasted malty chocolate and caramel flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish.
Flavour is of dark, roasted bitter malts. Body is thin and watery. Quite a light flavoured stout.

Almost black in color with a creamy tan head. Roasted malt, coffee, and mild chocolate are the primary aromas to the beer. There’s a subtle earthy hop aroma and a mild cocoa powder note. The flavor is a bit on the watery side. Mildly bitter with roasted malt, coffee, cocoa, and earthy hops. There’s a fair amount of dark chocolate character to it as well. Watery feel on the tongue.

Served on tap at the brew pub while in SB for the wife’s 30th. The appearance is a typical brown black. The nose is roasted malt, with light chocolate notes. The flavors followed. Nothing special nothing terrible and average stout.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown to black with a small, creamy, tan and dense head. Aroma is dark roasted malt and with a note of liqourice. Smooth roasted malt base. Lingering dry roasted malt flavoured. Mild bitterness but dominantly roasted malt. Nice roasted lasting impression.

allright im drinking a hoptown nitro brown on the nitro tap. it is..pretty brown. a little red tint. i uhh give appearance of like a 4. in appearance. aroma is stinky a little chocolatey alittle muddy. little raunchy. aroma 6. flavor is water. watery bland. a little spice. little uhh got a little bitterness to it at the end its creamy though. flavor is a 6. andddd palate is like a 3. and oi is like a 14

On tap @ Hopyard poured a clear dark brown with a small creamy lasting head. Aromas of cocoa, roasted malt, hint of nuts and a hint of coffee. Palate was light bodied and creamy smooth. Flavors of cocoa, roasted malt, a hint of coffee and nuts with a smooth semi sweet finish.
tap. Dark brown with a huge frothy head. The flavor as well as the aromas are dominated by roasted malts and nuts. The body is more solid than most brown ales. Nice bitter sweet finish.

(Cask. 03/2006) This should probably be classified as its own, unique brew. It was awesomel. Served from the cask with natural, soft carbonation, this presented wonderful, grassy, floral hop aromas balanced by chocolate, roasted barley, and deep earthy aromas with hints of dried fruits. Some oxidation was occurring -- which just enhanced this beer over the several days it was available Wonderful chocolate and notes of burnt toast with fig/date preserves for jam, full-bodied, yeasty, nutty, wonderful.

On tap at Hop-Yard Pleasanton Aroma: some floral notes and Roasty notes in the nose Appearance: Pourced a nice brown with a nice off-white head which lingered for a while Flavor: Starts off with roasted sweetness and some hints of coffee and buiscuits Palate: Light in body. malt, roast and clean hop finish come in quick succession Overall: A very drinkable representation of an English Style Brown Ale
Nice balanced brown from "Crazy", Very English toasted mouthfeel, Clean And fairly dry. Some Cocoa and bread flavors with a touch of bittering hops at the end.
on draft Pizza Port San Clemente, CA Clear brown color, dry flavor, light body, nice roasty nose. It’s a very taste brown ale.

(Draft: Pizza Port in Carlsbad, CA) This is a very flavorful, enjoyable and well crafted brown ale; The main thrust of this beer, the moderately sweet, toasty maltiness, is delicious; There’s a fair amount of yeastiness, and a moderate hops bitterness provides good balance; Medium bodied with a good solid mouthfeel; Nice, toasty nose with sweet and mild hops aromas pretty much echoes the flavor; Deep mahogany color; Tan head looks creamy, with small bubbles; The head fades to a thin layer, but maintains that level; No lacing to speak of
Blackish with a disappering tan head, nutty and chocolatey, malty/burnt chocolate finish, Good stuff
I can dig it, but the label should definetely have a more truer representation of the name. Deep color of black with a hint of brown. A roasty nutt flavor with a side of chocolate.

On draft at Canyon Crown in Tucson. Light haze and copper hued with a nice smooth egg shell head. Good tetention. Cool layered lacing. As a west coast American IPA this is down the middle. A nice citrus hop nose first and then caramel malts. A creamy feel is nice. Balance is good. Some dry bittering hops stay long after each sip. Citrus flavor is nice. Grapefruit is soft. A hint of oranges and an oatmeal effect. Floral hops grow with warming. A fine IPA.
this was a litle too bitter and flavorless. I couldnt really get into it.
Light amber color with diminishing head and minimal lacing. A very good San Diego style IPA with nice floral aroma and nice bitter hoppiness. Glad to see these guys back up and running.

This IPA pours with an amber body topped by a thin to medium thick off-white head with a good amount of lacing. The aroma is sweet and slightly bitter and boppy with a nice fruitiness and a touch of pine. The flavor is slightly sweet and hoppy with lemony notes and a hint of pint. Slight notes of apricot are also noticed. Medium bodied, relatively smooth and dry.

Sampled @ Pizza Port Real Ale Festival 2003. Dark copper pour with a quickly diminishing head. This is pure piney/citrusy hop juice! Hopheads rejoice for this medium bodied libation is made for backyard bbqs and easy drinking. Strange sweetly bitter finish which lends to this beers uniqueness.
GABF 2003: Small white head on a hazy amber/orange body, resin aroma. Lively carbonation, bitter throughout. A solid IPA

Draft at brewpub. Golden amber color with with a small, creamy, white head. Hoppy aroma, but fairly light in the nose for a California IPA. Nice flavor, good malt up-front followed quickly by the hop bite. Lingering bitter finish. Medium body with light carbonation.

2/5/03: Had a sample on tap@On Tap! Poured a bright bronze with an average white head. A little hops in the nose. Start is sweet malt followed by the hop bitter finish. Aftertaste is grapefruit. Very nice IPA. 3/21/03: Picked up a growler@On Tap! and I’ll stick with my initial review. Outstanding session IPA. 7/25/03: It really grows on ya! This is my favorite everyday session IPA. 9/27/03: Congratulations to Chuck for a bronze medal@the 2003 GABF. 9/8/05: This beer has retired, but Chuck is now the head brewer at Green Flash and his West Coast IPA is even better !!!

Well it surely smacks you in the face with this establishment's namesake..HOPS! Great hop aroma permeating from the bronz depths...Hops out-power the malts.. but... In an IPA That is surely OK Bitter pineapple fruity finish

On cask. incredible amount of head for a beer engine pint. good looking beer, bronzish in color with big white head. the aroma was rather weak but when it was caught it was definitely citrussy northwestern hops. a touch of malt at first taste and then the hops began. the bitterness was well controlled, it did not get too out of hand but it was definitely there. left of bit of a tart finish on the back of my tongue. a decent IPA.
Fruity sweet caramel aroma. Taste is spicy with again some sweet and fruity notes

Refrigerated 0.5 L brown bottle poured into a English pint glass. Black with medium beige head. Aroma is caramel, medium body, lower carbonation, and good small-bubble lacing. Taste is caramel, chocolate, and a little subtle fruit (mostly plumb).
Love this Beer. The Brooklyn Choc Stout is surprisingly a little too sweet and sickly for me so this is a perfect Girl Brew :)

Ar: Fig, burnt sugar; ash and red wine grape. caramelized pineapple. Ap: Deep true brown, almost opaque; very small light mocha head, leaves a ring of thin, medium bubbles. T: Clean alcohol and lots of ripe pineapple and burnt sugar; sherry and nougat notes; coffee and slight fruit leathers; bitterness is medium-low; peppery booze on the finish; very peppery. P: Very firm body despite extremely low carbonation; finish is medium-dry. O: A really unique strong English ale; lots of pineapple and burnt sugar notes; rich and powerful, with a clean booze backbone.

Bottle from Sainsbury at Machester Piccadilly railway station. Poured dark brown with an average sized off-white to beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, light coffee, dark fruits and alcohol. Toward heavy sweetness, medium bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, average carbonation.
An old ale with sweet stout flavours. Forward alcohol and a nice colour and head. However it really wasn’t my thing.

Appearance: Very dark brown, almost black. Some light tan head. Aroma: Dark fruit, prunes, dark malt. Roasted. Taste: Dark malt, dark fruit, smooth. Bought: Sainsbury’s, 500 ml, GBP ?.?? Info: 1/1-2017, BB: 8/6-2018
Nice dark ale although a little overpowering its a good example of this genre ok

Superowe piwo. W starym dobrym stylu. Ciemna brazowa barwa niemal czarne prawie nie ma przeswitu. Bardzo niewielkie refleksy czerwieni. Piana o atramentowym odcieniu, puszysta i gruba, sredniej wielkosci ale bardzo trwala. Zapach likierowego alkoholu i goracej czekolady. W smaku na poczatku likierowa slodycz, cos jakby porto i polewa czekoladowo-krowkowa na ciescie w ktorym jest mnostwo borowek i jagod. A wiec spora mieszanka ciemnych granatowych owocow, deserowa czekolada i uderzenie alkoholu szlachetnego. Po chwili po przelknieciu posmak slodyczy powoli ustepuje a alkohol blyskawicznie ustepuje tworzac rozgrzewajaca koncowke z lekka nute chmielowosci i palonego slodu. Bardzo zlozone i ciekawe piwo.

500ml bottle from Sainsbury’s. Pours black with a three-finger beige head. Aroma: chocolate and fruity malt. Taste: chocolate, ripe dark fruits, malt, slight warming spice/alcohol. Rich and complex. Oily/creamy texture, soft carbonation, medium body. Lovely stuff.

The brewer's new description of this seasonal reads: "The Boxcar Brown Ale is a medium bodied ale with a deep brown color and a distinct bitterness. Not to be compared to an English Nut Brown Ale, such as Newcastle. The American Brown is an extremely young beer style developed in the 1970's by homebrewers with a love for hoppy ales. The Boxcar has a 5.4% ABV." I can vouch for the bitterness, which dominated my impression of the beer, but I only had a sample. If the beer is still there when I next visit Titletown, I'll give a pint a try.
Part of a sampler tray during a visit to Green Bay. Unfrotunately, this was a couple of months ago, and my memory is faint. Nice place to visit, All the samples were tatsty.

An outstanding summer brew, my best kolsch experience so far. If you're ever in Green Bay, check out this brewpub - it's in a beautifully restored railway station with a tower on the bank of the Fox River.
On tap. Reddish color with little head. Aroma of sweet malt, sugar, light strawberry. Taste is of sweet malt, sweet tarts, unripe banana. Alcohol presence is strong. a good example of the style.
Strong and sumptuous. I must say that I really like living near the Titletown Brewing Company.
Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Light bitter flavor. Short light bitter finish. Watery palate.
A: Clear gold with a small white head. N: Sweet malts. T: Slight sweetness and mild bitterness. P: Thin O: Well-balanced pilsner.

Can, Legacy LRS, Vancouver So, mine is called Martens, no Pils, no Premium on the can, just 5% and it's brewed with corn; so I'll park this one here for the moment; it's tagged 30/08/19 which makes me think it was packaged 8 months ago.
