The colour is blond, pale, clean. The aroma is mild, not too smelly; dry, crisp, but that corn pops up, it has a bit of stale cereal feeling, the bitterness is very low, and the finish is short. This is a no for me.
While in Bocholt... Sitting in the really cool Baazaar bar, within a few minutes of the brewery, I had to check the local beer. Nice, clean standard pils on a beautiful spring day.

Review is for Bocholt Premium Lager (an alias of Martens according to Rate Beer): Served from 11.2 oz bottle into pint glass. A 1" pillowy white head falls slowly with mild lacing. Color is clear gold. Abundant streaming carbonation. Aroma of toasted malt, yeast, and grassy hops. Mouthfeel is light and crisp with a dry finish. Flavor is well balanced between sweet malt grain and grassy hops. Really enjoyable.
Couleur dorée avec légère mousse. Nez leger malté, un peu papier et sucré. Gout malté sucré très aqueux avec notes paille et buvard, rien sur le houblon, ca une pils???
Aroma: Hay and fruits. Flavour: Fruity sweet with very little bitterness. Colour: Pale amber with a ehite head. From: Can @ Grocery Fanabe Tenerife Jul. 2018.

Can from Pemborong Wholesaler, Kuala Lumpur. Courtesy of and shared with Deanso. Poured a clear straw colour with a frothy white head and lots of bubbles. The aroma is grainy corn, cardboard, light woody hop. The flavour is moderate sweet, light bitter with a grainy, light dry woody hop bitter palate. Medium to light bodied with lively carbonation. Quite uninspiring.
33cl can from a KL night shop shared with Jmgreenuk. Medium white head. clear golden pour. An average pils.

Labeled as Bocholt Premium Lager - 11.2 oz Beck's clone bottle - thanks to Aurelius for the trade! Sparkling medium golden, nice bubble action, creamy snow white head, Hint of skunk in the aroma, a bit of grain and fresh lake water. Standard lager flavor, some grain, hint of honey sweetness, bit of a saaz hoppy bite, Crisp mouthfeel.
Cloudy orange colour with a thin white head. Malty, fruity aroma with a pepper spicyness. Malty, fruity and spicy flavor. Highly carbonated.
200 cl. bottle. Golden clear colour with a nice white head. Yeasty and aroma of homwbrew (diacetyl). Also flavour of diacetyl yeast and caramel - ends up quite bitter.
Bottle. A amber beer with a big white head. A yeasty, fruity and spicy aroma and taste, sweet. Medium body with a sweet finish.
Bottle. Hazy amber coloured with an off white head. Fruity aroma of spices and yeast. Sweet fruity flavour of spices, caramel and yeast.

Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense beige head. Has some fuirst and rubber notes in the aroma. Flavour is spicy and fruity. Is a bit citric. Meidum bodied. Is a bit old in the flavour. Has some fruity and spicy notes in the end.

Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a thin orange head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of oranges and spices. The flavor is sweet malty with spicy notes of cloves and oregano, combined with notes of fruit.
2L bottle. Pale amber coloured. Fruity aroma and flavour with notes of lychee and some unpleasant notes of rubber.
(Bottle 200 cl) Pours a hazy amber with a creamy, off-white head. Lightly spicy nose with some caramel. Medium-bodied, some caramel malt and accents of ginger. Bitter, hoppy finish. 120506

green-amber (?!) colour, fine head, buttery, caramel aroma with notes of blood, fresh, sweet and quite neutral flavour, short finish - a deception - this brewery, like most of the italian microbreweries, still has a long way to go
Tap at a Thai Restaurant in Regensburg. Bright gold with a tall head. Nose is grain and wort. Flavor worty, grainy, cardboard, light lemon. Rather lame stuff.
Clear golden beer with decent lager head. Aroma & taste: pure malts, light bready notes, hop hints. Light to medium body. Low to light bitterness.

500ml bottle from Beer King, drunk at home on a cool December evening. Pours clear with a thin fluffy head that didn't last, heavy lacing but no visible rising carbonation. Gold in colour. On the nose, soft biscuity malt balanced by hints of floral honey. In the mouth, a frothy texture at first, giving way to smooth, soft slick, oiliness, flavours similar to the aromas, medium bitterness, slight sweetness with a short, crisp finish leading into a metallic aftertaste. Overall, malty rather than hoppy, but soft in texture and crisply refreshing. Quite good for an uninteresting style.

getrunken zu Weihnachten 2016 Ich habe dieses Bier gleich neben dem "Urhell" der selben Brauerei getrunken und da hat es mich echt enttäuscht. Das mag vielleicht an dem ausgezeichneten Urhell liegen, oder an der leichten Geschmack. Es ist insgesamt eher langweilig und vielleicht als leichtes Bier zum Essen vorstellbar, aber zum Genießen gibt es bessere aus diesem Haus.
Bottle from bier-kaufen.de. Clear yellow colour, white foam. Typical helles, sweet, malty, bready, light bitter.

On tap at Bischofshof. Clear light gold with a white head. Aroma of wet malt, a little grain and floral grassiness. Tastes sweetish, a little bit of pear. Medium body, fine fizz, long finish with notes of pear juice.
Bottle. Golden color. Malty bready soft hay flavor. Just enough hop character, The aroma is not very outspoken. Medium bodied. Drinkable.
Один из лучших напитков этого стиля, что я пил. Я бы покупал его, как пиво на каждый день. Плотное, как раз в меру, вкусное пиво.
Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Starts mild, malty, modest dry. Light hints of lemon. Finish with some metallically notes, but still okay. Average.

(bottle) clear golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of floral hops, pale malts and fresh yeast, with a touch of lavender and dandelions. flavour is mostly the same, lots of honey-tinged pale malts and floral hops, with some notes of canned tangerines, bread dough and a hint of ethanol in the finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Amber ale, head not persistent. Nice malt aroma, candi and caramel. In the mouth, some malt, caramel, candi, very light roasted malt and liquorice, but without character. Ordinary palate.
16.9 ounce bottle. Pours a unclear copper with a thin beige head. Taste is of caramel, roasted malt, some hops and grass. Malt forward aroma. Has a decent body that ends a bit bitter. Not bad.
Tap@ bb. Clear light amber color with ivory head.  Mild floral, spicy caramel, fruity aromas. Medium bodied.  Mild floral hoppage with toasted caramel, burnt butter flavors----yikes

On tap at the brewery. Dark golden-orange appearance with a small dissipating head. Mild aroma of sweet malts and light bitter hops. Similar flavor, a little bland, not much going on. Light body with a smooth finish. It was OK.

Growler. Pours a clear brownish-amber with a white ring. Crisp aroma, yeasty and fruity, with malt, and grass. Sharp, crisp taste, of yeast, malt, grass, that starts a little watery and ends with richer malt. Lingering yeasty malt. Decent.

On tap @ Bull & Bush. Maybe orange? in color with a white head. Grassy hops, some toast, and a grainy sweetness. Candy sugar and vegetal hops on the aroma as well. Flavor is really quite sweet. Candied orange peel, grass, and vegetal hops. Bitter, papery finish.

Draft. Pours a thin, poorly retained off white head, over a clear, amber (SRM 12) body......nose is light toffee/caramel, slight hop resin.....taste is mild toffee/caramel, slight sweet, ending with a bitter resin, hop bite, that lingers.....mouth feel light of medium, astringent, carbonation low. The finish is very off putting and this is a rather simple amber. BJCP 6/2/10/4/6

On tap at the brewpub. Pour is hazy amber with a small white head. Cereal, bread, grain, light grass, light caramel, and malt in the aroma. Taste is very malty, bread, grassy, some light citrus, and straw with a light bitter finish. Light body with medium carbonation. Not a bad amber.
Caramel color, nice sticky foam. Sweet and a bit bitter. Taste not very deep. High alcohol punch.

Tap. Pours clear pale amber with a medium, fizzy white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is light biscuit and caramel malt, floral and pine hops with fruity esters. Flavor is malt forward with medium hops and bitterness, fruity esters and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Tap. Pours clear gold with thin, fizzy white head; short retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is cookie malt, floral hops, pears, apples, and light caramel. Flavor is sweet malt forward with light fruit esters and faint hops; semi-sweet finish. Light body, low carbonation, and low warmth.
Pours hazy yellow, aroma of mild yeasts and hops, taste to match, full mouthfeel, bottle.

July 3rd, 2015 - Enjoyed at Bull & Bush (a Denver institution in these heady days of breweries opening everywhere). A dark brew with a slight haze (owed in part to the chill) it also features a handsome head, with a bee-hive of bubbles going down a solid inch of the glass. The aroma is lightly malty, but the flavor is more signatory. Lots of bubble gum up front with raspberry and sweet grapefruits, followed by strawberry in the finish. The body is substantial enough to support the brew, too. Nice work from this lodestone of Denver's beer scene!

Enjoyed on tap at Aviators, Denver Airport. I honestly didn't expect an imperial English IPA when I read the name, but I also didn't ask. That's a "just go for it" kind of beer. A clean but dark caramel color pour. Thick tan cream cap head. A quite bitter earthy like constant on the flavor here. Bold and bitter hops jump out front. Bready, earthy malt with almost a spice to it in the finish. I could guess a little rye, but I think I'm wrong based on descriptions. Has that citrus peel like bitterness. Not too bad. It's before 9am and I'm on vacation. It's kinda hard for any beer to be bad at this point. Unique brew here. I enjoyed it.

At the pub with Audrie, Zach and Marissa, pours a rusty gold color with a very small white ephemeral head. Nose is mild citrus with descent pine and resin. Taste is hoppy with moderate pine and resin . Ends on hoppy redinous piney notes. Quaff Score 6 / 10.....6-3-6-3-12

Bottle from Foothills Liquors. Malty IPA, almost close to an APA, malts dominate the hops. Amber pour with soft creamy head. Aroma leans on the malt bills, as does the taste. Not a hoppy IPA by any means. Yet, tasty in its own right. If you like English, this one’s for you.

16.9 ounce bottle. Pours a orange copper with a thin beige head. Taste is of malt, hops, pine, resin and citrus. Hop and malt nose. Has a mostly full body with a bitter and dry finish. Drinkable and quite tasty.

16.9 oz. bottle, consumed on 12-20-15. Bottled 9/15/15. Pours an effervescent, clear, dark bronze with a moderate to large amount of beige head. Pretty good lacing. Nice looking beer. Juicy, malty aroma features scents of cotton candy, mango, and mineral water. Malty, boozy taste. Sugary, fruit-juicy. Apricot, toffee, and caramel flavors. Bitter in the finish. Medium body. Smooth in the palate. Acceptable but forgettable palate effects. My guess is that this is past its prime at a little over 3 months old. It’s definitely not bad but probably would have been better a couple of months ago. Between lack of bite from aging hops, the juiciness of the hops that likely have been present from the beginning, and the maltiness of the beer by the standards of the style, the beer simply is sweeter than ideal. Note: Seeing after the fact that this is a British-style IPA makes me think that the flavor effects I’ve experienced were intended and not from fading hops. Regardless, the flavors aren’t great.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours hazy copper with a fizzy white head. Tastes like bitter hops, grapefruit, some pine, dry toasted malt, and a hint of fruityness. Light/medium body and medium carbonation. Smells like caramel malt, grapefruit hops, some resin, and bready.
Tap: mild for an American but just right if it’s an English IPA. Wonderful aroma of citrusy hops with a smooth finish. Nice.
Bottle..Pour is gold with a white head..Nose is pine, spicy hops, bubble gum..Taste is some sweetness, grass, pine, spicy hops, fruits..

column1: Bull & Bush Big Ben Brown Ale
column5: 16.9 ounce bottle. Pours a reddish brown with a two inch tan head that lasts. Taste is of roasted malt, caramel, fruit, barley and some nuts. Similar aroma. Has a decent body that is on the lighter side. Overall, pretty good.

column1: Bull & Bush Big Ben Brown Ale
column5: Bottle from Libations. Pours light brown. Smells and tastes fairly sweet and malty. Has kind of a brown sugar / molasses thing going on that makes it pretty sweet. Solid flavor overall. Medium bodied with a solid mouthfeel. Nice beer.

column1: Bull & Bush Big Ben Brown Ale
column5: Notes from recent Denver trip: at Cibo on Boulder St. medium brown pour, creamy off white head. Nose is dark malt. Bittersweet. Middle is brown sugar, malt and treacle. Finish is sweet, maybe a little too sweet.

column1: Bull & Bush Big Ben Brown Ale
column5: tap@ bb.  Clear mahogany color with ivory head. Nutty, dark bread, dark fruit aromas.  Light bodied.  Mild medium roast, nutty, buttery flavors---could be better

column1: Bull & Bush Big Ben Brown Ale
column5: Draught at the Falling Rock Tap Denver. AROMA: chocolate, malts mostly, caramel? TASTE: light bitter, light sweet APPEARANCE: brown, no head MOUTHFEEL: watery, thin, flat. OVERALL: drinkable, but nothing special. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Bull & Bush Big Ben Brown Ale
column5: caramelly, malty, with a boozy bite. smells boozy with a malt notes. pours dark brown with a thin tan head. had a bottle pour in steamboat. average beer at best eventhough it has one many awards.

column1: Bull & Bush Big Ben Brown Ale
column5: From the tap, Aroma is malts a little chocolate, pour is dark Amber and brown, taste is malty gently roasted flavor profile, finish is smooth

column1: Bull & Bush Big Ben Brown Ale
column5: At Bull & Bush with Stephen. Pours murky brown bronze. Aroma is light caramel. Taste is bitter, caramel, thin cardboard flavor, watery.

column1: Bull & Bush Big Ben Brown Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery. Brown and clear with a light tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, bread and earthy hops. Similar flavor, mild sweetness and light bitterness. Medium body with a rich, malty finish.

column1: Bull & Bush Big Ben Brown Ale
column5: On tap @ Bull & Bush. Dark brown pour with a tan head. Water, fruity esters, and dirt on the nose. Some sweet toast, bread, and a bit of toffee. Flavor is just kind of bland, but okay. Toffee, bread, and toast. Dirt/earth, fruity esters, and water. Bland, but at least it’s not offensive.

Draught at My Brothers Bar. Low but lasting white fluffy head. Hazy dark brown body. Weak fruity malt caramel aroma. Highly carbonated berries spicy flavor with a fair amount of hops bitterness and a long finish.

16.9 ounce bottle. Pours an unclear copper with a thin beige head. Taste is of malt, caramel, some grapefruit, pine, resin and grass. Slightly cleaner aroma. Has a decent body with a slight dry and bitter finish. Easy to drink and enjoyable, but a little underwhelming.

Poured from a bottle into a Delirium Noel chalace. Pours amber with head and lace. Aroma of toffee, peanut brittle, malts. Significant carbonation and medium mouthfeel. Flavors of rich grains, grapefruit rind, minerals, malts. Overall decent for style.
Clear amber color with ivory head. Spicy caramel, fruity, yeasty aromas. Medium bodied. Nice spicy caramel, pit fruit, light toast flavors----smooth finsh__ good.
From the tap - aroma is hops hints of citrus, pour is clear Amber in color, taste is hops smooth and finish is slightly bitter.
Bottle into a glass. Pours deep copper/brown. Persistent off-white head. Aroma of light caramel, roasted nuts, sugar. Taste is the same...nutty, caramel, lightly bitter, hints of grass.

Deep copper, clear. Light beige head persists well. Aroma: Light cereal note-not unpleasant, moderate caramel, light toffee, aroma hops not really apparent. Flavor: Buttery medium caramel, low pleasant fruity esters, earthy floral hops flavor enriches, Has perhaps a hint of chocolate malt here. Has typical elements of ESB in pretty good balance - no real complaints here. Bittering level is right - bitterness lingers in aftertaste as does slight spiciness (hops). Improves as it warms and malty qualities come forward. Definitely worth a repeat for me (I love British beers in general). BJCP

Bottle. Pours a medium, well retained, ivory head over a slightly hazy medium amber (SRM 12) body.....nose is light cereal, mild toffee/caramel.....taste is moderate roasted grain, cereal, toast, biscuit, slight sweetness of a toffee.caramel, finishing with a moderately bitter, non American hop tone....mouth feel, medium body, minimal astringency. This is a fairly typical ESB, with all of the usual characteristics. It is a bit unclean. BJCP 8/3/14/4/7

On tap at the brewery. Dark gold appearance with an off-white head, mostly diminishing. Aroma of butterscotch, caramel malts, toffee and light bitter hops. Similar flavor, mildly sweet with an average body.

On tap @ Bull & Bush. Amber pour with a white head. Butter, toast, and candy. Plum, raisin, and more butter on the nose. Weird spicy hops and some BO. Flavor is so damn buttery. Sweet, sugary, and toasty. Plum, raisin, and spicy hops. Weird funk and grass. Blech.

Draught. Lasting head. Body is light yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (light bread), moderately hoppy (flowers), with notes of lemon and coriander. Flavor is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation. Quite light, as designed, but the aroma is fresh and pleasant, and the mouthfeel is quite nice.

Standard longneck, lackluster label. Definitely a strong lager aroma - malty and akin to Baltic, Russian and Soviet Bloc beers that I've had. Clear and specimen colored. Boozy, bocky, medicinal. Slippery mouthfeel with a cough syrup finish. I don't have anything very positive to say about this brew. Pak N Save, Albany, Auckland.
330ml bottle. Pours pale gold with a bit of haze. Not much but some alcohol on the nose. Not enough of "Nelson's finest hops" in here, too mild for the ABV. Disappointing.
Beer with gold color, medium body, medium bitterness, some foam in the top, soft carbonized, (bought a 50cl bottle at FreshChoice supermarket, Queenstown, NZ #647)(#5 NZ).
My favorite larger. A fantastic drink for the hot months, smooth and a little sweet. If you like wheat beer, try this.
I do not condone vioence of any kind, but this upped my friend Mat’s fightin prowess by +2
330ml bottle Hazy pale straw with little head. Not much aroma. Mild bitterness followed by a sourness which lingers. Not great.
Very light gold in colour, with a thin head. Aroma is malty and lemony. Sweet, boozy taste, with pleasant malty finish.
Another poor effort from Harrington’s. The only differentiation from their other lagers is the higher alcohol, which is painfully obvious. Very bland.

It’s hard to be nice about a beer that is only and just about alcohol hidden by malt sweetness, and you can buy that for a bout 1/3 the price in cans from Germany if you wanted. This isn’t good, and I’m not even sue that the name of the beer isn’t a hat-tip to beer to get smashed by. Oh and the brewer just changed the style to "Strong Lager" say no more.
330ml botte, from the comments an interesting history, far more malty than hoppy & hides the alcohol well, not too bad
On tap @ 75th Street. Brownish amber appearance with an off white head. Caramel, nuts, and amber malts in the nose. Pretty hoppy bitter, caramel malty flavor. I think the hops are a little overdone.
Tap at Blue Moose. Straight forward amber ale. Taste malt, little bit of silkiness in the end. Not too serious, but went nice with my burger.

Sampled on draft at 75th Street in KC. Pours clear, amber-brown with a thick white head and nice lacing. Aroma is one-dimensional: caramel malts. Flavor is slightly bitter with notes of plum. Good malt backbone. Quite clean and dry. Medium-bodied and lightly carboanted. A solid Irish-style ale.

Good amber ale. Nothing spectacular. They also serve this exact beer at Fenton’s and call it Fenton’s Aviator Amber Ale. It’s an average to above average amber ale with a little hoppiness to it. Slight citrus flavor to it makes it an enjoyable brew.

Very fine carbonation and head. Hazy orange-red color. Caramel malt aroma, with a tad of hops. Flavor is mostly sweet, caramel-apple maltiness, but there are some earthy hops for balance's sake. Light bodied. Some citrus and apricot are apparent here, too. Long finish. Very odd gaseous nasal passage-filling sensation, I suppose this is the carbonation? Most unusual effect.
Yeasty, herbal aroma with citrus. Sweetish, yeasty taste, with citrus and pear. A bit thin, but refreshing.

(bottle) slightly opalescent amber-brown colour with a quickly-diminishing off-white head. aroma of milk chocolate and dried cherries, with a hint of roasted grain, some faint floral hops and simple honey. flavour is more of the same, lots of dark fruit and gently roasted malts, with a faint touch of chocolate cornflakes and chestnuts in the semi-minerally finish. medium-bodied with soft carbonation. surprisingly well done!
Roasted malts and bread on the nose. Medium sweet, quite malty taste. Strong carbonation.

Pours brown from the bottle. The foamy beige crown soon fades. Nutty aroma with roasted grains and brown sugar. Quite nice actually. Taste is mildly bitter with mineral and fleeting metallic hints. Body is medium, carbonation prickly. Not bad overall.
Pours - guess what - brown with a beig head. Malty aroma. Taste is also more on the malty end, goes along with some spice bute on a very mild scale, thus very drinkable when you're thirsty.
13-07-18 // taster at Bierbörse Mainz 2018. Unclear darker golden. Some malt sweetness, minimal cara. Boring.

Bottle at Detlef's. Pours clear dark copper with off-white head. Aroma of plums, dark dried fruits, dark bread, some chocolate and smoke. Tastes slightly sweet with balancing bitterness. Medium bodied, slightly bitter finish.

Flasche 0,5l: Kastanienbraun, schwarz, glasklar, feinporiger Schaum; kräftig würzige Nase, kräftige Röstaromen, Röstmalz, Getreide, dunkles Karamell, deutliche Hopfennoten, dunkle/getrocknete Früchte; sehr würziger Körper, kräftige Röstaromen, Röstmalz, Getreide, dunkles Karamell, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, Hopfenaromen, fruchtig-würzige Bitterkeit; angenehmer fruchtig-würziger Nachgang mit kräftigen Röstaromen

13th May 2017: Hamm Bierbörse. On-tap .3 litre pour. Clear brown pour, thin beige head. Malty throughout with some interesting aromas and flavours, slight singed/smokey notes intertwine with everything too, complex and different: liked it.

Vom Faß („Schinner Braunbier“) in den Schinner Braustuben, Bayreuth. - Schönes Rotbraun, üppiger beigefarbener Schaum. - In der Nase angenehmes Karamel, Toast, etwas Nuß. - Antrunk sehr angenehm nussig-malzig mit der gewissen Tiefe, die ein gutes Dunkles auszeichnet. Mildes dunkles Malz, leicht fruchtig-hopfig und zart säuerlich abgeschmeckt. Erfreulich wenig süß, daher auch als Essensbegleiter geeignet (es gab Saure Rindernierla: köstlich!). Mild, sahnig weich im Mund. Im Abgang schön hintergründiger Hopfen mit Anklängen an Moos und milder Bittere. - Schönes, tiefgründig dunkelmalziges, süffiges Bier, das nur wie so viele Dunkle zum Ende hin ein wenig nachläßt.
Clear dark brown, tanned lacing foam head. Light smoky, caramle aroma. Light in taste, not outspoken. A gently beer to be enjoyed slow. (Velp 201611)

This is very much in the British pale ale style. Dark amber copper color, frothy white head. floral hoppy aroma . taste is somewhat between a pale ale and a ESB. malty and slighly sweet but with a good bittering hop presence. a good beer overall , far superior to Eki the other Basque beer commonly available

Rated on 9-28-2010. This bottled beer pours a huge very fizzy beige head with a short retention, hazy amber body, suspended carbonation, and no lacing. The aroma is caramel malt, earthy, grassy, and herbal hops. The taste is earthy, grassy, caramel malt, and lightly bitter. The palate is tingly and this beer is medium bodied. This is a beer that I will not drink again as it lacks character, no WOW factor and the flavor was very bland.

Another decent looking beer, but a bit of a let down after that. Aroma is flat, not much smell, but not funky either. Taste is malt with a bit of tang on the tail end (hops?). Slightly sweet and dry finish.
Poured light amber with white head. Minimal hops, light to medium body, smooth malt taste. Drinkable beer

12 oz. Dark brownish amber pour wih a tan head. Smell is traditional. Dominated by English yeast. HAs dark fruits, some mustiness, dustiness, slightly tart aroma. Malt and hops are mild and add a backing to the yeast. Th flavor tart and fruity, lots of berries, medium to low bitterness, yest is there but milder. Not bad, but perhaps a bit sweet and tangy.

12 oz bottle pours a hazt brown with a fair off-white head and some lacing - looks liked iced tea. Aroma is full of wood, test, vegetables and hops -kind of weird, but not bad. Has a woody.nutty taste with a slightly bitter finish. Body is thin to medium. My rating would be higher if I took into account the bargain price of this one: about half of what others on the same shelf cost. The best $4.99 6-pack I’ve enjoyed in years.
Pours cloudy tea-brown with an equally ice tea-like bit of foam on top. Scent is caramel, toffee, malt....bread. Taste is a slight bitter wood, caramel.....nutty More like a brown ale. Pretty tasty.

Hazy, deep amber and brown coloured body with a thick, rich, dense, long-lasting tan head. Aroma of soap, caramel, apricots, pears, apples, toffee, light hops and a bit of malt. Medium-bodied; Assertive pear, apple and fruity flavours with a hint of caramel, toffee and a bit of earthiness on the back end. Aftertaste shows some sweetness, a lot of earthy and bready malts with a little hit of low alpha acid hops with a faint bit of soap at the very end. Overall, an okay english pale with more emphasis on the complexity than the hops or malt, but the flavours match up fairly well, just the complexity in this seems to be a deterrent from a typical beer of this style. I sampled this 12 ounce bottle purchased from Oliver’s Beverage in Albany, New York on 18-November-2011 for US$2.15 sampled at home in Washington on 27-November-2011.

Nice aroma of yeast, bread, wood, and a little caramel. Unfortunately, after a promising start the taste disappoints. Weak, watery, somewhat vegetal flavor. Probably OK with food, but doesn’t really stand out on its own.

12oz bottle 8/9/11 (Binny’s Naperville Singles Rack)-46° in English Pint-Pours a murky amber with a huge fizzy tan head that gushed everywhere. Aroma of malt, caramel, toffee, and light hops. Taste of the same. This medium bodied brew must be old as it is super carbonated. Still not bad. May be infected.

frothy white small head. clear orangeish-brown body. MD. aroma: wood, caramel, moderate malty, date. if and ff: moderate sweet light bitter; lng duration. palate: medium body, watery texture, medium carbonation, metallic finish. sabor caramelizado demais, fugindo ao estilo. gosto de damasco diferencial. 35s
Tap at the brewpub, Copenhagen. Hazy orange colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of yeast, wheat, banana and spicy notes.

Draught at the brewpub in Copenhagen. ABV 5.2%. Cloudy yellow beer with a rich lasting head. Malty caramel aroma, citrus, hay, grapefruit, wheat, banana notes, some bread. Yeasty fruity flavor, banana, spicy, caramel, citrus, pear notes, hay, some pepper. Creamy palate and with a fruity spicy finish.
From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is estery and light fruity. Medium dry and herbal estery finish. Bitter and dry.
Draught at the brewpub. hazy yellow coloured with a medium sized white head. Sweet and fruity aroma of spices and cloves. Sweet and fruity flavour of spices, hay and cloves. Spicy finish.

2013 version at 5.2%. Draft. An unclear yellow beer with a lazing white head. The aroma has notes of wheat, bananas, peaches, and bread. The flavor is sweet with notes of wheat, bread, bananas, and twards the end also cloves, leading to a dry wheaty finish.

Draught @ Bryggeriet Sct. Clemens, Kanikkegade 10-12, 8000 Aarhus, Denmark. Unclear - hazy medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, wheat, moderate yeasty, fruity, butter. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average to long duration, fruity, yeasty, spicy, citrus. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20120908]

On tap at Sct Clemens. It ours a hazy yellow-orange body anda big, dense, off-white head. It’s lightly acidic on the nose, making me think it’s nit only the regular weissbier lemon showing up. Some wheat, but not much of the usual banana, cloves and bubble-gum. Lemony acidity on the flavour with some pale malts underneath. Quite tart on the palate, medium body and lightly effervescent. Lemony and orangey finish. Sure drinkable, write refreshing as well, but definitely not my idea of a weissbier. 120820

At St. Clemens, Aarhus, DK. Tap, 130712. Hazy yellow with white head. Aroma of banana and wheat. Flavour of cloves and spices. Earlier Rating: 4/30/2008 Total Score: 2.9 Bryggeriet Skt. Clemens, Aarhus, DK. On tap. Banana and hospital notes. Some sweetness but refreshing

@ Sct. Clemens. Cloudy yellow with a big white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, banana, yeasty and spicy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry finish. Higher carbonation than normally for a hefeweizen. 220510

Draught at the brewpub Sct. Clemens in Århus Cloudy blond color. Weissebier aroma, spicy, but also some smoke. Dry and weak mouthfeel; simple weizen character, with light sourness. Dry final, bitter enough. Not very good.

The Canadian version of a cervesa/ corona style beer. The last time I had this little gem was I think the summer of 97. It was sold out everywhere at the time. I liked it better than Corona actually. My tasted have changed quite a bit since then.
Very sweet and bland in aroma and flavour. Clear golden with fizzy white fully diminishing head. Light, watery body with fair carbonation. Not offensive but very, very bland. Entered from notes.
One of the worst beer i ever tasted. A la Corona style but not as good. Very pathetic stuff. Dont try it.

Travelling through Quebec on a hot summer day my wife and I stop off to buy some beer. There's a nice selection in the the store and my wife says "oh this looks like Corona, let's get this" So, yes, it does resemble Corona, but just not as good. Is this the same stuff sold in Ontario as Brava??
(Bottle) Remember it stating 4.9%ABV not that it would make this beer tast better. Pathetic beer. Much like the brewer - Lakeport. Who'd want another Corona knock-off...
Yellow color, some lace. Fresh sugary fruit (apple) aroma. Faint hop presence in the body, finishes very dry. Nothing new here.

Total shit. On this special occasion of reviewing this sewage i actually disgraced my glass by dumping in this garbage. Monster blinding white foamy head probally caused from 355ml of beer hitting the glass in less than a second. Smells bad, tastes bad and very empty - just like any other less than low quality S. American beer brewed in a plastic pail. Almost invisible in colour, this is a harsh stinky grainy beer that even a lemon or a pail of sand couldnt help. Unfourtunatly it’s drinkable, but barely AND I didn’t flush it - it’s not bad enough to be flushable. 138% unsatisfying. I’ve said too much. Total waste of money. Stupid bottle collection.

From the beers of the world box. Do all these SABMiller Central and South American beers come from the same tanker truck and simply have different labels. As usual, light yellow, no head, and the aroma of corn. Watery mouthfeel. No flavor to speak of and a bland finish.

12oz bottle from trader Joe’s. Yellow with a thin white head that quickly dissipates. Light, skunky and veggie aroma. The flavor is almost non-existent and a little off in general. Quite watery stufff. The bottom of the barrel for Central-American stuff. I’ve got the light version on deck though so...

Pours a banana yellow with a small, fizzy head. No aroma detectable. Flavor is almost non-existent. This must be the MGD of Latin America, judging by the fact that the absolute minimum of the lowest quality ingredients were used. Pass on this. Overall, poor+.

Bottle out of the Beers of the World multi-pack from Cost Plus. Do all pale lagers from Central America taste the same? Gold in color with a slight bitter finish. This is what I would call a beach beer. Great on a warm summer day. I just rated Caballo and it tasted almost exaclty the same.

Has a poor aroma with very little to greet the nose and no hops or malt. The color is a very light yellow almost nonexistent and the head goes away as fast as you pour the beer and is white. Flavor is bland absent of any malt or hop charateristics.

One of the burdens of RateBeer addiction is buying crap beer because, hey it might be a new country, then logging on and finding out that not only is not a new country, but you already had three crap beers from that stoopid country. Arriba is from the SABMiller production line in El Salvador that brought you Cantina and Cabana. Judging by the pictures here on RateBeer, they all come in the same Corona-inspired clear bottles and have fairly similar ABVs. A look at the brewer’s page confirms that the Cerveceria La Constancia spits out dozens of these lagers with vaguely exotic names, which means at some point in the future I’ll find myself buying Tocayo or Bareno or Caballo because hey, it might be a new country. Arriba, funnily enough is remarkably similar to Cantina and Cabana. It smells like the interior of a new car with lots of factory-fresh vinyl and three tyres on fire. The dog in the backseat has been for a swim and wet himself when he realised the car was on fire. There’s a sheep back there and it hasn’t been sheared in... oh... at least three years, so the lanolin is ripe. The beer tastes heaps better than it smells. So does toe-jam. It’s one of those malt-and-hop-free lagers that appeal to people who don’t much care for beer unless there’s something else in it to take away the bitter taste. Corona drinkers. Shandy drinkers. Fortunately, SABMiller has done most of the work for them. Good old SABMilller. I look forward to buying Carriba, Carena and Tocata in the near future. Soon as I’ve got rid of this nasty smell. (355ml bottle from Liquor on Parade, KIngsford. Best Before May 09 or ideally never)
Bottle: Clean, crisp, slightly hopped. Medium body and refreshing. Typical Pale Lager.
An outstanding beer; excellent taste and hop aroma; clean finish; very good foam character

Soon as I sighted the faux Corona bottle and gaudy pyramid on the front I suspected this would be bad. I was not disappointed. Tastes of corn fired cheap alcohol. Had no head at all. Difficult to discern any hops at all in this. I’ll even drink VB over this. Awful.
Sweet and malty aroma and taste. Some fruitiness (pear). No hopbitterness. .

Cask, half-pint at Olde Dolphin Inne. Amber-gold body, next to clear. Ring to the rim of the surface. Poor lacing. Malt-fruity nose, sweet. Jam-like taste of caramel, forest and dried fruits. On the sweet side of bittersweet ending. Standard Brit bitter (Derby 21.02.2016).
Fra fat på Olde Dolphin i Derby 21 Feb 16. Gylden. Lavt tett kritthvitt skum. Lett plommearoma. Smaken uvariert. Svakt syrlig papp. Tørr ettersmak. Kanskje hint av karamell underveis.

Cask at the Eagle, Cambridge. Golden, clear. A bit of white head and loads of lacing. Smells of light orchard fruit, wildflowers and a bit if cleaning fluid. Taste is malty malty malty and sweet. Only a bitter-sour note in the watery short finish. An average and somewhat boring bitter.
On cask at Black Lion, Consall Forge. Pours amber with white head. Quite a malty session bitter, decent enough.

Another ’samey’ beer from Cottage: they produce hundreds (or so it seems) of brews that look, smell and taste very similar, this sits nicely within that range. Nothing wrong with the beer, it just doesn’t need a new name every time they brew it! Maybe I’m being unkind, because I’ve had some great beers from this brewery over the years. Anyway, this is a bog standard session ale and more than OK in all aspects, slightly more hoppy than malty, a well practised blend that works well for the brewery.

Cask at the Bird in Hand, Knowl Hill. A hazy pale amber pour with a loose white head; fruity aroma; very thin with a diluted fruit squash taste - so dilute in fact that it wasn’t possible to decide on what the fruit actually was; and a lacklustre biscuity finish. Not the best bitter.
Copper amber in colour without a head. Has an easy drinking texture but lacks any character. Maybe the slightest of fruits in its aroma.
Cask, The Crown, Nuneaton. Dusty gold, not much head. Heavily buttered aroma. Buttered sultana flavour, honey. The customary blandness. Very tired but drinkable.

Cask conditioned handpump Great Eastern Brighton. A brown beer with an off-white puddle of head. Too warm, malty and blighted with a little diacetyl. Sweet caramel notes. Tastes chewier than it should. Not the best.
Cask@Kitty´s, Helsinki. Poured slightly hazy amber color with a soapy white head. Slight malty and fruity aroma, melon. Flavor is fruity and quite hoppy, with a bitter finish.

Cask at the William Webb Ellis, Twickenham - 07/09/12. Mid chestnut brown with a white head that soon dissipates. Aroma of malts, toffee, dark fruit. Tastes of sweet caramel, biscuit, malt. Medium body, low carbonation and a bitter dry finish.
Cask at the Crispin, Wokingham. Dark reddish copper in colour with a thin cream head; red fruit aroma; sweet with red fruit and apple flavours predominanting; then a dry, malty, finish.
A - caramel and some fruit A - dark gold with dense head T - sweet with floral bitter P - mid and soft O - decent

Cask. Rated on 20110720. Pours amber with white head. Aroma is toffee, orange, apricot and malts. Flavour is toffee, orange, some citrus and a bit caramel. Slightly hoppy , smooth palate and a bit bitter at the end. Balanced 3313
cask at the bow ... copper ... creamy light tan ... soft toffee malt nose ... dull toffee malts ... light hop .little woody chocolate

Half-pint, handpulled from cask@White Horse on Parsons Green, London. A layer of creamy beige bubbles, covering a misty, dark brownish-amber body. Inviting caramel/toffee nose. Herbal hop notes. A refined soft caramelly sweetness in the flavor. Mildly hopped , some earthy bittering is noticable. Creamy mouthfeel. Sweetish caramel finish. A pretty good one with an inviting caramel aroma and flavor.

Cask at Green Man, Stamford, Lincolnshire. Dark amber with a white head. Curious aroma combing chocolate malt and just a little vinegar. Effect is not displeasing. Dusty slightly metallic taste with that taste of lint that often creeps into herby beers. A little bitterness.
cask. sopper body, white head. Fruity yeast aroma, some bitterness from hops and alcohol, too. Roasted malts. Thin, medium bitter, maybe watery. Sweet has burned candy, yeast and some hops.

Cask (HBF2010) 6 Very raw hoppy aroma, a touch sweet 3 Rich orange, but flat 6 Too hop dominated, and the malts are worty. 3 Raw hoppy finish 10 This is either way way way too young, or the brewer doesn’t know what to aim for. (And I’ve had his other beers since - he does know what to aim for, so this must have been underconditioned.) Rerate: Cask (St. Urho’s, Helsinki) 6 pungently hoppy aroma, quite earthy 4 deep orange, small loose head. 6 simple sweetise body. nettley retronasals, some undergrowth. bitterness and caramalt in good balance. 4 Low carbonation, soft palate. finish dry bitter, barky and musty. 13 competent bitter. weak in the mouth, but finish is more impressive.
Cask@HBF 2010. Pours amber colour with a next to no head. Aroma is swee, bread. Flavor is rye mostly and dark fruits. Quite bitter finish. OK ale.

Cask at the Fitzrovia. Dark orange/brown, still, hazy, small scummy off-white head. Aroma is twiggy toffee, chemical astringency. Body is medium, smooth, low carbonation. Taste is rounded malt, wholemeal bread, light treacle, a little astringent, soft bitterness. Some pleasant subtle flavours and very drinkable. Good beer for the season.

Cask at the South Western Arms, St Denys (So’ton) - 09/09/12. Light chestnut brown with a small off-white head that soon thins. Dark malt dominates the nose allied to a little smoke. Malt dominates the taste, fruit undertones. Not a lot else to report! Medium bodied, low carbonation lending to a bitter finish. File under ’W’ for whelmed!

Birthday Feathers’ Owl-Drawing Crawl, cask handpull, Cock and Hoop, Nottingham, 30/07/12. There’s no escaping Cottage. Generous-lacing, dirty copper clouded at the edges. Metal-rubbed berries aroma, coinage. Typical yeasty sesame and red berry Cottage with an added lick of copper. Overly metallic. Tweak of nut. Like the other beer in this pub, didn’t finish.

Cask@The Pineapple, London. Amber coloru, small white head. Aroma is fruits, wood, floral and a bit leathery and caramelly notes as well. Flavour is fruity, wooden, caramelly and mildly earthy. Brilliant pop-in with 4 of the 5 casks being new for me!

Cask at the Lyndhurst, Reading. Mid-brown with a scummy off-white head; aroma of apple and fruity malts; apple flavours too, with well-balanced lightly roasted malts; and a biscuit and toffee finish. Refined and elegant.

Cask Conditioned at The Bree Louise, London
Mahogany color, thin creamy head and nice lace. Good caramel aroma. It has a solid caramel flavor, followed by some chocolate and a hint of fudge that qualifies it. More chocolate and correct bitterness at the end. Good.

[cask handpull at Lyndhurst Arms, Reading] c7 Fairly dark for a bitter, medium creamy head, some sediment. Smooth creamy mouthfeel, lots of malt, a little chocolate, earthy bitter finish. Went down easily, but pretty unmemorable.

Cask handpump @ Allied Arms, Reading RG1, England. Clear medium amber color with a small, frothy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, toffee, notes of peat. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (010508)
Cask at The Priory Arms, Stockwell. Pours copper with a small offwhite head. Nice flowery toffee aroma. Solid bitterness, quite earthy, but with hints of lemon. Not much carbonation. A solid bitter.

A well hopped red-brown coloured ale, it is fruity with a chocolate aroma. There is malt and chocolate in the finish. On tap as a guest at The Oakhill Inn, Fosse Rd., Oakhill, BA3 5HU Somerset. 30-03-08

Cask at The Quantock, Bridgwater Sept 2015, rating from historic tasting notes. Pours clear mid amber golden with a white head. Aroma: malts, floral, straw. Taste: light sweet & moderate bitter, dry, sweet biscuity malts, some citrus, herbal hop. Light to medium body, soft carb, dry bitter close. Uninspiring

Cask at Swan, Farnborough. There is a something there - a hint of a floral aroma. Pale gold - almost hazy. Good creamy head, although it does develop an sickly blotchyness. A vague umami taste. Bitterness comes through in larger mouthfulls. Nearly medium in body. Oily. Carbonation. Long finish. Bland.
Cask@royal brittania, Ilfracombe. Golden beer with medium head. Aroma of malts and yeast. Taste is yeast, sweet, malts and some lemon. Decent.

Cask at the Green Man (GK), opposite Gt Portland St tube station, London. Pours golden with an average white head. Aroma of fresh hop, straw, light citrus and a touch of spice. Medium sweetness, light bitterness. Towards medium body, light/creamy texture, average carbonation level. Finish is sweeter, slight bitter fruit. Not bad.
Cask at Abbey Inn, Leek. Pours golden with a white head. Quite a sweet malty bitter. Not great.
Cask at the Pineapple, slightly hazy gold with a lacing head, malty nutty nose, initially dry-sweet malty body is rapidly overwhelmed by an acrid bitterness.
Slightly dusty hazy appearance. Quite woody aroma. Deep orange honey colour. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask at the Hole in the Wall, Waterloo. Flattish, citrusey but didn’t particularly enjoy the hop character and largely uninspiring.
Pint from the Three Horseshoes, Waddington. Deep gold colour with white head. Slight funk aroma, with a bitter aftertaste.
From cask. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild herbal toasted malty. Bitter, toasted and light herbal hoppy. Dry andslight bitter finish.
I sampled this one for a couple a years ago when I just turned 20. I do remember that I didn't like this one . Sweet flavour, notes of rice. Quite sour. Watery, chemical finish.
I can't add much more than what was already said...except it definately tasted stale.
Smells like washing-up liquid, tastes like water. Is it dishwater?..........
A clone of a lousy beer made by an even lousier brewery. ...................
Bottle. This was ok for a session beer. Primarily dry malt flavor, with hops at the end. Dry malt, early. Some hops at the end. it goes down easily, even if it doesn't push the style description.

Bottle to mug, the appearance was a murky amber color with a fingers worth of white foamy head that slid off at a decent pace. Some light lace. The aroma had some roasted malts, light nutty sweetness, some toast, light floral to herbal quality and then some dried leaves. The flavor was moderately sweet through the prior mentioned aromas to carry over in the aftertaste and finish. The palate was between light and medium bodied with a fair sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine and light. ABV felt right. Overall, seemed like a decent Irish red ale worthy of more pours.

Bottle in trade/share with Mr Cunningham cons 2016-06-18 Göteborg USState #37 AR: caramel fudge, wee nutty perhaps almonds AP: nutty amber clear, wee white head F: oily, roasted malt, nutmeg, fudge, sweet and dry, medium + bitterness,

Clear nutty color with a fine off white head. Good intensity in the aroma. Medium + body and a fine carbonation. Tad sweet and a fine bitterness. A bit oily texture. Bready, pine, fruity and hoppy flavor. A quite nice and tasty ale. [Bottle from a trade with Meilby] Brewery #1453

Another brew in the mediocre brew mass purchase made for guests who drank none. Reddish pour small head. Nose is herbal and brown sugar. Tastes of toasted malt, brown sugar, caramel, herbal, light red fruit, and that’s it. Semi sweet palate.
Amber color and mild hoppy aroma. Standard red taste, a little watery. Decent red but nothing special. On tap at cask fest.
Bottle. Pours caramel brown with a thin off-white head. Aroma of caramel, bread and mild nuts. Flavor of toasted malts, caramel, grains and had some nuttiness.
Bottle. Dark copper. Dominant caramel malts and some dark fruit. Interesting choice for a spring release but, very solid all around. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught @ Taproom, Coastal Extreme Brewing Company, Newport, RI Pours clear amber with a small off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, nuts, caramel, malt dust and hint of chocolate. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long malty, nutty and caramel finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. It’s more like a brown ale but still very nice.

On tap at the taproom. Almost clear in the glass, dark amber in color and with a small, dense, beige head. Nutty, earthy, roasted aroma with a nice fruityness and a piney touch. Coffee hints. The flavor has a nice bitterness, it’s dry and medium to full bodied and a nice carbonation level. Roasted malts, bread, nuts and coffee hints. All lasting for a good while. Pretty wonderful this one, would go well with burger, cheese, pizza and lots of other good food. 150607
Wickenden Pub. Pretty average with a bit more alc. than it needs. Would like this a little mellower.

12oz bottle in a shaker. Pours light copper with a thick, cream-colored head. Aroma of caramel and lightly nutty malts with floral and light citrus hops. Flavor about the same. Average texture. A decent beer.

On tap at the new brewery. This is the fourth out of four samples the poured as part of the tour. The pour some good sized samples here! As for the beer... the aroma and flavor of the Cascades are well noticable having brewed with them often. Distinct citrus and spice notes. Color is a medium orange-yellow. Crisp, slightly sticky finish. Would not be my first choice on a hot summer day, but otherwise a well-made IPA.

355 ml bottle. From Newport, RI. Clear amber colour with small to average sized white head. Caramel malt sweetness and exotic fruity hops in tempting aroma. Bitter citrus hops, lingering American hops, grapefruit and some maltiness in deliciously balanced flavour. Excellent tasty IPA. Very good for a Summer Ale.

The citrus aroma jumps right at you. Loaded with hops. Has a very thin head and the color is a deep copper. Very active carbonation. Has a citrus sour taste. A mild bitter aftertaste. One of the better IPA’s I’ve had as and I’m not a huge fan of the style to begin with and this one isn’t too bad.

Color is dark clear caramel brown. Very bubbly with very think foamy white head. Aroma is of grapefruit and piney hops. Taste is the same as aroma, however more piney hops follows thru the sip, leaving a bitterness in the finish and the mouth dry. Not a fan. Not what I think of when the label says “Summer Ale”. Very disappointed to find out that it was an IPA.

12 oz bottle, purchased @ Nikki’s Liquors in Providence, RI. Hazy orange in color. Thick full, fluffy head. Good retention and lacing down the pint glass. Smell of malt and light citrus hops. Taste follows the nose. The front end of the sips gives piney hops leading to light caramel malt in the background. Medium body. Minimal bitterness in the finish. Very mild, light and smooth. Some good drinkability. I actually like this IPA. And it was unexpected for an summer ale.
This is different then most summer ales. When I think summer ale I think of wheat beers, but this is full ipa with a fair amount of hops. Out of bottle.
Moderate hop aroma with a light amount of malt. Clear orange color with a small white head. Sweet floral hop beginning with a sharp bitter finish.

Draft on block island. Pours a light copper color with a small off white head. Nose is hoppy and bready, floral hops. Palate is medium with a refreshing light carbonation. Flavor is citrusy with some bready notes and a refreshing finish.
Recipe: Take 0.3 liters of the worst chemical swill you can find, for instance Arboga 5.6. Add 0.2 liters of tap water. Now, enjoy...

12oz bottle thanks to obguthr, pours a semi hazy orange/golden with a small white head. Meaty, almost smoked malt aroma, grain, with a German hop spice. Sweet, corn, malt and grain, slightly astringent bitter hop spice. Decent, but could be more balanced and smooth.
Bottled. NIce golden pour. White head. Hints of grassy pilsner and hops. Not bad pilsner.
Hazy golden yellow pour with a white head. Weak aroma of grain, lemon, and malt. Grain and lemon flavor. Decent body and flavor. Would drink again.

On draft at Whole Foods in Alexandria, VA. The beer is transparent and bright golden with a half inch of pure white head. Aromas of grain, earthy hops, malt. Pale malts and grain. Decent flavor, but could be cleaner tasting / feeling. Some nice aromas and tastes, but basically, a middle of the road pilsner. This was ok.

Poured from bottle into pilsner glass. Pours a medium gold color with 1 finger white head. Leaves a bit of lacing on the glass. Aroma is a little biscuit and a touch of citrus. Taste is crisp and clean, lightly bitter. Going down very easy with Chinese food.

Pour is a hazy golden with an average white head. Aroma is a decent pils malt with sweetness in there. Flavor again starts out with the pils malt but then kinda gets syrupy. Finish is dry and cracker malty. Would have gotten a better review if not for that secondary thick syrupiness.

Aromas are floral and biscuity. Appearance is pale golden with white head. Taste is clean, with subtle bready malts and light bitterness. Palate is crisp, light-medium bodied, with low carbonation and a clean finish.
Pours clear gold with a sticky, long lasting white head. Very little aroma. The flavor is lightly bitter and crisp.
12oz bottle pour into pilsener glass. Light hop bitterness. Fresh, smooth, flavorful. Finishes with touch of honey.

Poured slightly darker than an average pilsner; golden yellow in color. Thin white head that dissipated quickly with little lacing. Aroma has typical grain notes, with a faint whiff of honey. Taste is crisp and somewhat bready, with a lemony note.
Cask Stillage at the Community Centre, Frodsham 25/05/2002 Golden colour. Poured lively. Very bitter hop finish.
Sampled cask conditioned. Nice big citrusy hop aroma. Rather sweet and resiny with light mouthfeel. Hint of toffee and pine needles. Really bitter finish. A hop dominated ale.

Cask conditioned handpump Buckingham Arms Shoreham An amber coloured beer with a whitish head and lacing, Served too warm and with fizzy vinegar notes beyond the fruity taste. Similar in the nose although the vinegar is shrouded a little. Poor

As Wem ... Cask at Bow Bar edinburgh ... copper .. thikc creamy white head ... sweet toffee malts nose ... very sweet ... very fruity ... some cherry ... a little honey ... a little woody ... some pine resins ... real deep flavour ... sharp bitter bite at back.

Cask Stillage from the Outside Bar at Ye Olde Dolphin Inn, Derby 27/07/2007 Sour fruit aroma. Amber golden coloured and hazy with a sour fruit flavour. Slightly acidic. Some bitterness in a dry finish.

A Mes rate: Gravicask up the Junction. Amber appearance with a thin film on top. Grapefuity aroma. Tangy malt in the mouth with a little extra fruit. Bitter finish. Tad on the boring side but nice enough and the extra alcohol is hardly noticed.
Sampled cask conditioned. Amber coloured. Grassy hop aroma. Very salty, rathger light bodied, balanced bitterness. Salty finish.
Keg at Baggeridge Social Club, Gornal. Pours dark brown with a large head. Aroma is vanilla and caramel. Taste is toffee to start. Caramel vanilla finish.

12th November 2009 Spoons Fest.Clear amber beer. Pretty well balanced in it’s dullness. Dry malt, hops more bitter than fruit. Typical English bitter. Lingering bitter aftertaste. Hard to be offended but just dull.

First tasted this somewhere in Nottinghamshire in June 1990. Cask, handpump dispense. Jet black in colour with ruby highlights and a thin creamy buff head. Strong roast malt in the long aroma. Thin but creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Dark malt base gives a robust roast coffee, treacle fudge and bitter chocolate notes. Bitter hop resins give a dusty dry aftertaste. Finish is malty with juicy berry notes. A decent session mild and full of flavour considering the low ABV.

Cask at the Hay Inn, Shirland, Derbyshire. An appealling deep cherry red colour with a cream head; little aroma; but a fruity taste with cherries too; a clean light dry finish with a touch of biscuit.
NOt that bitter and it was well brewed, very creamy is this brewery’s beers but I like that in these. Very good foam.
Cask Stillage at Edgeley Park, Stockport 02/06/2006 Slight roast aroma. Dark coloured smooth and slightly rich on the palate. Fruity with some bitterness and dryness in a malt finish.
Cask condioned, GBBF 2005: Reddish appearance. Very sweet and malty. It’s maybe a bit thin, but still pretty nice.

[Cask at GBBF 2004] A deep red-brown beer with a small disappearing head. The aroma is sweet with primary notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel, licorice, roasted malt, as well as hints of metal, and with a dry end.
Cask conditioned and on Handpump at the Derby CAMRA winter beer festival on 09/02/05. Dark ruby brown colour. Very nice, very drinkable, Sublty malty. Very full despite only being 3.1%

(Cask-conditioned at Akkurat, Stockholm) Clear dark brown with reddish hints. One inch tall creamy tan head. Vague malty aroma with milky undertones. Malty soft flavour of plums, and dark chocolate. Watery body. Light malty finish. No hops.
Creamy & full bodied. Some kind of after tase but not completely descernible!
Good & creamy. Not above average though.....................................
My favorite Mad Crab brew. Dark red color with a beige, creamy looking head. Really good malty flavor accented my beer battered cod sandwhich perfectly. Wish I brought home a growler of this one!

Peachy, hazy. Musty, yeasty aroma with strong fruity character. A good Chimay knockoff. Very mature tasting Belgian for something that I know was brewed in the last two weeks. This was the farewell brew for the brewmaster who's leaving Tallahassee and heading to the Alpharetta store, so I'm not sure if it'll get resurrected or not up there. A fine Belgian.
Poured a pale yellow color, nice rocky white head. Aromas of hay, straw and light hops. Crisp and light bodied on the palate, with hay, straw and light hops.

Tap at Odell. Pours light yellow with an average, creamy white head, mostly lasting with good lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (hay, straw, meal), light hops (herbs), average yeast with notes of corn. Light bodied, creamy texture, and an average carbonation. Average duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.
Sampled at brewery. Clear light gold, foamy white head. Aroma of cereal grains, apple. Taste is light with sweet grain, some grassy notes, light citrus. Light body, crisp carbonation.

I found some old notes from back in the day. When I was first getting into the craft beer scene, I used to absolutely love this beer. This is crisp and light with some citrus and fruity esters mixed with the malts. Slight hops. I’ll miss you...
light brown body. grainy nose with a bit of honeycomb cereal. taste is light honey with a malty grain flavor. rather bland, but not too bad for what it is. 3 4 5 3 10

bottle -from somewhere in Omaha - small head, light yeast and malt flavor, a little watery, I hate to say but the flavor became worse as I drank it as it left a horrible favor in my mouth - I think it was some poor yeast- for that I can’t rate it higher plus the bottle is old
Slightly hazy golden color with a nice fluffy head-malty lemony aroma. Light bodied, thin maltiness, faintly fruity and lightly hopped, short clean finish.
medium golden color, no head, cloudy, 99% malt, not enough hoppiness to please me. fairly fruity, with a wheaty quality. not bad, but MIGHT be a bit past its prime.

Straw-colored with a thin, large-bubbled, white head. Aroma is sweet and grainy. Sweet, grainy malt flavor (hints of corn as well) with some spicy, floral hops. This is good but sweeter than most I have tried in the style.

First let me say that Bobby is much better on-tap than in the bottle. Sampled at the brewery. A light golden color with a wispy white head. Lacing was magnificent with this ale. Aromas of light malts, fruits, wheat and pears. Pretty tasty for the style. Pears, Peaches and yeast dominate the mouth. Nice dry finish with this beer as well but no mid-palate. Very drinkable but a poor mouthfeel. Overall, good for the style but not my cup of tea.

column2: Staten Island, New York, United States
column5: From old tasting notes. Mild toasted malt nose. Copper colored with a creamy beige head. Soft malty palate is reminiscent of an English Bitter Ale. Nice hop finish balances this ale nicely. Long bitter aftertaste. Very tasty.

column2: Staten Island, New York, United States
column5: Old notes from 1999: Gold with a white head. This one is caramelly and sweet with some grassy hints and some fruity touches on the finish.

column2: Staten Island, New York, United States
column5: Date: 02/21/1997 Mode: Draft Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs Appearance: golden, whispy head, Aroma: strong sweet malt aroma reminisant of Belgium candy sugar, Flavor: good malt flavor with balancing hops, slight bitterness in the finish Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column2: Staten Island, New York, United States
column5: On tap Major League Wrestling Show SEPT.’03 Can’t tell you much about this beer other thani Drank At least 6 of ’em that nite, and was happy to see something other than BMC as i flashed my Fake ID

column2: Staten Island, New York, United States
column5: Spot-on amber colour with a thin but soapy-large-bubbled off-white head. Aroma of light malt, a small amount of caramel and not much else...fairly light as well. Light-bodied; Taste of water with a bit of malt. Seriously, the taste is completely absent from this one. Aftertaste is nothing just like the inital taste. Overall, this one needs rework before they think they can sell a bunch of it. People will buy one or two, and thats it...because it isn't good. I bought this twelve ounce bottle from Beers of the World, but I would not reccomend you to do the same :-).

column2: Staten Island, New York, United States
column5: Slightly stale vegetable aroma with tinges of metal. Very light copper appearance, thin head with thin lacing. Very thin and watery overall. Slight nutty flavor is about the only thing going for this. Metallic finish.

column2: Staten Island, New York, United States
column5: Green peanut, vegetable, lagerish aroma. Ding for the screwoff cap, label is lacking, true amber color. Peanutty, lightly sweet, not much bittering. A wee, wee bit of fruit. Yawn.

column2: Staten Island, New York, United States
column5: Found this in bottles while in Staten Island. Pours a very normal looking amber. Clear, with a light misting of white head. Aroma is slightly malty and sweet. Hops are mild and seem to compliment the malt well. Flavor is malty, with a bit of a doughy flavor. It was kind of wierd and unimpressive. Kind of dull and unassuming. Balance is great, body is light, and carbonation is mild to high, which is not my cup of tea. Made me burp like crazy.

column2: Staten Island, New York, United States
column5: Had this on tap at the Liberty Heights Tap Room in Brooklyn. Nice clean crisp Amber. Nothing wrong with it. Had worse. Had Better.

column2: Staten Island, New York, United States
column5: Extremely Hoppy ale, really quite bitter and fairly good . Must be drank on tap at a S.I. Yankees ballgame to be properly enjoyed. Nose is quite redolent of herbs as well. It's not guinness or harp but its still good. Not much head on the beer though.

Bottled: Impressive ruby red coloured. Light brownish head. What a nose. Sweets, hops, spices and chocolate lingers pleasantly in your nostrils. Makes you wan't to "sniff" forever. Flavour is not equally good. Some roastyness, bites of hops and some maltyness that transfer into a pleasant dry bitterness in the end. Some bite in the mouthfeel. This is a very good dunkel. One of the best bottled I've tried.

I agree with Austinpowers; this is a beer whose idiosyncracies are endearing. Malt out the wazoo, nice body as a result, but with a nice hint of Saaz. This kind of old-school Czech dark lager always makes me think of the Good Soldier Svejk, the Czech equivalent of Homer Simpson, and his beer-soaked exploits in the hinterlands of the Hapsburg Empire...
Oh yeah! Virtually no head, malty and a bit flat. I know that doesn't sound real good, but trust me. This beer makes my short list of really tasty dark lagers! Don't be afraid of the dark!

Very nice dark golden color, draft. Not much of aroma. Taste is lite sweetness and sligth bitter. Lite body. Slick and abrupt. Tastes soapy. Watered down beer. Description says intense hop palate; I think my tap water is more intense than this. Did they forget to add the hops?
Lightly hazed, pale copper appearance. Citrussy aroma, fruity orange. Orange and lemony flavor, mild biscuity malt. Citrus and light greafruit in the finish.

Tap at brewpub. Nice clear copper color with a reasonable off-white head and some lacing. Mild malty aroma - not much else. Indistinct pale ale flavor, little bit of maltiness, little bit of hoppiness, thin and watery. Thin body and pleasant carbonation. This would definitely be a non-challenging, drink in quantity San Diego warm evening brew.
On tap at Taylor’s. Poured a medium orange color with a very small off white head. Ligh hops (citrus and maybe some flowers). No real flavors or aromas stand out. Watery body. Nothing special.

I'm sorry but...NOT A PALE ALE imo, grappish aroma with a pale color and small head, unpleasant acidic/bitter hop taste (what type of hops I do not know, but stay away), Just not a pale ale experience in the least

Draft at brewery in Mission Beach, CA: Amber color, light head/lacing. Nose of grassy hops, nutty caramel malt and diacetyl. The flavor is decent with some chewy body and a light bitterness. Dusty stale finish. Not good to drink either. Old lines?
Lightly hazed reddish brown. Sweet fruity aroma. Light fruit palate, pretty sweet, touches of caramel. A fairly mild straightforward amber.

(Draft: Taylor’s Restaurant and Brewery in San Diego, CA) Just a few blocks from my home, and 1/2 a block from the beach, Taylor’s is still one of those places I rarely visit. But on this glorious Sunday afternoon, I’m sittin’ on the rooftop deck, enjoying the sunshine and crashing waves. Unfortunately, I’m can’t say I’m enjoying the beer nearly as much. This amber is moderately malty, lightly toasty, but with barely any sweetness. It’s tangy and fairly bitter, but not especially hoppy per se. The aroma is lightly malty and equally lightly hoppy. Medium amber color and slightly hazy in the sunshine. Light tan head is small, but the beer was served right to the top of the pint glass, so who knows how much head would normally be present if left to its own devices. I had to check to see if this was an amber ale or lager, because it surely tastes more like a lager to me, but nope, it’s an ale all right.

Draft at brewpub. Slightly hazy copper color, long lasting off--white head with some lacing. Nice hoppy nose, malty flavor with good hop bite - unchallenging but a solid brew. medium body, creamy carbonation.
On tap at Taylor’s. Poured a medium amber color with no head. Lightly sweet a very light hops. Nothing stands out. Thin and watery.
Nice brownish color but little head, significant bitter hop presence & a bitter finish

Called James Brown Draft at brewery in Mission Beach, CA: Mahogany color, ruby edges, thick retentive head, very thick. The nose is dusty with some roast and oats in the taste. The flavor is lightly hoppy with a smooth creamy mouthfeel like nitro but it’s not. Best of the bunch.

Draft at brewpub. My favorite of the Taylors offerings. Dark brown, clear with mahogany highlight. Pleasing rasty malt aroma, almost porterish. Lots of flavor compared to other brews, roasty malts, good bitterness, hints of charcoal and chocolate. Nice smooth mouthfeel, medium to full body and pleasant carbonation.
Nice brown color with a thin but disappearing head, slightly nutty aroma, Bitter but roasted nut flavor and a noticeable alcohol background, slightly hoppy finish

I hate it when a brewer sasy their beer is a German Hefe, but it tastes like an American Wheat. Pour is cloudy gold with a decent white head. Aroma is all wheat. No banana, cloves, or yeast in the flavor. All wheat and honey. Blahhhh.

Draft at brewery in Mission Beach, CA: Light hazy yellow, no head. Nose of rotten fruit and spoiled wheat. Smelling this conjures up the memory about how prone rye is to botulism. Ugh. The wheat is crap, the flavor is dirty with honey and wheat husk and all sorts of bad things. Wow, bad, couldn’t finish without gagging.
Clouded yellow appearance. Mildly spiced clove aroma. Fairly well spiced palate, clove and white pepper, not much else though.

On tap at brewpub. Hazy light golden, little to no head.Sweet fruity, yeasty nose. Fruity flavor, wheat and banana, a little hoppiness, somewhat metallic, bit of spice and noticible alcohol. Light to medium body and minimal carbonation.
On tap at Taylor’s. Poured a medium, hazy yellow with a small white head. Subtle aromas and tastes of fruits and spices. Thin body.

Sampled at the Pizza Port Strong Ale Fest 2003. Light gold color, Medium head. Aroma is fruity and sweet. A medium bodied Hefeweizen. This is more like a pilsner than a hefe, as there was no real banana and clove thing going. But it is a big bold pilsner at that. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are slightly spicy. Nicely balanced. Smooth taste. Wish more people would make this kind of pilsner/hefe. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter
Cloudy/Tang-like appearance...Orange juice/wheaty flavor, orange soda-like aftertaste, One of the best at Terrific Pacific and I hate Hefeweizens, so...That's not saying too much
Artificial strawberry aroma, golden color with a lasting white head, flavor very similiar to freezer burnt strawberry ice cream...ending in a bitter hoppy finish

Tap at Hoppy Corner, Paris, 13th November 18. Pours a brown see through beer. Aroma is yeast, peat, floral, spice. Taste is typical Belgian ale with a earthy, peat, slight cararmel, yeast, spice, floral. Lovely take in the style.
From the 75cl bottle. Pours brown with a frothy beige head. Earthy, smoky aroma. Peat. Moor. Smoke. Taste is bittersweet, rich, earthy, malty. Body is medium. Balanced carbonation. Right up my alley.

Robe brun rouge, un peu voilée par de fins flocons de levure, très jolie mousse brunâtre, un peu visqueuse et assez durable. Nez original, notes boisées et vineuses qui se mêlent au malt, du fruit sec (noisette, pruneau, une pointe d'olive !). En bouche c'est assez corpulent sans être vraiment sucré : le boisé et le toasté viennent vite, pour équilibrer l'ensemble, qui devient facilement buvable. Comme une dubbel en plus léger, avec des arômes particuliers, dont cette olive qui ressort pas mal au nez. C'est plutôt agréable, manque peut-être un poil de richesse.

Mooi biertje van een vriend bij de bierkoning voor me verjaardag. Alleen kwam er tot mijn schrik achter dat deze ook nog dezelfde maand gedronken moest worden. Oftewel perfect gerijpt :-) Eerste indruk mooie lichte stout. Licht geurend naar koffie. Proef koffie, chocolade, notig. Vrij soepel maar redelijk moutig en een romige koffie kraag die zo fijntjes in van die mooie laagjes aan je glas blijft plakken. Fantastische donkere kleur met bezinksel wat eigenlijk ook wel bij dit type bier hoort en zeker naar deze perfecte rijpings periode. lol Vol van smaak en redelijk bitter, droog maar echt wel een mooie koffie boost. Het soepele geeft deze stout wat frisheid en ergens zelfs iets van doordrinkbaarheid. Maar waarom staat deze jongen als Belgian Ale??? Fact check: Volgens Wikipedia een Belgisch bier van hoge gisting dan nog zou ik hem meer stouterig beoordelen en dit alles met maar 6,5%. Proefglas 7-4-8-4-16

29 April 2018, at Zythos Bierfestival. Deputy Taster: Anke. Hazy dark brown with a lasting, foamy, tan head; lots of lacing. Aroma of caramel, herbs, yeast, raisin, licorice, roasted nuts, cinnamon, coffee with a cookie. It tastes light to medium malty sweet, some raisin & licorice, and light to medium roasted bitter, bit nutty. Not too dry, toasty, herbal hop finish. Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Pleasantly surprised by this brewery; you get so much at only 6.5%.

Bottiglia 75 cL, casa. Colore bruno molto scuro, con lievi riflessi rubino. Schiuma marrone chiaro, soffice, persistente e irregolare. Aromi classici e molto delicati: pane, canditi e lievito. In bocca ha un corpo fantastico, con il malto protagonista. Dolce ma non troppo (al punto giusto). Lievi sentori tostati. É anche molto fresca e l'alcol non è per nulla invadente. Luppolo quasi assente. Ho trovato questa birra molto più dissetante che altre birre nello stesso stile.

Piana obfita, trwała, drobna, pięknie zdobi szkło. Kolor rubinowa czerwień. Aromat drożdże, diacetyl, czerwone owoce, słodowy. Smak ciemne słody dające szorstkość, skórkę od chleba, są czerwone owoce, drożdże. piwo w odbiorze lekkie raczej mimo pełni wytrawne, w smaku diacetyl tez występuje ale w akceptowalnej przyjemnej formie, dobrze się pije. Bardzo dobre.

Robe brun très foncé, presque noire, reflets rouges. Col de mousse beige bien calibré, parfaitement stable et compacte, crémeuse. Nez torréfié de café, chocolat noir, tabac, sec. Bouche sèche café, chocolat noir. Amertume très légère. Très simple. Finale courte. Corpulence moyenne, texture crémeuse, carbonatation faible à moyenne. Bière de type porter/stout, simple, sèche, buvable. Un peu fade.

F: huge, beige, good retention. C: dark, opaque. A: malty, dark fruits, bit of chocolate, coffee, yeasty. T: malty, chocolate, coffee, fruity, cherries, medium body, medium carbonation, good one, enjoyed, 75cl bottle from Cora Woluwe-Saint-Lambert in Brussels.
Bottle at brauhaus. Pours brown, nose is toffee, caramel, roasted, taste is sweet, chewy, caramel, treacle
On tap: About average. Lots of carbonation, head quickly diminshing. Pale, golden color. Reasonably bitter. Watery. The brewery has a nice atmosphere.

Draught. Body is light yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie), lightly hoppy (perfume, herbs), with a light note of honey. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

I'm always curious to try "Blondes" because the style is so wildly interpreted. You get anything from an "American Standard Lager" to a hoppy "Pilsner." This one was decently flavored; a little rich and somewhat hopped with bitterness. Not bad, but not too good either.
You already know what this is - Linden's nod to the unitiated. Predictable sweet carboardy mash with a grandfather's beery aroma.
Nice cloudy orange appearance and some fruity-citrus action, but mostly bland, boring fare.

Cracker-like malt. Dry, bread-like, puckering bitterness in the finish. Sounds bad, but I actually enjoyed it a little in a sick sorta way. Yeah, I tasted the "charred almonds," as hennes writes, now that I think about it. Nice observation.

Now we're getting somewhere. The first three, lighter Linden's brews are rather weak, but this one has a good roast nuttiness, like slightly charred almonds, and decent hop edges. A big upgrade from its three ugly stepsisters.
14-OCT-2019, draft @Stone Brewing Escondido. Clear, dark golden, low, white head. Very very bitter. Dank, piney. Citrus, malt. Sweet, oily, bitter. Good.

Pours hazy amber with a huge white head. Aroma of tropical fruit notes and sweet malt. Taste has sharp hop bite on the tongue, pine and resin. Palate has sweet tropical notes overlaying the pine bite. Really good.

Au nez c’est frais, ça appelle les agrumes. Belle robe jaune orangée assez limpide (pour une DIPA), avec un col mousseux persistant. En bouche, l’amertume est forte et boisée, elle enrobe tout avec une longueur très juste. Les saveurs évoquent plutôt les fruits blancs, pêchés et litchis avec des arrières goût un brin résineux. Bien rond, bien fort, superbe équilibre, très bonne dipa
From the backlog, on tap. Pours hazy yellow orange, white head. Citrus, pine resin, rind, melon, orange, light booze. One of the OGs!

bottle from lcbo. Looking forward to this. I’m tiring of fruit injected lactose bombs & a big older school bitter blast sounds appealing. Frothy soap style suds across the golden. Dank, resin hop bomb as bitter as a republican on Martin Luther King day. I like that (the bitterness, not the racist). The hops fill the mouth with a nice relentless edge. Close to punishing finish. Love it. Sure, the bitterness drowns nuance of flavour & aroma but it’s a nice change up from the current fads.
Can 33cl. Golden with a foamy white head. Citrus aroma, buxus, pine and more hops. Nice rich taste. Firm bitter and a long finish. Really nice beer.

Bue aux Hoppydays de Liège 2018. Couleur : blonde limpide. Nez riche en flaveurs fruitées : tropicaux, pêche, pamplemousse, orange. Bouche ronde, à l'amertume puissante et aux goûts d'orange, de mangue, d'autres fruits. Bien épicée, un peu sucrée et superbe.

Pivo u limenci. Popijeno u Stella Beer2Go dućanu i kušaoni piva u Medulinu. Aroma voćna i malko hmeljna. Tijelo je solidno popunjeno , kakvo i treba biti za Double IPU. Okus je pun , voćkast , ali ono što obilježava ovo pivo je vrlo jaka "hmeljnost"...dakle pivo je dosta gorko , ali snažno tijelo to donekle balansira.. Znači "hmeljoljupci" navalite , ako naletite na ovaj Stonov uradak ;)

opalizujące jasne złoto, piana średnia, opadła dosyć szybko ale pozostawiła łany lacing, w aromacie głównie nuty żywiczne, trochę nuty.... ziołowo maślane/karmelowe? goryczka na znakomitym poziomie, przyjemna, dłuuuuuugo się utrzymuje. ostatni cudowny łyk zadecydował o końcowej ocenie, ZAJEBISTA DOUBLE IPA

One of the hoppiest, bitterest, IPAs out there. Major floral and grapefruit hops in this one. Still has some malty caramel flavors in the end, but hops is the theme here for sure. Appearance is not as orange as some other IPAs, but not not one of those pale yellow one either....somewhere in between. I prefer my IPAs just a tad less bitter, but if looking for a hop bomb, this could be the one. Not sure if it's quite a double IPA though.
GABF '03. Golden color with floral hop nose. Thin pale head. Hoppy taste but nothing more. Could use a bit more malt.

Head is initially small, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is medium amber. Aroma is moderately hoppy (orange/apricot, grapefruit, resin), lightly malty (cookie), light note of alcohol. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic. Competent American-style IPA...reasonable malt backbone, and better balanced than your average AmerIPA (though still pretty citric), but still doesn't quite have what it takes to rock my world.
Sweet candyish malts and hops intertwine - the hops are kind of raw and earthy, bitter, yes, but vegetabley. I like this a lot. Body kind of thick, but clear. Thanks Ringo!

I was never that impressed with Linden's brewpub offerings (I live a just a few miles from the pub). They recently went of business, and this was their first (and last) bottled beer. Too bad, because this is pretty damn good!
GABF 2003: Clear orange color, hoppy pine aroma. Full bodied and thick. Ends bitter with a long hoppy aftertaste.
Medium gold hue. Floral hop aroma. Good basic IPA aroma and flavor, not overdone. Sugar sweetness, with only mild bitterness, and a slight scotch like flavor.
Excellent sweet/hoppy aroma. Amber in color. Flavor is very good with a nice level of hoppiness mixed with a sweeter floral flavor. The beer feels good in the mouth - a good IPA.

The beer is slightly hazy in appearance, with a lingering head, and a nice sweet/hoppy smell. The initial flavor is bittersweet, followed by a strongly hop-bitter middle, and a pleasant finish. a very strong palate, overall the taste is bittter and sweet, a good IPA
