Good. Tending toward the sweet side but a solid effort. I'm warming to this brewery now after a few lackluster earlier samplings.
Dark brown. Mild soapy and floral aroma. Big banana flavor up front, good body with a syrup-tasting plum finish. Rich.
A floral smell, hint of bannanas and cinnamon. Three is a strong bannana flavor, and a bit too much sugar. seems to be trying too hard to cover the alcohol.

Very appealing aroma that is sweet and fruity. Appearance is a nice dark amber color. Flavor is slightly malted with a definite nutty/fruity flavor. The palate is full and the beer feels good on the tongue. I've only tried one other Abbey (New Belgium), but I definitely like this one.

Golden-orange; surprisingly light in color. Slightly hazy, almost clear. No head to speak of. Peculiar, strange, atypical, astringent, bitter, overly carbonated, and sour in many wrong ways. Seemed very undone and green to me. Did I catch them at a bad time... or bad batch?

With New Belgium just down the road this is an audacious entry, and they do fine. The beer is big on cinnamon and and more sharply sugary than I like, but it has a nice round malty body and masks alcohol with the best of them.
Tasted 10-7-2002, The main thing I remember about this beer was that it had an amazing aroma, almost exactly like a rose, it was incredible. The taste was also very good. Super beer all around.

Medium to dark ruby color. Boring at first, somewhat sickly, goes to cherries and honey and strawberries, and then finally a bit cloying before and unexpectedly wet finish full of cherries and honey. I can feel the alcohol in my nose. Nice, but nose my ideal barley wine.
A slightly bitter smell, a sweet cherry/berry flavoring. The palate was too thin though. overall it lacked a lot in body.
Sweet aroma dominated by a cherry/vanilla smell. Appearance is coppery in color. Flavor is mostly berries but with a definite alcohol bite. Mouthfeel is average.

A ruby-red orange with obnoxiously thick cream puff lacing. Aroma of the usual plus almonds, bubblegum and watermelons; not exactly what I was expecting. Flavor is indeed a big apricot bomb plus a helping pears, along with medicinal/gauze flavors. Faint flowers and cherry cough syrup round out the swallow. This has little body for a barley, yet somehow manages to coat your mouth with its overwhelming sweetness.

Clear copper with frothy lace. Super-sweet and sugary-smelling nose. Dried fruit flavors exuded. Very smooth nectar with a heavy mouthfeel. Intensely flavored and rich. One of Linden's best, that I tried.

Huge rasberry nose and flavour. Huge. I mean, this thing is malt infused razbry juice with interesting edges from hops, smoke, and alocohol. Very smooth, too, as the commercial description suggests. Aphrodiasiac? Well, you'll have to ask brownalegirl about that ...

Taking a stab at the abbey style - I suppose living in the shadow cast by NB's success, many western brewpubs will take this shot. Mantis is a decent effort, lighter and easier to deal with than most beers of the type - kind of a belgian lite, but with enough spicy character to keep me interested.
Urdålig, vem vill dricka denna kombination som smakar så urvattnat dåligt och tråkigt.
Certainly better than the Spendrups pale lager, but still nothin exceptional. It has a copper tone and more body, aroma and aftertaste is short.
Golden-brown with a low head. Malty aroma of caramel, nuts and corn. The flavour is sweet, metallic and a bit sour.
Can, 500ml, 2000-08-08, don’t bye this horrible mix. Why should you want to mix a ale with a lager?

500 ml can. A small beige head upon a clear, deep copper colored body. Modest aroma of nutty malts and cream-caramel. Whiffs of dark dried fruits. Much of the same in the flavor, with mild bittering hops and some notes of honey and fruity acidity in addition. Dry and acidulous mouthfeel. Light-bodied with short bitterish end.

0,5l can from a system bolaget in Stockholm. very good experiment from Spendrups. The lightness though a bit watery and delicious hops with caramel and beautiful dark amber colour: I want more of this.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber colour with a white head. Thin on the nose. Some caramel and bread. Flavour is a bit sweet and malty. Just a hint of bitterness. I did not enjoy this one all that much.

This mix between an ale and a lager has a dark amber color and an OK head. The aroma has notes of caramel and a bit of fruit. The flavour is a bit weak with notes of caramel, light fruit and citrus and the finish is unbalanced with too heavy grapefruit notes. 1920

50cl bottle at Botulfs on August 21, just found it on here today after much searching. Clear copper with a small head. So-so malts with some caramel, and a little hop balance. Nothing exciting, but drinkable, and good compared to the other Spendrups beers Ive had sinse. What I really want to know is where can I get a Spendrups scotch ale? I’m thinking that if you took the Spendrups lager out, you could have a solid beer.
50 cl. can. Pours an amber colour with a short head. Aroma of caramel and toasted malt. The flavour is a bit sweet with caramel, toasted malt and some fuitiness. Toastish finish.
Pilsnerfärgad klar med vit skum. Doftar och smakar inget. Men ren och krispig lager
Can from Systembolaget, Sweden. Very short head. Clear pale yellow color. Mild fruity aroma. Small sweet malty taste with a firm bitterness. Balanced body.
Can, 50 cl. A bit too sweet lager, would have preferred more malty features.
Burk från SB. Klar, gyllengul kulör med vit skumkrona med vit skumkrona. Doft och smak av knäck, bröd, metall och alkohol.
Nice Lager. Good choice for a 6%'er! One of my systembolaget favourites! Nice pic! Would recommend!! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from systembolaget. Pours a golden colour beer with a medium head. Malty with sweet banana notes. Dry finish.
50cl can. clear golden color. white head. sweet malt, grass, hops. boring..
How: Can. Where: Systembolaget. Appearance: Yellow colour with a white head. Aroma: Sweet malt, some fruit. Body: Medium body and carbonation. Flavour: Sweet malt.
Bez szału. Kiepski aromat, średni wygląd i smak. Ot, taki sklepowy lager.
Can from Systis. Clear golden with strong white head. Malty nose with some alcohol. Ach.
(Can 50 cl) 5,5% ABV in my version. Beautiful, fully golden brew with a small head. Nice full body and a clearly marked bitterness, but not overly bitter. A decent strong lager. 240901
5.5%, 550 ml can. I couldn’t say I didn’t like it: it was quite full-bodied, juicy and slightly alcoholic, but this alcohol bitterness served very well in the palate.

Canned. Blue Tiger turned Blue Zebra. Swedish fotballers started out as zebras but acted like tigers on the pitch in the second half. The aftertaste in that game wasn’t as sour as this beer. Sweden-Italy 1-1. Yihaa!
Blond beer with a small head. Weak aroma.The taste is light malty and a bit sweet. The finish is neutral. Tasteless name and the same goes for the design of the can.

Golden colour. Small bubbly head. Sweet malty aroma. Notes of corn and pear. Very sweet malty flavour. Notes of rotten apples/pear. Suddenly I expected a worm would come out of the dark hole of the can. It just tasted so sweet and nasty.
Canned. Aka as Blue Zebra. An international standard lager. A bit sweetish and malty.

My beer was named Blue Zebra, but I guess it is the same. Or at least very similar, why would Spendrups shock us and suddenly change anything else but the cans when they make different beers. This ons is very sweey and sugary. Flavor is very sweet as well, and I think there wasa touch of glue(!?) in it.
Boring lager with an unpleasant bitterness and some notes of green apples...
Pale golden coloured cheaply made lager. Grainy aroma. Thin and sharp, rather sweet with low bitterness. Substandard.
Pale yellow. Dry, medium bitterness. Neutral but with some apple aroma......
Golden brown with small creamy head. Caramel aroma. There is a slightly sweet start, some spice and a bitter, well balanced finish.

Pale amber. There is a hint of grassy hop aroma in the nose. Some toffeeish malt character. Not overly bitter finish. Considering the harshness of the winters in Northern Lapland you'd really expect the winter version to be something like World Wide Stout. I wish it was...

Also Jahki Vinter: Crystal clear dark amber with a medium size and lasting white head and some light lace too. Mild caramel and antiseptic alcohol with hints of fruit and spices aroma. Light body with mild bitter and faint sour palate at the start. Interesting honey, caramel and roasted smokey flavours drift in and out while tasting. Looks adequately carbonated but taste is relatively flat. Middle, finish and aftertaste are a tad bland spoiling what is otherwise quite a pleasant beer..
The character of this beer change with the seasons. Somtimes somewhat malty and sometimes somwhat hoppy. But basicly it's pretty much the same.
Bottle from a swedish crocery store. Light green colour with no head. Artificial aroma of lime and sugar. Sugar lemonade taste. Medium carbonation.
Bottle. Pale green colour without any head. Aroma and flavour of malt, lime and cactus is suppose.

Extremely sweet in taste. It says beer on the bottle, but this is not beer. Maybe I would have liked it better if my expectations had been different. For some reason I thought it would be remotely similar to beer. It is not.

Bottled. Pale poisonous green colour, no head to talk about. Artificial lime aroma, cactus maybe closer to the aroma... Flavour is quite the same, extreme sweetness with cactus and lime... refreshing drink while cold, but beer... naaah, rather lemonade...

Bottled (BB 08/2006) I wanted to celebrate my 200th Swedish rating with something special. And this is it. Pale green, disappearing head. Artificial aroma of lime and sugar. Very sweet and sugary, artificial "cactus" flavor. Nothing to do with beer, no taste of malts nor hops. Sugary lemonade.

The aroma is fresh with notes of lime - somewhat artificial. The color is clear green with no head. The flavor is also somewhat artificial with lime notes. A very refreshing drink - but nothing a beer geek will go crazy about.
Dangerous light green colour. If it did not say on the bottle, I would not have noticed that this was a beer.

Chernobyl inpsired bright turquoise/green colour, no head. Offensive bubblegum aroma, ridiculously sweet. Liquid candy for kids. Bears not much resemblance to beer, which is probably a good thing considering that this brewery has no clue how to make beer.
Tap at Fitger’s on Nov. 17, 2011. Red amber pour with a fluffy cream head. Aroma and taste are very mild caramel and bread. A bit watery.

I love mild. I’ve had some great ones (especially in England). The problem here is that it is too mild--it feels like fluffy water, with a very hollow flavor, like vanilla ice cream whip (the fake ice cream) that doesn’t really melt even when it gets warm. It keeps a light foam head. Not worth the effort. (on tap at brewpub)

On tap at the Fitgers Brewhouse in Duluth, MN, pours a coppery brown, almost Irish red, brew with a creamy off white head. Aroma is very light malt, some peat, farm barn mustiness, and a little raisined dark fruit. Taste is slightly sour/bitter, light body and quite watery. Finish is light and dry. Almost falling into the lawnmower beer territory.
Dark amber color with faint creamy head. Malty nose, faintly sweet with a raisin character. Slightly bitter malty body that didn’t have a lot going on - watery.
Dark Brown Coloring with Creamy Sandy Head. Dusty Malt/Grainy Aroma. Dry Grain/Barn Taste - Heavy and Dry Mouthfeel.. Ends with a Grainy Malt Aftertaste..Flavor Quite Subtle and Dry.
Dark brown color with a very creamy Guinness-like head. Just a hint of malt in the aroma. Very earthy and grainy taste. Bitter finish.

Clear dark brown topped witha full finger of super creamy and fine light chocolate head. Aroma of grass, earth, sheep barn, peat and oats. Interesting flavor complex as it warms on the tongue. Eart and grass continues, but backed off by strong diacetyls in the form of rich fresh buttermilk. This fades into a toasty burnt hazlenut profile. Combine all of this with a rindy and musty Cashel Blue cheese in the back ground. This is all riding on a waterfall of rich and bold roasted oats. Watery, lightly carbonated, and light on the alcohol, but very drinkable and smooth, with a smack of hoppy bitterness.

Salt air aroma, which is fitting. Held up to light, a dark reddish hue is apparent. Head and body similar in appearance to Guinness. Smooth flavor; like the nitro injected Guinness. As advertised, dark in color, but light in body. Drinkable but not all that special.
good for a mild beer...used to work there...good flavor and seeing it get made was cool

First real mild I have had the opportunity to sample, and I'm impressed. Light on the tongue, virtually no hop presence but there is an extremely nice maltiness here. Hints of roasty grains, as well as liquorice and of nuts. This is a high quality beer.

On tap at Republic, pours a deep dark mahogany with a small beige head. Aroma brings out a nice dry oat character upfront, with lightly toasted malt. Flavour is along the same lines, with oats, toasted malt and some earthy, chalky notes. Missing a little sweetness and roast to achieve better depth. Okay.
Really nice sweet stout. Deep and chocolatey. More than a little roasty coffee character. Jess and I tried at the brewery in 2018 on our way to Northern Lights.
Tap; pours nearly black with a tan head; aroma of coffee, roasted malt, and some chocolate; taste is chocolate with some coffee, malt, and hints of oats; dry, light bitter roasted malt finish

Keg @ Fitgers. Deep brown with a tight, creamy tan head. Mocha frappucino nose. Some peppered dark chocolate. Silky and fairly sweet. Just a bit of acidic charred grain on the finish. Silky and easy going palate effects. Pretty nice.

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours black with a dark grayish brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has strong dark grains and roasted malts with a slight creaminess. Flavor has dry, bitter dark grains with a good amount of roast and a hint of oats.

Tap - big dark tan foamy head, pitch black color, big toasty malt aroma and flavor, moderate chocolate and coffee notes, fair hop balance, nice creamy full bodied finish, good overall ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. Black/brown pour, creamy lighter tan colored head. Creamy thicker body for not too big of a stout, cocoa and roasted malt flavors, hint of dark fruit.

On draught at Fitger’s. APPEARANCE- Jet black, light nougat colored head with great lacing. NOSE- deep notes of coffee with a smidge of malty sweetness. FLAVOR- coffee blasts into my mouth my with every sip. Roasty malts prevail as the coffee fades into the distance. After suggestion, I taste a bit of dark chocolate residuals in my mouth.

Growler poured a cl;ear dark reddish brown with a small lasting tan head. Aromas of bakers cocoa, roasted malt, light earthiness and light coffee. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of roasted malt, bakers cocoa, light coffee and light earthiness with a smooth dry lingering cocoa finish.

On tap at brewpub. Complex coffee, chocolate, and roasted barley vanilla-probably some hops in there too. Opaque, oily black under a thin, tan ring. Sweet coffee with dark chocolate bitterness and hops bitterness and roasty vanilla. Medium body, moderate carbonation, clean finish.

Sold as "Farmhouse Saison." On tap at Tycoons, Duluth. Copper color. Lots of coriander and black pepper. This is dry, and even drier in the finish. I also pick up some lemongrass, but i do not think there is actually any in this beer.

Pours very hazy yellow with white head into snifter on tap, aroma has notes of bubblegum, barn, sweet fruity citrus, some slight earth. Taste is a bit odd, has sweet notes of fruit and citrus with a slight spice from the yeast, but then stays sweet without the dryness coming in but still has a slight bitterness. Good, but a bit left to be desired.

Golden apricot pour with a milky appearance. Pineapple, coriander and bananas on a nose with a sharp, zesty gin edge. A light, fruity flavor is obscured by a mild cloud of aerosol. Packs a punch even in a small amount. This evolves a bit into more of floral shampoo quality. Grapefruit and cantaloupe notes beside, definitely struggling with a weird IPA identity. Palate is too wet and creamy, with a very bitter bite. No discernable farmhouse qualities for all these hops to play with. Might have been interesting.

On tap at brewery. What a nice suprise this one is. Pours Gold/yellow with a small white head. Nice floral, grassy hop aroma with just a bit of farmhouse funk. Taste is mostly the same, but with a light pepper and coriander spice. This was good.

Pours a clear golden color with about half an inch layer of white foam. The foam quickly settles down to a ring and thin film. A little bit of lace. Good aroma of spice. The taste is of sweet, smooth, malt - with wheat and honey. There is a moderate floral hop presence. And lots of spice throughout. Finishes with a dry spicy coriander and a very subtle alcohol bite. You really notice the spicy saison yeast (I’m guessing WL 550) in this beer. Lightly carbonated and medium body. The spicyness really sticks with you in the aftertaste - very nice. Very drinkable - but watch it - its not a lightweight beer by any means.

Sample, then glass, at the brewpub. Pale golden, opaque and cloudy, swirling yellow starts...the ring of foam lasts indefinitely...soft sweet inviting nose, with ginger and coriander competing gently amidst an orangepeel center...sweet and yeasty initially on the tongue, a sour citrusy backbone is interrupted as it warms by light touches of oregano and tarragon...at the finish, citrusy acid and pepper win over the earthy malts and it goes on, and on, and on....

Cloudy Gold Coloring with Good White Creamy Head. Grassy Saison Aroma. Lightly Hoppy. Upon First Experiencing This Brew on The Tongue...It Tasted Like a Saison...With Many Grassy, Floral Flavors...And After Consuming This Pint, Coriander Became the Dominant Flavor and Made the Grassy Saison Notes Disappear. Light Hoppy Bite to it...Dry Ending But Balanced Overall. You Have to Enjoy the Flavors of a Saison, But Very Enjoyable and Presumably VERY Enjoyable in the Summer over the Winter.

I thought that this was a pleasant beer with nice hops good maltiness and quite a bit of buttery quality. Not sure about the stylistic description. It didn't seem to have any of the yeasty bite that I enjoy from saisons. (Perhaps I was served the pale ale? I did enjoy the beer quite a bit, I'm just not sure it was the saison.)

column1: Fitgers El Nino Double Hopped IPA
column5: My ultimate favorite IPA. Fresh. Hoppy. Tastes perfect. Haven't been able to top it's flavor anywhere. Best IPA so far and I've tasted many. I'm 30 yrs old so... ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Fitgers El Nino Double Hopped IPA
column5: This is a lot like Furious. A little lighter in appearance, but blindfolded I would have guessed this was Furious.

column1: Fitgers El Nino Double Hopped IPA
column5: Tap; pours orangish amber with a white head; aroma of citrus, caramel, honey, and some pine hints; taste has some bitterness to it with citrus and then some light sweetness with caramel and honey; dry, bitter finish with some pine.

column1: Fitgers El Nino Double Hopped IPA
column5: Keg @ Fitgers. Deep gold with a Prominent head. Nose suggests sweetness. Fresh brioche and honey. Some melon and tropical fruit accents. Drinks regrettably one dimensional. Blunt bitterness. Aspirin-like, sort of onion. Just a touch of plastic. A bit flabby. Medium / full. A bit oily. Not loving this.

column1: Fitgers El Nino Double Hopped IPA
column5: On tap. Off white head with lacing and amber color. A-citrus-orange, some light/medium malt. T-citrus/spice hop bite, light/medium malt. Drying.

column1: Fitgers El Nino Double Hopped IPA
column5: Draft. Goldne pour, very dank aroma, flaovr is danky, herbal, very sprucey, garlicy, maybe some summit hops in there cause it has some onion/garlic.

column1: Fitgers El Nino Double Hopped IPA
column5: Draft at the brewery. This is a ruddy-looking beer and starts like many D/IIPAs; overall it’s drinkable, but side by side with their flagship pale ale, I prefer the pale ... this has a nutty aspect that takes over that didn’t tickle my palate in the right way. (#5676, 8/29/2014)

column1: Fitgers El Nino Double Hopped IPA
column5: On tap at brewpub. Sweet strawberry and fresh orange hops aroma with some faint caramel in the background. Clear orange-amber under a lasting, lady, white sheet. Medium bitterness and caramel flavor with resinous hops bitterness and strawberry-grapefruit peel. Medium body, moderate carbonation, slight lingering bitterness.

column1: Fitgers El Nino Double Hopped IPA
column5: Dark amber / copper pour from a growler obtained last weekend. Nice white head and lots of white lacing. Big lovely hoppy nose with a hint of citrus and malt. Big earthy and spicy hops in the taste with a strong bitter finish. Full mouthfeel. Nice.

column1: Fitgers El Nino Double Hopped IPA
column5: Draft. Copper/Red with small off white head. Aroma of resinous hops and not much else. Medium/full body, medium hop bitterness, toasted malt, nut, and some fruit notes. Update: a creamer mouthful and denser head this time around.
On tap at the source. Pours penny copper with beige head. Nose is roast grains and some caramel. Taste is caramel, grains, nuts and a bitter smoky background. Body is medium. A decent ESB at best.
Cask, darker esb pour, dark amber. Its sweet and toffee-like not a huge fan of this esb style but the yeast character is absolutely spot on, very light herbs.

On tap at brewpub. Spicy toffee aroma with some faint earthy hops and dried fruit. Clear ruddy chestnut under a lacy, off white sheet. Sweet toffee flavour with some nuts, earthy hops, and medium bitterness. Medium body, moderate carbonation, lingering bier finish.
Draft. Dark copper with large beige head with nice lacing. Aroma of toasted malt and caramel. Medium/light body, malt sweetness, caramel, and light earthy hop bitterness.
Tap at Fitgers. Rich orange amber pour. Spotty white head. Earthy and grassy hops. Malty. Not bad.

Draft. Deep amber body with a foamy off-white head, lasting. Aroma of sweet caramel, toasted grain. Lightly floral with hints of lemon peel and citrus. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, moderate carbonation. Starts with caramel sweetness that surrenders to a lingering bitterness.
Tap - good size thick head, nice dark copper color, earthy hop aroma and flavor with a nutty malt backbone, smooth finish from the nitro ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Sample at ABR. Faint barrel aroma, neutral base allows barrel through. Light body.

Pours a nice dark ruby amber with a lasting frothy head. Scent is a nice roasted malt with a little caramelized sugar. Taste is a pretty smooth bitterness with a little malt backbone. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Part of a sampler had with lunch on the way to haul the sailboat for the winter. I have to say it just had little flavor except for some sour, so watery . . .
Draft. Hazed gold pour, very ho hum, not too sweet like some, mild wheat, basic stuff.
Sampled at All Pints North 2013 in Duluth, dirty hop aroma, taste is some dank citrusy hops
Sampled at All Pints North 2013 in Duluth, MN. Hazy yellow pour with a small white head. Lots of orange and spice in the aroma and taste - I enjoyed this quite a bit.

Pours a hazy gold with a medium white head. Aroma is wheat and a lot of orange citrus. Flavor is citrus orange and coriander with almost something of a household cleaner scent to it with some wheat as well. Light to medium body with medium carbonation and nice mouthfeel. Enjoyable white.

Date: August 11, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Fitgers Brewhouse, Duluth, MN Appearance: Opaque hazy yellow with some head. Aroma: Grainy and maybe some orange or citrus. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, light bodied.

On draught during Great Taste of Midwest 2009 in Madison, Wisconsin. Pours a semi-hazy golden straw colored brew with a fast dissolving white head. Aroma of coriander, golden grain malt, some white pepper and clove. Taste is light to medium bodied, flavors of golden grain malt with coriander and some mild spice and lemon zest. Finish is semi-sweet with a nice coriander and wheat malt aftertaste that slowly disappears.
It has the basic flavor profile, but there are better Wits. While at Fitgers, there are better offerings as well.
ABR 2008. Aroma is of orange, spices, and wheat. Flavor is sort of bland, a light sweetness, something there I wasn’t crazy about.
ABR 2007. hazy white color. Wheat on the nose and similar flavor with a faint spice to it. A little sweet.

Draft at the Brewhouse. Any domestic brewing of a Belgian Wit is much appreciated; but I found this one over-floral. The finish is very bold, too much for me. Ultimately I found this very cloying and tough to drink in more than small doses.

(drain pour and ticks’ night) pours clear very pale yellow with a decent white head, no retention. faint malts, faint corn, wet grass and herbal hops, blandness. aggressive carbonation, light body - watery. not much else in there. nothing off, not horrible, but incredibly bland and unimaginative.

Originally rated May 2006. Lakeport Light is $24 for 24 bottle (before deposit and taxes). It pours a normal golden lager colour with a white foamy head that dissipates fast enough. One bubble at a time carbonation and very mild soapy lace. Decent aromas, found in a normal lager (5% ABV). Watery mouthfeel. Starts off with some light malt flavour and very slim corn comes out in the aftertaste. An unexpensive, unoffensive light brew, and great for the hockey playoffs.
typical light beer, little flavour, goes down pretty easy, would drink if nothing else was around

Tall cans, and 6packs readily available at LCBO or Beer Store locations. Cannot really imagine why anybody would ever buy this stuff, basically just watered down Lakeport which is already like drinking carbonated water. No real smell, look, or taste to it. I guess the one thing it has going for it is that theres nothing noticably offensive about it. It’s just... nothing.

473 mL Can. Pale straw body with a large fizzy white head that settles to a foamy layer leaving some lace. Aroma is corn husk, wet hay, and musty basement. Corn dominates in the flavor along with corn husk, hay, eau de Hamilton Harbor, little to no aftertaste, and an unpleasant bitter phenolic / chemical / skunky finish. "Premium Light Beer", eh! I can’t bait my hook with that; I’ll leave the rest of my pint to the carps that live in Hamilton Harbor.
lets cap the night with a horrible beer! jesus christ who can possibly drink this and claim they like it!?!??!!?? awful!1 tastes of water infused with beer flavoring

473ml can from the LCBO. One asks, ’why’? I would answer, ’I know not...’. Anyways, pours a very pale, excessively effervescent yellow with a large frothy head. Smells like industrialized corn, cooked vegetables, all the usual Lakeport horribleness. The flavour is surprising in that it actually defies expectations of crap and takes it to a whole new level (a lower one). Sour, tart, salty, overly fizzy, generally very unpleasant. Good God. Even for Lakeport drinkers this stuff is pathetic. I don’t even think my sink drain liked it.

[1208-20080318] 473mL can. Corny grain field grass aroma with a hint of light floral hay. Clear, pale orange yellow body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. Watery crushed corn flavour. Watery light body, tinge of astringency. Not horrible for a light but not exactly enjoyable either.

Bottle. Light gold. Faint grain and cheap malt aroma and flavour. Over-carbonated palate dominates the experience, leading to a watery and mild bitter finish. Not hideous, and works only as a last resort.

Bottle. Pours a bubbly pale gold with an average size somewhat-lasting white head -- doesn’t look too bad for a cheap Ontario Pale Lager. Aroma’s corny and sweet along with some grain but there is a hint of hops there, it’s not great but I’ve smelt much worse. Flavour’s mild, there’s not much there, some corn, grain and just a hint of hops -- it’s inoffensive but also quite dull. Not something I’d ever drink, I like flavour in my beer, but If you have to drink some buck-a-beer Light beer then you might as well get this, it’s better then some of the other contenders out there.

Cask, The Salmon, Leicester. Dark brown, red with a thin head. Aromas are weetabix and chocolate malts with autumn fruit and mixed spice. Flavours are sweet weetabix and mellow chocolate with lemon. Dry on the finish. A decent mild.
Cask. 3.5% ABV. The Salmon, Leicester. Black body, medium white head. Apple, hop.Bittersweet. Dry finish.
Cask. The Wenlock Arms, London. Labeled as Lees’ Ansell’s Mild. Brown colour. Fruity, malty and lightly roasted. Dark fruits and chocolate. Light bitterness and dry finish. Light bodied.

Cask-conditioned at The Wenlock Arms as JW Lees’ Ansell’s Mild 23/0909 - the landlord told me the contract to brew this has been shifted across from Thwaites. As the Thwaites’ brewed rating is here, so is this one. This was dark brown with hints of red and a slight, off-white head. Big malty aroma of cereals, chocolate and dark fruits. A bit thin in the mouth, with more chocolate, a trace of sweet fruit and lightly bitter finish. Drinkable.

(Cask at Lion Tavern, Liverpool, 19 July 2009) Dark brown colour with frothy, beige head. Roasted, malty nose with chocolate, prunes and raisins. Roasted, malty taste with notes of cola, chocolate and dark fruit. As expected quite thin body, but well balanced and tasty. Good mild. (According to Good Beer Guide -09 it is now supposed to be brewed by Thwaites for Carlsberg UK.)
On draught at The Wenlock Arms as Thwaites Ansell’s Mild. Very dark brown with an offwhite head. Dark fruit and hints of chocolate. Short finish. Quite interesting.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Wootton WMC. A ruby coloured mild with an off-white head. A very mild mild with fruits and caramel. A short finish. Sweet yet bizarrely dry at the same time. Ordinary and neckable.
This is the best mild. Exactly half way between a bitter and stout. Sublime sweetness. Simply superb.

Cask (handpump) @ The Royal Oak, CV8, Kenilworth. Clear medium amber color with a small creamy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, dust. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a short to average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat.
Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 23/04/2004 Mid brown coloured with some sour fruit flavour. Hoppy with a dry lasting finish.
Brown bitter with a tight fine foam, lightly malty-sweet and faintly syrupy nose, watery and light with a little nutty malt and a touch of leafy hop bitterness. Clean but dull.

In the 80's it was the best bitter around. There was however a remarkable taste differential that made the difference. This bitter had to be served slightly chilled than conention dictated. I found that the pubs that Indians started to own used to serve this bitter colder than traditional "white landlords" pint who believed in bitters served in the typically established rules of room temp or slightly warmer. However we see times have changed and that the immigrants taste particularly the old rules have been thrown out and the traditionalists have failed. In that the taste of Lamb and chicken along with a whole number of other meats that the flavour of the meat has to com through and spices should not be allowed and infact Indians were berrated and riddiculled for employing spices to delicate meats, yet today everyone has to have a curry. This is the case in point with Ansells, if they tried it chilled slightly it would be the best beer in the world.

Cask@The Baker’s Arms, Broad Campden (Cotswolds). Bronze beer with a strong white head. The aroma is lightly roasted and toffee, and the flavour is hopped, bitter and mildy toffee. Overall a reasonable beer.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Coach And Horses - Wellingborough. A copper coloured beer which, in spite of its move to Leeds still has some sulphuric Burton notes to it. Fairly thin in body but some nice hops come through in the taste. Some bitterness. Old fashioned and approachable.
Kenilworth. Anaemic dribble of mealy biscuit, caramel, diluted raisiny fruit. But drinkable.

Cask (handpump) @ The Royal Oak, CV8, Kenilworth. Clear medium orange color with a small creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, toffee, butter. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Mild and easy to drink. Body is light to medium, texture is creamy, carbonation is flat.

Cask. Live. 3.7% April, 2004: Huntsman & Horn, Near Herne Bay, Kent. Copper orange coloured hoppy bitter with a pleasant sweetness under the earthy bite. An old school bitter, well made. Orange marmalade aroma. [2.9] Keg. Filtered and pasteurised. 3.7% Dec, 2004:Von Alten, Chatham Soft nitro. Dried apple flavour soon followed by cardboard staleness. Leaves a stale bitter taste. The first gulp is acceptable - then the badness settles in and this becomes very nasty indeed. [1.8]

Cask at the Red Lion, Shirley. I really enjoyed this one. Tight, creamy head, which remained about half an inch thick throughout. Light golden colour, with a fairly thin mouthfeel. Nicely bitter, balanced with a citrus freshness. Refreshing, crispy, full. I'd say spritzy. Nice.

Cask Conditioned at The Plough, Bicester. Amber bitter, a beer from my youth and now it has been reduced to this tasteless, watery rubbish. Originally brewed in Birmingham its now an unloved recipe in a faceless macro brewery.

Very standard bitter with that weird combination of wateriness and very unquenching fruity thickness. Not a lot to get excited about, apart from the uncanny taste of condoms (or what I imagine they taste like...).

on tap at the brewery in the middle of nowhere. referred to as both helles and lager but i’ll assume this is the appropriate listing. pale golden with a very light haze that seemed caused by how cold it was served rather than any sediment; the aroma was similar to that of the hefeweizen - yeasty and bready with a trace of vanilla; very simple flavours, a dry plain flour finish, quite lemonadey. not a helles at all and once the refreshment factor wore off it was an effort to get through
I’m not sure this is the right beer. Mine is breaed in Germany. Anyway, it’s too light, probably rice brewed. Not very exciting altogether.

Golden colour with low carbonation, lack of head. Light tasting with toasty notes. Maybe some Vienna malt. Low bitterness, slightly watery finish. Slightly spicy hop aroma is the only thing this beer has going for it...and it doesn’t go far.
Thanks to IslandHaole for this. Pours canary with big, white head. Aroma of malt, hopcit, some honey. Tastes malty, with honey and hopcit at the finish. Smooth, with decent complexity.
this beer has a sweet aroma, mild bitterness and malt and good medium palate. The only downside is a slight metallic tase.

I obviously had a good can compared to other here. Dark Golden color, thin head with a lightly lemon nose that oozes with clean maltiness. Full bodied and hoppy with just a touch of lemon dashing in and out of the tastebuds. Finishing dry and mildly bitter. I thought this was pretty good for the style.

Looks like any typical lager would. Clear and golden, small head, lively carbonation. As the others have mentioned, nothing noteworthy here. Too bad really, I'd expect a standout beer from this company.
Nothing to see hear really. Youve probably had about 100 beers that taste almost exactly the same. Its better than most macro lagers but nothing special.
Yes, a nice can but not a whole lot more. Something I could drink a lot of. Kind of like a Budweiser. Which isn't necessarily a good thing.
An unremarkable, fizzy, yellow lager that comes in a damn nice golden can. Sort of a Sapporo clone.

column1: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine
column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Can. Pours clear amber with a small light beige head. Caramel, brown sugar, bit of stone fruit, alcohol. Sweet warming finish.

column1: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine
column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: It pours chestnut brown with a beige head. It has a medium full body with semi sharp carbonation. It has over ripe fruit, toasted malt, brown sugar, dates and English yeast. Pretty nice. Not rich star, but for the price it's solid

column1: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine
column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Flaska importerad av Jonas. Bärnstensfärgad vätska. Doft av knäck, humle och barr. Mustig smak med tung maltkropp. Humle och lite druva. Sirap och trä.

column1: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine
column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Flaska, privatimport. Bärnstensfärgad med beige skum. Humlig och lite plastig doft. Lätt fruktig med inslag av aprikos.

column1: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine
column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: From Apr 2007 This one pours from 22oz bottle a clear deep amber with a medium sized head of foam. A couple of minutes in to the session, it shrinks to just a few islands in the middle and it has some lacing. The smell has a big nose of caramel malt with some hop notes floating in the background. The taste on first sip is also big on caramel malt but it is not overly sweet. A few more sips in and I'm getting some dark fruit flavours, and some hop bittererness...but not much. I'm also getting some roasted malt, some grain and a bit of an alcohol burn when it goes down but it's not objectionable in my opinion. This is a good BWSA. Bottom line: I picked this one up on my last trip to Ft Collins and it's a good example of the style. I'd buy it again.

column1: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine
column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Pours deep amber from the bottle. Aroma is apple brandy, caramel, schnapps. Taste is sweet, lightly peppery, full of alcohol, apple vinegar, and the warm presence of alcohol. Body is medium, with average carbonation. Finished me off for the night.

column1: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine
column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Deep garnet with a stiff khaki head. Appealing spicy earthy/piney hop aroma with toffee and grapey undertones (Vienna malt?). Some waxy and ethanol scents. Big, clean, spicy noble hop flavor and restrained maltiness. Spruce and burnt fig at the back of the tongue. Toasted cornmeal and leather. Not the caramel bomb that most brewers think defines the style. Juicy mouthfeel, not too thick. Carbonation has just enough lift to make the ale smooth and dangerously drinkable. Hop reemerge in the aftertaste, plus some pleasing coffeelike tannins. I love that it doesn’t taste like damn Chinook hops.

column1: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine
column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Rather alcohol filled and woody taste and it doesn’t really seem to be in harmony.

column1: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine
column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: (bottle) clear, fluorescent reddish amber colour with a small beige head; aroma of jam, stewed fruit; balanced flavour with a subdued, bit boozy flavour, long medium bitter finish; oily palate

column1: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine
column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Draught at the Santa Fe Brewing Co, Santa Fe, NM. Slightly cloudy deep mahogany color with a small creamy tan head. Sweet dark fruits, sweet sugar and sweet caramel malt in the aroma. Sweet it is. Sweet dark fruits, sugar, mild hoppy bitterness and caramel malt in the flavor.
Hazy amber color. Tart aroma, some hop, citrusy. Refreshing, slightly tart, pretty good malt and good hop. Interesting and original. Beers of Switzerland
amber-brown colour, nice creamy head, caramel and buttery aroma, creamy, strange sourness, dry fruity and caramel finish - infected ?
Piwo złote i klarowne. Dość fajna piana. Aromat słodowy, lekki diacetyl. Czuć estry. Średnie nagazowanie. W smaku słodowe, czuć posmak chmielu. Goryczka niska, ale obecna. Wodniste.
Bottle brought by a friend! Clear golden. Super bubbly head. Smell is a bit of rice. Taste is lots of rice and some sugar. Quite bitter.

Bottle @ [ Højbjerg Tasting ] - Saxo House, Højbjerg - Aarhus, Denmark. [ As SeyBrew Lager ]. [ As my country rating # 176 on ratebeer ]. Clear light to medium yellow colour with a small, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, pale malt, grain, corn, light cardboard. Flavor is light moderate sweet with a average duration, sweet malt, corn, grain. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20190419] 4-2-4-3-9

Bottle @ Johns. Pours clear light golden with an offwhite head. Aroma of malt, grain, corn, little fruit. Flavor is sweet, malt, grain, corn, little fruit. Medium body, average carbonation, light sweet finish. 220419
Sample. Clear pale yellow with tiny head. Aroma is malt, grainy and corn. Flavour is malt, grainy, corn, sweet, floral and very little bitter.
Sample @Højbjerg Tasting. Clear light golden, small white head. Sweet malt and light cornflake aroma. Sweet malty flavour, a little grain, a little cornflakes.

8/2/2019. Bottle and sample courtesy of Rasmus, cheers! Country #191. Pours pale gold with a white head. Aroma of corn, sweet malt, hops, light fruit. Medium sweetness, light bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily and watery texture, soft carbonation. Ok.
Aroma: Sweet corn. Flavour: Fruity sweet with sweet corn. Mouthfeel is watery. Colour: Pale yellow with a white head.

Bottle courtesy of ken1. Big thanks for sharing. Clear pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is sweet, light malty, cardboard and light corn. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. Watery. 020219

Great taste when there‘s nothing else than water. Looks fantastic in your hand with the sea in the back. Comparing it to Köpi, Fiege Pils, Küppers Kölsch or even Galway Hooker it‘s pretty drinkable. Although I must admit, that the other ones would probably also Taste good at the beach with 30 degrees 😋

An slighty orange coloured, a head is big and loght beige. Aroma is great, flowers and fruits, orange, apricot, sweetness and hint of spicyness. Taste has fruitness, fresh and riped, apricot, flowers, some spicyness in the end. Medium bodied. Good beer, complex and interesting.
Bottle. Color hazy orange with small white head. Aroma malt, some hop, yeast, some peach. Taste sweet, malt, some hop, yeast, spicy, fruits.

Avery Salvation Belgian Strong Ale 646412 Lukt: Malt, svak honning. Utseende: Gulbrun. Skum/kullsyre: Tynt dekkende, heng langs kant. Smak: Malt, krydder, frukter, karamell. Hvor: Samling hos Bryne. Medium: Flaske@650ml, ABV@9%, Når@27.04.2018.

From Jan 2007 Poured from 22oz bottle a clear light gold with a very large head of foam that shrank slowly leaving a fine solid layer and there's plenty of lacing. The smell is fruity and yeasty...about right for the style. The taste has some tartness that I noticed immediately with notes of semi sweet malt, hop bitterness, and yeast. A few more sips in and I'm getting some banana and clove but they're pretty sudued. The warming from the alcohol is there but not in abundance so that helps it to be pretty drinkable. Bottom line: This is a pretty good offering of the style from Avery and is at least worth trying.

640mL bottle from Carwyn Cellars, Melbourne. Pours a bright orange body, hazy, firm white head atop. Aroma quite fruity - orange, apricot, peach, toasty/bread crust malt, some spice in there. Big body, smooth texture, carbonation perhaps subdued for style but welcomed, good length. Toasty, cereally malts upfront on the body - leads onto notes of ripe apricot & yellow peach, savoury clovey/woody phenolic spice, finishes dry. Little indication of booze in this one, a nice drink, lacking a bit behind more authentic styles.

16.06.2017, 0,65l bottle shared @ local tasting: Big fizzy-creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly sweet floral, weeds, leafs, sap, minerals, yeast, grass, flowers, candi sugar, alcohol, old moss. Taste is slightly dry boozy, weeds, hay, alcohol, minerals, flowers, old leafs, grass, bark, paper, sawdust. Medium to longlasting bitterness, harsh mineraly mouthfeel. Boring.

[8953-20161227] 1pt6floz bottle. Burnt toasty caramel grains aroma. Clear, amber gold body with a quick foamy off-white head. Bitter caramel grains flavour has a sweet roasted finished. Medium-full body. Good. (8/3/8/4/15) 3.8 (c/o biegaman, w/ him, HogTownHarry, jercraigs, others) Overheard: "Lawyers always win, and border guards always win... And not always in that order."

On bottle from Vinmonopolet Aker Brygge. Clear golden color, good longlasting foam. Medium aroma intensity; honey, malt and fruitiness. Medium full body & complexity . A little on the sweet side. Very enjoyable ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Light gold color. Medium carbonation. Lots of malt aroma with some noble-like hops in there, clear notes of cookies and nuts. Clear alcohol aroma. Tastes quite dry and bitter, much more so than suggested by the smell. Lots of spicy phenols and hops. Quite good.
On draft at Isaacs. Sampled with Junior. Nice notes of Apricot, sugar, bread and spice. The blend was really nice.
Clear golden with a frothy head. Strawy, yeasty smell. Very smooth taste, it has the texture of an orange juice with the distinct hoppy and malty taste of a normal beer. Low carbonation.
Bottle from Euro summer Santa. Thanks! This is on of better helles I've tried so far. Full malty taste, sweetish, low bitterness, crisp. Tasty I would say

500ml bottle brewed in Germany at 4.9%. Crystal clear gold. Nice-sized fluffy head, superb duration. Sweet grassy aroma, minimal corn. Low carbonation, just a tongue-tickle, unusual for the style but welcome. Smooth mouthfeel extends to the flavour - slightly bitter grassy (almost lemony) hops and very mild sweet malt, brown bread-esque when it reveals itself. Splendid hell, simple and refreshing with not a single duff note, none of the corn in the aroma to be found in the flavour. This is not my preferred style of beer, but this particular brew I would not mind drinking any time at all. Ayinger is probably my top pick of German brewers, and may well be the most skilled if my opinion is anything to go by.
On tap at the brewery. Clear yellow pour with a white head. Clean, light, and refreshing. Malty with hints of corn. Average body and mouthfeel.

500ml bottle @ Chez Sophie. Pours a clear glowing gold, good white head. Sweet malt emerging on the nose. Taste presents a noticeable sweet start before settling somewhat, still retaining a pleasantly sweet malt character, clean and very well-rounded with doughy honey hints along the way. Excellent Bavarian lager.

Thanks, Alex, for telling me I have never rated this one. Clear golden. Grainy aroma, slightly floral. Slightly sugary. Sweet. Malty, grainy. Good balance. Light body, soft carbonation, light sweet finish.

Aroma; malt, caramel, straw, herb, wort. Look; offwhite head on near clear golden body. Taste; bread, malt, mash, caramel, juicy syrup tart, straw, bun, and finishes well malted. Feel; good body n ok co². Overall; it`s a nice n easygoing beer. [vom Faß sehr gut @Oktober-fest]

Pięknie prezentujące się piwo, złociste klarowne z obfitą pianą która ładnie zdobi szkło. Aromat lekko słodowy, trochę kwiatów i owoców. W smaku lekko słodowe, drobne nuty owocowe, praktycznie bez goryczki. Bdb hell w stylu monachijskim
Супер отличный лагер. Давно такого не пробовал. Солод,Хмель...Все что нужно в жару. Пьется легко. Запах...Что то невероятное.
Bottle picked up in Booths Carnforth. Deep gold thin head clean and rich lovely lager

A very pretty amber copper with a tall and firm white head. Very balanced crystal sweet malts and citrus. Medium bodied. Nice medium bitterness in the finish. This isn’t earth shattering just a fine IPA.
Earthy amber ale, rich and hoppy with caramelly, biscuity malt. Sweet, and a light hop bitterness.

On tap at Hood Canal, pours a hazy dark golden with a small white head. Aroma reveals notes of resinous and bittering hops. Flavour is overmalted, with bitter resinous hops and bready caramel malt. The balance isn’t so good, with too much malt and a weird hop characteristic. Not impressive.
Draft - Sweet citrus hops with some nice floral notes. Clear gold with a thin white head. Earthy hops, pale malts and a lasting bitterness.
October 2012. Bottle. Amber color with a white head. Nice aromas, but a bit bland and out of balance. Somewhat acidic on the finish.

Hazy orange, big white head. Aroma reminds me of Brett and Belgian IPA right off the bat with lots of tropical fruit and sweet malt. also kind of a lemonade thing going on. Note sure if this yeast is supposed to be so dominant. It’s not terrible, but it is a little on the sweet side and has too much yeasty gum flavor for my liking. Medium thin body, sweet and mildly bitter finish

Bomber from a Fred Meyer on 196th St in Seattle. Pours amber with a foamy 4 finger near white head. Maybe beige. Aroma is rather citric. Med body. Flavor starts a bit cardboard and metallic. There’s a caramel backbone and some citric/grapefruit. It’s nicely bitter. Bitter is the best point.

Bottle: &nbsp Orangish side of amber, slight haze, thin white head, spotty lacing, very light carbonation &nbsp Soft hop aroma, some sweet and zesty citrus rind too. &nbsp Fairly sweet on the tongue, hoppy but not biting. &nbsp Seems fairly malty too. &nbsp Does fall a bit flat as far as mouthfeel, lacks carbonation. &nbsp Lingering earthiness and soil. &nbsp Sweet citrusy aftertaste. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to thin. &nbsp Decent IPA, better than I was expecting but it needs to be more lively. &nbsp Sweeter than most, and less bitter. &nbsp Not bad.

Clear and copper-orange with a nice head -- tightly packed, creamy bubbles and big, bursting bubbles. Creamy carbonation created a nice softness on the tongue. Very fruity and flowery. In the background, I detected an odd, "synthetic" perfume quality, which was a bit off putting. I loved the sweet tropical fruit flavors, though. And the mild yet balancing bitterness. RERATE bottle: Overly carbonated; head overflowed with a gentle pour. Sharp and acidic on the tongue. Had some curiously interesting flavors; kind of reminded me of a Belgian ale. Hops were perfumey and floral. Very slight sweetness surfaced, like rock candy and scorched toffee. Overall, odd but decent beer.

Received 22-oz bomber via trade with 5000. Pours a semi-hazy orange amber colored brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that quickly dissipates to a thin ring. Aroma of caramel malt, some citrus zest a hint of dill, vanilla and grapefruit. Taste is medium bodied, a touch more malty flavor than hops with a touch of sweet apple. Finish is semi-dry with a hint of citrus and lemon aftertaste.
tap at the Bräustüberl. Golden yellow, tall white head. Full-bodied, solid and slightly sweet malty base, good grassy hops round it off.
Golden color, foam disappears quickly. Malty aroma. A little hoppy and caramel malty taste. Sweet and malty, but not balanced, and a little bit watery.

Der Stieglbock wurde im verregneten Frühling 2019 palettenweise beim Diskonter Hofer abverkauft; da nachm ich eine Flasche mit, um eine alte Bewertung nachzuprüfen und ich finde es passt ganz gut. Es ist ein vollmundiges Bockbier mit fruchtigen, schweren Grundtönen. Kein leichtes Bier, aber als Bockbier ganz gut erwischt.
Fles 50cl thuis. Zoetig, wat kruidig, drogige nadronk. (1-2014).-----------.
Süß getreidiger, trocken hellmalziger Beginn. Zu starke Süße, dadurch unsüffig, monoton, mittelstarke Würzigkeit. Leicht erhöhte Karbonisierung. Naja.. 10/7/7/8/9/7
The beer has got a deep golden colour with a small head and smooth body. Aroma of malt and barley. Taste of hops, malt, bread, barley, caramel and hay. Vanilla and barley finish.
Keg at Draft House London. Clear amber. Nose is sweet malty, caramel, ripe banana. Tastes big sweet caramel, hay, some fruitiness. Ok.
Aroma: caramel and malt. Taste: very malty and sweet. Plate: medium carbon, medium body, sweet alcoholic finish.
Goldgelbe Farbe, blank. Feinporiger, weißer Schaum. Hopfenaromatisch, alkoholaromatisch. Im Antrunk süßlich, karamelig mit Fruchtnoten. Im Mund cremig. 0,5l-Flasche am 29.12.17
Clear dark golden with a big white head; aroma is malty grainy, slightly herbal; taste is malty and grainy, herbal hops, low bitterness, some lingering sweetness; texture is a little sticky

Slightly brown deep orange without much of a head. Definitely get fruit in both the aroma and flavor overlaying herbal hops and a sweet caramel base. They served this on nitro as part of the tasting flight, delicious creamy mouthfeel.

I have drunk many moon dog bitters from Great Lakes, and was surprised to find a different ESB on tap at the brewpub during my last visit. The malt on this one tastes less sour than I remember moon dog as (I did not try them side-by-side though), and I think the beer tastes cleaner and fresher as a result. A middle-of-the-road beer that is light in color, and much less hoppy than an IPA or Burning river, but still has relatively strong hops. I think I might prefer if Great Lakes retired moondog and replaced it with this one, but I’d have to try them side-by-side to make a definitive judgment on that matter.

yellow with huge white head. nose of citrus hops. firm bitterness before nice citrus hop flavor without much malt component in this one. the interesting malt is the creamy head and moutfeel of this beer, likely secondary to a lot of wheat malt. overall an interesting beer that doesn’t really have a style, but is mostly enjoyable

On-tap at the brewpub. Hazy orange-golden color, with one finger frothy white head. Smell is of citrus and slightly floral. Big biscuity malt flavor, nicely balanced with the beer’s light hop bitterness (even if light, it tastes more bitter than other ESBs I’ve had). Medium body and carbonation.

Tap at the brewery. Deep amber pour with a thin white head. The aroma is quite spicy with a little bit of light orange marmalade character. A little bit earthy and lightly fruity. Soft and spicy with a nice light lingering sweetness. Earthy malts with some light spiciness on the finish. Well-balanced and fairly easy to put back.
tap @ Great Lakes - golden yellow pour. Smooth caramel malts, some grain notes and even a bit warm. Drinkable but not exciting.

On tap at Great Lakes on our way to RBSG. Pours a clear orange gold with a medium sized white head. Soft and lightly bitter, toast and a bit of caramel. Nice lightly sweet toasted malt. Medium bodied, very gentle and easy drinking. Soft bitterness on the finish. Really sessionable and quite tasty.
On tap at GLBC. Clear copper pour with a thin white head. Floral and citrus hop aroma up front with English malt on the back end. English malt flavor up front with a hoppy finish. Solid ESB.

Sample from a growler at Goodbar Beer Club, 5/09. Lighter gold, thin white head. Nose is bready malts, some lemony hops, a little mint. Flavor wise there is a really nice hop profile - mint & pine, with caramel. Breadiness comes out in the finish. I’d love to be able to drink this regularly.

Pours a clear copper with a creamy head that lingers and clings to the glass. Hops and a toasted malt make up the bulk of the aroma and flavor. The malt is verging on rich. Full, lingering bitterness.
Bit on the watery side with hop dominance that was all off kilter. The Seuss in me loved the name and made me say "no Pat, NO, don’t sit on THAT!"

Pale, weak head. I still gave it a 4 on appearance because of the cool tap handle, which had Grandpa Simpson on it. I could hardly detect any aroma, and the flavor consisted of poorly balanced Centennial hops. Blaugh. One of their worse efforts.
Bottle. This beer was not stored under good conditions. Hazy yellow colour with small white head. Very malty aroma. Sweet malty flavor. Watery palate.

Golden, head OK. The aroma is malty, and the taste is too, I also get notes of ryebread in the top of my palate in the last part of the finale in this otherwise rather sweet beer. I’m sorry to say that I do not like it...

I had a few of these back in 2002 and I still have one unopened one, though it is proberly very undrinkable now. Bottle. Yellow colour short head. Aroma of malts and hops with some sweetish fruitiness. Flavour of some toasted malts and good hoppiness. Thin aftertaste though. Nothing special.

(Bottle 33 cl) Golden beer with a lightly creamy head. Full-bodied with some malty sweetness and less bitter hops than what’s usual for Thisted. Apparently this has been lagered way longer than usual - even for Thisted. 140302
Bottle. Pale yellow colour, short lasting white head. Sourish aroma. Some malt. Notes of vinegar. Sour flavour. Some bitterness.
Bottled: Pale yellow. Clear. White dense head. Sweet, full and fruity aroma. Flavour is mild and a little boring. Not many nuances. Some malt and some sweetness. Is thin and watery in the end.
Pale golden, white lasting head. Sweetish flavour well balanced by hops. Some perfumy notes too. Overall a good pilsener.
Like most beers. Yellow, clear. Low head. Not much aroma. But the flavor has some sweetness. Bogmyrtle???
Golden. Non existing head but Lots of carbonation. Citrus and malts in aroma. Thin sweetness combined with balanced malts and citrus flavors. A nice balanced lager with potential.

Pours a tall snow white head on a clear yellow body. Aroma of brewing mash and some citrus in the background - somewhat mouldy. Flavor is quite sour with lemon notes and some malt and hops specially in the finish. Actually a quite fresh but rather thin lager. Would be nice outside on a warm summerday!
Bottle at a mini-RB gathering in November. Poured a clear copper color with a small white head. Aroma was earthy hops, light barley. Flavor was barley, bread.

Color cobrizo tirando a marrón, cristalina. Dos dedos de espuma con retención media. Aroma discreto a cereal y miel. Gusto a malta tostada, caramelo y ligero amargor herbal. Cuerpo acuoso. Amber clásica sin mucho que resaltar pero sin defectos.
From a bottle at the RB mini gathering in November. Pours a clear copper. Aromas are minty and bready. Flavors are sweet but decent.
More aroma than some of the pale lagers by these guys but mostly just rust. Copper pour with decent head. Tangy finish. Bottle.
Bottle @ home. Pours a copper colored liquid with a tan head. Malt-sweet aroma and taste with bread, syrup, toffee and cereals. Some fruitiness lingering.
A nice fresh tasting easy drinking Lager. Another nice product from Föroya Bjór.

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega piirdun iga õlle juures selle tekstiga.
Aroma: Malty sweet with ripe fruits. Flavour: Malty sweet with nutty notes and caramel. Aftertaste is sweet. Colour: Nut brown with a fading head. From: Bottle @ VildMedVin webshop Apr. 2019.
Bottle at Matt's Clean amber colour. Grainy aroma, grainy flavour, sweet, with low bitterness. Boring.

330ml bottle @ Matt's. Pours a clear amber copper colour with a small beige head. Nose is bready malt with some estery sweet notes. Flavour is similar, bread malty, light esters, and some mild spices. Decent.

Hazy copper orange body and off white, firm head. Mild spicy aroma, tutti frutti, sweet white bread and resin hops. Full, sweet taste with a fine bitter hop backup. Rich bodied, bit of alcohol. Marked on the bottle as saison, which I suppose it is. Very nice, fits my taste perfectly. (33cl bottle, cheaply bought at the brewer’s shop)

(Bottle 33 cl) Pretty and very simplistic label. Beautiful amber colour, slightly hazy with a dense head. Full, malty body with a perfect balance between sweet and bitter. Pleasantly spiced. Very distinct sediment. 071102
Best until jan ’05. Creamy citrusaroma and flavor. Hoppy, in fact an almost oily hoppiness. Long citric hopbitter finish. Very well balaced beer. Excellent!

Amber colour, generous head. Nice sweet aroma of malt, caramalt, hop, wallnuts. Harmonious mouth of malt and hop. Dry and bitter finish, with good caramalt and hop. When warmer, it gets sweeter, maltier, and of course also the caramel raises. Not outstanding, but fully enjoyable, to try again.

Strange, an American style pale ale from the Netherlands. Big citrusy floral hop aroma. I thought it was perhaps a tad sweet at the start, but the robust bitterness makes up for that. very enyoyable, as per says, very fresh tasting. I great little find.
Red-orange, slightly hazy. Big grapefruit hop aroma. Fruity, dry big hop flavour and really bitter finish. Fresh and tasty. Excellent!
Bottled. Amber coloured. Aroma of anis. Sweet and spicy flavour with alcoholic notes.

(Bottle 30 cl) Beautiful reddish amber with a gigantic head that refuses to settle. Unique spiciness sort of Orval-style. An almost vinous character. Presumably dry, but you sense an underlying sweetness and a discreet bitter finish. Nowhere close to any other Bock I’ve tried. Try to ignore the label art.... 300902
Authentic. A strong alcoholic taste. Quite fruity and powerful. No head. A diffent beer.
An amber beer with a white disappearing head. The aroma is sweet alcoholic with notes of oranges. The flavor is of cloves and peach. You can feel the alcohol. It ends on a dry note. An OK beer.

Orange-amber, very hazy, flunky even. Yellowish head, fast gone to white rim. Nose with chalk, rich malt, toffee, spicy. Taste: Licoriceflavour. And more licorice, to the exclusion of anything else, but a spicy-tingling tongueside sensation. Gives only licorice-aroma. Whatever sweetness there is, does not conform to licorice-sweetness. Again a citrussy-spicy flavour. Fairly refreshing for all its ABV, but there is some burning sensation that is too pronounced for me. A bit tart, spicy aftertaste, fairly long. This is the second Haerlemsche beer that has this spicy bite I dislike. Tastes like a homebrew-try, and not the best.

Purchased at De Bier Koning in Amsterdam on 5-25-03. Pours a cloudy blond with a small fluffy white head. The aroma is similar to a wheat beer - cloves, yeast, but with a sugary sweetness in the mix. Very pleasant! Very sweet taste, with the alcohol making it presence known. Perhaps candy sugar, honey, and fruit. Finishes with a little of the alcohol and more of the sweetness. Another interesting Haerlemsche beer. I almost want to say that they are as unique as Fantome, but that would be making too great a comparison. Plus Fantome is pure quality and Haerlemsche has been a little lacking from my experience. All in all, though, this was very good.
Aroma has honey, apricot, cherry and liquor. Flowery, very perfumed taste, like cologne, with rosebuds, alcohol and orange. Very good lacing, but not a very refined beer.
The beer is labelled with a photocopied label, however I bought it and it was definately worth the try. Nice fine bock-taste, nice sweet taste.

I thoght this was OK, but it does come across as a bit *amatuerish* as per says. Quite Belgian in taste, even though it was a bock. Some of the ugliest and largest blocks of sediment known to man sit at the bottom, isntantly taking marks off appearance. It was also funny to see the photocopied label, this brewer must have a really small production.

Dark orange very cloudy. Huge flower and apple aroma. Very malty with nice orange flavour which is overpowered by the big floweryness. The label looks like it's been made on a bad copying machine, and the beer tastes like a homebrew. Amateurish but interesting and flavourful, and in the end pretty good.
Clear golden colour, white foam. Bready, some notes of hay, soft carbonation, easy drinkable.

bread, hay, pale, golden, amber, orange, red, brown, sparkling, hazy, clear, light sweetness, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium sourness, light body, medium body, thin feel, oily feel, fizzy, lively,
On tap at Reichold. Golden with a lasting white head. Malty aroma with herbal hops and DMS. Sweetish malty flavour with a nice hoppy finish.
Pours clear Golden with a white head. Aroma of ceral, bready, slight grass, light herbal, yeast - Minerals. Light bitter, bready.

Drank from a Krug at Landbierparadies on Wodanstr. Honestly can't remember if it was on draft or from a bottle. Notes: "Sweetish, cool mineral/iron scent, some nutty sweet vanilla grain notes. Mild buttery diacetyl. Light, tangy, earthy bitterness."
11-11-17 // bottle shared. Clear amber golden. Small head. Sweet malty, some caramel. Smooth. Solid.

500ml bottle. Clear, orangey, dark golden colour with average, frothy, moderately lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Husky, minimally bready, yeasty doughy aroma, hints of buttermilk. Taste is spicy pale malty, husky, bready, hints of bread crust, grassy hints of fresh hay, minimally tart hints of buttermilk, subtle malt sweetness; oily texture, smooth and soft palate, gentle, refreshing carbonation. Very good.
Bernsteinfarben, mit kurzlebiger Krone. Schön würzig und feingehopft, leider ist hier ganz schön viel Kohlensäure drin, deshalb wird die Süffigkeit stark beeinträchtigt.

Bottle from Bierotek Bamberg. Clear amber colour lasting cream head. Yes a pleasant standard drinking lager bier some malt some good hops on the finish. slightly peppery hop . very drinkable. decent nutty malt. fine.
Vom Fass im Brauhaus ins Aufsess als "Helles". Dunkles Gelb, feiner Schaum. Grassiger Duft. Süsslich im Antrunk. Leichter Honig. Recht schnell weg.

This is a backlog rating from 2007 from a bottle shared by Tmoney99, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are citrus, pale malts, mild funk, hay.

Bottle from Willems, best before may 2018. Poors dark amber with thick, dense, pale mocha head. Aroma tasty and of good strength: pear syrup, sourish red currant, fruity caramel, light fruity hops, syrupy but not too sweet. Taste the same, well balanced and tasty but distinctly metallic too, maybe the age. Soft, dense MF, soft carbonation. Might have to taste a fresher one to appreciate the full taste.

A golden ale with a thin light mocha head. In aroma, sweet caramel malt with light honey and corn, oxidized notes, light grassy hops, OK. In mouth, a sweet fruity malt with loads of oxidation, treacle, light butterscotch, OK.

Aroma: Slight aroma of malts, caramel, Belgian yeast, fruit and grain. Appearance: Hazy/turbid amber/orange beer with a slight/medium off-white head. Taste/Palate: Starts medium sweet with malts, caramel, Belgian yeast and fruit; ends slightly dry with grain. Overall: This beer is rather intense and balanced, but lacks complexity. The flavour is more intense than the aroma, but both are still lacking. Okay beer, but nothing to write home about.
Helder roodgeel bier met weinig schium. Smaak is licht bitter zoet met iets van honing,, verder licht bitter met veel nuances. Erg goed, komt ietwat waterig over, vrij licht van structuur.
2/4/2009 6:41:54 AM Cracked Kettle. Amber body. Large head. Sweet nose. Taste of fruits, some caramel and quite spicy. Slightly bitter.
Très trouble. Mousse qui retombe vite. Odeur de miel. Goût de miel et puis plus grd chose. Bière peu intéressante.
It started with a fruity aroma and finished on a strong honey taste. Not a bad thing in fact, but you have to enjoy honey, because it’s what you’ll get.
Strong honey aroma. In the mouth we’re still on the honey side. Interesting aroma but the rest is a bit disappointing.

330ml bottle. Clear amber color. Medium size, beige head, stays. Raisins, fart, malty, sweet, metaboli in aroma. Metallic, malty, sweet, bit yeasty in taste. Metallic and malty in aftertaste. Messy and alcoholic. Brrrrr.

22-11-2019; bottle; at home (bought at an unknown location, courtesy of a friend). The looks of the beer are quite nice. The beer has a delicious ruby red/reddish amber colour. The beer has some haziness. On top of the beer there is a nice layer of soft slightly greyish-brown foam. Foam retention is low, but a nice creamy drape is left on top of the beer. Not bad. The aroma of the beer is nice, but it is not that special. The malts give some caramel and toffee notes. Hops are herbal. There are some notes of liquorice too. It is nice, but for a Grand Cru? It lacks some interesting features and some depth and layers. I miss something in here. The taste of the beer is fine, but again it misses that specialness. Sweet malts, bitter hops, a sour note there too. It is a bit astringent somehow. Could be more balanced. The palate of the beer is alright. Medium body, a bit sticky texture and a medium carbonation. The finish of the beer is soo-soo. Also a bit astringent. I expected more of the beer. Could be more special.

330 ml bottle, from Det Bette Ølhus, Aalbæk. ABV is 9.5%. Clear and deep reddish brown colour, large off-white head. Aroma of malts, caramel, brown kandij sugar, hints of mild spices. Smooth mouthfeel. Lovely malty flavour, caramel and brown kandij sugar again, but not too sweet, spicy hints. Moderate hops.

Color marrón rojizo, brillante, sin turbiedad, translúcida. Espuma marfil de tres dedos de espesor y buena retención. Aroma a cereal, cereal ligeramente tostado, frutos rojos, vino tinto, azúcar moreno y notas de chocolate. Sabor en esa línea, los frutos rojos más evidentes, leve cereza, al atemperar desaparecen, final dulce, alcohol inapreciable, al atemperar es más evidente pero sigue bien integrado. Textura entre acuosa y oleosa. Carbonatación media alta.
Lichtbruin bier met ruime witte kraag. Licht gezoet van smaak met zeer zachte afdronk
Lichtbruin bier met voldoende koolzuur. Geur, mout, kandij, fruit. Smaak gebrande mout, gebrande suiker, fruit, kruidig. Medium, zoet mondgevoel. Nasmaak, mout, kandij, kruidig, fruit. Zoet .
0.33l bottle. Orangish brown body with a pearl head. Aroma and taste of candi sugar, toast, orange zest, pears, red wine and some booze. OK beer.
Heel behoorlijke dubbel. Zacht zoetig, licht rozijnig en makkelijk drinkbaar. Prima te doen.
Ale fuerte belga. Marron-ambar. espuma densa que desaparece. Gusto dulce equilibrado, malta. retrogusto ligeramente amargo. Muy buena.

Bottle at home. Murky reddish amber colour, big creamy beige head: looking good. Really malt forward, honey, grainy, bready, slightly vinous, apples, some sweetish dried fruit, light bitter finish. Pleasantly balanced and actually complex, medium body, prickly carbonation.
Rödbrun, nästan klar. Maltig, syrlig doft. Smaken tillför dessutom fruktighet, körsbär o dadlar. Måttlig beska avslutar.
Geproefd op 24-11-2013. Lekkere blonde tripel van brouwerij Van Steenberge in Ertvelde. Zou een etiketbier zijn van Bornem Tripel.

The tripel in this series, deep hazy golden blonde with snow white head; yeasty and estery fruity main character on a somewhat caramelly malt base, sweetish, smooth with yeasty, herbally hoppy and somewhat alcoholic finish. Not too interesting and I bet this is an alias of something else, a practice often executed by Van Steenberge. Should do a retasting with Bornem Tripel right next to it...

8/XII/12 - 33cl bottle @ Culinair Bierfestival (Waasmunster) - BB: n/a (2012-1336) Thanks to Kris for sharing today’s beers! Clear yellow beer, big creamy white head, adhesive, pretty stable. Aroma: paint, chemical, citrus, dusty, yeasty, little fruity, white candi sugar. MF: lively carbon, medium body. Taste: citric start, yeasty touch, herbal, bitter, grassy hops. Aftertaste: white candi sugar, bitter touch, alcohol noticeable.

33 cl bottle @ home. Appears to have very lively carbonation as thousands of bubbles find there way up to the big, very solid, completely lasting, thick vast white head. Clear tripel-golden color. This is what a tripel should look like imo! Wow! Aroma is a big disappointment after such a good appearance. Malts, slightly musty, hay. Taste isn’t good either. Too bad. Malts, overripe fruits, a wrong kind of tart-bitterness. Weird. Too much carbonation as well. Unfortunate, it started out so well.
33cl bottle. decent white head. Hazy blond colour. slight bitter aftertaste
Golden coloured beer with a good head. Smell is citrus, spices and yeast. A bit to much herbs, alcohol isn’t hidden that good. Hops gets trough also, but it’s not what I expected.
Bottle in Waasmunster. Pours clear yellow, unequal large bubbly white head. Hay / cereal aroma with grassy hoppiness. A bit metallic. Quite watery, cidery and boring overall.
23rd October 2008. Hazy gold beer. Dry and floral. Wheaty dry tones with a little fruit. Very dry finish with some spice. A hint of caraway in there.
Bottle: A filtered clear golden with a frothy white lacing head. Aroma is fermented fruit. Taste is crisp fruit with nice dry warming finish.

Bottled. Hazy golden, rich head. Fruity nose with pickled onion. Swet and fruity with odd flavour of cornichon and pineapple. Juicy with well hidden alcohol, no bitterness. Not the most complex tripel ever but withsome unusual flavours.

On tap at the 2009 NABA. I was told that this brewery has come under new ownership and has reopened. Pours a light amber color with a medium white head. The aroma was rich caramel malts, light hops as well. A smooth flavor of caramel malts, light citrus hops as well. Pretty decent and quaffable.
On tap @ Dr. Hops. Pours a golden yellow color. Aromas of hops and a touch of malt. Flavor is a creamy malt and a nice citrus hop. Could use more hops though.

The aroma is the best quality of this beer; it is fresh and hoppy. The taste is thin and likewise hoppy, but not well-balanced. Color is on the golden side of amber. No head formation, so no retention, and only fair evidence of lace.

Honey colored with a small head. It has a hop smell and taste with a hint of malt. The bottle has a slightly soapy taste too. Might be a pretty good beer if it was really fresh. With a name like "Dr. Hops" though it isn't as hopped as a lot of beers.

A bland understated APA, this tastes a bit outdated. Not in age, but style. It just wasn't that impressive for a pale ale. I'm not the tyle to lower the rating based on hop content, but this just straight up didn't have enough hops for a modern APA.

I honestly think this is a pale ale in name only, or perhaps I could have purchased an old bottle. I taste hardly any hops at all, tasted lots of honey and malt. Soda like head that is gone almost as soon as you pour it. No complexities at all, and very bland and boring.
bought in a Pocatello gas station and consumed on the road. mild hop nose, nice golden color but no head. unchecked rough hop taste throughout, hardly any malt

pomeranian orange, with haze and unidentified floating objects, presumably it''s either bottle conditioned or it''s the chunky variety pale ale. dish water head just bums a ride for awhile, it''s thin as hobo trousers. a faint damp root-cellar smell suggests it''s past it''s prime, though it was purchased near the brewery. aside from that, it''s a malty, caramel pale, hop occurring more in a moderate finish than in the aroma. overall kind of a home-brew quality. pretty good, tho fred eckhart probably won''t come begging for the recipe.
Huge hops on the nose, good solid head. Nice citrus and malt flavors. Fine beer from Idaho Falls.
GABF 2002: Bright gold, thick head. Nice citric aroma. Creamy caramel and full malt flavor. Nice citric hops round out the malt. Well balanced.

Too flat and suurpy for my taste. It had carbonation bubbles but it still had that flat heavy taste to it. I will give it points for flavor and aroma because there was definitely a lot going on there.

Homebrewing at its finest. Certainly not Barley's best offering but if their annual Homebrew Fest yields beers of this caliber I am going to make it a point to try them. Similar to an APA in color. Light hops aroma. Satisfyingly rich malt flavor. This beer definitely has character.
Not quite up there with Barleys other offerings but still a good beer. Very malty and sweet. Very little hop presence.

This beer was the winner of last year's home brewmaster contest that they held and is currently on tap. It is a nice golden color with a decent white head which left some lace. Had some aroma of hops and slight aroma of malt. The taste was definately of hops, but not overpowering. The homebrewer, who's batch was number 666 hence the name, did a good job.
Cask by handpump at Four Marys, Linlithgow (25 May 12) - clear brown ale, bubbly tan head, sweet roasted malt, sweet, toffee, high carbonation
Cask Handpump at Wetherspoons, Manchester 30/05/2002 Golden colour. Poured lively. Hoppy and slightly rich on the palate. Lasting malt finish.
A jubilee special. Quite fruity for a bitter. There is an unusual cider-like acidicy to this beer. Strange but recommended. One for even the staunchest republican!
Offwhite small head, dark golden colour. Strong dominating hoppy flavour, malts. Hoppy, dull taste.
amber colour, sweet-bitter aroma, soft palate, some carbonation. Light bitter finish. Easy drinker

(Bottle 25 cl) Beautiful amber colour, although the label rather confusingly claims that this beer is "light as a pilsener". I mean, whats the point in producing an amber if you’d rather it looked like a pils? Anyways, De Smedt didn’t succeed - this is an archetypical "Amber" or "Speciale" in the same vein as De Koninck or Palm. Small, creamy head. Some caramel sweetness balanced by some hoppiness. High carbonation. 120305 and 111199
Amber beer with offwhite head. Te armoa is a bit metalic. Taste is thin and watery with some sweetness.
Bottle. (Label says Cabbac Speciale Amber). Sourish, bitter hop aroma. Dark amber colour. Caramel, spice hints. Quite boring, though. Aftertaste is yeasty and a bit like cheap lager.
An amber beer with a huge orange head. The aroma is sweet spicy while the flavor is sweet with primary notes of caramel and lesser notes of spices, while the body is thin.
Bottle. Golden colour with a small white head. Sweet light barnyard aroma and a light sour taste. Medium body and a light sour finish.

Bottle - in a side-by-side tasting with Op-Ale (wiich I heard of as being the same beer as this one Clear, amber body. Moslty lasting lightly brown head. Fair lace. Nose of yeats (light - dough) and hops (moderately - flowers) Lightly bitter, lightly sweet initial flavour. Lightly bitter finish. Slightly watery. Result of the side-by-side: the beers aren’t exactly the same. They are very similar, but the GB beer is a little bit more watery.

Typical bulk brew for Belgian supermarket chain GB. Amber copper clear with medium small white head. Faint hops, malt, acrylic plastic and sour milk aromas. Weak non-descript watery body. Bland mild bitter and some malt flavours with that plastic thing coming through at the end again. Fortunately they come in 250 cc bottles and I only bought one.
