Poured into a becher pint glass, the appearance was a dark brown color with a finger’s worth of white to off white foamy head that dissipated at a moderate pace. Subtle sliding lace. The aroma had some toast, nutty sweetness and crisp roastiness, some milk chocolate and then caramel/toffee malts. The flavor blended fairly well between the nuts and caramel/toffee malts. Chocolate lays further back in this department. Pillowy smooth sweet nuts and caramel/toffee malts in the aftertaste and finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sessionability about it. Moderate carbonation. ABV felt good as projected. Overall, good English styled brown ale worthy of having again.
APPEARANCE - perfect brown color. Nice light brown head with real persistence. NOSE - excellent maltiness. FLAVOR - excellent malty flavor with nice balanced. NOTES - excellent spot on brown ale.

Had on draft @ the Ellicottville brewpub in Ellicottville, NY .. . Had as Buchanan Brown .. . deep molasses and bark .. . pours a ruby brown .. medium lacing .. nutty deep roast .. . very surprising and tasty .. . . And also, you should win things by watching.

Got a 12 oz single from Oliver’s in Albany. A deep ruby brew with thin tan head. Good carbonation. Nice deep nutty aromas. Flavor is deep and malty. Lots of dark malts, some nuts. Almost porter-like with the roastiess. Chocolate and coffee notes. Well balanced. Slight fruitiness on the backside. Smooth and very quaffable, like a good brown should be.

Pours a dark brown color with a small tan head. Smells like roasted nuts with a little bit of chocolate. Taste is mild, slight nutty flavor. Not too shabby. EBC has better brews though, and there are better brown ales as well, but this is worth a try.

Bottle from Half Time. Pours dark amber with a decent foamy beige head. Roast caramel and "nutty" aromas. Med body. Flavor is that roast caramel with dirt typical of a brown ale. There’s some definite bitter behind the malt. So it’s pretty balanced and arguably more bitter than malty. Pretty clean for a brown.

On tap at Mr. Goodbar’s. Big brown sweetness with some spice. Not necessary but I just like to have a beer here. Reddish brown colour. Medium mouthfeel, carbonation right there. Not greatly drinkable.

Bottle into mug (sampled 6/20/10). Poured a clear medium brown with a one finger short lasting head. Aroma pulled in some nice nutty notes with a hint of the hops and a little sugar in there too -- very interesting. Very smooth in the mouth and while the malt sweetness was present it wasn’t as overpowering as I thought it would be and the hops added the right amount of bite at the finish to keep this refreshing. Overall a pretty good one!

12 ounce bottle. Pours a clear light brown color with a medium white head. The aroma is a sweet nutty malt and fruity hop. The flavor is a nice very hoppy brown ale; sweet caramel and toasted malts, pine and bitter hops, almost like a Brown IPA (just kidding), dry and malty. Very nice. An easygoing brew.

Ellicottville Nut Brown is a very clear copper ale with a foamy, waxy, bubbly khaki head that has excellent retention and lacing. It has a toasty, nutty aroma with notes of grass and flowers. It’s pretty light bodied and a little sharp. The finish is chewy. It has a light but well balanced taste, not sweet or dry. It’s toasty and nutty, just like the aroma. The finish is a little bitter with herbs and grass. The aftertaste is nutty. This is very drinkable. This would be an acceptable session ale.
From old tasting notes. Hazy yellow gold color topped by a big foamy white head. Sweet malt nose with a hint of noble hops. Dryish malt flavor upfront. Tart malty middle. Bitter dry hoppy finish.
Hop malt aroma. Clear yellow colour. Bitter malt hop flavour. Borning. Test of 01.10.2005.

#1156 Das Bier zum abgewöhnen, igitt!! Der Anker im Label zieht definitiv sämtliche Geschmacksknospen in die Tiefe...Herr Ober, ein Wasser bitte! Traurig aber wahr. Für mich bis dato das mit Abstand schlechteste Bier der Welt! Dagegen sind Billigheimer wie Oettinger und Hansa geradezu geschmackliche Offenbarungen; hätte nie gedacht, dass ich sowas mal schreiben würde, tsetse. Macht um diese Plörre am besten einen riesengroßen Bogen oder erlebt euer Bier-Waterloo in Reinkultur...

Ho riso, tanto! Non è raro ridere a causa della birra, ma sicuramente non capita tutti i giorni di dimenticare una lattina per mezza giornata nel freezer. Straordinaria idea, l’ho versata nel bicchiere da pils e in fondo tutto bene, poi comincia ad uscire del ghiaccio mollo sembra granita!!! Favoloso, ne ho dovuto togliere un po’ col cucchiaio perché mi faceva impressione bere ’sta roba. Poi ne ho bevuti due sorsi e il resto l’ho buttato! Ottima, la migliore birra mai assaggiata...

Can 500 ml 4.9% AVB. Brought to Sweden from Germany by a friend of mine. Clear golden color, big white creamy head, but non-lasting. Fresh malty scent. Light malty taste. Quite watery mouthfeel. Low bitterness.
Can (4.9%). Very little aroma. Golden colour. OK, stable white head. Quite watery flavour, otherwise pleasant enough. Has a little aroma hops and low to medium bitterness.
Canned. Golden coloured. Both hops and malt present in the light aroma. Fresh and crisp flavour with a rather dry and bitter finish.

(can) Clear golden colour with a fast diminishing small frothy white layer. Corny malty nose with glue and some hoppiness in the background. Very watery malty mouthfeel with a somewhat bitter and metallic finish, fizzy carbonated. The worst beer I had for months
(Bottle 33 cl) Very pale, with a fresh hoppy nose. There’s a hint of something slightly smoked in there - almost like whisky malt. Bitter finish. 200899
A run of the mill light bodied pils. With so many quality brews in Germany, why drink this. In fact, why make this?
Dark in color, pretty light otherwise. Not much roast going on, even the bitterness, which is small, shines through the thin body. But nevertheless it is clean and easy to drink. D&S Dresden
Bottle. Pours hazy dark Brown with a white head. Aroma of caramel, dried fruits, light raisins, light nutty. Taste is rather sweet, light bitter, light nutty, grains.

Bocken varer lige til påske. Dark amber with a small off-white head. Malty aroma with bread and toffee and a hint of dried fruit. Sweet malty flavour with bread and plums and a touch of herbal hops in the finish.
Bottle @ Dolles Bockstival - Bocken varer lige til påske, 5000 Odense C. Pours clear amber with a small white head. Caramel, bread and dark fruit. Medium bodied. Short bitter finish. Rye-bready.
From bottle. Transfer of an earlier rating without text recorded, rating only.
0,5 l bottle BB 22.06.16 Brown color, hazy and with a small tan head. cereal, roasty, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation,
*Old rating, best before 07.11.04. Dunkel-malziges, leicht süßliches Bier. Karamell, leicht röstig, malzig mit leicht herbem Nachgeschmack.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein dunkel rötlichbraunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, Karamell, leicht schokoladig. Geschmack röstmalzig, Karamell, Schokolade, leicht fruchtig.
bottle, kindly sent by kappldav123. Brown colour, beige head. Malty start with cereals and a touch of chocolate. Solid example of the style.

Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts fine malty-roasty, not too intense. Mild dry background. More and more earthy-malty with mild sourish notes. Well balanced finish and quite drinkable. Nice!

Reddish brown, airy quickly vanishing head, some floaters in the bottle. Slightly acidic aroma, big note of green apples. Not much body, rather obvious cellar flavour, a short sting of late sharp hop bitterness.
Overall: Young and slightly unbalanced. Note: On-tap at The Horse and Hound. Reviewed 2015-01-24.
Malty, hoppy aroma. Soapy. Malty, grassy taste with a bit of hopbitterness. Not too bad.

Robe blond doré, un peu foncée, mais certainement pas ambrée ! Mousse faible et éphémère, carbo faible. Nez un peu pâtissier, malté. En bouche, on a du malt pas trop expressif, et un petit côté acidulé (froment, mais aussi gingembre et citron). Le gingembre se déploie peu à peu en bouche. Agréable et rafraîchissant, mais ne casse pas des briques.
Blonde, un peu cuivrée et aqueuse en apparence. La mousse ne tient pas et le gaz est faible et court. Forte note de gingembre et de sucre en première bouche. Pas de seconde bouche, rien d’autre
On tap. @ The Frog and Rosbif, Toulouse 13/06/2018 Color amarillo corona de espuma blanca, aromas especiados, sabor especiado, jengibre, cuerpo medio.
Una cervesa que no aporta res de res! Plana i mal elaborada... un error que estigui al mercat!
Draft. Amber beer with a cream head. Malt aroma. Malt and light spice flavor. Medium bodied. Malt and light ginger lingers.

En fût au frog and princess. Tête se dissipe rapidement, mais laisse une trace blanche. Robe dorée très claire comme une blonde. Aucune amertume, arrière goût légèrement sucré. Gingembre à peine détectable à mon palet. Notes de citron (zest?).
On tap @ Frog an Princess. On part sur du gingembre mais cela ne va pas plus loin.

Un panaché. Une bière ? Mince... Une bière moderne disons, donc faite avec des ingrédients de qualité, et c’est là, la seule note positive de ce produit, gingembre, citrons,... Pour l’été, pour la soif.
08-12-16 // bottle from a supermarket in St. Etienne. Clear golden beer. No head. Taste is pretty light and refreshing. Citrus and ginger notes. Crisp. Quite nice.

Bottle 33cl, a golden beer with low head. Nose is on caramel, ginger and ripped fruits notes. Aroma is on ripped ginger, peppery, vegetables notes, very low body. Finish on vegetables notes not elegant.
12 ounce bottle. Pours almost black with an average tan head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, and a bit of dark fruit. Pretty good.

12oz bottle from Craft Beer Cellar in Pewaukee. Very dark brown pour. Little head. Aroma has roasted malts, milk chocolate, a touch of berry, and light lactose. Taste is of roasted & sweet caramelly malts, chocolate, and a bit of simple sugar. Rougher than expected. Still solid & nicely roasty in the sweetness. Finishes sweeter than bittersweet. 13.6

12 ounce bottle from Woodman's Oak Creek, 4/7/19. Black, large frothy brown head, good retention. Aroma of roast, coffee, chocolate. Taste is roast, coffee, chcoolate, caramel, nuts, cherries. Medium-full bodied, slick, chewy. Solid stout.
12 ounce bottle thanks to drowland. Dark pour. Some chocolate and burnt roast in pour. Thin body

2/17/19. 12oz bottle from Piggly Wiggly. Black pour with a small tan head. Roasted malt aroma, touches of coffee and chocolate. Roasted malt flavor, coffee, chocolate, a touch of caramel, cream, a hint of metal. Not bad.
Draft. A slightly nutty chocolatey stout nice and creamy. Not too strong reallypleasant and nice.

04-May-14 (12-oz bottle: Obtained in trade with hopdog, thanks Steve!) This Stout pours a black body and half an inch of tan head that settles to a ring. The nose is sweet and unexpectedly fruity, having a dried cherry character, but also lots of chocolate, so it smells like chocolate-covered cherries, but also coconut like an Almond Joy. For added complexity, there’s also a nice savory character, some cigar box, even a little grilled meat. On the palate, too, the sweet-and-sour cherry aspect jumps out, maintaining a prominent front from entry to finish. More typical flavors of dark chocolate, tobacco, dark toast, grilled meat, coconut, and brown sugar provide savory complexity and balance. Medium sweet is countered by mild roasty bitterness. The beer is full bodied and has a rich, creamy, round mouthfeel, and carbonation is light-medium. Overall, with the cherry imagery, it’s a little different from what I was expecting, but in a good way. Really enjoyable.

Bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lasting tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, milk chocolate and light coffee. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roasted malt, cocoa and light coffee with a smooth lingering cocoa finish.
Bottle. Black with small tan head. Aroma of caramelized sugar, light roasted malt, and a hint of coffee. Medium body, medium/heavy sweetness, caramelized sugar, light roasted malt.
Poured into a shaker from 12oz bottle. Nice head and lacing. Dark fruit flavors, chocolate and caramel. Nicely rounded and by far my favorite from south shore.
# 472; 10/2016. Velmi nepovedená pšenice. Vůně výrazně obilná, jemně karamelová. Středně plné, ječmený, mladinový, nakyslý.

Bottle at at Würzburger Hofbräu, Würzburg, Bavaria Saturday 9th March 2019. Pours dark gold bordering onto light amber with a large white head. The wheatiness here is subtle and restrained, however the beer is nonetheless most pleasant a touch straightforward perhaps, the slice of lemon in the glass rather tips the aroma into citrussy zone and was a touch unecessarry and frustrating but hey ho others probably like that and we can live with it so it's fine.

Barwa złota, klarowne. Piana średnia, drobnopęcherzykowa, średniotrwała, opada do obrączki, dobry lacing. Aromat: typowy weizen, banan, słód, chlebek, drożdże, goździk, może lekka guma balonowa. Smak: słodowy, bananowy, goździk, lekki kwasek cytrynowy. Wysycenie wysokie, goryczka praktycznie niewyczuwalna.
Banan, kolendra, trochę żelaziwa jakiegoś w zapachu. W smaku słodkawe, lekko plastikowe. takie sobie. Spróbować było warto, ale czy dopić, to już nie wiem.

500ml bottle. Pours clear golden colour, big off-white head. Aroma of dust, plastic, wet rag, caramel. Taste of banana for second, burnt plastic, caramel, herbal bitterness, rubber. Plastic in aftertaste. Medium bodied, over average carbo. Lots of problems here, bad off-tastes, banana is weak, far from proper kristallweizen. Bad brew.

Pours clear, medium-dark blonde ( darker than the average Kristalweissen ) medium-small white head with medium-low stability. Fades to a small layer of white, creamy head. Smell is phenolic, and esther ( such as every beer in this style ) in an about 50/50 equal intensity. mild wheat. Very small spicy hop background ( very hidden ) Taste is kinda toasty ( which is weird in the style ) very intense malty, as well as wheat. Very mild esthers and phenols ( for the style ) medium body, medium-high to high carbo. It's not a good style example for the kristalweissen, but I must say I like the toasty aspect in this.
Bottle from Landbierparadies. Clear golden colour, white foam. Banana, citrus, some spices. Easy drinkable, rather sweet. Not bad.

Pours golden with medium white head. Aroma is wheat, banana, some old socks, light floral, dough, cheese, some salatsauce. Taste is grainy, watery, some wheat, flour, raw bread, dough, some cookies, bratwurst dressing. Drinkable beer!
Heller, mild süß-hefiger Beginn. Eher dumpf bananig, trocken herb. Nicht sonderlich spannend aber sortentypisch und süffig. 9/8/8/8/11/8

From old tasting notes. Nice clear yellow gold color. Spicy dry, tart apple aroma. Spicy clove like malt flavor. Good crisp fruity notes. Light tart finish and aftertaste. Clean, crisp and refreshing.

(bottle) murky bright golden colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of grains, earth and caramelized wheat, with some light hints of banana and yeast. flavour is mostly the same, lots of grainy wheat, some yeast and earth, quite heavy on the popcorn, with a semi-dry finish. light-bodied with lively carbonation.
Bottle. Hazy yellow color with white head. Aroma is sweet unfermented wort, bananas, electrolytes, yeast. Taste is mineralic, wort. Silky mouthfeel with foamy carbonation. Pretty meh.

Bottle. Color: Hazy orange golden. Dense off white head. Taste: Wheat and sweet malts. Yeast and tiny hints of citrus fruit. Tasting like lemonade or alcohol free malt beer, no hops or alcohol whatsoever. Way too malty for me.
Bottle 50cl. Foamy white head, hazy green yellow color. Aroma is cabbage, yeast, wheat, grass, hint of garbage. Taste is sour and dry with a sense of flour.

Bottle 0.5l. Cloudy orange with big frothy off-white head. Yeasty aroma with notes of orange, citrus, dried fruits and fruit cake, hint of ash. Sweetish fruity aroma, yeasty and spicy with notes of orange and some nuts, sourish finish with hint of ash. Lively carbonation, medium-bodied.

Many thanks for this swing-top bottle to kevnic2008. Mala pianka ale za to sporo drozdzy. Metnosc w koloze blotnistym o odcieniu ciemnej pomaranczy. Smak chlebowo pszeniczny delikatny i lagodny. Nieco cytrusowe zakonczenie. Piwo pszeniczne sredniej klasy jak dla mnie.

Tåkete ravfarget med kremaktig hvitt skum som holder lenge. Kullsyren stiger fint opp langs sidene på glasset. Lett surhet i duften sammen med gjær og sitrus. Samme i smaken, men svakt. Frisk munnfølelse med behagelig karbonisering.

Bottle 0.5l at Beerville Beer shop Belgrade Serbia.Ciao Vlada! Taste with Vlada banana.28.04.2015.Pour it little bit hazy orange color.On the nose grains, citrus.Taste and aroma of citrus, grains, malted, not good balanced and not drinkable for me.
Klar lys gyllen farve med lyst skum. Lukt av karamell, frukt og krydder. Smak av karamell, frukt og krydder. Lett karbonert. Det Gode Brygg.

Lukt: Malt, karamell, banan og urter. Utseende: Dunkel lys gulbrun farge. Skum/kullsyre: Dekkende skum. Smak: Urter, en anelse karamell og en noe tørr avslutning. Hvor: Kjøpt@Det Gode Brygg, Sandnes, Nydt@Lokal hjemme tasting med Gorm Medium: Flaske@500ml, ABV@3,1%, Når@01.05.2015
Bottle from Rewe, Neumarkt - hazy golden color, white head. weak thin wheaty body. some banana, vanilla. sweetish. not too good.
Hazy orange colour, white creamy foam. Nose of banana, wheat, taste is rather weak, light banana, tart wheat.

Barwa ciemnozłota, piwo mętne. Piana obfita, drobna, średnio trwała, ładnie oblepia szkło. Aromat kojarzący się z piwem pszenicznym, nuta bananów. W smaku bardzo subtelna nuta słodu, pieczywa, piwo wytrawne, wodniste i trochę puste, lekko kwaśne.

0.5 l bottle from 'EDEKA Preller' (Breckerfeld), best before June 2018. Hazy, orangeish amber with a medium large, dense, stable, white head. Sweetish, slightly artificial, moderately yeasty aroma of lots of bubblegum, some banana juice and a touch of wheat. Moderately sweet, slightly bitter, artificial and slightly bready taste of bubblegum, wheat, some banana juice and a touch of wort, followed by a short, moderately bitter, quite dry and a little tart finish. Medium body, slightly creamy and moderately effervescent mouthfeel, average carbonation. Pretty bad, quite a letdown.
bread, banana, golden, cloudy, frothy, white foam, medium sourness, light body, average carbonation, watery finish, average beer
Nice orange color but beer contained a bit too much acid for me. Not fruity enough, was searching for the banana taste that i like so much in weizenbeer.
bottle. Cloudy amber with an orange glow, tall white head. Yeasty, wheaty and slightly fruity.

Bottle from Mitra Bunnik, BB Dec 2017, 50 cl sample. Cloudy beige color, medium frothy head. Aroma of grainy wheat, soft banana, bit caramel and slightly clove. Taste focuses mainly on malt and some caramel sweetness with the banana and clove on the background. Overall easy going low alcohol weizen with plenty of flavor and no usual offflavors. I would definitely take this again if Im the DD.
Nice alkoholfreies weizen with a decent banana aroma and a nice weizenlike taste and body and finish. This is a nice one
Glass, orange beer, hazy, medium head. Aroma is malt, wheat. Taste is the same, bitter with some sour. not bad
Bottle at a tasting. Hazy golden, big head. Malt and soap aroma. Sweet, malty, old earthy hops, floral, bitter. Medium-bodied, sticky.

At a tasting, big bubbly head, cloudy deepish and a bit oxidized orange color, yeasty, woody, plaster aroma with a fruity whiff behind, flavor of caranel, old malt and honey drops, Not really good, quite old.

Copenhagen 6/3 2017. 65 cl bottle from Høkeren. Chaotic Gaelic looking label with a couple of gold medals, a map showing the way to their Novato based brewery and signatures for the owner and the brew master. There is not room for much more. Pours hazy orange with white head. Settles as very thin patchy layer of foam. Moderate lacing. Aroma of fermented fruit, peach, mango and a solid dose of grape fruit. Strong carbonation and watery palate. Flavor is quite thin and watery. Medium sweet followed by slightly more distinctive bitterness. Aftertaste is bitter but thin. I would imagine it’s very refreshing on a hot summer day - but way too thin to be excellent.
Shared bottle at Cardinal. Pours clear golden with a small white head. Aroma is malty, fruity notes as well. Taste is moderate sweet, with a light resiny hop charachter at the finish.

Shared bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger. Pours hazy amber with little off-white head. Aroma of bread, some caramel, notes of grass and hay. Tastes bitter with some sweetness, medium bodied, bitter finish.

650 ml bottle, Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 5.0%. Deep golden colour, moderate white head. Aroma of piney American hops. The flavour is medium dry, again with notes of piney American hops, hints of grapefruit. Reasonably bitter finish. Refreshing.
Draft: Poured a golden with a tinted off white head. Aroma is hoppy. Taste is hops with grain and malt backbone.

On tap @ the brewpub during RateBeer weekend. Clear yellow appearance with a white head. Weak aroma with some pine and mild orange-citrus. Watery, thin, and bland flavor as well. There is some cereal and lemon in the mouth.
Sample at Delirium Brussels, shared with Mathieu87. APPEARANCE: light clouded blond beer. NOSE: sweet, sugar, somewhat hoppy. TASTE: quite sweet, fruity, slightly hoppy.

Sampled draft @ Delirium Hoppy Loft. Lightly hazy orange, off-white head. Nose is sweet honey, sugar, caramel, chestnuts. Taste is big honey & sugar sweetness, very sweet, caramel, marzipan, honey, flower, plaster. Milky honey body. Really excessively sweet & sugary. Don’t really get the sweetness or where it is coming from.
500ml bottle in 2017. Orange and hazy with a dense white head. Aroma of banana, cloves, cardamom, yeast and soft fruit. Nice full body, with some extra spiciness in the flavour. Very nice.
Pours hazy brown with thick white head. Has a rich aroma of banana. Flavour is less that of banana, but rather savory, grainy, wheaty, distantly boozy. Good.
orange, brown, white foam, frothy, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, medium body, full body, oily feel, creamy, average carbonation, lively,

Sample from 500ml bottle. Pours hazy orangeish coloured liquid, white fluffy head. Aroma is very yeasty atfirst, banana, spicy, wheaty. Taste is more sweetish, still yeasty, fruity, orange, wheaty, ripe banana. Creamy texture. Medium body, lively carbo. Even too creamy for style, but drinkable. Average hefe.
Dunkles hefetrübes cremiges Weizenbier. Röstmalzig und vollmundig, feingewürzt und süffig.

(Bottle, 0.5 l, from Alko, 20170128) The beer poured muddy orange and cloudy. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had banana, clove and caramel. Palate was surprisingly light bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were fruitiness, clove, sweetness and bitterness. Aftertaste was watery and thinly bitter. Aroma was good but the taste was a disappointment.
Schöne frische Nelkennase, leicht dunkel, stabiler Schaum. Im Trunk bitter, malzig, hinten leichte Süße, Karamell. Lecker Ding!

0.5 bottle from Alko Arkadia, Helsinki. Appearance is dark golden, cloudy, with a nice head. Aroma has very ripe bananas. Taste has them too. No banana aroma, but really ripe sweet bananas.Yum. This is a darkish very sweet hefeweizen - hopheads shouldn’t bother.
0,5l bottle. Pours hazy dark orange. At first quite normal hefe with banana, yeast and wheat malts, but there is a hint of spices too. Good hefe to be honest.

500ml Flip-top bottle (BBD 30th May 17): poured into an old Hofbrau Munchner Kindl Weiss glass at home on 13th Dec 16. Obtained from Beers of Europe and shared with my son. Hazy amber/old gold body, good sized white head that hung around. The aroma held the usual banana and vanilla esters you’d expect alongside a herbal twist of cloves and coriander like notes. Taste the same with a yeasty overtone. A little too herbal/spiced for my palate, but I enjoyed trying it.

aged about ten years!! ....sweet and winey apple juice smell...Pours with some small foam,is consent..Pours a dark gold...has held up really well!! sweet low apple syrup taste with some dust in the mouth...kinda funked up...GooD for being as old as it is with only 2% alcohol!
Smells a bit like honey. Sweeter and milder than most ciders, making it quite yummy. From that same brewery that produces Purpom Cider. Very good. Find this stuff.

Head is small, fizzy, white, fully diminishing. Body is hazy medium yellow, dense tiny particles, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately yeasty (cobwebs, leather), with a strong note of apple, lesser notes of grass and honey. Flavor is heavily sweet, moderately acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly astringent. Much better than mainstream ciders.
Bottle from Coppers, Newcastle. Pale hazy golden coloured with sweet passion fruit and melon flavours followed by citrus and pine on the finish.
33cl bottle. Pours golden with a white foam. Aroma is sweet malty. Buiscuit & butter. Some grass & a visible alcohol note. Could almost be a malt liquor. Thin palate. Not very nice!
Bottle. Small head with short duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are sweet malt with vague notes of caramel. Quite boring.
Botle.33cl. Clear golden color, small, disapearing head. Sweet malty flavor and a light bitter, the body is thin.

It’s a bit late to celebrate midsummer in November, but perhaps the beer can recall memories of summer? The color is golden with a greyish hue and an OK head. Both aroma and flavour has notes of wet grain and sour mash, and the flavour has sweetness, grain, hints of corn and a slightly bitter finish. Nope - no thoughts about summer, only: which sink is the nearest?
33 cL bottle. Pours golden yellow to orange with a lacing white head. Corn, a bit of caramel and slight metallic aroma. Vague malt and slight caramel flavoured. Dry bitter finish.

Harboe Heksebryg is a discount beer, so I had no big expectations tasting this. The beer has a fine golden collor, and a good “pilsner” head. Sweet aroma, and with a bitter but metallic and sweet flavour.
Yellow colour with thin head.Herbal taste with a light fruity aroma,medium bitter and light sweet finish.
Bottle. unpleasant bitter. boring yellow "gold" beer. Sweet smell.
Bottle. "Harboe Heksebryg Luxus Pilsner". Golden colour with a bubbly short lasting head. Aroma is malty with some hops, which is the same in the flavour along with some bitterness. Rather boring.
Cask Handpump at the Smithfield Hotel, Manchester 19/06/2001 Golden coloured light and pale. Hoppy finish.
Cask Conditioned at The Red Lion, Bloxham. Pale golden colour with thin head. Light malty beer with a spicy corriander like tone. Thin finish, a little sweet, peppery.
Sampled cask conditioned. Golden coloured. Spicy aroma. Sweet, medium bodied, fruity, hints of plum and vanilla. Some saltiness in the finish.

A little of everything here. Hoppy aroma and flavor, but with distinctive honey sweetness and a slight bitterness in the finish. Unlike a lot of typical English beers of this basic consistency, the palate here held up rather well. (Cask, Bookbinder's pub, Jericho, oxford)

Quite cloudy with a big frothy head, which looks great initially but doesn't really last. Aroma is nice and gingery and lemony like a soft drink ginger beer (yum). It tastes OK but it probably lacking in ginger bite and is definitely too sweet. I really did enjoy the taste but I really struggled to get through the whole schooner due to the sweetness. Judging by the people drinking this at the brewery I don't think I'm really the target market for such a drink, but good on them for having a crack at it.

Very nice beer made with us ladies in mind (let's go girls!). Shania Twain would love this beer as do I: a true late afternoon refreshment and energizer. We all have our Newcastle stories to tell, and what better way to tell yours than over a refreshing Newcastle Ginger, out on a wharf dreaming a dream of cranes and bridges, obelisks and beaches? Yours, Betty.

don't really have anything to compare this to. not overpoweringly gingery but refreshingly so. then the sweetness comes and it is too much and makes the beer a little sticky. this needs to be a little drier to be something you could conceivable drink more than one of

Initially, you think this is better than it really is. It has a pleasant aroma, decent-ish head and the first few sips are nice. Then after a while you realise the problem with it. It's just too sweet! You would almost swear you were drinking a soft drink (the head fades aswell). Nice to see someone having a go at this style though.
Draft. Golden beer with a low cream head. Light malt aroma. Citrus and light malt flavor. medium bodied. Citrus and light malt linger.
22oz old ass bottle. Poured a golden color with a large sized head. Smelled and tasted like the age it was ...
Pours a clear yellow with white head. A faint lemon and grain aroma. A very light and water body with citrus, zest and grains. A light citrus afteraste.
Bottle from New Beer. Pours cloudy blonde with white head. Nose and taste of bready malt, lemon peel, barley and sugared grain. Medium body.

Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a hazy pale golden color with a huge sudsy yellow-white head that lingered and left decent lacing. The aroma was sweet and tangy orange, lemon and sourdough bread. The flavor was bitter and very tart with strong citric acid and light touches of egg white and grapefruit. Long tart citric acid finish. Light to medium body. Not good.

Bottle: Poured a slightly hazy blonde color ale with a large white foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of semi-sweet cereal notes with light hoppy and floral notes. Taste is a mix between some semi-sweet clean cereal malt backbone with some light floral and hoppy notes. Body is about average with good carbonation. Enjoyable though nothing to write home about either.

Tap at Spuyten Duyvel. Wow, this stuff was money. I don’t think I have ever had a non-infected McNeills beer before so this was quite the treat. Super fresh, lots of hops, some nice honey malt sweetness to balance things out. Could have downed several more pints.

Bomber from Finger Lakes Beverage, served cool in a tulip glass. 17MR12. App.: Clear deep golden with a nice orange-white foam. Aroma: Oddly sharp, astringent, possibly medicinal, some light peach/apricot fruitiness, apple/pear as well, not great. Palate: Medium body, very relaxed effervescence. Flav.: There’s a medicinal note that reminds me of Buckley’s...pine gum or eucalyptus or something, still a decent amount of fruitiness, soft, friendly, inviting malts, I wish I could put my finger (tongue? Nose?) on the notes that I can’t describe; dry with limited bitterness and a mostly pleasant malty, biscuit, fruity finish. This blond is more eclectic than explosive.

Draught at Rattle ’N’ Hum, NYC, on January 30, 2012 Really hazy golden color, white head. Apricots, acidic, malty, lemon taste. Warming alcohol. Moussy (a bit) mouthfeel, low bitterness. Acidic scent, a bit too much so.

Bomber from Carl. Pours hazy orange gold with a fizzy/creamy head. Light citrus aroma. Med body, nearly. Very nice carb seems to enhance the citrus aspect. Malt is present, but this is more about fruity citrus hop than malt. Nice.

I tried the entire Yankee Jim lineup over a couple of days of BBQing. I will not be trying them again, that’s for sure. It’s a pale gold beer with a generous head. The aroma is all grass. The flavour is all grass.

Originally rated May 2005. All natural premium beer - says the can. Looks pretty trashy to me. Pours a golden colour with a decent head that leaves good lacing. The carbonation is made of medium size bubbles and seems natural (for a lager). Well for swill, this one has malt to its nose. The mouth is smooth with slight sweet malt. Better then the Lucky Lager I had last night.

355ml can from LCBO in Thunder Bay, Ontario pours a pale straw color with a small white head and no lacing. Aroma is light grains and faint hops. Body is light and watery. Taste is light grains and faint hops. Not very good and not recommended.

Canette 355ml. De couleur jaune pâle et claire. Nez de maïs sucré, léger de grains de malt pâle sucrés avec de faibles notes herbeuses (gazon mouillé) et des traces métalliques. Mince en bouche avec un pétillement moyen-fort et une texture légèrement aqueuse. Léger goût de grains de malt pâle sucrés accompagné de traces de légumes bouillis lors de l’entrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût de maïs sucré puis en finale l’on retrouve des notes amères de houblon herbeux (gazon mouillé) avec de petites traces métalliques. Post-goût court, composé de notes amères de houblon herbeux.
Can from LCBO Manu. Corny and metallic nose. Taste is corny with some malts. Foul metallic tastes. Not so good.
355 ml can from LCBO. Pours an ultra pale straw yellow with thin white head. Aroma is corny but blessedly mellow. Flavour likewise. Remarkably watery and thin-bodied. Terrible but not repulsively so.
Aroma of corn, taste of corn. Beer = corn. Basically this beer is overall extremely corny. It isn’t bad and for a light beer its right in there with others but I prob wouldnt drink this again

Can sample, purchased at the LCBO on a serious budget. It’s everything you would expect it to be. Pours a yellowish colour, with a very big white head that goes back to nothing within seconds. Taste and aroma is of corn and grain. Very typical.

355ml can 5.0% ABV I tried this beer on March 24, 2010 after purchasing from the singles bins at one of my local LCBO outlets. The beer poured a translucent medium gold with a generous white bubbly head which quickly disappeared. The aroma was grainy malt and metal. The mouthfeel was weak bodied and medium carbonated. The flavour was stale grainy malt, and acidic bitterness.

4th sample from the crap-pak at the annual K-W swillfest. No off tastes per se - just bland, fizzy thin and with sharp dextrin extract tastes and rice and corn aromas - like wet cardboard. Good to know crappy adjunct swill beer is not native to Canada’s macro brewers,. This is pure swail from the home of liberty.

Bottle to taster Blueberry, tons of blueberry, and really, not much else can be gleaned. Dark black with a thin creamy head. Taste is blueberry, oat, and malt. Interesting brew...aroma is amazing; taste is so-so.
One of the strangest beers that I have had. They had this on tap at Taco Mac in Decatur, GA. Was very good as a Black & Blue (mixed with Guinness).

Very simmilar to the Abita Purple Haze in that it is a wheat beer with added rasberry flavors. They only make one batch a year for the LA blueberry festival and it is available only there or at the Abita Brew Pub. Beer is tart and sweet and even seems to have a sting to it (very carbonated). Simmilar textures to Purple Haze, but not nearly as good. Some people, however, that do not like purple haze tend to like this brew. Go figure.

column1: Fredericksburg Not So Dumb Blond Ale
column5: Draft at Fredericksburg Brewing Co tasting room. Clear pale gold color with a white head and good lacing. Taste is very lager-ish and not very blonde-ish. Easy drinking.

column1: Fredericksburg Not So Dumb Blond Ale
column5: Tap at brewery. Yeast and bread; slightly sweet. Not good really, it’s all yeast. Utterly pale. Buttery feeling.

column1: Fredericksburg Not So Dumb Blond Ale
column5: Starts with faint bread malt. Light yellow color. Lightly bitter, overall taste is neutrally grainy. A touch watered down, refreshing somewhat. An anonymous and inoffensive brew.

column1: Fredericksburg Not So Dumb Blond Ale
column5: This was sessionable beer. The aroma is fragrant and spicy. The appearance is golden but a bit cloudy. The taste is rich in malt and properly bittered. The palate is medium-bodied and crisp on the finish. The best thing I drank at this brewery.

column1: Fredericksburg Not So Dumb Blond Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Yellow with a white head. The aroma and flavor are full of grain with some biscuit malt notes. Also get some grass in the flavor. Thin mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

column1: Fredericksburg Not So Dumb Blond Ale
column5: On tap) Pour is golden with a thin white head..Nose is lemon, grains, honey.. Taste is lemon, light hop, grain, cheese, Palate is light and grainy

column1: Fredericksburg Not So Dumb Blond Ale
column5: Tap at the brewpub. The smell is grainy, water, musty, and eh. The taste is water, dirt, corn, and malt. The look is clear, golden in color, with an ok lacing head.

column1: Fredericksburg Not So Dumb Blond Ale
column5: tap at brewpub-pretty much run of the mill beer here- not a great kolsch by any means-pours light clear yellow with a small white soapy head. nose is grainy and lite spicy hops with some adjunct qualities as well. flavors are lightly grassy, cardboard and lite dry spicy hops. decent albiet boring

column1: Fredericksburg Not So Dumb Blond Ale
column5: Tastes like a run of the mill, mass-produced rice lager, only neon yellow. Without question, the color was the most interesting aspect of this beer.

column1: Fredericksburg Not So Dumb Blond Ale
column5: Growler courtesy Fratto. Pours a bright Lemonhead yellow color. Small ring of white bubbles. Aroma is fresh grains, light citrus, fruit and other notes of lime. Flavor is sweet candy, praline, bready notes and yeast. Just a tad grainy on the finish but not too bad.
On tap at Draught House. Pours a cloudy orange with medium white head. The aroma is wheat, smoke, raisin. Medium body, toasted grain, smoke, bready malt, decent.

6-1-08 tap Mud brown in color with a hint of red in there too. Smell is light and malty. Flavor is sweet and a hint funky and strange. Nice carbonation and nice mouthfeel overall. Overall, another good brew from the Draught House.

Pours brownish amber with a light beige head. Smell is dark, nutty malt and wheaty. Taste is nutty, rich, caramelized wheaty malt. Nice moderately rich body and good carbonation. Flavorful and drinkable. Good beer.

Pours darker amber with a red tint. Very, very cloudy. Only a 1/2 inch head, or the bartender poured it out. Mild wheat aroma, a little sour smelling, and that’s it. Taste is a medium strength wheat and yeast taste with a hint of chocolate. There’s a bit of carbonation in this beer. Body is just shy of full. Finish is strong and lacing is relatively weak.

On tap at pub. This is always a summer favorite of mine. Murky red in color. Great banana, clove, caramel, fruit/bubble gum and bread dough aroma and flavor with a smooth mouthfeel. Very drinkable beer.

Pour is a hzy reddish color with a thin tan head...smell i s spicy with a strange mix of gingerbread, anise, cloves, and sweet light fruitiness...taste is sweet with the same spices...interesting Josh...

I love it when they bring this out in early autumn. Dark and rich looking. Smells excellent. Rich and tobacco like while at the same time tart and wheaty. Maybe a little watery but all in all not bad. I agree though...needs some more wheat. G-rat
Didn't taste the chocolate or biscuit notes, but there was definitely malts. Decent beer.

typical dunkel color with an average head....I love the glasses they use there too, they make most beers look better. Aroma was off sweet tobacco. The flavor was crisp, sweet malts...not enough wheat...but pretty good.
Golden and hazy with a thin white head. Light floral aroma. Smooth light hint of lemon. Very drinkable with a bit of a dry finish ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Simple pale golden beer with moderate citrus and pale malts controlling. Medium to light bodied, assertive carbonation. A tad sweet.

On tap at The Nodding Head. Pours a clear clean yellow with a medium sized beige head. Clean crisp grain, lemony, hints of vanilla. Very grainy, light plastic. Finishes with more grain and an earthy bitterness.

Draught at Nodding Head: Aroma of soap, herbs, slight hops, plastic and vegetables. Poured gold/blond/yellow in color with a medium-sized, white head that diminished but lasted throughout. Clear. Not sparkling. Flavor is lightly sweet. Tastes of vegetables, slight lemon, pale malts, toasting, and slight hops. Light to medium body. Oily texture. Soft to average carbonation. Slightly sweet, slightly lemon finish.
Tap at the brewpub. Mild saaz and noble hop aroma, lots of pine and herbals, if you dig. Flavor is sweetish, corny, flower stems, with beet notes. A bit off kilter.

Very pale straw colour. The aroma is sort of spicy with a lot of corianderish citrus and fresh cut grass. Low carbonation which makes this seem sweeter than it probably is. It tastes a little like a filtered/unspiced wheat beer. Grassy hoppiness but it gets a little bit soapy as I keep drinking it. Meh

Cask at the Brewpub. Clear light yellow body with a small but sturdy white head. I’m not a fan of the way they stack wet pint glasses, as there’s no carbonation in the glass. Aroma is a handfull of fresh hops. Flavor is the greenest kolsch I’ve ever had. A bit thin in body as it tastes like a light glass of hop water. A little soapy doesn’t help but it ain’t horrible either. After asking the bartender, this cask was dry hopped.
Hand pumped from a cask at the Brewpub. Pours clear gold with a white head. Lemony citric hop aroma. Same with the flavor, lemony citrus, decently balanced. Maybe a very light hnit of soap. Not bad.

Draft: I’m surprised at finding out this was a Kolsch. The description at the brewery said it was a Golden Ale. It poured a golden yellow color with not much head. The aroma was light hops and citrus. The flavor was weird. It started out smooth and sweet with hint of coriander. Then it finished by tasting like metal. Not a beer I’d ever drink again. I struggled to get this down.
Draft. Pale golden color with a thin white head. Fresh hop aroma with citrus and some grainy notes. Fresh hop flavor with a citric finish. Refreshing.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Red Leaf Lager
column5: Amber color and soft mouth feel. Less bitter and easy going. Slightly caramel and roasted nuts flavor.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Red Leaf Lager
column5: Sample at the brewery, the beer itself is a reddish brown color with a sweet grainy biscuit aroma, the taste is more of the same but the beer has a decent balance and tastes better over the Blonde Lager which was below average. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Red Leaf Lager
column5: Pint draft at Regan Airport. Pours nice clear red brown. Fast dissipating tan head. Scents of malt and caramel. Tastes of nuts and hops balanced with lingering sweet malt finish. Fizzy mouthfeel and above average carbonation. Quite good.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Red Leaf Lager
column5: Picked up a tallboy at the brewery. Pours a fairly large frothy off-white head that stays around long enough. Has a clear light amber appearance. Moderate carbonation. Lacing is decent. Aromas of toasted malts, notes of caramel. Flavours are sweet, subtle dark fruits. Also some  Average retention. Somewhat of wet mouthfeel. Not bad.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Red Leaf Lager
column5: Not bad but not great, easy drinking and pleasant but lacking. Had heard this was their answer to a certain "Red" on tap in a bjillion bars. Based on that this is superior, just not my usual GLB expectation. As I drink this it is actually very thin, was expecting better

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Red Leaf Lager
column5: Pours clear dark amber with a small off white head. Aroma is carmel malt and nuts. Has a carmel, roasted nuts and toffee with a mild sweetness and a smooth body. A good easy drinking beer

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Red Leaf Lager
column5: Toronto 2015 trip +++ Sampled from a 473 ml can this beer poured a nut brown color with an orange hue and a medium sized fluffy beige head that left decent lacing. The aroma was sweet and malty with notes of toffee and a strong egg white presence. The flavor was malty and sweetish with toffee and egg white. Medium length finish. Medium body. Meh.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Red Leaf Lager
column5: Pours a dark Amber, with a small bubbly head. Aroma has notes of nuts, caramel, toffee, and lightly toasted malt. Tasting notes include nuts, caramel, and rich malts. Mouth feel is slick and warm. Delicious!!

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Red Leaf Lager
column5: Can at airport. I would not call this smooth. The aroma is a bit lagers plastic. The taste is nasty, taste old somehow.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Red Leaf Lager
column5: 0.473 draft. Clear, coppery color and a small, off-white head. Aroma is standard, mostly malts, some sweet bread, hints of corn. Taste is simple; malts, a some caramel, a very delicate hint of alcohol. Light to medium body, slick texture, and an average carbonation. Finish is short-lived and generally follows the taste. Overall a mediocre beer.
8th February 2008 2002 bottle - duh! Fairly standard golden ale. Slight toffee in the undertone. Crisp but not that fruity -so maybe not so typical!
500ml Bottle at home 02/04/2010 (BBE June 2003) Hoppy aroma. Slight carbonation. Clear golden coloured smooth on the palate hoppy and a little fruity with a hint of bitterness in a dry malt finish.

God Save the Queen God save our gracious Queen, Long live our noble Queen, God save the Queen! Send her victorious, Happy and Glorious, Long to reign over us; God save the Queen! O Lord our God arise, Scatter her enemies And make them fall; Confound their politics, Frustrate their knavish tricks, On Thee our hopes we fix, Oh, save us all! Thy choicest gifts in store On her be pleased to pour; Long may she reign; May she defend our laws, And ever give us cause To sing with heart and voice, God save the Queen!

Bottled. Golden colour (what else would you expect) small head and moderate condition. Initial aromas of sulphur and hops with bread and malt becoming apparent as it warms. Well balanced malt and hops in the mouth with a dry bitterness towards the end.

column1: Capitol City Constellation Imperial Pale Ale
column5: Had this at the Baltmore location. An average IPA. Has a faint bitter finish.

column1: Capitol City Constellation Imperial Pale Ale
column5: Very nice head, dark copper in color, strong citrusy aroma, very hoppy, spicy aftertaste, very nice IPA

Tasted in DC at Capitol City. Very strong candy/strawberry aroma - overpowering. Cloudt appearance - orangish / yellow colour. Thin white foamy head. Way too sweet for my liking - difficult to finish.

Strawberry wheat beer, very strong berry aroma & flavor, the berries overpowered any kind of traditional weizen tastes, very strong berry-like aftertaste, after it sat for a while & got a little warm it almost tasted like I was drinking a strawberry flavored soda

On cask at Bertha's in the Fell's Point district, Baltimore, MD, where it is called Bertha's Best Bitter. The beer was served at a warm room temperature, rather than the "cellar temperature" stated on Bertha's menu." Or perhaps, Bertha's cellar is kept rather warm. Clear, dark amber-orange win an off-white head and excellent lacing. Aroma of fresh-baked bread. Taste of liquid brown bread and mild orange. Fairly sweet with only a hint of hops. Medium body and low carbonization. [This is the same as Bertha's Best Bitter, which is served at Bertha's in Fell's Point, Baltimore, MD. Bertha's originated the recipe and at first brewed it in their kitchen. Later, they contracted to (now closed) Oxford Brewery and eventually to Pratt Street (aka Oliver's).] ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This was an ok beer. Very malty but not much of a hop flavor and a little bit too thin of a beer for my liking

An on the money best bitter, served on cask and the bedrock of a session with mates. Pours a wonderful amber colour with an inch or so of head, the aroma is seville oranges, some spiciness and the grasiness of Fuggles. Tastewise, sweet pale malt with some judicious caramel malt and a firm though unobtrusive hop bite that lingered and left you wanting more, medium bodied and a superb representation of one of the more difficult styles to brew well.

Golden amber with a creamy white head. Sweet, malty aroma with a whiff of dusty hop. Seems to start sweet before near rescue by a fair, earthy bitterness. Pretty drinkable but I like ’em drier. Cask at the brewpub.

Cask at The Wharf Rat. Pours clear copper with a frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is cookie and biscuit malt, faint fruity esters, earthy and woody hops. Flavor is malt forward with medium hops and bitterness, faint fruity esters and a sweet finish. Light body and warmth with medium carbonation.

Cask. Pours hazy gold/copper with thick, frothy white head; good retention and spare lacing. Aroma is cookie and straw malt, leather, pears, floral hops, and light apples. Flavor is malt dominate with faint fruit esters and good; bland finish. Medium body, low carbonation, and low warmth.
On tap at Frisco Grille. Amber color with white head. Sweet malty aroma with citrus notes. Sweet caramel flavor with slight citrus hop finish. I always enjoy the Olivers beers.

Reviewed from notes. On cask at Pratt Street. Pours a moderate orange brown with a good white head and some nice lacing. Quite a bit of lace is there, but can’t bump to a 4.5 given that it doesn’t overpower and it is cask. Nose brings some light caramel and toffee and some slight hops. The taste is ever-so-slightly hoppy with a base malt that is nice. Good body with slight bitterness. Very sessionable. Serving type: cask Reviewed on: 11-03-2010

Cask at the Pratt location. Pours a clear amber color with a medium creamy head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of green apple, floral hops, faint malts. The taste is caramel, lightly toasted grain, apples, tart fruits and a bitter hop finish. Medium bodied.

Cask conditioned draft at Church Key in DC. Pours a nice copper, almost no head, low carbonation. Aroma and flavor are of rich caramel, apple, biscuity malt, a slight tartness. Some burnt malt creeps into the finish. A very nice bitter, particularly on the hand pull at the right temperature.
Cask at Pratt Street Ale House. Pours a cloudy brown with small creamy beige head that lasts. The aroma is toasted malt, earth, raisin. Thin body, spice, caramel, earth, light bitterness, good.
CASK. Served on tap at Pratt Street Ale House. Hazy Amber color with a white head. Malt light sweet fruit flavor. Medium body. Easy drinking but not much flavor. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On cask at Mad Fox Cask Festival 2015. Pours a clear amber with an off white head. Malty nose. Nutty flavor. Thin mouthfeel. Slight bitter finish.

6% ABV. Extra Special Bitter. Hand pumped out of the cask. Tapped a luscious dark nut brown at about 25ºSRM. Nose is full of nice vanilla, cream and oatmeal type flavors. All this came through so cleanly even though I had just got into town in the middle of some heavy pollen and the hayfever was kicking in. The palate is lusciously splendid, with full bodied deeply roasted malts. You can tell when you get that first shot of umami on the palate followed by a nice slow slide to ume. Light carbonation giving it a very hefty mouthfeel. Velvety smooth and a nicely balanced bitter finish. Honors the name "extra special". A creamy, rich and very satisfying pint. Likely one the finest. Gets my very special recommendation to try first if available on cask at the Pratt Street Ale House. Goes on Favorites List.

On tap at the Wharf Rat in the Fell's Point district, Baltimore, MD. Hazy, rusty amber-brown with an off-white head and good lacing. Aroma of caramel, toast, earthy hops and nuts. Taste of toasted malt, caramel, bread and mild earthy hops. Medium body and low/medium carbonization. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught @ Smoke and Barrel, Washington, D.C. Pours slightly hazy amber with airy off-white head. Clear aroma of oak cask, fruit, spices and hops. Clear, bitter flavour of hops and cloves with subtle fruity notes. Mildly bitter aftertaste. Decent.
On cask. Pours a glowing amber color with almost no head. Notes of caramel, earthy hops, cocoa, and wood.
Hand drawn at Pratt Street - Good head, great lace, plenty of malt, hops balance a little out of whack

RATING UPDATE: Tried cask version again, this time at Mahaffey?s. Better overall but still not my cup o? tea. A bit too sweet on the tongue for my tastes. ORIGINAL RATING COMMENTS: I’m HOPING that I just got a stinky pour when I got the cask version last night at Wharf Rat, and that perhaps there was something a bit funky as a result of nobody else imbibing of it... the place was DEAD, while just around the corner other joints were hopping! I tend to really like bitters, see that this ale is usually rated very well, and hope it was just an odd, rare miss. Anyway, it started well enough-- smelled nice and fruity-hoppy, and attractive coloring of amber-copper. Unfortunately it was downhill from there, as the taste ranged from soapy to sweet to sour, the body seemed off, and it became downright unpleasant to the point that I only drank about half before giving up (and that?s not at all a typical behavior for me!). I?ll look for it again elsewhere in the future and pray it was just a case of an off firkin/pour.

Tap. Pours deep brown with thick, creamy beige head; good retention and excellent lacing. Aroma is caramel and toasted malts, woody notes, nuts, dark fruit, and light toffee. Flavor is sweet malt dominate, faint hops, and light fruit esters; creamy mouthfeel with a sweet finish. Medium body and carbonation with low warmth.
Pours a slightly hazy rosato from a can, slightly pinkish head. Aroma is a faint cherry. Flavor is sweet cherry and a light wheat biscuit. Muddled, one-note only beer. Meh.

The arrow didn't exactly hit the cherry tree mark here. It flew over the tree and landed solidly in the chemically polluted tree next to the cherry blosson. Tangy sour finish. Tap at Cherry blossom beer fest.
Poured from can. Pours ruby color with light pink head. Aroma is tart cherry and yeastiness. Flavor is cherry with malt fruitiness and bready yeastiness.
Can - pours pinkish red pink head - nose/taste of cherry, floral and light gummy candy - med body
Can. Ruby pour with pink head. Sweet cherries, tart, fruit aromas. Flavors are light, cherry and malty tones.

appearance: gorgeous clear pinkish red, with a bright pink, fizzy head. aroma: tart cherries, floral honey, but of vanilla. taste: aspirin, flowery hops, tart cherry juice, cough drop. finish: astringent, bitter, sour, and slightly medicinal. notes: Extremely disappointed. Sure looked pretty though. Draft at Urban BBQ in Rockville.
Can from Bethesda Food and Beverage. Dark red body with medium head. Nose is sweet, fruity, cherries. Taste is floral, of cherries, tart. Sweet flavored. Creamy with soapy finish.

Sampled on draft this beer poured a pink-red color with a large foamy pink head that left good lacing. The aroma ws egg white and cherry and was a bit dry. The flavor was dry and yeasty with a bit of cherry and cherry pit. Medium length finish. Medium body. Disappointing.

5.8%ABV. Wheat Ale with cherries. Seasonal. NO head. Red color. When it tapped out, I was expecting a lambic. Wheat beer with nice solid wheat, bread and flour-like flavors. It had an light sour palate. No aroma hops expected or delivered. Bitter hops with a herbaceous bitter finish. No much in the way of cherry flavor, they are not kidding when they say it is "kissed" with cherry flavor. I suppose the sour could be interpreted to be the sour of fresh cherries. Pleasant enough seasonal.
Farbe rot. Geruch nach Hagebuttentee, das findet sich auch im Geschmack wieder. Kaum bitter zum Ende.
From tap. Pours hazy orange. Small white head. Aroma is grainy and slight fruity. Herbal hoppy. Bitter and dry herbal. Bitter and grainy finish.

Sampled on draft at the Pratt Street Alehouse this beer poured a copper color with a large foamy bright white head that left great lacing. The aroma was sweetish with golden and tropical fruits and a bit of honey. The flavor was bitter and sweetish with gold and tropical fruits and some honey. Long bitterish tropical fruit finish. Medium body. Well done.
On tap at the Wharf Rat. It is hazy cloudy yellow with excellent white head retention. It has a tasty malt beady flavor in the forefront with a light spicy and treacle flavor.
On tap at Pratt Street Ale House. Pours a hazy orange with medium white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is pine and citrus. Medium body, grapefruit, pine, lingering resin finish, good.
On tap in a shaker. Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel and pale malts, light hops, some dough. Flavor the same - generic for a pale ale and boring.
Pours a half finger of head on a clear dirty straw body. The aroma is mildly floral with honey. The taste is solid malt (caramel and honey) with a dry bitterness. The texture is smooth. Enjoyable.

6.2%ABV. English Pale Ale.. Roasted malty body. More pronounced and less hop balanced and highlights malt more than the previous American IPA that I had. Soapy mouthfeel. Carbonation is pronounced. Prolonged bitter herbaceous finish.. A little cloying on the bitter hops. There are some weedy finishing tones. :)

Pours a clear golden amber with a medium white head. Aroma has mild malty fruitiness. Flavor is malty/fruity with earthy bitterness and booziness...very slight buttery note. Mouthfeel is medium/full and oily with a dry earthy/minerally/resinous finish.

Pours golden color with thin white head. Aroma is caramel malt with floral and citrus hops. Flavor is sweet caramel malt with floral hops, citrus and pine. Smooth ale, well balanced. The malt flavor in this ale is nice..
Citrus with some malt that comes off a little on the funky side. Pours murky orange with good head and lacing. Tap at wharf rat.

This is the worst beer I’ve ever had. Expected a "light summery brew with some sweet vanilla flavor" (as quoted by the bartender). What I got was an aroma-less, flat, bland beer. It tasted like someone’s first crack at a homebrew that would make them think, "OK, it won’t kill anyone, but surely I can do better." It wasn’t helped by the hideously dirty draft lines, but since their beer is brewed on-site, I fault them completely. I would avoid self-brews at The Wharf Rat at all costs.
Pale, clear yellow, not much head. Lightly tart, cream soda aroma. Tastes like cream soda without sugar. Fizzy, thin. Mercifully, no cling. DLA trip.

A light yellow beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma is almost non-existing - maybe due to the fact that it is served very cold - the only note I can pick up is a faint malty one. The flavor is lightly malty with notes of vanilla, and the body is thin. Not my cup of tea.

Draught @ The Wharf Rat in Baltimore Clear yellow, light head and lacing. Nose of nothing, too cold to taste. Light vanilla. The flavor is like creamy soda, sugary and sweet, not bad if you treat it as such.
Like michael jackson (the singer) and children, the paths of vanilla and wheat should not be crossed. This blew.

Draft... RBSG2006... Barely yellow ale with a small, creamy, white head. Not much going on in the aroma other than a pleasant insinuation of vanilla. Much the same flavor-wise... seltzer water with a splash of vanilla. Short, crisp, clean finish. Refreshing, but so is club soda. Club soda is far less expensive... even a small bottle of vanilla extract is inexpensive and goes a long way.

Ice Ice baby. Very light colored. Said it was a wheat beer and ale, though it looks lighter than any lager. First sip was all Vanilla, and I even coughed a little bit in shock. Very carbonated. Light in alcohol A decent beer that does not really taste like beer. Good experiment.
Utter garbage. Tasted like cream soda. This beer is completely retarded. I can’t think of anything worse.
Clear, very light straw body. Aroma is sweet vanilla. Taste is cream soda. Light body, some crispness. Not what I want in a beer.
Smelled & tasted almost like I was eating an ice cream cone, could definitely taste the vanilla beans in the brew, very smooth, nicely done

20101011 Nitro at Wharf Rat. Dark brown with usual nitro head. Aroma is a touch vegetal, but mainly coffee and dark roast grain. Pleasant roastiness throughout, with soft, light body and lingering leafy bitterness. Mild sourness, bready. Nice match with a load of deep fried schwag.

Tap at Wharf Rat. Dark brown with a thick creamy mocha head. Good retention and sticky lace coats the glass. The nose is roast, light chocolate and brown sugar. Taste is lightly sweet, lots of roast, some chocolate and light molasses. Medium body is soft with light carbonation.

On tap @ Pratt St Ale House. Black with a creamy dense tan head. Mild roasty aroma with some bittersweet chocolate scents. Flavor is sweet with a bitterness from the roasty qualities. Medium body with a mild carbonation and a creamy mouth feel. Pretty darn close to Guinness.

Location: Nitro draft &#40on the menu as "smooth pour"&#41 at the Pratt Street Ale House, 9/6/09 Aroma: Roasted dark malts dominate the nose 6/7 Appearance: Black color, tan head, lots of lace Flavor: Strong roasted malt flavor with a bit of hops 7/8 Palate: A very smooth and rich beer 3/4 Overall Impression: This is a pretty solid, though slightly one dimensional stout. A nice beer none the less.

Black in color with rich creamy tan head... Aroma is extremely malty, but the flavor is surprisingly hoppy for a stout... Like a stout and pale ale fused together... Initially very malty with rich roasted barley flavor, but finish has a touch of bitterness, very mild however, probably from English hops... Very nice beer.

Nitro at Frisco Grille labeled simply as ""Olivers Oatmeal Stout."" Pours a deep brown with a eighth inch creamy tan head, coating lacing. Medium bodied with a smooth creamy texture. Mild chocolate and roast aroma. Flavor of dark roast, milk, and oats countered by a firm coffee-esque bitterness. I could use a little more sweetness. Finish has a lingering husky graininess.
Dark brown with a creamy tan head. Nice roasty chocolate malt aroma and taste with a watery palate.

on tap-pours a rich, creamy, cascading light brown head and black color. Aroma is dark malt-roasty/bakers chocolate, hint of acidic. Taste is dark malt-roasty/bakers chocolate, hint of acidic-hops, dry finish. Not my taste but nice. Occasional.
pint @ downtown Baltimore Wharf Rat. dark black with a nice tan head. Creamy smooth, nice roasted chocolate taste with a slight dry finish. easy drinking before and after the game
On nitro, at the downtown brewpub. Good roastiness, good lacing. On the thicker mouthfeel side. A bit sour.
Pours a pale yellow orange. Taste is slightly citrus with a light malt sweetness.
On tap at Pratt Street Ale House. Pours a hazy copper with medium off white head that lasts. The aroma is caramel, rye, raisin, toast. Medium body, earth, raisin, rye, bitter finish, good.

Sampled on draft at the Pratt St Ale House this beer poured a red-brown color with a medium sized creamy white head that left good lacing. The aroma was malty and a bit toasty. The flavor was bitter, dryish and astringent with a fruity undertone. Medium length finish. Medium body. Meh.
On tap - dark tea color with a decent head and lacing. Has an aroma of white grapes and a sweet taste up front. A malty profile, thin body and finish.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper amber with a thin tan to white head. Gentle malt and almost isopropyl, fruity bread, oxidized maybe? Odd for sure. Sweet, malt and toffee, something odd flavorwise, much akin to the nose. Gentle bitterness lingering on the finish, with more breast fruit.
Pours a finger of head on a dark brown body. The aroma is mild grain. The taste is lemon and grain, mild sweetness. The texture is softer with moderate carbonation. It’s a nice and easy drinker.

6%ABV. Irish Style Red Ale Not much in the nose, but then it might’ve just been me getting into town in the middle of pollen season. Deep amber red color about 16ºSRM. Soapy mouthfeel. Moderately carbonated. Nice clean bitter hops. Roasted malt body. Slightly sour tang but eclipsed by prolonged bitter finish. Smooth.

On draft at The Big Hunt in D.C. The beer is amber to crimson with a small, white head. The aroma is caramel malt, lightly sweet, a touch of hops. Malt forward and tasty. Very fresh. Mild bitterness and light hop presence. Easy drinking and smooth with a surprisingly robust body. I enjoyed this and would have it again.
Pours a reddish amber. Thin tan head. Nice lacing. At their tap room. Malty and slightly sweet. Nice beer. Under rated.

16oz pour at the Big Hunt DC. Pours a clear, brick red with some creamy, white head. Nose of cracker, malt, a little orange, some bread crust. Flavor is the same, fairly standard, light bitterness, orange, malt, cracker. Clean finish. You know... standard Irish ale.

Cask - Pratt St (ABV 6.8%). Soft rustic fig and raisin aromas warm to swirls of cherry toffee and yeast throughout. Flavor is similar with a musty dark fruit component riding a soft wave of caramel yeast. Touch of earthy hops in the background keeps most of the sweetness in check. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Nicely done...

A "northern European lunch beer?" Is that anew style? Is it OK that I drink it at dinner time? This one was full bodied, had an aroma of smoky nuts, and tasted like burnt caramel and light spice. Nice.
Cask at Churchkey. Poured a clear copper color with a small off-white head. Aroma was toffee, caramel notes, touch of toasted malts. Flavor was crisp sweetness, malty, touch of hops.
The dark color threw me off for a bit and the style of beer i had never heard of. Turned out to be a pretty thick and malty beer, enjoyable.

29100328 tap at Max’s. Dark amber with sturdy beige head of medium foam. Aroma is a bit vegetal, celery, on top of bready malt and sweet fruity notes. Light to medium bodied with mild eff. Flavor is mild, crackery malts, fruity light cherry and berry, a touch sweet. Meh.

Reddish amber color, don’t remember what the head looked like. Aroma of fruit and malt. Flavor was much of the same, but struck me as quite weird, especially for the style. Also, floral and sweet. Didn’t enjoy much at all.

A hazy red beer with a lazing beige head - doesn’t really look like the Biere de Garde’s I’ve had from France. The aroma is sweet with light notes of berries - it is served very cold, so not that much aroma appears. The flavor is sweet with primary notes of berries, but also a light note of butterscotch, leading to a bitter end with notes of berries. The mouthfeel is a bit sticky.
Draught @ The Wharf Rat in Baltimore Amber color, dark mahogany with nice head and lacing. Nose of musky, husky malt. A touch of the tart barny character and a lot of caramel malt. The finish
Ehh... biere de Garde? Clear and brown, with an off white head, malty (caramel) and lightly fruity aromas and flavor. Odd take on the style. Not a bad beer, just not expected.

Very pale aroma, hard to notice at all, but still has some faint tobacco and black cherry scents, just pretty light. Flavor is similar, with a moderately strong lactic off-flavor. Ok, but not what a biere de garde should be.
Medium brown, no head. Sweet malt nose, perhaps some toffee? Malty taste, surprising bitterness finish. A little thin.
With Tim. On tap at Pratt Street Ale House. Sweet with a hint of chocolate. Dark brown, smooth, minimal head.
hazy amber, light beige head, spidery lacing. Nose hides diacetyl behind grinds and chocolate. Cream and cigarette ash flavor, light chocolate and peanut butter before sticky end. A mess.

Tap at Pratt St Alehouse. Deep, clear brown to deep ruby pour. Medium tan head. Nose is toffee and diacetyl. Maybe some dark cherry. Taste is decent, some butter and cocoa powder. Chocolate milk perhaps. Not bad. Still mild diacetyl in the body. Palate is bubbly and buttery...becoming papery and bland. Diacetyl being a welcome brewing flaw after the other beers here exhibiting hazardous chemical astringency.

On tap at Pratt. Pours a clear caramel cola brown with a thin to medium sized yellowed beige head. Roast, chocolate, malt, dark fruit. Roast up front, bitter cocoa, chocolate. Medium bodied, roast, chocolate and cocao. Long roast bitterness, cocoa. Easy drinking.

Tap at Pratt Street - quite similar to the oatmeal stout - similar body, as well as similar notes of roastiness and a touch of woody notes - however, this one has quite a bit more sweetness, so the chocolate and light fruitiness (again, similar to the stout) become the mail focus of the beer, rather than balancing out with the other flavors - a decent brew, but go for the stout instead.

Tap. Pours clear black with a medium, creamy tan head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is chocolate, cookie and toast malt, dark fruity esters and light hops. Flavor is malt forward with medium bitterness, dark fruity esters and a dry finish. Medium body, warmth and carbonation.

Draft. Pours dark brown with a hint of red; thin, creamy beige head; decent retention and light lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, toffee, and light earthy hops. Flavor is malt forward (caramel), chocolate, light dark fruit, and a dry, hoppy finish. Light body, low/medium carbonation, and low warmth.

Dark beer with a small head.Was in a dark bar when I had this beer so it’s hard to get in to details about this beer.I would try again for shore and the one thing that stood out was the fizziness of the beer it’s dry and carbonated .

Draft @ The Wharf Rat, Baltimore, MD. Pours a dark brown almost black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty caramel aroma. Roasted malty caramel flavor with hints of chocolate and weak yeasty hints. Has a roasted malty caramel finish.

Sampled on draft at the Chadds Ford location this beer poured a yellow color with a medium sized foamy white head that left good lacing. The aroma was a bit grainy, yeasty and lemony. The flavor was crisp with notes of yeast, faint fruity hops and some citrus. Medium length finish. Medium body. Very nice for what it is.

Pours a pale golden yellow color with a one finger white head that quickly settles into lasting ring. Spotty lacing left behind. Sligtly floral, grassy hop aroma but otherwise bland with pale malt and grain. Little bit of light fruit. Medium bodied and more interesting than the nose suggests. Crisp hop bite lingers over lighter body and is counters by hints of grass, straw, light fruit and pale malt. Slightly grainy but not adjunct like. Toward the end if the palate I’m picking up some bread, biscuit and apple/pear sweetness. Not very interesting but it’s light and refreshing with a nice hop bite.
Draft in Devon. Pale yellow color, light aroma, and light taste. Pretty much a light lager.

Tap at CF, mine 3.5% abv and 7 IBU. Clear yellow-golden with a shor white head. Nose thin pale malt, taste brings out lemon, sour grass and sweat socks. Smooth fill body, has some Kölsch-y character, feels much much bigger and more filling than it actually is.
Draft at the brewpub. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. The aroma has light grain, semi bready. The taste is sweet grain and bread, light grass, not bad.
Pale golden little rimming head; aroma is hearty wheaty; Flava is grainy fresh and earthy; feels light and crisp and nice fizz; finishes dry malty grain
Very easy drinking lager with slight hops. Doesn’t have that outputting corn smell other pale light lagers do.
Crisp gold color. Corn, malt, some spice, hop. A good refreshing session able lager. Only 3.5%?? Tastes more like 4.5-5.
Pale straw colored body, thin white head, minimal lacing. Pale malts... nothing else. Light bodied, thin, moderate carbonation. I guess it’s better than a Bud light.
On tap at Devon brewpub. Pours pale gold with white head. Very mild aromas of straw, citrus. Body is mildly bitter and sweet. Crisp body.

Draft at the brewpub, July 2006. A very light yellow beer with a only a rim of white head. The aroma is artificially sweet with only faint hints of wheat. The flavor is sweet citrusy with only a light malt presence, and a dry slightly wheaty end. A beer without character, but probably good as a thirst quencher. Definately an American Wheat.
Pale gold/yellow appearance, with aroma and taste of lemongrass, wheat, some floral spices. Light in palate, and lacking in complexity and balance.
Sampled at brewpub. Poured very light straw yellow with a small white head. Very lemony nose. Flavor were sour lemon, grass, and some weird spices. Didn’t like this one too much.

Growler in the parking lot and then later at home in more ideal rating conditions: Clear light golden yellow with tiny bubbles visable rising to the surface. Has a small frothy white head that quickly disappears. Aroma: slightly sweet, grass, wheat, light lemon rind. Taste: light wheat, mild lemon, grass, and mild spicy hops. Light bodied, watery.

On tap at the McKenzie’s Brew Pub. Poured a light and clear yellow color with a small sized white head. Serverd with a lemon wedge (bastards). Aromas and tastes of lemons (could it be the wedge) and light spices. Some wheat makes an apperance in the taste. Thin, watery and fizzy body. Not my cup of tea.
Clear straw with white head. Aroma is medium sweet, wheat, light clove, grass. Taste is medium sweet, wheat, mild grassy, hop spicy. Light body, nice crispness. Decent lawnmower beer.
Pretty decent head, too carbonated, watered-down, not much wheat qualities to the brew

Pours a very cloudy, pale golden yellow color with a half finger white head that immediately settles into a thin ring. Minimal spotty lacing left behind. Spicy aroma with lots of pepper and coriander character followed by bready yeast, banana and citrus fruit. Nice spice and wheat character along with subtle lemon zest. Light bodied, crisp and refreshing with a strong zesty spice presence that lingers over the citrus and yeast notes. Clove coriander and pepper provide a crisp refreshing character but the citrus peel and banana notes are faint. Nice bread/yeast character but needs more sweetness.
A crisp and clean summer beer. Hazy yellow, the aroma is a bit sour with some spice. The flavor has the lemon and spices. The finish is clean and dry. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I’m not much of a fan of wheat beers but it seems ok for the style. Cloudy yellow with a semi-sweet aroma. It’s light & drinkable. Ok

Draft at Glen Mills. Pours turbid dull gold with white clingy head. Nose is limey, citrus, spice, mild florals and hops. Tastes crisp, with a mix of limey citrus, coriandery spice, and a finishing hop kick.
Pours gold with a white head. Aroma is clove, citrus, earthy and yeast. Taste is sweet with some spicy undertones. Light bodied and refreshing.
(Draught) Pours a lightly hazy yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of lemon, coriander, soap, and bubblegum. Flavor of wheat, clove, citrus, and coriander.

On tap as Belgian Wheat. pale straw yellow, cloudy and a bubbly white head. light belgian yeast, hints of white peppery spice, fair bit of lemon and light banana. Taste is light, flavors of yeast and spice. Lemon dominates. Medium to light body, fairly dry, lighter end on carbonation..
on tap @ RBSG-pours no head and straw color. Aroma is some wheat/light malt, some spice. Taste is some wheat/light malt, some spice/lemon hops. Drying.

On tap at McKenzie, the third stop on our RBSG bus trip. Pours a clear yellow with a thin white head. Soft Belgian yeast, wheat, crisp. Nice wheat but a little bit small. Wheat and toast, nice Belgian yeast. Warm and phenolic. Smooth carbonation, big yeasty finish.
This poured a clear dark straw color with a white head. Aroma was light belgian spices, coriander and wheat. flavor was a bit on the watery side, light spices and not much else really.
Draft at the source. Clear golden amber color. Aroma of light hay. Taste is herbal hay.
On tap at Devon Brewpub. Pours reddish brown with thin off-white head. Nuts, toast, caramel, citrus, earth. Mild bitterness. Moderately sweet. Medium, crisp body.

On tap as English Brown Ale. Pours a dark reddish brown color with very little head. Lots of malt, messy and unitegrated with burnt caramel and some sweeter toffee notes with toasted biscuit behind. The taste is much of the same, a bit sugary in flavor and muddles the feel with a burnt flavor amongst the malts. Light body, over carbonated, prickly finish.
On tap at McKenzie, the third stop on our RBSG bus trip. Pours a clear brown, light, with a thin white head. Toast, roast, sweet malt. Toast, light malt and a light earthy bitterness. Decent.

This one pourd a murky lighter brown color with a light beige head. roma was very light nuts, some toasted malt and some brown sugar too. Flavor was not as good as aroma, very light chocolate and some toasted nutty notes.

Tap at McKenzie as English Brown Ale. Pours a clear amber with no head or lace. Sweet, syrupy nose. Taste is raw grainy and oatmeal heavy but not as focused and loveable as the Light Lager believe it or not. Finish is soapy and dry.
Draft. Pours amber with an off white head. Sweet toffee malty aroma with some light toasty notes. The flavor has toasted bread with some lightly sweet toffee and a low bitterness. Not bad.

From tap at the brewpub as English Brown Ale. Pours hazy orange to brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is roasted and slight breadish to caramelish. Bitter and slight herbal. Dark roasted malty. Dry and roasted malty finish.
Draught at brew pub as "English Brown Ale". Pours caramel amber. White head. Nose/taste of brown malt and sweet caramel. Light and average.
A bit underwhelming. Pours light brown from tap with a smidgen of head. Not a lot of aroma. If you really really focus you might get some element of maltiness. Finishes fairly clean.
I don't know a whole lot about this style, but it was a very enjoyable brew, nicely balanced

Pours a deep dark brown color with mahogany edges and a 1.5 finger mocha head that quickly settles into a thick, lasting ring. Streaks and splotches of soapy lacing left behind. Slightly smokey roasted malt aroma with a nice balance of sweet and burnt malt notes. Hints of oatmeal, toffee, gourmet espresso bean, toast and nut countered by sweeter chocolate notes. Kind of tame though for the style. Full bodied with a dry roasted malt presence that’s countered by chocolate malt sweetness. Strong oatmeal character with burnt toast and deeply roasted coffee bean flavor followed by dark chocolate malt, toffee and hazelnut. Subtle lactic presence smoothes things out but it’s pretty dry/roasted and somewhat acrid. Subtle alcohol sweetness towards the finish but there’s little to no heat. Easy to drink but could use a little sweetness. A touch too dry for my preference.
Good enough to go back for another glass. Heavy and thick head. They only offer tap and no bottles

On tap at McKenzie’s ( Glen mills). Pours a deep dark brown color with a two finger mocha head that quickly settles into a thick, lasting ring.
