Slightly smoky roasted malt aroma with a nice balance of sweet and burnt malt notes. Hints of oatmeal, toffee, coffee, toast and nuts also. Taste has strong oatmeal character with burnt toast and deeply roasted coffee bean flavor followed by dark chocolate malt, toffee and hazelnut. Full bodied with low carbonation.
Dark, subtle roastiness on the nose, almost light & quite drinkable. Solid effort but definitely more oatmeal then milk.
Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate and roast. Taste is sweet with light bitterness. Light bodied work a almost but not quite creamy texture.

On tap at Devon. Mostly opaque black with moderate foamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, licorice, oatmeal. A little bit sweet, low bitterness. Medium bodied, mostly smooth. Pairs well with food, but leaves a little to be desired on its own. Updated 8/23/2012. Much better when I had it last night. Bumping the Aroma and Overall.

On tap as Oatmeal Stout. Pours a dark brown with thin light tan head. Nose is light with notes of roasted malts and tangy sweet anise. Light notes of oatmeal, roasted malts underneath, tons of boozy anise almost jager like. Light body, soft on the palate, strong carbonation, prickly finish.

On tap at McKenzie, the third stop on our RBSG bus trip. Pours a clear ruby tinged brown with a thin beige ehad. Sweet oatmeal, roast and char. Malt and roast. A touch sweet, oatmeal sweetness. Roast, toast, sweet malt and chocolate. Nicely balanced.

This poured a darker brown color with a beige head. Aroma was light bakers chocolate, medium roasted malts> flavor was a bit more roasted than expected for an oatmeal stout, very smooth and drinkable though.
Brown black pour with tan head and lace. Aroma of toasted malt and light chocolate. Toasted malt, light chocolate, very light coffee, and a good malt bitter. Medium bodied but a tad fizzy for me.
2004 bottle. Pours a hazy copper orange body with a white head. Brett, leather, light spicy and yeast character with a dry finish. A bit oxidized for sure, but not bad.

Date: 07/20/2005 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting hazy dark yellow, huge white head, big funk aroma and flavor, nice malt, good spices well blended with the funk, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

another bottle found n the basement. I’m pretty sure it’s a 2003. aroma is just about all brettt, very nice. the beer was not cloudy and clear. flavor, no oxidation, very hoppy still and nice brett flavors, horseblanket, and musty, but still well balanced by hops. medium to full bodied, just an amazing beer that I wish I had bought more of. held up very well. I’d put it in the same ballpark as orval. very nice.

Thanks to Slander for sharing this one at heavyweight open house. 750 ml bottle- label fell off, but labelled on the cap. This was a bottle from 03, so I think the brett characteristics may have increased over time. Pours a clear light gold with a nice fluffy lasting head. Aroma is out of control with brett, in a good way. A crapload of barnyard aromas- hay, horseblanket, musty cobweb like, and even a bit of lemony citrus to it as well. Flavors are loaded with horseblanket, leather, nice citrusy notes, light bready malts, and a dry slightly acidic and bitter finish. Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth despite a relatively high carbonation. Excellent beer- similar, but better than many other beers that use brett to try to replicate orval.
Shared 750ml bottle. Not a bad beer. Was expecting something a little more. Tasted what it should be.

Pours a clean, medium golden color with a giant foamy head that’s gonna be here a while. Yeasty aroma with a little barnyard funk, and a subtle hop nose. Flavors are yeast, a little lemon, and some pepper with a light finish. Nice fizzy palate.

750ml bottle shared with scubatrip: Slightly cloudy light orange-amber that is a pale straw golden yellow when held to the light. Medium white head that lasts for the first few sips and then dies. The aroma has some barnyard to it, and at first I’m worried that maybe I have a bad bottle. Checking other ratings here it seems like it’s supposed to have this light farmhouse quality to it. There are also hints of lemon zest, spicy cloves, yeast, wood, and wet leather. The taste has some barnyard & leather flavors at first, and opens up to show apple, tart orange rind, sweet light malts, biscuit, and a hint of peppery alcohol if held in the mouth. Finishes dry with grassy/spicy hops, sweet light malts, and funky yeast. Tastes a bit more like a farmhouse ale, as BobSandage points out that what I was expecting.

Pours a murky medium yellow with lots of head. Aroma of sweat socks. Yeasty and medicinal in flavor. If the beer was classified as a farmhouse ale, I could see the justification in the high ratings this beer achieves. As a Belgian Pale Ale, I don’t think it is that good of an example of style.
Poured a dark gold with a fluffy off white head. Aroma was yeasty with some clove/spices and barnyard funk as it warms. Flavor starts a little sweet and tart with a dry light bitter finish.

Pours a clear deep golden with a huge, puffy and well-lacing white head. Has a very interesting, complex, earthy barnyard aroma. Body starts lightly creamy, dry, earthy and malty with some mild leathery sweetness. Nice complexity and balanced lead to great authenticity. With a touch more hops, this would be a very close duplicate to Orval. Thanks go out to slob for the trade!
Tap at the brewpub. Hazy light orange pour with a white head. Light citrus and light bread. Okay.
On tap at the brewery. Comes a hazy gold with a decent white head. Mild aroma and taste of malt, wheat, and grass. Pretty good.
Taster at the brewery. High creamy lasing white head. Hazy yellow body. Weak and sweet banana aroma and flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a short finish.

On tap at Pumphouse. Pours a slightly hazy straw with a half finger of quickly diminishing, rocky white head, Mild aroma, tones of wheat/grain, bread, mild sweet malt. Very slight hop up fron, moderate wheat flavor. Mild wheat finish. Moderate carbonation, light body, and light/watery mouthfeel. Drinkable, mild, a decent wheat beer but could be stronger in terms of flavor and alcohol.
Draught at the brewery, on October 10, 2012 Marked as 5.0% ABV and 23 IBU Cloudy orange color, white head. Sweet, spicy taste. Dry aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Sweet, malty scent.
This beer was a little to mild for me as far as the wheat beers are concerned i would like a little more from that type

I don’t normally like wheat beers, but this one wasn’t too bad. It did not have that spicy flavor/aftertaste that so many wheats have. Very refreshing on a hot day, but I wouldn’t drink more than one.
From the Jug at the Pumphouse Brewery & Restaurant, Longmont 08/10/2008 Hoppy aroma. Thick white head. Light golden coloured and hazy in appearance with a little dryness and bitterness in the finish.
Crushed with Jakebra at the brewpub. Malt staleness gets to you. Blah. Very wheaty and yeasty. Almost overpowering, and that’s not a compliment.

On tap at Pumphouse poured a cloudy yellow with a small lasting white head. Aromas of wheat, bread dough and yeast. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bread dough, wheat and yeast with a smooth yeasty finish.
Gylden klar skum hvid lidt Humle karamel korn citrus Vande flad Cask @ Prince of Wales ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
When compared to other Colorado IPA’s this one holds its own. It has a nice hop-to-malt balance, a crisp mouthfeel and a good finish.
From the Jug at the Pumphouse Brewery & Restaurant, Longmont 08/10/2008 Hoppy aroma. Golden coloured strong in alcohol hoppy and pale with pine fruit flavour. Crisp and bitter in the finish.

Draft at the brewery. Dark amber in color and flavors of caramel malts with light spice and a very light hop profile make this a very average pale ale. Pretty plain, non-descript even and certainly nothing to get too excited about especially on a beer trip through Colorado.
Crushed with Jakebra at the brewpub. Light hops and caramel malt on the nose. Great bitter hoppy flavor and finish kicks ass. Excellent pale ale.

I’d say the American beer community has moved beyond this hoppy pale ale with the advent of extreme brewing. But this is a nice beer and should be enjoyed for the balance of hop and malt, for the contrast of sweet malt and bitter hop, achieved without one overpowering the other. It’s a nice beer.

Tap @ Pumphouse: Poured a lightly hazed dark copper color with a small off-white head. Grapefruit and citrus aroma with some malt trying to get through. The flavor was dominated by grapefruit hops and some caramel. Bitter rind finish. Long bitter finish. Light to medium body.

On tap at the brewpub on 10/14/07: Pours a transparent copper bronze with a nicely-lacing froth of clingy white head. Aroma of fairly fresh citrusy hops and mildly sweet toasty pale malt. Body starts with a decent malty sweetness and some citrusy, earthy hop balance toward a crisp, very drinkable bittersweet finish.

Date: 10/14/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear copper, fine white head, scattered and drippy lace, sweet grapefruit aroma, lots of sweet crystal malt flavor, well balanced with lots of citrus hops, nice lasting bitter finish, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4

Nitro tap at brewpub. Pours hazy amber with a large creamy off-white head, good lacing, head mostly lasting. Aroma is average malt (cereal, meal), heavy hops (flowers, pine), average yeast (sweat) with notes of peach and dust. Medium bodied, creamy texture, soft carbonation and a bitter finish. Average duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness. Earlier Rating: 7/23/2005 Total Score: 3.4 Draught. Pours hazy copper with a small tan foamy head; creamy spotty lacing. Pine and citrus hop aroma with roasted caramel malt nose. Pine and citrus hop flavor with roasted grain malt body and an acidic alcohol hint. Medium bodied and spicy.
On tap at the brewery. Comes a somewhat hazy reddish brown with an average beige head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Taste is malt, caramel, and dark fruit. Decent Amber Ale.
Sample at the brewery. Medium high fluffy white lasting head. Hazy red body. Cocoa caramel fruity sweet aroma andf flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a short finish.

Draught at the brewery, on October 10, 2012 As "Red Alert Amber" at 5.7& ABV and 24 IBU. Clear brown color, tan head. Sweet, malt, roasted, taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high dry bitterness. Sweet, malty scent.
This was one of the best beers that pumphouse produced to me it was a nice caramel flavor.

(growler 5/13/11). Clear amber color. Medium off white head. Moderate sweeet caramel and toast/malt aroma. Flavor of the same. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

Draught. Sweet caramel and cherry aroma. Dark ruby with a thin swirly head and slow but active carbonation. Good malt depth but a touch too sweet. Caramel with chocolate and nutty notes. Palate is thin, but more than that particularly watery, as in diluting of the flavor of the beer.

Tap at the brewpub - a very malty amber ale, so much so that it is hard to even notice those hops trying to break through - very sweet, nutty, with touches of nutmeg and other spices (this makes things a little more interesting) - the boiled vegetable character I noticed in their IPA is even more noticeable here, and it really detracts from my enjoyment of the beer.
From the Jug at the Pumphouse Brewery & Restaurant, Longmont 08/10/2008 Malt aroma. Bronze golden coloured and malty with a crisp dry and slightly bitter finish.

Crushed with Jakebra at the brewpub. Sweet malt nose. Lots of sweetness. Definite initial hop bitterness that mellows into a very pleasant malt sweetness. One of the most appealing ambers I’ve ever had.

Tap @ Pumphouse: Poured a clear red copper color with a thin off-white head. The aroma was malty with some sweetness. Toasty caramel notes. The malty flavor had a little roast to it. Hints of chocolate and citrus. Semi-dry and bitter finish. Medium body.

Sadly, a high carbonation plus low malt levels creates a thin body in this one. Some astringent bitterness detected from the carbonation. Pleasant chocolate and coffee notes though. Unfortunately, hard to detect behind the fizz and rather harsh bitterness (not a "hoppy" bitterness, but rather an "astringent" bitterness). Maybe it was a bad batch?

Draught. Black (possibly opaque, but I forgot my flashlight). Aroma is moderately malty (strong coffee, roasted nuts, dark chocolate). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly acidic, moderately bitter, hint of husk/vegetable. Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation. More like a stout than a porter to me, but overall very good...the aroma is more genuinely coffee-like instead of the biting roasted grain note of most American stouts, and the flavor is nicely balanced except for a bit of husky aftertaste. The recipe reportedly changes somewhat with each batch.

(Trinity Saison Festival 4/17/10). Light rose/blush color. Medium white head. Moderate brett and tart cherry aroma, with light sweetness. Tart cherry and brett flavors. Avg duration. Light tart finish. Thin texture. Soft carbonation. Spare lacing.

Avery Sour Ale Fest. I just wrote down "nope" for my notes on this one. Can only assume that there was neither a cherry nor a bomb in this brew. Compared to other Pumphouse fruity beers I’ve had, I wouldn’t be surprised if the fruit was either flat and stale or basically non-existent.

Boulder Sourfest ’10 - promising nose, with a nice cherry character, mild spiciness and subtle yeast phenols - the taste, however, was waxy, artificial, like poorly made cherry syrup - it kind of tasted like the inside of a Yankee Candle shop - yick.
11th October 2008. GABF. This version a stronger 6.4% abv. Hazy gold beer. Nicely sour with only a light touch of cherry. Nice palate cleanser.
(Draught, 6.4% version) Pours a cloudy yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of cherry, wheat, grass, citrus, and florals. Flavor of hops (grassy, herbal), light cherry, and yeast.
draft. Lots of brett phenolics. Hint of cherry. Light yellow color. No sourness. Low flavor, but still very good. Wonderful.
Nose with lots of fruit and yeast, followed up by great balance of flavors. It has the typical cloudiness of a Saison. a very nice beer.

Very promising nose. Upon the first sip, it actually delivered. Near equal amounts of yeasty and alcoholic flavors. Malts were mild, yet noticeable. Cherry notes were subtle in the aroma and flavor departments, thankfully. Actually, I thought it had the perfect amount of cherry infusion; not too much, but just enough. It provided some subtle fruity flavors and a nice tartness in the finish. Interesting sensation of hotness on the tongue. Very well-made and tasty.

Draught. Medium yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (light bread), lightly hoppy (flowers, citrus - lemon), lightly yeasty (barnyard), with notes of cherry, orange, and apricot. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Nice fruity aroma, mild quick tartness, decent brew.

Draught. Hazy medium amber. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel), lightly hoppy (citrus - grapefruit), with a light note of peach. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Light to medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation, lightly astringent. A bit thin for an ESB, but so is Natalie Portman.
1/27/2011 1:11:59 AM Bottle from Bierparadijs. Dark brown body with huge head. Sweet malty nose. Taste of caramel, toffee and sugar. Syrupy texture. Nice

The first of the Roosenbergs, since 1992. Hazy brown beer with fluffy off-white head and estery profile with red berries, pear, peach, caramelly malt background, soft herbal hops and some warming alcohol in the finish, in which sweetness lingers a bit. Okay but nothing to make a special effort for to purchase.

8/XII/12 - 33cl bottle @ Culinair Bierfestival (Waasmunster) - BB: n/a (2012-1337) Thanks to Kris for sharing today’s beers! Clear red brown beer, big aery beige head, pretty stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: caramel, lots of dried fruits, some couch syrup (elder berries?), mocha and chocolate. MF: ok carbon, medium to full body. Taste: caramel, quite some dried fruits, mocha, chocolate, little bitter, roasted flavours, some sour touch. Aftertaste: overripe berries, some ripe banana, little bitter, mocha.
Bottle@home (0,33l) Head fat foam. Color red-brown.Aroma grass silage Taste little sour, alcohol. Palate thin, wavery. Overall not my taste.

Bottle @ home. Full white to off-white head on top of a nice red colored beer. Smell malts, raisins, sweetness. Taste malts, slightly a hint of bitter, sweetness, raisin, dried fruits. Medium to full carbo, medium body.
Pours a nice cola colored brown. Aromas of dark malts, fruit, and a touch of spice. Has flavors of chocolate, caramel, and a touch of wood.
330 ml bottle a dark brown colored beer with a white head aroma malts caramel spicy and fruits flavor malts spicy some fruits and caramel
33cl, from De Bierloods Adegem, not complex brew, yet easy to drink, balanced, clear, good head, nice brew

Bottle: Poured a caramel to molasses color with a two finger creamy off white head. Aroma is of dark fruits and hints of alcohol. Taste is a winey fruit with a nice sweet malty caramel finish. Leaves a dry warm alcohol finish.

Bottle 33cl. @ home. Clear dark red brown color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to light beige head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, roasted, light caramel, light to moderate yeasty, spicy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090606]

Abbey blond but ’fake’, i.e. brewed not for an actual abbey, but for Bierland in Hamme, if my memory doesn’t fail me. Strong estery fruitiness, sweetish, pale malts, sourish touch especially in the finish, insufficient hops in the finish to balance out the sweetness. Did not like this too much.

8/XII/12 - 33cl bottle @ Culinair Bierfestival (Waasmunster) - BB: 10/I/14 (2012-1335) Thanks to Kris for sharing today’s beers! Clear blond beer, big creamy white head, stable, adhesive. aroma: bit sweet, grassy and herbal, peppery, some citrus, sugary. MF: quite some carbon, medium body. Taste: little sweet in the start, grassy hops, citrus. Aftertaste: alcohol noticeable, citrus, bitter, not too complex, metallic.
Bottle@tasting (2001), 33cl. Head: thick, white colored foam. Color: yellow golden. Aroma: stale. Taste: some bitter and sour. Palate: watery, bitter finish. Overall: ok.

33cl bottle @ home. Decent sized white head that diminishes quickly on top of a very hazy yellow / orange colored brew. Aroma of malts, grapes, plums, sweetness. Taste sweet, grapes, slightly overripe fruits. Average carbonation, medium body.
330 ml bottle a golden yellow colored beer with a white head aroma malts spicy fruits and some hops flavor malts spicy citrus fruits and some hops
Bottle: Poured a hazy orange yellow with an off white head. Aroma was fruit straight from first pour. Taste was fruit and fresh. Not crazy complex, but a solid brew from top to bottom.
33cl, from De Bierloods Adegem, not complex brew, balanced, hazy, good head, nice brew

Bottle 33cl. @ [ Fastelavns Tasting Ulfborg ]. Light light unclear medium orange color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, fruity, moderate to light heavy yeasty. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090221]

BEER VAGABOND ROBS OLD JINN ! A surprisingly good beer which demonstrates immediate strength that holds to the end. The head is as big as any drunk yet, and the only major downside is a bit too much reliance on A coppery flavour. The bottle promises little but this is a good solid blonde
Hazy golden with a big white head. Fruity, herbal and yeasty aroma. >Dry and fruity flavour with a citric tartness. Weak hoppy aftertaste.

500ml can from the shop in Wroclaw. It's back and it's good. Didn't pour, but definitely clear. Strong complex malty aromas driven by honey and soft caramel with a healthy dose of floral and herbal hops. More of the same in the mouth, balanced by sweetness and mild bitterness, fairly rich texture leading into a full-flavoured but clean finish. A lager for ale lovers. Really good.
Pale golden color, weak white head. Bready, malty aroma. Taste is sweet, lightly malty. A little weird in a good way. Weak body, medium carbonation.
W zapachu wyraźne aromaty owocowe, estrowe. W smaku niska pełnia, lekkie nuty słodowe, trochę owocowych estrów, niska goryczka.

Blind test - 25 koncerniaków. Wygląd: Barwa jasnozłota, klarowna. Piana niska, drobnopęcherzykowa koloru białego, szybko redukuje się do małego pierścienia, nie pozostawiając lacingu. Aromat: Znikomy, głównie estry w postaci sztucznego jabłka i gruszki, diacetyl, lekka chlebowa słodowość oraz kwiatowy chmiel. W tle nuta kartonowego utlenienia. Smak: Tak jak w aromacie. W ustach półsłodkie, treściwość niska i wodnista, wysycenie średnie. Goryczki brak. Finisz wytrawny z nutą ziołowego chmielu.

5.0% Bottle from Continental Delicatessen, Unit 11, Co-Op Buildings, Durham Rd, Birtley, DH3 2PS. Pale golden with a thin white head. It has a malty and toffee flavour with grassy notes and biscuit on the finish. Ok.
# 139, 11/2015. Na první napití poměrně nevýrazný, ale v závěru hodnotím jako velice slušně pitelný pivo, který zanechává poměrně příjemnej ječmenej ocas.
Clear, golden color and white head from medium to high. Malty light bitter. Medium carbonation.
Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnień z degustacji w ramach uzupełnienia profilu.
Aromat słodowy, dosyć wodnity. W smaku podobnie. Gdzieś w tle przewija się lekki chmiel. Wszystko niestety jest wodniste
Burk, importerad av kompis. Gyllengul vätska. Doft av bröd och blöt kartong. Tunn smak med lätt humleton och bröd.

Bottle - my first foray into Good Bastards beers. A good dark brown colour. Just a little sweet malt on the nose, with a hint of chocolate. A dryish palate with a very grainy malt flavour. The mouthfeel is overall thin and watery. Made to be unoffensive, and meets the mark. Would be popular in Cossie Clubs I’m sure. Does what it says on the label - and there’s nothing wrong with that.

330mL bottle. Pours red/brown, thin tan head. A sweet nose, smooth smelling with roasty malt. Flavour comes mainly from roast malt, with smooth cocoa and a hint of bitterness. The let down is a very thin, watery body. Very drinkable, very mild flavour.
330ml bottle. Rich black in colour with a velvety creamy slightly tan head. Burnt toffee and chocalte aroma and feels smooth and silky in the mouth. Taste of burnt malt.

Roasted malt nose, milk chocolate and some coffee. A hint of hop in there too. Rather watery mouthfeel that doesn’t support the aroma. A bit of an off flavour of nuts... Reminds me of a simple, watery lager with burnt malt added.

Shared this one with my wife over lamb burgers at Tuatara Backpackers. There are equal touches of chocolate and crystal malt, lending a nice flavour without any complexity. But the label makes this clear: this beer is NOT about complexity and all about having a good session. Fair enough. Cheesy label though.

Dry molasses, roasty aroma. Overly chummy label. I’m sure someone was laughing their arse off while designing the label, but it’s just not funny. Medium dark brown and clear. Dry coffee porter. Slightly tangy and mulchy. Medium light body. Light metal, light roast soy in the finish. A bit watery. Fair enough session beer.
Black in colour, pours with big head. strong malty aroma. Sweet cappicinao tatse, needs more bitterness.

Butterscotchy, caramelly, slightly raosty nose. Sweet, mossy, hints of roastyness on the palate, dries out a touch towards the finish, a touch better than my first sample, a cross between, Newcastle Brown and tooheys Old or something, not a favourite style, easy to drink, but not overly interesting. This time, my bottle appeared to be quite old, it had avery rusty cap, it was better than the first bottle i had of it.

Flaska från Landbierparadis. Gyllengul klar vätska med med vitt skum. Hö, gräs och säd i doft och smak. Inga krusiduller. Riktigt bra balans. Frisk, lätt sötma, fyllig och medelstor precis lagom beska. Riktigt gott.
Táp @ porch Bayreuth. Ízletes kis helles mely könnyen csúszik az ebéd mellett

resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, light body, medium body, full body, thin feel, oily feel, creamy, sticky, slick feel, thick feel, long finish, abrupt finish, bitter, astringent, fizzy, lively, average carbonation, soft carbonation, flat,
500ml Bottle - Golden with a white head. Grassy aroma with notes of lime. Lemon, lime, grass and straw in the taste. Quite refreshing.

500 ml bottle. BB 23/06/17. Thanks Timo A! Clear pale golden color with a small white head. Honey sweetness, malt and some dryness in the aroma. The flavor is malty with some dry papery notes. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
50 cl bottle @ Timo A. BBE 23.06.2016. Pours pale clear golden color with a small head. Starchy aroma, toffee, butter and some pale malts. Flavor is grainy, some starchy notes, clove. Boring. 3313
50 cl bottle @ Timo A, BBE 23.06.2017 Aroma has hayish grain and grassy hops. Flavour has grainy malt, some grassy hops, minerals and mild honey tones. Quite typical helles.
Bottle @ Bayreuth. Pours clear Pale yellow with a white head. Grains, cereal, bread and grassy hops. Short bitter finish. Elegant and rather tasty.
50 cl bottle. Golden color. Grains and malt aroma and flavor. Watery body. Average carbo. Unpleasant alcohol notes.Average Helles
50cl bottle. Pours clear golden color with a huge most good lasting white head. Aroma of grains and pale malt. Taste of grainy malt and mild spicy hops, nothing special.
From backlog. Bottle at Viking Line Amorella. Golden with white head. Malts, hops, sweetness and bitterness.
Bottle on M/S Mariella, Sto-Hel. Light golden with a white head. Aroma and taste of grass, bread and light hops. Thin and boring, nothing special.

330ml brown bottle poured into a pint glass. Appearance is clear pale golden with a medium sized white head. Aroma of grains, wet grass, mineral notes. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter. Palate is light bodied, watery texture and average carbonation. Kukko Pils is a simple uncomplicated Pilsener without any surprises for better or worse.
Can, enjoyed straight from it. Aroma of grass, malts, lager yeast, grain. Light body, short aftertaste. A bit watery, but still enjoyable.
500 ml can at home. Clear bright golden with white head. Pale malt, slight grain, fairly high bitterness, hay, grass and faint apple juice
Aroma malt, eple, humle. Utseende klar gylden med lite skum. Smak malt, humle, karamell. Medium fylde, maltpreget, bitterbesk. Boks kjøpt i Kilpis Finnland, 50cl 4,5%
50cl can, local store. Pours golden color, thin white head. malty aroma. Hoppy flavor, with a sweet finish.

Can from Sale, Pusula, Finland Pours pale golden with a quickly diminishing mediud sized soapy head. Leaves a foamy lacing on the glass. Pale aroma of malts, cereals, mild herbs and a hint of citrus. Taste is quite light too: pale malts, crispy hops, some cereal/biscuit and citric notes. Delicate carbonation, light to medium body, tender hoppy finish. Pleasant easy drink to go with grill food on a hot summer’s day, but doesn’t stand out in any way. Extra points for being gluten free.
Smell of hay, malt. Pale golden colour, high white head. Aroma of hops, malt, some yeasty notes. Mildly bitter. Rich carbon, light body. Does not stand out in any way.

Pale yellow pour topped by a fluffy white head with some lingering lace. Nose is cereal grains, hops in the background. Bitter. Middle is lightly malted grain, herbal hip character, some crisp apple. Finish is bitter and refreshing. Not bad.

Draught (HBF2001) Dark, small keggy head. Sweet bready yeasty aroma, fruit esters, a little sickly. Palate too a bit slick. Good roast, and gently hop components, but not subtle enough for me, not to the Belgian style. Rating rediscovered while packing for a move in 2010.

Pours beutifully cloudy reddish brown with a firm brown/beige head. Nice strong fruity, nutty, spicy aroma. It is balanced dryish and is firmly malty. Roasty and earthy with hints of oranges. Bitterish finish. Very complex and superbly balanced. This is an outstanding ale!

Draught @ Villi Wäinö. Hazy amber, thin white head. Light soury nose, citrus, yeast, quite spicy. Flavor has yeast, dough, citrus, spices, hops. Interesting tripel-like brew with some twists. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Tap@blackdoor. Yellow, cloudy. Fruity malts on nose. Really fruity- apples, pear, melon, like a fruit cider really. Good soft smooth body, almost creamy, real nice. Dry, bitter, but nicely soft though. Apple seeds&zest flavour-wise, pale malts, some hay. There’s probably some yeasty tripel esters there, but the fruityness is just so overwhealming right now. I guess this is a bit too young. Doesn’t taste like a triple, more like a fruit beer/cider. I hope I’ll find it after a month or so...

Draught (HBF2001) Dry hoppy aroma, closer to the belgian style than the dubbel was. Peppery hoppy bite, but also plenty of sweet malts and yeastiness. My last Stadin of the evening, and a good one to end on. Rating rediscovered while packing for a move in 2010. Yes, I was an idiot - I should have stayed for the Stadin Festari Sahti, and Barley Wine. Rerate: 250ml bottle - From Timo Konttinen’s personal stash - Brewed 2002, drunk 2015. (7:3:8:3:15=3.6) Lovely sweet malty mammi aroma, lots of raisins, plenty of oxidisation too. Pours a flat dark orange, with almost no head. Wow - what a gorgeous taste. Everything from the aroma is improved - beautifully rich malts, some mjod-like aspects, lovely sherry for the raisins. Palate is a bit flat, but it is a very old beer. Finish is honeylike malts, and a lovely dry resiny hop finish. Overall - this is fantastic, and has survived the ageing very well. The whole thing is so light, there’s no sign of 8.7+% at all. Respect, StaPa, the first Finnish micro brewery I ever heard of, and the one I fell in love with immediately afterwards.
Golden colour, slightly hazy, firm white head. Distinct aroma of banana and white wine(!). Sweet and full bodied, fruity, pineapple flavour. Honeyish finish.

250ml bottle (thanks FatPhil and congratulations on 10k!). Slightly hazy dark amber color. No head. Dried apricots, sweet, honey, fruity notes in aroma. Dried fruits, apricots mainly, woody, bit of straw, caramel, sweet in taste. Woody bitterness. Sweet, caramel in aftertaste. Feels thin (fuller as it warms up), but it’s 10%!? Nice one!

250ml bottle - from Timo Konttinen’s personal stash - thanks! Quite spicy aroma, apricot, some apple from Anna, almost a little watery, touch of mint later. Quite a light palate, no sticky sweetness at al, carbonation very low. Taste is mostly of rich roasty bread, some mintiness in the retronasals too. Very pleasant bitterness in the finish, dry and noble. Later some dark treacle. Palate remarkably light, absolutely no sign of 10% at all, almost watery. Gentle woodiness. Very easy sipper. Fills out a little as you go down the bottle, but never becomes dirty. Finish even has a little bit of a coffee later, quite unexpected, but nice. Prefered this to the Lee’s Harvest - and that’s saying something.

(BBE 4/03) Orange colored, vanishing yellow head. Strong alcohol in barley winish aroma, fruits, mild developed cardboard and raisins there also. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is sweet with nuts, balanced and still very warming alcohol, nice woody tones and toffee. Excellent flavor. Aftertaste is vinous with lasting fruits also. Nice treat!

Orange coloured, cloudy, no head. Pours thick. Restrained aromatic hop aroma. Fruity, very malty, hints of pineapple. Bitter finish with hop aroma all the way through. This excellent barley wine is dominated by the chewy malt.

(Tapped) Deep red, almost black color, small head. Mild, sweetish, fruity aroma. Quite sweet, a bit thin and alcoholic palate. Bittersweet aftertaste. Seems like someone added water to this. Needs more body.
Black with rich beige head. Very roasty and very dry. Light bodied. Earthy. Very biter finish. Flavourful. Perhaps a little too light bodied, but still very good.

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy la Fausse Blonde
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: Goudgeel met een bescheiden witte kraag. Zeer zwakke blonde met bloemen en licht zuur, zoet appeltje op de achtergrond.

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy la Fausse Blonde
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: Bottled 26cl. 5.2 ABV. Courtesy of Bov. It pours a hazy deep golden beer with a fizzy, quick diminishing white head. The aroma is mainly of chlorine, cork, glue, lemonade, jarred pickles- unusual. Acidic taste. Slightly astringent. High carbonation. Medium bodied. No lacework. Long dry finish. Thanks Bov!

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy la Fausse Blonde
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: Golden color, no head, fine perlage. Light malt aroma. Weak malt body, yeast. Poor hopping. Brewed with extracts? Beers of Switzerland

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy la Fausse Blonde
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: 5.2%, hazy blond colour, fine head, soapy hoppiness with notes of detergent, lot of carbonation, tart and slightly acidic with a very rough and aggressiv bitterness, unpleasant dry soapy finish - HELP ! Jun 17, 2002 / 5/2/4/2/7: cloudy orange colour, no head, discreet fruity hop aroma, sweet and quite neutral flavour with a strange, dry finish - hard to understand ...

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy l'Eau de Rose (Fox)
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: Bottled 26cl. Courtesy of Bov. It pours a lactic murky yellow beer with a fizzy white head. The nose is reminiscent of pataks chilli & lime pickle, arabic gum, candy sugar, lemon peel and vinegar- very distinct. Extremely sweet taste. Metallic, sulphury, acidic and reminiscent of a mixture between maple syrup, lemonade and and brown sugar. This beer gets cloying after a few sips. Disgusting sticky metallic finish which is reminiscent of maple syrup and iron tablets. The aroma was interesting and not unpleasant. Awful taste. Thanks Bov!

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy l'Eau de Rose (Fox)
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: Golden colour, poor (or not at all ) head. Fruity aroma, not expecially interesting, winy, sweet and a little fruity. Too sweet, a lot of sugar syrup, fruit syrup (did they use any real fruit?). Sweet palate, no hop. Drinkable, as a soda, but I don't consider that a beer. Beers of Switzerland

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy l'Eau de Rose (Fox)
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: re-rate 8/13/2003 Now called Eau de Rose - cloudy orange colour, big creamy head, fruity nose (currant ?), cane sugar aroma, deadly sweet, heavy and sirupy, disgusting sugary finish - this is an awefull juice of sugar 6/17/2002: cloudy red-amber colour, no head, aroma of dark fruity, extremely sweet, slightly tart with a long sweet fruity finish - very dubious

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy la Chaste Clef
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: hazy red-amber colour, fine head, light aroma of red fruits, sparkling and very sweet with a dry sirupy finish - good for children and people who don't like beer. Dec 18, 2002 / 5/3/4/2/7: unusual red-orange colour, lot of foam while pouring in the glass but the head is reducing very quickly, fruity aroma (cherry?, plum?), slightly overcarbonated, tart and very sweet, dry sugary finish - hum, hum ....

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy la Chaste Clef
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: Amber color, frothy head. Winy aroma, esters, lightly fruity (red fruits, strawberry, granadine syrup). Poor malt, pretty dry; the (sweet) fruitness given by a syrup doesn't match with the bitterness, resulting in one of those undrinkable lambics. Simple palate. Good only for girls who don't like beer. Beers of Switzerland
355ml bottle. Had this side by side with a german doppelbock and this left me confused. Its like chocolate balsamic syrup.

28-Jul-10 (12-oz bottle) Cellared a few years now, this beer pours hazy, dark-amber with nearly an inch of creamy, light-tan head. The beer smells very sweet and fruity, with raisins and figs coming out much more than dark malts. The sweet, dark fruitiness continues on the palate, offering honey, prunes, figs, molasses, brown sugar, milk chocolate, and dark, slightly smoky malts, but the overall sweetness is a bit excessive. Full bodied in weight and moderately carbonated, it’s rich and smooth on the palate. Sure, it’s certainly a bit older than what is ideal for the style, and there’s some oxidation present, but it’s still quite enjoyable.

Draft at Old Fashioned. Thick, opaque brown. Thin, oily head. Rich and chocolaty. Very thick and rich body with some dark fruit tones as well. Doesn’t really nail the style. Lots of roasty character. Fairly unique or just oddly executed.

Pours a hazy mahogany color, with a sudsy lace - quite a nutty aroma, with some dough, faint diacetyl, fig, raisin - smooth, creamy, medium-bodied - quite nutty, with notes of brown sugar, a lot of raisin, toffee, caramel - finishes with loads of chocolate and a spicy/peppery character, which is a nice twist - aside from the mild diacetyl in the nose, this is a pretty solid brew - quite underrated - maybe they just have poor quality control.
Pour was dark copper with a roasted caramel and sweet malt aroma. Dark fruit character came out in the flavor with more sweet malt. Well blended brew.

Bottle. Poured a clear orange brown color with a khaki head. Smelled of glazed donut, hay, and nonspecific spices. Medium bodied with low-ish carbonation and a bit of sweetness. tasted of toffee, ice tea, and a bit of grassy hop. Fresh cereal grain aftertaste. So so.
Pours reddish brown with large head. Earthy aroma with some nuttiness. Flavor is fruity yet bland and sour.

12oz bottle. Not sure who traded me this one as I just found it when I was cleaning up some old boxes (so who knows how long its been in there). Poured a medium and cloudy reddish / brownish color with a huge sized off white head. Aromas of dirt / earthy, roasted nuts, and some card board. Tastes of dark fruits (raisins with some plums and cherries), caramel, and nuts. A little off and a little sour finish that I actually kind of liked.

Aroma is slightly vinegary and sweet. Dark brown body with a quickly diminishing head. Flavor is light roasted malt, some chocolate, slight dirt/earthen flavor. Palate is weak and lacks carbonation. This bottle may be past prime. Flavor was pretty good nonetheless.

(12oz bottle) Small tan head atop hazy dark brown body. Aroma is sweet, chocolate, confectionery sugar, light hazelnut. Taste is sweet, chocolate, some caramel, icing, faint alcohol. Watery medium body, undercarbonated.

Bottle. Very cloudy orangey gold in colour. Fruity spicy hoppy wheat beer. Fruity (grapefruit-citrus). Spicy (coriander & cloves). Yeasty (lots of sediment). Hoppy. Quite a tart bitter citrus hoppy edge. A rare thing - a hoppy wheat beer. A cross between a Saison and a Witbier. Unusual. Nice! (2008)

A somewhat different wheat beer, as there are several in Wallonia. Yellowish white, regular, sticky but not very stable head, colour of ’old gold’, clear instead of the expected mistiness which typifies a standard witbier. Light fruity aroma, grapefruit, green apple, pine resin, grains, honey, grassy and somewhat peppery hops. Grainy taste with a brief, honeyish sweetness in the onset, drying up from the middle onwards, slick and resinous with a hop bitter finish, especially for this style; no classic coriander taste.

Watery yellow appearance with a big-bubble head, not an attractive beer. Aroma of banana and bubblegum, maybe some black pepper in the background. Banana flavors, probably ketones, and some malt. Very light bodied. Unimpressive.

8/VI/14 - 33cl swing top bottle from De Zytholoog/Bierloods (Adegem) @ home - BB: V/2011 (2014-609) Clear orange beer, small big bubbled head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: oxidized, bit soapy, floral, sweet, oranges and tangerines. MF: no carbon, medium to light body. Taste: very spicy start, cinnamon, cloves, bitter, little sourish, very oxidized. Guess a swing top bottle doesn’t really help for ageing.
Bottle. Slghtly hazy amber pour, with a thin almost non-existent head. Caramel, wheat, a bit of tartness, yeast, and stale bread. Not good.
Belgian witbier that’s a little more yeasty than usual. Other than that, it’s wheaty and fruity of course.

2008 bottle 11.2 oz swing top. Pours hazy amber with a soft faint white soapy head that dissipates to a thin collar and a couple spots in the middle. Aroma is sweet caramel pepper and burnt sugars. Taste is flat and sweet caramel with some faded pepper and just plain old. Palate is thin flat and dry. Bad choice on taking a chance on this one, but it did not break the bank.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this beer. Drank in November 2011. Clear yellow pour with a white head. The aroma has a ton of fruit notes with a lot of lemons and peaches, as well as some wheat. The flavor is similar with some wheat and earth notes complimented by some peaches, grass and light pepper. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Flaska med bäst före datum november 2011. Orange, dimmig öl med vitt skum. Torkad frukt, bananestrar och lätt kryddighet i doften. Bananestrar och en hel del russin, vilket jag antar kommer av lagringen. Denna flaska verkar ha klarat lagringen bra.

undated 11.2 oz bottle served in a snifter. Just plain ugly looking: a murky orange amber with almost no head; minimal lacing left on the glass. Some sediment included in the pour but most left on the bottom of the bottle. Aroma: fruity, including plums, currants and apples. Biscuit base. T: no detectable hops although this is only mildly sweet. Fruity, modest complexity, with a light wheat note. Little banana-yeasty flavor for style. O: low pressure upon opening and low carbonation revealed in the pour suggest a bottle past its prime. Still tasty and enjoyable but likely better fresher.
330 ml bottle, rated from backlog. Both aroma and taste is pretty standard for danish pilsner, nothing special.
33 Bottle. Golden with small diminishing white head. Flavour is malt, sweet and hops.
Superbrugsen, Fynshav, DK Bottled. Had a lot of them - with a range of different proflles.
Bottle. Thin yellow colour, no head. Grainy sweet aroma. Flavour is waterish, grainy, some bitterness. Nasty aftertaste. Terrible brew!
Bottle, at No. 5 (040301). Looking typical for a pilsener. Aroma moderate malty (fruit) and hoppy. Flavor moderate sweet and bitter. Light body. Blindtasted.

(Bottle 33 cl) Golden beer with a thin head. Surprisingly hoppy and flowery nose - with the hops even spilling into the flavour adding more aroma than bitterness. Not bad for a discount beer. "Star" was a legendary working class brand back in the 50’s. Now owned and brewed by Carlsberg. 070700
SIL (Standard International Lager). Lacks bitterness. Cheaper than most in Denmark so good value for money !!
Bottled: Light yellow. Small white head. Quickly diminishing. Malty and ligth sweet aroma. Malt and sweetness with a note of hops in the flavour. Very light bitterness in the end.
Very average Danish pilsener: No head, too much carbon dioxide, but ok malty flavour

A yellow beer with a small and fast disappearing head. It has next to no aroma - hints of malt. The flavor is a little thin to star out with, then an OK sweetness ending on an OK bitterness. For a discount beer this is good - especially because it doesn't contain brewing cereal.
Dose - Ein typisches Tankstellenbier in Schleswig-Holstein. Netter Name irgendwie, aber man wird bitter enttäuscht. Algig-brackiges Meerwasser
330 ml bottle, rated from backlog. Both aroma and taste is pretty standard for danish pilsner, nothing special except the teenage memories. Ah, the memories.
15.09.2006. 0,33l Bottle. In Ebeltoft. The label says "Produced for Saltum og Neptun Bryggerierne". Pale yellow colour with white head. Weak malty aroma. Moderate bitterness.
In lattina, color oro pallido, aroma quasi inpercettibile, poco luppolata al palato, niente di che. Ma se si ha sete è perfetta!
Pale yellow with a low head. Sour aroma of corn and hay. The flavour is dominated by a metallic bitterness and funky corn-like sweetness.

Light yellow colored with medium sized white head. Esters dominate this aroma with fruits and some grains. Thin to medium bodied, high carbonation. Flavor is also dominated by esters, some weird toffee note from grains also present. Aftertaste dries with some lemon.
Aarhus, DK. Bottled. Stinging palate and very different from tiem to time

Straw color and a small head. The aroma has notes of wet grain and very weak hints of hops. The flavour has a light sweetness, notes of wet grain and a tiny bit of bitterness. The overall impression is thin and boring.
Bottle. pale golden. No head. Grassy hoppy and citrus aroma. Flavor is little bitter. Palate is OK.
Clear yellowish with a very small head. Good flowery taste with hops, grass and malt. Quit fresh and lemon-like.
Draught. Brown-reddish appearance, very thin head. Medium caramel aroma. Similar flavor, lacks as much sweetness as I would like it to have. Slight alcohol in aftertatste, bitter finish.

Draught pint at the brewery, 4/14/06, listed only as "Bock", but until I can verify whether the "bock" is different than this, I will just put the review here. Amber-golden highlights throughout a chestnut-auburn body, low filtration, with a strong chill haziness and a small, poorly retained walnut colored head that laces minimally. Aroma touches on lightly nutty malt notes, becoming lightly fruity from moderate melanoidins (cherries, dates, currants) and finally sweetening somewhat with a rather straightforward, but very well-extracted, caramel maltiness. Hops are lightly tangy, bouncing around in the aroma but never setting in strongly. Lager yeast bite is rather minimal on this example, the sweet caramel seeing to that. Almost more like a strong American amber ale in the nose, save for the tangy German hops and light melanoidins. Warming provides the nose with creamy toffee, a hint of toastiness and more fruits, and an even deeper, toasted graininess that grows more dry and balances the aroma further. The flavor is more to-style, shall we say, relying on light sour dough breadiness and spicy/tangy hops dryness to give the bock the bite that exemplifies the style. With warming comes the crisp yeastiness (though still rather reserved) and light mineral-soiliness of the toasty brown malts and yeast. Up front it is medium sweet, of caramel and toffee-like notes, with a touch of golden raisins and buttercream. It comes together, in the end, thanks in part to a wonderfully creamy, smooth texture, soft and round allowing the fruity melanoidins and hops room to sparkle. Gentle, moderate effervescence, no alcohol apparency and little to no wateriness.
On tap at the Portsmouth Brewery restaurant. Beautiful dark dark color with a huge sweet malty-ass flavor. Slightly on the watery side, but otherwise, it’s an excellent beer.

I started out thinking "Wow. I've never been so enthusiastic about a lager before. I've enjoyed dopplebocks and a few good pils, but this is amazing." The color of fresh cherry juice. Carbonation is low and head sluggish. Flavor is all kinds of malt, mostly caramel, but also some funky malt flavors like what you get from Special B. However further into the bomber it started getting to me a bit. The low carbonation (maybe to do with it being bottled in extremely low quantities) kept this beer from reaching it's potential. Also possibly related to the way it was bottled is that it seemed to be showing a few signs of age possibly. Still a great lager though.
Pours with a fizzy head that quickly goes away. Sweet tasting with dark malt notes. This beer goes down really easy.
Draft at the source on 5/17/2016. Pours almost black with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee. Similar taste with a hint of smoke. Lightly acidic. Decent.

Tap at brewery with commonmac and rosskyle and samadouche. Black with thick tan head. Roasted malt aroma. Soft and gentle, creamy. Not overly complex. Bitter slight smoke finish. Not bad if this one crosses the road in front of you, but not amazing.

Sampler at brewpub. Pours Coca Cola brown with a thin khaki head. Leaves trace lacing in the glass. Nice roasted malt notes on the nose that almost suggest coffee. Malty on the tongue with a nice clean finish. Good example of style. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask @ Portsmouth Brewery, Portsmouth, NH Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, toffee, chocolate, coffee, burnt malt and hint of cinnamon. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long very roasted, chocolate, toffee and hint of licorice in the finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Cask at the brewpub. Cinnamon edition. It’s an almost black one, topped by a creamy, finger-thick beige head leaving lacings. The aroma has burnt malts, coffee, some dried fruits and hints of burnt down bonfire. It’s full-bodied, dry and with a creamy carbonation, and flavors of burnt malts, bonfire, some coffee and prunes. Lasting mostly burnt finish. A tad too boyscout-ish this one, but I sure like it anyway. 150908

On tap at the brewpub. Black pour with creamy, lacy, gold foam. Aroma is roasty, dark chocolate, spicy, black pepper, earthy notes. Taste is sweet, nice chocolaty flavor, dark chocolate, light earthy notes. Palate is creamy, dry finish, med bodied.

Northeast Bucket List Trip Beer #45. Nitro at the brewpub. Pours a dark brown with a large creamy tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, mild dark fruits. The taste is dry roasted malt, nuts, herbal hops. Medium bodied, mild lingering bitterness.
I had this during my honeymoon. Draught at the brewery. Black of course with a thick foam. rich with dry malt flavor, much better than average of its style.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass and a mug. The appearance was a nice looking dark brown close to black color with a decent one finger white to off white foamy head that once it dissipates, there’s a decent amount of white foamy lacing that’s kinda light for the most part. The smell had a nice dry roasted coffee aroma with some light chocolate trying to come through but stays in the background for the most part The taste was mostly dry with a nice roasty sort of coffee-ness coming through. On the palate, this one sits about a light to medium on the body and it has a fairly decent sessionable aspect about it. Overall, I say this was a decent Irish Dry Stout worthy of having again.
Noire avec des reflets rouge. Café. Aqueuse. Un peu fumé. Amertume de torréfaction. Bien.
Good, but a bit disappointing compared to most of their other beers. While it had a good flavor, it was still a little thin, almost falling into the light category

This was the second sample I had at the pub that I decided needed a whole pint for tasting. Though not nearly as impressive as the Black Cat Stout, it was still worthwhile; the very faint aroma was the only real off point. Otherwise, this is a zesty, lemony, light crisp summery ale, with caraway flavor indeed present and an interesting dryness akin to some dry ciders. A little on the thin side; worth trying though.

Can from the source. Just a touch of haze in a light golden beverage with a good sized long lasting head that persists. Rich bready crackery pilsner against a spicy floral hop. Well made tasty lawnmower beer.

On tap at Portsmouth, pours a hazy golden blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out biscuity malt and light straw. Flavour is pretty neutral, with straw, earthy notes and biscuity malt. Dry and earthy. Meh.

Draft @ the source on 24 April, 2014. Easy to drink with my dinner. Clear gold pour with a small cap of head. Aroma is light grain, corn and pale malt. Flavor starts with a grainy texture leading to traces of caramel malt. The light body and dry texture leads to notes of hay. The finish displays a bit more hops than you normally find in the style. Nothing over the top, just enough to know its there. Grassy with low bitterness. Simple style that is help by the grassy hops.
Draft at Portsmouth brewery. Deeper golden pour, grassy and sauvignon blanc like wineiness in aroma. Wineiness really carries over into flavor. Grassyn grapiness. Floral and dry fruitiness. Ok

Bottle courtesy doulos/goodgrief. Pour was light straw colored, thin head. The aroma was straw, some grass, sweet caramel. The flavor was caramel, bubblegum (a little off for the style, maybe toasted marshmallows captures it too), slight astringency, grassy hops in the finish. Mouthfeel is fairly full for the style, on the malty side, a tad too malty perhaps. A decent example of the style, though, just looking for more crispness, although the reviewers below seemed to all find enough crispness.
Bottle. Clear, dirty straw color.. Grainy flavor, grassy...just the wat one of these should be. A little oversweet finish . Still, pretty good example and pretty enjoyable.

Golden pour from a bottle Aroma is clean, grassy, some toasted maltiness. Very drinkable, mouthfeel is crisp, clean. Light sweetness from toasted malt up front with some light bitter grassiness on the finish. Leaves a pleasant lingering grassiness as well, crisp and refreshing. Pretty much what I was expecting.
Pours pale gold into a shaker. Bright white head recedes leaving no lacing. Sweet marshmallow aromas. Crisp with toasted marshmallow front to back. Dry, lasting hay finish.
On tap at the brewpub. Clear yellow gold with a fluffy white head. Light, sweet malt and grain, somewhat grassy. Better that expected, and very drinkable.
Draught at GABF 2008. Clear yellow coloured with a medium sized white head. Fruity aroma of malts and hay. Fruity flavour of malts, hay and hops. Hoppy finish.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.
Came with the sampler. Typical lager pour, nose, and taste. Its good if you like Lowenbrau.

Perfectly acceptable, thirst-quenching beer made for the masses that can't or won't appreciate this pub's finer offerings (see Black Cat Stout, mmm). I could drink a dozen pints of this without a hangover and without being able to tell you much about what I drank. Decent body and color, and nothing "off" about it, anyway.
Pours clear dark golden with a fizzy white head. Aroma is apple and light spice. Taste is sweet and tart apple with light cinnamon. A good cider.

Sampled during Bengals Tailgate 12/13/15. 750ml bottle, from Dutch’s. Totally clear golden color. Ring of white head, few bits of lace. Nice mildly tart apple, and a great bit of farmhouse funk, pretty tasty. Light tart taste, light to moderate sweet, very nice dryness. Medium-plus body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. A great “farmhouse” cider. Very much my style.

750 ml bottle shared by DrSilverworm - thanks again, Chris! Pours a pale clear gold with a small white head that settles into a rocky ring. Very clean - apple, pear, minerals, and hay without much depth at all. Light-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a clean, mineralic, dry mouthfeel. I don’t know why this didn’t do much for me. There’s just very little going on here.

Bottle shared by Dr Silverworm. Poured clear pale color with a minimal head that diminished slowly with fair legs. Medium floral tart apple aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft legs. Medium tart apple flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Soft drinkable beverage.

750 ml bottle shared by DrSilverworm. Pours a clear yellow color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have sweet and tart green apples, dry, apple peel, light tart and funk, ok, but..... I do like this better than most ciders.

750 ml bottle. Pours deep golden with some bubbles. Aroma is of sweet and sour apples. Body is medium, crisp, biter-sharp. Taste fruity, acidic notes following with some bitterness. Finish is long, semidry. Great cider.
Yellow pour with no real head. Apple aroma. The flavor is dry, tart and earthy apples. Not overly sweet like some ciders.
Yellow pour with watery head. Aroma is sweet apple. Flavor is a dry apple with a tartness on the finish. Medium light body with good carbonation. Ok dry cider

750ml for $10 at 802bws, poured into tulip glass A very clean, crystal clear cider. It’s a bit sweeter than I expected - I’ve only had their drier ciders. Very thin bodied and has a nice flavor, but mostly subtle. Not overly sweet, but definitely sweet. Very enjoyable.

75CL picked up @ Farnum Hill. 6.5% ABV on the label. No batch number. enjoyed @ 39F in a Teku. Honey like appearance, 7up carbonation fades quickly. Certain smells sweet, almost pear like. Taste is crisp, sweet, raw apple skin, very little dryness, not cloyingly sweet but is sweeter than their other offerings. would go nicely with seafood. it’s nice.
33cl bottle. Pours clear yellow with a off white foam. Very weak with notes of grain & corn. Watery palate with metallic notes!
Aarhus, DK. Bottled. Very thin. Hint of malt and note of bittereness. Stinging palate
Straw with a big bubbly and vanishing head. The flavour has notes of wet grain and mash and a very light bitterness. But is’ extremely quick to pour down the drain.
Bottle. Clear pale yellow colour with a small mostly diminishing head. Weak aroma and taste of water. Watery palate.

Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Dark yellow colour. Week to no aroma. Exstremely watery flavor and palate. This is the closest to water I have tasted yet. Wayter doesnt taste bad so either does this one, but beer? No way.
Bottle, uellow colour, short head. Weak grainy aroma. Waterish grainy flavour, touch of hops. Boring brew.
(Bottle 33 cl) 2,6% ABV in my version. Pilsener golden, no head, heavy carbonation. But a fairly decent attempt at a pilsener without being one. 251103

(on bottle) For starters, this looked great . Nice dark/yellow color and heavy sent of mash, might be a light pilsner with sm spunk to it. But, no. Total lack of sweetness and hoppig left a blank ook in my eye, I needed a real beer to become happy again. Too bad, it looked good.

The aroma is faint malty. The color is golden, and it has a small but fast disappearing head. The flavor is thin, bubbly, with a faint malt note and a very faint boring bitterness. This is definately a low-alcohol beer. It's not discusting just plain boring and thin.
Low alcohol (2,3). Ok appearance, head and yellow. Aroma near water and the same goes for the taste.

Bottle into wine glass. Golden yellow very fine carbonation, clear. Nose of apple melon and honey. Fairly straighteners Apple flavor with a bit of tannins, dry as advertised. Moderate acidity keeps the palette clean and refreshed. Finishes short with more tannic apple. Not bad as a super, much better with food (grilled kielbasa and brats, both with mustard, baked beans in this case).

Medium Gold Smells like old towel and old apple Just off-dry. Medium-low acid, tannins, and bitterness. Creamy carbonation. Med-full body. A bit of funk, soap, chalk, apple, and pear. Medium-long finish. At first I wasnt super impressed by this cider, but once I let it warm up, it came to life. Complex.

750 bottle. The cider is a hazed gold color with a white head of foam. The aroma has musty, earthy apples with a noce level of funky acidity coming through. The taste is earthy, musty, and has some tartness. Medium body and higher carbonation levels. Very nice cider.

Very nice clear golden a 7up like head. Nose is great. Lots of great grape nose. I like the peach and kiwi notes. Taste is a bit less exciting. very dry, lots of grape, kiwi, some wood but a pretty bland taste compared to the nose.

Bottle. Pours a clear gold with visible carbonation and no head whatsoever. Aroma has lots of dry wine notes with a bit of a white wine note. Flavor starts with more sweetness but finish is extremely dry with a bit of tartness.

Bottle. Appearance: Clear golden with some white fizz leaving the body but quickly settling to nothing. Aroma: Very Bretty, but in a dry rubbery way. From far away I get tart notes but up close it’s all leathery Brett. Taste: Up front is a dry, slightly tart slightly apple flavor that leads to a heavy Brett finish. Rubbery/leathery. It lingers of dish soap. Not a fan of this. Palate: Vibrant and effervescent. Overall: Second cider dominated by Brett that I don’t want to finish. This tastes pretty bad and reminds me of dish soap on the finish.

Rated on 12-09-2009 (Bottle) This Cider pours a medium sized head, transparent yellow body and very little carbonation. The Aroma is sweet, apples and hints of tropical fruit. The Taste is sweet, acidic, fruity, and finishes semi-dry. The Palate is clean and this Cider is medium bodied. In conclusion, this is a tasty Cider and one that I would consider drinking again.
The smell is apples, fruits, tart, and butter. The look is clear, golden, no head. The taste is sweet, fruits, apples, and ok.

Bottle. Poured a few glasses for myself in between serving patrons at some fest in the Lexington Armory. Clear, golden, sort of browned amber. Fizzy. Smells sharply of skins, acidic fruit, hay & minerals. Very bubbly. Murky apple butter & old chardonnay sweetness. Astringent & even a bit sour. Pretty dry, with burn on the finish. Not my favorite from Farnum Hill.

Sample from the Farmer’s Market. Of course there are the apple juice notes, but there’s also a pleasant acidity to go with the dry carbonated finish. The extra acidity separates it from the Woodchucks of the cider world.

Pint at Great Lakes Brewing Company in Cleveland Ohio. Smell the wheat. Cloudy dark golden in color. Taste the wheat and light bottle. Smooth. Little bit of spice aftertaste. This is delicious. Cheers!

On tap at the Rigby in Madison, WI. for Great Lakes GToM pre-party, served to a goblet showing a hazed, orangey/gold color, with soft white head foam, and spiraling cling to the lacing. The nose was soft grain, slight yeast, light citrus, some circus peanut candy scent, and spice. Medium bodied, with decent carbonation, the taste was similar notes, with clovey phenols that was dominant in the flavor. A refreshing Hefe, nonetheless.

Sweet banana nose with traces of spice. Cloudy golden pour with thick white foam. Initial peppery (clove) notes quickly give way to bubblegum / banana taste. Soapy mouthfeel that begins with some active fizziness. It never quite delivered the dryness that I expected from the style.

Tap. Darker hazy orange with minimal head. Lots of citrus in the aroma, some wheaty grain notes as well, just really basic and subdued. Same goes for the flavor, some citrus and a touch grassy for the style and slight white fruits. Lighter chalky body.

Pint at GLBC on 5/3/14. Cloudy yellow gold in color with a thick white head. Aroma of banana, clove, marshmallow, creamy wheat and pepper. Creamy wheat flavor with banana and clove giving way to citrus and pepper before a watery finish.

Draft sample at brewpub. Poured cloudy amber color with an average fizzy white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate banana, clove and yeast aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a solid sweet finish of moderate duration. Good refreshing brew.

On tap. Pours hazy reddish golden color, thin white head. Aroma of banana, cloves, yeast. Mild sweet flavor. I liked this one because it wasn’t too clovey or too citrusy. Nice balance of sweet and spice, very refreshing.
Great summer beer. Not too harsh for those that like a lighter but tasty beer. Can only get it at the brewery.
Draft sample at the brewery. Pretty big overall. Thicker than expected mouthfeel from the wheat. Definitely a big helping of banana and clove notes. Pretty good.
Ok. Nothing special here. Very wheat taste that is notice bc of the unfiltered beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the Rigby in downtown Madison, WI. for pre-GT festivities, dispensed to a shaker, showing a clear, orangey amber color, with a persistent & frothy layer of tan head foam, and clingy, sheet-like lacing. The nose was lightly toasted & malty, with touches of caramel & toffee sweetness. Light to medium bodied, the flavor was similar notes as the aroma, a bit thin textured, but decently carbonated, and quite drinkable.
Not a big fan of this, brewery part of sampler, weird finish, so not high on my list here
Smooth drinking Scottish ale. Deep color and mild hops. Very refreshing ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This poured a lighter brown color with an off white head. Aroma was lightly skunky, stale grassy hops and light roasted malts. FLavor was stale bready and moldy german hops. Bleh.
Tap. Clear gold amber pour. Minimal head. Malty nose, taste of malt and caramel. Decent Scottish ale, but just not my style.

72oz growler fill from brewpub ($34!!). aroma is lightly smoked well toasted malt. quite savory. khaki pour with fine head that lingers a spell but little carb. flavor is a touch flat and metallic. little of the toast from the nose visable in the flavor though when it reveals its welcome. lightly charred sawdust character, just a kiss of smoke.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear amber with a medium beige head. Faint malty and caramel nose. Flavor is also light caramel malt without much else. Could use a bit more complexity and strength.

Had a pint of this on tap at the brewpub before the Nine Inch Nails concert Sunday night. Nose of brown sugar, malty cereal, and a hint of resin. Pours a clear orange copper. The nice tan creamy head is mostly diminishing with thin lace. The brew tastes malty and sweet with hints of spice and coffee. The medium body is creamy, soft and feels slightly sticky at the finish. The only disappointment for me at the brewpub. I expect more from an example of this style.

This is a great beer, from the greatest brewery ever. The beer has a very nice brown with reddish tint color. The head stayed well on the beer but did fade slowly. The body is thin but feels smooth on the palate. The aroma is full of malt, ans sweetness. The flavor is full of malt, light hops, and some sweet and spice. This is the closest thing to the GLBC Christmas Ale, which is the best beer I have ever had.
Draft - Great Lakes. Had a unique brown color. Had a nice malty flavor, but was just a little too thin. Smokey malt and sweet flavor. Good--Not great.

Yellow straw pour. Aroma is sweet, apple fruit, floral aromatics. Mouth is very wine like, still. Flavor is more sweet apple, pungent floral character. Sweet finish with a touch of acid. A bit rough around the edges

750 ml bottle from the Beverage Warehouse in Winooski, VT, consumed around cellar temperature in a wine glass. This is, interestingly, not even remotely still in appearance, with lots of bubbling and even a bit of fizzy foam (instantly dying) atop the light gold, clear body.....moderately sweet, rustic, earthy nose of damp humus, band-aid and oak....fairly sweet initially shading to moderately sour midpalate and quite tart at the finish, light alcohol presence throughout, very mineralic and reminiscent of a drier Riesling....becomes a bit too alcoholic in presence at the very finish as it warms. Interesting but only partially successful, just too rough and boozy.

Bouteille verte de 750 ml achetée au Beverage Warehouse (Winooski, VT). Partagée avec Goldorak et une amie. Arôme: Odeur d’urine de chat (?). Apparence: La couleur est jaune pâle. Saveur: Gout de pommes. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence d’une légère amertume en arrière goût. (Rating #472)

Thanks Marc for splitting this with us! Pilsner-like yellow and with the consistency and robe of dry white wine. My friend Caro’s first reaction was "Hey, this smells like Vanilla!" Marc and I looked at her funny, because there was no doubt that this had nothing even close to that aroma. She then explained that Vanilla is the name of her cat. She nailed it right on the head, the first whiff is very catty (I don’t see it as a bad thing, by the way), the feline urine slowly turns to hay, then gives out wooden notes, but not oaky. It made me think of those crates they use in orchards to carry around the apples. Still and dry, with lavander notes and really tannic for a cider, I don’t really know which type of apple gives these characteristics, I checked out the website and the varietals were unknown to me (there are so many types of apples out there it’s insane!). The tannins and visible alcohol in the finish really makes it dry. As the bottle says, I agree that it’s a good alternative to white wine, but nothing to really make it stand out from whatever you’re serving it with.
Same as other semi dry, lacking carbonation, and seems a little more sweet, though prolly just my imagination.

Flat..obviously. Picked up 2 weeks ago @ Farnum Hill. light yellow pour. Smells nice, light with honey, sweeter apples and pear with grapes. light mouthfeel, dry finish. not too sweet. has a lot of grape, oak and pear notes.
750ml bottle. A pretty damn dry cidre that has a tannic bite, presumably from lack of carbonation, woucl like to try the carbonated version.

Bottle at Jimmy43s. Stemmed wine glass. The bacon grease nearly vented from the surrounding airs. Moody lighting at the bar leads me to believe that this clear, golden cider might just be a bit fainter. Smell is of tin-y apples, unripened fruit & green peppers, citrus rind, big acidity, grain. Taste is initially mellow, building to a quietly lingering acidity. Void of any real tartness. Thick/husky, apple peels & drying, mildly bitter core. Browned apples. Salad greens. Missing that suckling dry finish. Texture is more runny then thin. Quiet alcohol. Very hard for me to enjoy crazy dry still ciders without them having some other note, like a little barrel, odd florals, or just a little more sugar to make the fruit pop.

Apple aroma, with an oh-so subtle hint of chocolate and funk that is barely perceptible. Crystal clear yellow, no carbonation. Dry and slightly blitter, slightly tart. Apple initially with apple core at midpalate. Oak and twigs throughout. Not dissimilar to a Chardonnay in its earthiness. Some pleasant astringency with a still mouthfeel make it velvety smooth on the palate. I at times feel like I just don’t like dry cider, but I attribute that to the fact that there are so many bad ones on the market. This, I like.
Sampled with Linh at 61 Local in Brooklyn during NYC cider week 2012. Somewhat plain, typical apple flavors both in aroma and flavor. Somewhat dry.

Bottle. Pours a clear gold. Big sweet apples on the nose, candy soft, soft apple flesh. Medium bodied, much drier than the nose would indicate. Thins out a bit, somewhat empty. Very dry, lightly acidic apple. Tart finish, dry, with some warming alcohol on the back end.

Straw pour with no head. Aroma is sweeter apple with some floral aromatics, a bit of earthiness. Mouth feel is a bit thin, no carb. Not a huge fan of the still ciders, a little effervescence can go a long way. Flavor is apple, a bit of earthy funk, some good acid at the finish. Ok, but again, not a fan of still ciders.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye. poured yellow with no head and some nice legs. aroma was pear and honey with the flavor being the same. light and dry body.

(750ml bottle thanks to bu11zeye) still gold, decent glass coating. Nose of sweet apple, very light florals. Taste of sweet and very tart apples, not acidic, braeburn apples, very thin body nice palate linger though. Dinged it a bit for being so thin.
(750ml bottle) Pours a clear pale yellow body with a spare bubbly rim. Aroma of apple, butter, and earthiness. Flavor of sweet, somewhat tart apple and Band-Aid with a dry finish.
Poured from a bottle, thanks to Craig. Aroma: Spicy yeast character, berries, solvent-high alcohol Taste: caramel, fruity alcohol notes Overall: the alcohol was out of control, hot and solventy

Bottle labeled as "St. Donmon Belgian Style Abbey Trippel Ale" thanks to AirForceHops Appearance: Poured clear golden with a big white head and some lacing Aroma: Yeast, lemon, fruity and sweet malts Taste: Sweet malts, yeasty, light fruits and citrus OK.

Bottle thanks to Craig. Pours a clear golden color with a large white head. The aroma is pear, sweet malts and some heat coming in the nose. The flavor is slightly oxidized giving it a funky character, bitterness, sweet dry malts, very light fruit for the style.

Awaiting me is the St. Dammmon Belgian-style Abbey Tripel from Portsmouth Brewery out of Portsmouth, New Hampshire. Just what the doctor ordered. There is nothing quite like a Belgian brew to set me once more upon cloud nine. I haven’t had any of Portsmouth’s beers yet, so I look forward to supping thirstily upon their interpretation of a Belgian abbey Tripel. Like an angel bring me salvation, the St. Dammmon Tripel pours a clear, gentle orange with a subtle yet supple halo of white foam. She is adorned in a robe of the finest lace, and as her arms reach out to comfort my battered soul, I close my eyes in sweet surrender. Thick, yeasty, doughy and sour with moist banana bread while over-ripe bananas fill out her aroma as I watch fresh dough be kneaded and rolled to create the finest artisan loaves. Light and yet full, her spirit uplifts even as I settle comfortably into her enveloping embrace. My first quaff is thinner and lighter than expected, but it doesn’t take long for her true colors to reveal themselves. She quickly builds into rich, warm sour breads, kneading dough, and banana bread practically bursting with soft, pungent, over-ripe bananas. Spice and dry grass lingers in the finish and tinges my breath. The longer we stay together, the more I am impressed by how she balances a light start with a robust middle, and a spiced, hoppy finish. A well played interpretation, the St. Dammmon Belgian-style Abbey Tripel from Portsmouth Brewery was quite tasty. It didn’t floor me, but she was a solid brew and perfectly suited to bring me back from the depths of despair I had been tossed into.

Courtesy fogdog. Pours a hazy, dark golden-copper color with a small, foamy, off-white head. Spots of lacing mark the glass. The nose is mostly sweet and doughy, showing blonde candy sugar, mild toffee, phenolic, bready yeast, and hints of citrus zest. Flavors follow suit, sweet toffee and imperial pils-like malts showing strong, with more doughy yeast and citrus essence. Lightly syrupy and moderately carbonated, the palate is substantial but overly warm from the alcohol. I’m not a big tripel fan, and this one really doesn’t do much for me either.

CPLYFO 09. Thanks to Fogdog for sharing. Pours a light amber, clear copper with a thin lasting head. Aroma of citrus and yeasty phenols, along with some lemony fruit and ok doughy malts. Green raisin and apple flavors form the fruity yest, lemon zest, westmalle-ish, and some bubblegum esters- hints of banana as it warms. Somewhat on the sweet side for the style.

Bottle from the Otown throwdown. Another brew from fogdog, yes! Copper pour. White head. Typical aroma wtih stone fruits, apples, syrup and yeast. Flavor is pretty sweet with yeast, spices and fruit. Pretty good.

C&PLYFOTD: Bottle, courtesy fogdog. Very clear golden copper pour, slight lacing and a white head. Dark fruits in the nose, slight chalkiness, some wheat. Slight funk in the flavor, creamy cider and plum, peach, and yumminess, of course. Very good.

Sample at O-town throwdown ’09 pours golden with white head. Aroma is sweet, with good notes of brown sugar. Taste is similar to aroma yeasty with nice honey touch adds plenty of sweetness to this beer as well as esters with some sweet fruits.

Sampled out of a bomber labeled "St. Donmon Belgian Style Abbey Trippel Ale". Assuming this is the same beer. Bright copper color with a thin head. Aroma is butterscotch and sweet, soft apple and melon. Flavor is fairly sweet; low carbonation for a tripel, but a nice round mouth feel. Some caramel, a little vegetal character. Pretty solid.

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy la Fleur du Malt Ambrée
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: Amber colour, poor head (golden-amber). Poor aroma, watery taste, ordinary bitterness. Can be brewed with any beer kit; to be forgotten. Beers of Switzerland

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy la Fleur du Malt Ambrée
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: cloudy amber-orange colour, fine creamy head, grapefruit aroma with a touch of vinegar, light- to medium-bodied with a brutal and unpleasant bitterness, the finish is very dry and tart - urghhh ... Jun 17, 2002 / 4/2/3/2/5: cloudy dark orange colour, very few head, light apricot aroma, fresh, sweet and flat, no aftertaste, no character, absolutely unremarkable

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy la Sainte Bernadette
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: Golden color, no head. No aroma. Stronger body, similar to a malt liquor, as you may perceive the alcohol but not the malt. Poor palate. Beers of Switzerland

column1: Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy la Sainte Bernadette
column4: Cave des Brasseurs (Brasserie Artisanale de Porrentruy)
column5: hazy orange-amber colour, few foam, strong bad vinegar aroma, medium-bodied, tart with a rough bitterness, the aftertaste is very dry, slightly fruity with a deadly unpleasant finish - brewed in association with Sint-Bernardus ? come on... this is not even bad homebrew level ! Jun 17, 2002 / 5/2/3/2/6: this beer is brewed in collaboration with the brewery St Bernardus (Belgium) - reddish-amber colour, few head, apple and alcohol nose, too much carbonation, sweet and flat, no character - desperately nothing to find here ...
Bottle at Kent BF 2015. Hazy amber colour lasting white head. Slightly Juglandaceous. Nutty sweet some hop. Over carbonated ok.
