column5: on tap at the brewpub; citrusy hoppy aroma; citrusy hop flavor with a medium bodied malt background , although still fairly light

column1: A1A Ale Works Porpoise Point Pale Ale
column5: St. Augustine, Fl. - on tap at A1A. Dark golden pour, off-white head, nice lace. Brief spruce in the aroma. Flavor has a hint of mint, light citrus bitterness, some malty biscuit-like qualities. Crisp moutheel. Pretty solid - refreshing after a walk through hot St. Augustine.

column1: A1A Ale Works Porpoise Point Pale Ale
column5: A lovely amber/brown IPA. Gives a citrus taste with hoppy undertones, but non to strong a flavour. Makes this overall a very drinkable session ale. Nice.

column1: A1A Ale Works Porpoise Point Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Clear amber pour with a small khaki head that fades. Light citrus aroma with pale malts and caramel. Light citrus in the flavor as well with touches of maltiness. Not bad.

column1: A1A Ale Works Bridge of Lions Brown Ale
column5: Flight too. Was really nice and quite refreshing. Not so hard to analyze and nice with the food there .

column1: A1A Ale Works Bridge of Lions Brown Ale
column5: From the brewpub in St. Augustine. Deep dark brown with nearly no head. Aroma is a roasty and a hint of chocolate. Flavor is a bit sweet and a little tart. Unexpected but not a bad flavor. Sweet malt with a hint of citrus. Medium light mouthfeel with low carbonation. Meh.

column1: A1A Ale Works Bridge of Lions Brown Ale
column5: On draft at A1A. Pours a mostly clear cocoa color with a white head. Nose is toasted malts, some cocoa, some light bitterness, and some mild floral notes. Flavor is similar with some toast, some light bitterness, and some mild cocoa and tobacco. Light to medium in body and lingering cocoa and bitter on the finish.

column1: A1A Ale Works Bridge of Lions Brown Ale
column5: Clear brown in color... Aroma of light chocolate malts and nuts... Flavor was nutty and malty with notes of chocolate, slightly bitter finish, not the best on the palate, slightly off... Decent brown

column1: A1A Ale Works Bridge of Lions Brown Ale
column5: Sampled at the Florida Brewers Guild Beerfest, March ’11. Good brown ale with nice sweet malts and hints of honey.

column1: A1A Ale Works Bridge of Lions Brown Ale
column5: Dark brown-red, beige cover. Sweet, nutty, cocoa aroma. Taste is sweet, malty, chocolate.

column1: A1A Ale Works Bridge of Lions Brown Ale
column5: Tap at brewpub. Good brown ale, light-bodied but with a full-taste, with notes of hazelnut and a discreet sweetness. I enjoyed the hoppiness, quite present and leafy. I liked that one pretty much!

column1: A1A Ale Works Bridge of Lions Brown Ale
column5: Sampler at brewpub pours brown, off white head. Aroma is malty some roast and light chocolate. Taste, light caramel malts, with nutty palate and some chocolate. Light in body but with some nice roastiness. Easy to drink and taste.

column1: A1A Ale Works Bridge of Lions Brown Ale
column5: En fût. Verre de dégustation directement à la brasserie. Arôme: Odeur de caramel avec une pointe de noix. Apparence: La couleur est brune. Présence d’un moyen col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût de caramel avec une pointe d’épices. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #2269)

column1: A1A Ale Works Bridge of Lions Brown Ale
column5: Rich dark brown with thick, rocky tan head. Fresh aroma is nutty, smooth, and dry. Thin finish but it was served too cold and needed to warm to bring out the body. Medium to high carbonation. Nice nuttiness persists throughout and finishes dry.
Bottle at The brewery. Hazy gold orange lasting white head. Wort on aroma few esters. A little muddy. Not a great weisse very worty. A bit dirty.

It’s unclear, warm orange with a rather small head. The aroma is sharp and tart with notes of sour yeast and strong barnyard. The flavour is very like the aroma and has additional notes of fruit, and the finish is spicy. Not a weiss to my liking.
Bottle, 5.2%. Mild buttery aroma, hint of citrus. Hazy golden colour. Nice stable off-white head. The flavour is quite citric, bordering on Bretty. Drinkable, but strange.

Bottle 50cl. Light unclear medium yellow orange color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, moderate yeasty, banana, toffee, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and light citrus acidic with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft. [20090625]

Draught at the brewpub. Cloudy straw colour, creamy head. Fresh light banana aroma. Very light and airy. Cloves are very evident, banana less. There is also a vague hint of vegetables and a late bitter twist.

Bottle (purchased at the brasserie): Hazy, golden to orangey coloured, smaller, very stable creamy white head; dry sharp sourish, wheaty and cellary - Gueuze-like - nose; moderate sour-sweet flavour with a light tartness, soft MF, light to medium bodied; becomes a bit sweeter (!) towards the sour-tart finish. Interesting, a franconian Gueuze, presumably created by accident.........
Bottled Hazy orangy color, good white head. Good smokey banana-aroma. Dry banana flavor, a bit roasted. Good balanced dry weizen.

Yeasty butteraroma. Strong yoghurt and fresh cheese taste. Some fruitiness (grapes). The most peculiar weizenbier I have ever tasted. Drinkable, but probably some mistakes have been made in the brewing process.

It’s mahogany-red with a creamy head, and the aroma has notes of roasted malt, syrup, caramel and a little nuts. The flavour is modeerately sweet with notes of syrup, roasted malt, caramel, nuts and the finish is dry. It’s a nice dunkel.

Bottle, 5.0%. Quite roasted aroma, seems buttery. Nice clear brown colour. Small stable light brown head. The flavour has a good shot of soy, some spicy hops. Seems old, but is not. Not very good at first, but grows tolerable after some sips.

Bottle 50cl. Clear dark amber color with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, light chocolate, old malt. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090625]

Draught at the brewpub. Clear mahogany colour, creamy head. Evident roasty malt aroma. Salty with some aniseed and licorice, lots of tasted bread. Salty finish with light tarry bitterness. Flavourful, but slightly edgy.

On tap at Brauerei Georg Hummer, Breitengussbach, Frankonia. Brown to chestnut with cream head. Quite nutty, hazelnuts, right from the start, roasty with toffee caramel and burnt treacle. Some alcohol notes, quite heavy. Reasonable.

Bottle (purchased at the brewery): Amber coloured, quite stable off-white head, sticking to the glass, dark-malty, slightly toasted nose with a barnyardy and nutty touch; bitter-sweet flavour, quite dry, light to medium bodied; dry, again, bitter-malty finish with a light sourness. Quite dry for the style........

(bottle) Clear, chestnut-brown colour with a mid-sized beige foamy head. Sweet, slightly toasty malt aroma with caramel, butter and herbal hops. Light-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Toast-malty, caramelly and slightly herbal taste; moderately dry and bitter hoppy finish. Almost Schwarzbier-like Dunkel (23.01.08).
Malty barnyard aroma. Sweet, malty taste with milk chocolate and coffee.....
Great Maibock, clean malty flavor, slightly bitter, with crisp finish, dark copper colored and good drinkin!

Bread. Raisin. Fruit. Cloudy yellow amber. Thick frothy white head. Great retention. Lots of chunky foam left on the glass. Hard candy. Sweet. Bread. Wood. Sticky. Pistachio. Thick. Chewy. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Seen before but never consumed, I purchased a single 2017 vintage, 12 oz bottle at the only real craft beer store in the Petroplex a couple of weeks ago. Ready to pour into my Buffalo Bayou snifter, here it goes. I note an opaque, dark gold liquid with a decent pure white head, looks like good lacing possibilities. A smell, some ripe yellow fruit and cereal. I take a full drink. A bit different taste, yellow raisin, somewhat vinous, crackers and a surprising hoppiness. Not exactly my style but I can appreciate. The alcohol is not apparent. Certainly a bottle to finish. Buy again? Likely not.

Clear honey-copper hue with a thin off white head. Rich honeyed boozy bready and leafy hoppy nose. Thick full flavor of honey and pale malt and warming soft fruity esters. A little hoppy but honeyed and wonderful and warm.

From Mar 2008 I got this in a trade with JDV. Thanks Deniz! This is the 2007 vintage: It pours a clear deep amber/copper with about a 1" head of foam from a vigorous pour. Good lacing here. The smell is very fruity(dark fruit) and yeasty? I also get a touch of caramel and some alcohol. The taste is loaded with dark fruit...plum, black cherry, some fig, and they're pretty tart but tasty but I also get some sweetish notes from the malt and some tobacco. Nice. I think this is the fruitiest BWSA I've tried so far and it's a nice slant on the style me thinks. The mouthfeel is kind of on the thin side and the carbonation is low(appropriate for a BWSA)and it finishes on the tart side because of the dark fruit. Pretty tasty fresh and I could see this would be interesting as to where it would go with a bit of aging on it. I'm certainly glad I got the chance to try it!

2011 Sisyphus on draft at Whip-In. Pours clear amber gold with no head. Honey, maple brown sugar oatmeal, raisin. Cardboard, butterscotch little to no carbonation. This beer has done exceptionally well.

Tap at Whip in, Austin. Vintage 2013. Clear nut brown color, firm white head. Aroma is bready and hoppy. Medium to full-bodied. Sticky. Fruity, piney hoppy, a bit bready, sweetish. Covers its abv. Hop-dominating barley wine.

Feb. ’14 bottle from Errl-thanks, Chris! In 12/16. Copper gold. Nose is slightly soapy hops, light oxidation, toffee. Taste is burnt toffee, astringent and bitter hops, on a malty sweeter base. Has held up well.
2014 bottle, honey copper pour, no head. Clove, nutmeg, ripe molasses and malt nose. Dull malt/grains that go from brief bitter to long lasting alcohol and caramel
'10 Bottle. The pour is a hazy vibrant orange. The aroma is full of toffee. The taste is spot on barleywine. Smooth. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle thanks to Zinister. Poured amber orange with white head. Aroma malty sweet caramel juice. Light carb med bod. Taste juicy light bitter hop
10 mois avant DLC avec Milinf. Blonde tres citronnée et hyper desalterante. Dommage qu'elle soit si aqueuse !

Robe blonde, à peine voilée, très belle effervescence et très belle mousse. Nez saturé de banane ! Semble plus proche d'une weizen que d'une blanche belge. Un peu de malt ressort au nez, mais pas d'acidité. En bouche, de la banane à gogo, une certaine sucrosité. Original. Manque cependant de fraîcheur et d'acidité pour le style. Le corps semble l'emporter, ce qui ne la rend pas si légère. Amertume quasi inexistante, juste une légère trace en fin de bouche.

Une petite bouteille rapportée de France. Cette bière blanche est plus pâle que la blonde. La mousse est belle. Un nez spectaculaire de blé, de banane et de sucre. Une bouche de froment marquée par la levure de gomme à mâcher et de banane. Correcte sans plus. À boire avant le 31 décembre 2014.

33 cl. Meilleure avant le 31 décembre 2014. Une bière de blé complètement filtrée. Une petite tête mousseuse. Des arômes de bonbon et de gomme-balloune avec une petite pointe d’épices. Des saveurs douces. Un retour de la levure. Une épice plus discrète. Une bouche incertaine. Une finale qui se fait oublier. Une blanche de soif, sans aucun doute. Merci à Isabelle et Yan pour la dégustation.

Tap @ De l’autre côté du pont. Pours hazy pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is yeasty, cereals, a bit sour, fruity and apples. Flavor is a bit sour acidy and fruity apples in the beginnig adding some bitterness in the middle and finishing bitter sourish and fruity.

The bottle resembles the monthly wine from the local restaurant Olympia. The Frenchmen has here made a really good beer. Wit or pilsner is a little unclear but a good beer with a touch of honey flavor.

Golden beer, little white head. Diacetyl!? And quite some, too. Bananaester. Cookies, sweet banana, and (less) diacetyl. Again quite carbonated beer, medium bodied, oiled by the buttery ketone. Sorry for the diacetyl, as the Weizenbase seems OK.
Bottle. Sweet-sour orange juice, clove and wheat malt aroma. Clear golden yellow color with minimal head. Sweet orange/lemon and wheat malt flavor. Nice, drinkable beer.
From Voldby, DK. Bottled, 260410. Pale yellow with white head. Aroma of wheat, yeast and spices. Flavor with fruit and coriander
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are yeast, banana and wheat malt. Nice and smooth.
10 mois avant DLC Avec Milinf. Moins aqueuse que la blanche mais aussi moins tranchante et plus ordinaire
Average sweetish blond pils. Not bad but nothing special. Cereal. Malt. Slight bitterness.
Tap at punk place in Lyon. Clear golden with small white head. Light pils malts, soft grass, a bit of white bread and honey, bread crust. Light sweet and bitter. Under medium bodied.
Mignon. Une blonde de type un peu belge, sans intérêt ni grand arôme si ce n’est une jolie finale (et légère longueur) céréalière un peu gourmande.
Flasche 33cl @ Nyons. Recht laffes, ausdrucksloses, leicht trübes Helles. Absolut kein Pilsener, kaum Hopfen, schade um den schönen Saazer. Enttäuscht.
75 CL Bottle@Home. Appearance: Cloudy pale yellow with white head. Aroma: Flowery hops, vague malt. Taste: Light bitter. Palate: Refreshing, light bodied, medium carbonation. Overall: OK.

Une petite bouteille rapportée de France. Une bière blonde dorée avec une belle mousse blanche. Un nez simple avec une touche sucrée de malt et de houblon noble. Une bouche simple marquée par le grain et les céréales sucrées. Meilleure avant le 24 décembre 2014.

33 cl. Meilleure avant décembre 2014. Une bière blonde qui montre un petit col mousseux. La parfum est malté. Les céréales blondes sont sucrées et légèrement grillées. Le houblon ne se fait pas sentir. Au goût, une blonde sucrée qui cache son jeu. Une ale ou une lager? Une impression en bouche qui n’est pas ratée. Une finale qui n’est pas sucrée ni amère. Merci à Isabelle et Yan pour la dégustation.

Blonde dorée trouble, mousse moyenne et fugace. Nez malté, miel, foin, houblon. La bouche est douce, fruitée, céréales avec des notes de miel et caramel, pointe anisée et épicée. Pas mal de rondeur et un peu picotante. Amertume terreuse, bière équilibrée et agréable.
330ml brown bottle. Christmas gift. Pleasant pale lager with moderate dusty hops in the finish. Neutral palate and balanced carbonation. Drinkable.

Pours clear golden with thin white head. Nose is malty. Aromas are sweet malt, herbal hops. Average carbonation, light body. Short sweet finish, with a metallic aftertaste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Blond beer, slightly sour, no head. I do not know what to make out this beer. Interesting.

Very faint hazy pale yellow/gold with no head. Floral green grapes acid, faint hops and a touch of old wet leather yeast. That faint canned metal whiff is there in this one as well. Also has a touch of gueuze about it but not as much as the Mange -soif blanche. Light bodied and sweeter middle and clean refreshing dry finish. Different and interesting - quite drinkable.

Pours clear golden with a white, smallish head. Aroma has malts and rather strong grassy notes of hops. Taste is smooth and surprisingly malty after crispier nose. Grainy maltiness dominates but it finishes with a touch of grassy bitterness. Average carbonation. (0,5l bottle,bb 04.06.20, from a random supermarket in Freising, Germany)

Bottle courtesy of our landlords Peter and Elke, (cheers you two!). Had this Sunday 17th March 2019. Pours light gold with a nice frothy white head. There is a little more hops on the nose than the export, light fruity, perhaps a touch of citrus, or to be more exact lemon. Malts show, it's a touch sweet, it's an ok beer, fine without ever getting me excited.
Klar, hell, schwach karbonisiert. Minimale Zitrusnote, etwas DMS, leichte Malznote.
Bottle, Freising, Germany. Pale yellow. Mild grass aroma. Weak flavour, mild spice finish.

Fass 0,5l@Gasthof Neuwirt, Hallbergmoos: Golden, glasklar, kräftiger mittelporiger Schaum; frische+fruchtige Nase, angenehm malzig, leichte Zitrusnoten, sehr mild gehopft; frischer+fruchtiger Körper, leichte Süße, Malz, Getreide, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, leichte Zitrusnoten; angenehmer fruchtig-milder Nachgang

Bottle 50cl, a clear yellow beer with medium head. Nose is on grassy hops and grain. Taste is sweet medium bitterness, aroma is on sweet grain and crisp but body is a bit low with wet paper touch, quite classic, properly hopped.
Hell herber Beginn, mild hopfig. Der Hopfen steigt zwar an, wird aber dumpf. Leicht getreidig. Okay. 10/9/8/9//8
Pours clear pale golden with airy white head. Clear aroma of hops, malty and grain.
Jasno złote, z miłą białą pianą. Lekkie aromaty słodu i chmielu. W smaku słód i aromaty trawy. Pijalne, średnio wysycone.

This beer seems to have it all except a distinct pep. It is really decent and drinkable and seems to evaporate, i.e. it let’s you drink it quickly. It is a very typical bavarian Helles that grows on you.
11.2oz bottle. $8.99 USD a sixpack in Madison, WI. Medium bodied. Sweet. Smooth caramel, toffee, brown sugar tone. Easy enough to drink, true to style. A respectable example of the style.

В аромате просто дохера солода, карамельные слегка жженые нотки зерна. Много конечно хлеба, белого и темного, дрожжей тоже вагончик. Цвет немного не выразительный, слишком светлый, пенка маленькая, падает быстрее Пизанской башни. Вкус средний, все портит слишком сильная кислинка, легкая не сбалансированность при глотке а также отсутствие так называемой бархотистости. А так карамель есть, много солода и дрожжей в принципе не портят впечатление. Послевкусие с намеками на патоку даже ну и конечно хмель на месте. Но в целом нормально, но пил в стиле и лучше.
Taste: earthy dark roasted malts, some fresh hop character, bready, clean in the finish. Same with the nose. Mahogany, mostly clear, tan head some lace. Medium to med/light.

Bottle courtesy of our landlords Peter and Elke, (cheers you two!). Had this Sunday 17th March 2019. Pours brown with a mid sized head. Light chocolate notes, a little roastiness, some dark fruits, caramel and malts. Re: fruit, I am thinking dates perhaps. Quite a decent dunkel all told.

Bottle. Pours a clear very dark red-mahogany color with a small beige head and poor retention. Spotty lacing. Dark malts aroma. Fairly flat mouthfeel. Caramel and dark malt flavors dominate. Lightly sweet, no bitterness. Simple profile. One dimensional but very good. Very clean and easy drinking.
Hy-Vee Oktoberfest 2018. Bottle. Poured brown, off white head. Aroma of caramel, malty, grassy. Taste was mild sweet, toasted grain, caramel, nut.

Half liter at Brauhaus Schmitz, pours a brown color with medium sized off white head but was prettt dark this night in the bar. Notes of prunes, fig, dark bread, German earth, cherry, and dark laggah. Medium to fuller body.

Many thanks for this Bavarian Beer to Mariusz. Piwo ma ladna srednia i sniada piane, trwala. Kolor czerwony niczym rumiane policzki zawstydzonej dziewczynki. Smakowo stare sucharki, tosty i nieco chleba posmarowanego malo slodzonymi powidlami

Oh, this is dunkel heaven. I've been working my way through a few Bavarian dunkels over the last months: they are now my favourite beer style, and this is one of the best. They do vary slightly, and the closest to this, for me so far, is the Augustiner Dunkel. The pour is the classic dark umber with a good, lasting head and an intoxicating smell of malt and alcohol. The first mouthful, as so often with dunkels, tastes very yeasty, but--I anticipate it now--that quickly wears off as a chocolaty, malty character takes over, rising from within the the flavour depth. Another transition is that from a fine, fizzy bite to a smoothness at the back end. And the finish packs a slight touch of hop bitterness to top off the tastebud adventure. This is my second beer from Hofbrauhaus Freising--after their Jägerbier Export Hell--and it confirms this ancient brewery knows what it's doing. In with a bullet to my top four dunkels.

Fass 0,5l@Gasthof Neuwirt, Hallbergmoos: Kastanienbraun, leichte Trübung, deutlicher feinporiger Schaum; frische Nase, deutliche Süße, kräftig Malz, Karamell, leichte Röstaromen, Kaffee, dezente Hopfennoten, leichte dunkle Fruchtigkeit; frischer + fruchtiger Körper, kräftig Malz, Malzzucker, Karamell, leichte Röstaromen, Kaffee, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, dezente Hopfennoten, dunkle/getrocknete Fruchtigkeit, Rosinen; angenehmer fruchtig-malziger Nachgang

I find more life in this than JP did - a little spicy edge tickles it away from boring. It''s decent fare with a subtle pecan sweet edge. All flavors ARE toned down, though - it''s not a big fest by any means.
Decent amber color that lacks some clarity. Smallish head. Flavors of caramel and darker malts. Lacks nutty/roasted malt flavors. Slightly thin in body. Just a boring amber beer.
Tested Cask Version. Dark. Not much in the way of hops, and a rather unpleasent cloying sweetness. Too much body for summer. Average.

Distinct and cloying raspberry aromas, white foam, color is a bit too dark for a Koelsch. A bit too hoppy to be a drinkable lawnmower beer. Still tasty. Odd and interesting -- especially the bizarre and unmistakeable fruit flavors -- that's Bison!

Date: 09/25/1995 Mode: Draft Source: Maine Coast...Tap room, BH, ME rich, smooth start, slight bitters on the finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Growler. Sour milk and cola aroma. Dark opaque brown with small head. Sour/green banana or orange peel flavor - very astringent with only a light hint of malt to finish. Think something was wrong with this one - little porter character in the flavor. Will have to try again someday.

On tap at brewpub. Interesting; certainly a porter, but not as roasted. Instead it was sweeter, with heavy notes of chocolate of doughy malt. Decent, but I only wanted a 10oz and they gave me (and charged me) for a 22.

Leathery black with one really cool looking cap on it. Looks like a dollop of vanilla malt shake was placed on top. Nicely placed lacing in fluffy sheets with a few moth holes in em. Aroma is thick of char and ash. And that’s about it. Dry and ashy. Whoa is it ever. Wow. A bit much and a bit weird. And so it goes... Why cook out when you can drink the stuff right off your grill. Cuz that’s what this stuff tastes like. Definately smokey, ashy, charred, smokey, everything that has been fired up on the grill; corn cobs, steak, old iron, and blackened/burnt juices from various food items placed on the grill. Now with that said, it is definately not the norm for a porter, at least that I know of. This is a stretch on the interpretation of the style if there ever was one. No real balance as its all smoke, ash, and char. Interestingly unique, and a tad much, with lots of complicated smokey stuff going on. I would imagine a forest fire fighter might know some of these flavors more then I, but to me this is nearly like walking into a huge pit of ash and burnt stuff scraped from the grill. Feel is a tang of ash and smoke within a dryish, ashtray-like medium-light body with no real fashion or care to making the flavors any more interesting then they already are. One bizarre, smoke filled porter. Not something that can be enjoyed fully. Strangely capativating, yet not. If ya like stuff charred, this might be just the thing for ya.
Poured black with a huge tan head. Very rasty aroma with notes of coffee. The flavor was roasty and sweet with coffee and a light tartness. Some earthy notes and even some plastic.

Any first impressions? -Inordinately large foam bobs atop the browned black. -The horror! Iodine-based shoe wax is not what I look for in my porter aromas. -Roastiness battles the rising iodine, and its deep wounds are inappropriately covered in wet Band-Aids. -The large, frothy bubbling and lean maltiness could have been passable, if not for the rampant technical problems. What if you dig deeper? -Roasty bitterness and wooden hops are mroe than bothered by the surging iodine. -Yeast problem, you say? Ha! -Alright, my gag reflex is about to take control, so I’m done here. -Better luck next time; this shouldn’t be on the shelves. Bottle; no date.

(Bottle from the brewery) Cap opens with a very strong pffffffftt! Pours a dark cola brown with a huge tan head that eventually recedes to a soft foamy cap. Aroma is vinegar-like sour, plasticy and Band-Aid. Some spotty lacing. Mouthfeel: inconsequential because this is totally undrinkable. A sour, infected bottle of dark brown vinegar. This ratng was based on 2 bottles - both the same. Really outrageous they charge $9 or so a 6-pack for this. I will be notifying them FWIW.

Pours a tan, two-finger head that goes slowly and leaves a good lace. Black color. Light carbonation and heavy bodied. Roasted coffee/smokey nose. Starts slightly sweet but mainly roasted coffee. Smokey/tobacco finish. $1.83 for a 12oz bottle from Maine Coast Brewery Bar Harbor, Me. And FWIW Eden was the old name of Bar Harbor until about 1870.
Clear dark brown color with a thick frothy light brown head. Unpleasant sour aroma. Roasty flavor with unpleasant sourness.

Enjoyed at the brewery on the 4th and this was a pretty good beer. Probably the best that Maine Coast makes. Aroma is malty and coffee. As is flavor. Not too dominated by any one flavor, this is pretty well done.

Reviewed from old notes. On tap at brewpub. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a dark brown color with a bar pour’s kind of head. The smell was malty dry, light coffee persists and then a dry bitter chocolate. The taste was semi-sweet with a nice dry coffee enthralling my taste buds. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a good sessionable quality about it. The carbonation finishes somewhat smooth, still good for the style. Overall, good Irish Dry Stout, I’d have it again if I could.

tap at the brewpub - Pours dark brown with a lingering head. It smells of dark roast malt with coffee and has a similar flavor with some good bitterness. This brew is medium bodied and has a lingering, roast finish. It’s the best of the four when I visited the brewpub.

Draft at the brewery/restaurant. Finally! A decent beer in Bar Harbor. Poured like a champion Irish stout, although the bartender kept trying to knock down the awesome creamy head (ditz). There’s a nice roasty aroma, and the beer drinks with a well rounded malty aroma. Although just a bit chalky, the creamy character of the beer prevails, and this is ultimately a fun, drinkable Irish stout. (#4222, 8/21/2011)

On draft at the brewpub. Poured a dark black color, thin off-white to tan colored head, splotchy nice lacing all the way down. The aroma was chocolate, faint coffee, faint roast. The flavor followed, the body a bit grainy and silky, smooth. In want of more coffee flavors, something beyond the chocolate, but a good brew.

En fût. Verre de 12 oz dégusté chez Jack Russell’s Steakhouse & Brewery (Bar Harbor, ME). Arôme: Odeur de café. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence d’un moyen col beige mousseux et d’une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café avec une pointe chocolatée. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture crémeuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de café en arrière goût. (Rating #2710)

Any first impressions? -A humongous head lingers atop the dense blackness. -The potentially tart fruitiness of citrus and white grapes blurs the rising roastiness. -Astringency mars the dry roastiness. -Unbridled effervescence expands on the mouthfeel. What if you dig deeper? -Herbal hop bitterness and roastiness battle the astringency and minerals in an awkward finale. -The carbonation would fit a Saison perhaps, but not this stout. -At this stage, this isn’t as problematic as other bottled beers I’ve had from them, but a few weeks and I think it would’ve developed some uvula-spinning iodine nastiness. -This brewery reminds me more and more of La Barberie; mostly drinkable to good fresh on tap, but really worrying once bottled. Bottle; no date.

Nice roasted grains, slightly alcoholic scent. Dark brown, almost black with a thick tan head. Way too carbonated, it made a mess just opening it. Carbonation makes it a little too acidic, but otherwise the flavor is nice, full of roasted grains and coffee. This would be a much better beer with less carbonation.

Pours a brown, five-finger+ head that goes slowly and leaves a chunks of lace. Black color. Explosive carbonation and light bodied. Roasted coffee nose. Starts and finishes dry (the only part that is "Irish style") almost watery but with a good roasted coffee flavor. $2.13 for a 12oz bottle from Bayside Liquors Bar Harbor, Me.
Black color with a brown hue and a thick foamy light brown head. Aroma and flavor of roasted malt with unpleasant sourness.
I’m thinking this brewer was looking to Guiness when brewing this one as it was almost a clone of Guiness.
75cl bottle at home. Clear amber, stable foamy offwhite head. Lightly sweet and grainy malts, caramel, hint of apples, a tat herbal, liquorice: quite crisp and balanced. Light body, high carbonation.
8 mois avant DLC avec Milinf et Boulinf. Ambrée moyenne sur le malt grillé sans plus. Pas de fausse note mais pas d'originalité non plus

Shared at a tasting, thanks Roei and Natalie, very little head, clear dark red to light brown color, bready biscuit aroma with some nuts, malty metalic flavor with a bit of honey, quite sour , light bitterness, a touch fizzy. Not good, not a Biere de Garde.
Bottle at a tasting, thanks tomer. Clear amber. Caramel, honey, yeast aromas. Sweet, honey, floral, candy, oxidized. Medium-bodied, syrupy texture.
Bottle sample at a tasting at Max's place. Thanks tomer. Amber. Malt, caramel, candy, sweet, oxidation, slightly bitterish finish.
At Max Place, pours rusty with a small head, aroma of caramel, toffee, malt, flavor is sweet with caramel, toffee, light bodied
Bière ambrée. 4,8%. Goût caramélisé. Finement pétillante. Jolie couleur très légèrement trouble.

Tap at some punk place in Lyon. Almost clear amber with small beige head. Some sweet malts, light grass and herbs and a touch of wood. Really light aroma actually. Taste is also quite light, with both light sweet- and bitterness. Just medium bodied. Inoffensive beer.

Aucun intérêt. Autant la mange soif blonde présente un peu de goût, autant celle-ci ne propose rien. Le nez porte sur quelques levures mais le malt est insipide. En bouche, on a de la flotte, le malt essaie de ne pas paraître inaperçu en finale légèrement céréalière et difficilement caramelisée.
0.33 l bottle from a cafe in Lyon. Deep golden-amber color, white head. Hops, hay and herbs in aroma. Earthy taste with hoppy aftertaste. Medium body, lively carbonated. Interesting.
hay, cereal, brown, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, slick feel, average carbonation, long finish

Actually called Mange-Soif Brune de Dégustation Dark cognac colour, little yellow head. Caramel, toffee, Haagse hopjes , sweet-smelling. Sweet, but not cloying; caramel/toffee, bit of greenery in the finish. Quite slick, better bodied than most of Grihète’s beers, and carbonation held in check. Better than expected, could be pleasing with a meal. Kind of table beer version of Dunkelweizen.

Botella. Red brownish colour. Well toasted malt and aramel in the aroma along with some dark fruit. Ok mouthfeel. Caramel and toasted malt in the flavour along with some spice and dark fruit, light acid touch, fair bitterness.
From Voldby, DK. Bottled, 170410. Brown with off-white head. Aroma and flavor of roasted malt with wheat spices and some esters

Bottle. High fluffy and long lasting light brown head. Clear dark ruby body.Light roasted barley malt aroma with light fruity sour notes and caramel. Heavily carbonated roasted barley malt flavor with caramel and a bit of liquorice. Fair amount of hops bitterness and a long aftertaste.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with large creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Malty aroma with notes of caramel. Sweet flavor. Light bitter finish. Watery palate.

Bottle 33cl. @ home. Clear medium red brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, chocolate, moderate yeasty, sweet barberque grilled banana. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090201]
Amber coloured. Clear. White head, fully diminishing. Aroma of malt, caramel. Flavor is moderate sweet and lightly bitter. Syrup texture. Soft carbonation.
Moderate malty aroma. There is no head. Clear brown body. Light bitter flavor. Light to medium palate.

Bottled A dark brown coloured beer with a red hue and no head. The aroma is fruity with plenty of plums and various berries. Fruity in the mouth too; a hint of dark cherry and some bready malts. Pretty nice Score 3.5 Subsequent rating scored 3.7. Average becomes 3.6
Draught at Den Billenkletser, Antwerp Blond color, medium sized head. Mild and anonymous lager, dry and quite bitter; could be brewed in a million countries in the same way.

Standard lager Alken-Maes (now under Heineken) took over from Campina in Dessel when it ceased activities in 1989. In that sense, they did the same as Interbrew (now AB InBev) did in those days: keeping brand names alive in order to gain their respective audiences, that often were used to their familiar brands for many years. This one was turned into a fairly neutral, bland, soft malty lager with very low hop bitterness, totally forgettable. zachte, fruitige pils, in 1989 door Alken-Maes overgenomen van de toen ter ziele gegane brouwerij Campina te Dessel; te weinig hop in de afdronk.
Poor foam, metal scent, soapy flavour and texture. Prettt poor, even for a pilsener.

Straw gold colour, decent white head. Carbonation average. Aroma of malts and hops, bit fruity. Flavour sweet malts, bit hoppy. Finish little bitter, little sweetness. Rather balanced. -Slightly- above average pilsener. Old fashioned Belgian brand, less and less places where it’s on tap. (draught @ cafe Nova, Baarle-Hertog)
Clear gold coloured beer with no carbonation. Small white head. Fruity hoppy aroma.Palate is hoppy and a bit wattery, some hints to butter, ending is a little bitter. A regular pilsener.
gold blond coloured body with a small white head a sweet hoppy aroma a nice sweet taste and a short sweet bitter finich

Had it on tap. Clear, yellow blond colour, Small and diminishing white head. Nice, fruity aroma, little bit hoppy. Smouth palate, some bitterness in the finish. OK for a pilsener, but nothing realy special.
(Bottle 25 cl) Pale golden with a small white head. Very decent and harmonious pilsener. Very soft mouth-feel and only a discreet bitterness. Very close to a Danish premium pilsener. 190498
Draught. Looks and smells like pils. Tastes like boring, thin pils..........
Blond pilsner with a unexiting hop aroma and a boring taste.This beer has a medium body and a unbalanced bitterness in the end.
Sampled at the Midlothian location. Pours a light amber color with a medium head. Aroma is sweet malts, honey and grassy hops. Taste is bitter grassy hops, grain and honey. Medium bodied. Solid beer.
On tap at the Newington, CT. brewpub, listed as Hang 10 Honey Wheat. Clear gold, slight white head. Lots of honey in the nose and flavor, some fruitiness. Not bad.
Hang Ten Honey Wheat @ Hops MiamiStraw colour. Very honeyish aroma with light tropical fruit. Sweet, honeyish taste. Comes across balanced despite being really one-dimensional.

Draught at Hops Miami, billed as Hang Ten Honey Wheat. Hardly any color, so pale I confused it with a glass of water. Nothing offensive in the nose but nothing is there to begin with. Again with the water. More watery than water, unbelievable. Flavors are actually clean with some malt apparent but that is about it. Shockingly bland.

Draft... West Palm Beach location... Mostly clear, piss-yellow ale with a small, creamy, white head. Grainy, citric aroma with a twist of lemon peel. Perfectly balanced, dry, grainy flavor with just a touch of diacetyl (hardly worth mentioning, but oops, I did). Restrained, lemony citric acid. Light to medium-bodied with a skim-milk mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, crisp, tangy finish.
I would have taken this as more of a blonde style ale than a wheat. Does not have any of the slightest wheaty notes, more biscuity in maltiness, with some light but bittersweet fruit.
Also known as the Summer Ale. Golden body with a white head. Sweet toffee, light fruit in the taste. Clean ending, with an aroma of malts with some hops.
The guy told me it was the Summer Ale, but this seemed to resemble it the most. Clear light golden body with a thin white head. Light malt aroma. Sweet lightly spiced flavor.

Palm Harbor location. <!-- P --> Like many Hop’s beers this one is nearly aromaless with only a slight suggestion of honey and malt providing any aroma. Body is a clear golden color and is effectively headless. Light, crisp fore holds a comfortable touch of honey in the fore and middle and a very slightly floral showing in the finish. Not bad really for a a beer brewed to be low intensity. Could use more hops to balance the honey notes. This is listed here as an American Wheat, but the one in Palm Harbor seems very much to be a Golden Ale or the worst attempt at a Wheat ever.

Draught at the Pembroke Pines, FL location. Very pale yellow. Neutral nose. Sweet and watery with some honey, vegetables and fruitiness. No bitterness. Tastes like a poor wheat beer diluted with 70% sparkling water.

F: big, brownish, quick diminishing. C: dark brown, opaque. A: malt, caramel, brown sugar, metallic, hint of chocolate. T: malty, watery caramel, brown sugar, thin body, average to high carbonation, far from stout but as thirst quencher ok, 0,25l bottle from Shopping Peltri in Overpelt.

24/XII/15 - 25cl bottle from Bierfestival Onder ’t Schuim @ home - BB: 10/V/16 (2015-1774) Thanks to Inny and Marc for getting me the bottle! Clear dark brown beer, small creamy beige head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: very malty, sweet, caramel, cow fodder. MF: soft carbon, light body. Taste: very sweet, malty, lots of caramel, sugary, more caramel. Aftertaste: more sugar and caramel, that’s about all. Pretty bad.
Pours dark brown. Aroma and taste are sweet caramel and malts. Not enjoyable.

25cl flesje via Janssen-Baijot, Veldwezelt Alcoholpercentage van 1,35% Uitgeschonken in Amstel glas Uiterlijk: als een glas cola, geen schuim Aroma en smaak: sterke ijzersmaak, caramel, chemisch, veel te zoet Conclusie: tafelbier, vind deze te smerig en heb het bij 1 slokje gelaten ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Light brown. Very bland metallic caramel, and same on the palate. Very thin and fizzy, like a lot of table beers.

Good, but rapidly dwindling cream-tan head over big bubbled deep brown beer. Molasses’ nose, green winterleaves, rainwater. Very sweet, Traubenzucker , cola. Bit of metal(oxide) in the end. Sweetness intensifies in time, resulting in a long, sticky MF and finish. Prickly, but not sustained carbonation. Feels denser than it is. Decent in its kind. I think the kids would love it, if the official nincompoops wouldn’t prevent them of tasting it.
Dark brown, low carbonation. Very bad beer. Very very sweet. Aroma is caramel with loads of sugar and sweeteners. Undrinkable sweet.
black dark brown colored body with a disappearing off white head a malt sweet fruit aroma a, sweetish fruit caramel malt flavor with a sweet finish
25cl bottle. Colour is so dark brown that it is seemes more like black with medium, tan head. aroma is caramel, malts, kvas like. The taste is extremely sweet kvas.

25cl bottle @ home when having dinner. Clear ruby red color, small off-white to beige head. Smell malts, sweet. Taste malts, sweetness and (Dutch) ’stroop’. Low carbo, low body. Nice to have with dinner, obviously that’s what it’s intended for.

column1: Bert Grant's Deep Powder Winter Ale
column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: From 2010 file notes. Pours brown w/garnet notes. Malty aroma. Tastes malty, spicy. I liked it.

column1: Bert Grant's Deep Powder Winter Ale
column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Winter Ale--1997 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV. 30 IBU’s. (2.0 / 5.0) Winter Ale--1998 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV. (3.0 / 5.0) Mt. Hood Hops Featured. Clear dark copper color. Hop Spicy body. Lots of hops in finish, but few in front. Malt has hints of being tasty, but gets overwhelmed by hops before you can tell. Unbalanced. Sampled 11/28/1998. Winter Ale--1999 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Mt. Hood Hops. Clear robust bronze red color. Spicy from rich hop character. Body is complex medley of hop cherry chocolate nut malt cinnamon flavor. Light sweetness and clean light hop hot end. Sampled 11/14/1999. Winter Ale--2000 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Mt. Hood hops. Clear rich bronze black cherry red color. Roasted fruit front with mild winter spice and floral Mt. Hood signature. Crisp richly roasted balanced mild sweet fruit body. Clean mild end. Sampled 11/26/2000. Deep Powder Winter Ale--2001 12 oz. Bottle 6.00 ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) Clear rich copper bronze red color. Creamy lacy tan head. Rich roasted winter spice floral hop malty front. Robust roasted dark cherry fruit spice body. Honey doughy and dry. Tart spiced dry citrus hop end. Sampled 11/28/2001. Deep Powder Winter Ale--2002 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) Clear rich dark garnet red black cherry color. Light lacy head. Roasted floral fruit hop mild nutmeg front. Thick sweet rich burnt black cherry caramel biscuit body. Roasted spicy rich hop end. Mt. Hood Hops. Sampled 12/22/2002. Grant’s Deep Powder Winter Ale--2003 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Mild lace head. Clear thin dark red bronze color. Roasted mild winter spice Mt. Hood hop front. Tangy dry sweet thick honey robust mild roasted mild clean spice body. Rich tangy hoppy end. Mild spice nice. Sampled 12/31/2003. Bert Grant’s Deep Powder Winter Ale--2004 12 oz. Bottle 6.00% ABV. 35 IBU’s? (4.25 / 5.0) Tan lacy head. Clear dark mahogany bronze red color. Spicy toasted mild nutmeg Mt.Hood hop front. Tangy dry roasted crisp robust black cherry honey caramel nutmeg biscuit body. Crisp mild hop spice end. Sampled 12/3/2004.

column1: Bert Grant's Deep Powder Winter Ale
column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Very tasty winter. Frothy and delicious. Honey and breads are the dominant force. Rated 5/14/04

column1: Bert Grant's Deep Powder Winter Ale
column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Had this beer on 2/17/1999. Color is a deep dark brown with good carbonation and a light head. Aroma is a dark roasted malt scent. Taste is rich and strong. It starts with a medium body that is full of a rich roasted malt taste that goes down with a slight sharpness and the roasted flavor gets a bit stronger. The finish caries the malt flavor backed with a light bitterness and light hop flavor. It makes for a good winter brew but is not as good as most Bert Grant Ales.

column1: Bert Grant's Deep Powder Winter Ale
column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Date: 12/05/2003 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting dark amber, stale hop aroma, light body, malt flavor with a well balanced bitterness, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column1: Bert Grant's Deep Powder Winter Ale
column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: There is a malty aroma and the color is amber with shades of copperish red. The head is a nice long lasting tan. Deep Powder begins with a slight malty sweetness and builds to a roasted bitterness. The body is medium and the aftertaste has a pleasent bitterness that lasts.

column1: Bert Grant's Deep Powder Winter Ale
column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: maybe i had a dead bottle (actually 2) the honey doesn’t go over too well with me. not at all bad. a little thick and not very carbonated. like kramer says sherry, toasty thats it for me.

column1: Bert Grant's Deep Powder Winter Ale
column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: I was surprised at the low ratings on this one. Lots of coffee, chocolate, toffee and toasty malt. Silky smooth with a light sweetness on the tongue. Sort of chocolate milk like, and really tasty.

column1: Bert Grant's Deep Powder Winter Ale
column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Aroma shows some oxidation, but a good strong caramel malty smell, I detect a hint of chocolate in there as well. The flavor sure has died down some I assume. It lacks a real punch but still maintains some clean amber roasty flavors. Palate, indeed has smoothed over and killed the hop profile. Not impressive, but still pretty decent given its age.

column1: Bert Grant's Deep Powder Winter Ale
column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: There is a malty aroma and the color is amber with shades of copperish red. The head is a nice long lasting tan. Deep Powder begins with a slight malty sweetness and builds to a roasted bitterness. The body is medium and the aftertaste has a pleasent bitterness that lasts.
Burn't/slightly sour flavour and aroma. Nice beer overall..................

Light golden colour with a fine white head. Ok lacing. Mild grainy aroma. Moderate sweet and light hoppy. Medium to light body. A bit thin texture. Light malt flavour, and also light hoppy. [Can from a friend working at Svalbard, Norway]

Bottle @ Danish Summer Gathering, Ulfborg 2011. Having tried the non-Ice version which was utterly shite I wasn’t that eager to try this one. My expectation where met as they outdid themselves creatign this abomination that is labeled as beer.
Can at Papsoe’s - Thanks. Clear yellow - white head. White bread, citrus, corn, light light body, light light malty, metallic, cardboard, thin. Plain.
Can at Papsø. Clear yellow coloured with a medium sized white head. Malty aroma of grain with notes of hops. Malty flavour of hay and corn with bitter notes. Bitter finish. Light watery.
50 cL bottle. Pours clear and pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is cardboardish and flat malty. Cornish and cardboardish flat. Bitter and dry finish.

Can. A light yellow beer with a lazing white head. The aroma has notes of ice, water, cardboard, and a bit of malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of straw, cardboard, and ice, leading to a dry finish.
Can 50 cl. Courtesy of Rune. Pours a clear yellow with a white head. Heavy brewing cereal nose. Thin body, brewing cereal and cardboard with just a little hops in the finish. Poor. 011211

Can 500ml. @ The Danish Summer Gathering, TFODRBSG11. Clear light yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, grain, toasted, acidic malt, vegetables, cardboard. Flavour is light to moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20110820]
Lata. Yellow, lear, short white head. graina roma. Thin mouthfeel. Grain bad hoppy flavour... cheap..
Bottle@TFODRBSG11.Pours pale yellow with a small white head.Aroma of malt, grassy hops and fruitiness.Flavor is sweet and fruity with some malty notes.Medium to thin body, lively carbonation.
Keg at The Windmill, Southport. Clouded amber with Nitro head. Ok it was a rate, but when you spot these things!. Tinny, metallic background, soapy flavour, poor stuff. Thin through to finish.
Keg Handpump at the Pullman Lodge Hotel, Seaburn 01/11/2005. Golden coloured and smooth with a slight hint of hoppiness. Slight malt and bitterness in the finish.
NOt bad, but a little bitter more than the other. Any way, it was ok, but for me was not that creamy.

One of my old student bars used to serve this, it was introduced to me by one of my Yorkshire mates. Thick, creamy texture, strong flavour (I’m sure the one I had was 5.5%) and long finish. Lef tme with a smile on my face anyway, and remains one of my favourite cream ales.

Draft at Quorn Grange Hotel, Quorn. Mild bitter hops aroma, with a hint of fruity character. Otherwise, pretty dull. Dark golden amber clear, light haze, with creamy thick off-white lacing head. Medium watery body with thin carbonation. Light in both the malt and hop area, with a tint of fruity character. Some bitterness towards the end, with light bitter after touched with a watery cider tang. Clean, but not much character.
Golden darkish color, little head. Sour and bitter taste. Weak hoppy aroma.
Clear orange color, medium creamy haed. Not much aroma. Smooth creamy taste, bit sour, bitter, bit sweet. Very soft and creamy. (tnx caesar)
Clear orange color, medium creamy haed. Not much aroma. Smooth creamy taste, bit sour, bitter, bit sweet. Very soft and creamy.
Nitro keg, The Air Balloon, Blackpool. Amber coloured. Tangerine fruit. Cream soda. Gentle tingle bitterness. A drink.
Extremely creamy and mild. 1/4" head that lasts! Wow. Must be nitro'ed.

12 ounce can from Total Wine Brookfield, 9/17/19. Hazy yellow, large foamy white head, fair retention. Aroma of banana and not much else. A mild bit of spice. Taste is banana, spice, yeast, wheat. Medium bodied, lingering spice.

Can/Fest. A- Bubblegum, banana. A- Yellow color, clear liquid, white head. T- Banana, bubblegum. P- Light body, average texture, average carbonation, balanced finish. O- Banana and bubblegum are the prevalent flavors. A touch of clove and wheat as well. Really good take on the style. Schell continues to impress me with their no nonsense traditional approaches. As good as any Hefe I've had in Germany.

16oz pour of beer in a plastic cup at the brewery's biergarten. Light straw golden color with a healthy cloudiness. Nose is predominantly banana and wheat like a true hefeweizen. Taste follows suit with banana, wheat, and clove. A healthy dose of fruit without too much sweetness. Fits a warm summer day perfectly. Easy to drink. If you want to experience a true German atmosphere in without traveling abroad, this place and this beer fit the bill. Prost!
12 oz. bottle. Poured light hazy, light golden, foamy white head. Aroma of banana, bubblegum, spice. Taste was mild sweet, yeast, bread, citrus, watery.
Tap at new bohemia golden valley with samalito. Hazy yellow with small white head. Banana nose. Taste is heavier on sweetness . A lighter version with more sweetness and less yeast and spice.

Not a bad traditional style Hefeweizen beer. Oromo was the best part here with cloves bananas and malt. Flavor was like nose Carbonic Tang was a little strong body was a little thin and watery likewise with carbonation a little strong. Still decent enough beer overall.

Approximately 2 oz. pour, on tap at Union 32 in Eagan, Minnesota. Consumed on 7-13-17. Cloudy pale straw. Small amount of nearly white to beige head. Lovely banana aroma. Bubblegum scent. Smells great. Strong banana and clove in flavor. Quite tasty, although flavor could stand to be stronger. Frothy in the palate. Light body. Insubstantial palate but works. A darn good hefeweizen. 8.3.7.3.14=>3.5
From old tasting notes. Clear deep bronze color. Nice creamy white head. Faintly sweet wheat malt aroma. Tart citrus malty foretaste. Brief tangy finish and aftertaste. Refreshing and very drinkable.

Bottle poured a hazy yellow with a small lingering white head. Aromas of wheat, yeast, clove and light banana. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of wheat, yeast, clove and light bubblegum with a smoith lingering clove finish.

12 oz single bottle from Hy Vee Wine & Spirits - Council Bluffs (Madison Ave). Hazy, unfiltered, pale yellow appearance with a white head. Aroma of wheat, mild clove, light banana and a bit of citrus zest. Similar flavor, adding mild sweetness. Light to medium body with a pleasant finish. Solid.
(draught at the brewpub) Bronze red with small light tan head. Slightly sweet malt aroma. Flavor is caramel malt and some hops in the finish.

On tap at the brewpub. Pour is bronze - red, very little head. Aroma is not really present. Taste is a little bit of malt, no hop, and really nothing else until the finsish, which was putrid. I certainly hope I got a bad one. Other raters I respect scored this one far higher, so I’ll give it a go next time and hopefully have an improved re-rate.
On tap. Reddish color. Aroma is caramelly. Taste is caramelly, nutty, mildly spciy. Not too bad.

The body was dark copper with a light khaki colored head. The aroma was iced tea with apples and a hint of oranges. The taste had orange liqueur wit some caramel and old leaves. Something was musty and off in the finish.

Lots of of strong caramel and a touch of roast malts, fruity yeast esters, and no hop aroma. Nice and clear reddish brown with little head. Very caramelly with a great dark malt and hop bitterness at the end. Full bodied with the right amount of carbonation. Rate Beer has this listed as an amber ale, but I think it fits the Irish Red style better.
A bronze brew with a typical head. Little to no aroma and same for any flavors. Barest of malt notes, otherwise this is vapid.

On tap at the brewpub. Copper color with an ivory head. Exceptional lacing. Sheets of foam coat the sides of the glass. Very smooth tasting. Same brutal hop finish as the wheat, unfortunately. However, I like the malty palate.
Probably the best beer at the Power Plant Brewery. Full color and flavor, with a pleasant aftertaste.
Probably my least favorite offering from this brewery. Classic ruby appearance with a very malty nose. the flavour is somewhat metallic and unbalanced.

Light ruby color. Slight head but some visible carbonation. Sweet and fruity malt aroma (banana, bubblegum). Mostly malt flavor profile, sweetness is evident, but hoppiness is right on its heels. This gives the beer a surprisingly good balance. Some mild hop bitterness for the finish, followed by sweetness for the aftertaste. This is actually better than I was expecting, if you're at the brewery give it a try.

A good summer brew. Reminded me of a Kolsch. Could use a little more flavor. About average all-around (flavor almost a 7 but not quite). Kind of pricey for what it is though. Grabbed a single to sample first, but not really interested in getting again with some better stuff out there.

12 ounce can. Bright honey gold pour. Large dense creamy beige head. Light lemony malt aroma. Crisp light malt flavor has a hint of wheat character. Thin bodied and dry. Very refreshing, though lacking in complexity.
I had it from the can. It's wheat, lemon, and fruit. It's got a fluffy and smooth palate. It's refreshing but still has good flavor. There's a nice, malty sweetness to it.
Not too sure about this one. Nice slightly cloudy yellow colour. Wheat notes as expected with a light citrus taste and slight bitterness. Not really much of anything.
Fles 35,5cl thuis. Fris hoppig, wat fruitig, bittertje. (7-2015).-------------
12 ounce can from the remainder shelf at Liberty Beer in Pittsburgh. Nice. clean and fresh. I wish I had saved it for a hot summer day.
Keg at the brewery. Clear golden. Nose is light wheat, sweet grass, fruits. Tastes light wheat and fruits, bland.

355ml Can: Pours a clear golden with thick white head that retains well. Lacing. Aroma of citrus and marshmallow. Spicy notes fill the mouth, finishing quite dry. Interesting candy-like flavours as well. Bitterness is medium, body is medium to low, carbonation is medium. Overall the beer is crisp and clean with a great flavour. I really like this style of beer.

Anchor Summer Wheat pours a clear golden color and sports a fluffy white head with beautiful lacing. The subtle nose leads with aromas of pineapple and green apple, backed by bright tropical fruits. The taste is acidic from attack to finish, with more hoppiness than the nose suggests on the mid-palate with light astringency and a hint of resin. The fluffy body is light, bordering on lean. Quaffable.

Summer beer campaign down at Familymart. Aroma: rather sour. Appearance: clear dark amber, minimal head. Palate: light-bodied and thin, average carbonation, bitter finish. Taste: moderately bitter, bananas and pear drops at the end. Misleading, tastes more like an IPA, where’s the wheat?

The .8% alcohol you gain by picking this over the regular hoffbauer pays its dividends in splitting headaches about two minutes after consuming one of these hellish brews. Hands down the best thing about Hoffbauer beers is the "medals" displayed on the packaging that on closer inspection appear to be ancient roman coins.
clear golden yellow, small head of fine white bubbles. nose is metallic and sweet. Taste is nothing, but aftertaste is a odd mix of malt, hops and adjucts. bad.
if you plan on drinking this beer for taste, you’d be better off chewing on the can.

This was just about one of the most repulsive beers I have ever had the displeasure of trying. Chalky metaalic tinges with corn and other rotting vegetables. Very light and watery with some vinous fruit flavors and alcohol

12 oz can, courtesy of da Iceman. Very thin yellow hue, even for swill, with alka-seltzer like carbonation. Smells like sucking on pennies. The initial flavor is a barage of old pocket change which segues seamlessly into a backend comprised of a fresh cabbage bouquet. Warming, notes of stale corn pops become evident. Thin, watery, fizzy body has no flaws other than being thin, watery and fizzy. This...is...not good.
This wasnt too bad. A pale yelllow appearance. The flavor had some sort of weird apple juice quality to it. It hides the booze well and its chuggable so I guess its ok? For swillathons only

My friend gave this to a girl in an Easter basket a few years ago. Surprisingly, she was not impressed. Don’t spend too much time on this one. Skunky aroma, corn in both the flavor and the nose, and a horrible hangover as reward.

When I was in school and could not afford good beer, I was would drink this stuff. For a cheap ass beer it is not bad at all. It grows on you. Its smoother than other ice beers in the same cheap arena and has a better taste. Thumbs up!
pretty hideous on the flavor basically its like someone threw some alcohol on some canned corn and lit it on fire. and then threw that on ice.
Pours golden in color. Aroma is sweet and grainy. Taste is of really sweet corn and alcohol. Funky cereal type after taste. Sweet finish as well. Not a very good brew. At least it’s cheap.

On cask at the Waterman's near Ashprington. Appearance - amber to copper. Proportionate head. Nose - spiced biscuit but mainly caramel and toffee. Taste - more caramel and toffee. Some breadiness. No spice this time. Palate - light to medium bodied with a finish that could be fresher. Overall - so so!
@GBBF - clear copper-amber beer under a solid creamy beige foam; nice lace; yeasty with a flowery hoppiness; low carbonation and body, quite tasty; aftertaste of quince and tea, decent bitterness
Junction Inn, Southampton. Soft, sweet, nutty session beer. Hint of crystal malt. Finishes dry with a lingering dusty bitterness. I like it.

Cask at The Three Horseshoes, Powerstock. Near clear brown with a small tan head. Aroma of caramel, malt and dried fruits. Flavour is light moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter. Light to medium bodied with very soft carbonation.

Cask at Prince of Wales, Farnborough. 25/08/16. Torn over this beer. Pretty much zero aroma. In terms of taste/palate it’s extremely soft and sweet, but picking up very little. It is copper and has a healthy off-white head. I suppose it’s harmless - could knock back a few but not really notice.

13th October 2015 The Royal Standard, Lyme Regis. Cask. Clear dark amber beer, small bubbly pale cream colour head. Palate is light and semi dry and has mild fine carbonation. Taste is most reminiscent of their best bitter but somewhat watered down. Tangy caramel malts. Tangy dried fruits. Trace of ripe orange. Quaffable. Fine!

Cask at the Harp, Covent Garden. Pale orange, small foamy white head. Aroma is caramelly but there’s also plenty of sulphur unfortunately. Body is light, smooth, low carbonation. Taste is citrussy, soft bready malt, light bitterness. Flavour is nice enough, shame about eggy smell.
part of my 2013 backlog. Tried at the New Inn Cerne Abbas, Dorset. Amber colour with a white head. Aroma has fruit and toffee. the taste more of the same.

Cask at random pub in Dorset. It pours deep copper with a small white head. The nose is earthy, nutty, light caramel and wood. The taste is bitter, earthy, wood, tame bitterness, chewy malt and astringent bite with a dry finish. Light-medium body, soft carbonation and chewy mouth-feel. A bit chewy, but not too bad.

Cask at The Ropemakers, Bridport; copper coloured with a head of loose white bubbles; light fruity aroma; taste is dry citrus fruit and malt; some dusty, flowery hops lurk in the background; simple, light, unexciting but perfectly ok for what it is.

Draft. A black beer with a brown shin under a thin tan head. The aroma has notes of malt with a light note of roasted malt. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of roasted malt as well as lighter notes of wood, leading to a dry roasted finish. The body is light. Boring stout.

On tap. Opaque dark brown with an orange hue and a creamy, beige nitro head. Discreet aroma of hard roasted malt and licorice. Rather light in body with a low carbonation - due to the nitro - and hence a soft mouthfeel. Notes of licorice and hard roasted malt, but also a light fusty edge. Has a light malt bitterness in the finish. 100709

From tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown to black with a small creamy and tan head. Classic nitro pour. Hardroasted and dark malty aroma, light coffeeish. Creamy mouthfeel. Quite sweet and toffee roasted caramel malt towards dark breadish. A bit thin in the mouthfeel for the finish but with a nice lingering roasted malt flavour and light bitterness coming through.

Date: July 09, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: black, creamy beige head, heavy lace Aroma: rich roasted aroma, dark chocolate, touch of dark caramel sweetness Body: thin but creamy body Flavor: rich roasted malt flavor, bitter dark chocolate, a bit watery Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4
Draft at the Brewery. Nearly black in color with a tan nitro head. Aroma of roast and coffee. Flavor more of the same, a little sweeter than Guinness but not very dissimilar. Dry finish.

Tap. Deep dark brown, small tan head. Aroma is soy sauce, coffee, roasted malts, and chocolate. Aroma is better than the flavor, which is thin for a stout--thin mouthfeel too. Flavor strongly of chocolate and roast coffee. Uncomplicated.
Dark black in color with a tan head... Flavor is roasted malts with crisp clean finish... Guinness clone... Aroma faint of roasted malts... Average beer.

On tap at 21A, 4.2% abv for this batch. What can I say, it’s a nitro stout and looks the part. Super dark red (black) with the whole cascading bubble number down pretty well, and a dense, fake tan head. Light aroma of cocoa powder and some roast. The flavor is roasty and pretty dry,with a nice bitter chocolate flavor and some coffee lingering in the finish. More malt then you would get in an Irish import, and a touch more sweetness. My dad said he wanted it dryer, but then it would taste like the black water that Guinness passes of on us these days. I enjoyed the flavor, but the nitro thoroughly killed the mouth-feel for me; it was just flat and lifeless, with a fake creamy feel. I know that this would be more enjoyable out of a regular tap, but I also know how well nitro works as a marketing tool for dry stouts these days.
A nice deep dark dry stout. Just a great session beer, not much to set it aside, but i’s a well done stout.
Pours dark with a tan foam head. Aroma is of roasted/burnt malt. Flavor is smooth and creamy but a bit bland. Not bad.
Does anyone know where I could get this beer on the East Coast? I have sampled it on the West Coast but was like to find some closer to home. I am in Pennsylvania. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. The appearance is a semi clear golden amber color with a small white head. The aroma is bitter hops. The taste follows the nose.

Poured a clear copper color. Medium head. Aroma of floral hops and a caramel malty backbone. Taste is medium bitter with malts in the background. Pine. Bread, slight grass. Decent. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Resembles more to the original English IPA’s than to the more popular brews that have flooded the market recently. Malty and bitter, good one!

12 ounce bottle to wine glass Appearance: reddish amber, light brown, hazy, minimal tan foam Aroma: Nose: not much aroma, malty drink:malty, slight scent of alcohol, ho hoppy aroma Taste: medium to very bitter Feel:full body, sticky, lively, long finish OA: good beer, ok to repeat, not to look for Drank: April 25, 2016
Bottle: Poured an amber color with a thin white head. Light citrus aroma with flavors of grapefruit, pine and some caramel on the end. It has a slight bitterness on the finish.

330ml bottle served in a pint glass. Enjoyed @ Hong Kong Brew House. Pours a slightly cloudy orange color forming a medium white head with low retention forming lots of thin soapy lacings in the glass. Nose is grassy and fruity. Strong fruity notes: mango and grapefruit, mainly. Resin, zest and pine notes. Taste follows the nose: slightly sweet upfront. Sweet pale and caramel malts. Resin, grapefruit, grass, pine, earth. Medium bitterness (was expecting more). Light body. Average carbonation. Caramel, grapefruit and grass in the aftertaste. Not very persistent. Not bad brew.
Pours a clear orange Amber with a light tan head. Aroma of musty orange caramel. Taste is malt forward with a stiff bitterness in the finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
So much orange! The orange flavor and aroma overpower this Ipa. It isn’t bad, there is an interesting bitterness at the end. But too much citrus for me liking.
(7) Drink again. A fine hoppy good fresh beer. Wonderful aroma. Fine crisp taste.
Draft. A pitch black beer with a thin tan head. The aroma is dominated by roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with primary notes of roasted malt, leading to a dry roasted finish. The body is light.
Poured dark brown/black, roasted malts, chocolate, little nutty, little coffee, little licorice, little earthy hops.

On tap. Pours black with a vague orangey hue and a beige head. Hard roasted malts and licorice in the nose. Medium body with hard roasted malts and licorice. Some malt bitterness in the finish. 120709
Dark brown with a fizzy tan head. Roasted malt chocolate and citrus aroma and taste with a smooth finish.

From tap at the brewpub as Jupiter Pedros Porter. Pours dark brown to fully black with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted and mild yeasty fruity. Slight sweet malt flavoured, nice roasted note. Light bitter to acidic flavoured finish.7-3-7-3-14=3.4 From tap at Jupiter, Berkeley. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is dark roasted malty. Light chalky note. Smooth roasted and dark breadish malty. Light liqourice note to this too. Bitter and dry roasted into the finish. Lasting hardroasted malt impression.7-4-7-4-14=3.6

Date: July 08, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: dark brown with ruby edges, creamy beige head, drippy bits of lace Aroma: sweet chocolate aroma, light earthyness Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, nice caramel sweetness, light balancing earthyness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: *4

Draft at the brewpub. It’s a great looking pour, almost black with a small but moderately thick off-white head. Aroma of caramel, coffee, and nuts. Initial flavor is very good with dark and milk chocolate, caramel, and almond notes. As it warms, however, the hops seem to take over and turn the beer overly bitter, and this bitterness lingers long on the palate. I loved it at first sip, but the increasing bitterness made it a chore to finish.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty chocolate aroma. Roasted malty chocolate flavor with some hoppy bitter hints. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish.

Poured from tap at Jupiter, icy cold, a black with brown hues and a very thin tan head. Aroma was mostly dark roasted grains and caramel. The flavor was bitter coffee, dark roasted grains, a floral peachy hoppiness, toffee, and a woody/grain husk astringency that turned tart/sour and charcoaly toward the end. Palate was dry throughout with a rather thin body for a porter and heavy tartness at the end. Overall, this was served much too cold and had to warm for full flavors to develop. There was a lack of malt sweetness to balance the harsher tones in this one. Ok at first but hard to finish the whole pint.

pours near black with some tan head...coffee and malt flavors dominate with some definate bitterness, not a bad beer at all but I find the mouth feel much thinner than i would of liked and i get a little burnt flavor out of it as well

I had the opportunity to try this beer, in the dining-car from Lausanne to Bern, going to Colmar. The body has a perfect touch of copper color, average carbonatio, clear, thin and white foam. In my point of view, it was a good vienna lager, a good balance of malt, bread and a metalic side, generous note of perle or saaz hop, round and refreshing.
Finally a great malt forward driven red in switzerland. Clean and crisp and nothing off. beers of the world Zurich

Ich weiß nicht, ob dieses Bier noch produziert wird -ich habe es anno 2013 getrunken und kann mich noch an den malzig-samtigen Geschmack erinnern. Es ist ein sanftes Bier, das nicht zu süß, aber trotzdem ordentlich karamell-malzig ist. Ein braves Bier, das aber schnell langweilig wird.
Pours copper with medium head. Strong nose of malt and caramel. Taste of malt, caramel and bread. Saturated flavor. Very good lager

Review: 50 cl. Can of Eidgenoss: ABV: 5% vol Really dull looking can has a picture of Swiss cross/flag on the can, but it doesn’t really stand out amongst all the other beers on offer. On pour, dark orange coloured beer with a reddish hue and a nice big frothy white head, all looks good. Head maintains and there is also some nice lacing. The smell was lagery, got the barely and the yeast, the malts, and fruits all on the nose. Very nice and piercing, a nice smell. On taste get a nice smooth pleasant drink, that is very tasty, not bitter and very easy to quench. Nice enough mouthfuls, not bad, I like it, it is very good, very easy to drink. Malty and light bodied. A long lasting pleasant taste that is left in the mouth for one to savour. Creamy mouthfuls. Very smooth. Not a large array of flavours, and it is very light but it is all nice and easy to drink, very easy to drink. Lovely. Quiet strong actually, definitely felt the alcohol after. Like it a lot, very refreshing, recommended.
I guess not to everybody’s taste, but I enjoyed it! Amber coloured, smooth,yeasty. Very good.
Brownish copper color with foam layer. Sweet ambery nose. Sweet taste with a sticky mouth feeling with a round almost berry fruity hint. Sticky calm aftertaste.
pours hazy amber with a creamy head and a nice lacing. aroma of caramel and almonds. flavour malts, bread. semi-dry finish, no bitterness.
Farbe orange. Geruch: Unendlich Kara. Im Geschmack wässrig, wenig bitter, nachhängend Kara. Wenig mundvoll.
Geruch malzig. Geschmack alkoholisch bis estrig mit Karamell und Butterpopcorn. Merkwürdiger Nachgeschmack.
Only very slight hoparoma. Malty and a bit skunky. Hopbitter finish. .......

A bottle of this got popped around the shop sometime in 2006 or 2007. For the most part even over the beer itself I remember how excited I was to even be able to taste this beverage, which had been long gone from the shelves to the public for years. Being an IPA it had lost a bit of it’s up-front-ness, but it was still big and grapefruity, with lots of doughy malt to back it up. Citrusy goodness all the way through past the finish. I can only imagine it fresh being as close to a 5 as you can get!

INDIA PALE ALE--12 OZ. BOTTLE. 1997--6.00%ABV. (2.5 / 5.0) Sampled 1/10/1998. 1998--6.50% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Clear pale golden color. Nice floral hop front. Lightly carbonated body is slightly sweet and on the thin side. Hop bitterness is strong in a very dry finish. Good use of hops, but could be bigger. Sampled 2/14/1999. 1999--6.50% ABV. (4.5 / 5.0) Clear light amber color assumes orange juice appearance with pellicle. Big floral hop front leads to creamy rich sweet crystal malt body. Spicy earthy end almost balanced by sweet body and pellicle. Sampled 8/8/1999. 2000--7.00% ABV. (4.5 / 5.0) Rich smoky floral earthy hop front. Slightly hazy rich golden color. Rich sweet caramel malt body continues earthy floral flavor. Big hops. Floral takes over at finish. A wow hop brew. Sampled 5/31/2000. 2002--6.00% ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) Rate Beer Club Selection. Tight sediment. Hazy rich amber color. Light head. Medium lace. Rich earthy floral hop front. Balanced crisp malty sweet creamy yeasty caramel fruit body. Clean mild earthy citrus hop spice bitter end. Sampled 10/9/2002. 2003--7.00% ABV. (4.75 / 5.0) Light sediment. Lightly hazed rich thick golden color. Rich floral earthy big malty hop front. Rich creamy hot sweet caramel body. Thick texture. Mellow yeast sediment. Earthy rich hop end. Lacy light head. Sampled 2/27/2003.

12 oz. bottle; thanks BillKismet for breaking this out; the legendary hop cone…haha; decanted and poured slowly revealing a muddy dark orange with no head; musky, moldy, citrus hop aromas that are surprisingly floral and pleasant; smells much better than it tastes at this point with some ethanol and stale malt; still remains quite bitter and dry; while kind of a novelty to drink this IPA at this age; the nose was quite nice after all this time

Name: India Pale Ale &#40Bottleworks&#41 Date: July 06, 2005 Mode: Bottle Source: Trade Appearance: opaque orange, big off white head, chunks of whole hops floating on top Aroma: fresh hop aroma with a touch of sweetness Flavor: big bitter hop flavor, picks up some sweetness in and a malt backbone after the hops are strained out, bitter finish lasts forever Overall: too much gimmic, the extra long dry hopping makes it too bitter Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.9/5.0 Score: 4 The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

12-oz. Thanks BillKismet! I had given up on the idea of ever rating one of these. Pours cloudy golden-amber with a white ring of foam. Earth, flowers and pine aroma. Medium body, nearly still. Taste of mango, caramel and earth. Amazing for it’s age - I’m spotting it a couple of points on overall impression just for being an IPA senior citizen. This had to be awesome when it was even remotely fresh.

Seriously BillKismet, thanks dude, what a treat. No. Way. Jasmine and herbal nose, gusher, lots of head. Very chewy, you can taste the hop pellets, though the bitterness has fallen off to the floral foundation. Never thought I’d be able to have one of these.

Thank you so much BliiKismet, I wasn’t sure if I was ever going o get to try this one,definitely a pleasant surprise. Matt knew what this one was going to do, we had a strainer ready and waited for the gush, I thought for sure there would be oxidation and loss of some of the hop aroma, but the kitchen was instantly filled with an awesome citrus fruit aroma. Great hop bitterness and hop flavor backed up by a nice sweet maltiness. The transistion from initial hop bitterness to flavor was near spot on. Awesome!

12-oz. Wow, wow, wow, thanks BillKismet! Can’t hardly believe I get to try this. Murky dark orangeish amber. Towering gushy head. Huge herbal, slightly buttery/spicy nose. Creamy medium body. Beautiful floral fruity hop with doughy malt on the mid-palate. Awesome, awesome beer, magnified all the further by thinking we’d never get our hands on any.

2004 - This is absolutely one of the most fantastic things I have ever had the pleasure of drinking. The hops are way intense, way more than anything else I had experience at the time, with an herbal stinging bitterness almost making my tongue and lips nimb, definitely tingly. The malt backbone does a great job of stnading up to this onslaught but it really gets overpowered, but you still get a lot of chewy caramel maltiness flooded with citrusy hop goodness.

12 oz. bottle has " DH " hand written on the green cap. Amber colored with a huge head that took several minutes to settle. Massive smell of grapefruit and pine tree resins. Has a malt sweetness which mingles nicely with the huge hop flavor. Chewing on the hops will kill your taste buds. My guess is cellaring this beer for twenty years won’t diminish the hop flavor. Sept 4/2004

Sour Rhasberry nose, tastes like not well rhasberries are added. Very bitter aftertaste and watery. Very sour, but not nice on the roof of the mouth. The color very nice orange. The more you drink the better it gets. Maybe the draft wasn't well!

I was lucky enough to get this beer the day after it went on tap at the Alpharetta (metro Atlanta) location of the Buckhead Brewery. I have to say I was impressed. I'm not usually big on the Belgian whites. Hooegarden was too bland for me and Blue Moon too spicy. Blanche de Buckhead, however has the spiciness of the coriander and citrus of the orange peel, but manage to balance it with the esters of the abundant yeast. Actually the yeast tasted a little more like German hefeweizen yeast than belgian white yeast, but since I don't know what yeast the brewer used in the brew, I can't say for sure. Good beer.

Draught at the brewpub. Drank this years ago on holiday but on a recent trip back to Kauai I found out Whaler’s is now closed. Just a weird stout. Seemed like a beer they called a "stout" because it was dark?

Draught. Body is black. Aroma is moderately malty (burnt grain, dark chocolate). Flavor is lightly sweet, moderately acidic. Finish is moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Light body, watery texture, soft carbonation.
