It was the worst Stout I had so long. Not only because this was our last stop before we start to take of from Kauai, Lihue. Very thin almost oily finish. Dirty black color.

Light roast nose and a dark black color. The nitro tap gives an attractive frothy head. Weird bitter finish that didn't mix well with the roasted malt. Thin and cardboardy. Great location (can't beat it), but the beer needs a little more attention.

A bit reddish in the deep golden colour. Big, creamy head. Almost the taste of a porter. Rich, and a body big enough to let you feel the nuances of burned, sweet and dry notes. A bit spicy in the end. Very Good.
A nice and lovely copper coluor and it have a sweet and malty taste.no bitternes ,but sadly the taste disapears directly afterwards A common Maibock I think

Clear gold with a moderate white head. Aroma: malt, corn, fruity yeast, spicy notes. Medium body. Average to lively carbonation. Taste: malts, sweet corn, Belgian yeast, light spiciness, old hop. Light to medium bitterness. A middle-of-the-road Belgian blond. Not much of a saison.
Perfect zomerbier, hoppig (dry), frisse afdronk heerlijke schuimkraag aanrader, maar in deze kan ik een beetje chauvinistisch zijn :-)
Botella 0,33l Color dorada clara,espuma blanca,fina,alta,resistente.Aroma malta,frutal.Sabor ligero amargor combinado con suave dulzor, frutal,lupulada.
Geproefd met Roelzie1986 bij de Gouverneur in Maastricht. Het is een goudgeel bier met een volle schuimkraag. Het heeft een lekkere zoete moutige smaak. Drinkt lekker weg.
Helder simpel geel... frisse gist en wat apart fruit, appel... licht zoet... frisse eenvoudige body erg doordrinkbaar...

From old tasting notes. Clear, bright gold color with small bubble carbonation leading to a dense creamy off white head. Fragrant fruity malt nose. intense hop character in foretaste dominates the palate. Bittersweet malty finish and aftertaste with a hint of dry hoppiness. Not as complex as some Belgian ales, but very well hopped and full bodied. Quite good.

Bottled during Brussels vacation. Hazy golden with white head. Aroma sweet and fruity, grain, grain dust, light chlorine. Taste is medium sweet, malty, grain dust, light wheat, yeast, fruit with a sweet finish.

Classic Limburg ale, one of the very few from Martens which are commercialized under their own name; the name of the beer refers to the Wallonian saison tradition. Rating from old notes. Peach blonde with medium, off-white head; sweetish fruitiness (pineapple, peach, apple peel), bready and somewhat caramelly maltiness, yeasty touch, lightly sourish accent actually enhancing drinkability, herbal hop bitterishness in the finish. Nothing very complex, but balanced and relatively refined for such an old school beer, as well as very quenching. Liked this when I tasted it ten or twelve years ago, but I’ll retaste it just to be sure as it may have changed meanwhile.

Taster from draft at au phare . Pours unclear , light orange . Good , cloudy white head . Smell is heavy on coriander . Taste is spiced ( coriander ) yet very common . If anything , it reminds of blanche de namur . Bit sweet , but in blalance . Certainly ok .

Bottle 25cl. Clear golden color, two finger foamy white head, good lacing; aroma bread, grain, citrus, bit yeast; taste moderate sweetbitter, bit grainy, herbal tones; medium body, oily texture; mild sweetbitter finish. Nice but this is a blond beer and not a saison.

column1: Artisans Brasseurs la Ambrée du Samson
column5: Amber colour, big bubbles, frothy head that disappears suddenly. Ordinary aroma, light malt, alcohol, citrus. Very poor body, dry, poor malt and hop, very light bitter-sourness in the palate

column1: River City Billys Bad Ass Lager
column5: Perhaps ostensibly in the pilsner style? Possibly also in the American standard category, but seemed all-malt. Almost in the steam style. It had a strange, lightly sweet fruitiness up front. Flabby. Highly flawed for a light lager, or acceptable if not great for a steam beer. I was told the beer was cold fermented but...? Clean, lightly bitter finish. Pale, dull gold color, no head, under-carbonated.
Very dark brown color. Great aroma of coffee, roast. Really falls apart in the body though. Some roast, very thin. Finishes bitter.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy orange gold with small white head. The aroma is wheat and cough syrup. Medium body, wheat, berry, cereal, light finish, decent.
(Draft) cloudy orange, white foam. Nose of raspberry, wheat, syrupy. Taste is sweet, artificial sweetener, wheat, grainy, clean medium body and not a ton of linger.
sure, its not some imperial this or barrel aged that. but its head and shoulder above most fruit beers out there.
...at the brewery, garbage. Get a new job brewers at Dunedin, talk less, brew more.

On tap at Cajun sour festival as Y2k bug ale. Fom my understanding this has been aging for a while as a Brett version. Dry and astringent, slight beery and syrup notes, light. Interesting and strange at the same time.
tap at the brewery. Pours reddish and nose is of raz syrup. tastes of wheat, earth, minerals, and raspberry syrup. A little sweet and fruity for the tough as nails person I am

On tap at the brewery. Poured a reddish, yellow color with very little head. Aroma of raspberry syrup. Nothing too special here, has a wheat base with an almost artificial raspberry syrup. Overall hit the spot after a nice bike ride on the bike trail.

Draught at the brewery on January 30, 2011 As part of a sampler plate Murky orange color, white head. Raspberry, fresh, fruity taste, very thirst qlenching. Raspberry, sweet scent. Moussy mouthfeel, low bitterness.
Draft @ Brewpub: Hazy orange, nose of raspberry extract, light wheat. Thin body, lots of raspberry extract. Not for me. I thought breweries stopped making these a decade ago?
Honey-colored w/ nice white lacing. Medium-bodied palate is sweet with notes of raspberry jam. A little too sweet and not complex, this is a good "beginners beer"
Fles 33cl thuis. Sterke koffie, bitter, flink droog, pure chocolade, zoetje, donker fruittonen, flink roasted malts. Goede balans. Goed. Geen doordrinker. (22-11-2019).

Tap at Redbeard's on Sixth, Pittsburgh, PA. Pours dark, almost black, with very limited foam. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, licorice, liquor. Body is somehow dense, with moderate carbonation. Taste is medium-sweet, with some roastiness bitterness. Final is fairly long and sweetish.

12 ounce bottle at Winking Lizard in Copley Ohio. Smell chocolate and malt. Black in color with a tan head. Taste chocolate, coffee and malt. Totally smooth and alcohol well hidden . Medium to heavy bodied. Chocolate aftertastes. Just a wonderful beer! Cheers!

12 oz bottle into shaker. Thick pour with a very thick, creamy light brown head. Head stayed prominent the entire beer w an 8th inch of head remaining til the very last swig. Very dark, sweet coffee and chocolate aroma. Thick mouthfeel. This is literally if a very dark, slightly sweetened mocha was made into a beer. Heavy dark roast coffee flavors with a dark choc finish. Not at all a session beer, as it is quite rich, thick and heavy. One, MAYBE two at the most. I would love to have this on tap. Would def buy again. Delicious.
Fajna kawa w aromacie i smaku, trochę ziemista, spora goryczka kawowa, czekoladowa, nie zalepia. Alkohol ukryty i lekko rozgrzewa.

Keg at The Euston Tap in 2017. Black with a brown head. Aroma is super full, with booze soaked fruits, dates, coffee, cocoa and cinnamon. Full bodied and thick. Dark chocolate, dark roast coffee and liquorice flavours with loads of lingering bitter-sweet medleys.

Nera, impenetrabile, con un filino di schiuma color nocciola. Al naso non è molto pulita: le note di caffè e cacao vengono intervallate da un lieve tono di salamoia. Al palato è un capolavoro: il corpo vellutato, denso, mostra le piacevolissime note di crema pasticcera al cioccolato fondente. Il caffè è molto dietro le quinte, ma male non fa. Nonostante il tenore alcolico e la densità, scorre via veloce.
On n’a des notes très prononcer de Cafe c est un expresso pour adulte très bonne bière

Te tomarías un desayuno con esto? Porqué no? Es quizá una de las apuestas que hace reflexionar la elaboración de esta cerveza. Las notas de avena, café y chocolate, llevan esa sensación a eso. Un buen cuerpo, baja espuma y no dura mucho tampoco. Además, también de sabor marcado, tiene esa personalidad que se diferencia de la Founders KBS, pero sin dejar ese sello característico.

Samen met Yves bij hem thuis een zwart donker bruin kleurig lichaam met een bruinige kop en met een geroosterde mout koffie chocolade aroma een geroosterde mout koffie chocolade droge bitter alcholic smaak met een alcholic bitter einde
Draft pour at Monterey coast brewing. Black creamy with thick tan head. Very chocolatey. Cocoa and coffee. Delicious
Another awful beer from Founders. Stale chocolate malts and mettalic bitterness were some of the worst qualities about this beer.
Dark brown color. Fruity aroma, no chocolate. Unappetizing chocolate notes in the finish. Somewhat bitter.

Pours a bright, cloudy light orange color with a light bubbly white head. Nose is light banana and yeastyness. Palate is nice and full with a dryness. Light hops and bananas and light fruit notes in the taste.

(Sampled 7-5-08 at brewery from sampler) Non transparent and cloudy yellowish/orange in color, white ring head that actually laced, aroma of wheat, oranges, coriander, and banana. Hits the mouth with a high-thin body, the malt is weak again, a concoction of sugar, oranges, and coriander hit all the same taste buds at once and made it a very unenjoyable experience, finish lingers- which isn’t enjoyable at all. The aroma and appearance had promisings, but it ended up a train wreck.

12 oz Bottle. Aroma glows as light herbal leaf and orange juice. Pours opalescent yellow, with white rim. Dry lactic tang dominates right off the bat, carrying fermented wheat. Lots of orange oils and extracts. A bright currant hop finish. A real lactic infection. Also clean. It’s obvious that the lactic infection eats up the remaining sugars in the Wit. What’s left behind is the nice orange peel and spicing, leaving a Berliner Weisse-like spice pale ale. There’s some coarse bitterness in the back end that brings this down a little bit. But, I appreciate the dry, curt sippability of this unintentionally sour beer. Thanks Sean!

Draft sample at MBGF07. Pours clear amber color with an average fizzy white head that was lasting with fair lacing. Light to moderate spice and orange citrus aroma. Light to medium body. Medium sweet flavor with a light citrus sweet finish of short duration. My expectations where met.

On tap at GRBC. A traditional witbier, nothing out of the ordinary or "Americanized" about it. Hazy yellow-orange body, medium off-white head. Sweet orange peel aroma with notes of grass and biscuit. Grassy body with nice touches of coriander, orange peel, and clover honey. Relatively light-bodied but pleasantly so.

this was worse than expected, and i dont expect much from this brewery....too much wheat...i would describe this as an extreme version of bell’s oberon...orange and lemon prevalent...harsh palate...at least it LOOKED okay

The name of this beer descibes its overwhelming flavor. The brewery describes this as a wit beer, but I think that this is in a style of its own. The taste of oranges pervades this whole beer making it difficult to pick out any other flavors. Expecting to taste a traditional wit (coriander, lemon, etc) I was a little thrown off by this beer. But, I give a decent rating for trying something new.

On tap at the Umami Burger Beer Garden & Sports Book bar in SLS Las Vegas, shaker served showing a hazed, golden hue, with a frothy layer of soft white head foam, and wavy cling to the lacing. The nose was soft grain/wheat, a hint of husk, and a subtle note of citrus. Light to medium bodied, with appropriate carbonation, the taste was similar, with modest bitterness that was lightly earthy, with a hint of pepper, and pleasant dryness that lingered into the finish. Alcohol was negligible, but posted as 4.6%. Clean & refreshing.

Sampled at GABF 2015 in Denver. In the tasting glass this was clear gold with a white cap of foam. Nose of light fruit with bit of citrus. Light to medium in body. Flavor is big on the light fruit and there is a hint of floral hops. Finish is crisp and dry and this is very much to style and enjoyable drinking. A winner.
On tap at the brewery. Clear pale yellow pour with a white head. Nice corn notes. Light and refreshing. Spot on for the style......

Sample at the brewpub. Clear pale golden color with a medium white head that evaporates quickly to a film. Spotty lacing. Aroma of fruit, hops and malt. Light-bodied with flavors of grassy hops, fruit and bready malt. The finish is fruity with a short mild hops aftertaste. Average overall.

***On tap at the Freakin Frog Nov 2008*** Palest of yellow gold with a bright white cap, good retention and 360 deg lacing. The aroma has lemon and apricots with dusty grass. Is this supposed to be some sort of fusion Wit? Super light, watery bitterness... too much bitterness I think, weak citrus and not much more really. Medium light body, no carbonation, dry and finishes with a super watery malt. This was a waste of money.
Draught at the brewpub Pale blond color. Some aroma of paper. Quite poor Lager, only at times a light crispy touch appear. Useless.
Pretty solid beer. Looks right. Flavor is definitely light, but refreshing. Actually not all that crisp, and a little thin in the finish, but certainly easy light drinking.

On tap @ Tenaya Creek poured a clear pale yellow with a small lasting white head. Aromas of bread, yeast and lemon. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of bread and light citrus with a crisp clean finish.
Pale color, not much aroma, decent head. Very refreshing, a bit more flavorful than the average Kolsch, but still very true to style. Definitely a good summertime brew.

Typical Kolsch, a little watery for my liking though. Don’t even bother trying to drink this unless you’re in the drudges of Vegas’ frying hot summer, as then is when it will taste the best and be most refreshing..
20080730 Tap at brewpub. Certainly not exciting stuff, and clearly meant for the masses to wash down a burger. Thin, sweet, and tart on finish.
Light lager with delicate malty aroma. Hops don’t really come through. Some toasted malt. Light body. Drinkable.
Poured an amber color with a small head. Nothing special to report. No distinguishable unique flavors, simply malt. Pretty similar to a typical lager, such as Yuengling.
3oz sample, copper pour with a small white head. Slight malt aroma. Cloyingly sweet with malt. Ugly, funky...not my cup of tea.

Bready nose with cereal aroma. Light malt nose. Virtually no head with no lacing. Lightly bitter initial flavor, and moderate acicity. Acidic flavor mellowed toward latter half of swallow giving way to a slightly sweet, malty finish. The aftertaste was slighly soapy. I may have been the victim of an improperly washed glass here...

Crisp, light, refreshing pale lager; definitely better than most American macros, but not what you go into a brewpub for unless you're a backwards-baseball-cap-wearing-fratboy. Light hoppy taste, some wheat & corn notes it seemed, but also some stale, carboardy textures. One of the weaker beers from this pub. Corona's cheaper if you must look for flavorlessness.

More enjoyable than I expected or than my friends expected. A big full bodied wheat beer, with sweet fruit, pepper and clove spice, and a little lemony sourness at the end. Almost clear ... odd for a wheat ... but great lacing.

Tap at the brewery. <!-- p --> Pours a relatively clear gold with a modest head. The aroma is fruity - lemons and pineapple and banana - with slight yeast hints. The flavors fairly much as expected - cool, fruity, sweet, banana and lemonade and bit of tropical fruit, adequate grassy hops on the close. <!-- p --> This is pretty nice, and plenty refreshing. I’d call it an American Wheat rather than a German Hefe, but that’s semantics.

Hazy gold with a frothy head and nice lacing. Light wheat aroma with a hint of fruity hops. Slightly bitter with citrus throughout. A touch of yeast is noticble. Flavor is husky and malty mixed in with the wheat. Bitter hops along with citrus again. This goes down very smooth and is greatly refreshing. I’m glad I hopped on the wrong 75 bus and ended up in the U District today.
Hazy golden orange. Grainy nose. Spiced (cloves) yeasty wheat flavor in the german style. Refreshing.

Hazy orange with a light underbody, this beer has a pleasant wheaty and grainy aroma with the presence of banana increasing with time. Excellent german wheat flavor, with the eventual appearance of banana, cloves, and esters. Somewhat light on the palate, it leaves the taste of unripe banana. Smooth, light, and refreshing.

Sampler at brewpub. This is one of those American ESBs, you know full of hops. This one has particularly lots of hops, an offense to the style I haven’t experienced in a while. The hops are nice, sweet bubblegum hops, my tav. Once my nostrils adjust I can pick up the British dusty malts and toasty character. Same in taste, lots of awesome hops that are fresh and once I get passed the strong bitterness I taste the toasty dusty malts. Frankly I don’t want those two styles mixed but its done as the brewer intended. No complaints there just nit my scene.

Very well carbonated. Dark amber pour with a thin white head. Smells a bit citrusy. Taste is surprisingly mellow, was expecting more of a bite, but it’s a lot like drinking an amber. Very smooth. Decent brew, but there are usually better options.

Draft at btbc. Pours a cloudy dark amber with a loose white head. Light drippy lace. Toasty brown bread nose. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Toasty malty mid palate with a mild bready finish. Appealing and inoffensive.
Not the best aroma. This is pretty decent at first, some malts, but the remainder of the body is very very thin.

Light caramel and toffee notes in the aroma followed by some earthy hops. A touch fruity too. POurs dark amber with really awesome lace and a great head. Nice amber colors - guess I was the only one to find this visually appealing. Flavors of light caramel malts, toffee, burnt toast, and a soft earthy bitterness. Smooth medium bodied ale with a nice balance.

Cask pour@ Big Time. Clear copper with a viscous tan head. Nice floral hop caramel sweet aroma. Medium body. Smooth chewy mouthfeel. Toasted caramel sweetness up front, with a nicely bitter hop twang to finish. Hard to beat the cask version of any brew.
Draught. Low and quickly disappearing off-white head. Hazy muddy yellow body. Mild malty aroma. Bitter malty and salty flavor with low carbonation and a long aftertaste.

Draught @ WABF 2008. Pours a slightly hazy copper color with an off-white head. Sweet malty caramel aroma with some weak hints of hops. Sweetish malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a slightly sweetish malty caramel finish with a citrus hoppy aftertaste.

On tap at WABL Brew Fest 2008. Pours clear copper with a lacy white head. Medium-light body & light carbonation. Definitely in the ESB area code, but there is an estery quality that doesn’t quite fit.

On tap at the brewery. Pous a hazy gold without much head. Seriously fugglesy aroma, somewhat swampy, mavellous hop blast on the flavor at nearly IPA strength. plenty carmal-malted compared to the British renditions (and also a bit more citrus hops). This is a curious beer, but it is actually a pretty darn drinkable one. Nice!
Definitely tasted a little sweeter and a little more watery than most hefe's, but good nonetheless.

I decided that I'm knocking off a point from the standard 4 of any beer that is served with a lemon that I didn't ask for. I definitely got a banana taste in it along with the cloves. What it did have that set it apart from other hefes was stronger notes of sweetness which I found to be a plus. Definitely not bad.
Interesting hefe...it didnt have that banana taste that most hefes do. It was citrsy with notes of clove though. Very crisp and refreshing, notes of cereal in the finish.

well i suppose my thoughts about how old this bottle must be are correct ! today this brew tastes like an old ale. and a good one i might add. malty with that old rummy alcohol flavor yet still a bit of fresh farm flavor of straw and wet hay rounding it all out. deep dark fruit punch flavor that is butterscotch sugar and lingers a bit i doubt it tasted this way before it sat in a dank deli fridge on 9th ave and 40 th st NYC for years but hey it’s good now. of course looked pale when bottle put up to light but got cloudy as a wheat beer when poured. REST IN PEACE GOOD SOULS!

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Apparently composed from a recipe by a retired firefighter as support and homage to the policemen and rescue workers of 9/11. Amber coloured lager with a pretty decent head. Malty with excellent hop aromas.
This beer is an american amber lager witha tarty after flavor.I liked it alot.The appearance of the bottle I really liked. Can anyone tell me where I can buy this beer?

Contrary to the description, this is an amber lager. The malts used in this are very good, and it could have almost passed for a bitter ale. I'm going to leave aside the whole "a portion of the proceeds goes to Police, Fire..." etc., and just talk about the beer. Light to medium amber. Decent mouthfeel, tart in the finish which hips you to the fact that its lager, I guess. Drinkable, but perhaps commerically maudlin.

’Versnijbier’ (blended beer) sold as Cherish Kriek outside of Europe; does show a certain lambic tartness and woodiness, but for the most part it is just as sweet and syrupy, even artificial, as the ’industrial’, sweetened fruit lambics we all know. Not my cup of tea.

8.4 oz bottle to snifter. This bottle is labeled Cherish, and has been merged with this name. Looks decent; undercarbonated though. A semi-transparent ruby with virtually no lacing. Smells like cherry cough syrup. Tastes like it smells with a bit of tartness. Medium-bodied and a little sticky. Not bad, but medicinal.

"looks similar to belgian red or lindemans kriek. smell is quite nice. fresh cherries, non-medicinal. still tastes like a beer-not oversweet, but assertive. i’ll buy again. don’t know about the 8.4 oz. bottle though."

Red cherry color with a moderate head and good lacing. Aroma of sweet cherry skin and somewhat like a cherry soda. Taste is sweet cherry skin with a bit of tartness. Soft mouthfeel and light bodied with high carbonation. Flavor is not very complex.
2013 to a snifter. Pours a clear cherry red with a small white head. Aroma is sweet cherry. Taste is a slightly sour and tart cherry 7 up. Slightly dry. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A red wine color. Smells of cherry cough syrup and not much else. A nice sweet cherry taste with a just a hint of sour, dry, kind of like a cherry soda taste. Not bad but sweetness overpowers another flavors that may be there. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Reddish pink with a pink head. A little milder than most lambics. Not very tart or full bodied.

Bottle. Poured a ruby red color with a smaller white head. Aroma was dominated by cherries and what smelled like cherry cough syrup. Flavor was very sweet and had lots of cherry flavor. Malts and syrup in there. Kind of a tart acidic aftertaste. Average beer at best.
Old 330 ml bottle a purple colored beer with a tiny white head aroma cherries candy some sourness and sugar flavor cherries candy sugar and some spicy and sourness

A red beer with a barely there pink head. The aroma is dominated by cherry, of course, as is the flavor. I don’t have much experience with many lambic beers, but the flavor and aroma are pleasant, though a bit too sweet to drink a lot of.

Cask at The Moon Under Water (JDW), Watford in 2012. Murky brown with a scummy white head. Aroma of chewy grain, caramel and straw. Flavour is full on malty, with biscuity and toffee notes. Fairly sweet.

Since drinking this dark ale for the last 10+ years. Trying a pint in my local tonight I was disappointed to discover that it was now a amber beer with a weak happy taste with a hint of chestnut. Very disappointed
Bottle. Orange Amber. Sweet, tangy, citrus-fruity, marmalady, toasted-malty ale with full hop flavour. Dry malty bitter finish. (2008)

Bottle thanks to allmyvinyl. Appearance - a lovely amber with a decent head. Nose - toffee and red fruits. Light orange peel. Taste - toffee, biscuits and tangy fruit. Palate - light to medium bodied with a creamy yet tangy texture and a long dry tangy finish. Overall - nice ESB.
500ml bottle thanks to my big brother. Pours clear red-brown, thin white head. Aromas of red fruit, hazelnuts, mixed peel. Taste is fruity, light malt, light soapy bitterness. Not bad.
light brown in colour malty on the aroma and taste with a little bitter finish don’t think i wouldn’t rush to have it again
smells of nothing, dark gold foamy white head. tastes like unsalted crisps which must be the only thing good about it?

Cask @ The Olde Sun, St Neots. Light to mid brown, clear. Full white head. Toffee/caramel and alcohol in the nose: smells stronger than 5%. Multi-layered taste: the initial sweetness masks an intense bitter edge. Apparently now only available during the Christmas period, so seek it out while you can.

Bottle conditioned: 500ml’s best before the end of Oct 2012, some 5 days away. The beer is 5% ABV and was poured slowly @ home into an Abbot Ale glass tankard. No sediment left the bottle in my gentle pour: clear, bright, chestnut reddish body, the head a full covering of white foam which hung around for the duration of the tasting. Feels and smells like a ’winter warmer’ sort of beer, rich, woody and Christmassy. The malts are roasted and full flavoured in the aroma and taste, toffee being the main maltiness I got. Fruity hop notes in the mix as well, a liquid toffee apple with extra candid fruits as the beer warms in the glass. The actual body depth isn’t that heavy or full, but the flavours carry the beer nicely and the 5% ABV sits well overall.

Cask, JDW, Carlisle. Toffee-tasting amber beer that lacks any great aroma. Sadly, quite bland, with an almost synthetic sugariness on the tongue. Some late fruitiness saves a bit of face, but generally disappointing.
From old tasting notes. Bright yellow gold color. Fluffy white head. Fragrant malt nose. Refreshing honeyish malt flavor hints at lemon and peppercorns. Refreshing floral hop finish.

12oz bottle (Old Notes)-Pours a medium golden with a medium white head. Aroma of sweetness and citrus. Taste of the same with some hops coming thru. This light bodied brew is well balanced and easy to drink.
Pours gold with a white head. Smells of sweet malt, some wildflowers, perfumy. Tastes sweet and crisp with some fruity hints and a grassy finish.

Golden pour with smallish fizzy head and no lacing. Malty aroma. Flavor was light grainy malt with a mild hop bitterness. High level of carbonation present in this one as well. Kind of boring...but it is a blond ale, so go figure.

pours a clear amber with a white head. aroma is hoppy; light sweet citrus and floral notes. taste is crisp, a bit sweet, lightly hopped with a smidge of pine. mid-light bodied with an average carbonation. smooth, nicely rounded. quick finish. decent lacing. would be a great session beer or just a nice refresher on a summer afternoon. bonus points for the low price.
Had this beer on 9/14/1999. Color is a hazy gold. Taste is damm good. Light body goes down smooth with a very good hoppy finish.

12 oz bottle, thanks to Secret Santa! Pours orange and semi-clear. Very malty grain, and sweet bread like aromas. Smells like brew day. The taste is straight golden ale. Very light grain, with just a hint of sweetness. Fairly plain on the whole. Light watery body. There is nothing offensive about this brew and no off flavors or aromas. It’s just kind of blaa.

I sampled this hometown beer poured from the bottle. The beer had a long-lasting white head and was a full amber color. The flavor was both moderately bitter and sour. It had a medium body with lively carbonation. A somewhat grainy aroma of hops can be detected.

12 oz Bottle-Pours a cloudy golden color w/a slight white head which dissipates quickly. Grassy, citrus aroma. Crisp, clean grainy flavor w/traces of fruit & lemon. Very fresh tasting with decent carbonation which seems to add to the flavor. Very smooth-very refreshing-very drinkable. Reminds you somewhat of a witbier. Good choice if you are looking for a refreshing "summer" brew.

12oz bottle via trade with hopscotch! - Thanks Jason! - Pours golden with a short white head that didn’t stay long. Aroma is mostly light grains and not really much there. Flavor is much more fruity. Lemon notes, over those light grains. Some light hops. There just isn’t much to this one. It is light and refreshing and crisp and clean on the palate though. A fair session I guess and would be refreshing in the summertime.

(11/16/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Philadelphia. Aroma has some artificial blueberries, some soap and other bad off-aroma I’m sure how to describe. Nasty sweet artificial flavor with saccharine. Light-bodied. Horrible.

Draft. Pours clear yellow with little head. Aroma is blueberry juice. Watery body. Sweet, fresh, lightly tart flavor with some basic malt flavors. Really not that bad for a blueberry beer, I usually hate these.

Date: 07/26/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy yellow, fine white head, streaks of lace, sweet bready blueberry aroma like a blueberry muffin fresh from the oven, lots of blueberry flavor on a generic malt base, light bitter blueberry skin character, all about the blueberry but the aroma beats the flavor Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4

Tap @ Manayunk. Poured a clear yellow color with a white head. This beer had a strong blueberry aroma. Mixed with the malt it smelled like a blueberry muffin. That was nice since the beer was my breakfast. The flavor was also a mix of malt and blueberry with a hoppy bitter finish. The finish was crisp.
Light golden color with a subtle blueberry aroma. Taste is light and a bit sweet with blueberry and grainy flavors. OK for a fruit beer, but nothing special.

On draft (kind of). Ordered a draft and the bartender pulled a pitcher out of the fridge and filled my beer in a plastic cup. It’s things like this at Manayunk Brew Pub that continually dissapoint me. Anyway, poured a hazy gold with virtually no head. Sweet aroma with a faint touch of blueberry. Flavor was sweet with very minimal blueberry flavor.

On tap at the Manaynk Brew Pub. Poured a medium golden color with a smaller sized white head. Aromas of blueberry and light wheat. Tastes of blueberry, wheat, and had a general fruitiness to it. Light honey sweetness. I found the blueberry aromas and tastes to not be over powering and done just right.

This was a nice fruit beer. The hue was golden with a tad of green/blue. The aroma had a great natural blueberry and muffiny smell which I absolutely savored. The flavor had a natural blueberry taste, with some finishing hops. The palate was smooth, and the beer very refreshing. Had the IIPA and a delicious porter not been on tap during my visit, I would have had no problem ordering another of these, or even grolwering it, for that matter.

A lot of blueberry smell and taste. Overall, though, not a bad beer. It has some of the microbrew"sterile" flavor, but a decent amoutn of taste. I typically don’t like a fruity beer, but this is pretty good.

Good God this is an awful beer. Sampled on draft at Zeno’s in State College PA this beer poured a nice dark golden color. The aroma is mildly fruity and vinegary. Taste was pure vinegar with just a dash of artificial blueberry flavor. Pure stubbornness alone kept me from demanding my money back.
Cask at The Bell, Aldworth, 28th October 16. Pours dark, red brown. Aroma is malty, cararmel. Taste is malt, caramel, slight bitter, nice and full flavoured ale.
Cask at the Northumberland Arms, dark mahogany with a light haze. Lightly fruity and faintly tart nose, body malty but dulled. Not quite ready to serve?

Cask at the King and Castle, Tourist Town Zentrum, 14/11/15. Rich amber with a well appointed egg shell white covering that retains well. Nose is biscuit, toffee, earthy, grain, light hop notes. Taste comprises biscuit malt, straw, toasted brown sugar, light bread dough, caramel. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close with a light bitter edge. Decent ESB.

Aroma: grain, bread malts, caramel, light roasted flavours. Appearance: clear, dark amber, small, frothy, white head. Taste: light sweet. Palate: sweet malts continue, grain, bread, caramel, soft carbonation. Overall: decent ESB, nice sweetness throughout. Pint at the brewery, Marlow.
Fat, oily and malty. Fruity and sweet from the malt with no head on a deep mahogany pour. A little bit of citrus and exotic fruit in the hops. Very drinkable.

The big brother to IPA and Smuggler, this is a typically malty ale. Neither aroma nor finish are particularly pronounced but has a nice mouthfeel which makes it very drinkable. Wouldn’t describe it as an ESB though, more an old fashioned special bitter. One for the malt fans, best avoided by the Hop Nazis.
Really lovely, full beer, balanced and without either being a bitter or a stout or mild, it slips nicely into its own groove! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask at the Kings Head W2. Ruddy red in colour, thin head. Tasty malty backbone, fresh fruity hop flavours with moderate bitter finish. Pretty decent.

Pint at a wetherspoons. Very dark red with an initial creamy head, but it doesn’t linger. Smooth malty beer with hops and a nice bitter light crystal malt finish. Pleasant lightly hopped aroma. Perfectly drinkable. Fruity notes.
Cask at Ealing. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.

Cask. Old notes from 2002. A paler bitter than normal from Rebellion but still manages to be dominated by a sweetish, fruity malt character. Light, leafy, grassy hops present in the background introduce a welcome touch of bitterness. Quite pleasant.
Tested Cask-conditioned. A pale, light beer. Bitter, with plenty of hops....
An unimpressive sour ale. More acidic sweetness than any tartness. Medium bodied.
No notes on this, only numbers....however it was a gorgeous day to sit on the patio watching people.

Cask@Steamworks Brewery Brewpub, Vancouver. Dark brown beer with a lightly fruity and musty aroma. The flavour is bitter and warming. Overall a very average beer where you struggle to taste the fruit.

Lots of fruit in the nose, but not nearly as sour as I was expecting. Slightly medicinal but not sweet or syrupy, just really nice fruit. Soft on the palateand has the slightest bit of sour on the tail. This would be great if it was bigger, barrel aged for about 3 years with some brett added.

I don’t make it down to the brewpub often enough to get in on the sour cherry every year but when I have had it, I found it surprisingly delicious, with a lovely color and surprisingly assertive tartness. Sure, it’s not the world’s best cherry beer but I wish more BC brewpubs would make interesting beer. I’m tired of the array of crap on tap.

Amber with hints of red. Light head and some stringy lace. Slight hint of cherries in the nose along with some bitterness. Malty and a touch sour. Some more of the cherry comes out, though it’s not too profound. Bitter at the end with a smidge of cherries.
Ruby color, thin white head fades to nothing very quickly.Acetic cherry nose. Tart and vinegary taste, very light cherry flavor,bordering on the edge of just being vinegar. Poor effort

(Draught) Sampled at the brewpub on Thursday, November 23rd, 2006. They referred to this as the Sour Cherry Kriek. Pours a thin, white dissipated head with a ruby orange body. Nose of sour cherry pits. Tart. Tonic. Cherry. Hmph... seems right.

Tart cherries with plenty of underlying sweetness and strong spices (clove, cinnamon) in the aroma. Clear amber body is topped by a low but lasting, fine bubbled, off white head that leaves some lace as it eventually recedes to partial cover. Spicy cinnamon and cloves are joined by light banana esters that complement the tart cherries. Sweetness builds throughout but stops short of cloying. Alcohol notable in the aftertaste. Medium body is quite dry with lively effervescence and some alcohol warming. Sampled on tap at the brewpub while watching the snow fall!

Cloudy amber colour, i found that the aroma was fairly strong, but i could not tell exactly what it was, there was cherry, but also something almost smokey. The taste however i found to be very cherry with what felt like a hint of spice. A little cough syrupy almost in flavour.

Sampled this ale at the Last Post, Paisley in July 1999. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear amber in colour with a loose frothy white head. Slight citric notes in the aroma. Tasted like a very weak version of Burton Ale but sorely lacking in the complexity and range of flavours one would expect from this English brewery. Biscuit malt evident but metallic hop notes overpower any malt & fruit present. Astringent hops continue into the metallic finish. A poor session bitter.

Handpulled cask at the Red Lion in Radlett last year. Amber with a thin white head. Although totally clear the predominant flavour was yeast and citrus hops were only just detectable. One of the poorest summer ales I’ve tried.
Cask Handpump at the Bankers Draft, Sheffield (JDW) 23/06/2007 Hop and fruit aromas. Golden coloured hoppy and fruity with some bitterness in a crisp and slightly dry malt finish.
knocked back a couple of these at the local wetherspoons the other night, not bad

Cask, The Lamplighter, St Hellier. Amber with a small head. Aromas are caramel malts with yeast and citrus. Quite soft in the hops. Flavours are sweet toffee malts with soft citrus and a gently hoppy finish.

Pint at The Queen Adelaide, Wandsworth. Not very visually impressive - clear light amber with no head, but a nice aroma of hops and cut grass. Flavour is distinctly yeasty but the palate is reasonable and there is a pleasant cittrus aftertaste. Overall, a very refreshing summer ale that is better than the sum of its parts.

Cask gravity at Bowl Inn, Charing. Gold colour with thin off white head. Some yeast, some lemon citrus aroma. Again, fine, just a little bland. Easy drinking. Decent lemon citrusy finish which lifts the whole beer.
A Mes rate: Cask at Chelmsford Beer Festival. Pale golden yellow colour. Lemon and grapefruit hop aroma. Similar citric and fruity flavour. A little acrid in the finish. Dull.
Winstons edinburgh ... Golden amber ... soft hops ... fruity hop ... lots of hop resins ... little juicy ... some malts ... juicy bitter linger.

Pint pulled at the (new) Spotted Horse in Putney (London), a clear light amber with a white bubbly head. A nice flowery hop aroma with a generous maltiness. A strong malt flavour and a light hoppiness. Though smooth, I found it a little grainy.
Slightly darker malt taste than with Castle. Slightly bitter, but no massive hop influence.
Cotts 2019. Can. Aroma of glue and saccharine. Pale gold. Foamy translucent white head. Sweet taste, as per aroma. Light. Thin. Fizzy-soft carbonation. Abrupt finish. Inoffensive.
Can at Cotteridge Wines V Ratebeer event; clear straw yellow pour with creamy white head, wet cardboard aroma, taste also has cardboard, with some light citrus trying to escape

Shared at the Cotteridge convention 2019. Poured a clear straw colour with a bubbly white head. The aroma is lager yeast, malt, light woody hop. The flavour is moderate bitter, light sweet, with a light, watery, crisp, malt, light woody hop bitter palate. Medium to light bodied with average carbonation.
At Cotteridge Convention V 2019. Clear pale gold lasting white head. shitty pale lager aroma. cardboard. rubbish not great. Some lemon just rubbish.
Tap. Clear golden, white head. Malty, slightly bready aroma. Bitter, hoppy flavour, ok bready malt.
In mijn ogen het beste (fabrieks) lager bier van S.A. Heeft een mooie moutige smaak met een fijne hop bitterheid. -backlog de BierApp-
Solo correcta, sabor y textura aceptable. Fria es mucho mas amena que cuando gana temperatura
Best standard lager beer. Perfect balance. Not too much hops not too much barley, just perfect and crispy! Absolutely love it!

Not a terrible lager. In fact my favourite of the generic SAB crop. It's a cheerful beer....to me anyway. With a little bit of banana flavour somewhere. Problem is that there are now so many exceptional beers available that there doesn't seem much point in buying it. Nice on a hot day after a long surf.

Medium gold color. Small head. Aroma is malty and fruity. A medium bodied saison. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are spicy. Smooth tasting. Fruity and very clean. Slight taste of barnyard, leather and must are balanced with apples and bubblegum. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
Dark straw colored with a clean and grassy nose. Thin for sure and unfortunately, that was my first impression. Boring. Real boring.

Had at the wonderfully SMOKE-FREE Bridgeport Brewery in Portland. Sugar, bubble-gum hop fruit aroma. Clear amber appearance. Apple juice flavor and consistency. Wet finish, even carbonation. It's light enough to be appreciated during a porch-sitting, but not an ideal session ale.
A rather bubbly French cider in a champagne style bottle. A little on the boozy side relative to its aftertaste, but not bad overall.
Drier and crisper than most ciders, including its cider sibling, Normandy Cider. Very solid.

Flasche 0,5l: Kastanienbraun, kräftige Trübung, kräftiger stabiler feinporiger Schaum; frische + kräftig malzige Nase, Malzzucker, Getreide, dunkles Karamell, reife Bananen, kräftige Hefearomen, Röstaromen, Schokolade; frischer + leicht fruchtiger Körper, kräftige Hefearomen, malzig, Getreide, dunkles Karamell, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, leichte Röstaromen, dezente Hopfennoten, dezente fruchtige Säure; angenehmer malzig-trockener Nachgang
Bottle shared at THT June. Hazy amber with white head. Sweet malts, banana. Moderate sweet and bitter. Medium body and soft carbonation.

Sampled at THT June. Thanks to SinH4 for the bottle. Bit hazy dull brown with light beige head. Caramel, wheat, banana, soft malts, light earthy, dead leaves, light toffee and bread. Medium sweet, under medium bitter. Medium bodied.

hazy brown colour, one inch beige-ish off-white head, which disappears fuly within a minute; aroma of banana, clove, some cocoa and wet wheat; taste has the same notes with some bread, caramel and sourness; good one
Banana citrus notes refreshing flavour Muddy blur. A little bit too cold. Maybe the polar Beer.

Nice brown bottle with brown labels and also the beer is cloudy brown with very nice long stable cream-colored head, smell is yeast and light overripe bananas, taste is yeast, fresh, fizzy carbonation, light bread, light caramel and chocolate, for me more malty than hoppy and absolutely dominated is the yeast, in summary too watery, light body, why not more character? (I have 0.5l bottle with best-before 12.04.19
Tap at the Wirtshaus. Nose is bread, citrus, rye. Palate is tart orange, bready citrus, some banana, metallic finish. Meh
Bottle. Hazy light brown with nice head. Big carbonation, crisp at first, some mild citrus, then sweeter malt. Nice yeast, soft water finish. Enjoyable.

Bottle from SinH4 @ home. Slightly murky brown colour with a medium sized white to offwhite head. Smells sweet, malty, banana, slightly sharp. Tastes sweet, wheat, banana, brown sugar, caramel. Medium body, soft carbo. Slightly unpleasant aftertaste.
citrus, amber, clear, frothy, light sweetness, light body, thin feel, soft carbonation,
Bottle. Clan gold with a pockmarhed head. Aroma is grain. Flavour is grain, a little herb, sweetish finish.

Bottle @ home. Thanks Bierkoning! Clear golden color, medium sized white head that lasts for a decent while. Smell and taste malts, hay, a touch of sweetness and a touch of bitter at the same time. Average body and carbonation. Hmm decent.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, leicht würzig. Geschmack angenehm malzig würzig, minimale Bitterkeit.

A mid yellow gold coloured bee with a thick white head. A light malty aroma, with a slightly metallic element. Dry mouthfeel. A tart hop flavour, pithy lemon and grapefruit and a hint of forest fruit. The malt element comes through in the end, giving the finish a pleasant smoothness. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It’s yellow-golden with almost no head. The aroma is weird, really weird, this beer must be off. It’s heavy in celluloses and wet cardboard and wet grain. The flavor is moderately sweet with the same weird notes - but after a few sips, not as pronounced - I prefer to think this is off.

0,5 l bottle. BB 03. Jan. 14 Very close / similar to the Staudenland Beer from the same brewery. bread, cereal, citrus, grass, pale, clear, frothy, white foam, medium sweetness, quite onedimensional, medium body, oily feel, thin feel, soft carbonation,

(Flasche) Es hat eine sehr, sehr helle, zitronengelbe Farbe, es ist klar filtriert mit einer weißen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist getreidig und süßlich mit einem bisschen Würze. Der Geschmack ist süß, fast honigartig mit einem bisschen retronasaler Würze. Bittere ist kaum vorhanden. Alles in allem stink langweilig.
Clear yellow with a small white head. Grassy aroma, bread. Taste is malty. Sweet-malty finis
Bottle @ Southern Germany. Pours clear golden with a small creamy white head. Grain and grass. Dry and bitter. A bit thin. Some bisquit. Ok
Bottle 50cl. Dead cooked and filtered Helles with no special character. Dull.
50cl Bottle @ De Bierkoning, Amsterdam, Netherlands. Amber colour with a thin white head. Aroma is malt, grain. Taste is malt, sweet, bread. Medium body, average carbonation.

Flaska från landbierparadis. Bärnstensfärgad klar vätska med smutsvitt kompakt skum. Maltig doft av sött mörkt bröd, rostade nötter och karamell. Storr kropp, len munkänsla, ganska söt smakbild utan att bli för sött, bra balanserad beska med smak av hö och gräs. Trevlig.
Optisch Kupfer, in der Nase würzig, Karamell, ebenso deutlich kommt das Karamellmalz im Trunk zur Geltung. Wirkt lang nach, kernig wie ein Keller sein muss. Astreines Ding.

Bottle from Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Aroma is bready toasted malt with notes of caramel, slightly fruity. Flavour is moderate sweet and light bitter. Body is medium. Pretty smooth and pleasant, nice bready malts.

Bottled 500ml. -at Café Abseits Bamberg. Darker golden coloured, small to medium sized white head, weak grainy nose. Sweetish malty, caramel, light grainy and touch of spices with some flowery honey touch. Sweetish finish. Had better had worse.
500ml Bottle - Amber with a small head. Nuts, sultanas and caramel in the aroma. Malty and fairly sweet taste with toffee, dates, sultunas and walnuts.

12th Sep 2018, 500ml bottle in the garden of Cafe Abseits, Bamberg. Clear amber body, thin, wispy head (I didn't pour it, or see the bottle). Malty nose and taste, caramel and bread rolls, not a lot of hop action going on.
Tap @ Source. Pours hazy Golden with a white head. Aroma of white bread, citrus, flowery hops, quite flowery, hoppy. Honey dew, slight malty, mostly honey dew alike hops, grassy light bitter.
Bottle from Landbierparadies. Clear dark amber/reddish colour, white foam. Nose of caramel, sweet malts. Taste is bready, light sweet, caramelly. Ok beer.

500ml bottle. Clear, reddish, pale amber colour with average, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, off-white head. Mellow malty, minimally bready aroma, sweet-ish whiffs of cherry. Taste is mellow malty, some malt spiciness (reminds, especially in combination with reddish colour at a rye ale), fruity hints if cherry and red berries; smooth and super-soft palate.
Brown with small beige head. Roasted malt aroma. Medium bitter, moderate sour roasted malt taste, some sweet caramel touch.

Light malty and coffee/dark chocolate aroma, pours like pepsi with white-brownish head, very light bready taste with light caramel notes. A bit watery. Greatful to parents who bought it from Stockholm, Sweden. Skol!

Flasche in einem Restaurant in NYC. Schwaches Porter. Dunkle Farbe, wenig hellbrauner Schaum. Aroma und Geschmack werden dominiert von Malz (Karamell, Brot, geröstetes Getreide). Nicht unangenehm , aber auch keine sonderliche Begeisterung

(500ml bottle from Hemköp) Bought for making a stew, little sample drank. Clear cola-coloured pour with an off white head. Notes of caramel, toasted grains, bread, light nuts, a hint of chocolate, slightly acidic, stale coffee, dry moderately bitter finish. Light bodied, soft carbonation. Fine enough for a supermarket 3.5% porter, I'd not buy it to drink but convenient for cooking.

04-12-2018; bottle; at home (bought somewhere in Sweden). The looks of the beer are nice. The color of the beer is a dark ruby red/brown. The beer has a nice ruby red glow. The beer seems to be clear. On top of the beer there is a almond coloured layer of frothy foam. Foam retention is low. A small drape is left on the beer after a rather short time. The aroma of the beer is very weak. There are just some light toasted malts, with hints of chocolate and caramel. Very mild and also a bit bready. Hops are just simple. They give some spicy notes, but way to mild. I expected more. The taste of the beer is also not extremely great. Medium sweetness, dry bitter hops. Rough, not extremely balanced. Should and could be better. The palate of the beer is also weak, especially for a Porter. Medium-light body, sticky thin texture, high carbonation. The finish is almost non-existing. Some malts at first followed by very dry bitterness. All in all, a weak beer. Not as the Carnegie Stark Porter, what I expected this beer to be like.
0,5 l bottle. I never tasted porter with so few percent of alcohol. I thought that 3,5% porter is weird but not the worst, drinkable.
Flaska från ICA Örebro. Mörkt brun med ljusbrunt skum. Doft och smak av sött mörkt bröd.

Fles Zeker een Porter maar door het lage alcohol percentage wel iets minder uitgesproken als de gemiddelde Porter. Proef lichte tonen van chocolade, koffie en licht rokerig, licht kruidig met o.a een klein rozijntje. Cola kleur met crème kleurige schuimkraag. Kuddo’s voor smaak gezien het lage percentage. Geur neutraal.
God kraftig porter med duft af kaffe og chokolade. Den har den fylde sådan en øl skal have.

Served up from a brown bottle in a cruise ship bar on a Caribbean trip. The tall fluted glass shows a dark, almost totally black body and a decent almond colored top. The smell is of licorice and grain. A drink gives back malt, grain, pecan and a bit of chocolate sweetness. Firm bitterness at the finish. Not great but pleasant.

Draft sample at MBGF07. Poured dark brown with an average fizzy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Light to moderate toasted malty aroma. Medium smooth body. Flavor was a good toasted balance of bitter and sweet with an average bittersweet finish of moderate duration.
Tap @ MBG brown with decent white head. Very muted aroma only a little malt. Flavor has decent amount of caramel and some strange spice, but not much going on at all.

Medium brown bodied, faint off-white head. Rummy, fruity and nutty nose. Another scotch ale without any peaty character unfortunately, focusing perhaps a bit too much on spicy earthiness, cardamom and cinnamon reminiscent. Caramely, toffeeish scottish accents. Restrained hops. Strong and sweet. Medium bodied, malty, light carbonation.

a nice dark reddish brown appearance with little off-white head....aroma was of fruits and malts; flavor was odd, yet appetizing (sugars malts with a touch of scotch)...palate was typical of GRBC, a tad watered down
Draft at MBG as a 2003 bourbon barrel aged brew. Smokey flavored. Dark brown. Aging has served this well I believe. Very smooth.

Dark brown appearance. Nose is malt and touches of fruit. The body is hoppy with notes of smoke and a sweet malty backbone. One of the better beers from this brewery. When I had it, it was called "Braveheart Scotch Ale".

Excellent version of scotch ale. I have to include the disclaimer that this is not my favorite style of beer. But, I really enjoyed this particular interpretation. True to style, this is very malty and high in alcohol. Some butterscotch overtones can be noted. Ends with the smell of acohol, but I didn't really notice too much in the flavor. I would like to have tried this beer sometime in the spring or fall. Overall impression: a great seasonal offering from one of Grand Rapids best brewpubs.

Had this in the City Hotel Dunfermline when it was first released which I believe was for Burns Day in 1995. Deep oak brown to black this had a rich yet perfectly balanced structure of rich roasty nuts, toffee and earth. Dense magnolia head. Beautiful.

Cask at the Southsider, Edinburgh. Vintage notes from January 1997. Digging out these old notes because this beer seems to be retired. No great loss. Sweet and malty. Minimal hop influence. Slightly sticky stuff. Didn’t like it at all. According to my notes it was 4.1% way back then for what its worth. 4/10 on my old scoring system. Made at the old Maclay brewery (long since gone) in Alloa back in those days of course. I’m not sure this one survived the transition to contract brewing at Belhaven.
Bottled. Ruby red with moderate head and condition. Aromas of malt and buttery hop. More roast malt in the mouth and a smokiness that wasn`t apparent in the nose, finishing sweet and malty
Cask Handpump at Wetherspoons, Manchester 30/05/2002 Copper golden colour and light. Slightly dry malt finish.
Cask at Bonnie Prince Charlie, Chellaston, Derby. An inoffensive, light, spring ale. Attractive golden copper colour, slightly fruity, slightly bitter, pleasent enough for an evening’s easy drinking.

Sampled cask conditioned. Attractive brownish copper colour. Sharp blueberry aroma. Slightly fruity, a bit watery mouthfeel, more blueberries. Light bodied and not much in the way of bitterness. Slightly salty finish. Despite it's lightness it has qualities and, it grew on me.
Boks. Lys gylden farge med en liten hvitt topp. Ikke spesielt mye lukt dessverre og smaken er ikke helt min greie. Helt klar og gjenomsiktig med minimnal aroma. Besk uvanlig heteølsmak.

330 ml bottle. Golden body with a medium white head. Aroma and flavor like any other Aass pilsner, just a bit more fruity and perhaps even lighter body. Definitively no wheat beer this, just another pale lager with a small amount of wheat. Actually really boring.

This test is some years old, so I don't know if theys still make it....They pretend to have made a Weizen - but they have not. More like a modern lager, with some wheat added. It's a bit fruity, a bit malty and a bit hoppy. Result: A bit anonymus.

Lukt: eple, gress, Smak: sitrus, eple, svakt havre på ettersmaken Prikkete munnfølelsd, ok karbonering Standard pilsner med mindre bitterhet og mer sitrus. Ikke spesielt mye smak, men går som tørstedrikk. 4,4/10 180608
Et ganske godt øl, passer til det meste av mat. Også behagelig som tørstedrikk. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Kjøpt på Extra Isrenna. Aroma eple, malt, humle. Utseende klar lys gylden med hvitt skum. Smak eple, humle, malt. En tynn øl med lite fylde, med fin friskhet. Smakt Mai 2013
-After great trombone quartet rehearsal- Malt and cereal. Sweet and light floral finish.

Can at home. Has a straw-golden color and with a large white foam that drops quickly. The aroma is fresh with a touch of light malt, dry hay, freshly cut grass, corn, light bread, citrus fruit and mineral undertones. Light, fruity taste first before it goes over to grass and pale malt towards the end. Light and water mouthfeel, light body and bitterness. Easy drinking pale lager with fine fruity and malty tones I could wish for more of.
7/15/2009 4:27:43 PM Can in Oslo. Golden body with huge head. Corny nose. Malty and spicy flavour. Watery. Taste falls off quite quickly. Cardboard finish.
Lys strågult med fint hvitt Smaken er mye det samme. Til tross for at smake og duft bare er halvveis er det overaskende friskt.
God øl, rund i smak og fin bitterhet. Fin humleduft. Godt valg til en fin sommerdag. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can. Pours a clear pale golden with a bubbly and fast diminishing head. Faint aroma of pale malts, corn and vegetables. Taste is faint fruity, faint sweet and even more faint bitter. Light body, just above avg co2 levels.

0,5 boks delt med Ovesen en regnfull oktoberdag: kklar lys gylden med kort hvitt skum. Blomsteraktig aroma blandet med hermetiserte pærer. En enkel og grei sommerforfriskning med lett bitterhet i avslutningen.
0,5 litre Can from Gulating Åsane Storsenter. Pale yellow with white head. Malts, hops, grain, sweetness.

50 cl can, BB Dec 20th 2019. Clear, very light straw colour, tick white head, medium low carbonation. Not much aroma, just a hint of pale malts and white bread. Mouthfeel is thin, but sharp, bitter, well carbonated, refreshing and extremely drinkable. Taste is like the aroma, with a light touch of citrus (lime?) notes. For what it is, a light summer beer to pair well with any kind of foods or enjoyed as is, it's almost perfect.
Lys gulbrun med lavt beige skum. Lukter noe metallisk og noe honning. Lett. Vannete. Inge usmaker, men heller ingen andre smaker. Lett metallisk avslutning.
Strågul, frisk, korn, lett sitrus,lettdrikkelig......................................
Strågul farge med tynt hvitt skum. Lukter av malt - korn. Lettdrikkelig men samtidig noe mer smaksrik en vanlig til og være en tradisjonell norsk sommerøl.
Kjøpt på Eurospar Kræmer. Aroma noe eple, malt. Utseende klar lys gylden med hvitt skum. Smak eple, humle, malt. En lett lagerøl lett friskhet. Boks smakt juli 2012, 50cl 4,7%

50cl can. Pours clear pale golden with a small white head. Weak malty aroma with hints of apples and cooked vegetables and some grassy notes. Light body with fairly soft carbonation. Sweet, watery and not much flavour. Probably ok on a hot summer day, but...
50 cl bottle in Grebbestad. Clear golden bubbly beer with a big white head. Hoppy and floral aroma and flavour.

Canned, from a trade with Cunningham. Golden beer with an airy white head. Malty bready aroma, sweetish and with some dough. Malty bready flavor, dough, spices, fruity notes. Thin but still rather clean. Malty bready finish with grass notes.
Golden colour with a white head. A very standard lager beer, nice and easy drinkable. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma and flavour [Can from Coop Obs Moelven, Norway]
From can. Pale amber, clear. No discernible aromas, hardly any taste. Very watery, thin, sweet aftertaste. Absolutely meaningless.
Docela dobré pivo plzeňského typu. Jen by mě zajímalo, kde v norsku roste chmel...
Golden colour with a white head. A very standard lager beer. Mild malty nose. Flavour are just LIGHT. [Can from Coop Mega Torvbyen in Fredrikstad, Norway]

0.5l can. This is a clear pale golden beer with lots of unfiltered particles and quite the big just off-white head. The aroma is light hop-dusty and mildly malt-sweet. Not much more. Fizzing and average carbonation level with a thin and quite watery mouthfeel. Weak flavors. It should perhaps have been served a bit colder to camouflage the flavors even more. Not sure it would have been anything left to taste then.. Thin hints of sweet caramel-butter in the finish. It’s no off-flavors what so ever in this one, but it’s just extremely plain.

Can 500ml @ home Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, grain and some hops. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Can 500ml. @ home. Clear medium yellow color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, fruity, light to light moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light metalic. [20100827]
Very bland. Very boring. Not bad, but not too good either. Not really much to say here; just anutha everyday lagah f’yall to quaff in between the good stuff.

Bottled in Trysil. Clear pale golden, small head. Dryish and fruity, light bodied with clean, rouned mouthfeel. Mildly malty with low hop rate and no bitterness. Rather edgeless. A weak effort by Aass, but their malt structure is quite superior to most commercial brewers, so the even their Ice Beer is pretty drinkable.

Handsome penguin-adorned silver tin swigged in Vigeland Park. No idea what the contents looks like. Slick creamy m/f, hay, flour, discreet honeyish aroma. Clean and faint with grass and almond milkiness, some clinging....erm, hop? Bitterness, anyway. Not digging the slushy fat feel of this at all. Watery, nitrogenous, but generally so inoffensive it’s barely there..
15.08.2008, 0,5l Can. Pale yellow colour. Firm head. Aroma is weak. The beer is lively carbonated and the taste is bitter.

Aass Halling is a straw yellow beer with aroma of corn and malt. The beer has a distinct sweetness and tuned bitterness. Brewed according to the German purity law. This is one of my least favorites coming from Aass brewery. Watery, tasteless and boring. Yeah and by the way ! This beer is 4.7%

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega piirdun iga õlle juures selle tekstiga.
Et ganske godt øl, passer til det meste av mat. Også behagelig som tørstedrikk. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

50cl bb03/2018 from a supermarket near source, en route mot Nord-Trøndelag. - Dusty sulphurous barley wafts from the can into the car, some metallics. Sweetish corn and watery barley run-offs with a clean-while-watery caramel tinge. Instant oblivion with a flott-looking label.
Boks kjøpt på Extra Isrenna. Aroma eple, karamell, humle, malt. Utseende klar gylden med hvitt skum som daler fort. Smak eple, karamell, humle, malt. en grei lagerøl

Can, enjoyed two months before bbd. Pours clear yellow, with a small creamy head. Aroma is zesty hops, with light malty notes of biscuits. Light to medium body, with average carbonation. Flavour is light malts with cereals, as well as hops with herbal and citrusy notes. A fair, drinkable macro pilsner. Nothing more, nothing less.
Golden with a white head - Malt in the aroma - Malt body with some bitterness in the back - The malt goes into the finish - This was ok
How: Can Appearance: clear pale yellow, medium white head. Aroma: cooked vegetables, floral, light caramel. Palate: light body, average carbonation.

50 cl can. Pale yellow, thick creamy head, lively carbonation, nice lacing to the glass. Not much aroma through the foam, but a hint of white bread and malt is hiding behind it. Taste is floral, grassy hop notes and malts. Easy, smooth and VERY drinkable. Brewed to the demands given in the Reinheitsgebot dating back to 1516, means no other ingredients than malt, hops and water. Good "all-rounder" in combination with almost any kind of food, or enjoy its own qualities in your "King’s throne" at home...

DAA; Take away from Valdres. Can 0, 5l. Pours large, clear gold and frothy with a lasting, lacing white head. Nose is moderate malt and bread, light caramel, grass and spice. Taste is moderate sweet and light bitter with a moderate lasting sweet malt finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

Whew! On tap at the brewery. This was not good. Fairly true to style (English)...malty, flat carbonation, relatively lifeless, got sugary when it got warm. Hmmm...these guys lagers are good, but if this ale is any indication...
Slightly bitter hop aroma. Semi-bitter, very dry palate. Not much here. Bad.

Draft to pint (from memory). Looks decent; golden. Smells okay; bitter and a little skunky. Tastes good; bitter with a crisp finish. Average on the palate. I wish Kraftbrau were still around. This was a nice light warm weather beer.

White gold with floaters. Looks like a belgian white, frothy white head. It kind of stinks. Strong sulfur, egg odor that plagues a lot of Kraftbrau’s beers. Sour pungent odor, too bad. The taste is really awful. Quite a sour beer but does also taste like they took a bunch of lawn clippings and added them to the beer. It has a lemony grassy taste. And it counts as a summer beer. Dry finish. I cannot believe that anyone thinks this is any good. I’m sorry. I support local beer but this one sucks.

This really hit the spot, even though it is light. Cloudy light yellow body (almost the color of lemonade, quite suggestive), with a thin, clumping off-white head. Grassy wet hay hops aroma with some biscuity malt, slightly tangy. Biscuity, grassy body with a touch of pepper, not tangy or sour, but crisp and light with a clean, smooth finish. Good.

Pale straw yellow with a large fizzy and fading head, some lace. The aroma hints of buttery biscuit, chalk, veggies, floral, and a touch of citrus. The taste is shockingly lemony and almost weiss like, that is almost. The tart and bitterness covers most malt and leaves you with a crisp and clean taste. The mouthfeel is fizzy and watery, but duh, it’s a lawnmower lager for pete’s sake. All thing considered, this beer is better than I expected.

Actually, this is a bit better than I expected. It's an unfiltered light yellow lager. Much better than your typical American Lager beer though. Has a light citrus flavor. Nothing to go crazy over, but definately interesting. Thanks PsychProf for this bottle!
As bad as you'd expect, some bitterness in the palate though................
On tap @ the brewpub: Pours copper with a white head. Aroma yeast and pale malts, some pine. Flavor, floral notes, pale malts, yeasty, some more pine. Not bad.

tap at the brewpub - Pours coppery with a small head. The aroma and flavor both feature some moderately strong pine hops. There’s some light malt as well in this medium bodied ale. It’s a fairly average pale ale.

On tap at Kraftbrau. Poured a small white head that mostly diminished, excellent lacing, fine-small sized bubbles, transparent, no visible carbonation, and a pale yellow hue. Aroma was malty, sweet and hoppy. Flavor was sweet, hoppy and lightly malty. Hoppy mouthfeel. Medium body.
citrus nose, thick head, salty soapiness in the taste; not the best I have ever had, no the worst.

Dark golden beer out of the bottle with a solid white head and a very fresh, pine citrus nose. Tastes of orange peel, pine and I swear celery leaves. Thinnish body with lots of carbonation on the tongue. As it warms it gets more of a raw hop juice burn. Enjoyable pale ale but better with a sandwich.

A cloudy copper-colored beverage with a thin, off-white tan head. Aroma was that quaint combination of pine and popcorn. Strong buttered popcorn flavor, with notes of pine. Very thin body overall. Somewhat tedious and uninteresting.

A fairly hoppy pale ale, with fair body, deep bitterness, relatively little fruitiness. My aroma and flavor was all bitter hops, tinged with malt. Perhaps it wasn't fresh enough to get the sweet fruit that dabosk and marinaro500 got...who knows? But not bad, just doesn't distinguish itself.
Light golden beer with some carbonation detectable. Dry malty beginning with sweet fruity burst ending with a soapy hops flavor.
Some peach and some sort of melon in the aroma. Slightly bitter finish, some fruitiness. OK.

If Kirtland’s Warbler knew it was the spokes-bird for this autrocity, it would hire Johnny Cockran, sue Kraftbrau, win, then buy kraftbrau, bulldoze it to the ground and plant a jack pine forest over its remains. I, like Silph, at first thought this was an infected bottle, but reading other ratings, either every bottle and keg of this stuff is infected or it was a putried brew that was bottled against its will. I certainly hope the latter is not the case. Regardless, the quality control at Kraftbrau is to be berated. It is always a bad sign when you open a beer and it weeps from the top as though expressing its bubbly shame. I find not figs or raisins in the taste, rather taint, swamp-ass and vinegarish putridity. Do not try this beer unless you have a hot plate of fish and chips that needs some dressing. Long live the Kirtland’s Warbler, may he be avenged.

I admire the idea of putting the kirtland’s warbler on the label, but this beer is an injustice to that rare avian resident. The beer overflowed the bottle after I opened it (usually bad news), and the aroma was initially disturbing with burnt rubber, tar, vinegar, and red wine character. Sadly, the beer was almost undrinkable as the same characteristics spread to the flavor. I don’t believe the beer was infected, but it was rather foul, with burnt rubber/plastic ruining the palate. Dark fruit, including fig (at suggestion) were apparent, as was asphalt and metal. The jack pine plains and the kirtland’s warbler deserve better than this pathetic effort by Kraftbrau. I fear for my health after drinking this beer. This beverage is about rarity- it will kill you off if you’re not careful. Avoid it.

Brown hue with a rocky tan head and good lace. The aroma hinted of sweaty and earthy yeast esters, grapefruit, light pine, vanilla, dust, grainy and toasted malts. The initial taste was twangy yet earthy, different. The finish had a bitter bite and light alcohol presence noted. Rough mouthfeel, just didn't feel right. Okay I guess, but the palate took some abuse. Very earthy and dusty character.
Didn''t really see how this matched an Trappist-style ales. Dark ruby color with no head. Some sweet tones - cherries, alcohol and malt.

On tap, this was lifeless and seemingly infected. Luckily, BBB63 brought a bottle over and it was much better. Alcohol, musty nose with hints of fruity yeast and pale malts. Medium bodied and somewhat grainy mouthfeel. Nice yeastiness and freshness unlike the tap version, as well as a nice hoppy and alcoholic snap at the finish. Much better than the initial 1.2 rating..

Not a bad Belgian styled beer from the US. A little too sweet, even if they are shooting for a trappist like daboskabouter says. Nice dark red color with a good sweet, raisin-ish fruity flavor to it. Another good offering from Kraftbrau.

Dark auburn appearance. Sweet malt and light fruity notes in the aroma. Body is much too sweet, sugary. Notes of dark fruit and sweet malt. Not much to the brewers claims of "trappist style", but it is one of the more interesting from this brewery.

Unfiltered draft sampler at Kraftbrau. One of only 3 ales out of 12 taps here. This is actually a very dark dorwn, even in a sampler glass. Thin head on top. The malts seem more mellowed than roasted, it seems. Hops and yeast give it a nice fruity profile, not citrusy or overbittered; maybe like a pear or a "Juicy Fruit."

GTotMW. Red in color with a nice head. Hops and sweet malt in the nose. Nice balanced flavor, hops sweet & toasted malt. Bitter and finishes smooth. This is a really good red, the best one at the Great Taste.

HUGE light brown frothy head, and a dark red/amber body. Pleasant and surprising hoppy aroma. Mostly pine, with an astringent/spicy resin to it. Strange fruity burnt nuts with coffee hints (a bit like chicory) and over the top peppery floral taste. Mouthfeel is decent, and body is good.

poured a dark amber with a massive tan foam with nice lacing. nice earthy hop aroma. Taste is of floral and piney hops, sweet malt, and some roastiness with an earthy like mouthfeel, and a slightly bitter finish.
A nice sparkling beer with ample fizz and a smooth palate. Hoppy citrus and sharp malt mixed with candy carmel flavors. Red and bubbly, this brew is quite favorable.

When my glass was full upon pouring,there was about an inch of amber-colored beer and seven inches of thick tan foam. The cap almost burst from the bottle! A very nice spicy, sweet, floral hops aroma tops this one off. Flavor was lighter than expected, with woody, spicy, floral hops and a light malt backbone. Flavor tended to leave an earthy feel on the tongue, but the individual flavors were pronounced enough to shine through. Finishes quite dry. Overall, solid. I'll have to try more of this brewer's products, preferably when I don't have to purchase a 6-pack!

Dark red brown, minimal head. . . thick, murkey hop aroma, almost muddy - one of the more unqiue hoppy aromas I have experienced. Smooth bitter flavour, with some citrus rinds and a bit of malt on the palate. Nice.

Very well made, and quite fresh. I have only had a few of this brewery's ales, but this is the best. Alot like an American Strong, yes, but with more hop presence than malt. The malt is a bit sweet, but the hops are earthy and floral all over the place. A gorgeous color, with some unfiltered cloudiness.
Brown ale color. Some malt tones, but the hops really dominate both in nose and in taste. Very fresh.

Deep amber with a thin head, this glass of beer actually has bubbles, unlike most of the beers here. Nose is dominated by cascade hops. Sugary start on the palate which turns all hops. alcohol is present but welcomed. Best from this brewer by far!

column1: Kraftbrau Bent Cedar India Pale Ale
column5: Slightly cloudy dark orange appearance. Fruity, slight hop aroma. Nice smooth, balanced bitter hop tastes. The best Pale that I tasted in Michigan!
On tap @ the brewpub: Clear gold with a white head. Aroma, light malts, some floral and citrus notes. Flavor, pale malts, some citrus, floral notes, not bad.
One of my favorites from Kraftbrau. Cascade and orange/lemon balances are superb. An excellent thirst quencher (albeit a potent one), and a great summer beer.

Phew...after trying that Bird in the Hand this offering is a relief. Seems like Kraftbrau’s take on Bell’s Two-Hearted Ale (hence, the "alt" on the label is a misnomer), with abundant Cascade hops lending pine, grapefruit, lemon, guava, and mango skin aroma and flavor that combines for a quite tropical feel. Has just enough toasty malt balance to keep it eminently drinkable. Kudos, Kraftbrau!

RBSG2003 (extended) (On tap at the brewery) Almost clear, straw-colored ale. Small, white, creamy head. The nose is citrusy and yeasty with notes of sweat and leather. Mild, refreshing and nice overall. Very well-balanced flavor. Lightly bitter and grassy with whispers of grapefruit rind. Bone-dry finish with moderate bitterness. Very nice seasonal. If this beer is called Summer Alt, how can it be classified as a Winter Seasonal? Just something to think about.

Fogged yeast laden peach. Billowy gleaming white foam. Bottle conditioned. Stunningly clean aroma of fresh green leaf, lemon, peaches and cream, white grape, glue, and bready, subtly musty yeast notes. Voluptuous earthy, noble-like hop profile. How can these be Cascades? Underlying crushed oranges, phenols, and tobacco notes. Soft mouthfeel. Lightly prickly carbonation. Candy-dusted malt flavors are paired with delicate leafy, minty hops. Notable bitterness. Soft, dainty tea-like finish alongside mineral notes, tropical fruits, earthy bitterness, peaches, and leather. Could benefit from more malt emphasis, but the yeast is clean and delightful, and the hops are remarkably well placed. It’s overly yeasty and hoppy, and not malty enough to be an Altbier. Imperial Heller Alt de garde? Thanks, Prof.

Well, there seems to be deliberate misuse of the Alt label here; this is a pilsernish Ale, or a super malty Kolschish thing with Cascades, but hwatever the hell it is it is certainly refreshing, clean, and well made. Malts do have a bit of sweetness reminiscent of an American Strong, but Paul, do you really think that's the style? It is good!
Slightly cloudy yellow appearance. Citrusy hop aroma. Quite bitter finish. Nicely balanced. So, the issue is, they call this an Alt and then describe is as a pale ale. hmmm.
On tap @ the brewpub: Clear copper in color with a white head. Aroma, some fruits, yeast and caramel. Flavor, nutty, caramel, some grassy hops, but overall very malty beer.

Hazy copper amber color, about an inch of tighly packed tan head. Head quickly recedes to a very thin ring. Some spotty lacing, not a whole lot however. Prominent aroma as soon as I twist the cap off the growler. Malt and spicy hop aromas are very nice, but there is a certain something in there that is difficult to identify. The closest thing that comes to mind is kalamata olives. It is strong each time I twist the growler cap for a refill. It is mild in the glass. Nice flavor of malt and spicy hops. There is certainly a lager character to this beer. It is clean and softly carbonated. Aftertaste is more spicy hops and unfortunately that olive taste.

Another ridiculously overcarbonated Kraftbrau lager...I lost a few ounces again. This is a caramel-colored maibock that poured with a thick light tan head. Caramel and alcohol notes in the aroma. Flavor is caramely, somewhat fruity, and musty, with strong bread-like notes and touches of alcohol. Fairly smooth for a maibock, as these tend to be a bit harsh.

Nice cloudy orange to brown wheat looking beer. Nice foamy off white head. I smell apple, caramel, lemon peel perhaps, toffee, malt, & some bitterness. Great smelling for a Kraftbrau beer. Tastes quite light actually, a little bitterness, toffee, slightest bit of alcohol. This is the best beer from Kraftbrau for me so far. Awesome. Too bad its seasonal. Actually after the beer sits for a little bit a foul rotten egg smell has been discovered. Why is it that Kraftbrau beers stink. Hope they aren't using water straight from the Kalamazoo river.
poured a murky copper color with a massive white head. sweet malt aroma, taste is of mostly sweet caramel malt with some light fruitiness, with a nice bitter finish.

There's that wacky Kraftbrau nose again. I love it. Flavor is fruity, grassy, malty, sour and bitter all at once. Probably the most bitter maibock I've had, with the possible exception of Einbecker. Thanks, Prof!
Cloudy copper color. Great white head. Sweet malty flavor with a bitter finish. An interesting beer.
I'm not a bock fan and this was pretty darn good. Super pronounced malty sweetness (caramel) but immediately tempered by noble hops, flat and bitter. Wonderfully full body but not syrupy.
A little lighter than I expected a bock to be. And very sweet with a malt flavor I can't quite place. One of my least favorite Kraftbrau offerings lately.
Light golden color. Light hoppy, sweet malty aroma. Quite sweet malty finish, a little hops. Probably not a bock considering the golden color.

12 oz bottle from Dick’s brewery pours a murky copper with a big tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty with esters of banana. Taste is sweet and earthy. Banana and raisins. Very earthy with bread like qualities. Not too boozy for 10%. Smooth and I think it’s a little underrated. Great beer!
